DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Monday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The Legislative Yuan will elect speaker and deputy speaker today.
The China Times:
A nationwide teachers association has been formed with a membership of more than 100,000.
The United Daily News:
Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said mainland China will restrict imports of Taiwan-made synthetic fibers.
The Liberty Times:
The supervisory board of the China Youth Corps received new blood after Sunday's re-election; Pan Chen-chiu unexpectedly lost his re-election bid.
The Commons Daily:
Local government chiefs of the island's three southernmost city and counties gave a thumbs-down to the construction of a new reservoir in Meinung, Kaohsiung county.
The China Post:
The legislature is to elect speaker, vice speaker today.
The China News:
US Independent Counsel Kenneth Starr says presidential indictment constitutional.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 1, or the 16th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1899: The US flag is hoisted over the Pacific island of Guam.
1902: The Ching dynasty orders the lifting of a ban on marriages between the Manchus and the Chinese.
1913: The first Far Eastern Games is held in Manila, the Philippines, with athletes from the Republic of China, Japan and the host country attending.
1917: The German government decides to allow its submarines to attack merchant ships from neutral nations bound for Britain. This move leads the US to enter World War I.
1924: Britain recognizes the Communist government of the Soviet Union.
1948: The Bank of Taiwan issues a new edition of Taiwan's 100-dollar bill.
1950: Deputies of the National Assembly respectfully invite Chiang Kai-shek to succeed acting President Lee Tsung-jen as the president of the Republic of China. Lee remained in the US following the Nationalist government's retreat to Taiwan after being defeated by the Communists in China's civil war.
1951: The UN General Assembly condemns the Chinese communists as aggressors in Korea.
1952: The UN General Assembly finds the Soviet Union guilty of violation of the 1945 Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1956: South Africa asks the Soviet Union to withdraw all consulates.
1958: The first US satellite, the Vanguard-1, is launched into orbit successfully.
1963: Taiwan's 'king of iron and steel' Tang Jung dies at the age of 83.
1967: President Chiang Kai-shek establishes the National Security Council. Vice Premier Huang Shao-ku is secretary-general of the organization and Ku Shu-tung is its deputy secretary-general.
1968: The Republic of Nauru in the central Pacific becomes an independent country.
1980: Taiwan's North Link Railway is formally open for operation. The project cost the government NT$7.3 billion and took six years to complete.
1990: South African President F.W. de Klerk announces the legitimacy of the African National Congress and other political organizations. He also promises the unconditional release of jailed ANC leader Nelson Mandela within two weeks.
1995: The World Trade Organization passes a resolution to accept the Republic of China as an observer country.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In my method of teaching, I always wait for my student to make an effort himself to find his way through a difficulty, before I show him the way myself. I also make him find his own illustrations before I give him one of my own. When I have pointed out the bearing of a subject in one direction and found that my student cannot himself see its bearings into other directions, I do not then repeat my lesson."

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.019 against the greenback in Taipei on Monday, closing at 32.279.
The local currency opened at the day's low of 32.293, and had a high of 32.268.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$277 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIEF KMT AIDE MEETS AIT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Visiting American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush paid a visit to Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang on Monday.
Although the two men refused to disclose the contents of their discussion, the Chang-Bush meeting commanded widespread attention prior to Chang's departure for the United States on Monday evening.

Chang, at the head of a KMT delegation, will attend an annual breakfast prayer slated for Thursday in Washington D. C. While in the US, the KMT secretary-general will meet with US congressmen and host seminars with local Chinese community leaders in Los Angeles, Houston, New York and San Francisco.
Bush, the top US liaison official in charge of Taiwan affairs, arrived here on Jan. 24 for a two-week visit.

It is widely believed that Bush has a special political mission in Taiwan seeing as there are several major issues of national concern -- such as Taiwan's inclusion in the US-initiated theater missile defense system and Taiwan's partial cabinet reshuffle -- which have sparked discussion here.

Bush played a round of golf with Vice President Lien Chan on Sunday, during which the AIT chairman reportedly expressed concern about Taiwan's democracy development and the island's relations with mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREANS SPENDING THEIR WAY TO BANKRUPTCY

TEXT.P: An increasing number of Singaporeans are overspending, sinking deeper into debt and bankruptcy despite the relatively somber consumer sentiment, figures from the Official Assignee indicated on Monday.

The number of people who filed for bankruptcy because they lived beyond their means doubled from about 170 people in 1997 to 336 last year. These new bankruptcies joined about 2,000 other "big spenders" who are bankrupt today because they did not watch their spending.

There was an increase in the total number of bankruptcies as the economic crisis took its toll, with 2,585 people declaring bankruptcy last year. Of these people, 2,250 cited reasons other than overspending for their insolvency, up from 1,530 in 1997.

A spokesman for the Official Assignee said as in previous years, these people went bankrupt mainly because their businesses failed or they were unemployed -- factors which might be beyond their control.
As a result of their business losses or losing their jobs, they could not pay their creditors and loans for property or cars, and so become insolvent.
But a cause for concern, he said, was that overspending continued to feature as the main "self-induced" cause of bankruptcy.

According to the law, when a person is declared bankrupt, he cannot travel or run a business without the court's permission, or invest in private property. He also has to disclose that he is bankrupt when borrowing more than S$500 (about US$312).

DOC.HEADLINE: WORST MAY BE OVER FOR SINGAPORE FIRMS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: An improvement in company performance in Singapore during the fourth quarter of last year suggests that the worst of the economic downturn may be over, a recent survey indicated.

The survey, conducted by the Business Times and the Center for Business Research and Development (CBRD) of the National University of Singapore, showed the number of companies which reported a worse rather than better performance, shrank.
While performance indicators -- such as sales, profits and new orders -- improved yet again in the fourth quarter, they still registered negative figures.

This suggests that the Singapore economy is still far from a full-fledged recovery, said Chow Kit Boey, director of CBRD. "Business conditions were still weaker than they were in the fourth quarter 1997, but there is less pessimism over business prospects in the next six months.
The results may well indicate that the worst is over in Singapore, barring any unexpected adverse global development," she said. (Sherman Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA SAID TO BE CURBING TAIWAN FIBER IMPORTS

TEXT.P: Mainland China is rumored to be planning to reduce synthetic fiber imports from Taiwan, textile and fabric industrial sources said on Monday.

That has sent shock waves through Taiwan's textile and fiber industries, as the island is the largest synthetic fiber maker in the world. More than one-third of the textiles it produces are exported to Hong Kong and mainland China.
In 1997, Taiwan exported US$16.6 billion worth of textiles and garments, with 37 percent going to Hong Kong and mainland China.

Last year total exports declined to US$14.7 billion, with 33 percent going to Hong Kong and mainland China. The reduction in exports to those two areas amounted to a loss of NT$42 billion (US$1.3 billion) for Taiwan companies in 1998, sources said.

According to Taiwan textile and fabric industry sources, Taiwan makers have been feeling mainland China's pinch on imports from Taiwan since last year, when authorities intervened to restrict imports. The intervention was said to be politically motivated and, coupled with a crackdown on imports through "irregular channels," it has resulted in Taiwan synthetic fiber makers facing a "cold winter" earlier this year than usual.

Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang warned against Beijing's taking unanticipated prohibitive measures against imports, and urged Taiwan businesses to diversify their overseas investments rather than concentrating solely on mainland China.
Wang said that as mainland China is not yet a member of the World Trade Organization, it has every right to ban imports whenever -- and to whatever degree -- it wants.
Wang added that the government will work to help domestic synthetic fibers makers tide themselves over during this period of difficulty.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG CHIN-PING, JAO YIN-CHI ELECTED NEW LEADERS OF LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Candidates Wang Chin-ping and Jao Yin-chi from the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) on Monday were elected the new president and vice president of the Legislative Yuan on the first day of the new legislative session.

Wang, 58, the former vice president of the legislature, garnered 134 votes to win the presidency. His nearest rival, Chang Chun-hsiung from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), received 72 votes.
Previous Legislative President Liu Sung-pan received two votes, and there were seven invalid votes in the presidential election.
Jao pocketed 133 votes to win the vice president post. His nearest rival, Shih Ming-teh of the DPP, garnered 89 votes.

As the KMT had expected the election for the vice presidential seat to be closer than the presidential race, a relieved Jao embraced Wang after the results of the vice presidential election were announced.

The election for president and vice president were held in the morning and afternoon in a generally peaceful atmosphere although the New Party was not happy that four KMT legislators were elected to monitor the voting process.
Hung Chao-nan of the KMT, who presided over the election, said that the four-man list was presented by the KMT and the DPP. They offered to give one seat to the NP, but it was not accepted.
Candidates for the posts up for election were required to garner a total of 113 votes to win. If there was no clear winner, another round of votes would be cast.

According to Taiwan's revised Constitution in 1997, the legislators were increased from 164 to 225 this year. After the year-end elections last year, the KMT took 123 seats, while the DPP had 70 seats, and the New Party had 11 seats. The rest 21 seats were shared among the minor parties and independent members.
After being sworn in, all 225 legislators took part in the elections for president and vice president.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES, FUTURES FALL SHARPLY

TEXT.P: The government's decision not to suspend the imposition of securities transaction taxes delivered a blow to the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, nose diving 135.53 points to close at 5,862.79.
Three of Taiwan's industrial and commercial groups had suggested that the government suspend the imposition of securities transaction taxes to prop up the bearish local bourse.
After careful consideration, the government decided not to suspend the implementation of the tax.

Finance Minister Paul Chiu said the decision was correct and revealed that the stock market stabilizing task force will withdraw from the market on schedule before the lunar Chinese New Year. His remarks led to the heavy drop of share prices.
Monday's turnover amounted to NT$39.79 billion, down from the NT$51.73 billion recorded in the previous session.
The over-the-counter market also closed lower, with the market's index sliding 3.75 points to finish at 147.55 on a turnover of NT$2.15 billion.
Meanwhile, Taiwan stock index futures closed lower.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for February were down 155 points to close at 5,955, with 3,284 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for March were down 138 points to close at 5,990, with 589 contract transactions, while those for June were down 97 points to 6,023, with 24 contract transactions. No contract transactions were recorded for September futures. December futures moved down 81 points to 6,040, with five contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA WANTS TO HELP POLITICAL REFORM IN INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Australia has launched a diplomatic drive to win international backing for political reform in Indonesia, warning major powers that without such reform the world's largest Islamic country could plunge toward chaos and a bloody breakup.

Foreign Minister Alexander Downer last weekend urged government representatives to support Indonesian elections scheduled for June by sending an international monitoring team to observe the elections and by providing logistical help, according to a dispatch from The Sydney Morning Herald in Davos.

At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Downer warned that Indonesia's political and economic future depended on credible elections. Otherwise, there could be an upheaval that the country's armed forces would be unable to contain.

Downer also took the opportunity to seek support for Indonesia's decision to review the status of East Timor, and perhaps grant the territory full independence, saying this is an encouraging sign of Indonesia's willingness to embrace reforms.
Downer met Indonesian Economics and Finance Minister Ginandjar Kartasasmit to offer Australia's help and to encourage the Indonesian government to help East Timor with its transition to independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA AIMS AT CUTTING UNEMPLOYMENT RATE TO 5 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The Australian government is determined to reduce the country's unemployment rate to 5 percent from the current 7.5 percent, a rate on a par with that of the United States.

In an exclusive interview with The Sydney Morning Herald, Federal Treasurer Peter Costello said he would slash Australia's jobless rate to a level near the United States' "full employment" level of 4 percent to 5 percent through further reforms to the country's welfare system and labor market.
The unemployment rate plunged to 7.5 percent in December, the lowest level in about nine years. Costello stressed that reducing the rate to 5 percent was not a goal subject to a particular timetable.
He said he does not have a time frame to reach the target of 5 percent unemployment rate because "it depends on the progress we make on reform."

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO FURTHER OPEN MARKETS TO THE US: REPORT

TEXT.P: Beijing is expected to further open its markets to the United States, and an announcement to this effect may come from mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji when he visits the United States in April.
The gesture is seen as a bid to boost mainland China's chances of joining the World Trade Organization (WTO).

According to a report appearing in The South China Morning Post on Monday, foreign trading companies will be allowed to open joint ventures in Beijing, Tianjin, Chongqing, Wuhan, Zhengzhou, Lanzhou, Shantou, Xiamen and Zhuhai, in addition to Shanghai and Shenzen.

Moreover, businesses in the service industry, such as retailers, will be able to set up joint ventures in all provincial capitals, administrative cities and a few central cities, the report quoted sources as saying.
Restrictions on wholesale and secondary telecommunications businesses may also be lifted.
The report revealed that mainland Chinese and US diplomats are making final preparations for Zhu's first visit to the United States as premier.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MAC HEAD VOWS TO PROTECT HAPPINESS OF TAIWANESE

TEXT.P: The new Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) chairman said he will make it a top priority to protect the happiness of people in Taiwan as the leading ROC official in charge of mainland China policy.
Su Chi, formerly deputy presidential secretary-general, was sworn in as MAC chairman on Monday, succeeding outgoing Chang King-yuh, who will soon be appointed another post.

In his speech, Su said he was honored to be assigned to the post, one which is not to be taken lightly. He added that although his predecessors have laid a solid foundation for him, he will try his utmost to push forward Taiwan's relations with mainland China, a job the word "tough" can hardly describe.

Su said both cross-Taiwan Strait relations and regional stability in the Asia-Pacific area are engulfed in uncertainties. Although good cross-strait relations require goodwill from both sides, Taipei has vowed to take the initiative to show friendship toward mainland China which would prevent the cross-strait issue from being one of the factors of uncertainty in the region.

One is lucky enough already to be Taiwanese, the chairman said, and one of the MAC's tasks is to protect the happiness of Taiwanese. In the meantime, he hopes people in mainland China will lead lives as happy as their counterparts in Taiwan.

Su's predecessor, Chang, lauded Su as a young but capable official who is both well educated and experienced. With his past experience in cross-strait relations, Su is actually "taking a familiar path" to assume his new post, Chang noted.

Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China in the absence of formal contact, also wished Su good luck at the swearing-in ceremony.
It is hoped that under Su's leadership, the MAC will collaborate even closer with SEF to jointly to open up a new era of relations across the Taiwan Strait, Koo added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW JUSTICE MINISTER SWORN IN

TEXT.P: Minister Without Portfolio Yeh Chin-feng was sworn in as Minister of Justice on Monday, succeeding outgoing Cheng Chung-mo who was appointed vice president of the Judicial Yuan.

The changeover ceremony, presided over by Minister Without Portfolio Shirley Kuo, was held at the building of the Ministry of Justice (MOJ), where Cheng handed the MOJ's official seal to Yeh as a symbol of the transfer of power.

With regards to her new post, Yeh said she will continue the MOJ's current efforts in cracking down on crime, especially offenses which jeopardize the physical safety of children, teenagers, and women.

She also vowed to fix the public's trust in the judicial system, which Yeh described as functioning poorly in its role as guarding the spirit of justice in society. She cited survey results that said more than 60 percent of the island's residents have expressed low confidence in the MOJ's capability.

The new justice authority reiterated that the major functions of the MOJ is to take charge of legal affairs, including the prosecution of suspects and investigation of crimes, all of which serve to protect national safety, stable social order and public welfare.
Yeh, the first female justice minister of the Republic of China, previously held the posts of interior minister and vice chairwoman of the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW GOVERNMENT AGENCY HEADS SWORN IN

TEXT.P: More than 60 new heads of government agencies were sworn in on Monday at a solemn ceremony presided over by President Lee Teng-hui.

At the swearing-in, which took place at the Presidential Office at 9 a.m., the heads and deputy heads of the Executive, Judicial and Control yuans, and the secretary-general of the National Security Council, as well as new government ministers, raised their right hands before the ROC national flag and a portrait of modern China's founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen, and pledged to fulfill their duties faithfully.
The president, Vice President Lien Chan, and invited guests then shook hands with the new government leaders.

Lee also presented medals to Ding Mou-shih, former secretary-general of the National Security Council (NSC), and Yin Tsung-wen, former director of the National Security Bureau, in recognition of their contributions to the country. Ding will now serve as senior advisor to the president, while Yin will take over as NSC head.
Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng, former grand justice, pledged to promote a fair and just litigation system as one of his goals.

Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien took over the helm of the highest watchdog body of the ROC from Shih Chi-yang. Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh remained in his post, but he oversaw the changeover of the head of the Ministry of Examination from Chen Chin-jang to Wu Wan-lan. Chen has been elected deputy speaker of the National Assembly.
Meanwhile, new Minister of National Defense Tang Fei took over from his predecessor, Chiang Chung-ling.

Justice Minister Yeh Chin-feng, who was the last to be chosen in the lineup of the new Cabinet headed once again by Premier Vincent Siew, vowed to promote trust of the judicial system among the public.

Chang King-yuh handed over the reins of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), the agency which charts the government's mainland policy, to Su Chi, former deputy secretary-general to the president, who vowed to continue to promote cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: RENMINBI MAY DEVALUE IN 2000: TAIWAN SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Although the renminbi, mainland China's currency, is facing pressure to devalue, it will not likely be devalued now as the proper time for such action will be in 2000, said a Taiwan financial scholar.

Wu Chung-hsien, a monetary expert, said the Chinese yuan may be devalued next year by 5 to 10 percent, which will provide the mainland with the exact volume to offset losses from its export declines in 1999.

Furthermore, said Wu, if the renminbi is to be devalued next year, it will not wreak havoc to those Southeast Asian countries which have just recovered from the latest financial turmoil, and thus can ease the region's concern over the possibility of a further devaluation.

A seminar, co-sponsored by the MasterLink Securities Corp., will be held on Wednesday to address issues regarding Taiwan's industries amid the financial storm and ways of coping with it. Wu was invited to offer possible strategies to ward off risks in foreign exchanges.

Wu said in an interview that it is simple to evaluate the trend of a currency's exchange rate. To come out a winner in the foreign exchange market is not necessarily being an expert in finance, Wu added.
Wu offered methods of evaluating the rate of a currency as follows:

--The exchange rate in black market: it offers a direction for a correct evaluation of a currency's exchange rate. In view of the current exchange rate of the renminbi in the mainland's black market is 9.40 yuan against one US dollar, or 13 percent lower than the official rate; therefore, a devaluation of 10 percent in the renminbi may be a rate nearing a realistic rate after deducting the risk costs in an illegal transaction.

--The forward exchange rate: the quotation of forward exchange rate of the renminbi given by foreign banks in Hong Kong is about 15 percent lower than that of the spot exchange rate, which evidently has taken the 13 percent devaluation rate into consideration.
--Using practical experiences and international experts' opinions as reference.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT EMPHASIZES IMPORTANCE OF GROOMING NEW LEADERS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 1 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui has reiterated that he will not run for reelection, and stressed in an interview with a well-known Japanese monthly the importance of grooming a new generation of leaders for Taiwan.

In the latest issue of the political magazine Shokun, due to hit newsstands on Tuesday, Lee praised Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi's resistance to pressure from Beijing in refusing to declare the so-called "three noes" policy during the visit to Japan last year by mainland China's President Jiang Zemin.

The "three noes" refers to no support for Taiwan independence, no support for "one China, one Taiwan," or "two Chinas," and no support for Taiwan's membership in international organizations requiring statehood.

He welcomed Tokyo's characterization of the "areas surrounding Japan" in the Japan-US defense guidelines as a concept to be determined by "the nature of an incident" rather than defining it in geographic terms.
The guidelines provide for Japanese logistic support for US military operation in the area.
"This will curb the potential military threat in East Asia," Lee said in the interview conducted in January by famous Japanese writer Yusuke Fukada.

As for Taiwan's relationship with mainland China, the United States, and other neighbor-states, the president said he believes preservation of the status quo is the best the island can hope for, and that he is looking forward to preserving it.

DOC.HEADLINE: TANG TO LEAD ROC MILITARY IN CROSS-CENTURY MILITARY BUILD-UP

TEXT.P: Four-star General Tang Fei donned mufti on Monday to assume the post of national defense minister.
Tang, who is regarded as an "enlightened general" in the Republic of China military, was promoted from vice chief of the general staff to chief of the general staff in March last year.

He has long been responsible for the improvement and build-up of the ROC's new generation military, and is one of the generals who helped Taiwan weather the crisis of the threat of mainland Chinese missile attacks in 1996.

He also became the first military officer to attend an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan, a move which was highly praised by legislators. At that time, he expressed his opinion that the post of national defense minister should be assigned to a civil servant, because a defense minister with a military background would probably be biased to his own branch of the armed forces.
From his remarks, it seems Tang may never have thought he would one day have the opportunity to serve as defense minister.

A graduate of the ROC's Air Force Academy, Tang served for a long time as a military attache to the ROC embassy in South Africa, putting him "out of the loop" in terms of promotions, but after returning from South Africa, he rose through the ranks, serving as principal of the Air Force Academy, director-general of the Air Force political warfare department, commander-in-chief of the Air Force, vice chief of the general staff, and chief of the general staff.

Tang's military experience is well-rounded, and he possesses an international point of view. He also maintains good relations with the US military, all of which are factors conducive to the collection of military information and military procurement.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING ACCUSED OF PERSECUTING INTELLECTUALS

TEXT.P: The "Democratic China Front," one of the major overseas organizations of mainland Chinese dissidents, issued a statement here Monday, accusing Beijing of persecuting intellectuals.
The statement said that mainland Chinese authorities have detained recently a number of dissidents, including Peng Ming, founder of the "China Development Union."

These dissidents are intellectuals with strong sense of responsibility for the nation. They have only advocated political reforms in a "mild" way at a time when the country is facing serious social and economic crises, the statement said.
These intellectuals have long been kept under surveillance, and some of them have recently been detained by authorities on the allegations of "patronizing prostitutes," it pointed out.
The persecution of intellectuals will only lead to social chaos in mainland China, the statement said.

Public security officers detained Peng on Jan. 25 when he talked with friends at a night club in suburban Beijing, and imposed a 15-day "administrative detention" on him, according to a foreign wire service report.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET PRESENTS FIVE-POINT ADMINISTRATIVE POLICY TO LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has presented a five-point administrative policy for the coming one-and-a-half years to the Legislative Yuan, placing priority on cross-Taiwan Strait relations, economic growth, and educational reform.

The newly elected Legislative Yuan convened its first session on Monday, and the Cabinet, in accordance with traditional practice, sent the administrative policy for the new year to the new lawmakers.
The new administrative policy addressed the following five areas:
-- Security for national survival and development, and promotion of cross-strait interaction;
-- Promotion of steady economic growth, and moves to maintain the nation's continued development;
-- Safeguarding of social security with all-out effort, and raising of quality of life for Taiwan's people;
-- Continuing the reorganization of the government, and improving the efficiency of service to the people; and
-- Engaging in all-out educational reform, and cultivating a new and super-quality culture.

The Cabinet pointed out that the 21st century will be filled with challenges and opportunities, and that all nations have been making plans to cope with the new millennium, with the aim of gaining superiority.
It said the government has encouraged the private sector to take part in public construction projects, in order to push forward the plans for the nation's cross-century development.
The government will continue to promote its plans to build Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center and a science-technology island, it added.
The Cabinet also noted that priority will also be given to government reorganization, improvement of administrative efficiency, and strengthening of relations between central and local government.

Through such efforts, the Cabinet expects to attain its administrative goal of national prosperity, political democracy and social security, based on the concept of "respecting public opinion, and allowing actions to speak louder than words."

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC SENIOR OFFICIALS' MEETING TO BE HELD ON FEB. 1-10

TEXT.P: Senior officials of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) are expected to discuss a range of issues in their first meeting of the year in Wellington to be held from Feb. 1-10.
Trade practices, regulatory reforms, early voluntary sector liberalization, the social impact of the financial crisis, e-commerce and Y2K are all likely topics for the agenda.

Officials will also review the progress made in the individual action plan which are goals on free trade and investment in the region by 2010 or 2020; economic and technical cooperation; the establishment of a task force to study APEC member countries' food system; management reform to promote efficiency and effectiveness; as well as the integration of women in APEC.
The senior officials' meeting was tasked by APEC leaders and ministers during their meeting in Kuala Lumpur in November to provide overall coordination and direction on APEC issues and decisions.

The senior officials will make their recommendations to their respective foreign and trade ministers who will in turn report to APEC leaders and ministers prior to their meeting in Auckland in September.
As chair, New Zealand will host all APEC meetings during its term.

DOC.HEADLINE: THEATER MISSILE DEFENSE SYSTEM WOULD BE DETERRENT: DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Defense Minister Tang Fei said on Monday that introduction of the theater missile defense (TMD) system would be to build up a deterrent power, and not for offensive purposes.

Speaking at a press conference organized by the Government Information Office (GIO), Tang pointed out that the purpose of augmenting the nation's military power is to prevent a battle from occurring, rather than to instigate a battle.
The new defense minister said that the introduction of the TMD system would bear a political significance bigger than its military significance.

The TMD system is an umbrella of missile defenses which the United States wants to raise over the Asian region as a deterrent to aggression. Because of its prohibitive cost, however, it is seeking the collaboration of countries such as Taiwan and Japan to spread the financial load.
He noted that if a political solution or other means better than the TMD system can be found to lessen mainland China's military threat to Taiwan, the ROC Defense Ministry will support it fully.
Tang said the ROC has been assessing the feasibility of joining the TMD system from the points of view of technology, cost and benefits, as well as possible sources of finance for the project.
When the assessment has been completed, he said, it will be submitted to the Legislative Yuan and the government.

Tang noted that the armed forces began studying the TMD issue in 1996, and currently consider it appropriate for the ROC to join a "lower-altitude" defense system, the technical requirements of which are already well-developed.
Further study is required on whether to join the "higher-altitude" TMD defense system, he said.

Meanwhile, new Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi criticized Beijing for its opposition to the TMD plan, saying that it is mainland China's military threat that prompted the United States to come up with the plan in the first place.
The TMD system would not have appeared in East Asia, he said, if mainland China had not engaged in rapid military modernization, posing a threat to Taiwan and the entire East Asian region.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MAC CHIEF EXTENDS WELCOME TO VISIT BY ARATS CHIEF

TEXT.P: Newly appointed Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi on Monday reiterated Taipei's welcome to a visit to Taiwan by the mainland's top negotiator with the island.

"Our stance on the matter has not changed, that is, it would be better for Wang to come (to Taiwan) than not, and the sooner the better," Su said at a press conference held immediately after his swearing-in.

Wang, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), promised during a meeting in Shanghai last October with his Taiwan counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu, to visit Taiwan.
Su said that he hopes the leaders of both sides' intermediary bodies can meet in a "totally free atmosphere" with no preconceived agenda or topics for discussion.
Su, formerly deputy secretary-general to President Lee Teng-hui, stressed the need for Taiwan to maintain flexibility as far as its mainland policy is concerned.
"There is neither a hawkish nor a dovish stance on the issue," he said, adding: "We just want to keep our policy flexible to cope with any eventuality."

On the development of Taiwan-mainland relations, Su, who once served as MAC deputy chief, predicted that the imminent changes in both the regional economy and the mainland's situation will be crucial to future relations between the two sides of the strait.

He stressed the need for dialogue and exchanges between the two sides in order for a stable development of cross-strait ties. "We should not allow the uncertainty of cross-strait ties during the past three years to again take place," Su added.

Meanwhile, the SEF received a letter from ARATS re-extending its invitation for an SEF deputy secretary-general to visit Beijing, and said that it would "at the proper time" send one of its deputy secretary-generals to Taipei for discussions in the run-up to Wang's Taipei trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DEMANDS MECHANISM TO IMPROVE HEALTH OF BOURSE

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Monday that he has ordered the Ministry of Finance to work out a mechanism to ensure the long-term stability of the bourse, following the day's 135-point plunge of the weighted price index, the market's key barometer.

Noting Taiwan's sound economic fundamentals in comparison with those of its Southeast Asian neighbors, Siew said at the first press conference after the swearing-in of his new Cabinet that market forces are what ultimately decide whether the stock market rises or falls.

Siew cited the island's growth rate of 6.8 percent of 1997, and 5 percent in 1998, pointing out that the figures put Taiwan almost 11.6 percentage points ahead of South Korea, Japan, and the states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations for the last couple of years.

Although psychological factors and investors'confidence may affect the movement of the bourse in the short term, stock prices will always mirror economical fundamentals in the long term, said the premier who resigned on Jan. 21 to set a constitutional precedent and was immediately re-appointed the next day.

Declaring that economic reforms will soon be made out by the Council for Economic Planning and Development under the Cabinet after wide-ranging consultations with scholars and industrialists, Siew said the new scheme will stimulate economic growth through fiscal, financial, and business restructuring, as well as manpower training, efficiency improvement, and the upgrading of productivity.
Meanwhile, Minister of Finance Paul Chiu said late on Monday that an outline of the package demanded by the premier to boost the bourse has already been settled.

Refusing to disclose when the new measures will be ready, Chiu said that his ministry still needs time to flesh out the package with the purpose of revitalizing the flagging stock market without cutting down or phasing out the stock transaction tax.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI'S CHARITY EXPANDING IN SOUTHERN AFRICA
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Feb. 1 (CNA) (By Chang Jer-shong and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The charity work of the Taiwan-based Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Association is expanding in southern Africa, through deeds aimed at relieving suffering as a result of poverty and illiteracy.
The association's charity mission was introduced to South Africa by T.S. Huang in 1991, since which time it has donated funds for the establishment of three schools in the country.

In addition, it has established 53 vocational training centers in the eastern KwaZulu-Natal Province of South Africa, providing courses to help local people learn woodworking skills, according to Tzu Chi members in South Africa.

In 1995, Tzu Chi also shipped 15 containers of supplies, including clothes and wheelchairs, from Taiwan to Pretoria. Along with 350 tons of maize, and money donated by Tzu Chi members living in South Africa, the activity benefited more than 100,000 suffering South Africans.
The Tzu Chi members said they have earned the friendship of the South African people, and have found that this friendship expands to all Chinese in South Africa.

In addition to its work in South Africa, Tzu Chi is also active in other countries in the region such as Lesotho, one member said, pointing out that the association sponsors an aid activity in Lesotho every month, providing basic supplies to local people in need.
It also supports four Lesotho orphanages accommodating a total of more than 300 children, and is planning to build a school.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CENTRAL BANK LOWERS REDISCOUNT RATE AND RATE FOR SECURED LOANS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Central Bank of China (CBC) announced on Monday that its rediscount rate and the rate for secured loans will be lowered by 0.25 percentage points respectively, effective Tuesday.

The rediscount rate will be reduced from 4.75 percent to 4.50 percent per annum, and the rate for secured loans will be lowered from 5.125 percent to 4.870 percent. Both are the CBC's lowest-ever rates.

This is the fourth time the central bank has lowered the rediscount rate and the rate for secured loans since the second half of 1998, and it indicates the government's intention to increase economic growth and encourage private sector investment willingness through lower interest rates from the island's commercial banks.
CBC Deputy Governor Hsu Yi-hsiung gave the media the three major reasons for lowering the rediscount rate and the rate for secured loans:
-- A more relaxed currency policy is required in order to improve domestic economic performance;
-- Commodity prices and the current exchange rate of the new Taiwan dollar are relatively stable; and
-- Interest rates have been on a downward trend on the financial market, and the CBC action matches this trend.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP BELIEVES LIEN CHAN WILL BE MAIN RIVAL IN 2000 PRESIDENTIAL RACE

TEXT.P: Although not the most favored candidate in the ruling Kuomintang's camp, Vice President Lien Chan will still enter the 2000 presidential race on the Kuomintang ticket, according to a panel of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

One day after a Sunday poll which said that about 60 percent of the public believe the 2000 presidential race will be a competition between Lien Chan and former DPP Taipei City Mayor Chen Shui-bian, the DPP panel on the presidential campaign concluded that former KMT Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong has little chance of being nominated by the KMT, despite his high approval rating in various polls.
Wu Nei-ren, convenor of the panel, concluded that the strong support Soong commands at the grassroots level will fizzle out if he enters the race as an independent candidate.

In addition, action by Beijing to influence the outcome of the election by stirring up unrest on the island is another risk which cannot be ignored, Wu cautioned, warning that Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, could hint at Beijing's favored party or candidate during his planned visit to Taiwan later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC REFUTES ALLEGATIONS OF FINANCIAL CRISIS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC) on Monday refuted allegations by Fortune magazine that it will probably become the next economy to fall victim to the global financial storm.

The CBC cited facts such as the island's balance of international payment surplus, declining interest rates, sufficient self-owned capital by local banks, and huge overseas assets, as the reasons that it considers Taiwan unlikely to be engulfed by a financial meltdown.

The leading US magazine said in its latest issue that although Taiwan has emerged relatively unscathed from the Asian financial crisis, but with a worsening economic situation which is evidenced by financial institutions going bankrupt, it seems it will be difficult for Taiwan to escape an imminent storm.

CBC Deputy Governor Hsu Yi-hsiung said in a press statement that Taiwan, like many other countries, saw a decline in its exports last year. But Taiwan's exports are expected to gain momentum this year as the economies of Japan and its neighbors, traditionally important markets for Taiwan, gradually recover.
He said that Taiwan will also continue to enjoy a surplus in its balance of international payments, despite its shrinking exports.

With regards to the island's financial system, Hsu said that local banks generally have sufficient self-owned capital, enabling them to shoulder risks. In addition, he added, those banks have adopted a more cautious attitude towards lending to property developers and stock investors.

The huge overseas assets owned by Taiwan's banks, which totaled US$128.2 billion last year, compared with their combined overseas debts of only US$35.2 billion, will add to the island's ability to guard against any financial disaster, Hsu said.
Moreover, Taiwan has been able to maintain low commodity price growth and an adequate money supply, substantially reducing the risk of inflation.

Hsu said forecasts by several foreign research institutes have agreed that a recovery in the economies of Asian countries will give a shot to the arm to Taiwan, allowing it to register moderate growth for the coming years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Wang Jin-pyng and Rau Yin-chi were elected legislature's new speaker and vice speaker, respectively.
The China Times:
The Ministry of Finance is planning a comprehensive package to prop up the shaky stock market.
The United Daily News:
The Finance Ministry will come up with a well-designed package to stabilize the stock market on a long-term perspective.
The Liberty Times:
KMT's Wang Jin-pyng and Rau Yin-chi were elected speaker and deputy speaker of the Legislative Yuan.
The Commons Daily:
Wang Jin-pyng and Rau Yin-chi took over as speaker and vice speaker of the new legislature.
The China Post:
The KMT claims speakership; the opposition DPP protests over KMT intervention in vote.
The China News:
Mainland China reportedly will curb imports of Taiwan-made synthetic fibers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION HEADS FOR NEW ZEALAND FOR APEC MEETING

TEXT.P: The secretariat of the Board of Foreign Trade will head an ROC delegation to New Zealand on Wednesday for a series of Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) meetings there.
Wei Ker-ming will discuss the liberalization of automobile, civil aircraft, food, rubber, fertilizer and oil seeds with representatives from APEC's 20 other member countries.
As member nations are widely divided over the tariff reduction in the above mentioned sectors, a heated debate is expected to arise in the meetings.

The Republic of China supports the liberalization of the aircraft and rubber markets, but the opening up of the other sectors will pose a serious threat to relevant local industries, trade officials said.

There are two scheduled APEC meetings in New Zealand. The first is sponsored by the APEC trade and investment committee to be held from Feb. 4-6, while the second will be attended by senior APEC trade officials.
