DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 2, or the 17th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1535: The Argentine city of Buenos Aires is established.
1848: Mexico, according to a treaty signed after the US-Mexico war, cedes Texas, New Mexico and California to the United States.
1913: The world's biggest railroad station, New York's Grand Central, is formally open for operation.
1943: German troops surrender to the Soviet Union in Stalingrad.
1946: Taipei's Yuanshan zoo is open.
1953: The US government announces it will no longer block Chinese Nationalist troops in raids against mainland Chinese troops stationed along mainland China's coastline during the period of the Nationalist-Communist struggle.
1970: China Airlines launches ROC-US flight services with its first flight to San Francisco aboard a Boeing 707 airliner.
1970: British philosopher Bertrand Russel dies at the age of 98.
1979: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini returns from 14 years in exile in Paris to rule Iran. He succeeded the Shah of Iran who fled to Egypt 15 days prior to Khomeini's return after failing to resist mounting opposition masterminded by Khomeini.
1989: A coup in South America's Paraguay topples President Alfredo Stroessner who ruled Paraguay for 35 years.
1989: The last of the Soviet troops withdraw from Afghanistan, ending a nine-year occupation of the country by Communist forces.
1994: The Republic of China and Burkina Faso announce the restoration of diplomatic relations, which was suspended for 21 years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If there is a sure way of getting rich, even though one had to be a groom and keep horses, I would be willing to be one. But as there is really no sure way of getting rich, I prefer to follow the pursuits congenial to me."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILLING TO COOPERATE WITH MAINLAND IN NON-POLITICAL FIELDS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Monday told Richard Bush, visiting chairman of American Institute in Taiwan, that Taiwan would like to cooperate with the mainland in some nonpolitical fields.
The two sides could cooperate in the fields of agriculture, weather forecasting and other areas with little political connotations, Siew said.

Such cooperation will depend on the sincerity of the mainland, the premier added, noting that the most thorny issue across the Taiwan Strait concerns the ROC's participation in international activity. He cited Beijing's reaction to the ROC's established ties with the Macedonia Republic as an example.
Another major issue is the mainland's continued military threat against Taiwan, making the island's population think that the mainland is hostile toward Taiwan.

Bush, who arrived here on Jan. 24 for a two-week visit, congratulated Siew on his appointment to the premier's post again. He also said that Taiwan and the United States, share common interests and values.

He said the US' policy to support Taiwan's bid to enter the World Trade Organization remains unchanged, and the US would consult on bilateral and multilateral trade issues with Taiwan. Bush said he believed Taiwan has a chance to join the WTO this year.

The AIT chairman also said the US would like to see a positive development of relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. He noted that the visit last year to the mainland by Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, was an ice-breaking trip and a good beginning.

In response, Siew said Taiwan has made every preparation for the visit of Koo's mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, who promised to visit the island during his meeting with Koo last October. But the premier noted that there should not be any preconditions for the visit.

Siew also mentioned that the appointment of Su Chi as the chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, which charters that nation's mainland policy, does not mean that there will be any change to Taipei's mainland policy. The decision to appoint Su to the post was based on his long-term participation in the drafting of the nation's mainland policy, as well as his expertise and experience in mainland affairs.
Bush made note that the Kuomintang's victory in elections last December showed that most of the public supported the KMT's mainland policy.
The AIT official met with ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu earlier in the day to exchange views on matters of mutual concern.

Hu said there is still room for the development of relations between the ROC and the US, and that both sides could further strengthen substantive relations this year, the 20th anniversary of Taiwan Relations Act which provides a framework for Taipei-Washington ties in the absence of diplomatic relations.
Bush is scheduled to hold a news conference on Friday before his scheduled departure from Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIALS ARRIVE IN MACEDONIA TO SHORE UP TIES

TEXT.P: A team of Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials arrived in the Macedonian capital of Skopje on Monday to consolidate bilateral relations, ministry spokesman Roy Wu said on Tuesday.

"The team will meet with Macedonian officials on the opening of our embassy in the southeastern European country," Wu said, adding that the MOFA delegation will also discuss details concerning a planned visit to Macedonia by ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu later this month.

The Republic of China established full diplomatic ties with Macedonia on Jan. 27. A newspaper report said as Macedonian President Kiro Gligorov continues to oppose the establishment of official links with Taiwan, the future ROC ambassador to Macedonia may not be able to take part in diplomatic activities there in his official capacity.
According to the report, the future ROC ambassador may have to use the title of "charge d'affaires" while participating in diplomatic activities in Macedonia.
Commenting on the report, Wu said it was still too early to discuss such an issue.

Vice Foreign Minister David Lee said last week that even though the Macedonian president does not support the newly forged ROC-Macedonian diplomatic ties, he cannot veto the decision made by his country's prime minister and Cabinet.

A CNA report from New York said Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georievski is scheduled to issue a formal statement on the establishment of ROC-Macedonian diplomatic relations in Washington, D.C. on Friday.

Georievski was quoted as saying upon his arrival in New York on Sunday that his country's decision to establish diplomatic ties with the ROC remains unchanged. Nevertheless, he would not go into detail.

"Please wait for a few days. We'll explain details about the issue. By then, we hope news media in all major countries around the world will give extensive reports on the event," Georievski told a group of Taiwan journalists covering his arrival in New York.

Georievski is scheduled to visit the United Nations headquarters on Tuesday to meet with UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan. He will then travel to Washington, D.C. later in the day to start an official visit.

Macedonia, a former Yugoslavia state, gained independence in 1991 and was admitted to the UN in 1993. It forged diplomatic ties with mainland China in October 1993, but Beijing has threatened to sever their relationship after Macedonia diplomatically recognized the ROC last week.
Macedonia is the only former Yugoslavian state that has not suffered from war and chaos after becoming independent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES CONTINUE FALLING, FUTURES CLOSE MIXED

TEXT.P: Investors cashing in their stocks to repay stock market investment loans, and an allegation that legislator Liu Ping-wei had defaulted on honoring checks, imposed a heavy blow on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday.
The weighted price index, the market's key barometer, plunged 113.15 points to close at 5,749.64.
Tuesday's turnover amounted to NT$44.76 billion, up from the NT$39.79 billion recorded in the previous session.
The over-the-counter market also closed lower, with the market's index sliding 3.61 points to finish at 143.94 on a turnover of NT$2.28 billion.
Meanwhile, Taiwan stock index futures closed mixed.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for February were down 74 points to close at 5,880, with 3,803 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for March were down 70 points to close at 5,920, with 579 contract transactions, while those for June were down 67 points to 5,956, with 20 contract transactions. September futures were up 54 points to 6,050, with six contract transactions, and December futures were up 21 points to 6,055, with two contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: INFLUENZA OUTBREAK LIKELY: DOH OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: There is a high possibility of a major influenza outbreak this year, an official from the Department of Health (DOH) warned on Tuesday.

Tu Hsing-tze, the director of the Bureau of Communicable Disease Control under the DOH, said that last week alone, the number of reported cases of acute respiratory infection topped 183,000. The figure is similar to one reported in the peak week of a 1997-1998 outbreak.

Tu noted that the influenza virus is able to mutate so rapidly over the course of a single year that antibodies produced by the body against the previous year's vaccine become largely ineffective the following year.

Tu noted that 1968-1969, 1978-1979, and 1988 saw major outbreaks of influenza, and pointed out that Taiwan is now entering the crucial period of what can be seen as a 10-year cycle of outbreaks. He warned that the outbreak could begin before the Chinese New Year holiday, which falls on Feb. 16, and last until mid-March, because of the warmer-than-usual winter weather.

He also warned in particular that the hustle and bustle of crowds during the holiday, and the annual mass migration of people traveling all over the island to be with their families, could fuel an outbreak, and advised the public, especially the old and the young, against going to public places where there are likely to be large crowds.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVEN MAINLAND CHINA FISHERMEN RESCUED OFF PENGHU

TEXT.P: Seven fishermen from mainland China were rescued and six others were still unaccounted for after their fishing vessel was rammed by a Hong Kong freighter off the Penghu archipelago in the Taiwan Strait, police said on Tuesday.
Police said that the freighter rammed the mainland ship at around 10 p.m. on Monday, causing the boat to sink.
Chen Junyi, captain of the fishing boat, said his ship was heading toward a sheltered bay to avoid rough conditions when the accident took place, and that most of his crew were asleep at the time.
Chen and six others were rescued by the Hsin Hung Ming, a Taiwan fishing vessel which was operating in the vicinity.
Liu Yin-bin, captain of the Hsin Hung Ming, said he gave chase to the Hong Kong vessel for about 40 minutes and that the freighter actually stopped for a while before running off again.
The seven mainland fishermen, who suffered only minor injuries, were taken to a Penghu fishing harbor for temporary shelter.
Penghu police and military are still searching the area for the missing six.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA URGES SENATORS TO RATIFY VISITING FORCES PACT

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada on Monday came out in full support of renewing the US Visiting Forces agreement, saying it offered the most favorable conditions given the prevailing situation in the Philippines.

The Senate is due to vote on the agreement which Estrada signed after extensive negotiations between government representatives from the Philippines and United States. A two-thirds majority is required to ratify the agreement. Once approved it will pave the way for the resumption of joint military exercises between the two sides.

Presidential spokesman Jerry Barican said Estrada remains confident that the Senate will concur with the agreement as it would mean support for peace and stability in the region as well as the promotion of its economic growth and development.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA HAS SECOND HIGHEST NUMBER OF SHAREHOLDERS

TEXT.P: Australia has the highest number of shareholders per capita in the world next to the United States, according to the Australian Stock Exchange.

The latest stock exchange survey showed that more than 5.5 million Australians have invested as shareholders, accounting for 40.3 percent of the total adult population in the country. That figure is virtually unchanged from February 1998.
About 4.4 million people hold shares directly, or 31.9 percent of the population, up from the previous level of 28.5 percent.
"The results show that interest in the share market is still growing," Australian Stock Exchange Managing Director Richard Humphry told reporters on Monday.

The proportion of Australian shareholders has more than doubled in only seven years, Humphry said, adding that the survey showed that 2.3 million new investors or 17 percent of the adult population have invested in the stock market since 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA BEING BROUGHT DOWN BY RISING CRIME

TEXT.P: A wave of bombings and widespread protests in mainland China has sent a warning signal to Beijing officials that an economic slump and surging unemployment pose a threat to social and political stability.

In a dispatch from Beijing, the Sydney Morning Herald on Tuesday said there have been eight reported bombings in the last month as frustration appears to be mounting over economic hardship and rampant government corruption.
The fatal bombings are particularly difficult to stop as explosives are easily available in a country with thousands of mines and sprawling military industries, the daily reported.
Chinese authorities have also been confronted with persistent demonstrations in many major cities and towns as unemployed workers, retirees and heavily taxed peasants take to the streets.
Crime appears to be soaring in many bigger cities as jobless workers move in from the countryside or provinces.

Late January, an explosion on a stretch of the Beijing-Guangzhou railway line damaged tracks. On Jan. 17 workers were blamed for a bus blast which left 37 passengers injured in Changsha, the capital of Hunan Province. Meanwhile, 19 passengers were killed in Liaoning province on Jan. 8 during a robbery attempt in which bombs were exploded.

In one of the major protests reported this year, about 5,000 farmers in Hunan province clashed with police and military troops on Jan. 8, leaving one person dead and about 100 injured, according to a human rights group in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIA, MAINLAND CHINA NO GREAT THREAT TO US SECURITY

TEXT.P: While serious military threat to US security has diminished dramatically since the end of the Cold War, both Russia and mainland China should be closely watched, according to a policy analysis by a Washington think tank.

Ivan Eland, director of defense policy studies at the Cato Institute, wrote Monday in an analysis titled "Tilting at Windmills: Post-Cold War Military Threats to US Security" that the threat from conventional Russian military forces has all but disintegrated and would take many years to reconstitute.

"China would take 20 to 30 years to transform its bloated and obsolete military into a major threat to US vital interests. The militaries in both nations should be watched, but they may never develop into credible threats," noted Eland.

In addition, the US government tends to overstate regional threats (for example, Iraq and North Korea) because it still sees them through Cold War lenses, the director said. A rival superpower no longer exists to back surrogates or to exploit potential regional conflicts. There is no longer any danger that Middle East oil or the Korean peninsula will be controlled by the Soviet Union.

Before the Persian Gulf War, prominent economists across the political spectrum noted that the small costs (in higher oil prices) to the US economy of Saudi Arabia's potential fall to Iraq did not warrant American military action.

Saudi Arabia and other oil-rich Persian Gulf states have combined economies that greatly exceed those of the weakened Iraq or Iran. Likewise, South Korea's economy surpasses that of North Korea. Those nations can afford to defend themselves and should be weaned from US protection, added Eland.

One threat that is becoming more severe in the post-Cold War world is the proliferation of chemical, biological, nuclear and missile technology. The probability of a retaliatory strike on the US homeland by rogue states or terrorist groups using such weapons, however, can be reduced by ending unneeded and provocative US military intervention abroad, concluded the policy analysis. (by Nelson Chung)

DOC.HEADLINE: INACTION ON Y2K BUG SEEN THREATENING WORLD STABILITY

TEXT.P: Inaction in many countries to fight the millennium bug -- Y2K -- is expected to disrupt world trade and financial markets, according to a World Bank survey.

In the survey of 139 developing countries, the bank found only 54 have initiated national Y2K policies, 21 were taking concrete action remedial steps to safeguard their computer systems and 33 reported high-to-medium awareness of the problem but were not currently taking action.
The World Bank warned that the mere existence of a national Y2K action plan should not be taken to imply that countries will be fully compliant by the end of 1999.
Inaction appears to stem from a lack of appreciation or understanding, of the gravity of the 2000 date problem, which may cause computer systems to fail on Jan. 1, 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.008 against the greenback in Taipei on Tuesday, closing at 32.271.
The local currency opened at 32.267 and was traded between 32.257 and 32.286.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$338.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA SHIPBUILDING PROMOTES DIVERSIFIED BUSINESS STRATEGY

TEXT.P: China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSC) is planning to expand into the field of manufacturing machine tools, with an eye on diversifying its business operations, a company official said on Tuesday.

Tan Tai-pin, deputy general manager of CSC's Kaohsiung shipyard, said that because both domestic and foreign shipbuilding markets have experienced a sharp decline in recent years, average shipbuilding prices have dropped about 20 percent.
To make matters worse, he went on, customers who have made 10 percent down payments might be reluctant to pay installments on their purchases due to the continuing sluggish pricing market.

Tan said that CSC faces increasing pressure from shipbuilding companies in Japan and South Korea which are cutting prices in order to win contracts. Competition is also especially strong from mainland China, which has experienced rapid growth in the development of its shipbuilding industry, he said.

CSC's Kaohsiung Shipyard officials feel that plans by the local petrochemical industry to further develop naphtha cracking plants and plans to develop more industrial zones around the island offer golden opportunity for the company's future business operation, Tan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG APOLOGIZES TO KAOHSIUNG COUNTY RESIDENTS OVER TOXIC WASTE

TEXT.P: Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) on Tuesday made a public apology to the residents of southern Kaohsiung County for dumping more than 10,000 tons of mercury-laced industrial waste in local landfills.

FPG Vice Chairman Wang Chin-shu and General Manager Lee Chih-tsun openly apologized to Kaohsiung County Chief Yu Cheng-hsien for the incident and promised that FPG will ship all the mercury-laced waste produced in its Jenwu and Chienchen plants -- both located in Kaohsiung County -- to advanced Western countries for proper disposal.
A further 2,700 tons of the FPG waste which was shipped by a Taiwan contractor to an open dump in Cambodia will also be transported to Europe or America for processing, Lee added.
Foreign news reports in November that toxic waste had been dumped in the impoverished Southeast Asian country provoked a wave of panic among the people living near the dump.

FPG, working through Kuomintang lawmaker Tseng Chen-nung, who maintains close contacts with the Cambodian government, agreed to ship the waste back to Taiwan until alternative plans could be made to dispose of the waste. The company is Taiwan's largest petrochemical producer.

In response to Lee's remarks, Ting Shan-lung, head of Kaohsiung County's Environmental Protection Bureau, pointed out that about 1,300 tons of the more than 18,000 tons of mercury-laced waste produced by FPG's Chienchen plant are still stored within the plant compound.
Claiming that the amount is not that high, Lee said that this waste will also be shipped to advanced countries for handling.

Brushing aside Lee's explanation, another Kaohsiung County councilor demanded that FPG remove the more than 10,000 tons of mercury-laced waste currently buried in nearby landfills, in order to protect the health of local residents.

Since the public remains skeptical about FPG's sincerity in handling its waste, the Kaohsiung County Environmental Protection Bureau has requested the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration carry out tests on the industrial waste buried in three landfills within its jurisdiction.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPS GROUP TO INVEST OVER NT$10 MILLION IN TAIWAN'S ERP MARKET

TEXT.P: Holland-based Origin Technology Inc. is to invest over NT$10 million in its Taiwan subsidiary for its specialized "Enterprise Resource Plan" (ERP), with the aim of providing its customers with the techniques for building up ERP structures, global CEO Robert Pickering said on Monday.

Pickering said the global market for ERP is growing, and added that his company is anxious to grab the lion's share of Taiwan's market. He described ERP as a system which integrates enterprises' resources and allows the re-engineering of working processes, both of which are helpful when an enterprise intends to open up its market abroad.
He predicted a 25 percent growth rate in the global ERP market, and a 40 percent growth rate in the Taiwan market.

Origin Technology Inc., which has already spent over NT$10 million in Taiwan for a "solution center," is a subsidiary of the Netherlands technology giant Philips. This year, Origin plans to combine the solution center with the ERP to create a package that covers services such as hardware, licensing, consultancy, and network solutions for local small- and medium-sized enterprises wishing to engage in on-line trading, said Pickering.

The company will also design a special version of ERP that can be applied to an enterprise with branches in Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China, and which requires computer software that can function using three different character types -- standard Chinese, English, and mainland China's simplified Chinese characters.

Meanwhile, the company's CEO for the Greater China region, Lee Lian-yo, added that Origin will continue to invest in Taiwan to facilitate local enterprises wishing to expand their businesses into global markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MAC CHIEF CALLS FOR END TO ZERO-SUM CROSS-STRAIT DIPLOMATIC WAR

TEXT.P: The diplomatic competition between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is a tough battle, the Republic of China's new chief mainland China policy planner said on Tuesday.

"We do not like engaging in a `zero-sum' diplomatic war with mainland China. But if Beijing continues to adopt this strategy, we can but follow suit," said Su Chi, newly appointed chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).
Su, a former deputy secretary-general to President Lee Teng-hui, said the ROC must maintain bilateral and multilateral relations with other countries to sustain its survival and development.
Noting that military and diplomatic issues are the thorniest cross-strait problems, Su said they are also the fields most prone to conflict.

He pointed out that the ROC has long adopted a defensive military deployment strategy and a "win-win" policy toward diplomatic issues. "However, mainland China has continued its military threat to Taiwan and has even intensified its diplomatic strangulation strategy against us," he noted.

The scholar-turned-official further said mainland China's recalcitrant, hegemonic attitude is not only detrimental to the development of cross-strait relations, it has also triggered a backlash from the people of Taiwan.
Commenting on mainland China's strong reaction toward the recent establishment of diplomatic ties between the ROC and Macedonia, Su said the ROC has applied its "win-win" policy to the issue.

Noting that Macedonia currently maintains diplomatic ties with both sides of the Taiwan Strait, Su said the ROC does not care whether or not its diplomatic allies adopt a "dual recognition" policy toward the two sides of the strait. "Nor do we care whether or not our allies sever their diplomatic relations with mainland China after they forge official links with us," he went on.
"We hope to make friends with all countries around the world. In this post-Cold War era, we hope mainland China will not block any country from making friends with us," Su stressed.
Touching on cross-strait exchanges, the new MAC chief said that exchanges of visits by top leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will become a reality "when the time and atmosphere are ripe."

"If Wang Daohan, mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan, can visit Taiwan smoothly this year, it will help cultivate an environment conducive to further high-level cross-strait exchanges," Su said.

Wang, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), agreed to make a reciprocal visit to Taiwan when he met with his Taiwan counterpart, Chairman Koo Chen-fu of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), in Shanghai last October.

"Last year's Koo-Wang meeting marked the opening of constructive cross-strait dialogue. We hope Wang's planned visit to Taiwan this year will continue this trend and help pave the way for a resumption of systemic SEF-ARATS dialogue and consultations," Su said.
As for the agenda for the planned Koo-Wang meeting in Taipei, Su declined to speculate, saying that now is not the right time to make any predictions on such topics.

Nevertheless, he pointed out some of the many practical issues which exist between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, such as the personal safety of Taiwan business people on the mainland, fishery disputes, and cross-strait drug and firearm trafficking.
Su said mainland China should not force the ROC to accept its "one China" concept.

"Beijing should face up to the reality that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are now ruled by two separate governments," Su said, adding that it is the ROC's consistent stand that each side should be allowed to maintain its own definition of "one China" prior to eventual unification.
Su further said that if mainland China can accept Taiwan's stance on the "one China" principle, many cross-strait issues can be resolved more easily.

Commenting on a proposal that Taipei, Beijing and Washington form an unofficial "second track" dialogue channel to strengthen contact and communication, Su pointed out that such informal dialogue channels have long existed.

"We do not oppose the formation of informal Taipei-Washington-Beijing dialogue channels. What is most important is that such informal channels should never replace the legally authorized `first track' dialogue channel," Su stressed.

The "second track" dialogue channel was first broached by a group of retired officials and academics from the United States, Taiwan and mainland China. Their informal three-way contacts actually increased the 1996 Taiwan Strait missile crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF TO PROPOSE LONG-TERM MEASURES TO PROMOTE LOCAL BOURSE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) will propose a plan to promote the local bourse on Feb. 10, the final day of stock market trading before the Lunar New Year holiday, Vice Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang said on Tuesday.

The plan will include the normalization of parent and subsidiary companies' mutual holding of each other's shares and consolidated financial reports. It will also encourage individual stock investors to hold on to their shares on a long-term basis.
However, the MOF denied that it will cut or exempt taxes on those long-term stockholders.
The local bourse has been in the doldrums recently, and some industrial and commercial groups have proposed exemptions or cuts in securities transaction taxes for two years to prop up the market.
However, the Cabinet and the MOF are opposed to any such moves, and Premier Vincent Siew has instructed the MOF to map out an alternative medium- and long-term plan to safeguard the sagging market.
The timing of the plan's announcement will coincide with the withdrawal of the stock market stabilizing task force which was established recently as a short-term measure to prop up the bourse.
Yen said the plan will emphasize ways to maintain medium- and long-term stabilization of the local bourse, and to ensure the sound development of the island's capital market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MYOPIA RATE WORLD'S HIGHEST

TEXT.P: As many as 85 percent of Taiwan's high school students and 90 percent of its college students are nearsighted, figures high enough to give Taiwan the sobriquet "the island of myopia," a leading local ophthalmologist said Tuesday.

Taiwan has the highest number of nearsighted people relative to its overall population in the world, as well as the highest percentage of people with advanced myopia, said Dr. Lin Lung-kuang of National Taiwan University Hospital.
Nineteen percent of the people in Taiwan who are nearsighted suffer from advanced myopia, compared with about 2 percent of populations in Europe and the United States, Lin noted.
According to a report in the latest issue of Health Magazine, the number of young people in Taiwan who are nearsighted is increasing more rapidly than in the past.
In 1996 12 percent of first graders in Taiwan were myopic, against 3 percent in a similar poll 10 years earlier, according to the report.
Seventy-five percent of junior high school students in Taiwan, 85 percent of high school students and 90 percent of students in colleges and universities are nearsighted.
Taiwan's myopia levels are higher than those of Japan or Singapore, two countries generally considered to have more myopic people, the report noted.
Dr. Lin, meanwhile, noted that in Taiwan people are developing myopia at an earlier age, the number of people with myopia is increasing and more people are developing advanced myopia.

Taiwan's staggering myopia levels are the result of parents having children read and write at too early an age, he said. The longer a person goes without developing myopia, the less severe the condition is likely to be, so it is especially important to ensure people do not develop myopia as children, he said.

Acknowledging the seriousness of Taiwan's myopia problem, Department of Health Director-General Chan Chi-shean said that beginning this year, eyesight examinations will be given to students in kindergartens islandwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GOLF CLUB MAKERS DENY COUNTERFEITING CHARGES

TEXT.P: Two Taiwan golf club manufacturing firms denied on Tuesday that they had counterfeited US brand-named golf equipment.

Tourney Golf Co. and Join Wee International Co. made the denial after three of their staff members were arrested by US customs agents on Monday when they were attending a trade fair in Orlando, Florida.
The US Customs Service announced on Monday its agents had arrested six golf club distributors and four manufacturers who allegedly sold millions of dollars in counterfeit golf equipment.
Among the arrested suspects were Midi Cheng of Tourney Golf and Ben Liao and David Lioa of Join Wee International.
Tourney Gold said Midi Liu, a saleman, went to the United States last week to attend the Orlando professional golf equipment trade fair and to negotiate some export deals.
A company spokesman said Tourney Golf has not produced any brand-named golf equipment on an OEM (original equipment manufacturing) basis. "We couldn't understand why Liu was arrested," he complained.

Bei Liao and David Liao are brothers and their father is head of Join Wee International. A company spokesman said Join Wee has produced golf equipment on an OEM basis and has not produced any counterfeit goods.
Both Tourney Golf and Join Wee International denied the counterfeit charges and have asked the government to assist them in resolving the issue.

According to foreign wire service reports, the arrests by US customs agents in Orlando, Atlanta, Houston and Savannah, Georiga, followed an undercover investigation, dubbed ``Project Teed Off,'' in which agents posed as importers for two major counterfeit golf club manufacturers.

US agents made 303 seizures of phony golf equipment worth US$6 million during the two-year investigation, which was initiated at the request of the golf equipment industry. The arrests were timed to coincide with the US Professional Golf Association's Merchandise Show being held this week in Orlando.

"We were aware of a counterfeiting problem in the golfing industry and we attempted to infiltrate the underground, the counterfeit component," said Joe Henderson, an agent in charge of the US Customs Service's Orlando office.

The investigation focused on fake US brand-name golf equipment made in Taiwan, mainland China, Vietnam and Thailand. Investigators said the majority of counterfeit golf club parts in the United States are imported into the country, sold to a group of distributors and resold to retailers. Some distributors also had their own retail outlets and some of the sales were made by mail orders or over the Internet.
The counterfeit golf clubs were sold for a third of the price of the real product, agents said.

The distributors arrested were Andrew Lee and Oscar Gonzales in Houston; Mike Cohen and Rob Isola in Savannah, Georgia and Albert and Angie Chung in Atlanta. Two distributors in Los Angeles were still at large.

The manufacturers arrested in Orlando were Midi Liu, owner of Tourney Golf in Taiwan; Ben Liao, and his brother David, whose father owns Join Wee International, a Taiwanese golf manufacturer; and Stephen Cheng, of Los Angeles. Cheng was released on a US$50,000 bond. The three others were being held in federal custody.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MAC CHIEF CALLS FOR END TO ZERO-SUM CROSS-STRAIT DIPLOMATIC WAR

TEXT.P: The diplomatic competition between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is a tough battle, the Republic of China's new chief mainland China policy planner said on Tuesday.

"We do not like engaging in a `zero-sum' diplomatic war with mainland China. But if Beijing continues to adopt this strategy, we can but follow suit," said Su Chi, newly appointed chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).
Su, a former deputy secretary-general to President Lee Teng-hui, said the ROC must maintain bilateral and multilateral relations with other countries to sustain its survival and development.
Noting that military and diplomatic issues are the thorniest cross-strait problems, Su said they are also the fields most prone to conflict.

DOC.HEADLINE: RIOTS TOOK PLACE IN WESTERN XINJIANG LAST SUMMER: REPORT

TEXT.P: At least eight riots took place in Ili Prefecture in western Xinjiang last summer, and hundreds of people were arrested as a result, the "Xinjiang Fazhi Bao" newspaper reported recently.

The report quoted Wang Mingshan, director of the Ili Prefecture Public Security Bureau, as saying that all of the riots took place before August. "Hundreds of terrorists were arrested afterwards," he said. It did not elaborate.

The newspaper also reported that in February, 1997, when mainland Chinese paramount leader Deng Xiaoping died, a serious riot took place in Ining, a major city in Ili Prefecture. Nearly 1,000 people took to the street to intercept the cars carrying criminals to be executed that day. At least 12 people were killed in the clash between them and the armed police.

The city was placed under curfew after the riot for a long period of time, the report said, adding that violent actions against the Han people, government officials, police, and the military continued despite the curfew, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHAIRMAN CALLS ON DPP LEADERS, TAIPEI MAYOR AND LEGISLATIVE HEAD

TEXT.P: Visiting American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush called on newly elected Legislative Yuan President Wang Chin-ping Tuesday afternoon, and during their meeting Bush congratulated Wang on winning the post and exchanged views with him on ways to beef up exchanges between lawmakers in the United States and Taiwan.
Earlier on Tuesday Bush visited the headquarters of Taiwan's major opposition party, the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), and met separately with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
In his meeting with DPP leaders, Bush reiterated Washington's official position that it will not interfere in relations between Taipei and Beijing as long as they remain peaceful.

He politely acknowledged the view of DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung, who said to Bush that Taiwan is an independent sovereign state whose application for membership in the World Trade Organization (WTO) should be processed separately from that of mainland China.
Beijing, which considers Taiwan a breakaway province, has repeatedly demanded that Taipei be allowed into the WTO only after Beijing is admitted.

Bush met with Ma for about 30 minutes in a closed-door meeting. Ma told reporters afterward that Bush, who is worried over the surging rent prices the AIT is being charged for its Taipei office, has asked the city, which owns the office, not to further raise rent prices.
Bush arrived in Taiwan on Jan. 24.
The AIT was set up in 1979 as the US organization responsible for relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal ties, which were severed earlier that year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROCSAT-1 OPERATING NORMALLY AS CONTROLLERS PREPARE FOR EXPERIMENTS

TEXT.P: ROCSAT-1, Taiwan's first wholly owned and operated satellite, is functioning normally and has passed over Taiwan 40 times since it was put into orbit on Jan. 26, the National Science Council (NSC) of the Republic of China reported Tuesday.

NSC officials involved in Taiwan's space program said that the satellite has so far orbited Earth 89 times. Five days after its launch the satellite began using its solar panels to collect energy from the Sun to power itself.
The NSC's space center in Hsinchu is making adjustments to ROCSAT-1's orbit as operators prepare the satellite to begin conducting scientific experiments.

Chu Fei-hung, head of Taiwan's ROCSAT-1 project, said on Tuesday that all research-related trials will be completed by the end of March. ROCSAT-1 will then begin to collect data on the effects of ionosphere plasma electrodynamics, take pictures of various oceans, and perform a variety of communications-related experiments.
The research satellite has 72 kilograms of fuel, enough to operate under normal conditions for four years, two years longer than originally planned, Chu said.
At the space center, located in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, a total of 120 technological experts, grouped into three task forces, are monitoring ROCSAT-1.

ROCSAT-1's successful launch, which indicates the ROC's advanced satellite-manufacturing ability, is expected to bolster the island's development of high-tech industries and attract foreign buyers to Taiwan-made satellite components.
The launch marks a new era in the ROC's scientific research and development, NSC Vice Chairman Tsay Ching-yen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL DENIES REPORTS ON TAIWAN'S TMD SYSTEM PARTICIPATION

TEXT.P: A ranking official with the Republic of China's Foreign Ministry on Tuesday denied a press report that Taiwan has been excluded from the US-proposed theater missile defense (TMD) system.
The press report allegedly claimed that a report prepared by the US Department of Defense has reached a conclusion that "Taiwan is in no condition to take part in the TMD system."

The ROC official said that the press report was incorrect. But he said Taiwan is not in a position to comment as the US Defense Department's assessment on the TMD issue would be sent to the US Congress in one or two days and has not been made public yet.
The official also denied another press report that former US Assistance Secretary of Defense Charles Freeman made a secret visit to Taiwan recently to invite Taiwan to participate in the TMD system.

He said the Taipei visit by Freeman and three other scholars was in connection with a study on how Asia's political and military landscape will look in the year 2025. That study will be used to help the United States map out a middle- and long-term defense plan, and it falls under a project undertaken by the National Security Group, a consultancy commissioned by the Pentagon to conduct the study.
The official acknowledged that Freeman and his party did hold talks, arranged by the American Institute in Taiwan, with some ROC government leaders.

In addition to Taiwan the US group also visited mainland China, Japan and South Korea. That shows the purpose of their visit was not to invite Taiwan to join the TMD system as reported by some media, he said.

The Republic of China has been assessing the feasibility of joining the US-initiated TMD system. Newly appointed Defense Minister Tang Fei said on Monday that if a better means than Taiwan's participation in the TMD system can be found to reduce the military threat posed by mainland China to Taiwan, then the ministry would fully support such measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: VETERAN ROC JOURNALIST CHIA LEE REMEMBERED

TEXT.P: Chia Lee, a former Tokyo bureau chief of the Central News Agency, died of an illness in the United States in December last year. He was 81.
Lee's friends in Taiwan will attend a memorial service at CNA's head office on the morning of Feb. 6 to remember the outstanding journalist and writer.
Lee joined CNA in 1947 and was the first Chinese reporter to cover the Korean War in 1950.
His wife Topaz said in an interview that her husband was a "loyal journalist," and that was why he turned down several invitations to serve the ROC government.
Lee, who was fluent in Chinese, Japanese and English, worked for CNA's Tokyo bureau for three decades. In 1963 he served as president of the Foreign Correspondents' Club of Japan.

In 1988 Lee underwent a successful operation in Taipei to treat prostate cancer. In 1991 Lee and his wife left Japan to stay in the United States. In 1997, cancer cells were found to have spread to his liver. He died on Dec. 17, 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD COMMAND LOOKING INTO GROUPING OF UNIDENTIFIED BOATS

TEXT.P: The Coast Guard Command (CGC) is closely watching the recent convergence into Republic of China waters of unidentified vessels, and will continue to monitor the development for reasons of national security, CGC sources reported Tuesday.

In a formal statement released Tuesday, CGC said that over the past month, many unidentified boats, most of which are believed to be of mainland Chinese origin, have converged in the waters off Penghu in southwestern Taiwan and off Miaoli in northern Taiwan. Officials said the boats had likely entered ROC waters to seek refuge from bad weather at sea.

Starting 2 a.m. Tuesday the vessels began to converge on Penghu and Miaoli. By 6 p.m. that same day, 61 boats had entered the Penghu area -- only 0.2 nautical miles from Penghu's Kupuoyu, while four others were anchored 1.2 nautical miles from Miaoli.

As has been the case during the past month, ROC marine police have been ordered to take a hands-off approach to the encroachment and, for humanitarian reasons, to allow the boats to seek shelter in ROC waters.
CGC officials said the boats will be ordered to leave as soon as the weather clears up, adding that they will closely monitor the boats in the meantime.

The vessels' classification, characteristics, sailing routes and operations are being studied and analyzed, as are relevant weather factors, to ensure Taiwan's continued national security, officials said.

Mainland fishing boats constantly sail across the demarcation line dividing the Republic of China and the People's Republic of China to fish in defiance of ROC warnings. The incursions have seriously endangered Taiwan's security and local fishermen's livelihoods, CGC officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT APPROVES GOVERNMENT'S BUDGET REQUEST

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui gave a green light Tuesday to the government's budget for the fiscal year running from July of this year to June, 2000, clearing the way for the Executive Yuan to present it to the legislature for approval.

The budget, which contains expenditures totaling NT$2.25 trillion (US$70.03 billion) and revenue of NT$1.94 trillion (US$60.31), has a deficit of NT$313.2 billion (US$9.72 billion). The government must also pay a total of NT$193.4 billion (US$6 billion) over the next fiscal year to service its existing debt, which means it must raise an extra NT$506.6 billion (US$15.73 billion) through loans.

In explaining to President Lee the preparation of the budget, Wei Duan, director-general of Budget, Accounting and Statistics under the Executive Yuan, said the government's outstanding debts account for 22.1 percent of the country's gross national product (GNP).

Specifically, central government debts accounts for 15 percent of Taiwan's GNP, while local government debts account for 7 percent. Taiwan's overall debt level relative to its GNP is relatively healthy compared with other countries, he said.

The budget counts on NT$140 billion (US$4.34) in income being generated through stock transaction taxes. This virtually rules out the possibility of phasing out the tax to reinvigorate Taiwan's flagging bourse.

Given the widening budget deficit, Wei said there is no possibility of a pay hike for public employees during the next fiscal year. A decision on the matter will be announced by Premier Vincent Siew at the end of February when he formally passes the budget on to the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AIRLINES SAW BLEAK YEAR IN 1998

TEXT.P: Last year was a bleak one for all Taiwan airlines because of a variety of factors, sources from the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) reported Tuesday.

Domestic and international carriers in Taiwan suffered declines in both the number of flights made and in passenger loads in 1998, mainly because of an economic slump and a series of air disasters, CAA officials noted.
Domestic airlines conducted 250,000 flights last year, averaging 684 flights per day, a decline of 12.82 percent from year-earlier levels.

The number of seats available on flights by all Taiwan airlines last year totaled 25.98 million, a year-on-year decline of 7.13 percent. The total number of passengers carried on those flights, however, totaled only 16.67 million, or an average of 45,672 passengers per day. That figure is down 10.41 percent from year-earlier levels, according to CAA tallies.

Passenger loads dropped 2.34 percentage points from 1997 levels to 64.16 percent. Only those air routes connecting Taiwan and the offshore islands of Green Island, Lanyu, Penghu and Matsu, maintained average passenger loads of 75 percent or greater.

CAA officials attributed the sluggishness suffered by airlines in 1998 to the region's economic slowdown, a series of crashes that began last February, and an islandwide enterovirus outbreak that begain in the spring, an strike by pilots with Transasia Airways.
Other factors included a spate of mechanical problems faced by UNI Airlines, the financial crisis of U-Land Airlines and insufficient ground facilities at aiports in Taipei and Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION TO VISIT MACEDONIA IN MARCH: TUPURKOVISKI
DOC.DATELINE: Bonn, Feb. 2 (CNA) (By Lilian Lin and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Vasil Tupurkovski, head of the Macedonian government agency responsible for reconstruction and development, has said that a large Republic of China delegation will visit Macedonia in March for discussions on trade and economic cooperation between the two allies.

Tupurkovski mentioned the visit in an interview with a Macedonia daily. He accompanied Foreign Minister Aleksandar Dimitrov on a trip to Taiwan last month to forge formal relations with the Republic of China.

Tupurkovski said the visit will allow the two countries to evaluate potential Taipei-Skopje cooperation projects. He said an agreement by the Republic of China to help Macedonia with trade and economic cooperation was an essential element in discussions that led to the countries forging diplomatic relations.

He said through the cooperation his country is expected to obtain benefits that can help Macedonia's financial balance for four years, while annual technological assistance worth US$3 million is expected from the Republic of China.

Taiwan's annual exports to the European Union as a whole reached US$40 billion, Tupurkovski said, stressing that if as little as 5 percent of that amount was processed in or shipped through Macedonia, his country could earn a fortune.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The Ministry of Finance will unveil a new package to stabilize the bearish stock market next Wednesday.
The China Times:
Legislator Liu Ping-wei, also a former Taiwan Provincial Assembly speaker, defaulted on checks worth more than NT$100 million.
The United Daily News:
Legislator Liu Ping-wei failed to honor checks worth more than NT$100 million.
The Liberty Times:
Taipei will have the world's highest building -- a 508-meter, 101-story skyscraper.
The Commons Daily:
Mainland China faces many crises under President Jiang Zemin's leadership.
The China Post:
Legislator's financial woes rock the local stock market.
The China News:
Taiwan stocks nosedive on margin-call strains.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 3, or the 18th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1468: Johann Gutenberg, a German goldsmith who developed the letterpress printing method and oil-based inks, dies in obscurity.
1488: Portuguese explorer Bartholomeu Diaz, after rounding the Cape of Good Hope, lands on Africa's eastern coast. He is the first European to land on African soil.
1730: The London Daily Advertiser publishes the first stock exchange quotations.
1919: The League of Nations holds its first meeting in Paris with US President Woodrow Wilson presiding.
1924: Woodrow Wilson, the 28th US president and the winner of Nobel Peace Prize in 1919, dies at the age of 67.
1930: Ho Chi Minh establishes the Vietnamese Communist Party in Hong Kong.
1931: An earthquake jolts New Zealand, killing 256 people.
1945: US troops recover Manila in the Philippines from Japanese forces in World War II.
1966: The Soviet unmanned spaceship Luna IX lands on the moon and sends signals back to Earth.
1969: Yasser Arafat is elected as the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1994: US President Bill Clinton announces the lifting of the United States' trade embargo on Vietnam.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Living upon the poorest fare with the cold water for drink, and with my bent arms for a pillow, I could yet find pleasure in such a life, whereas riches and honors acquired through the sacrifice of what is right, would be to me as unreal as a mirage."

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA OPENS IN HONDURAS THIRD OVERSEAS TRADE CENTER
DOC.DATELINE: Panama, Feb. 2 (CNA) (By Eduardo Chen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) on Tuesday formally opened in San Pedro Sula, Honduras, its third overseas Taiwan Trade Center.

CETRA Chairman Lin Chen-kuo presided over the opening ceremony, which was attended by 60 officials and business representatives of Honduras and Taiwan, including Honduran presidential adviser Juan Bendeck, San Pedro Sula Mayor Roberto Rarios and Republic of China Ambassador to Honduras C.Y. Chang.

Addressing the participants, Lin explained that stable economic development in Central America was the major reason why Taiwan decided to establish the trade promotion center in San Pedro Sula, which lies is the middle of Central America.
The Republic of China will rely on the new facility as it seeks to boost foreign trade and expand its economic relations with regional countries, Lin said.
CETRA's two other overseas trade center are located in Poland and Paraguay.
Leading a 25-member delegation, Lin arrived in San Pedro Sula on Sunday for a fact-finding visit. The group is scheduled to return home via Miami on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIES WITH ROC ARE BIG FINANCIAL STEP FORWARD FOR MACEDONIA: PAPER

TEXT.P: The establishment of formal diplomatic ties between Macedonia and the Republic of China represents a giant step forward for Macedonia in its financial and business development, said a leading Macedonian newspaper on Tuesday.

The Macedonian Diary gave a thumbs-up to the new Taipei-Skopje ties, saying it has ushered Macedonia into a new era financially and commercially, according to Chi Wang-teh, the ROC diplomatic attache in Skopje who is keeping Taiwan abreast of the latest reactions in Macedonia regarding the ties.

Chi arrived in the Macedonian capital of Skopje Monday to prepare for Taipei's opening of an embassy there. The Republic of China and Macedonia forged formal diplomatic relations on Jan. 27. Chi will also begin making arrangements for a visit at the end of this month by ROC Foreign Minster Jason Hu.

Chi quoted The Macedonian Diary as reporting that Macedonia's decision to establish formal ties with the Republic of China was not made with the aim of bringing money into the eastern European country, nor was it intended as a snub to mainland China. The newspaper, however, said Beijing's opposition to the Taipei-Skopje ties is understandable.

According to another Macedonian newspaper, The Macedonia Today, some lawmakers from opposition parties are said to voice strong opposition to the move in new parliamentary sessions. They said they will publish the telephone numbers of various Macedonian officials involved in the decision so that the public can contact them to express their disapproval.

A leading Macedonian political commentator, however, said formal ties with the Republic of China is not harmful to Macedonia, and "there is no foundation for negative reactions," according to the newspaper.
Meanwhile, Professor Skaric, a constitutional authority in Macedonia, suggested that Macedonia and the Republic of China form a confederation for even closer ties, Chi said.

Chi quoted another report as suggesting that Macedonia should remain firm in its resolve to establish full relations with the Republic of China. Otherwise, it may follow in the footsteps of Latvia, which initially attempted to establish relations but ultimately abandoned that attempt. If that were to happen to Macedonia, it could create bad feelings, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE GANGS FLOOD CANADA WITH HUMAN CARGO

TEXT.P: Canada has become a prime target for mainland Chinese gangs trying to funnel illegal immigrants into the United States in what is fast becoming a multi-million-dollar operation, a major Canadian newspaper reported Tuesday.

The Globe and Mail quoted official sources as saying that last year, 1,365 mainland Chinese nationals were arrested trying to enter Canada illegally -- and the number who succeeded in entering undetected is many times higher.

The discovery on Sunday of four mainland Chinese women wedged under a fish truck preparing to cross from Ontario into New York state was "a small but newsworthy example of the growing trade in smuggled humans that has developed in Canada," according to the daily.

It quoted Canadian government sources as saying most of the illegal immigrants pass through a lucrative, highly developed international pipeline run by professional criminals, many with links to triads, mainland China's brutal equivalent to the Mafia.

Taiwan has become part of the "international pipeline," according to the report. It noted that the illegals are usually sent by boat from Fujian to Taiwan, "where they are given forged passports and visas, then flown to South America or Europe." Paris has become one of the most popular stopover spots, according to the paper.

They then board a flight to Canada. Most often, the newcomers arrive in Toronto's Pearson Airport, where they present themselves as refugees and ask for asylum. After making their refugee claim and promising to appear for a hearing at a later date, they are released.

The Mail quoted an immigration official as saying, "Many of these people claim refugee status and then cross the border to the United States soon after they enter." Government tallies show that the number of abandoned or withdrawn refugee claims has soared in Canada, from 126 in 1989 to 5,663 in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: IOC CLEARS SYDNEY OF WRONGDOING IN BIDDING PROCESS

TEXT.P: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) on Tuesday night cleared Sydney Olympics officials of breaking any rules when bidding for the rights to hold the 2000 Olympics.

At an IOC meeting in Lausanne, Switzerland, officials investigated Sydney's offer of sports aid payments to Olympic authorities in both Kenya and Uganda on the eve of the Olympic host city vote in 1993.
Sydney defeated Beijing, winning the rights to serve as host city for the 2000 Games.
Investigator Dr. Jacques Rogge -- the IOC member in charge of the 2000 Games -- said he was satisfied that everything Sydney Olympic officials did was legal.
The Sydney bid payments to Kenya and Uganda were disclosed after a bribery scandal erupted over Salt Lake City's successful bid for the 2002 Winter Olympics.
"The Australian Olympic Committee acted within the rules. There was no cash given, no under-the-table payments, everything was straightforward and correct," Rogge told reporters.
Australian Olympics officials were pleased that they were cleared of any wrongdoing.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA EXTENDS ITS PAPERLESS VISA SYSTEM TO TAIWAN, HK

TEXT.P: In a move to lure more foreign tourists to the country, the Australian government on Wednesday announced it would expand its electronic travel authority (ETA) system to include Taiwan and Hong Kong starting July 1.
In a statement faxed to CNA, Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said, "The ETA system has been a great success, with more than 70 percent of all visitors to Australia using the system."
"In the lead-up to the introduction, officers of my department will continue working with officials in Hong Kong and Taiwan on administrative and technical issues,' he said.
Tourists from mainland China, however, will still have to apply for visas to visit Australia.

"Tourism provides major economic benefits to Australia and the continued expansion of the ETA system will considerably improve Australia's ability to handle the expected increase in visitors, particularly in the lead-up to the Olympic Games in the year 2000," Ruddock said.
ETA entry is currently available to nationals of 29 countries, including the United States, the United Kingdom, parts of Western Europe, Singapore and Japan.
The system makes it easier for tourists and short-term business travelers to enter Australia.

"It is important for genuine travelers to be able to take advantage of this service but at the same time it is essential to ensure that suitable measures are in place to ensure the security of Australia's borders," Ruddock said.

"In (fiscal) 1997-98 some 2.9 million visitors obtained visas to travel to Australia on business or to take a holiday. Of these, 75,000 were issued to residents of Hong Kong and 140,000 residents of Taiwan."

Tourist arrivals from Taiwan fell 2.2 percent to 129,299 between January and October 1998 from a year earlier, and the number of Hong Kong tourists dropped 6.7 percent to 118,864 during the same period, according to the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC).
An ATC spokesperson attributed the decline to the lingering impact of the Asian financial crisis on the one hand and the exclusion of Hong Kong and Taiwan from the ETA system on the other.
Australian tourism promoters said the expansion of the ETA system will definitely help boost the number of tourists from Taiwan and Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLAN TO REDUCE PROVINCIAL STAFF BY HALF

TEXT.P: The number of civil servants in provincial governments in mainland China will be cut by half, according to a plan by Beijing to streamline the country's bureaucracy.
The Hong Kong Standard reported Wednesday that the plan is to take effect after the lunar New Year holiday.

According to the report, Premier Zhu Rongji last March launched a three-year program to trim the army ranks of civil servants. Personnel of the Central Government would be cut by at least one-third under the plan.
By the end of last year the streamlining of a new State Council was almost completed, with the number of ministries reduced from 41 to 29, the report quoted sources as saying.
The State Council, it noted, issued the circular on streamlining several weeks ago, and provincial governments are expected to start shedding staff members immediately after the lunar New Year.
Half of the total number of provincial government staff members would lose their jobs under the plan, sources were quoted as saying.
Provinces were only allowed to make their own decisions on specific issues in accordance with the central authorities, the sources said.
