DOC.HEADLINE: CIA DIRECTOR SAYS PLA'S MODERNIZATION PUSHES ON

TEXT.P: Despite a slowdown in economic growth, mainland China is still actively pursuing its military modernization program while seeking to prevent US intervention in the Taiwan Strait, a top US intelligence official said Tuesday.
"China's military modernization program continues apace despite slowing economic growth," according to George Tenet, director of the Central Intelligence Agency.
Their efforts are assisted by sustained levels of defense spending and by the availability of weapons and technologies from the former Soviet bloc, he told the Senate Armed Forces Committee.
Testifying on threats to US national security, Tenet said mainland China is increasing the size and survivability of its retaliatory nuclear force.
Mainland China is, however, "unlikely to make the resource commitment needed to approach the (nuclear) force levels either of the United States or Russia," he added.

Mainland China is also developing and acquiring air and naval systems "intended to deter the United States from involvement in Taiwan and to extend China's fighting capabilities beyond its coastline," he said.

"Although China does not want a conflict over Taiwan," the told the senators, " it refuses to renounce the use of force as an option and continues to place its best new military equipment opposite the island."
In his prepared testimony, Tenet described mainland China as "a great power on the rise, diplomatically, militarily and economically."

He said mainland China has the potential to affect the United States' security posture in Asia but said that "the extent to which its ambitions and growing capabilities represent a challenge or threat to US interests is still an open question."

Despite having more favorable conditions than Russia, mainland China's future is uncertain because of some domestic challenges, such as doubts over sustained economic growth and labor and social unrest, he said.
During the hearing, the CIA director also talked about "regional troublemakers" such as Iraq, North Korea, Iran, the Balkans and the South Asian subcontinent.
He said Russia is "increasingly unpredictable" in political terms and that its worsening economic situation "affects all aspects of the Russian scene."
For example, Tenet said, Russia "has magnified the proliferation threat across the board, as growing financial pressures raise incentives to transfer sensitive technologies."

DOC.HEADLINE: 1999 KEY TO TAIWAN'S WTO BID

TEXT.P: This is a key year for Taiwan's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Director-General Chen Ruey-long said on Wednesday.

Canada and Hong Kong are currently the only two WTO members which have not yet signed formal protocols with Taiwan on the island's membership at the world trade regulatory body. However, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said it hoped to complete the signing by the first half of this year, Chen noted.

He told CNA that Taiwan wishes to join the WTO as soon as possible, preferably by 2000 when contracting parties will start a fresh round of negotiations. The third WTO ministerial meeting, slated for December in Seattle, will determine the timetable and how new negotiations will be handled, he added.

If Taiwan cannot enter the WTO by 2000, Taiwan may have to conduct a new set of bilateral talks on its terms for joining the Geneva-based organization with its contracting parties under new requirements, MOEA officials warned.

It is understood that relevant trade authorities have been pushing up the schedule for the signing of a protocol with Canada on Taiwan's WTO membership while seeking to persuade WTO's working party to conclude all procedural issues in the first half of this year.

Taiwan applied to join the General Agreement on Tariff and Trade, WTO's predecessor, in January 1990. A total of 26 WTO contracting parties voiced interest in holding two-way negotiations with Taiwan on its terms for entry, 24 of which have clinched bilateral accords with Taiwan on its membership at the world body which oversees global trade.

Meanwhile, three international trade experts -- John Jackson, Robert Hudec, and Deora Steger -- will visit Taiwan to help local businesses familiarize themselves with WTO regulations in the face of Taiwan's foreseeable entry to the trade organization.
While here, they will take part in a seminar on international trade at the Taipei International Convention Center on Friday, according to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 40 PERCENT OF TAIWAN PEOPLE HAVE HIGH BODY FAT

TEXT.P: Nearly 40 percent of Taiwan residents polled have a high level of body fat and about 90 percent do not know how to measure their body fat, results of a recent survey on obesity showed.

While people in Japan and the United States regularly check their body fat rate as an index of whether they are obese or not, a majority of people in Taiwan don't have a clear idea about the body fat factor or they don't know how to have their body fat checked, said Dr. Hsiao Tun-jen of Provincial Taoyuan Hospital.

A recent poll of more than 6,000 adult residents in Taipei and Kaohsiung cities found that 37 percent of the respondents have a high level of body fat, while 67 percent don't know what body fat rate is, and 55 percent said they didn't know that obesity equals a high body fat rate.

As many as 30 percent of those surveyed said they have tried to control their weight. Of these, 86 percent chose to diet as a means to cut weight, 61 percent chose exercise, 13 percent elected to fast, and 7 percent used weight-control pills and medicine.
In general, a man is overweight if his body fat rate exceeds 25 percent of his body weight, compared with 30 percent for women, Hsiao noted.
He stressed the importance of controlling one's body fat, citing statistics that six out of 10 major causes of deaths in Taiwan last year were related to obesity.

Hsiao said the best way to control body fat is to exercise. He recommended that people follow a 3-3-3 rule to get the best results -- exercise at least three times a week, at least 30 minutes each time, and exercise to a degree that your heart beats 130 times a minute.

In addition to exercise, Hsiao said a balanced diet is equally important. A balanced diet involves controlling one's intake of sugar, eating the right fat, drinking enough water, and consuming a sufficient amount of fresh vegetables and fruit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES CLOSE SLIGHTLY LOWER, FUTURES END MIXED

TEXT.P: Late buying of special category stocks reclaimed most of the lost ground on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday, with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, declining a slight 5.78 points to close at 5,743.86.

Affected by the overnight drop in the New York Stock Exchange and news that Legislator Liu Ping-wei may have defaulted on honoring checks, the local bourse opened low and fluctuated later in a downward trend.
At one point Wednesday, the weighted price index had plunged 153.06 points to 5,596.58, the lowest level of the day.
Late buying on electric machinery stocks pulled the index up to recover most of the losses.
Turnover amounted to NT$57.29 billion, up from the NT$44.76 billion recorded in the previous session.
The over-the-counter market also closed lower, with the market's index sliding a slight 0.46 points to finish at 143.48 on a turnover of NT$2.44 billion.
Meanwhile, the Taiwan stock index futures closed mixed.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for February were up 10 points to close at 5,890, with 5,641 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for March were up 10 points to close at 5,930, with 1,320 contract transactions, while those for June were down 34 points to 5,922, with 30 contract transactions. September futures were down 67 points to 5,950, with 15 contract transactions, and December futures were down 62 points to 5,970, with one contract transaction.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.02 against the greenback in Taipei on Wednesday, to close at 32.251 -- the highest level in the last two weeks.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$259 million -- the lowest in the last two weeks with the exception of the weekends.
The local currency opened at 32.251 and traded between 32.25 and 32.264.

Investors worried that the US Federal Reserve Board may increase interest rates to curb the overheated US stock market. The Dow Jones Industrial Index closed lower and the US dollar was also in a slump.
Affected by the sliding US dollar in international trading and the increased long-term interest rate in Japan, the Japanese yen ended stronger. Major currencies in Asia have also closed higher.

Dealers said the Taiwan dollar was recently affected by the local and overseas economic situation. But with the Central Bank of China closely monitoring the situation, the NT dollar fluctuated in a narrow range.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CUSTOMS ARREST TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN FOR COUNTERFEIT GOLF CLUBS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 2 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: At least eight Taiwan businessmen were among 12 people arrested in seven major US cities on Monday as a part of a crack down on counterfeit brand-name golf equipment, customs officials said on Tuesday.

From Taiwan are Midi Liu who heads Tourney Golf Co.; Ben Liao and his brother David Liao of Join Wee International, a golf equipment manufacturer; Albert Chung and his wife Angie Chung; and Andrew Lee. Two additional Taiwanese were reportedly arrested but their names were not released.

Liu, and the Liao brothers were arrested in Orlando, Florida, Chung and his wife were arrested in Atlanta, and Lee was arrested in Houston, customs officials said. The remaining two were arrested in Savannah, Georgia and Los Angeles.

Liu, who is believed to be a key figure in the counterfeit ring, reportedly sold 10,500 brand-name golf clubs to Lee at a lower price than the authentic clubs Lee purchased last year. Lee is accused of selling these lower-priced clubs and passing them off as the real brand.

Customs officials said most of the phony golf equipment they seized was made in Taiwan, mainland China, Vietnam and Thailand. The contraband goods were then shipped to the United States and passed off by involved distributors as well-known brands such as Calloway, Taylor Made, Cobra, Titleist and Ping.
Titleist and Cobra representatives were first alerted to the counterfeit goods during a golf fair held in the US in 1996, during which they discovered inauthentic goods carrying their brand name
Two years ago, the US customs began an undercover investigation, called "Project Teed Off," with customs agents posing as importers.

The arrested suspects will be prosecuted on charges of counterfeiting. According to US law, if they are found guilty, they face a maximum prison sentence of 10 years and a fine of US$2 million or less.
Officials with Taipei's representative office in Miami set off for Orlando on Tuesday in the hopes of providing relevant assistance to the three men there.

DOC.HEADLINE: US PROSECUTOR DROPS CHARGES AGAINST TAIWAN PROFESSOR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 2 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan professor, who was accused of trying to steal technology trade secrets from a US drug company for the Taipei-based Yuen Foong Paper Co., has cleared his name, his lawyer said on Tuesday.
"US prosecution authorities have dropped all criminal charges against Chester Ho, a professor at Taiwan's National Chiao Tung University," said William E. McDaniels, Ho's lawyer.

According to McDaniels, US prosecutors filed an application with a federal court in Philadelphia last Wednesday saying they would drop all charges against Ho in connection with the Yuen Foong case to uphold "judicial justice."
US Federal Court Judge Stuart Dalzell issued a decree on Jan. 28 approving the prosecution's request.

Nevertheless, the US prosecution maintains charges against two Yuen Foong executives -- Hsu Kai-lo and Chou Hua-ping. They were charged with attempted theft of technological secrets relating to the anti-cancer drug Taxol belonging to New York-based Bristol-Myers Squibb Co.

A federal court in Pennsylvania is scheduled to hold a hearing on Hsu and Chou's case on April 5. A grand jury, composed of 12 jurors, will be present at the hearing and is expected to make a decision on whether the two are guilty. If they are convicted, federal judges will mete out sentences within 45 to 75 days.

If convicted, Hsu faces a maximum jail term of 60 years and a fine of up to US$2.5 million, while Chou could receive up to 55 years plus a maximum US$1 million in fines. Chou, who is now in Taiwan, would be arrested if she sets foot on US soil.
Ho and Hsu were arrested by Philadelphia FBI agents upon their arrival in the United States on June 14, 1997 on charges of attempting to steal Taxol-related technological know-how.

Ho has been living in Boston since he was released on US$1 million bail on June 19, 1997 and was forced to give up his US and ROC passports and driver's license. Ho is now a visiting scholar at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Ho, also a technology broker, has reclaimed his passports and driver's license after all six criminal charges against him were dropped. He has yet to decide whether he will return to Taiwan to continue his teaching career at National Chiao Tung University's Graduate Institute of Biotechnology.
Ho's lawyer said US prosecutors decided to drop charges against Ho after a careful, comprehensive scrutiny of available evidence.
"The prosecutor has done so purely out of the consideration of upholding judicial justice. Ho has not struck any secret deals with US prosecution in exchange for his vindication," McDaniels stressed.

The "Taxol" case began in 1995 when an FBI agent, posing as a technology broker, sought to mediate a deal related to Taxol production expertise for Yuen Foong. Between 1995 and mid-1997, Yuen Foong allegedly contacted the undercover FBI agent 135 times by telephone or letter regarding the proposed deal.

Yuen Foong has consistently denied FBI accusations that it attempted to steal trade secrets from the US pharmaceutical company. Noting that the proposed Taxol deal was a FBI set-up, Yuen Foong said it had contacted the phony technology broker simply to gather information to evaluate a Taxol-related investment project without ever attempting to steal US trade secrets.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA RULES ON TIN PLATE DUMPING COMPLAINTS

TEXT.P: Indonesia has ruled that Taiwan, Australia, Japan, and South Korea have been dumping tin plate, and will impose anti-dumping taxes, Taiwan's Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said on Wednesday.

BOFT officials said they have received reports from Taipei's representative office in Jakarta that a committee of the Indonesian Ministry of Industry and Trade has completed an initial investigation of the dumping complaints.

The officials said that Taiwan manufacturers will be subject to a 41 percent punitive anti-dumping tax, while Japan will be taxed at 68.8 percent, Australia at 28 percent, and South Korea at between 5.22 and 9.88 percent.
Tin plate manufacturers from the four nations can file appeals to the Indonesian ministry within 30 days of receiving official notification of the anti-dumping tax.

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG ROTATES CADRES TO CURTAIL FIEFDOMS

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin introduced a new rotation of cadres to promote honesty in government and curb regionalism, the South China Morning Post reported on Wednesday.

According to the report, senior cadres have circulated a recent dictum by Jiang on the "principle of the five lakes and four seas." It refers to how officials, including those in the provinces, must come from different geographical and "factional" backgrounds.
The Post's report quoted a Beijing source as saying the continuing rotation went deeper than previous exercises, which were restricted to senior cadres such as provincial party chiefs and governors.
"This time, even mid-echelon cadres such as heads of counties are affected," the paper said. "Before, Beijing usually allowed 'native sons' to fill the positions of county chiefs."

A PLA source also noted similarly thorough personnel changes were taking place in the army, down to provincial and sometimes even smaller military districts. The source said Jiang was playing a personal role in both civilian and military reshuffles.
Political analysts said the key concern among the Jiang leadership was to boost the authority of the Communist Party amid decentralization and potential social unrest.
For example, Jiang recently approved a plan to tighten the party's control over local-level people's congresses.

The analysts said more provincial and municipal party secretaries would double as the chairmen of people's congresses in their provinces or cities. This was despite Jiang's recent instructions to "run the country according to law". (Stanley Cheung)

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES PLANNING ADDITIONAL 53 ECONOMIC ZONES

TEXT.P: Following the success of the Philippines' economic zones, the government is considering establishing 53 additional such sites to attract greater foreign investment and revitalize the countryside and increase rural incomes.

Speaking in a radio interview, Secretary Jose Pardo of the Department of Trade and Industry said the zones will attract businesses, provide jobs, boost home-based businesses as well as micro-enterprises.

Small- and medium-sized enterprises and housing projects will emerge around these new growth centers, Pardo said, adding that he is confident that these economic zones will be as successful as the first 56.
According to a recent survey conducted by the Makati Business Club, the business community shares Pardo's positive outlook on the economy.
The survey showed that 73.3 percent of the respondents expect "strong or modest revenue growth" this year.

The business community attributed the economy's stronger performance on four factors: the lowering of interest rates, a stabilized peso, the restoration of peace and order, and the continuity of the reform programs initiated by the administration of former President Fidel Ramos.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OOLONG TEA BECOMING FASHIONABLE IN MOSCOW
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, Feb. 3 (CNA) (By Chang Hong-kuan and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Tung Ting Oolong Tea from Taiwan has become very popular among Moscow's artistic and literary set these days, a vogue which just a year ago would have been unthinkable.
Traditionally, Russians far prefer tea to coffee, but in the past they have been accustomed to drinking black tea. This means that promoting green tea in Russia is no easy task.

However, ever since the owner of the Cosmopolitan Tea Shop in Moscow began working to combine the art of green tea-drinking, research into the I-Ching, or Book of Changes, the Chinese martial art of Tai-chi, and the art of Chinese painting, into an all-round interpretation of Chinese culture, it has become more than just a pipe dream.
The tea house, which is located in the vicinity of three of Moscow's major theaters, has now become a haunt of the city's literati.
Within a year, several other clubs and restaurants have followed the Cosmopolitan's lead, and business has become so brisk that customers now often have to stand in line for a seat.
In view of the latest fad, tea merchants from mainland China have been quick to make plans to market mainland green tea in Russia.

However, since Taiwan's tea processing techniques are considered to be closest to the traditional Chinese methods, it is Taiwan's Tung Ting Oolong Tea which is served in the Cosmopolitan, and has become the most popular among Moscow customers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONTINUES TO FARE WELL IN REGION: BUSINESS TIMES EDITORIAL

TEXT.P: Although Taiwan has steered clear of much of the turmoil during Asia's economic crisis, there are signs its economy could come under stress in the months ahead, the Business Times said in an editorial on Wednesday.
In a year which saw negative growth figures in other countries, Taiwan achieved 5 percent growth in 1998, down from 6.8 percent in 1997 and the lowest in more than a decade.

An increasing number of bounced checks, bad debt, and high unemployment are worrying finance officials as key economic indicators remain low. Exports, which account for more than 40 percent of Taiwan's economic output, are declining as its cash-strapped Asian trading partners buy less. And the stock market index has fallen to a 32-month low.

The economic slowdown in Taiwan began in the second half of last year as East Asia's economic crisis began to sap the Taiwanese economy. Just before last December's parliamentary elections, the Kuomintang government had to direct state-owned banks not to cut off credit to those companies which faced short-term financial problems and could not repay their loans.

When it became known that several large firms were suffering cash-flow problems, it caused jitters in the stock market and the government set up an US$8 billion Stock Stabilization Fund to prop up sagging shares prices. Taxes on business incomes have been cut to help small- and medium-sized enterprises -- the backbone of Taiwan's economy.
Despite these efforts, the economy is expected to revive only in the second half of 1999 as the impact of these will take some time to kick in.
Premier Vincent Siew has set a 5.5 percent growth target for 1999. Private sector analysts are less sanguine, with most predicting a figure of about 4.5 percent.

Taiwan is not without its strengths. It has ample foreign reserves of US$85 billion, little foreign debt, and like mainland China, has tough capital controls which make it difficult for speculators to attack its currency. Indeed, it was probably this combination of factors that kept out the troubles faced by the other East Asian economies in the first place.
But there are a few clouds gathering on the political horizon which could hurt the economy. Beijing seems to have raised the stakes on the reunification issue.

How the island's politicians manage this, the most delicate of relationships, will clearly have an impact on consumer sentiment and investment decisions. It can be safely said that this will be a challenging year for Taiwan, the business daily predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 'FATHER OF TECHNOLOGY' MARKS 90TH BIRTHDAY

TEXT.P: A tea party was held at the Taipei International Convention Center on Wednesday to celebrate elder statesman K. T. Li's 90th birthday.
Li, now a senior adviser to President Lee Teng-hui, is widely reputed as Taiwan's technology godfather and a chief architect of Taiwan's economic miracle.

During his tenures as economics minister (1976-1980) and finance minister (1980-1987), Li pushed for the establishment of export processing zones, the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park and the privatization of state-run enterprises. All these projects have helped lay a solid foundation for Taiwan's economic take-off and phenomenal development over past decades.
More than 2,000 well-wishers, including Vice President Lien Chan and Premier Vincent Siew, attended the tea party to wish Le many happy returns.
At the beginning of the party, Lien led all well-wishers to bow to Li to express their respect and best wishes to the elder statesman.
Lien said Li's devoted, down-to-earth working style and moral stature deserves emulation by all local people.

"Li has also set a model for today's civil servants by strictly keeping personal interest and preferences from affecting policy-making procedures," Lien said, adding that Li is a man of capability and virture.

Moreover, Lien said, Li has continued paying great attention to national and social affairs after his retirement. "His devotion to public-spirited community development programs in recent years is his intangible contribution to our country," Lien noted.

Speaking on the same occasion, Premier Siew said the younger generation of Taiwan's civil servants should learn from Li's innovative thinking, far-sightedness, and efficient, passionate and energetic working-style.
A devout Christian, Li has led a simple, orderly life. His self-discipline has helped keep him healthy at an advanced age.

An outspoken man, Li has not hesitated to criticize government policies or social trends. On Tuesday, Li criticized the government's NT$150 billion plan to rescue the rescue the property market by offering low-interest loans for homebuyers. The loan package has been blasted as a bailout to over-extended land developers. Li said the government should have offered other alternatives.
Li was also critical of the government's measures to prop up the shaky stock market, claiming the best policy is to allow the market mechanism to work its way out.

"Government intervention would only make the problem worse," Li said, adding that the government should reduce interference and concentrate on helping local enterprises upgrade their competitiveness in the world market.
Li won the 1968 Magsaysay Award for his outstanding achievements in government service.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP HEAD DETERMINED TO JOIN 2000 PRESIDENTIAL RACE

TEXT.P: While the nation's three major political parties have yet to announce their respective candidates for the 2000 presidential election, the former opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman on Wednesday expressed his determination to join the fray.
Hsu Hsin-liang said in an interview with the CNA that it is his "sacred mission" to run in the 2000 presidential race.

Hsu said he does not care whether or not he wins the election, adding that he only wants to forward the concept of "rising people" and describe what he thinks Taiwan's development direction should be in the next 20 years.

His so-called "rising people" refers to the creation of a new culture in Taiwan whereby the island will become more positively involved in economic activities in mainland China, will compete with the mainland in the international economic arena, and will maintain political dialogue with the mainland.
The concept also emphasizes that in the new international order, Taiwan will no longer need to worry about attack by Beijing.

Hsu first proposed the "rising people" concept in 1994, and said that although the concept was severely criticized then, it has "been proved correct," and that "now is the right time to discuss the idea."

Commenting on reports that some people within the DPP hope he will withdraw from the race, Hsu said he is not worried that his opinion is not accepted by the party because he believes his concept represents the views of the majority of the people of Taiwan.

Hsu also suggested that a special unit be set up under the direct jurisdiction of the presidential office to deal with cross-Taiwan Strait relations, and suggested that the government adopt a "go west" policy toward mainland China under the principle of separating politics from economics.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MOST PREMATURE BABY CHECKS OUT HEALTHY

TEXT.P: An "extremely premature baby" which recently checked out of the hospital has grown to his normal weight of 5.2 kilograms, the Linkou Chang Kung Memorial Hospital announced on Wednesday.
Pediatrician Lin Jui-ying said that the boy, surnamed Lin, had a birth weight of just 540 grams, setting a record for what may be the most premature birth in Taiwan.
Lin's mother went into labor for unknown reasons when she was only 23 weeks pregnant, and gave birth to two babies, only one of which survived.

Doctors at the hospital said that according to medical literature, a 23-week-old baby has only a 30 percent chance of survival. However, with the skill and teamwork of the hospital, the boy overcame the symptoms most common in premature babies such as chronic pulmonary disease, sepsis, and retinal problems.
Dr. Lin said that the boy checked out on Jan. 25, by which time he was in a normal condition, except for some difficulty in coordinating his suckling motions.
The doctor said she expects the boy to grow up to be a normal and healthy adult.
The hospital said that its success in nurturing the tiny boy puts it on a par with the most medically advanced nations in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: 97 PERCENT OF NBA FANS IN TAIWAN WILL WATCH GAMES THIS SEASON

TEXT.P: The results of a survey released on Wednesday on NBA fans in Taiwan show that 97 percent of them will still watch the reduced number of NBA games.

The survey, conducted by a market research company commissioned by cable television channel ESPN, shows that the NBA has loyal fans here, despite the fact that there are now just 50 games in the regular season. The reduction in the number of games is a result of a long lockout triggered by disputes between players and management.
The survey targeted fans aged 16-30, and the ratio of men to women was six to four.

With Michael Jordan's retirement from the Chicago Bulls, the survey also asked fans to choose his successor. Some 20 percent of those polled nominated Kobe Bryant, while 11 percent named Scottie Pippen, and six percent said Grant Hill should take up the mantle of "his airness."
The NBA season will start on Saturday, Taipei time.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP NAMES FORMER SECRETARY-GENERAL AS REPRESENTATIVE TO US

TEXT.P: Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Wednesday appointed its retired secretary-general, Chiu Yi-jen, as its representative to Washington.
The appointment was made by party chairman Lin Yi-hsiung and approved by the DPP Central Standing Committee.
Chiu will fill the post vacated by Parris Chang last August, and will work for two weeks in Washington every two months.

At a press conference following the announcement of his appointment, Chiu outlined six goals of his new job, including establishing regular contacts with the US government, Congress, think tanks, mass media, private groups, and Taiwanese communities in the United States.

Noting that Washington's misunderstanding of the DPP's campaign for Taiwan independence and the party's policy on national security, economy, trade, and foreign affairs, will hamper the party's development, Chiu said that he will try to strengthen the party's communications, and rid Washington of its misconceptions.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF TO ASK BEIJING TO TAKE BACK HIJACKERS BEFORE LUNAR NEW YEAR

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng said on Wednesday that over the next couple of days, the SEF will ask its Beijing counterpart to take back nine mainland Chinese hijackers in detention on Taiwan.

Jan said the SEF hopes to deport the nine mainlanders via sea, following the pattern of the two previous such handovers. On both occasions, one hijacker was flown to Kinmen, Taiwan's frontline island outpost, and thence taken by boat to a point between the island and the mainland coast to be handed over to mainland security officials.

The SEF told the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) of its intentions on Jan. 11, and has received a positive reply from ARATS, welcoming the proposal and referring the SEF to the Red Cross Society of Fujian Province, which would take delivery of the criminals.
Jan said the SEF hopes to complete the deportations before the Chinese New Year, which is only 11 days away.

The nine mainlanders, all of whom hijacked mainland Chinese aircraft to Taiwan on various occasions, have either completed their jail terms or have been released into illegal alien detention centers in Taiwan.

Legal documents relating to each of the cases will also be turned over to mainland security officials in the hope that the jail terms they have served in Taiwan will be taken into account when Beijing imposes its own punishment on them.
Two children who were brought to Taiwan by their hijacker parents will also be sent back to the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALISHAN STEAM LOCOMOTIVE TO HIT RAILS AGAIN

TEXT.P: Riding the steam locomotive up the steep slopes of Alishan (Mount Ali), the famed forest resort in Chiayi, southern Taiwan, is an indelible memory for many people in Taiwan.
Now, after a six-month period of renovation and repair, the old steam engine will again take to the rails to puff gracefully through one of the country's most beautiful forests.

Testing of the 86-year-old refurbished train has now been completed in readiness for its comeback journey during the Forest Rail Legend trip, the feature attraction of the Chiayi Cultural Festival at the end of the month.

The locomotive, one of 20-odd that have been gradually phased out, is once again in fine working order, and Chiayi City Government said the train will make four round trips daily between the North Gate stop and the stop at Chuchi, starting from the beginning of the festival on Feb. 27, so that the public can relive their fond memories of steaming along the green forest railway.
Chiayi City Cultural Center said the old, once-moribund locomotive will once again demonstrate its agility when it negotiates a tight hairpin bend at Chuchi.

Testing of the locomotive was overseen by old master Lin Mou-shan and the workers at the repair plant Wednesday. Lin was the first to fire up the boiler, and in no time, the old engine was brought chuffing into life and began to inch forward. The overjoyed repair staff also tried blowing the whistle, amid cheers and applause from the other workers.
Lin said that he still has some final touches to add to the locomotive before it meets the public later this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: F-16 CRASH MIGHT BE LINKED TO INSTRUMENT FAILURE

TEXT.P: Evidence gathered during the course of an initial investigation reveals that the fatal crash in Taitung County of a US-made F-16 fighter last month might be linked to instrument failure, high ranking air force officials said on Wednesday.
The air force managed to locate the aircraft's flight data recorder at the scene of the crash and sent it to the United States on Tuesday to try to determine the real cause of the accident.
But air force generals said that all evidence from the initial investigation points to instrument failure as the cause of the crash, although they did not rule out other factors.

They said that if the crash can be attributed to a problem with the plane's instrumentation, all the F-16s delivered by the US and remodeled by the air force will be grounded for an overhaul to avoid similar tragedies from occurring in the future.

The jet fighter, one of the 30 twin-seater F-16B's delivered by the US since 1997, smashed into a tea plantation in eastern Taiwan's Taitung County on Jan. 25, killing Lt. Col. Chang Chia-kun, 43 and Maj. Tai Wei-kang, 30, who were on a routine training flight.

It was the second accident involving a F-16B since the air force began taking delivery of an order for 150 of the planes in the 1997. The last incident occurred on March 20, 1998, when another of the planes disappeared over the sea near Penghu County, a group of small islands off the west coast of Taiwan. The wreckage of the aircraft has not been found, and its two pilots are presumed dead.
The advanced warplanes, ordered in 1992, form the backbone of the air force's new generation fleet of jet fighters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The Bank of Panhsin received NT$10 billion in loans from other financial institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 4, or the 19th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1793: France abolishes slavery in all its territories.
1904: The Japanese-Russian war breaks out.
1906: New York police adopt fingerprint lifting methods to collect evidence in criminal cases.
1922: China signs an agreement with Japan in Washington, D.C. to settle the Shandong dispute.
1945: Leaders of the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union meet in Yalta, USSR and reach a so-called "Yalta secret agreement." According to the pact, Soviet troops enter the war against Japan on the condition that its former land rights in China, grabbed by Japan in 1904, are later restored.
1948: Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) gains independence from Britain.
1949: Taiwan Provincial Governor Chen Cheng publicizes the practice of the Farm Rental Reduction Program, which was put into force on April 12 in the same year.
1966: An All Nippon Airway plane crashes in Tokyo's Haneda airport, killing all 133 aboard.
1976: A disastrous earthquake measuring 7.5 on the Richter scale jolts Guatemala, claiming more than 22,000 lives.
1986: Twelve political dissidents jailed for the Formosa magazine incident are released on parole. The incident occurred in 1979 when political dissidents clashed with police while celebrating the anniversary of the publication of the magazine.
1992: The Republic of China's Fair Trade Law goes into effect.
1998: A strong earthquake measuring 6.1 on the Richter scale hits northern Afghanistan, killing 4,000 and leaving more than 15,000 homeless.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I am not the one born with understanding. I am only the one who has given himself to the study of Antiquity and is diligent in seeking for understanding in such studies."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-MACEDONIA TIES CAN SERVE AS FORMULA FOR OTHER BALKAN STATES

TEXT.P: The establishment of formal diplomatic relations between Macedonia Republic and the Republic of China can serve as a formula for other Balkan states to help cement ties between Taiwan and that part of the world, a leading Macedonian lawmaker said Wednesday.

Savo Klimovski, speaker of the Parliament of Macedonia Republic, said the new ROC-Macedonia relations is conducive to stability in southern Europe. He added that some day, small nations like the ROC and Macedonia will be granted due justice and proper recognition.

In an exclusive interview with the Taipei-based Chinese-language China Times, Klimovski gave the thumbs-up to Taipei-Skopje ties, saying it has ushered bilateral relations into a new era of financial and political cooperation.

Klimovski urged Taiwan not to worry about noises in Macedonia toward the new diplomatic ties, saying Macedonia's decision to establish formal relations with the ROC was supported by more than two-thirds of the country's coalition parties currently in power.

Meanwhile, Klimovski described Taiwan's proposed financial aid to, and investment plans in Macedonia as reciprocal cooperation which is mutually-beneficial. Macedonia's economic prospects, however, will hinge on the results of the year-end presidential election, he pointed out.

On Beijing's strong protests against the new Taipei-Skopje ties, Klimovski said Macedonia has maintained cordial ties with mainland China, and he would hate to see the good relations be affected by such an issue. He said he would feel sorry if Beijing were not able to accept the fact rationally.
Besides, he said, Macedonia is a sovereign country which has every right to make its own decision on whom to make friends with.

Concerning Macedonia's national security, Klimovski said Macedonia has its own measurement of national security and diplomatic relations, such as its relations with mainland China, which is now a super power.

"My point of view is that Macedonia's internal stability and sovereignty will face challenges if the economy is shaky and funds are short. Economy and finance are also key factors related to national security," he added.

ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu and his Macedonian counterpart, Aleksandar Dimitrov, signed a joint communique in Taipei on Jan. 27 on the establishment of full-fledged diplomatic relations between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: LONG-ACTING PAIN KILLER DEVELOPED BY LOCAL RESEARCHERS

TEXT.P: A long-acting pain killer developed by local researchers has been approved by the United States' Food and Drug Administration for clinical testing on humans, the National Defense Medical Center said on Thursday.

Center researchers said Sebacoyl Dinalbuphine Ester (SDE) will be the first drug developed in Taiwan to gain such approval, marking a big step for local biopharmacuticals making inroads into the international market.
SDE is said to be effective in fighting pain for up to a week or longer, greatly relieving the suffering and inconveniences of patients as well as cutting medical costs.

In 1994, the medical center, Tri Service General Hospital and the privately-run Yung Shin Pharmaceutical Industry, began to work together in developing the drug in a project promoted by the National Science Council.

Hu You-pu, the head of the project and director of the medical center's Pharmaceutical Research Institute, said the total research budget for SDE, about NT$200 million (US$6.15 million), was about one-fortieth of a regular budget in the United States to develop a new drug.

Hu said terminal cancer patients and those recovering from surgery normally require a great deal of analgesic. Currently, the most common pain killers are effective for only several hours and the patients will need injection every few hours, while SDE has been developed to continue to be effective for days.

Researchers have completed all experiments and animal testing as well as toxicology tests on SDE, an injected intramuscular drug, and results have shown that it is safe and has no annoying side effects, Hu said.

SDE now faces between three and five years of clinical testing before it will be available for sale. It is expected to hit the US and Taiwan markets simultaneously once approval has been granted, Hu noted.
Some 15 pain killer chemical components along with SDE have been developed under the project, and have applied for patents in the ROC, the United States, Japan and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREST FIRE CLAIMS 5 HECTARES IN CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Fire broke out on a hillside of Shuimeishan in Taichung County on Wednesday, and burned away five hectares of forest land.
The fire continued to burn large areas of grass and trees on Thursday, fire-fighters said.
Fortunately, the affected plant life had no economic value, forestry officials said. The forest on Shuimeishan is mostly under the administration of the Taiwan Provincial Forestry Bureau.
So far no casualties have been reported, according to the bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIANS MAY BE ALLOWED TO KEEP DUAL CITIZENSHIP

TEXT.P: The Australian government is considering allowing Australians to retain their passports after taking up the citizenship of another country, Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said.
Currently, those born in Australia must relinquish their citizenship if they become nationals elsewhere.
Analysts said the new plan to allow dual citizenship could have significant implications for foreign ownership limitations in corporate law.
Changes to dual citizenship have come under discussion because of the globalization of the workforce and markets, the immigration minister noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE LEADERS ALARMED BY DEMOCRATIC VOTE IN SICHUAN

TEXT.P: A daring democratic experiment in a remote township in Sichuan where farmers selected their local leaders in a secret ballot sent alarm bells ringing in Beijing, according to the Sydney Morning Herald.

Voters in Buyun township, a rural village with a population of about 20,000 in the central Chinese province of Sichuan, defied central authorities on Dec. 31 and cast their ballots for a new township chief after two weeks of spirited campaigning by three candidates, the Herald reported from Beijing.
Chinese leaders have ordered a news blackout of the poll in the official media to avoid other townships following suit during a period of widespread economic and social turbulence.

The poll has been declared illegal and was attacked in the state-run media before the blackout but it remains unclear what the central authorities intend to do about the tiny outbreak of democracy, the daily reported.

China has promoted village-level elections across the country in recent years to demonstrate that the Chinese Communist Party was gradually working towards democracy. But these low-level polls are closely controlled with the candidates carefully screened and little opportunity allowed for real challenges to local party authority, the daily reported.

Reform-minded officials in Sichuan have apparently now taken the radical steps of allowing an election in Buyun for the next highest level of government, the township, where officials can collect tax, build public works and spend grants from provincial and central governments.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT PASSENGER SERVICE UNDER STUDY: MOTC

TEXT.P: Taiwan is still studying whether to permit direct passenger transport across the Taiwan Strait, officials of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said on Thursday.

The officials made the remarks amid reports that the MOTC is planning to begin allowing such services starting in May. Reports have also said that Fujian province on mainland China's southeastern coast has constructed a passenger wharf on Meizhou Island, and will push for cross-strait passenger services this year.

Another report said that a Singaporean ocean liner has applied to Keelung harbor authorities for permission to establish a triangular chartered liner service route that stretches from Keelung to Japan's Ishigaki Island and on to Meizhou.

MOTC officials said that direct cross-strait shipping and passenger transport would be one of the key issues studied this year, but they said that the MOTC has not yet made plans to permit such services, let alone formulated a policy on the issue.

They noted that the issue of cross-strait passenger transport is affected not only by Taiwan's mainland China policy but also by such considerations as entry and exit procedures for people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, as well as navigation safety.
Meizhou boasts a century-old temple dedicated to the Goddess of the Sea, more commonly known as Matsu in Chinese culture.

According to MOTC tallies, Taiwan pilgrims make more than 100,000 visits to the Meizhou Island every year to pay tribute to Matsu, The peak season are around March 3 and Sept. 9 on the lunar calendar. March 3 is Matsu's birth anniversary and Sept. 9 marks her deification.

As Taiwan still bans direct cross-strait transport service, local pilgrims have to spend nearly a day reaching Meizhou via either Hong Kong or Macau. The direct travel ban prompted many local residents to illegally travel to Meizhou by fishing boats.
Mainland officials in charge of cross-strait navigation affairs said that the mainland welcomes any Taiwan measures to promote direct cross-strait shipping and passenger transport.

They noted that most of the Taiwan tourists traveling to Meizhou Island, located off the coast of Fujian province, have gone there in fishing ships, which sometimes experience difficulty in navigating the strait.
The officials noted that Meizhou has constructed a passenger wharf to accommodate passengers arriving on liners, but they said that the liners could also berth in Xiamen.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROPOSED TAX MAY COST AUSTRALIA DEARLY: REPORT

TEXT.P: The federal government's proposed 10 percent goods and services tax (GST) may cost Australia 59,000 in jobs and US$1 billion in lost revenue from decreased foreign tourism, the Tourism Task Force said on Thursday.
The number of overseas tourists is expected to drop about 10 percent once the GST is introduced in July 1, 2000, the task force told the Senate committee.
The parliament is deliberating a federal government tax reform proposal which includes the controversial GST.

"This would result in a loss of over 25,400 jobs and the loss of A$1.6 billion (over US$1 billion) per annum in export earnings, equivalent in export terms to the abolition of the sugar or iron and steel industry overnight," the report noted.
Another 34,100 jobs will also be lost as a result of the decline in foreign tourist arrivals in service-related sectors such as restaurants and hotels.
Tourist promoters and travel agencies are putting pressure on the government to exempt foreign tourists from the tax to prevent the loss of jobs and revenue.

DOC.HEADLINE: COLD FRONT KILLS MILKFISH IN YUNLIN COUNTY
DOC.DATELINE: Yunlin, southern Taiwan, Feb. 4 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A large number of milkfish, a seafood delicacy often bred and raised in freshwater ponds, froze to death Thursday morning in the coastal county of Yunlin as a cold front lay over Taiwan, fishery sources reported Thursday.
About 50,000 milkfish in ponds scattered around Taishi in Yunlin County were found belly up early Thursday morning when the temperature there dropped to 8 degrees Celsius.
Fishermen said a power outage Thursday morning at 4 a.m. shut down the ponds' temperature regulators, which resulted in water temperatures dropping even more quickly.
The total loss to fishermen is estimated at NT$1 million, and further losses are expected as the cold front is expected to remain over Taiwan for the next couple of days.
The frozen milkfish will be taken to canneries or food processing plants, where the fish will be ground into powder and used as foodstuffs, fishermen said.

Although southern Taiwan has average temperatures that are generally warmer than those in northern Taiwan, portions of Yunlin and Chiayi counties often see the coldest weather around Taiwan during the winter because of special oceanic and geographical factors, weather forecasters said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC TAKES 3 MEASURES TO HELP AREA BANKS COPE WITH Y2K

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) has taken three measures to cope with the year 2000 computer crisis, also known as Y2K, and to prevent the millennium bug from having an adverse effect on the operations of the nation's foreign exchange market.

First the CBC has urged appointed foreign exchange banks to be aware of the legal risks stemming from Y2K. At the invitation of the CBC, Nigel Li of the law firm Lee and Li spoke on Jan. 22 to banks on the legal problems they could face in 2000 and provided them with reference information on the problem.

The bank has also urged appointed foreign exchange banks to be aware of need to test all their computer systems. The CBC gave written notice to all appointed banks last Dec. 24, asking them to make sure they test their systems early enough to ensure that the banks will be able to weather the Y2K crisis smoothly.

Finally the CBC has urged appointed foreign exchange banks to be aware of the importance of emergency measures. Last Dec. 31 the CBC provided the banks with a list of questions and answers regarding the emergency measures adopted by US financial institutions to cope with the Y2K bug.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINDERGARTEN GROUP BUYS INTO FINANCIALLY STRAINED EVENING PAPER

TEXT.P: The Dao Sheng Group, owners of kindergartens in and around Taipei City, has reportedly bought the Independence Evening Post (IEP) on Thursday, a move that may stem the growing dispute between the owner and employees of the financially strained Independence News Group.

Jiang Dao-sheng, owner of the Dao Sheng Kindergarten Education Group, was said to have acquired the IEP at a cost of NT$1.3 billion (US$40 million) after signing an agreement with Independence News Group owner Chen Cheng-chung, who is also a Taipei city councilor.
The purchase has helped to defuse, at least temporarily, a two-week standoff between the paper's management and labor union over unemployment compensation and employee rights.

Labor union leaders said they were pleased with the alleged purchase and would call off protest activities triggered by Chen's failure to agree to provide what the labor union considered adequate unemployment compensation.
The IEP ran into financial trouble just days after a sister newspaper, the Independence Morning Post (IMP), unexpectedly announced an indefinite suspension of publication on Jan. 21.
But labor union leaders said protests will resume if the employees were not paid by Friday afternoon.
The IMP, a liberal daily news founded 11 years ago, suspended publication without warning, a move that shocked the paper's employees and triggered immediate protests.

Chen, who brought into the Independence News Group in 1994, said employees of the group would receive unemployment compensation and back-wages if he found an individual or business group willing to buy into the newspapers.
No buyer has yet been found, however, for the IMP.

Jiang and the Dao Sheng Group, which maintain a dozen kindergartens in Taipei city and county and other businesses, including a communications company and an information technology (IT) firm, have declined to comment on the purchase.
Dao Sheng sources would only say that if indeed the group acquires the IEP, the actual buyer would be the affiliated communications or the IT company.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW MAY VISIT MACEDONIA TO CEMENT TIES: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) does not rule out the possibility of Premier Vincent Siew visiting Macedonia at an appropriate time to shore up the newly established bilateral ties, ministry spokesman Roy Wu said on Thursday.
Wu was responding to a newspaper report that Premier Siew is scheduled to head a large delegation of ROC government officials and business executives to visit Macedonia in March.
Wu said MOFA has not received any Cabinet instruction regarding the premier's possible visit to the southeastern European country.
Nevertheless, Wu said, MOFA does not rule out such a possibility.
"Since the Republic of China has forged formal diplomatic ties with Macedonia, it is a natural thing that senior officials from the two countries exchange visits," Wu explained.

The spokesman went on to say that Macedonian Foreign Minister Aleksandar Dimitrov invited President Lee Teng-hui to visit his country when he came to Taipei late last month to sign a joint communique with his ROC counterpart, Jason Hu, on the establishment of official ties.
"Against this background, we do not rule out the possibility of Premier Siew making an official visit to Macedonia at a proper time," Wu added.
He also clarified a press report concerning US stance on the establishment of full diplomatic ties between the ROC and Macedonia.
Wu said MOFA has contacted American authorities over what US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright said during her meeting with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georievski on Wednesday.
According to press reports, Madeleine had told Georievski that the establishment of ROC-Macedonian diplomatic ties may cause some problems.

However, Wu said, the reports might not be correct. "To our knowledge, Albright just reiterated that the United States would not adopt any official stance on the issue and that it's up to Macedonian leaders to decide whether to forge ties with any other country."

Asked about the US stance on the establishment of ROC-Macedonian ties at a Wednesday news conference, State Department spokesman James P. Rubin also said that the issue should be decided by Macedonian political leaders.
Rubin stressed it is a long-term US policy that the United States would not take any official stand on whether any other country should establish diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

Rubin further said the United States sees no reason why one ought to connect the issue of United Nations forces in Macedonia and the mandate with Macedonia's establishment of official ties with Taiwan.
Rubin said the United States supports the extension of UN Preventive Deployment (UNPREDEP) force in Macedonia and urges all UN Security Council member states to do the same.

The UN currently deploy more than 900 peacekeeping troops along Macedonian borders with Kosovo and Albania to contain a further spread of military conflicts and instability in the Balkan peninsula. In addition, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) also stations 2,000 to 3,000 troops in Macedonia to help cope with any contingencies.
Mainland China has threatened to boycott a proposed extension of the mandate for UNPREDEP force in Macedonia after the former Yugoslavia state forged diplomatic ties with the ROC.

Commenting on Beijing's threat, MOFA spokesman Wu said Macedonia has carefully evaluated all related issues, including the mandate for UN military deployment on its territory, before it finally decided to establish ties with the ROC.
Wu further said the ROC will gradually discuss with Macedonia various cooperative programs in economic, social and technological fields.

"We hope the newly forged ties will benefit both countries. We also hope our economic cooperation programs will help increase Macedonian people's job opportunities and boost that country's overall economic development," Wu said, adding that he believes this kind of development will contribute to peace and stability in the Balkan peninsula.

DOC.HEADLINE: US RESOLUTION ON TAIWAN SECURITY INTRODUCED
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 3 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Two members of the US House of Representatives submitted Wednesday a concurrent resolution urging President Bill Clinton to seek from Beijing a public renunciation of the use of force against Taiwan.

In the non-binding concurrent resolution, Robert E. Andrews (D-N.J.) and Steve Chabot (R-Ohio) jointly called on the president to help Taiwan in the event of a military attack, or the threat of such an attack, by Beijing.
The House of Representatives voted 411-0 in favor of a similar resolution in June 1998.

US senior officials from the executive branch have also called on authorities in Beijing to renounce the use of force against Taiwan, the resolution noted. It cited the 1979-enacted Taiwan Relations Act, which said US policy is "to consider any effort to determine the future of Taiwan by other than peaceful means, including by boycotts or embargoes, a threat to the peace and security of the Western Pacific area and of grave concern to the United States."
Under the act the United States may provide Taiwan with defensive weaponry.
The Washington-based Formosa Association of Public Affairs (FAPA) praised the passage of the resolution. FAPA is a political organization that lobbies for Taiwan's interests.

FAPA leader Chen Wen-yen said that mainland China's 1996 missile exercises in the Taiwan Strait, which he described as an attempt to interfere in Taiwan's first direct presidential elections, caused the US Congress to reconsider its position on Taiwan.

Since that event, congressmen have continually demanded that the Clinton administration take a strong stand against mainland China. In Taiwan, meanwhile, most lawmakers believe the United States should help Taiwan defend itself if it is attacked by Beijing, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slid NT$0.01 against the greenback on Thursday, closing at 32.261.
The US dollar appreciated against the NT dollar after US Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin said the United States would ensure the continued strength of the US dollar.
The local currency opened at 32.26 to the US dollar and was traded between 32.259 and 32.27.
Interbank US dollar trading amounted to US$222 million, the lowest volume in full-day trading in the past 45 days.
Trading on Saturdays lasts only half a day.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAI SHAN GROUP HEAD AND BROTHERS HAVE LEFT TAIWAN FOR US

TEXT.P: The parents and brothers of newly elected legislator and Hai Shan conglomerate head Liu Ping-wei have, like Liu, left Taiwan for the United States.
Their departure, recorded by immigration authorities at CKS International Airport, came after checks issued by Liu and worth millions of NT dollars bounced this week.

Liu Ping-hua, a younger brother of Liu Ping-wei who is deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council (NSC), left for Los Angeles on Tuesday night, while another younger brother, Liu Ping-chung, left Wednesday night. He was also bound for Los Angeles.
All three brothers' tickets were for one-way travel, according to the airlines that issued the tickets.

The NSC confirmed that its deputy secretary-general is on leave and has gone abroad for several days. But the council declined to indicate the duration of the leave or Liu's whereabouts. Calls to his office are directed to an answering machine.

Liu Ping-wei, according to reports, has over the past two days bounced checks totaling more than NT$100 million. Analysts say the resulting turmoil may threaten the stability of Taiwan's banking system because the Hai Shan Group, which has partial ownership of companies in fields ranging from construction to banking, has total debts of NT$6 billion.

Upon reaching Los Angeles Wednesday Liu Ping-wei told the media that he would stay in the United States for four or five days before he returns to Taiwan, reported a CNA correspondent in Los Angeles. Liu stressed that his financial problems have nothing to do with the recent elections for speaker and deputy speaker of the legislature, adding that he deeply regrets the trouble this matter has caused his family.
Media reports have suggested Liu Ping-wei's current financial troubles stem from his bid for the deputy speakership of the legislature.

Officials with the Union Commercial Bank (UCB) in Taiwan said that Liu's checks bounced on Feb. 1 and that he should deposit funds sufficient to cover the checks within seven days and in accordance with banking regulations. Otherwise he will have legally defaulted.
UCB officials clarified that the total value of bounced checks issued to the bank by Liu was about NT$120 million, not NT$210 million, as had been reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW COSTA RICAN ENVOY PRESENTS CREDENTIAL TO MOFA

TEXT.P: Costa Rica's new Ambassador to the Republic of China, Oscar Alvarez Araya, on Thursday presented a copy of his credentials to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

Alvarez told ROC Foreign Minister Jason Ju that mutually beneficial relations between Taipei and San Jose remain close and that Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez is scheduled to visit Taiwan in March.
It will be Rodriguez's first visit to Taiwan since he assumed the presidency last year.
Praising the ROC's achievements in democratization, its economy and human rights, Alvarez said he believes two-way ties between the two countries will further develop under the mandate of Rodriguez.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SAILBOAT LEAVES SINGAPORE FOR MALACCA
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Feb. 4 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan sailboat left Singapore on Thursday bound for Malacca, the third leg of a round-the-world voyage aimed at inspiring the nation's younger generation to cultivate an adventurous spirit and embrace Mother Nature.

It will take only three to four days to reach Malacca, capital of Malaysia's Malacca State, but Liu Ning-sheng, skipper of the 35-ton "New Era," said the voyage may be the riskiest of the whole journey.
"The winds in the Malacca Strait are notoriously fickle and there may be pirates in the region," Liu said.

Hundreds of Singaporeans and overseas Chinese well-wishers showed up to bid farewell and pray for God's blessing for the vessel's crew, including the Republic of China's de facto ambassador to Singapore, Ouyang Jui-hsiung.
Liu expressed his heartfelt gratitude for all the assistance and hospitality extended to the "New Era" and her crew during their two-week stay in the city-state.

"Some friends have helped repair the boat's engine, while others have provided us with weather information, cash donations and various gifts," Liu said, adding that the crew endured hardship during the Kaohsiung-Manila and Manila-Singapore legs of the voyage because they failed to lay in enough provisions before leaving Kaohsiung late last year.

"After two weeks of repair and maintenance of our equipment, and purchases of foods and other necessary supplies in Singapore, we believe the rest of our journey will proceed more smoothly and comfortably," said Liu.

The 16-foot sloop left Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan on Dec. 24, 1998. It will call at 20 major ports around the globe during its 21,250-nautical mile, 680-day voyage, dubbed the "Journey of Hope." It is scheduled to return to Kaohsiung in November 2000.

The ROC government and many Taiwan enterprises have offered financial support for the trans-century voyage, which is expected to further attest to the bravery and pioneering spirit of the Taiwan people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES, FUTURES DROP SHARPLY

TEXT.P: A run on Pan Hsin Commercial Bank stemming from check defaults by a political heavyweight trounced the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, nose-diving 228.97 points to close at 5,514.89.
It was reported that Legislator Liu Ping-wei has bounced NT$125 million-worth of checks in the last few days. Pan Hsin is an affiliate banking company under Liu's Hai Shan Group.
By Thursday morning, Liu was in Los Angeles, news which resulted in panic selling throughout the trading session, with more than 200 stocks falling to their lower daily limits.
At one point, the weighted price index plunged 241.32 points to 5,502.54, the lowest level of the day.
Turnover amounted to NT$56.67 billion, down from the NT$57.29 billion recorded in the previous session.
The over-the-counter market also closed lower, with the market's index sliding 4.49 points to finish at 138.99 on a turnover of NT$2.99 billion.
Meanwhile, Taiwan stock index futures closed lower.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for February plunged 332 points to close at 5,558, with 5,240 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for March sank 300 points to close at 5,630, with 1,457 contract transactions, while those for June were down 208 points to 5,714, with 55 contract transactions. September futures dropped 136 points to 5,820, with 18 contract transactions, and December futures declined 126 points to 5,820, with 11 contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE HOSPITALIZED FOR FLU TREATMENT

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui went to National Taiwan University Hospital Thursday to be treated for influenza and will remain hospitalized for three days at the advice of his attending physician.

The physician, Dr. Lien Wen-pin, said the president's temperature had almost returned to normal when he arrived at the hospital, adding that the results of blood tests and further medical tests have turned out normal.
This winter season more than 180,000 people in Taiwan have fallen victim to influenza, including the 76-year-old president, whose temperature at one point during his illness was 37.8 degrees Celsius.
Lien said that when Lee was admitted into the hospital, his temperature had fallen to 36.8 degrees.
The doctor said that Lee had no cough and that his breathing was also normal. The results of blood tests, chest X-rays and a supersonic check on Lee's abdomen were all normal, he noted.

Lien said President Lee's health was sound, adding that in the past 11 years he has caught cold only three times. Lien nevertheless advised Lee to remain the hospital for three days so that he could take a rest.
At the request of the media, Len will give a briefing on the president's health on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: US FAVORS MACEDONIA UN FORCE DESPITE THREATS FROM BEIJING

TEXT.P: The United States conceded on Wednesday that there could be "problems" ahead but said that it favored maintaining a UN task force in Macedonia despite threats by mainland China to block its continued deployment.

State Department spokesman James Rubin told reporters that Washington opposes any linkage between an extension of the mandate for the 800-strong force and Macedonia's recent decision to establish diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
"We don't see a reason why one ought to connect the issue of the UN force there and the mandate with the subject you asked about," Rubin said at a regular briefing.

"We support the extension of the mandate in the (UN) Security Council and would urge all council members to do the same. The presence of this force has had regional benefits in limiting instability in the Balkans," he added.

Mainland China's ambassador to Skopje was quoted last week as saying that unless Macedonia retracts its decision on Taiwan, Beijing will reconsider an extension of the mandate for the UN Preventive Deployment Force (UNPREDEP).

The UN Security Council is expected later this month to consider extending the UNPREDEP mandate, which has been renewed every half year since the force was first sent to the former Yugoslav republic in March 1995.
Composed mainly of US and Scandinavian troops, UNPREDEP's mission is to prevent conflicts in other parts of former Yugoslavia from spreading.
Rubin's statement came after Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski and US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright touched on Taiwan during a discussion at the State Department.
Georgievski told Taiwan reporters that during their meeting, Albright expressed concern over implications at the UN following Macedonia's decision to recognize Taiwan.
He said that the secretary of state asked about the decision and said that "she presented her opinion that we should have consulted between us."
"She indicated problems that we can have in the future, especially at the UN, when the decision about the station of the UNPREDEP mission in Macedonia is going to be taken." he said.
Answering questions on the exchanges about Taiwan, Rubin said the United States does not take a position on whether other countries should establish diplomatic relations with Taiwan.
"That is a matter for the Macedonian political leaders to decide," he said.
Later, the State Department tried to clarify Albright's remarks about consultations between Macedonia and the United States.

"In the course of the meeting, the secretary of state underscored US interest in close consultations with the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia on important matters of mutual concern, including UNPREDEP," an official said.

The official said that Albright also reiterated "the long-standing US policy that the United States takes no official position on whether (other) countries establish diplomatic relations with Taiwan."

The Macedonian prime minister is on a four-day visit to Washington, where he will have meetings with President Bill Clinton, Defense Secretary William Cohen, members of Congress, and officials of the International Monetary Fund.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA AT RISK OF FURTHER FINANCIAL CRISIS: US BANK

TEXT.P: A coming slowdown in economic growth in the United States, mainland China and Europe, combined with uncertainty in Japan, could cause a new phase of the Asian financial crisis, according to the chief economist and managing director of Chase Manhattan Bank.

John Lipsky forecast that US growth will probably slow to about 1 percent this year, compared with 3.4 percent in 1998, which will limit the ability of the United States to serve as a locomotive for the world economy.
The slowdown will be driven by a further widening of the US external current account deficit, a decline in capital investment growth following lower corporate profits, and weaker housing activity.
Lipsky pointed out that an important additional cause of the slowdown will be a decline in consumer spending growth to only around 2 percent this year, from 4-5 percent in 1998.
Given declining inflation and a slowing economy, the US Federal Reserve will cut interest rates this year, according to Lipsky.
With regard to the economy of mainland China, Lipsky pointed out a number of "risk perceptions." One is that capital flight might be increasing.
If indeed capital flight is occurring and is rising, this will heighten market perceptions of a future renminbi devaluation, Lipsky said.
Perceptions of a renminbi devaluation could also put pressure on the Hong Kong dollar, Lipsky said.
Turning to Japan, Lipsky pointed out the need for the government to "break the deflationary psychology" prevalent in the country.

"Japanese policy should not be oriented to maintaining any particular level of the exchange rate, but to reviving domestic demand," he said, noting that the country's policymakers are still "describing goals in exchange rate terms," as evidenced by Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi's recent endorsement of "target zones" for currencies.

However, Lipsky said he is hopeful that Japan will eventually succeed in reviving domestic demand -- a side effect of which would be a weakening of the yen against the US dollar. But this in turn could lead to new pressure on Asian economies, especially in Korea and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA SLAMMED FOR LAXNESS AGAINST PIRACY

TEXT.P: Mainland China was criticized on Wednesday for its record in fighting piracy and its failure to prosecute suspected pirates at an international conference on piracy in Singapore.
The actions of the mainland authorities in piracy incidents were described in a paper by Capt. Jayant Abhyankar as "unbelievable" and as "encouraging pirates to carry on."

At the International Maritime Organization (IMO) seminar on piracy and armed robbery against ships, he singled out two cases in recent years to illustrate the failure of mainland China to act against pirates.

Taking last year's hijack of a Malaysian-registered tanker, he said: "What makes his case important is that although the alleged pirates, the ship and its cargo were found intact, the pirates were not prosecuted."

"Despite indisputable evidence, the pirates who had committed a serious offense of hijacking a vessel and attempting to sell the cargo were simply sent back to Indonesia without being prosecuted," he said.

He made similar comments about a much earlier case of a vessel which was hijacked in October 1995. In December 1995, mainland China's Public Security Bureau (PSB) said it found the ship, renamed the Arctic Sea, and detained it and 14 pirates aboard. However, by February 1997 they had all been released without charge.
Indonesia remains the hotspot for piracy, with some 59 actual and attempted piracy attacks out of a global total of 192.
Southeast Asia as a whole accounted for over half of the 192 attacks, including 15 in the Philippines, 11 in Malaysia, and nine in Bangladesh.
However, the total number of attacks worldwide dropped by 20 percent compared with the 1997 figures.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTLAWED OPPOSITION PARTY EXPANDS IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Five provincial and municipal branches of the China Democracy Party (CDP) were established without government approval Thursday, increasing the number of the outlawed political party in mainland China to 23.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said Thursday that the five new CDP organizations are the Hebei Provincial Branch, the Liaoning Provincial Branch, the Henan Provincial Branch, the Municipal Branch of Xian City in Shaanxi Province, and the Municipal Branch of Huanggang City in Hubei Province.

They said in an inauguration statement that to form political parties is a basic human right endowed by God, and is consistent with the International Convenant on Civil and Political Rights. Mainland Chinese law does not ban the establishment of new political parties, it added.
They also said that they will immediately begin to expand CDP membership.

The would-be political party was banned soon after its establishment was announced in June, 1998. Three of its founders-- Wu Wenli, Qin Yongmin, and Wang Youcai-- were sentenced to 13, 12 and 11 years in prison respectively in December on charges of "endangering state security."
Despite the government crackdown, members of the party plan to hold a national "congress" and a seminar on the "issue of human rights in China" in Wuhan city in March, the information center said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABORTION RATE IS HIGH IN TAIPEI: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Nearly half of Taipei's adult women have had an abortion, and about 40 percent of unmarried Taipei women have experienced sex, according to the results of a survey released by the Bureau of Health under the Taipei City Government.

The bureau commissioned the Taipei Women's Rights Promotion Association to conduct the telephone survey between May 11 and May 21 1998, with the aim of finding out more about female Taipei residents' demands regarding health care and services.
The association managed to complete interviews with 981 adult Taipei women.
The survey results show that about 40 percent of Taipei women use various methods of contraception, including intrauterine devices, contraceptive pills, or surgery, to prevent pregnancy.

Roughly 40 percent of the respondents said their husbands used condoms. Looking at the figures, one municipal health official said local men should be educated to enhance their sense of responsibility regarding contraception.

The poll found that 45 percent of adult Taipei women have had an abortion, and 50 percent of the respondents aged between 20 and 30 said women should have the final say in deciding whether or not to terminate a pregnancy.

As 38.9 percent of unmarried Taipei women responding to the survey have had sex, municipal health officials said they will launch a campaign to encourage women under 30 to have regular pap smears to facilitate early detection of possible cancerous cervical growths.

Only 35.4 percent said they have had a cervical smear test, results which indicate that municipal health authorities should strengthen health education to encourage women to pay more attention to their own health.

According to the survey, 64.2 percent of those interviewed said they have conducted a breast self-examination at least once, but only 26 percent said they give themselves regular examinations. A further 35.6 percent said they have never examined their breasts for lumps.

One particularly shocking finding was that many women have had a total hysterectomy simply because of a benign tumor. The health bureau said it will set clinical regulations to minimize unnecessary removal of the uterus. The bureau said it also plans to inspect hospitals with high records of such operations to probe whether any irregularities are involved in the practice.

The survey also found that 5 percent of the respondents had encountered sexual harassment while seeing doctors, and 10.7 percent said they have never undergone a physical checkup because they fear sexual harassment by the physician.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIFICATION, WISDOM TEST FOR TAIWAN AND MAINLAND CHINA (I)

TEXT.P: Finding a formula which respects the separate rule in Taiwan and mainland China before the two sides of the Taiwan Strait eventually achieve peaceful unification will be a test of wisdom for the governments of both sides, political observers say.

Ever since mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin issued his "eight-point statement" regarding Taiwan on Jan. 30, 1995, the statement has become the principal factor governing mainland China's key policies in its dealings with Taiwan.

Although Jiang's statement does not oppose Taiwan developing trade and cultural links with other countries under Beijing's "one China" principle, it clearly states that mainland China will never accept Taiwan's drive to expand its niche in the international community.
