In Beijing's view, all such efforts by the Taiwan authorities are tantamount to creating the so-called "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan," which are seen by the Chinese communists as promoting Taiwan independence, blocking eventual unification of China, and impeding the mainland's territorial integrity.
However, "reaching out" has been the focus of President Lee Teng-hui's pragmatic foreign policy since he assumed the Republic of China presidency.

In a speech to the National Unification Council in April 1995, Lee stressed that the ROC's bid to expand its international presence is to create a "win-win" situation for both Taiwan and mainland China and an attempt to find a way to give Taiwan's 21 million people a voice in the international community.
Lee claimed that Taiwan's pragmatic foreign policy does not seek Taiwan independence, and that the ROC government has never deviated from its ultimate pursuit of China's unification.

Although there are voices within Taiwan opposing the ROC government's policy of pragmatic diplomacy, accusing it of conducting "money diplomacy," the latest public opinion survey carried out by the Mainland Affairs Council shows that about 70 percent of the people of Taiwan are in favor of pragmatic diplomacy, while the number of local residents who believe that relations with foreign countries should take precedence over cross-strait ties has also increased.

The poll results indicate that most of Taiwan's people back the government's efforts to win international recognition, but political experts point out that Taiwan's drive to increase its presence on the international scene is effectively the central conflict between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The major difference between Taiwan and mainland China over the issue is their different perceptions of the concept of "one China," according to political analysts.

Taipei cannot accept Beijing's view that the so-called "one China" refers to mainland China, while Beijing also shrugs off Taipei's view that the concept refers to a "China which is currently divided and under separate rule."

This dispute has led to a fierce diplomatic wrangle between the two sides, and the competition to win international recognition has degenerated into a "zero-sum" game, the political observers say. (By Flor Wang) TO BE CONTINUED

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO REPATRIATE NINE MAINLAND CHINESE HIJACKERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan has decided to repatriate nine mainland Chinese hijackers on Feb. 9, while two children brought to Taiwan by their hijacker parents will be sent back to the mainland via Hong Kong on Feb. 6.
Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) informed its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), of the decision on Thursday.
The SEF and ARATS are the quasi-official organizations set up to handle cross-strait contacts in the absence of official ties between the two sides.

In accordance with past practice, the nine hijackers will be transferred to the mainland authorities in the Taiwan Strait, at a point midway between the ROC island outpost of Kinmen and the mainland Chinese coast.
SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng told a press conference that the decision to repatriate the hijackers and their children was based on the principles of humanity, safety, and convenience.
At the same time, he urged ARATS to resume consultations on the handling of hijacking problems at an early date in order that a mutually acceptable agreement can be reached on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIFICATION, WISDOM TEST FOR TAIWAN AND MAINLAND CHINA (II)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 4 (CNA) (By Victor Lai) (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Over the past four years, Taiwan has forged diplomatic relations with several countries in Europe, Africa and the South Pacific, but the island also lost one of its traditional and major allies -- South Africa -- last year. Currently, Taiwan is officially recognized by 28 countries around the world.
Trying to consolidate their countries' ties with foreign nations, the leaders of both governments have also launched intensified diplomatic offensives, increasing the number of their overseas visits.

ROC President Lee made a historic visit to his alma mater, Cornell University in the United States, in 1995, and pulled off a very successful tour of ROC allies in Central America and the Caribbean in 1997.

On the other side, mainland Chinese President Jiang held his first summit meeting with US President Bill Clinton in New York in 1995, followed by a visit to Europe in June 1996, and the second Clinton-Jiang summit in October 1997. In November 1998, he also visited Russia and Japan.

Amid the changing global political climate, Taiwan's democratization and desire for membership of international organizations, as well as Beijing's increased leverage and its endless efforts to isolate Taiwan internationally, all reflect a "blind point" in mainland China's dealings with Taiwan.

Judging from the experience of the former two Germanys and the two parts of the Korean peninsula, it would not seem impossible for the two parts of a divided country to have separate representation in the international community, political experts say. Although the cause of their separations may be different, they all have strived toward unification and eventually, at least in Germany's case, have accomplished their aspiration.

In view of such historical precedent, the challenge for the leaders of Taiwan and mainland Chinese now is how to achieve the goal of national unification through acceptable means to both parties, while respecting the current state of affairs on the two sides, they conclude.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACEDONIAN JOURNALISTS TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A group of journalists from Taiwan's new diplomatic ally, Macedonia, will visit the island between Feb. 7-12, at the invitation of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) a ministry statement said on Thursday.

The 28-strong group, led by Macedonian Information Minister Redzep Zlatku, consists of press and electronic media reporters. They will call on government leaders, visit local cultural and economic facilities, and exchange views with their Taiwan counterparts at a seminar.
This will be the first Macedonian private group ever to visit the island since the Balkan state declared independence from Yugoslavia in 1991.
Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu is scheduled to visit the Macedonian capital of Skojpe on Feb. 22 to consolidate the bilateral ties forged on Jan. 27.

The diplomatic move has irritated Beijing, which considers Taiwan a province of mainland China, and has threatened to sever ties with Skojpe and veto a United Nation proposal to extend the mandate of UN peacekeeping forces in Macedonia if it doesn't back down on the decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, IRAN INK PACT ON SPORTS EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Iran signed a memorandum of understanding on Wednesday, in which both sides agreed to further strengthen sports exchanges between the two countries.

The accord was signed by Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) Chairman Huang Ta-chou and visiting vice chairman of the Iranian Olympic Committee, Bahram Afsharzadeh. CTOC Secretary-General M.H. Tang and his Iranian counterpart, Seyedamir Hosseini, witnessed the inking of the agreement at the Taipei Grand Hotel.

Afsharzadeh and Hosseini flew into Taiwan from South Korea. While here, the two men visited the National College of Physical Education and Sports and called at the CTOC's national training center in southern Tsoying before departing for Iran on Thursday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO ENTRY FOR TAIWAN, BEIJING LINKED INEXTRICABLY: US EXPERT

TEXT.P: Although the Republic of China is fully eligible to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), it will not be allowed in ahead of mainland China because of Beijing's insistence, a US trade expert said on Thursday at a seminar in Taipei.

Taiwan might not like it, but will have to come to terms with the political reality that most of world's powers will tie the island's WTO bid to that of mainland China, said John Jackson, a professor at Georgetown University, Washington, D.C., and drafter of the Special 301 provisions of the 1984 and 1989 US Omnibus Trade Acts.

Beijing, whose application for the WTO membership has been held up by its persistent reluctance to open its markets, has always claimed that Taiwan is a part of mainland China, and should not be allowed into the world trade regulatory body ahead of it.

As Taiwan's economic miracle is indisputable, so is the fact that most states in the world acknowledge Beijing as the sole legitimate ruler of China, and accordingly would give in to its demand that Taiwan's access to WTO should be granted only after Beijing's membership is secured, said Jackson, cautioning that he was expressing his personal view.

Contrary to many people's fear that the current Asian financial storm will postpone Beijing's WTO entry by impeding its economic reform, Jackson said the economic tumult will remind the WTO of the importance of bringing in a powerful economy such as mainland China to ward off further financial crises.

Later in the seminar, in a veiled rebuttal of Jackson's argument, Chen Rue-long, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade and one of Taiwan's chief negotiators on WTO access, pointed out the necessity for would-be WTO members to meet the entry criteria, including market-opening and bringing their trade system into line with WTO rules.

Noting that Taiwan has almost completed its application procedures, Chen urged the WTO not to take political factors into account when reviewing Taiwan's bid, and vowed to seek the support of other member states for the island's membership, irrespective of Beijing's demands.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAMBODIAN GROUP ARRIVES IN TAIWAN FOR TALKS OVER WASTE CLEANUP

TEXT.P: A delegation of three Cambodian officials was expected to arrive in Taiwan on Thursday night for negotiations with Taiwan's plastics giant, the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG), over the cleanup of industrial waste dumped by FPG in Cambodia.

The three-member group, consisting of Om Yem Tieng, a private advisor to Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen, and two environmental officials -- Heng Mareth and Su Suvuth -- will meet FPG General Manager Lee Chih-chun to work out a plan for removing 3,000 tons of mercury-tainted waste dumped in Sihanoukville, 185 km southwest of Phnom Penh in late November last year.

The waste, wrapped in plastic bags bearing the international danger sign of a skull and crossbones, caused panic among Sihanoukville's residents, who fled in droves after five deaths were blamed on the waste last December.
Angry Phnom Penh authorities demanded that FPG take back the waste immediately, but FPG was hesitant about agreeing to the demand because of strenuous opposition from Taiwan environmental groups.
Instead, FPG sources said, the group began weighing the possibility of shipping the waste to the United States and storing it on the premises of an FPG plant in Texas.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHAIRMAN, AIT CHAIRMAN SPEAK OF CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said on Thursday that he is willing to exchange views on any issue with Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) Chairman Wang Daohan.
He made the remarks while delivering a report titled "Pursuing Peaceful Cross-Taiwan Strait Relations" at a dinner party hosted by the American Chamber of Commerce.
Wang is scheduled to visit Taipei some time this year to reciprocate Koo's mainland trip of last fall.
Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), and Director Daryl Johnson of AIT's Taipei Office were also invited to the dinner party.

Koo said the United States is a long-standing friend of the Republic of China. He pointed out that Taipei supports the US government's policy of engagement with Beijing, and urged Washington to balance its policies regarding Taipei and Beijing.
In response to Koo's overture, Bush reiterated Washington's five principles governing Beijing-Taipei relations as follows:
-- There must be a peaceful solution to problems arising between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait;
-- Constructive and meaningful dialogue between Taipei and Beijing is the best way to solve cross-strait disagreements;
-- Cross-strait disagreements and other problems should be solved by Taipei and Beijing without outside interference;
-- The US will take a neutral stand over cross-strait dialogue; and
-- All agreements reached by Taipei and Beijing should be based on conditions acceptable to both sides.

Bush said he believes Wang's hoped-for Taipei visit this year will improve the atmosphere of cross-strait relations. He said the US will not lean on either side, and will not pressure either side into making unwilling concessions.

In his speech, Koo pointed out that the basic reason for the stalled cross-strait relations is the lack of mutual trust, and added that bilateral relations may worsen if highly sensitive political issues are taken up under such conditions.
He said mutual trust can be built up through continuous dialogues, implementation of already-concluded agreements, and solution of less-sensitive political issues.

Koo acknowledged that peaceful reunification of China can be attained only when Beijing respects Taiwan's political and economic development, as well as the fact that there exists separate rule in mainland China and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Legislator Liu Ping-wei flew to the United States to seek financial support.
The China Times:
Debt-ridden lawmaker Liu Ping-wei asked the ruling Kuomintang's chief financier, Liu Tai-ying, to offer him financial assistance.
The United Daily News:
The Ministry of Finance to adopt a package of measures to stabilize the reeling stock market.
The Liberty Times:
The Ministry of Finance may re-consider the feasibility of cut the stock transaction tax rate.
The Commons Daily:
US congressmen introduced a concurrent resolution urging the US government to push mainland China to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.
The China Post:
Hai Shan Group chief's departure abroad sparks market plunge.
The China News:
Taiwan's stock market falls to three-year low.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSES URGED TO BID FOR ADB CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan businesses are being urged to take part in open bidding for infrastructure and reconstruction contracts under an Asian Development Bank (ADB) framework to help invigorate Taiwan's exports.

ADB authorities are scheduled to hold a presentation on ADB business opportunities in Taipei March 22-23 under the joint auspices of the CBC and the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT), according to CBC officials.

CBC officials said Taiwan contractors and suppliers have been awarded only some US$20 million worth of contracts since 1997 by the ADB for infrastructure and reconstruction projects. This figure pales in comparison to those of other ADB member countries. Since 1997, the ADB has offered US$6 billion worth of business opportunities to bidders in member countries.
CBC officials urged Taiwan businesses to take the advantage of ADB business opportunities to expand their exports to Asian nations.
According to BOFT statistics, Taiwan's exports fell 9.4 percent in 1998, with those to Japan dropping 20.2 percent and those to Southeast Asia sliding 27.8 percent.

The Republic of China's current stake in the ADB stands at 1.25 percent, which puts it 13th among the organization's 56 members. Japan and the United States hold the largest stakes, at around 16 percent each, according to CBC officials.
The ADB changed the Republic of China's designation to "Taipei, China" after mainland China was admitted into the body in 1986.
The Republic of China, a founding member of the regional financial organization, rejected the change and has since taken part in ADB meetings and activities only under protest.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 5, or the 20th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1922: The first issue of the US magazine Reader's Digest rolls off the presses.
1924: French automaker Renault launches an epoch-marking car safari in the Sahara.
1929: The Nationalist government changes the name of Fengtien province to Liaoning province.
1945: Gen. Douglas MacArthur and US troops enter Manila. On Oct. 20, 1944, MacArthur and his forces landed on the Philippine island of Leyte, fulfilling his pledge to return to the Philippines.
1955: US President Dwight Einsenhower instructs the Seventh Fleet to assist Nationalist troops to withdraw from Tachen island, opposite mainland China's Chechiang province.
1959: The Republic of China's Cabinet adopts a resolution to open Hualien port in eastern Taiwan as an international port.
1959: The Ilan branch of Taiwan's East-West Highway is formally opened to traffic.
1962: A total solar eclipse occurs in the morning.
1971: US Apollo 14 astronauts land on the moon.
1977: Brazilian football star Pele arrives in Taiwan for a three-day visit.
1990: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev indicates that the Communist Party must abandon its monopoly on power.
1996: Rene Preval succeeds Jean-Bertrand Aristide in a peaceful transfer of power in Haiti.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When three men meet together, one of them who is anxious to learn can always learn something of the other two. He can profit by the good example of the one and avoid the bad example of the other."

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF REUNITED MIGRANT FAMILIES IN AUSTRALIA DOWN

TEXT.P: The number of parents migrating to Australia to join children already living there has plunged dramatically -- from 7,580 in 1996-97 to 1,080 in 1997-98, according to the Department of immigration.
The department reported the decline was due to a change in the government's immigration policy, which now emphasizes the migration of skilled workers.
Skilled migrants accounted for about 52 percent of the total intake of about 68,000 in fiscal 1997-98, Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said.
He said the government would introduce more measures to put quotas on the number of visas for spouses and fiancees.
"It is pleasing to see those entering Australia under the migration program are becoming younger, better educated and more highly skilled," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE EXPORTS TO ASIA SHOW SIGNS OF RECOVERY

TEXT.P: Australian exports to many Asian nations, including Taiwan and mainland China, showed signs of recovery in the second half of 1998, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).

ABS figures show merchandise exports to Taiwan, mainland China, Singapore, Thailand and Malaysia grew by 20 percent from July to December 1998, a growth rate higher than those of exports to other parts of the world.
Exports to other Southeast Asian nations remained sharply lower, and a full recovery to pre-crisis levels is still some way off, according to the ABS.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE RETURNS 600-YEAR OLD SAMURAI SWORD TO JAPANESE

TEXT.P: A 47-year-old Australian and one-time Ninja fan has returned a 600-year-old samurai sword to its original Japanese owners following a two-year search for them.

Peter Buckle, who became a Ninja fan when he was 15 years old, has had custody of the ancient weapon for 37 years, though he has now returned it to the two sons of its former owner -- the late Maj. Takao Kobayashi.

Kobayashi received the sword from his mother-in-law, whose family had possession of the sword for more than 200 years. The sword was made by the famed sword maker Tsunahiro in the Kamakura period between 1180 and 1330, it was reported.
Buckle said he received the sword from his uncle, Maj. Robert Williams. Williams took the sword as a souvenir from an arms stockpile during the 1945 surrender of Japanese forces, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN MAKER SELLING BREWERIES IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Foster's Brewing Group, Australia's beer-making giant, is selling two loss-making breweries in mainland China to cut further business losses from investments in that country.

Jim King, Foster's managing director of the Asian region, told the Australian Associated Press recently that company officials are now negotiating with executives of South African Breweries in Beijing on the sale of operations in Tianjin and Guangdong.
Foster's has a third brewery in mainland China in Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEADER TALKS ABOUT 'NEW TAIWAN PERSON' CONCEPT

TEXT.P: Mainland China should not fear or misunderstand the concept of "New Taiwan Person," said KMT Secretary-General John Chang, who also noted that Taiwan will not declare independence because the ruling Kuomintang is against it and because Taiwan has been a sovereign and independent state since 1912.

While addressing the Washington-based Heritage Foundation Thursday, Chang also noted that after the ruling party won Taipei's mayoral seat and captured a clear majority in the Legislative Yuan in December 1998 elections, some members of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) are now advocating either modification or outright deletion of the call for Taiwan independence that is part of the DPP's party platform.
These trends should increase the stability of the cross-strait relationship, he said.

But the elections that have served to consolidate democratic freedoms on Taiwan also show the disparity between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. Taiwan simply cannot seek reunification while the mainland is still under a one-party dictatorship and while its people lack such freedoms as those of speech and association. Bridging this gap will take much effort and will likely be a gradual process, added the former foreign minister.

Chang told participants that only the people of Taiwan have the right to decide their future and that the leaders of all political parties in Taiwan have to preserve its existing system, freedoms and rights, as well as protect the island's people from the threat posed by mainland China.
Taiwan will be better treated in the international community if the world understands the truth about Taiwan, and "only with your help, Taiwan will have a better future," Chang said.

He emphasized that the "New Taiwan Person" concept is designed only to eliminate tensions between various ethnic groups in Taiwan, such as native-born Taiwanese and the "mainlanders" who came to Taiwan from the mainland earlier this century.

The concept is not intended to create a "Taiwan person" that stands in opposition to a "Chinese person," he said. While some people on the mainland believe this is the real intent behind the concept, "there is no need for such misunderstanding," he said.

He explained that a "New Taiwan person" is Chinese by ethnicity, although that person may have arrived in Taiwan at any of several different historical stages. Distinctions between various ethnic groups have become blurred because of marriages between the groups. As a result of this blending, a person born in Taiwan today is "Chinese by birth and a world-citizen in outlook."

Chang added that between 60 percent and 85 percent of the people in Taiwan favor either the status quo or reunification with the mainland, while only 10 percent to 20 percent favor independence, according to nearly 30 surveys conducted between 1994 and 1997 on the question of Taiwan's status. Therefore, Beijing should not worry about the intentions of the people of Taiwan.

Talking about Taiwan's democratic achievements, Chang noted that the 1996 presidential election has proved that the Chinese on Taiwan are both interested in, and capable of implementing, democracy, and helped debunk the myth advocated by many Sinologists and China watchers in the West that two or three thousand years of imperial monarchy has left the Chinese incapable of establishing a democracy.
Moreover, the fact that Taiwan can openly embrace democracy should also serve to show that once the mainland throws off the straitjacket of communism, it too can make democratic changes, he said.

While expressing deep gratitude to the United States for answering the mainland's belligerence by sending two aircraft carrier battle groups to the region during the 1996 missile crisis, Chang said these courageous actions have answered once and for all the question of whether or not the Taiwan Relations Act has teeth.

Through the combined efforts of Congress and the Clinton administration, the United States has shown its willingness to take heavy risks to fight against unjust militarism and to ensure peace throughout the world, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIR CREW FAILS TO UNFOLD SPACE MIRROR

TEXT.P: The sun will not be coming out tonight.
Russian cosmonauts aboard the Mir space station failed to unfold a giant space mirror designed to reflect sunlight onto darkened areas of the earth Thursday evening.
"This is an emergency situation. The mirror is not unfolding," the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. quoted a spokesman for Russian mission control as saying.

The cosmonauts issued a command to the unmanned Progress supply vehicle to begin unfolding the flexible foil-like mirror. The material, however, got caught in the capsule's antennae and would not open.
Sometime on Friday the cosmonauts may attempt to use centrifugal force to untangle the mirror, the CBC said.

The project is designed to shed light on portions of the world that are often immersed in darkness for extended periods of time, but some astronomers have complained that the mirror could interfere with their observations of the night sky.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ TO PROBE RUMORS BEHIND MARKET POUNDING

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan is establishing a task force to investigate the source of rumors that have caused Taiwan's stock market to take a pounding in recent days, government spokesman Chen Chien-jen said on Friday.

Partly because of a bounced check scandal involving Kuomintang Legislator Liu Ping-wei, who is also founder of a Taipei-based business group, the Taipei bourse plunged 4 percent on Thursday, continuing a bearish trend which has lasted throughout the week. The market shed another 0.7 percent on Friday.

The business and industrial groups that have been affected by the recent rumors include the Koo Group, Hualon-Teijran, Pacific Electric Wire and Cable, and Walsin Lihwa, all of which slid to their floor prices in Thursday trading.
Chen said the Ministry of Justice has been authorized to form the investigative task force. Rumor-mongers will be dealt with severely once they have been pinpointed, he added.

Meanwhile, Premier Vincent Siew appealed to the general public not to be too pessimistic over Taiwan's economy in the wake of the recent spate of economic irregularities, including bounced checks, bad debts, and high unemployment.

He said the Executive Yuan is scheduled to call a meeting on Feb. 15 of top thinkers from the industrial, government, and academic sectors to jointly oversee an economic pump-priming package recently devised by the Council for Economic Planning and Development.
The package is expected to help usher in a new era for Taiwan's economic development after the prolonged slump which has continued over the past year, Siew added.
He stressed yet again that Taiwan's economy remains healthy, and urged the public not to lose confidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME NOT YET RIPE TO OPEN CROSS-STRAIT PASSENGER SERVICE: MAC

TEXT.P: The time is not yet ripe for an opening of maritime passenger transport services across the Taiwan Strait, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Friday.

MAC Vice Chairman Sheu Ke-sheng made the statement following press reports that the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) is considering allowing foreign-flagged ocean liners to operate cross-strait passenger transport services via a third area.

Sheu said the MOTC clarified the reports on Thursday by saying that it did not take the initiative to draw up a blueprint for such a plan. The proposal was broached instead by private industry associations, the MOTC stressed.

Sheu pointed out that various government agencies reached consensus during a Cabinet-sponsored working meeting on mainland China affairs on Nov. 1, 1998 that cross-strait shipping services will be liberalized step-by-step under the premise that the nation's security and dignity, as well as the people's well-being, are assured.
The MAC spokesman went on to say that the government's stance on cross-strait transport services is clear and consistent.

"At present, our policy is that indirect cross-strait cargo transport links should be established before passenger services, and that shipping services should take precedence over flight services," Sheu said, adding that the government will deregulate cross-strait transport services gradually, in order to protect national security and stability.
Taiwan still bans direct cross-strait transport services because mainland China remains hostile and has never renounced the use of force to overrun the island.

Sheu said the government opened direct cross-strait cargo transshipment services in January 1997 mainly to facilitate the development of Taiwan as an Asia-Pacific maritime transshipment center. As for passenger services, Sheu said, the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, has never planned to open either direct or indirect cross-strait passenger services.

Noting that cross-strait passenger services, regardless of scheduled or chartered services, involves many complicated problems, including civilian-exchanges, crime prevention, and public security, Sheu said now is still not the right time to open such services.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS CALL FOR SUSPENSION OF HIGH-POLLUTION INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: The government has been working in cahoots with Taiwan's industrial sector on actions which are endangering the environment and ecology of coastal areas in western Taiwan, a group of scholars and academics said on Friday.

The members of the liberal Taipei Society, most of whom are university professors, joined a group of aquaculturalists from Yunlin County's Taishi township at a press conference to call for the government to stop allowing high-pollution industries such as the petrochemical industry, to operate in the Yunlin and Chiayi areas. The areas, spread from central to southern Taiwan, are home to Taiwan's large clam fishery industry.

The aquaculturalists said Taishi's salt-water clam ponds, which have the world's best clam breeding and cultivation technology, are in grave danger from water and earth pollution caused simply by initial preparations for construction of an industrial complex which is to be developed nearby.
The pollution levels are expected to become much higher once the complex has been completed, the clam farmers warned.

Prof. Chujoe Hsia of the Graduate Institute of Building Planning, National Taiwan University, who is one of the Taipei Society members, said that while Taiwan strives to raise its GNP by developing economy and industries, the GNP may end up an acronym for "garbage, noise and pollution" if care is not taken to simultaneously protect the environment and ecology.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIEX INDEX FALLS BELOW 5,500

TEXT.P: The government task force designed to stabilize the stock market failed to reverse the market's bearish trend on Friday, with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, dropping to below 5,500 by the closing bell.
The index closed at 5,474.79 on a turnover of NT$60.74 billion, up from the NT$56.67 billion recorded in the previous session.
The local bourse opened low and seesawed until 9:40 a.m., when the index climbed to 5,625.65, the highest level of the day.
The over-the-counter market closed higher, with the market's index rising 1.09 points to finish at 140.08 on a turnover of NT$2.74 billion.
Meanwhile, Taiwan stock index futures closed mixed.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for February rose 22 points to close at 5,580, with 5,807 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for March rose 20 points to close at 5,650, with 1,957 contract transactions, while those for June were down 35 points to 5,685, with 43 contract transactions. September futures dropped 148 points to 5,631, with 12 contract transactions, and December futures declined 137 points to 5,702, with nine contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAC BUYS OUT BELLY-UP NEWSPAPER

TEXT.P: A lengthy dispute between the owner and employees of the cash-strapped Independence News Group came to a happy end on Friday when a business group announced that it has bought the Independence Evening Post (IEP).

Chiang Dao-sheng, chairman of the Dao Sheng Group and an affiliate company, China Agritech Corporation (CAC), signed a buyout agreement with Independence News Group (ING) owner Chen Cheng-chung on Friday morning after an overnight marathon negotiation.

Under the terms of the agreement, CAC acquires the newspaper at a cost of NT$1.3 billion (US$40 million), while Chen on Saturday will clear up the accumulated wage debts, including back-pay and unemployment compensation for the Independence Morning Post (IMP) employees, as well as overdue wages of IEP employees.

Independence Group labor union leaders said at a news conference on Friday that they are pleased with the deal, and will immediately cease all protest action. They also expressed regret over their unpleasant protest against Chen and his family.

Chen, who bought the ING in 1994, unexpectedly announced an indefinite suspension of publication of the IMP on Jan. 21 due to financial problems. A few days later, IMP's sister newspaper, the IEP, also ran into financial trouble. Chen's failure to pay wages and unemployment compensation to his laid off employees triggered a two-week management-labor standoff.

CAC was transformed by Chiang from China Agricultural and Economic Co. after he bought a 60 percent stake in the company. The Taipei-based company is involved in bio-technological research and development.

In addition to CAC, Chiang's Dao Sheng Group also owns several other businesses, including Filmate Communication International Corp., and Dao Sheng Kindergarten Education Institution. Filmate Communication owns eight cable TV channels, and enjoys annual turnover of more than NT$1 billion.

According to a CAC press release, the company is responsible for the IEP purchase, with Filmate Communication International in a secondary role. The CAC-led team will issue a public statement as soon as the process of business transference is completed, the news release said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar rose to a three-week high on Friday, climbing NT$0.022 against the greenback to close at 32.239.
Most Asian currencies appreciated against the US dollar on Friday after a sale of US dollars in the Tokyo market.

Dealers said that domestic demand for funds is increasing with the approach of the Lunar New Year festival, a trend which is helping the local currency to maintain its stability against the US dollar.
However, they also warned that the NT dollar is expected to undergo an adjustment in the foreign exchange market after the festival.
The NT dollar opened at the day's low of 32.254 and had a high of 32.233.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$372.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT OPTIMISTIC ABOUT DEVELOPMENT OF ROC-US RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Richard Bush, chairman and managing director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), said on Friday that he is optimistic about the future of relations between the Republic of China and the United States.
Bush made the remarks in a press conference wrapping up a 13-day visit to Taiwan.
He noted that this year marks the 20th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act, which provides the framework of Taipei-Washington relations in the absence of diplomatic ties.

Looking forward to the next 20 years of relations between Taiwan and the US, Bush said he was optimistic since both sides have established solid and friendly relations, and that they also share common interests and values.

During his third trip to Taiwan as AIT head, Bush said that he was met with warm hospitality everywhere he went on the island, saying that he had seen examples of Taiwan's long and rich history in places like Tainan, Meinung, Peikang, and Lukang in central and southern Taiwan. He also saw an example of Taiwan's future when he visited the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park.
He said that he was struck more than ever before by the basic vitality of Taiwan's economy, made even more obvious by the difficulties plaguing other parts of the Asian region.

On the ROC's establishment of diplomatic relations with Macedonia on Jan. 27, Bush noted that the event took place during his visit to the island, and he reaffirmed the comments by State Department spokesman James Rubin on the issue.

Bush said that the "US does not take a position" on whether or not two political entities should establish relations. He said there should be no linkage between the extension of the United Nations peacekeeping force deployment in Macedonia and the East European nation's recognition of Taiwan, and added that the United States is urging other UN Security Council members to support this position.
Beijing, one of the security council permanent members, is threatening to reconsider the extension of such forces unless Macedonia retracts its decision to establish diplomatic ties with Taiwan.

On whether Taiwan should join the US-proposed theater missile defense (TMD) project, Bush said that the US Defense Ministry's report on TMD has yet to be sent to the Congress, and that the content of the report has not yet been made public.

He said that the United States understands the anxiety of the Taiwan people over mainland China's missile capacity, but pointed out that before Taiwan makes a decision on TMD, it has to clarify many questions, such as its cost and its effect on the cross-strait relations.

He also said that the US has always supported dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, but stressed that the timing, venue, and agenda for meetings must be decided by both sides of the Taiwan Strait on mutually agreed basis.

Bush said that the US will not suggest any ways for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to solve their problems, saying that the Chinese have always been creative in solving their problem, and that this may be a chance to show these skills.

On whether Taiwan will be able to join the World Trade Organization this year, Bush also reaffirmed US support of Taiwan and mainland China's entries, saying that Taiwan has made a lot of progress in its application to join the WTO, and that its application should be treated independently from that of the mainland.

Bush arrived here on Jan. 24. During his visit, he met with President Lee Teng-hui, Premier Vincent Siew, and other political heavyweights from the ruling and opposition parties, to exchange views on matters of mutual concern.
He last visited Taipei in July 1998, when he came to brief Taiwan leaders and officials on the summit meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENIOR TAIWAN RULING PARTY OFFICIAL MEETS MACEDONIAN PM
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 4 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will speed up exchanges and cooperation with its new diplomatic ally, Macedonia, for the mutual benefit of both sides, a senior Taiwan ruling party official said here on Thursday.

John Chang, secretary-general of the ROC's ruling Kuomintang, made the statement after meeting with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georievski, who is currently on an official visit to the United States.

Both Chang and Georievski attended the annual US national prayer breakfast on Thursday, where they were seated at the same table. Chang later took the initiative to pay Georievski a visit in his hotel room.
Chang said after the meeting that his talks with the Macedonian prime minister will be conducive to the development of the newly established bilateral relations.

"I have assured Georievski that our ruling party firmly supports the establishment of full diplomatic ties with Macedonia," Chang said, adding that his meeting with Georievski has helped enhance the Macedonian prime minister's confidence in making friends with the ROC.
During their talks, Chang said, Georievski expressed a strong desire to promote exchanges and cooperation with the ROC in various fields.
"Georievski told me that he hopes various ROC-Macedonian cooperative programs can be launched as soon as possible," said Chang, who once served as ROC foreign minister.

For his part, Georievski later told reporters that he had exchanged views with Chang on a variety of possible cooperative programs. "We look forward to seeing fast and fruitful cooperation with the ROC. We also expect to see frequent exchanges of visits by political leaders from the two countries," he added.

Some Macedonian politicians, including the president, still oppose the establishment of diplomatic ties with the ROC. However, Chang said both he and Georievski believe that the ties are in the interests of both sides.
"I believe that Georievski will be able to resolve Macedonia's domestic issues satisfactorily," Chang said.

He further said Macedonia really needs foreign economic aid. "We have exchanged views on the promotion of bilateral trade and Taiwan investment in Macedonia. Nevertheless, we have not touched on any concrete, specific programs," Chang said, adding that he will convey Georievski's opinion and recommendations on possible bilateral cooperative projects to the relevant ROC government authorities.
Chang will travel to New York on Friday to continue his US visit.
The ROC and Macedonia forged formal diplomatic ties on Jan. 27. The southeastern European state is the ROC's second diplomatic ally in Europe, after the Vatican.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS COMPLETED WTO ENTRY PROCEDURES: BOFT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has completed its application procedures for entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), one of Taiwan's chief negotiators on WTO access said on Friday.

Chen Ruey-long, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) who is also one of the island's chief WTO negotiators, said he anticipates an average tariff cut to agricultural and industrial products to 13.11 percent and 4.06 percent, respectively, when Taiwan joins the world trade regulatory body.
In addition, restrictions on regions from which cars and motorcycles can be imported will also be lifted, he added.

Chen pointed out that since the ROC applied for entry into the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade -- the forerunner of the WTO -- on Jan. 1, 1990, Taipei has almost completed all the procedures for entry.

Negotiations have been concluded with 24 countries out of the 26 countries which requested negotiations on Taiwan's entry terms, the BOFT head noted, adding that polylateral consultations have already been convened nine times.

BOFT officials said that apart from rice, all other agricultural products will be permitted to be imported, while in order to meet tariff-cutting agreements, tariffs on agricultural and industrial products will be reduced even further to 10.76 percent and 2.61 percent, respectively.

State-owned enterprises have already completed their preparations for privatization, said Chen, a requirement for WTO entry. A total of 42 state-owned enterprises will have completed privatization by 2000, while all restrictions on foreign investment in Taiwan's bourse are expected to be lifted in 2001, Chen revealed.
However, he stressed that the lifting of restrictions on foreign investment in Taiwan's stock market does not mean the lifting of restrictions on capital movement.

The ROC is the world's 14th-largest trading nation, and the seventh-biggest in terms of investment, Chen pointed out. The WTO will remain incomplete until Taiwan is allowed to participate, and the island will surely be an excellent market in the world community, the director-general said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOVIE STAR APPOINTED TAIPEI RAPID TRAIN AMBASSADOR

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on Friday awarded a plaque to popular movie star Andy Lau in honor of his appointment as "Taipei Rapid Train Ambassador" with the right to travel free on the Taipei MRT for the rest of his life.
Lau in turn gave the Taipei Rapid Transit Systems Co. Ltd. the right to use his image, allowing the company to print his likeness on its tickets.

Ma and Lau appeared together at the Taipei mass rapid transit systems' main station in Taipei for a year-end charity event sponsored by the company together with a local radio station and record company, drawing widespread attention from the public and media.
More than 70 children from two orphanages, one in Taipei and one in the central city of Taichung, were brought to the station to welcome the two celebrities.
Ma hailed Lau as a good actor and singer with a heart full of compassion, while Lau praised Ma as a politician who respects public opinion.

Ma and Lau later accompanied the children on a MRT ride to the village of Tamsui and presided over a charity donation at the plaza in front of the Tamsui station. All gifts and proceeds collected at the event were to be donated to the two orphanages.

DOC.HEADLINE: JORDANIAN CROWN PRINCE FRIENDLY TOWARD ROC: MOFA

TEXT.P: Jordanian Crown Prince Abdullah bin Hussein, who was appointed heir to Jordan's Hashemite throne just 10 days ago, is very friendly toward the Republic of China, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday.

Chen Kuo-huang, director of the MOFA's West Asian Affairs Department, said Jordanian King Hussein's appointment of his eldest son Abdullah as crown prince has won positive response from the international community.
"International political observers generally believe that Jordan's political and economic situation will remain stable under the new crown prince's leadership," Chen said.

Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, substantive relations between the ROC and Jordan are traditionally cordial. King Hussein, who is critically ill with cancer, has maintained close friendships with many senior ROC officials.
Chen said Crown Prince Abdullah also maintains close ties with top ROC leaders.
Abdullah, 37, has made three visits to Taiwan -- in 1991, 1993 and 1996.

Chen said Abdullah hosted a dinner in honor of ROC President Lee Teng-hui, on behalf of his father, when Lee made a private visit to the Middle East kingdom in 1995, and held wide-ranging talks with Foreign Minister Jason Hu when he visited Jordan last October.

Chen said Lee, Vice President Lien Chan, and Hu all sent their congratulations to Abdullah on Jan. 26, when a Jordanian royal decree announced that he was formally appointed his country's crown prince, replacing King Hussein's brother Hassan as successor to Jordan's throne.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER OF INTERIOR VOWS TO PROTECT PUBLIC FROM FEAR

TEXT.P: The interior minister reiterated his commitment to promoting social order and said the public should enjoy a peaceful life free from fear on Friday, the first anniversary since he first assumed the post.
Huang Chu-wen announced that 1999 has been declared national safety year. He said he will mobilize the public's assistance to help maintain social order.
The legislator-turned-minister noted that the ministry's crackdown on crime will be relentless.

He said there are currently 80,000 police, and 60,000 volunteer firefighters and other public security personnel in Taiwan. Huang, citing figures in the latter part of 1998 to indicate that social order has improved.

Violent crime dropped 16.5 percent from the corresponding period the previous year, while the number of cases solved increased by 7 percent. Reported kidnapping cases fell by 33.33 percent, robbery dropped 28.77 percent, burglary was down by 20.2 percent, and armed crimes sank by 34.7 percent, the interior minister noted.

But he said the number of police was limited and to further improve social order, the ministry will have to mobilize the assistance of the public. Huang said he hoped more people will join the fight against crime.

In addition to promoting a community safety net by setting up a watch team to patrol neighborhoods, Huang said he has also used 24-hour convenience shops as liaison points for police to provide emergency rescue services.

On smuggling rings involving shipping containers filled with motorcycles and automobiles headed for the mainland, Huang said he has asked the police and custom officials to step up their monitoring procedures and asked the Ministry of the Finance to buy large X-ray machines for container checking.
Huang said he will call on Justice Minister Yeh Chin-feng, a former interior minister, next week to discuss issues on cooperating in the battle against crime.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARSHALL ISLANDS PRESIDENT ARRIVES FOR STATE VISIT

TEXT.P: Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua and first lady Hiromi Kabua arrived in Taipei on Friday for a week-long state visit.
The Marshall Islands head of state was accompanied by a 46-member entourage on his Taiwan visit.
ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu greeted President Kabua at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.
President Lee Teng-hui will preside over a military ceremony at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex in downtown Taipei on Saturday to welcome Kabua.
This is Kabua's first visit to the Republic of China since the two countries forged full diplomatic ties on Nov. 20, 1998.
During his visit, Kabua will meet with President Lee, Premier Vincent Siew and other senior ROC officials to discuss feasible ways to further boost bilateral cooperation in various fields.
Kabua and Lee will sign a joint communique on Wednesday, reaffirming their commitment to further promoting bilateral exchanges and cooperation.
During Kabua's stay, the two countries will also sign an agreement on cooperation in agricultural development and civil aviation services.
Kabua and his entourage will also travel to southern and eastern Taiwan to tour Taiwan's industrial and cultural institutions and scenic spots.

Members of Kabua's entourage includes Finance Minister Tony de Brum, Foreign Affairs and Trade Minister Philip Muller, Justice Minister Hemos A. Jack, Vice Speaker of the parliament Jurelang Zedkaia, several senators and business executives.
The Marshall Islands has issued operating permits to 33 Taiwan fishing boats to operate in its waters under a two-year bilateral fishery cooperative agreement.
The Pacific island nation has a population of about 60,000, with a total land area of 171 square kilometers.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR TAIWAN ALPINISTS SURVIVE STORM, SAFE IN CHILE
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Four mountaineers from Taiwan arrived safely in Chile on Wednesday from Argentina after their attempt to climb Aconcagua Mountain was cut short by a fierce storm.

Steven F. Wang, representative of the Republic of China stationed in Santiago, Chile's capital, said the four men -- Wu Liang-ching, Chen Chiang-shan, Tang Ker-ming and Tai Man-cheng -- are the pride of all Chinese around the world for surviving the attempt amid the worst storm in 14 years.

The group retreated before reaching the 6,959-meter peak. However, the nearly 70-year-old Tai, the eldest of the four, had climbed to the height of about 6,500 meters, only 450 meters away from the top.
The four men are currently in a good condition, according to the ROC Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Santiago.

The white-peaked Aconcagua Mountain, located in Argentina and borders Chile, is the highest mountain in the Western Hemisphere and South America. The Aconcagua River and Aconcagua province in the neighboring Chile are named after the mountain.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MAYOR JIA QINGLIN TENDERS RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: Beijing Mayor Jia Qinglin tendered his resignation Friday at the annual municipal people's congress of Beijing, according to a report by mainland Chinese news media.
It is likely that he will be replaced by Liu Qi, a vice mayor of the capital city, if his resignation is approved in the meeting, which opened Friday.
Jia is concurrently secretary of the Beijing Municipal Committee of the Chinese Communist Party.

Liu had served as minister of metallurgical industry from 1993 until March, 1998, when he became vice major of Beijing and deputy secretary of the communist party's Beijing Municipal Committee. Liu is also a member of the Central Committee of the communist party.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLASTIC GROUP REACH PACT WITH CAMBODIA TO TAKE BACK WASTE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's plastic giant, the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG), reached an agreement with Cambodian authorities on Friday to take back industrial waste it dumped in that country, according to a statement issued by the group.
FPG promised to clean up the 3,000-ton, mercury-tainted mud then re-package and ship it out of Cambodia within 60 days after the pact was formally signed.

The group didn't elaborate on where the waste will go for fear of opposition from environmental groups. Instead, the statement said the compressed and solidified mud will be shipped to "the country of origin or a third country."
Cambodian authorities promised to facilitate the shipment of the mud by providing FPG with the required documents within 30 days after the signing of the pact.

The agreement was reached between FPG Deputy Chairman Wang Chin-shu, General Manager Lee Chih-chun and three Cambodian officials, led by Om Yem Tieng, a private advisor to Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen.
Om Yem Tieng, accompanied by two Cambodian environment officials, arrived in Taiwan on Thursday evening to negotiate a deal whereby FPG would remove the sludge.

The mercury-tainted waste dumped last November in Sihanoukville, 185 km southwest of Phnom Penh, has scared Sihanoukville's residents, who fled in droves after five deaths were blamed on the waste last December.
Angry Phnom Penh authorities demanded that FPG take back the waste immediately, but FPG was hesitant to do so due to strenuous opposition from Taiwan environmental groups.
FPG sources said the group is weighing the possibility of shipping the waste to the United States and storing it on the premises of an FPG plant in Texas.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP LIEN OUTLINES FIVE NATIONAL GOALS FOR THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan on Friday put forward five national government goals for 1999 during a dinner party for senior advisers and strategic advisers to the president.
Lien was standing in as host of the regular year-end event for the flu-stricken President Lee Teng-hui who was admitted to the hospital on Thursday.

The five priorities were to consolidate democracy to ensure it takes root on the island; fully implement government restructuring to promote efficiency and bolster the nation's strength; ensure steady development of the economy by intensifying international cooperation; speed up reforms to the judiciary to boost its efficiency and credibility; and realize social justice through the establishment of a comprehensive social security system.
Vowing to pursue the goals with determination, Lien urged the public to join forces with the government to fight for brighter prospects for the nation.
On behalf of the president, Lien expressed thanks to the presidential advisers for their opinions and advice on national issues and wished them a happy Chinese New Year.
Thirty presidential advisers attended Friday's dinner. Also present were the heads of five government branches as well as Speaker of National Assembly Su Nan-cheng.
The post of presidential adviser is largely a ceremonial job awarded to retired government and military leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARSHALL ISLANDS URGES END TO SELLING OF ITS PASSPORTS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Republic of the Marshall Islands urged Taipei authorities to crack down on the selling of its passports in Taiwan, said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Friday.

In a letter to MOFA, the Marshall Islands' Foreign Ministry said the sale of Marshall Islands' passports has been banned since 1996 and ROC nationals who wish to immigrate to the island state should contact the nearest embassy or wait until its embassy is opened in Taipei, which is expected soon.
To attract foreign capital during the mid-1980s, the Marshall Islands offered its passports to foreign investors who funneled a certain amount of money to the state.
This move lured many Taiwanese to that former US trust territory as its passport holders are granted free access to the United States.
However, the huge influx of Taiwan immigrants triggered a backlash among Marshall Islands residents and led to the banning of the sale of its passports in Taiwan.

After learning that Taiwan newspapers continued to run advertisements soliciting immigrants by this program, the Republic of Marshall called the matter to Taipei authorities' attention and said it hoped MOFA will warn the public against the illicit practice, MOFA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEGISLATIVE DELEGATIONS OFF ON FACT-FINDING FOREIGN TRIPS

TEXT.P: A Taiwan legislative delegation comprised of ruling Kuomintang lawmakers set off on Saturday for a fact-finding visit to Britain.

KMT sources said that in a January meeting with KMT legislators elected last December, President Lee Teng-hui, who serves concurrently as KMT chairman, spelled out the importance of overseas visits to the island's constitutional reforms.

The sources said Lee places great weight on foreign experience and the carrying out of constitutional affairs of other democratic countries, believing that they can provide references for Taiwan's own parliamentary reforms.

The delegation to Britain is one of four similar groups undertaking fact-finding visits to United States, France and Japan, respectively. The mission to the United States set off on Friday, while the others are scheduled to take off on Monday.

The delegations will hold talks with ranking government officials and scholars during their visits. They will also call on overseas Chinese representatives to exchange views on matters of mutual concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUNE 4 TIANANMEN MASSACRE TO BE COMMEMORATED ACROSS EUROPE
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: At least 500 cities and towns throughout Europe this year will commemorate the 10th anniversary of the June 4 Tiananmen massacre in Beijing, according to a supporter of mainland China's democratic movement on Friday.

Marie Hozman, chairman of the French Maison de Democracie (House of Democracy), said an international committee for the commemoration of the massacre organized the one day Tiananmen Square activity and has received warm support in Europe.

Hozman said she and several mainland Chinese pro-democracy activists met recently with Jacques Lang, chairman of the French National Assembly's foreign relations committee, to discuss the issue, and gained his support.
After communication by Lang with the Association of European mayors, 500 members have expressed their willingness to take part in the activity.

This year is also the 10th anniversary of the collapse of the Berlin Wall. Lang, representing France, and former German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, representing Germany, are now actively organizing a historical commemorative activity.

Because the June 4 massacre means as much to mainland China's democracy movement as the collapse of the Berlin Wall does to Europeans, Lang will meet with Kohl on how to coordinate the two commemorative activities to heighten the current of democracy and perhaps bring about another round of democracy movement in mainland China.

Lang said he believes that this year's June 4 commemoration will be a spectacular and impressive display, and will put strong pressure on Beijing to force the regime to promote the maintenance of human rights and the reform of democracy.

Mainland Chinese democracy activists also asked for Lang's support to urge the French National Assembly and the European Parliament to unite with all the governments of European countries to pressure Beijing to release illegally indicted and detained dissidents.
