DOC.HEADLINE: SONS OF MAINLAND CHINESE HIJACKERS REPATRIATED VIA HK

TEXT.P: Two children who were brought to Taiwan by their parents in two separate hijackings from mainland China a few years ago were repatriated via Hong Kong on Saturday.

Three staff members from the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) accompanied Luo Wanghuan, 16, and Yang Yang, 11, to Hong Kong, where the two youngsters were handed over to representatives from the SEF's mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
An SEF press statement said that the repatriation was handled "according to the principles of safety, humanitarianism and convenience."

Luo Wanghuan is the son of hijackers Luo Changhua and Wang Yuing, while Yang Yang's parents, also air pirates, are Yang Mingde and Han Fenging. Luo's parents and Yang Yang's father will soon be repatriated by ship together with six other mainland Chinese hijackers. Yang Yang's mother was repatriated in 1997 after serving a jail term here.

The two youngsters looked grim and didn't utter a word before their departure for Hong Kong. Tung Shan-chih, a teacher at the Taipei Children's Welfare Center under the Chinese Refugees Relief Association and who was responsible for taking care of Yang Yang, said the center gave US$2,900 in cash to Yang Yang as a parting gift.
After living and studying in Taiwan for several years, the two children may need time to re-adapt themselves to life in mainland China, Tung said.

The Beijing-based (ARATS) asked three officials from the Hong Kong office of mainland China's mouthpiece Xinhua news agency to receive the two children at Hong Kong's Chek Lap Kok airport and complete some formalities with the SEF officials who brought them from Taiwan.
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.
SEF has also informed ARATS of its plan to repatriate nine mainland hijackers via the Taiwan-held island fortress of Kinmen before the Chinese New Year holiday.

The nine are Liu Baocai, Shi Yuebo, Yang Mingde, Wang Zhihua, Luo Changhua, Wang Yuing, Zou Weiqiang, Li Xiangyu and Lin Wenqiang, all of whom have served jail sentences and are now qualified for parole.
Two of 17 people involved in hijackings, most of which occurred between April 1993 and June 1994, were sent back to mainland China via Kinmen in 1997 following extensive SEF-ARATS discussions.

Due to the lack of a binding agreement on the issue, Beijing declined to inform Taipei of the fate of the hijackers, who stood trial in a mainland court after their return to the mainland. Beijing does not recognize judicial rulings handed down by Taipei.

SEF again urged ARATS on Saturday to seal a bilateral agreement to regulate the repatriation of cross-strait hijackers and other criminal suspects. Without a formal agreement, SEF said the repatriation of mainland hijackers can be processed only on a case-by-case basis.
In May 1997, mainland China repatriated Taiwanese hijacker Liu Shan-chung, who forced a domestic flight to the southeastern mainland port city of Xiamen in March 1997.
Political observers said the upcoming repatriation of the nine hijackers will help cultivate a good atmosphere in the run-up to a planned visit to Taiwan by ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan.

ARATS will reportedly send its deputy secretary-general to Taiwan later this month or in early March to discuss details concerning Wang's planned Taiwan visit, which is a reciprocal trip to SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu's ice-melting visit to the mainland last October.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slid NT$0.008 against the greenback in Taipei Saturday, closing at 32.247.
The local currency opened at 32.252 and was traded between 32.242 and 32.254.
The interbank US dollar trading amounted to US$47 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACEDONIAN INFORMATION MINISTER ARRIVES FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: Macedonian Information Minister Redzep Zlatku, traveling at the head of a 30-member journalist delegation, will arrive in Taipei on Sunday for a weeklong visit at the invitation of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

The group's impending visit has commanded widespread attention here as it is the first official visit by a group from the Balkan state since Taipei and Skojpe formally set up diplomatic ties on Jan. 27.

Government Information Office (GIO) Director-General Chen Chien-jen described the event as being of great significance to the future of bilateral ties between the two countries, and said that the GIO has made all necessary arrangements to ensure the visit is a success.

While here, Zlatku and the other delegates will visit MOFA, the GIO, and leading local media organizations, in addition to holding seminars with local business and cultural representatives, according to Chen.

In return, Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu is scheduled to depart for Macedonia on Feb. 23 for an official visit. He will be accompanied by a local trade delegation which will be seeking business and investment opportunities with that country.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAYSIA ECONOMY IS RECOVERING: MOEA REPORT

TEXT.P: Malaysia's economy is becoming more stable and forecasts for its growth in 1999 are posted at 1 percent, shaking off the cloudy recession caused by the Asian financial storm, according to an official Taiwan report.

A Southeast Asian investment mission from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is visiting Malaysia, a key market for Taiwan investments in the region. The delegation's report pointed out that Malaysia is recovering from its financial difficulties.

The Southeast Asian nation has launched new incentive programs to attract investment, which widely loosen limitations on foreign investment in the manufacturing industry, the report said. But it warned Taiwan businesses building factories there to be aware of the lack of professional manpower and that loyalty among Malaysian employees is not as high as that among Taiwan workers.

Nevertheless, the report said the advantages of investing in Malaysia include the fact that the country is a key resource of imports of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) market and that Malaysia enjoys steady social order, stable currency, and a complete basic economic infrastructure.

The MOEA fact-finding delegation also reported that the regional financial assault, which began in mid-1997, has damaged many Taiwan enterprises in Southeast Asia. It suggested that the government in Taipei provide more complete information on avoiding risks, as well as business operation and management advice for those Taiwan companies having or intending to develop overseas business.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FINANCIAL CRISIS DEEPENING: CANADIAN DAILY

TEXT.P: Taiwan sank further into a financial crisis on Thursday as investors staged a run on a family-owned bank and a prominent businessman flew to the United States on a one-way ticket, a major economic newspaper in Canada reported on Friday.

The Taipei-datelined story said Liu Ping-wei's arrival in Los Angeles helped drive the Taiwan Weighted Stock Exchange index down 4 percent on concerns about the finances of the Liu family's Hai Shan group of companies.

The report said Taiwan's benchmark index has fallen 14.1 percent this year, the worst performer among all the major Asian stock exchanges, amid a spate of scandals involving bounced cheques and share trading defaults. These defaults have amounted to more than NT$6 billion over the past four months, it noted.
The departure of Liu destroyed confidence in his business empire, whose debts are estimated at between NT$5 billion and NT$6 billion by the government, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES, FUTURES RALLY

TEXT.P: Due to the government's decision to crack down on the dissemination of rumors adversely affecting the stock market, and a buying spree after several days of decline, the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) rallied on Saturday.

The weighted price index, the market's key barometer, closed at 5,710.18, the highest level of the day, on a turnover of NT$67.53 billion, up from the NT$60.74 billion recorded in the previous session.
The local bourse opened high and maintained an upward trend throughout the day.
The over-the-counter market also closed higher, with the market's index rising 6.17 points to finish at 146.25 on a turnover of NT$3.7 billion.
Meanwhile, Taiwan stock index futures closed higher.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for February rose 187 points to close at 5,767, with 5,022 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for March rose 176 points to close at 5,826, with 2,414 contract transactions, while those for June were up 170 points to 5,855, with 37 contract transactions. September futures rose 178 points to 5,830, with 14 contract transactions, and December futures moved up 197 points to 5,899, with six contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAMAICA THREATENS DIPLOMATIC ACTION AGAINST CANADA

TEXT.P: Unhappy about a Canadian document alleging that high-level Jamaican officials are involved in visa scams, Jamaica is threatening diplomatic action against Canada.

An internal document by diplomats at the Canadian High Commission in the Jamaican capital of Kingston alleges that prominent Jamaicans are involved in visa scams, and that people are being allowed to flee the country illegally after committing crimes.
In the document, Canadian diplomats also comment unfavorably on the social conditions of most Jamaicans.
The Jamaican government countered by saying the statements are "outdated, unfair and dangerous." It said it will take diplomatic action against Canada over the document.

DOC.HEADLINE: EURO WILL NOT RAPIDLY REPLACE GREENBACK: US REPORT

TEXT.P: The euro offers certain specific benefits and potential costs, but is unlikely to rapidly replace the US dollar as the world's premier currency, according to US President Bill Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers (CEA).

In a newly released annual report, the council said that for the countries participating in the single European currency, costs in trade among members of the European Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) will be lowered as exchange rate risk and currency transactions within Europe will both be eliminated.

These reduced trading costs will further market integration, enhancing price competitiveness. The countries participating in the EMU will also be required to show more discipline in fiscal and monetary policies, according to the report.

The loss of monetary autonomy, however, will deprive EMU countries of a tool that they can use to "respond to asymmetric national shocks -- unexpected economic developments that affect some countries differently than others," noted the CEA.
In addition, the report said, while Europe will have a single currency, the countries will maintain separate fiscal arrangements, including their own tax policies and social service organizations.
But the CEA stressed that the odds are against the euro's "rapidly supplanting the dollar as the world's premier currency."

An international currency is one that people use because everyone else is using it. Two of the four determinants of reserve currency status -- highly developed financial markets and historical inertia -- support the dollar over the euro, explained the report.

The third, economic size, is a tie (or will be if the United Kingdom joins the EMU). The fourth, stable monetary policies, is also a tie, as both Europe and the United States follow these policies with the aim of keeping inflation low, said the CEA.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACEDONIAN PM STICKS TO DECISION ON TAIWAN TIES

TEXT.P: Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski said on Friday that despite pressure from mainland China, his government will not change its decision to establish diplomatic ties with the Republic of China.
Asked whether Beijing can force Skopje to reverse its decision, the prime minister acknowledged that there has been "certain pressure."
"However, the decision of the (Macedonian) government is very clear," he added. "And we do not contemplate at this moment to reverse it."
He also said that his government hopes to continue cooperation with mainland China and will not cut ties with Beijing.
Answering questions at Washington's National Press Club, Georgievski shrugged off internal differences over Skopje's decision.
He said that Macedonia is a democratic country with a strong opposition, which "reacts to any decision by the government," he said. "So in this respect, we are not much excited."
Georgievski told reporters that seeking economic cooperation is the main motive for recognizing Taiwan.

"In cooperation with Taiwan we see an excellent opportunity to accept their experience. Their companies can find space where they can build factories, thus connecting their experience with our need for foreign investment," he said.
Forty percent of Macedonia's labor force is unemployed and 22 percent of the population live below the poverty line.
On Jan. 27, Skopje and Taipei announced their decision to establish diplomatic relations but Beijing apparently has not given up hope that Macedonia might change its mind.

Mainland Chinese officials have threatened over the last week that, unless Skopje retracts its decision, Beijing might reconsider an extension of the mandate for the UN Preventive Deployment Force (UNPREDEP) in Macedonia.
On this issue, Georgievski said that during his talks with US leaders, he was assured that the presence of UNPREDEP not only benefits Macedonia, but it is also required for the whole region.
He said he believes that the international community should not refuse to renew the UNPREDEP mandate at the United Nations Security Council, where mainland China has the power of veto.

The Security Council is expected in late February to consider extending the UNPREDEP mandate which has been renewed every half year since the force was first sent to the former Yugoslav republic in March 1995.
Composed mainly of US and Scandinavian troops, UNPREDEP's mission is to prevent conflicts in other parts of former Yugoslavia from spreading.
At the press conference, the prime minister elaborated on the concerns expressed by US Secretary Madeleine Albright over Macedonia's decision to recognize Taiwan.

During their discussion on Wednesday, according to Georgievski, Albright said that the decision "may create some complications for Macedonia, especially in the United Nations," a point which he said is "undoubtedly true."
The US secretary of state expressed the opinion that, before Macedonia made the independent decision, "wider international consultation could have been made," he added.
On Wednesday, the US State Department said that it favors maintaining the UN force in Macedonia and opposes any linkage between extending the mandate and Macedonia's recognition of Taiwan.
State Department spokesman James Rubin said also that Washington does not take an official position on whether other countries should recognize Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA ORDERS SCRUTINY OF OLYMPIC BIDDING RECORDS

TEXT.P: Australia has bowed to mounting public and media pressure by ordering the scrutiny of the 3,000 files containing details of how Sydney was successful in its bidding to host the 2000 Olympic Games.
The order was announced by Sports Minister Michael Knight on Friday, who said the public were entitled to know whether Sydney's bid and all those involved were "beyond reproach."
Sydney beat Beijing in 1993 for the right to host the 2000 Olympic Games.
Knight's order followed an announcement early this week by a member of the International Olympic Committee, who cleared Sydney of any wrongdoing or breach of rules.
The IOC move followed a corruption scandal revealed in Salt Lake City in the United States, which won the right to host the Winter Olympics in 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN DOLLAR EXPECTED TO APPRECIATE FURTHER

TEXT.P: The Australian dollar is expected to appreciate further after hitting a nine-month high against the US dollar on Friday, dealers here have predicted.
The Australian dollar closed at 65.17 US cents on Friday, up 1.27 US cents from Thursday's close.

Dealers said frantic offshore buying propelled the Australian dollar up more than one US cent to its highest level in nine months amid a rally in commodity prices and predictions it will be one of the year's most improved currencies.

The appreciation of the Australian currency was also helped by a weaker greenback and an upbeat report from US investment bank Goldman Sachs, which said the Australian dollar was 20 percent undervalued and likely to be one of the world's strongest currencies in 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE NATION PARTY OF AUSTRALIA SAID WEAKENING (I)

TEXT.P: Less than eight months after its stunning victory in parliamentary elections in Queensland, the One Nation party is weakening, political analysts said.
One Nation stunned Australian politics after a sweeping victory in the June 13 election, in which the emerging party won 11 seats in Queensland.

Public polls show its support, mainly from grassroots levels in the countryside, reached its zenith at over 13 percent across Australia after the June election and One Nation became one of the country's political forces.
The rise of One Nation was the result of long-term frustration by the grassroots over mainstream parties becuase these parties ignored their pleas.

One Nation's popularity started falling after Pauline Hanson, the creator of the party, lost in her bid to be re-elected to the Federal parliament for a second three-year term in an October 3 election. In addition, her senior adviser and strategist -- David Oldfield -- also failed in the same elections.

Hanson, a fish and chip shop owner in Brisbane, won overnight fame after being elected to the federal parliament and delivered a maiden speech in September 1996 attacking Asian migrants, Aboriginal people and multiculturalism.
Hanson's controversial remarks were reported around the world, with growing fears that Australia might return to the White Australia Policy it followed in 1950s and 1960s.

One month after Hanson's defeat, however, One Nation suffered its first blow when one of its 11 MPs in Queensland quit the parliament, and her new candidate also failed to win in a by-election to fill the seat, causing the number of One Nation MPs to fall to 10.

To make matters worse, three more One Nation MPs from Queensland have resigned after a wave of party infighting, accusing Hanson, now party president, and her two senior advisers -- Oldfield and David Ettridge -- of undemocratic practices in the party hierarchy and financial management.
The latest resignations also cost One Nation its status as a political party because of its reduced numbers in the Queensland parliament. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE NATION PARTY OF AUSTRALIA SAID WEAKENING (II)

TEXT.P: Queensland Premier Peter Beattie is expected to decide whether to strip One Nation of its Parliament House headquarters, staff and funds when the parliament resumes next month.
Hanson and Oldfield on Friday played down the party infighting, telling reporters that their fledgling party was holding together despite the latest resignations.
But analysts said Hanson is distressed by the latest resignations because it could damage One Nation and cost the party the election in New South Wales.
Analysts predict One Nation is facing its death if infighting continues without any solution.
In its editorial on Saturday, the Australian newspaper sums up in its analysis:

"One Nation was born from a political revolution sparked by Ms. Hanson's complaints about the contemporary political system. It now faces its own internal revolution which may deliver it democracy in the most crucial step towards the party's long-term survival. If it fails this test, can it really have any future?"

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG TYCOON GETS 3-YEAR-AND-2-MONTH JAIL TERM

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court sentenced Hong Kong business tycoon Lim Por-yen, who has been detained in Taiwan for more than a year, to three years and two months in prison on Saturday for his role in a bribery scandal.

The court also required Lim, chairman of the Hong Kong-based Lai Sun Group and a major shareholder of Hong Kong's Asia Television, to pay an additional NT$30 billion (US$930,319) in bail in exchange for the lifting of a ban on his departure from Taiwan.

Lim, 88, was convicted of charges of bribery. The district court verdict said Lim had offered US$4.14 million to Taipei County government officials so that he could receive an exceptionally high compensation, about NT$890 million, for the site of his Dollar Textile Manufacturing Co. in Sanhsia, Taipei County, which was conscripted to make way for the proposed National Taipei University.
Lim was arrested in Taipei in December 1997 and was released on a bail of NT$10 million on Jan. 19, 1998, but he was prohibited from leaving Taiwan.

Lim said after learning the court's decision that he is planning to return to Hong Kong on Monday after paying the additional NT$30 million in bail. The businessman promised that he will respond to any Taiwan court's summon in the future.
Lim's lawyer said Lim will file an appeal with the Taiwan High Court after receiving the district court verdict because the sentence was not fair.

Meanwhile, Chuang Yu-kun, a former director of the Taipei County Land Administration Bureau, was sentenced to 20 years in jail plus an eight-year suspension of his civil rights for his role in the National Taipei University land conscription scandal and another bribery scandal involving the rezoning of a tract of land in Sanchih, Taipei County.
The district court ordered the confiscation of US$4.14 million in bribes given to Chuang by the Hong Kong business tycoon. The court also rejected Chuang's application for bail.

Chuang's in-law, Lin Chin-jung, received an 11-year prison sentence plus a four-year suspension of his civil rights for involvement in the Taipei University land conscription scandal. Nevertheless, he was granted a NT$300,000 bail.

Also convicted of two bribery charges were Lin Wen-nung, a technician with the Taipei County Public Works Bureau, who received a suspended one-year-and-two-month jail term; Cheng Ya-yun, an entertainer, who received a two-year-and-10-month prison term plus a two-year suspension of civil rights; and Lee Chen-tung, a business executive, who got a suspended two-year prison term.
Seven other suspects indicted by prosecution for involvement in the two scandals were acquitted of the charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA VICE MINISTER PLANS A VISIT TO MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) plans to send its Administrative Vice Minister Lin Yi-fu to Macedonia, ROC's new ally in Europe, to learn about trade and investment opportunities there.

ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu is organizing an economic and industrial delegation to visit the Balkan state later this month and the MOEA planned to send Lin as its representative as a part of the mission.

However, members of the economic and trade delegation are still awaiting final approval from Economic Minister Wang Chih-kang. If the MOEA were to send a vice-minister level official to join the trip, Lin -- who is responsible for economic and trade affairs -- will be MOEA's representative, according to informed sources.
A MOEA internal report pointed out that the economic recovery of Macedonia hinges on its ability to attract foreign capital and its determination in liberalization.

The privatization of Macedonian state-run enterprises has been successful. A total of 1,160 out of 1,261 state-owned enterprises have completed the privatization process as of April 1998. However, the managing and administrative powers of the enterprises are still in the hands of their former managers. Foreign capital is therefore needed to make a thorough reform of such operations.

Seeing as Macedonia is in the vicinity of the European Union, the world's second-largest market, Taiwan businessmen can use it as a bridgehead for breaking into the European market if they invest in Macedonia, noted Lin.
As of date, Lin added, textile, machine and machine parts are items worthy investments in Macedonia for Taiwan businessmen.

The MOEA vice minister further indicated that the total trade volume between Taiwan and Macedonia up to present, has been rather low: Taiwan's exports to Macedonia was valued at US$1.86 million in 1998, while Taiwan's imports from Macedonia was only to the tune of US$593,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSTRUCTIVE DIALOGUE KEY TO CROSS-STRAIT PEACE: KMT AIDE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By K. C. Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Visiting ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary-General John Chang said on Friday that continued constructive dialogue between Taiwan and mainland China will ensure peace and prosperity across the Taiwan Strait.
Chang made the remarks here at a lunch banquet sponsored by the Asian Association in a speech on cross-strait ties after Taiwan's elections in December 1998.

The results of the elections are a reflection that the people of Taiwan support the Republic of China government's policy toward mainland China, Chang said, adding that it is apparent the KMT will continue to play a dominant role in Taiwan's dealings with the mainland and there will be no change in this role in the foreseeable future.

The outcome of the elections also helped clear up some facts which include the Taiwan people's aspiration for democracy, prosperity and a stable relationship with mainland China, and their refusal to support political parties or candidates who advocate "immediate unification," or "imminent independence," he noted.

The poll results have also prompted the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party to review its platform on Taiwan independence amid the party's efforts to replace the KMT as Taiwan's ruling party, Chang noted.

On the issue of the "new Taiwanese" concept, all Taiwan residents regardless of those born in Taiwan or the mainland who came to Taiwan after 1949, have realized the importance of working together for Taiwan's continued development and prosperity, he said.

Stressing that the Taiwan people will never allow Beijing to decide their future, Chang lamented Beijing's reluctance to forswear its hostility toward Taiwan and its instance that Taiwan must unify with mainland China under its conditions.

Although Taipei differs from Beijing on the definition of "one China," Chang asserted that the ROC government has never shifted away from its "one China" principle. At present, Taiwan prefers to maintain the status-quo to preserve its democratic system and prosperity, he claimed.
Chang, at the head of a KMT delegation, flew into Washington D.C. to attend the annual US prayer breakfast on Thursday. He will depart for San Francisco on Sunday.
Although Chang has expressed a keen interest in visiting Madame Chiang Kai-shek before leaving New York, the KMT secretary-general said he is still awaiting Madame Chiang's reply.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ETERNAL CHEMICAL CO. TO BUILD PLANT IN VIRGINIA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Virginia Governor Jim Gilmore announced on Thursday that Eternal Chemical Co. of Taiwan has decided to invest NT$580 million (US$18 million) to build a chemical plant in Chesterfield County, Virginia.
Construction of the plant will start soon and is expected to be completed at the end of this year. Formal operations will start in January next year.

Gilmore said at a news conference that the state government has attached much importance to Eternal's project and will provide Eternal with necessary assistance as this is the first major high-technology investment project to be launched in Virginia from Taiwan.
He expressed the hope that more Taiwan companies will follow suit to invest in Virginia.
Benjamin Lo, the Republic of China's deputy representative to the United States, said at the news conference that Eternal had been looking for a site for the project in the United States since 1996.

He described the decision to build the plant in Virginia as a "wise choice," adding that Taiwan and the United States have maintained close economic and trade relations, with Taiwan being the seventh largest trading partner of the United States.
The deputy representative was standing in for Stephen Chen, ROC representative to the US, who was accompanying an ROC mission to the White House for a breakfast prayer.

DOC.HEADLINE: CDC INVESTS US$2 MILLION IN NCOMPASS LABS OF CANADA
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China Development Corp. (CDC) on Friday announced its plans to invest US$2 million in Vancouver-based NCompass Labs Inc., a Canadian software company in network system integration.
This is CDC's largest high-tech investment in Canada, CDC members said. CDC is a business arm of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang.

NCompass Labs is a three-year-old company with some 70 employees. Its capability in product development has a good reputation while it has obtained backing from business tycoons as well as the Royal Bank of Canada and the US' Intel company, according to the Vancouver Office of Taiwan's Far East Trade Service Inc.

Attracted by trade opportunities in the information sector, CDC has not only invested in Taiwan's leading semiconductor and computer makers, like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing and Asustek Computer, but also spared no efforts in pushing into the overseas markets.
According to statistics in Canadian newspapers, Taiwan was ranked the 14th largest investor in Canada while the United States was the country's largest source of foreign funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE TO BE DISCHARGED FROM HOSPITAL ON SUNDAY

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui, who was admitted to the National Taiwan University Hospital for influenza on Thursday, will be discharged on Sunday, according to the Presidential Office.
The Presidential Office said in a news release that the 76-year-old president has fully recovered from the flu, which has affected more than 180,000 people in Taiwan in the past few weeks.
It said Lee will leave the hospital at 10:30 a.m., adding that the first couple expressed their appreciation for the public's concern over the president's health.
They also extended their gratitude to the medical team of NTU Hospital for their thoughtful care during the president's hospitalization.
Dr. Lien Wen-pin, the attending physician, said earlier that Lee's health was generally sound, but he asked the president to stay in the hospital for a few days so he could get more rest.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 6, or the 21st day of the 12th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1643: Abel Janszoon Tasman, Dutch mariner and explorer who was the first European to discover Tasmania and New Zealand in 1642, discovers the Fiji Islands in the Pacific.
1778: Britain declares war on France.
1788: Massachusetts becomes the sixth state in the Union of American States.
1819: The East India Company, represented by Stamford Raffles, sets up settlement at Singapore.
1840: Britain annexes New Zealand.
1895: Babe Ruth (George Herman), American baseball player with a tremendous ratting record, is born.
1899: The Treaty of Paris is ratified, whereby Spain cedes Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam and the Philippines to the United States for US$20 million.
1911: Ronald Reagan, an actor turned politician and the 40th president of the United States, is born.
1932: Japanese troops capture Harbin in northeastern China.
1932: The ROC National Military Council is established.
1938: The ROC National Military Council sets up Political Department, with Chen Cheng serves as director and Chou En-lai (Zhou Enlai) and Huang Chi-hsiang as deputy directors.
1941: Erwin Rommel, a German general known as "the Desert Fox" who committed suicide after his implication in the July Plot to assassinate Hitler in 1944, becomes the supreme commander of German forces in Africa.
1945: American General Douglas MacArthur announces the retaining of Manila and the rescuing of more than 5,000 prisoners of war.
1952: King George VI of Britain dies peacefully at Sandringham. He was succeeded by his eldest daughter Princess Elizabeth.
1957: Taiwan's textile industry enters the age of chemical fibers as a man-made fiber company's plant in Toufen begins production.
1958: The Manchester soccer team of Britain, one of the best teams in Europe, is virtually wiped out in an air crash in Munich.
1983: Klaus Barbie, known as "the Butcher of Lyon" during World War II, is charged in Lyon, France, with crimes against humanity.
1983: Lee Mei-hsu, Taiwan's noted painter, dies at the age of 82.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Holy, sainted men I do not expect to see; if I could only meet with wise and good men I would be satisfied."

DOC.HEADLINE: MARSHALL ISLANDS PRESIDENT GRANTED MILITARY WELCOME

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan presided over a military ceremony on Saturday to welcome Marshall Island President Imata Kabua, who arrived in Taipei Friday evening for a week-long state visit.

Lien hosted the ceremony at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex in downtown Taipei on behalf of President Lee Teng-hui, who has been hospitalized since Thursday with a flu infection. This was the first time that Lien has presided over such a ceremony on Lee's behalf.

Kabua was granted a red-carpet welcome complete with a 21-gun salute. This is the Marshall Islands president's first visit to Taipei since the Pacific island nation established full diplomatic ties with the Republic of China on Nov. 20, 1998.
Lien said in his welcome speech that he admires the Marshall Islands' progress in political democratization and economic development since Kabua assumed his post.
The vice president further said he believes Kabua's current visit will help cement bilateral relations and expand cooperation in various fields.
For his part, Kabua said he hopes his visit will help lay a solid foundation for the development of cooperative ties between his country and the ROC.

During his visit, Kabua will meet with President Lee, Premier Vincent Siew and other senior ROC officials to discuss general international and regional affairs as well as other matters of mutual concern.
Kabua and Lee will sign a joint communique on Wednesday, reaffirming their commitment to further promoting bilateral exchanges and cooperation.
During his stay, Kabua will preside over an inaugural ceremony for the Marshall Islands Embassy in the ROC.
Meanwhile, ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu and Marshall Islands Foreign Affairs and Trade Minister Philip Muller will sign an agricultural cooperation agreement and a civil aviation accord.
Kabua is accompanied by his wife and a 46-member entourage, composed of senior officials, senators and business executives.
Kabua and his entourage will also travel to southern and eastern Taiwan to tour major industrial and cultural institutions and tourist attractions.
Under a two-year fishery cooperative agreement, the Marshall Islands has issued operating permits to 33 Taiwan fishing boats to operate in its waters.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T AFFIRMS DETERMINATION TO CRACK DOWN ON BOURSE IRREGULARITIES

TEXT.P: The government on Saturday affirmed its determination to crack down on stock market irregularities with the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) setting up a one-stop service counter to receive reports of improper dealings.
The measure was taken amid the recent bearish trend of the stock market and the growing number of rumors that have caused investor confidence to waver.

Ting Ke-hua, vice chairman of the SFC, said the one-stop service counter will accept reports of any inappropriate dealings in the stock market including the manipulation of company securities by insiders and the dissemination of rumors.
Ting said the SFC will work with the Ministry of Justice to hit out at stock market irregularities.
Meanwhile, the Taiwan Stock Exchange is offering NT$3 million in reward money to the public in exchange for information on bourse irregularities.
The SFC has also established a special telephone line to take calls on illicit stock market activity. The phone number is (02) 8773-4136.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS TO VIETNAM ENTITLED TO RECIPROCAL TARIFF

TEXT.P: The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said on Saturday that Vietnam has agreed to provide reciprocal tariff for Taiwan products retroactive from Jan. 1 this year.

BOFT said Taiwan was originally not listed by Vietnam as a country entitled to reciprocal tariff, but following strenuous negotiations, Hanoi finally agreed to provide the reciprocal tariff status on an equal basis.
Exporters who want to use the reciprocal tariff are required to produce certificates of origin for their products from the Taiwan Chamber of Commerce or 78 other trade organizations in Taiwan.
The Vietnamese authorities said the reciprocal tariff being granted for Taiwan products are different from preferential tariff, according to the BOFT.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL PROTESTS AGAINST BEIJING ATROCITIES
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Feb. 5 (CNA) (By S. H. Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: An ROC official stationed in South Africa harshly criticized Beijing's human rights abuses and suppression of democracy in a letter to a local newspaper on Friday.
Chen Tien-chue, head of the information section at the Taipei Liaison Office in the Republic of South Africa, wrote a letter to the editor in the largest-circulation daily, the Star.

He urged the South African government, public and media to protest the visit of mainland Chinese Vice President Hu Jintao, who was in South Africa from Jan. 31-Feb. 4, for Beijing's atrocities against human rights, freedom of speech and assembly. All such rights are ensured in the South African constitution, he noted.

Chen said mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin is not effectively committed to political reforms. According to Chen, Jiang asserted in a December speech marking the 20th anniversary of the mainland opening its doors, that the Chinese Communist Party will hold onto the reigns of power and any element which poses a threat to state security must be eliminated.

Pointing to the arrests of several leading political dissidents such as Wang Youcai and Hsiu Wenli late last year as example, Chen said mainland authorities also imprisoned Lin Hai, a businessman in Shanghai, on charges of leaking secret information to hostile foreign organizations as part of their efforts to harass Internet users in the mainland.

Chen said Hu is one of the top Chinese Communist Party members with experience in quelling large-scale dissent when he cracked down on an uprising in Tibet during his tenure as party secretary-general in the region from 1989 to 1992.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE COMPANY TO BUILD FACTORY IN SUBIC BAY

TEXT.P: A large manufacturing company from mainland China will build a US$10 million assembly factory for air conditioners and other appliances at Subic Bay's freeport zone.
The move involves LPL-Gree, Inc. in their first factory outside of the mainland, the Subic Bay Metropolitan Authority (SBMA) said.
LPL-Gree is a mainland China-based distributor of the Gree brand of home appliances. The appliances to be produced in the would-be Subic plant will be sold locally and exported.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC DEPUTY SECRETARY-GENERAL RETURNS TO QUELL SPECULATION

TEXT.P: Liu Ping-hua, a deputy secretary-general of the National Security Council (NSC), returned to Taipei early Saturday to quell speculation about his abrupt departure for the United States Wednesday night.
The NSC issued a news release saying that Liu reported to duty and met with NSC Secretary-General Yin Tsung-wen shortly after his return.
Liu, a younger brother of indebted Legislator Liu Ping-wei, left for Los Angeles after his brother's financial woes were reported.

Liu said he was originally scheduled to return to work on Monday. "As my leave has caused concern and unnecessary speculation, I decided to return to work in advance to silence speculation," he explained.

Liu, a former lawmaker, said he didn't meet with his debt-ridden elder brother during his brief stay in Los Angeles. Nevertheless, Liu said he believes his brother will be able to resolve his financial difficulties after his current effort to seek funds in the US.
Liu said he is sorry for all the disturbances and panic selling in the Taiwan Stock Exchange triggered by his brother's check defaults in the past few days.
Liu said his elderly father, infuriated by his brother's improper financial management, has suffered a relapse of his heart problems and is now receiving medical treatment in Los Angeles.

Liu Ping-wei, a former speaker of the now-abolished Taiwan Provincial Assembly, has bounced checks totaling more than NT$120 million over the past three days and has some NT$1.7 billion worth of checks due in the next couple of days. He left the island on Wednesday night with a one-way ticket to Los Angeles.
On appearing at the Los Angeles' Tom Bradley International Airport on Thursday, Liu claimed that he was there to seek financial assistance from his friends.

"I came here to see several friends, hoping they will be able to help me survive the financial crisis," Liu explained. "Just allow me five days to find the money and I'll be back home to face all the problems."

Liu, whose family runs the lucrative Panchiao-based Hai Shan Group in Taipei County, admitted on Thursday that he was responsible for the entire crisis himself, stressing that his family's other businesses remain unaffected by the crisis.
Share prices for Advancetek Enterprise, the only Liu family business to be listed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange, have plunged dramatically in recent days.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS BLAST KMT FOR ALLEGED STOCK SPECULATION

TEXT.P: Three lawmakers from the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party on Saturday accused the ruling Kuomintang as the culprit for the unhealthy development of the Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex).

The lawmakers -- Chen Sheng-hung, Chen Chung-hsin and Lin Feng-hsi -- said the KMT's Business Management Commission has long been deeply involved local stock trading through the seven investment holding companies under its jurisdiction.
"The commission's complicated political and commercial connections have sown seeds of political and economic crises in Taiwan," the lawmakers said in a joint press release.

The press statement said KMT-owned enterprises raked in more than NT$12.5 billion in profits last year. "The amount was five times the party's business earnings recorded five years ago. We believe that KMT businesses have used their political clout for windfall bonanza and that many of recent corporate financial crises were related to KMT's business operations," the statement claimed.

The three lawmakers demanded that all KMT businesses publicize their financial reports and their stock trading records in recent days in line with the Ministry of Finance's requirement of all listed companies to keep their financial status transparent.
They voiced strong opposition to KMT enterprises' involvement in the local stock market, saying such operations would only destroy normal market mechanism.
The lawmakers also opposed the involvement of special government funds in the stock trading because such activities violate fair market rules.

Moreover, the lawmakers said the Finance Ministry should not suspend the stock transaction tax under pressure from KMT-affiliated business heavyweights. "What the ministry should do is to work out a comprehensive package of measures to promote structural market and taxation reforms to ensure healthy development of local capital markets and maintain domestic financial stability," the statement added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 300 TEXTILE WORKERS PROTEST IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Some 300 textile workers staged a demonstration Saturday in Wuhan, capital of Hubei Province, because they have not received any payment since last October from their former employer.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said the protesters are among the 2,700 textile workers who were laid off after Yongsheng Cotton Textile Company, a state-run textile factory in the city, was purchased by the Shengsheng Group of the city in 1996.

The information center said that the number of workers laid off by state-run enterprises will increase to 2.7 million next year from 1.6 million this year, and that jobless workers and corruptive officials are sources of crimes and instability in mainland Chinese society. Urban unemployment is expected to exceed 15 percent next year, it added.

DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:

Troubled lawmaker Liu Ping-hua met with creditors to reschedule loans.

Official, HK tycoon were sentenced over land scam.

Jordan crown prince was sworn in as regent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Jan. 7, or the 22nd day of the 12th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1792: Austria and Prussia sign a military pact against France.
1812: Charles Dickens, the great English novelist who wrote a number of well-loved classics like "Oliver Twist" and "David Copperfield," is born.
1886: George Walker, an English carpenter, strikes gold in the Transvaal in South Africa while building a cottage for a prospector.
1948: Liaoning Province falls into the hands of Chinese communist troops.
1955: ROC government troops begin to evacuate the Tachen Islands.
1968: The ROC's Ministry of Education agrees on the establishment of National Central University in Chungli, Taoyuan Hsien (County).
1971: Switzerland allows women to vote in elections.
1973: Former Kaohsiung City Mayor Yang Chin-hu and his wife are arrested for suspected involvement in a bribery case during his term of office.
1985: The Executive Yuan approves the project to make Yushan a National Park.
1986: Both Ferdinand E. Marcos and his chief election opponent Corazon Aquino claim victory in a presidential election. The National Assembly ruled that Marcos won the election.
1990: The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party votes for a package of reforms that will end its monopoly of power.
1996: A Boeing 757 from Dominican Republic to Frankfurt crashes into the Atlantic Ocean, killing all 189 aboard.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Perfectly honest men I do not expect to see; I could only meet with scrupulous men I would be satisfied. But in a state of society in which men must pretend to possess what they really do not possess; pretend to have plenty, when they have really nothing; and pretend to be in affluence when they are in actual want -- in such a state of society, it is difficult to be even a scrupulous man."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE LEAVES HOSPITAL AFTER FULL RECOVERY FROM INFLUENZA

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui left National Taiwan University Hospital Sunday morning after fully recovering from influenza.
"I am all well," Lee said with a smile to a group of well wishers in the hospital's hallway.

Noting that Lee had a normal temperature of 36 degrees Celsius and a normal white blood cell count as well, the president's personal physician, Lien Wen-ping, confirmed that Lee has fully recovered from the influenza for which he was admitted to the hospital four days ago.

Dr. Lien said he suggested to Lee that he remain in the hospital for two more days, but Lee told him that he preferred to recuperate at home, saying that a hospital is a place for treatment rather than for rest.
An official at the Presidential Office said that Lee will return to work on Monday, when he is expected to meet with visiting Marshall Islands President Image Kabua.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN 4TH-LARGEST BUYER OF US ARMS IN 1998
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 6 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: In fiscal 1998 the United States was contracted to sell US$441 million worth of arms to Taiwan, according to a report soon to be sent to the US Congress by the US Department of Defense.
Taiwan was the fourth-largest buyer of US military equipment and services, behind Saudi Arabia, Israel and Greece.

The US Department of Defense said that as of year ending Sept. 30, 1998, the United States had delivered a total of US$1.5 billion worth of arms and equipment to Taiwan, mainly F-16 fighters, which the United States agreed to sell to Taiwan during the Bush administration.

Major items the United States agreed to sell to Taiwan in fiscal 1998 included 61 Stinger missile systems worth US$180 million, 131 MK46 torpedoes worth US$69 million and 58 Harpoon anti-ship missiles worth US$101 million. The package sale, with a combined value of US$350 million, was announced last Aug. 28.

After the Pentagon announced the sale, however, Taiwan decided to reduce the number of Stinger missile systems it would purchase. The United States suggested last year that after Taiwan acquires such sophisticated weaponry as Mirage-2000 and F-16 fighters, it should focus on integrating software rather than acquiring more hardware.

According to the Pentagon, the United States agreed in fiscal 1998 to sell US$2.2 billion worth of arms to Saudi Arabia, US628 million to Israel, US$531 million to Greece, US$441 million to Taiwan and US$348 million to Japan.

The five countries to which the most US arms were actually delivered in fiscal 1998 were Saudi Arabia, which received US$3.9 billion worth; Israel, US$1.6 billion; Taiwan, US$1.5 billion; South Korea, US$956 million; and Egypt, US$585 million.

According to the report to the US Congress by the US Department of Defense, the United States agreed to sell US$354 million worth of arms to Taiwan in 1997, while the actual value of arms delivered that year was US$261 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WARNS AGAINST SPREADING RUMORS AIMED AT BRINGING DOWN BOURSE

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew vowed on Sunday to track down people who are spreading rumors aimed at bringing down stock prices on the local bourse, said government spokesman Chen Chien-jen.
Siew presided on Sunday over a preliminary meeting of Taiwan finance and economics officials that comes before a full-scale economic conference, to be held Friday.

Chen, who briefed reporters after the meeting, said that Siew reiterated the government's determination to maintain order in the financial market and to root out rumormongers who are spreading false information in hopes of causing panic selling.

A task force set up under the Ministry of Justice has been asked by Siew to step up their efforts to stop the spread of rumors by picking up those who circulate them. Many of the rumors being spread involve well known tycoons or business groups, said Chen.
Taiwan's bourse never fully recovered from last year's regional financial storm and has seen further declines recently because of a series of high-profile business failures.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange's benchmark weighted stock index surged more than 235 points on Saturday after sinking to a 13-year low on Friday. The decline came despite government moves to shore up the market.

Siew was quoted as saying at Sunday's meeting that as much as the government would like to reinvigorate the sagging economy, it will never try to bail out businesses that went under because of imprudent, high-leverage investments or ventures financed largely through loans rather than by capital raised through selling shares.

Siew in his remarks was referring to Advancetek Co., owned by business tycoon and newly elected Legislator Liu Ping-wei. Advancetek tumbled after Liu bounced checks worth more than a hundred million dollars and flew to the United States on Feb. 3.

Friday's conference will be attended by President Lee Teng-hui, as well as by 50 to 60 business leaders and about 20 lawmakers and will be aimed at generating ideas on how to lift Taiwan out of its current economic doldrums.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOHN CHANG SAYS TAIWAN NOT USING "DEMOCRACY CARD" TO DELAY REUNIFICATION
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 6 (CNA) (By Bear Lee and Huang Kuan-chun)

TEXT.P: A top official from Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang on Saturday rejected allegations by mainland China that Taiwan is "playing its democracy card" to postpone China's unification.

"It's ridiculous to say that the Republic of China is playing the democracy card," said KMT Secretary-General John Chang at a dinner party held in his honor by Teng Shen-sheng, director of Taiwan's representative office in New York.

Recounting the commitment of various ROC leaders to democracy, Chang said that the late President Chiang Kai-shek urged the building of Taiwan as "a model province of China featuring the 'Three Principles of the People' initiated by Dr. Sun yet-sen, while the late President Chiang Ching-kuo called for the unification of China under the Three Principles.

Meanwhile, he added, incumbent President Lee Teng-hui has set forth Taiwan's "Guidelines for National Unification," which calls for a united China under freedom, democracy, and an equal distribution of wealth.
He said that ROC leaders have been consistently pursuing a free and democratic system in Taiwan with the hope of "having a positive influence" on the mainland.

Chang said that nothing concrete could be achieved through negotiations between Taiwan and the mainland if both sides cannot stand on an equal footing and if the differences between them cannot be solved.

"China cannot be unified with two totally different systems on both sides. It's impossible to ask Taiwan to back off from its democratization process, or even to implement communism to accommodate itself to the mainland's system," he added.
Chang was in New York as head of a Taiwan delegation to last Thursday's prayer breakfast meeting at the White House.

In an earlier meeting with leaders of New York's Chinese community, Chang said that the ROC government is determined to safeguard its existence and its people's interests, and it will continue to stand firmly against Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, MACEDONIAN LEADERS TO EXCHANGE VISITS

TEXT.P: Despite the difference of opinion within Macedonia regarding its establishment of official relations with the Republic of China, Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georievski is expected to visit Taipei in May, said ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu.
Hu was referring to the opposition of Macedonian President Kiro Gligorov to relations between Skopje and Taipei.

After the trip to Taipei by Macedonia's prime minister, ROC Premier Vincent Siew will lead a delegation to visit the Balkan country, Hu told reporters after paying a visit to the Taichung City headquarters of the Kuomintang.
Hu and Macedonian Foreign Minister Aleksandar Dimitrov signed a communique in Taipei on Jan. 27, forging diplomatic relations between the two nations.

A group of 30 Macedonian journalists is scheduled to arrive in Taipei to see for themselves Taiwan's development, Hu said. After the Chinese lunar new year, Hu will head a delegation of Taiwan reporters in a visit to Macedonia, Taiwan's 28th diplomatic ally, he said.
Moreover, a delegation of ROC trade and economics officials will tour Skopje in March or April to seek trade and investment opportunities there, he said.
In the afternoon, Hu also visited business groups in central Taiwan to encourage local enterprises to invest in Macedonia.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN'S ELECTION AS PRESIDENT SAID BENEFICIAL TO TAIWAN DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Of all the prospective candidates in Taiwan's next presidential election in 2000, current Vice President Lien Chan is the one best able to deal with the crucial issues that will affect the future of the Republic of China, according to survey results released on Sunday.
The survey was conducted by Shih Hsin University, which asked political opinion leaders, namely legislators and National Assembly deputies, about their views on the presidential election in 2000.

In the survey 63.8 percent of respondents said cross-strait relations will be the main issue affecting the future development of the Republic of China, while 20.7 percent said the economy will be the main issue and 5.4 percent said it would be the island's political environment.

Respondents were asked to assess the ability of various people to deal with these issues. Lien was thought to be capable of improving cross-strait relations by 47.4 percent of respondents. Moreover, 54.4 percent said Lien would be able to improve the island's economy and 38.9 percent said he could ensure Taiwan's political environment remains stable.
Lien's ratings on all three fronts were far higher than those of other prospective presidential candidates.

Some 91.9 percent of those surveyed said that they believe the ruling Kuomintang would nominate Lien as its presidential candidate, while 82.8 percent said they believe the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will nominate as its candidate former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian.

Fifty-three percent of respondents said Lien is the most suitable presidential candidate for the KMT, while 23.5 percent selected former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong as the party's best choice. Meanwhile, 60.2 percent of respondents said Chen is the best choice for the DPP, while former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang was chosen by 17.5 percent.
Some 15.4 percent of respondents said that if Soong is not nominated by the KMT, he will run on his own.

As for his personal attributes, Lien was noted for his stable personality (36.9 percent), vision (35.4 percent), and tolerance (30.3 percent). But he was said to lack amicability (46.7 percent), not favored by the media (30.9 percent), and to lack charisma (26.4 percent).

Chen's merits include his resolution in solving problems (58.7 percent), his charisma (35.1 percent) and the fact that he is well liked by the media (29.7 percent). He was faulted, however, for being narrow minded (34.4 percent), arbitrary in his practices (29.4 percent), and mean (27.6 percent).

Soong was lauded for his amicability (45.8 percent), his charisma (34.2 percent), and for being well liked by the media (27.9 percent). But he was said to be unstable (38.1 percent), narrow minded (23.7 percent), and arbitrary (22.8 percent).
The survey was conducted between Jan. 8 and Feb. 3 and administered to 537 people. Of that number, 332 provided valid responses.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISSIDENT SUN WEIBANG RELEASED AFTER 10 YEARS IN PRISON

TEXT.P: Sun Weibang, a mainland Chinese dissident who was sentenced to 12 years in prison for giving free food to student demonstrators in Qingdao, Shandong province, during the 1989 Tiananmen incident, was released on Feb. 4.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said Sunday that Sun was released two years early because of his good record in meeting his production quota, not because of any political reason.

Sun, 47, lost his family because of his long imprisonment. In his seventh year in prison, his wife divorced him and brought her little daughter back to her parents' home in Guangxi province, the information center said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VFA AGREEMENT WILL NOT HELP PHILIPPINES IN SPRATLY ROW

TEXT.P: Contrary to claims by Philippine President Joseph Ejercito Estrada, the Visiting Forces Agreement (VFA) is practically useless in the territorial conflict in the Spratly Islands, since the United States does not recognize the disputed area as part of the country's territory.
This surfaced in Friday's Senate hearing on the VFA. The Philippine Senate is considered a bastion of support for the controversial agreement.

Foreign Affairs Secretary Domingo Siazon said while being questioned during the day's hearing that the Philippines cannot count on US assistance in resolving the dispute over the islands since the area is not listed in the VFA as Philippine territory.
Noting that the conflict involving the islands does not fall under the provisions of the VFA, Siazon said, "The US will not go to war just because of the presence of armada of warships in the reef."
An earlier defense agreement, signed in 1951, also fails to identify the Spratlys as Philippine territory. The country did not lay claim to the supposedly oil-rich island chain until 1973.

Estrada has previously argued that the VFA would provide an effective deterrent against foreign invasion, particularly against mainland China's recent intrusions into Mischief Reef, an area within the Spratly Islands.

DOC.HEADLINE: LI RE-ELECTED AS CYC PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: China Youth Corp. (CYC) President Jeanne Tchong-koei Li was unanimously re-elected on Sunday.

After the vote Li said that she felt honored and that she had been given a great responsibility, adding that the selfless devotion of her colleagues and volunteer partners has been the main reason she has stayed on the job.

She also announced, however, that she would step down as president in one year. Li, who has been CYC president since 1987, said that her stepping down would help the CYC to meet the challenges it will face in the next millennium.
She said she hopes the CYC can compete fairly with other civic groups and get its due support and assistance.
Until she steps down as president, Li will work with all CYC members to transform the organization into a civil group that serves Taiwan's youth, she said.

At a CYC member congress on Jan. 31 it was decided to lengthen the terms of the organization's convenor and its president from two years to three. Members were concerned that frequent personnel changes could have a detrimental effect on the organization.
Fifteen of CYC supervisory board's 17 members held a meeting Sunday to vote for the organization's convenor. Former Education Minister Chu Fei-shen garnered eight votes to win the post.
Chu then nominated Li for the post of CYC president, and her nomination was passed unanimously.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARINE TYCOON'S PRIVATE CRUISER DEBUTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan marine tycoon Chang Jung-fa boarded his new private cruiser, a 2,621-ton ship berthed off Keelung, northern Taiwan, over the weekend.
Chang, head of Evergreen Group, quietly boarded the ship, Evergreen, on Saturday with several guests without fanfare. Reporters were asked to keep a distance from the ship.
But it is understood that the luxurious cruiser -- 92 meters long, 13 meters wide and is four stories high -- has an interior design that combines traditional and western styles.
The ship's living quarters contain furniture made of cypress and ornate room dividers. The boat also contains Western-style clubrooms and ballrooms, as well as a karaoke room and a cafe.
Construction on the ship, which costs 8 billion Japanese yen (US$72 million) began in Japan in August 1995. It will stay in Keelung Harbor for six days before leaving for Japan, Guam and Singapore.
It is understood that Chang will use the ship to entertain local businessmen as well as political figures.
The ship has a crew of around 17, of which the captain and senior officers are from Taiwan, while the rest of the crew are from Singapore and Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Monday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The Ministry of Finance (MOF) announced three emergency measures to prop up sagging stock market.

The MOF unveiled three price support measures to revitalize the battered stock market.

Abdullah was sworn in as king of Jordan.
The China News:

DOC.HEADLINE: MACEDONIAN INFORMATION MINISTER ON VISIT

TEXT.P: Macedonian Information Minister Rezxep Zllatku, at the head of a 30-member delegation of journalists, arrived in Taipei Sunday evening for a six-day visit.

The Macedonian media group, the first of its kind ever to visit Taiwan, will see for themselves the Republic of China on Taiwan, with which the Balkan state forged formal diplomatic relations on Jan. 27, said Zllatku.

The visit will greatly help the Macedonian people to understand the Republic of China, Zllatku said upon arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport. He and the Macedonian media delegation were met at the airport by ROC government spokesman Chen Chien-jen and Vice Foreign Minister David Lee.
Zllatku said it is hoped that a reciprocal visit to Macedonia by a delegation of ROC journalists will take place soon, so that mutual understanding between the two countries can be enhanced.

During their stay, Zllatku and his group will call on government officials and visit Taiwan's Science-based Industrial Park in Hsinchu. The group will also visit Taiwan's flagship export processing zones and other economic and cultural establishments.
ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu and his Macedonian counterpart Aleksandar Dimitrov signed a communique in Taipei on Jan. 27 forging diplomatic relations between the two countries.
Along with a delegation of Taiwan journalists, Hu is scheduled to head to Macedonia on Feb. 23 for an official visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION IN WASHINGTON TO STUDY FAMILY VIOLENCE PREVENTION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 7 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: A 43-member Republic of China family violence prevention study group arrived in Washington on Sunday for a three-day visit to study family violence prevention practices used in the United States.

The group, led by Pan Wei-kang, an ROC legislator and chairman of the ROC Modern Women's Foundation, will call on family violence prevention specialists under the US Justice Department, and several private groups during the visit.

The ROC Legislative Yuan adopted the Family Violence Prevention Law on May 28, 1998, making Taiwan one of several Asian nations that actively seeks to prevent family violence and to assist victims of family violence.
Members of the delegation said they hope that their visit to the United States will help to ensure Taiwan's Family Violence Prevention Law is properly enforced.
