DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Jan. 8, or the 22nd day of the 12th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Spanish explorer Capt. Francisco Hernandez de Cordoba sets sail from Cuba to discover Mexico.
1587: Mary Queen of Scots, who had been found guilty of plotting to assassinate England's Queen Elizabeth I, is beheaded.
1725: Peter the Great of Russia dies. He was succeeded by his wife Catherine.
1902: The eruption of a volcano on French Martinique Island in the Lesser Antilles kills more than 26,000 people.
1904: Japanese warships launch a surprise night attack against Lushun (Port Arthur) in northern China, destroying three Russian warships and fusing the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War.
1906: A strong typhoon hits Tahiti in the South Pacific, killing about 10,000 people.
1910: The Boy Scouts of America organization, a cousin to the movement founded by Sir Robert Baden-Powell in Britain two years earlier, is inaugurated.
1924: The gas chamber as a method of execution is used for the first time in Carson City, Nevada, on Gee Jon, a Chinese gang member.
1926: American archaeologists discover relics from the Mayan civilization in the jungles of the Yucatan Peninsula near the coast of the Caribbean Sea.
1931: More than 3,000 miners are killed in an accident at the Fushun mine run by a Japanese company of the Southern Manchuria Railway in Liaoning province, northeastern China.
1931: James Dean, the American film actor and cult hero who died young in a road accident, is born.
1946: A provisional people's council is set up in North Korea, which is still under Soviet occupation, with Kim Il Sung serving as chairman.
1949: The National Central Library moves to Taiwan from the Chinese mainland.
1954: More than 14,000 Chinese communist prisoners of war in Korea who refuse to return to the Chinese mainland begin to undergo job training in Tahu, Siahu and Yangmei in Taiwan.
1962: The US military council is set up in South Vietnam.
1964: Princess Irene of Holland renounces her right to the throne to marry Spanish Prince Carlos Hugo of Bourbon-Parma.
1965: British Health Minister Kenneth Robinson announces that cigarette ads will be banned from television.
1984: Athletes from the Republic of China re-enter the Olympic Games by taking part in the 1984 Winter Olympic Games in Yugoslavia under the name "Chinese Taipei."
1995: An earthquake rocks Colombia, claiming more than 38 lives and injuring more than 230 people.
1995: The US liaison office in Vietnam begins business operation, marking the first step in the return to normal relations between the United States and Vietnam.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are, perhaps, men who propound theories they themselves do not understand. That is a thing I never do. I read and learn everything and, choosing that which is excellent, I adopt it; I see everything and take note of what I see: that is, perhaps, next to having a great understanding."

DOC.HEADLINE: CREDIT CARD CHARGES IN TAIWAN LAST YEAR BROKE NT$400 BILLION MARK

TEXT.P: Taiwan credit card holders charged a record amount of goods and services in 1998, which suggests they were unaffected by the regional economic slowdown in Asia, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported on Monday.
Charges by credit card holders for the first 11 months of 1998 totaled NT$439.26 billion (US$13.64 billion), the highest level ever seen in Taiwan since the introduction of credit cards in 1989.
Credit card charges in Taiwan totaled NT$64.84 billion (US$2 billion) in 1992, NT$94.99 billion (US$2.95 billion) in 1993 and NT$100 billion (US$3.1 billion) in 1994, according to MOF tallies.
Charges nearly doubled in 1995 to NT$190.68 billion (US$5.92 billion), while totals for 1996 and 1997 were NT$272.4 billion (US$8.45 billion) and NT$374.42 billion (US$11.6 billion), respectively.

Cash advances via credit cards have also posted remarkable growth over the last three years, MOF statistics showed. Credit card holders borrowed NT$14.7 billion (US$456.52 million) in cash in 1996, NT$25.74 billion (US$799.37 million) in 1997 and NT$35.55 billion (US$1.1 billion) in the first 11 months of 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACEDONIAN INFORMATION MINISTER REAFFIRMS TIES WITH ROC

TEXT.P: Visiting Macedonian Information Minister Rezxep Zllatku reaffirmed on Monday that his country will not change its decision to forge full diplomatic ties with the Republic of China on Taiwan.

Zllatku, who headed a 30-member press delegation to Taipei on Sunday for a six-day visit, made the statement after meeting with Chen Chien-jen, director-general of the Government Information Office (GIO).
This is Zllatku's first visit to Taiwan since the two countries established formal diplomatic relations on Jan. 27.
Zllatku told local reporters that the establishment of official ROC-Macedonian links is an unexpected joyful event for Macedonian people.
"Even though some different views were heard in Macedonia, the majority of our people are happy with forging diplomatic ties with the ROC," Zllatku said.

He stressed that some Macedonian people's opposition to the new ties has nothing to do with the ROC. "The opposition was basically a partisan strife," Zllatku said, adding that such domestic political wrangling will not affect future development of ROC-Macedonian relationship.

Asked about mainland China's intention to use its clout in the United Nations Security Council to veto a proposed extension of the mandate for the UN Preventive Deployment (UNPREDEP) force in Macedonia, Zllatku said he does not think that a big power like mainland China would really block the deployment of UN peacekeeping force in his country to retaliate against the establishment of ROC-Macedonian ties.

Noting that maintaining world peace is the UN's main function, Zllatku said the UNPREDEP force has contributed much to safeguarding stability in the Balkan Peninsula and that many big powers, including the United States, support the extension of the UN mandate.
Speaking on the same occasion, GIO Director-General Chen refuted an allegation that the ROC has offered economic aid to "bribe" Macedonia to forge ties with it.

Chen said the ROC itself received financial aid from the United States in the 1950s and 1960s. "We have never regarded such aid as a bribe. It's a mutually beneficial assistance. We believe that such a formula can be applied to our ties with Macedonia," Chen added.
During their stay, Zllatku and his group will call on government officials and visit the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park as well as other economic and cultural institutions.
Chen said he is convinced that the Macedonian media delegation's visit will help boost Macedonian people's understanding of Taiwan's latest developments in various fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCTOGENARIAN TYCOON EXPECTING TO RETURN TO HK AFTER PAYING BAIL

TEXT.P: Hong Kong business tycoon Lim Por-yen on Monday visited the Taipei District Court, where he paid NT$30 million (US$931,670) in bail in exchange for the lifting of a ban preventing his departure from Taiwan.

Lim, 88, was arrested in Taipei in December 1997 on charges of bribery. He was released on a bail of NT$10 million (US$310,550) on Jan. 19, 1998 after being detained for 34 days. Since his release, however, he has been prohibited from leaving Taiwan.
Monday's additional bail payment, however, has cleared the way for his departure.
Lim, chairman of the Hong Kong-based Lai Sun Group and a major shareholder of Hong Kong's Asia Television, said he will leave Taiwan for home on Wednesday or Thursday.

The Taipei District Court convicted Lim on Feb. 6 of offering US$4.14 million to Taipei County government officials to ensure he would be compensated to the tune of nearly NT$900 million for land he owned that was to be used as the site for a new university, National Taipei University.
Located in Sanhsia in Taipei County, the plot of land was the site of Lim's Dollar Textile Manufacturing Co., which went out of business several years ago.
On Feb. 6 he received a jail term of three years and two months, although the court agreed to lift his travel ban for the sum of NT$30 million.
Lim's lawyer, however, said Lim will file an appeal with the Taiwan High Court because the sentence is too harsh.
After learning of the court's decision, Lim promised to come back to Taiwan whenever summoned by the court, provided he is allowed to return to Hong Kong soon.

Chuang Yu-kun, a former director of the Taipei County Land Administration Bureau, was sentenced to 20 years in jail plus an eight-year suspension of his civil rights for his role in the scandal. Chuang was convicted of illegally authorizing the rezoning of the land on which Lim's textile plant was located.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO DISPATCH DELEGATION TO MOURN KING HUSSEIN'S DEATH

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Monday extended its condolences over the death of Jordan's King Hussein and announced plans to dispatch a special delegation in the next few days to Amman to mourn the king's passing.

MOFA noted in a written statement that King Hussein had ruled Jordan for 46 years. While in power, King Hussein not only dedicated himself to the development of Jordan's economy, but also strived for peace in the Middle East. He also won the love of the Jordanian people, the statement said.
With his death, not only does Jordan lose an intelligent leader, but the international community loses a peace-loving friend, the statement said.

King Hussein visited the Republic of China in 1959. Throughout his life, King Hussein was friendly toward the Republic of China, and the two nations have enjoyed a strong relationship, the statement said, adding that the ROC government is deeply saddened by the king's death.
King Hussein conferred his eldest son Abdullah with the title of crown price on Jan. 24. Abdullah was crowned king Sunday after the death of his father.

The Western-educated Abdullah has visited the Republic of China three times and is very friendly toward the Republic of China. He also values the establishment of cooperative relations with the Republic of China.

The Republic of China believes that the two countries will maintain substantial relations after Abdullah establishes himself in his father's place and hopes bilateral ties will be further strengthened, the statement said.
King Hussein died of heart failure Sunday afternoon, Taiwan time.

DOC.HEADLINE: TASK FORCE SET UP TO CLEAN UP INDUSTRIAL WASTE

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) will establish a task force to treat mercury-laced waste recently discovered in southern Taiwan, the administration's director Tsai Hsung-hsiung said on Monday.
The ad hoc group, composed of officials from relevant agencies under the EPA, will be headed by EPA Deputy Administrator Lin Ta-hsiung.

Tsai also ordered local environmental protection authorities in the Kaohsiung and Pingtung areas to join forces with the cabinet-level task force to immediately begin with the cleaning mission. The special group will also be in charge of carrying out damage-control countermeasures after locating the whereabouts of industrial waste.

Tsai expressed grave concern over the illegal dumping of mercury-tainted industrial waste recently found in the water resources of conservation areas in the southern region. Condemning such immoral acts, the EPA head attributed the deplorable situation to relevant authorities' lax control and inspections in the past.

To prevent the situation from deteriorating and becoming a public threat, Tsai said the ad hoc group will announce the results of its investigation as soon as possible to give people a first-hand understanding of the facts, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC SIGNS US$83 MILLION CONTRACT WITH DSS ON ROCSAT-2

TEXT.P: The National Science Council (NSC) on Monday signed a contract with the German-based Dornier Satelliten Systeme GmbH (DSS) to build a satellite bus and remote sensing payload for ROCSAT-2.

ROCSAT-2 is scheduled to be launched in 2002, becoming the first Taiwan-owned satellite with practical functions such as helping agricultural planning and land use. ROCSAT-1, which was launched successfully at Cape Canaveral, Florida in January, is mainly used for scientific research.

The signing ceremony took place at the NSC offices in Taipei. Representing their respective sides, NSC Chairman Hwang Jenn-tai and Vice Chairman Tsai Ching-yen along with DSS Executive Vice President Hubeert Hofmann and head of Contract Department Gerhard Lotz signed the agreement.
Witnessing the event were Hsu Chia-ming, director of NSC's National Space Program Office, its deputy director Wang Hung-chi, as well as DSS director of the ROCSAT-2 program Bernhard Doll.

The DSS won the bid at price of US$83 million to build the satellite bus and remote sensing payload in January. The entire ROCSAT-2 project has a price tag of around NT$4 billion (US$123 million) which also includes the ground control station and launch vehicle.
Hofmann said DSS will do everything possible to ensure the project proceeds smoothly. He expressed the hope that during the process of cooperation, each side will meet the needs of the other.

ROCSAT-2 was approved as a low-orbit remote sensing satellite by the Executive Yuan in October 1997. The NSC National Space Program Office then formed a task force and completed its needs analysis, its definition of the mission and its system design.
Bilateral cooperation will formally start March 1, and its research and manufacturing is expected to be completed by September 2001, and will then undergo tests by the Space Program Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TWO-WAY TRADE WITH ASIA SOAR REMARKABLY IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two-way trade with Asian countries soared in January leading to regained momentum in overall foreign trade during the month, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported on Monday.

Taiwan's exports to Asia in January made up 46.5 percent of the island's overall exports last month, marking a six-month high since last June. Meanwhile, imports from Asia constituted 52.9 percent of the island's overall imports, a new high since 1994, according to MOF statistics.
The country's foreign trade is expected to resume steady growth this year if there are no major setbacks affecting trade in months to come, MOF officials said.
Battered by the Asian economic crisis, Taiwan's exports plunged 9.4 percent in 1998 from the year-earlier level, while the imports fell 8.5 percent.

It is hoped that Taiwan's foreign trade will regain its momentum in the second half of 1999 on the grounds that the international and regional economic slowdowns are bottoming out, while domestic investment and consumption from the private sector are expected to turn brisk later this year, MOF officials said.

Taiwan exported US$9.81 billion worth of goods and services in January this year, up 28.8 percent over the year-earlier level, while imported US$9.29 billion worth of commodities, up 24.1 percent, MOF tallies showed.
As a result, Taiwan posted a surplus of US$520 million in January, up 292 percent or US$390 million from the same month of the previous year.
The MOF attributed the marked growth in January mainly to a lower basis of comparison from January 1998 which posted a low in two-way trade due to the Chinese Lunar New Year holidays.

In January, Taiwan's exports to members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations rose 21 percent from the year-earlier level, while imports from Europe jumped 25 percent. Taiwan's surplus with the United States and Hong Kong, meanwhile, increased US$610 million and US$570 million respectively in the month, MOF officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 8 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: This is to replace CEP item 7, with added information. MACEDONIAN INFORMATION MINISTER REAFFIRMS TIES WITH ROC

Meanwhile, Vice Foreign Minister David Lee said in a radio program on Monday that the ROC government is determined to make the newly forged ROC-Macedonian relationship a showcase of mutually beneficial cooperation in southern Europe.

"We'll join forces with Macedonia to make our new ties a successful model for bilateral cooperation with a view to attracting other countries in southern Europe to cultivate friendly cooperative ties with us," said Lee.

He divulged that ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu will head a delegation of government officials and business executives to visit Macedonia later this month to shore up bilateral relationship and to inspect market situation and general bsuiness climate there.

"I myself will also lead a group of industry and commerce executives to Macedonia in late March to look into that country's investment climate and regulations as well as to explore trade and investment opportunities," Lee said.

Noting that Macedonia is close to the main European market and has well-developed infrastructure and low-cost labor force, Lee said he believes that Taiwan entrepreneurs will be able to find market niches or profitable investment opportunities there.
Lee went on to say that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs plans to invite Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski to visit Taiwan in the first half of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA EXPRESSES SADNESS OVER KING HUSSEIN'S DEATH

TEXT.P: Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien expressed his "deep sadness" Sunday over the news of the death of King Hussein of Jordan. He has sent his foreign affairs minister, Lloyd Axworthy, to attend the state funeral in Jordan.

In a statement, Chretien said: "King Hussein was a champion of peace in the Middle East. He was one of the true statesmen of the post-war period, an abiding voice for civility and moderation who made an indispensable contribution to fostering reconciliation. He was beloved and held in the highest esteem by the Jordanian people.

"On behalf of the government and people of Canada, I salute King Hussein and his personal legacy of courageous support for peace and stability in the Middle East. I look forward to the continued commitment of Jordan to the peace process.
The Canadian leader pledged his country's continued friendship to Crown Prince Abdullah as he assumes his father's throne.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEVELOPMENT OF PUDONG PUT ON HOLD TO PROTECT HONG KONG

TEXT.P: Beijing has put on hold the development of Shanghai's industrial area of Pudong as a financial center and regional hub for multinationals to avoid undermining Hong Kong during the current economic recession, The Hong Kong Standard reported Monday.
Beijing, the report said, fears that the further upgrading of Pudong at this stage will put more pressure on the Special Administrative Region during a very difficult period.

"With support from top leaders, including President and Communist Party chief Jiang Zemin and Premier Zhu Rongji, the Shanghai municipal government had been working on a plan to turn Pudong into an attractive area for multinationals to house their regional headquarters," the report quoted sources as saying.
But Beijing has put these plans on hold for fear their aggressive efforts would undermine Hong Kong's status as a regional business hub.

The blueprint for Shanghai's development has drawn on the experiences and policies of Hong Kong, Singapore and Tokyo. Development plans have included a fundamental restructuring of Pudong's legal, economic, financial, banking, foreign exchange, investment and trade sectors to make the city as competitive as the ones on which it is modeled.

If the proposal had been endorsed by Beijing and implemented immediately, it would give Pudong a very special status in the mainland's economy in the next millennium, said sources, pointing out that the district would enjoy more privileges than those granted by Beijing to its five Special Economic Zones in the early 1980s.

Under the development plans, restrictions would be removed on the free movement of capital, goods and personnel for conglomerates based in Pudong. Multinationals would also be allowed to conduct foreign trade and divert their investments to other businesses or mainland cities without formal approval from government agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI WILL NOT PUT RESTRICTIONS ON WANG'S TAIWAN VISIT: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: Taipei will not put any restrictions on the topics to be discussed when mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan comes to the island for a visit, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi said on Monday.
However, he added that political discussions alone will not help the development of cross-strait relations.

Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), agreed to pay a reciprocal visit to Taiwan after meeting in mainland China with his Taiwan counterpart Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, last October.

Wang said he will not be able to make the trip to Taiwan before May despite that he hopes to do so some time this spring. Su said Wang is welcome to visit the island at any time, even in December when the island will be preparing for the 2000 presidential elections. The MAC head said a visit at that time would not disturb the election campaign process.
Su said the MAC, which charters the nation's mainland policy, is open to the timing, agenda and itinerary of the high-level, cross-strait meeting.

ARATS should send vice secretary-general level officials to Taiwan to work out the details of Wang's trip so both sides can avoid any misunderstanding, Su said. He added that the MAC hopes Wang can see as much as possible during his first visit to Taiwan in five decades, including calling on SEF and MAC, but he said he would respect Wang's wishes.

Su stressed that Wang's visit to Taiwan will be significant, indicating that cross-strait relations are back on track after Beijing's intimidation tactics during the last presidential election in 1996.

The MAC chairman expressed the hope that the agenda could cover every field, and not just political issues and the three direct links -- trade, postal, transportation links -- between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. Su noted that discussions on political issues and direct links will not be conducive to the development of cross-strait relations.
Su made the remarks during an interview by a local broadcasting station on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN 4TH-LARGEST US ARMS BUYER IN 1998

TEXT.P: The US Department of Defense signed military equipment contracts to Taiwan valued at $441 million for the fiscal year 1998, according to the current issue of the US Arms Trade News.
Taiwan was the fourth-largest US arms buyer for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, 1998, according to the report.
The Washington-based monthly publication quoted Pentagon documents as saying that the United States agreed to sell arms worth $8.5 billion last year and delivered a total of $13.9 billion in weapons.
It said Taiwan received $1.5 billion in US weaponry last year, most of which resulted from the delivery of F-16 fighters the United States agreed to sell during the Bush administration.

The $8.5 billion in total US arms sales commitments for fiscal year 1998 is the lowest level since before the Berlin Wall fell in 1989. The total for fiscal 1998 represents only one-fourth the value of contracts signed in 1993, according to the report.
The decline in weapon sales can be attributed to several factors, including the global economic downturn and an arms glut in many regions.

Saudi Arabia was the largest US arms customer in 1998 with $2.2 billion in weapons commitments. Israel ranked second with arms purchases valued at $628 million, and Greece ranked third with $531 million.
Saudi Arabia also took delivery of the most military equipment shipped by the United States last year with imports valued at $3.9 billion.
Israel received $1.6 billion in arms for fiscal year 1998 from the United States, while Taiwan ranked third with $1.5 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE OIL FIRMS REDUCE SPENDING ON OIL EXPLORATION

TEXT.P: Major Australian oil companies are reducing their spending on oil exploration by as much as US$650 million this year because oil prices have fallen to 25-year lows.
A report by the Australian Petroleum Association found that development and exploration spending would be cut, while the greatest impact would be felt by onshore activities.
The same report showed that the total expenditures of the 38 oil and gas companies throughout Australia would be around US$1.6 billion this year.
The number of wells to be drilled is expected to come in at the lower end of expectations, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN BEINGS ARE ADDICTED TO LOVE: SCIENTISTS

TEXT.P: Scientists have discovered that love is simply a from of addiction through their experiments involving a genetically engineered mouse, The Australian reported on Monday.
From investigating the chemistry of love, the scientists from the United States said they have genetically engineered a mouse known as "Monogamous" that stays faithful to its mate.
The normally fickle rodent became a more loyal lover after receiving genes from a prairic vole, noted for its fidelity.

This suggests that a lifetime of dedication to one partner may be a matter of having the right brain chemistry, said Thomas Insel, the head of the research team at a US university that performed the experiments.

DOC.HEADLINE: YEAR-END ELECTIONS SAID POSITIVE FOR DOMESTIC POLITICS
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Feb. 7 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's "three-in-one" elections held on Dec. 5, 1998 had a stabilizing effect on the island's political situation and cross-strait relations, a top official from the ruling Kuomintang said here on Sunday.
KMT Secretary-General John Chang made the remarks after arriving in San Francisco from New York.

Chang earlier led a delegation to attend a prayer breakfast meeting at the White House on Thursday. During his stay in New York and Washington D.C., Chang met with US congressmen, scholars from US think tanks, as well as US high-ranking officials including those in charge of East Asian affairs at the State Department.
Through his extensive contact with the US Congress and academics, Chang said the US is very concerned with the development of cross-strait relations.

Chang said he has conveyed his views about the KMT's victory in the year-end elections which he believes will have a positive effect on local politics and the development of cross-strait relations, and added that the US has agreed with such a view.
The KMT secretary-general, who departed for the US on Feb. 1, is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DROPS AGAINST GREENBACK

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan Dollar dropped NT$0.018 against the US dollar in Taipei, closing at NT$32.265.
The New Taiwan dollar opened at NT$32.242 and fluctuated between NT$32.238 and 32.270. Interbank US dollar transactions totaled US$197 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: EMERGENCY MEASURES PROP UP TAIEX INDEX TO ABOVE 5,800

TEXT.P: Three emergency measures aimed at supporting the local stock market have successfully achieved their goal with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, climbing 112.8 to close at 5,822.98 on Monday.
Turnover for the day amounted to NT$74.19 billion, up from the NT$67.53 billion recorded in the previous session.
The Ministry of Finance offered three short-term stock market stimulating measures on Sunday night. The measures are as follows:
-- loosening limitations on cash loans and securities loans.
-- publicizing in time data on financial transactions of listed companies and companies whose shares are traded on the over-the-counter market.
-- cracking down on rumors that adversely affect the market.
The local bourse opened high and maintained an upward trend throughout the day.
The over-the-counter market also closed higher, with the market's index rising 3.25 points to finish at 149.5 on a turnover of NT$3.96 billion.
Taiwan stock index futures closed mixed.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for February rose 68 points to close at 5,835, with 3,574 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for March rose 51 points to close at 5,877, with 2,812 contract transactions, while those for June were up 66 points to 5,921, with 23 contract transactions. September futures rose 93 points to 5,950, with four contract transactions, and December futures moved down 28 points to 5,950, with two contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABORIGINES ASK TAISUGAR TO RETURN LAND

TEXT.P: A group of aborigines from the eastern Taiwan county of Hualien on Monday demanded the state-run Taiwan Sugar Corp. (Taisugar) return to them a large area of land in the county's Fenglin township.
About 50 indigenous people, wearing headbands and carrying posters, demonstrated in front of the Taisugar headquarters in downtown Taipei with their demand.

The aborigines said Taisugar has illegally occupied their land near the Wanli Bridge in Fenglin over the past 50 years. "We demand that Taisugar return the land to us as soon as possible; otherwise, we'll continue our protest," said an aboriginal representative.
Over the past decades, Taisugar has developed the land into a sugarcane farm.

A Taisugar spokesman said the land belonged to Yenshuikang Sugar Co. during the era of Japanese colonial rule. The ROC government assigned the land to Taisugar after it reclaimed control of Taiwan at the end of the Eight-Year War of Resistance Against Japan in 1945, he added.
Over the years, the spokesman said, Taisugar has paid taxes for the land in accordance with government regulations. "We have not illegally occupied any public land or aborigine-owned land."
The spokesman suggested that the aborigines file a petition either with the Ministry of the Interior or local-level governments, asking them to help resolve their housing problems.

The Taisugar executive recalled that the company sold two pieces of land, totaling 25 hectares, in Fenglin to the interior ministry and the Taiwan Provincial Government in 1990 and 1996, respectively. The land lots have since be designated as special land reserved for aborigines.
"We hope those who demonstrated at our company today will switch their petition targets to rightful government agencies, such as the interior ministry or local governments," the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DGBAS REVISES TAIWAN'S 1998 ECONOMIC GROWTH DOWNWARD TO 4.83%

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy in 1998 grew by 4.83 percent, a drop from the government's previous estimate, according to statistics made public by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics (DGBAS) on Monday.
The revised economic growth rate was 0.3 percent lower than government's latest estimate and was the lowest level since 1983, said officials of the DGBAS under the Executive Yuan.
DGBAS officials also predicted that the island's economic growth in 1999 would only reach 4.74 percent.
This is the first official estimate made by a domestic government organization anticipating a worse economic performance this year than in 1998.
The DGBAS's economic growth estimate is also lower than those made by private organizations. It highlights the fact that in the face of the Asian monetary storm, the DGBAS is reacting with prudence.

The goal set by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) is an annual economic growth of 5.5 percent in 1999. Against this backdrop, the DGBAS' estimate hinted that CEPD's goal would not be achieved.

Chen Chien-jen, director general of the Government Information Office (GIO), stressed that amid the effects of the Asian financial turmoil, Taiwan's economic performance has been decent compared with the performance of other Asian neighbors.
Singapore and Japan registered zero and negative 2.7 percent economic growth in 1998 respectively, pointed out the government spokesman.

In view of Taiwan's financial woes, Premier Vincent Siew met with top finance and economic officials on Sunday at the Taipei International Convention Center to prepare for an economic conference this Friday. Conference members will discuss the economic problems Taiwan is facing and ways best to deal with them.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE CHING-HUA ELECTED NEW PARTY PANEL LEADER

TEXT.P: A founding member of the opposition New Party was elected on Monday as the head of the party's National Campaign and Development Committee.

Lee Ching-hua, who garnered 21 of the total 23 votes, expressed appreciation for the support and used the word "responsibility" to describe his feelings after being elected the head of an important New Party committee.
He said the New Party must correct its shortcomings and adjust its policy to begin anew after its humiliating defeat in December's national and local elections.

Stressing that his goal was to transform the New Party into a "tiny but beautiful and vigorous" political party, Lee voiced confidence in rebuilding the party and developing it into a political party for everyone in the general public.

Claiming that the New Party will begin to improve itself by listening carefully to public opinion, Lee revealed that he will seek alliances with other political forces to allow the New Party to exercise greater influence. Taiwan's current corrupt political climate has effectively buttressed the importance of the New Party's existence, he added.

Lee also emphasized that the New Party will strengthen its contact with women and youths to consolidate its power base. He added that he will try to forge a consensus within the party on issues of major national concern such as constitutional reforms.
Turing to the candidate for the post of the New Party secretary-general, Lee admitted that he has not made a final decision but that he will do so on March 1 when he takes over the committee post.

DOC.HEADLINE: 9 MAINLAND HIJACKERS SENT TO KINMEN FOR REPATRIATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan sent nine convicted mainland Chinese hijackers to an island fortress near the southeastern mainland coast on Monday in preparation for repatriating them via ship on Tuesday.
The nine hijackers, who were on parole after serving jail terms in Taiwan, were sent to Kinmen by a chartered plane amid tight security.
They will be repatriated from Kinmen via a ship to be dispatched by mainland China's Red Cross Society from its southeastern port city of Xiamen on Tuesday morning.

Political observers said the repatriation is a goodwill gesture to Beijing in the run-up to a planned visit to Taipei by mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Wang Daohan, later this year. Wang's visit will be a reciprocal event to his Taiwan counterpart Koo Chen-fu's ice-breaking visit to the mainland last October.

Jan Jyh-horng, deputy secretary-general of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and a number of police officers from the Criminal Investigation Bureau, escorted the nine paroled mainland hijackers to Kinmen.

The nine were Liu Baocai, Shi Yuebo, Yang Mingde, Wang Zhihua, Luo Changhua, Wang Yuing, Zou Weiqiang, Li Xiangyu and Lin Wenqiang. Worrying about their fates after their return to the mainland, the nine hijacking convicts looked grim and kept mum throughout their flight from Taipei to Kinmen.
Yang even refused to leave his seat after the plane arrived at the Kinmen airport, and had to be removed under police guard.

A mainland Chinese Red Cross Society ferry boat is scheduled to arrive in Kinmen on Tuesday morning to take back the nine convicts. Mainland Red Cross Society personnel and SEF officials will exchange relevant documents and complete some formalities before the hijackers' return.

This will be the second time that Taiwan repatriates mainland hijackers by this way. Two of the 17 people involved in hijackings of mainland commercial airliners to Taiwan, most of which occurred between April 1993 and June 1994, were sent back to the mainland via Kinmen in July 1997 following extensive discussion between SEF and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

Due to the lack of a binding agreement on the issue, Beijing declined to inform Taipei of the fate of the hijackers, who stood trial in a mainland court after their return to the mainland. Beijing does not recognize judicial rulings handed down by Taipei.
SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan said he will hand over to mainland Red Cross Society personnel documents detailing the nine hijackers' trials, sentences and time served in Taiwan.
"We hope mainland judicial authorities will respect these hijackers' basic human rights and give them lenient treatment since they have already served prison terms in Taiwan," Jan said.
He again urged ARATS on Saturday to seal a bilateral agreement to regulate the repatriation of cross-strait hijackers and other criminal suspects.
Without a formal agreement, Jan said the repatriation of mainland hijackers can be processed only on a case-by-case basis.
In May 1997, mainland China repatriated Taiwanese hijacker Liu Shan-chung, who forced a domestic flight to the southeastern mainland port city of Xiamen in March 1997.

Meanwhile, two children -- Luo Wanghuan and Yang Yang -- who were brought to Taiwan by their parents in two separate hijackings from the mainland were repatriated by air through Hong Kong on Saturday.

Luo Wanghuan is the son of hijackers Luo Changhua and Wang Yuing, while Yang Yang's parents, also air pirates, are Yang Mingde and Han Fenging. Luo's parents and Yang Yang's father will among the nine hijackers to be repatriated by ship on Tuesday. Yang Yang's mother, Han Fengyin was repatriated in 1997 after serving a jail term here.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY TO SURPASS 1997 LEVEL

TEXT.P: More than one year into the Asian financial crisis, Taiwan's economy is forecast to recover this year to exceed 1997 levels in terms of gross national product (GNP), according to a government prediction released on Monday.

The prediction, made by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), put Taiwan's GNP at US$286.4 billion in 1999, a moderate rise from US$262.3 billion in 1998, and almost the same as the US$284.8 billion recorded for 1997.
That means the regional financial storm has set the island's economy back only one year, said Director-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics Wei Duan.
The figure, calculated on assumptions of an economic growth of 4.74 percent and a consumer price inflation rate of 1.58 percent, will translate into a per capita income of US$13,016.

The statistics also show that although the island's GNP dipped in 1998 as a result of the regional financial turmoil, its economy still grew by 4.83 percent, which is better than the forecast for this year but still worse than expected.

Wei laid the blame for the less-than-expected growth on last year's persistent decline in private investment which, as a percentage of the island's total investment, decreased from 39 percent in the first quarter, to 19.8 percent in the second quarter, 11.7 percent in the third quarter, and 3.8 percent in the fourth quarter.
The credit crunch following the high-profile failure of several well-known companies last year also aggravated the slowdown in economic expansion, said Wei.
The 4.83 percent growth in 1998 ranked the island 15th in global terms, which is three spots behind the 12th place the island enjoyed in the previous year, Wei said.

However, he added, Taiwan should take comfort in the fact that it was much better than its Asian neighbors. The Philippines had only 0.3 percent growth; Singapore had zero growth; Malaysia and South Korea each had negative 6 percent growth; Thailand had negative 7.2 percent growth; and Indonesia's growth was negative 13.5 percent.
If Taiwan reaches its estimated growth of 4.74 percent, it should rise to 13th in the world in 1999, the DGBAS said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OVERSEAS CHINESE AFFAIRS COMMISSION CHIEF VISITS ARGENTINA
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Feb. 7 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Chiao Jen-ho, chairman of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission under the Republic of China's Executive Yuan, arrived in Buenos Aires on Sunday following a two-day visit to Chile.
He was greeted at the airport by some 40 representatives from the Chinese community in Argentina.
Shortly after his arrival, Chiao visited the Free Overseas Chinese Federation, where he presided over a symposium to exchange views with more than 100 overseas Chinese residents on various issues.

Chiao said he was deeply impressed by the intention of Chang Chung-hsi, president of the Free Overseas Chinese Federation, to donate the Chunghua Building in Buenos Aires as the site of a hoped-for overseas Chinese cultural and educational center.
Many issues were discussed at the symposium, and Chiao promised to relay some of the suggestions to the relevant ROC government for reference.
He later visited several shops operated by Taiwan emigrants, and attended a welcome dinner party hosted by the Chinese community.

In a speech at the party, Chiao said his commission will do its utmost to serve overseas Chinese residents. He also conveyed ROC President Lee Teng-hui's greetings to the Chinese residents of Argentina.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP HEAD MEETS SINGAPORE OPPOSITION LEADER
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Feb. 8 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The former chairman of Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Shih Ming-teh, met on Monday met with a leading Singapore opposition leader following the latter's release from jail.
Shih said at a press conference after the meeting in a hotel room that he visited Chee Soon Juan to extend his "concern, encouragement and support" to an old friend.
Chee, secretary-general of the Singapore Democratic Party (SDP), said that he was surprised and honored to meet the renowned Taiwan politician, who himself served time for his political beliefs.

Chee was found guilty of breaking Singapore's public speech law by delivering a speech in public without a permit on December 29. He was fined S$1,400, but refused to pay the fine and chose instead to serve a seven-day jail term.
Shih, who spent 25 years in Taiwan prisons and is now a legislator, said that in meeting Chee, he definitely had no intention of "interfering in or criticizing Singapore's internal affairs."

He praised Singapore for its economic development, sound social welfare and public housing policies, and infrastructure construction, saying that these achievements are greatly admired by the people of Taiwan.
He said that as a former political prisoner, he can fully understand the pain suffered by those who are deprived of the freedom of speech, and therefore cherishes very much the concern of others.
Chee, who will face another court trial on a similar charge on Tuesday, said that Shih's visit gave him moral support in his struggle for human rights and freedom of speech for Singaporeans.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO SEND ECONOMIC MISSION TO MACEDONIA: ECONOMIC MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Monday that an economic mission from Taiwan will leave for Macedonia in the near future to study the investment environment in the European country.

He made the remarks following talks with visiting Macedonian Information Minister Rexhep Zllatku, who arrived in Taipei at the head of a 30-member press delegation on Sunday at the start of a weeklong visit.

Wang said that Zllatku indicated his deep interest in the success story of Taiwan's economic development, and expressed the hope that economic and trade relations between the two countries will be strengthened.
The ROC and Macedonia established diplomatic relations late last month.
Wang said the ROC mission to Macedonia will include officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and representatives from private enterprises.

According to government statistics, Taiwan's trade with Macedonia in the past has been tiny. Last year, Taiwan's exports to Macedonia stood at US$1.86 million, and imports from the Southeast European nation, part of the former Yugoslavia, totaled just US$593,000.
Wang said the MOEA is studying the feasibility of asking some state-run enterprises, such as Taiwan Sugar Corp., to make investment in Macedonia.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEADS OF ROC AND MARSHALL ISLANDS EXCHANGE MEDALS

TEXT.P: Visiting President of the Marshall Islands Imata Kabua and the President of the Republic of China on Monday awarded each other medals in honor of their contributions to cement bilateral ties at a ceremony at the Presidential office

President Lee Teng-hui conferred upon Kabua the Order of Brilliant Jade with Grand Cordon, the highest civil honor awarded by the ROC, while three members of Kabua's entourage -- Finance Minister Tony de Brum, Foreign Affairs Minister Philip Muller, and Vice Speaker of the parliament Jurelang Zedkaia -- were awarded with the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon.
Kabua returned the honor by presenting Lee, Premier Vincent Siew, Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu, and other government leaders with medals.
Speaking after the ceremony, Kabua and Lee lauded the decorations as a token of the firm friendship between the two countries, and vowed to build on the amicable relationship.

Before the ceremony, Kabua and Lee also exchanged views on a broad range of issues, and Kabua expressed concern over the health of Lee, who had just returned to work that day after a four-day stay in hospital suffering from influenza.
Later in the evening, Kabua and his entourage were honored by a state banquet hosted by Vice President Lien Chan on behalf of the president.
Kabua arrived in Taiwan with a 43-member entourage on Friday for a weeklong visit.

DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Tuesday are as follows:

Taipei prosecution questioned five people suspected of floating rumors for stock market manipulation.
The China Times:

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 9, or the 24th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1825: John Quincy Adams, an American politician who helped formulate the Monroe Doctrine and advocated antislavery measures, is elected the sixth president of the United States, defeating Andrew Jackson.
1881: Feodor Mikhailovich Dostoevski, Russian writer who wrote such great novels as "Crime and Punishment," "The Idiot," "The Possessed," and "The Brother Karamazov," dies at the age of 60.
1899: The Boxer Uprising breaks out in China. Sparked by popular discontent with internal misgovernment and anti-foreign sentiment aroused by unequal treaties, the boxers lay siege against the foreign legion in Peking, where a combined force of Japanese, French, British, Russians, and American troops held out for over a month.
1921: The Living Buddha of Outer Mongolia proclaims "independence" after Mongolian and Russian communists gain control of Outer Mongolia. They established the Mongolian People's Republic in 1924, after the Living Buddha died.
1942: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek visits India after assuming office as supreme commander of the China Theater of War on Jan. 2, 1942.
1945: Mia Farrow, the American actress who first made her name in the television series Peyton Place and went on to make many films, notably comedies with Wooden Allen, is born.
1955: With a vote of 64 to six, the US Senate approves the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty.
1957: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China advocates independence for the Ryukyus. China and Japan both claimed the Ryukyus until 1874, when the Ching court signed a treaty recognizing Japanese rule. After Japan's defeat in World War II, the US took over the Ryukyus. In 1953, the US returned the islands north of Okinawa to Japan. Okinawa and the southern Ryukyus were returned in 1972.
1962: The Taiwan Stocks Exchange formally begins operation.
1964: Beatlemania hits US as 73 million Americans watch four lads from Liverpool appear on the Ed Sullivan Show.
1981: General Wojciech Jaruzelski, Poland's defense minister, becomes prime minister and chief of the Communist Party.
1993: President Francois Mitterrand visits Vietnam, ending Vietnam's isolation in the international community. He was the first Western head of state to visit the communist country since 1966.
1994: President Lee Teng-hui leaves for the Philippines, Indonesia, and Thailand on an eight-day visit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Why should one be too severe? When a man reforms and comes to me for advice, I accept his present reformation without inquiring what his past life has been. I am satisfied if I find that, for the present, he has really reformed, without being able to guarantee that he will not relapse again. But why should one be too severe?"

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FIRMS ATTEND INTERNATIONAL MULTI-MEDIA EXHIBIT
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Feb. 8 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The sixth international multi-media exhibition, Milia '99, kicked off in Cannes, France on Monday with 950 firms from more than 50 countries participating.

Ten Republic of China firms, led by Chen Ching-wen, executive director of a five-year program to promote the ROC's software industry, set up a joint pavilion with the China External Trade Development Council to display their multi-media products.

Chen said although Taiwan's software development lagged behind other countries in the initial stages, Taiwan has quickly picked up the pace. The fact that Taiwan has become the third largest computer hardware supplier has also prompted the progress of its software industry, he noted.

Chen said the ROC government has launched a five-year software industry development program. Under the program, the government plans to produce a variety of multi-media software products with the Internet using technology from electronics, television, satellite communications, stereo, video and movies. These products will in turn supply a new international electronic information market, Chen said.
Prior to the exhibition, French and Taiwan businessmen met to exchange views on the production of multi-media software.

It is estimated that the global multi-media market registers an average annual market value of US$23 billion at present, and the figure is expected to show an average growth of 30 percent in the next five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO SIGN PRISONER EXCHANGE AGREEMENT WITH THAILAND
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Feb. 9 (CNA) (By F. C. Kuo and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan nationals imprisoned in Thailand are urging the ROC government to sign a prisoner exchange agreement with Thailand so they can return to Taiwan early to serve their prison terms.

ROC Deputy Representative Chen Cheng-hsiung heard the requests during his visits to five Thai prisons prior to the Chinese Lunar New Year which falls on Feb. 16. Chen offered new year gifts and daily necessities in the run up to the most important holiday of the Chinese calendar.
Two Taiwan women found guilty of drug smuggling, tearfully told Chen that they missed their children who are in Taiwan.

A Taiwan man serving a life sentence for drug smuggling said only King Bhumibol Adulyadey has the power to grant amnesty in Thailand, adding that it was very difficult for foreign prisoners to receive such status. He added that his family could not afford to travel to Thailand to visit him.

Another Taiwan national who has already served several years in a Thai prison said when Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou was justice minister he promised to sign a prisoner exchange agreement with Thailand, but with the frequent changes in the ministerial post, his belief in such an agreement is evaporating. The prisoner said he hopes newly appointed Justice Minister Yeh Chin-feng will take up their cause.

Taipei should consider signing a prison exchange agreement with Thailand as the number of Thais imprisoned in Taiwan is rising, another Taiwan prisoner said. He added that most of his cell mates from Europe and the United States have been repatriated to serve out their terms under respective agreements with Thailand.

According to Thai statistics, there are currently 44 Taiwan prisoners in five Thai prisons on the outskirts of Bangkok. Among them, four have been sentenced to life imprisonment, one sentenced to 50 years, and 11 sentenced to 40 years.
Most of them have been found guilty of drug smuggling while others were convicted of murder, followed by arm robbery, theft and check default problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW RECEIVES MACEDONIAN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew met with visiting Macedonian Information Minister Rezxep Zllatku on Tuesday for discussions on a broad range of issues of mutual concern.

Stressing that Taipei and Skojpe decided to forge official diplomatic ties because the two countries share the same aspirations for democracy, human rights and peace, Siew expressed the hope that bilateral exchanges will be further strengthened.

As two-way relations are based on mutually beneficial ties, Siew said no third party has the right to interfere. "No matter how, the two nations have (established relations) to gain greater international presence," he noted.
Answering questions from Macedonian reporters who accompanied Zllatku to Taipei, Siew said Taiwan's "economic miracle" is built upon a solid economic foundation coupled with public efforts.
The premier said he believes many Taiwan businesses are willing to invest in Macedonia as long as the government provides them with sufficient information.
Siew also related the story behind the forging of ties between the Republic of China and the Balkan state.

He said Vasil Tupurkovski, chairman of the ruling Party for Democratic Alternatives (PDA), paid a secret visit to the ROC last year. Tupurkovski, leader of then opposition PDA, was very impressed with the island's economic development, and began to actively push for the establishment of diplomatic links with Taipei after his party won in the general presidential election late last year.

Zllatku, at the head of a 30-member press delegation, arrived in Taipei on Sunday for a six-day visit. The mission is the first of its kind to visit Taiwan since the two countries set up officials ties on Jan. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO SUSPECTS DETAINED FOR SMUGGLING HEROIN

TEXT.P: Two suspects were arrested for smuggling heroin from mainland China, agents from Taiwan's Investigation Bureau (IB) said on Tuesday.

Agents said that Chi Pao-chai, 48, and Chu Yu-hsin, 32, concealed 1.4 kilograms in three Jiouguei (drunkard) liquor bottles from the mainland. Chi was also found to be carrying 1.073 kilograms of amphetamine taped to her body.

The IB was tipped off last June that Chi, who has previous convictions for narcotics possession, had smuggled drugs from the mainland for huge profits several times, and began a surveillance operation on her.

After staking her out for a period of time, the agents found out earlier this month that Chi, along with her accomplice Chu, was planning to travel to the mainland via Macau, but that they had not booked return tickets.

The agents later discovered that the two arrived back in Macau from the mainland on Monday afternoon, and returned to Taiwan on Monday night. They were apprehended at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport as they were about to leave in a taxi.

It is understood that Chi has taken advantage of duty free liquor allowances to smuggle heroin before. An initial investigation found that the drugs might have come from Shantou, in Guangdong province.
The agents are conducting further investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 27 CHINESE POLICE KILLED IN WAR ON DRUG TRAFFICKING

TEXT.P: Twenty-seven police officers have been killed and 207 injured in mainland China's recent crackdown on drug trafficking in Kunming, Yunnan province, the China Daily reported on Tuesday.
An average of 25 incidents of drug trafficking are discovered a day along the province's 4,060-kilometer border with Myanmar, Laos and Vietnam, also known as the "Golden Triangle," the daily said.
The recent anti-drug campaign, centered on the southwestern region, has delivered a hard blow to drug dealers, the paper noted.
Yunnan took the lead in the mainland by setting up 17 drug-control agencies last year, comprising 116 police squads made up of 2,000 officers. (Stanley Cheung)

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PRECONDITIONS SHOULD BE IMPOSED IN US AGREEMENT: ESTRADA

TEXT.P: No preconditions should be imposed on the United States in exchange for the Philippine Senate's ratification of the RP-US Visiting Forces Agreement, President Joseph Estrada said on Monday.
We cannot make conditions on other countries before we approve anything, Estrada said in an interview at the Bureau of Customs in Manila.

Last weekend, a Senate leader said the US must first fulfill three conditions before the chamber approves the VFA. The conditions include altering Washington's official view that the Philippine-American war was an "insurrection" and that Filipino leaders in the war were "brigands."

However, Estrada has repeatedly stressed there should be no preconditions to the passage of the VFA by the Philippine Senate, noting it would not be a sign of good faith to do so. He urged senators to look at the VFA from the standpoint of enhancing national security and helping ensure stability in the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar moved down NT$0.023 against the greenback in Taipei Tuesday, closing at 32.288.
The local currency opened at 32.277 and was traded between 32.263 and 32.31.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$445 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA DECLARES STATE OF CALAMITY IN FLOODED REGION

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada on Monday declared a state of calamity in the Caraga region in Mindanao after prolonged flooding killed 20 people and displaced over 100,000 residents.
Upon recommendation by the National Disaster Coordinating Council, Estrada made the declaration and ordered government agencies to help relocate displaced residents and provide relief aid.

Authorities are providing around-the-clock assistance to some 100,000 residents in Mindanao in Davao province, Davao Oriental, Surigao del Sur, and especially Butuan City and other areas of Agusan del Sur where floods were triggered by continued heavy rains, Mercado said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ZEALAND TO CHANGE ITS MONETARY POLICY

TEXT.P: New Zealand has decided to change its monetary policy by replacing its current complex Monetary Conditions Index (MCI) with a cash-rate-based system, the Australian Financial Review said on Monday.
The cash-rate-based system is used by many central banks around the world, and is said to help reduce volatility in short-term interest rate regimes.
New Zealand's foreign exchange market reacted positively to the news, as trading in the currency was up more than one US cent to close at 55.90 US cents from 54.83.

The government will formally introduce the first official cash rate on March 17 and review it every six weeks thereafter, broadly in line with the practice of central banks in Australia and other developed countries, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK WARY OF INCREASE OF ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS FROM CHINA

TEXT.P: Amid growing unemployment, Hong Kong is increasingly concerned about the influx of illegal immigrants from mainland China, the Australian Financial Review reported from the former British territory.

In the past, Hong Kong welcomed mainland immigrants to help reduce the cost of labor, but as factories moved to the mainland and as Hong Kong matured, it increasingly became a service-based economy which is now in a recession.

Hong Kong now has a record unemployment rate of 5.8 percent and the figure is expected to further increase. Many Hong Kong residents accuse mainlanders of stealing their jobs, reducing wages, and sponging off welfare resources and draining school and health resources.

To make the matter worse, Hong Kong, under the "one country, two systems" formula, can not reject or reduce the influx of mainland immigrants because its Basic Law, promulgated by China's National People's Congress, allows these new migrants to enter the territory.

Chinese rulers have never historically accepted the institutional constraints and tolerated autonomous courts from Hong Kong. That's why China has no history of taking legal drafting seriously, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT MONITORING MAINLAND CAPITAL MOVEMENT: SECURITY CHIEF

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government is closely monitoring illegal mainland Chinese capital movement in Taiwan, and has obtained substantial information in this regard, National Security Bureau (NSB) Chief Ting Yu-chou said on Tuesday.
Ting made the remarks during a visit to the newly installed fourth Legislative Yuan, which will kick off its first session soon.

Ting stressed that mainland China's intention to penetrate the fabric of Taiwan, regardless of whether it is through private or public channels, will have a serious negative impact on local society. He told Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyin and his deputy, Rau Yin-chi, adding that his bureau will step up monitoring and information gathering in the runup to the island's presidential election slated for 2000.

The new NSB head promised that he will fully carry out his duties "on the right note" while he is in the post. Saying that his bureau will never ease its efforts in this mission, he called on the public to join forces with the government to crack down on mainland China's clandestine activities here to safeguard national security.

Ting also called on ruling Kuomintang legislative caucus leader Tseng Yung-chuan and Tseng's counterpart in the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party, Chang Chun-hsung, to discuss related issues.
Ting was appointed to the post of NSB chief in a recent partial Cabinet reshuffle by Premier Vincent Siew.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIJACKER ATTACK ON SEF OFFICIAL SAID `PLANNED' ACTION

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese hijacker's attack on an official from the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) was a planned action, not an individual acting on the spur of the moment, SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow said on Tuesday.

Shi made the remarks after Yang Mingde, who was being repatriated after serving a jail term for the 1993 hijacking of a Sichuan Airlines plane to Taiwan with his wife Han Fengying, slashed the neck of SEF Deputy Secretary General Jan Jyh-horng as he was accompanying them on a flight from Taiwan to the ROC-controlled island of Kinmen on Monday afternoon.
Shortly after the plane took off at 1:50 p.m., Yang reportedly said he wanted to talk to Jan over some urgent matter. Yang's 11-year-old son Yang Yang was repatriated to the mainland on Saturday.

Yang requested that he be allowed to come closer to Jan, and then suddenly pulled out a sharp object which looked like a metal door handle and attacked Jan, who subsequently suffered a 7.5 cm cut on the neck which required two stitches.

Shi traveled to Kinmen on Tuesday morning to visit Jan and discuss the issue with him, following which the SEF decided to repatriate only five of the nine hijackers scheduled for repatriation, holding the four others, including Yang, for further questioning.
Shi said that those found responsible for the incident will be dealt with according to the law.

He noted that the incident is not an isolated case, saying that as early as last December, Yang and three others began preparing for their uprising, and that they had hidden pieces of metal and razors in the lining of their clothes or in the soles of their shoes.
The five repatriated hijackers were picked up by a ship sent by mainland China's Red Cross Society from Fujian province.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FAIR TRADE OFFICIALS MEET AUSTRALIAN COUNTERPARTS

TEXT.P: Four members of Taiwan's Fair Trade Commission (FTC) met with their Australian counterparts Tuesday to discuss the cooperation and exchange of information and personnel between the two sides.
Led by FTC Commissioner Lo Chang-fa, the group was received by executives of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) in Canberra.

In an interview with CNA, Lo said the ACCC has already sent a staff member to work at the FTC to see how the commission operates. The FTC will shortly send an official to the ACCC for the same purpose, he added.
"Through this kind of exchange of visits and learning, we can forge closer ties between our two organizations," he said.

Lo and his group traveled to Australia from Wellington, New Zealand where they took part in the Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation committee conference on investment and trade. The Taiwan delegation is scheduled to return to Taipei on Monday. (By Peter Chen) ENDITEM/S CEP0017 [02/09/99 17:17:47] JD5K7325.CEP 02-09-99 LABOR PARTY NAMES ETHNIC CHINESE IN AUSTRALIAN ELECTION
Canberra, Feb. 9 (CNA) Sydney Deputy Mayor Henry Tsang was chosen as the first ethnic Chinese candidate in parliamentary elections for New South Wales slated for March 27 by Australia's Labor Party.
Tsang won the eighth and final spot in the Labor Party's Upper House ticket under Labor Premier Bob Carr's recommendation.
"I want to use him overseas, to tell people in Hong Kong, for example, that Pauline Hanson (One Nation Party leader) doesn't speak for Australians," Carr said.
Tsang has been deputy mayor of Sydney for several years.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARSHALL ISLANDS OPENS EMBASSY IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Republic of Marshall Islands opened an embassy in the Republic of China on Tuesday, heralding a new era in relations between the two countries.

Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua, Foreign and Trade Minister Philip Muller, and ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu jointly cut the ribbon to inaugurate the new embassy in Taipei's diplomatic district in suburban Tienmu.
Speaking at the inaugural ceremony, Hu said the opening of the Marshall Islands Embassy marks a step forward in the bilateral relationship.

"I hope our two countries will make concerted efforts to further strengthen our cooperation in various fields," said Hu, who is scheduled to visit the Marshall Islands between late March and early April.
On behalf of President Kabua, Muller said his country is satisfied with the establishment of full diplomatic ties with the ROC.

"Our two countries decided to forge official links after only a few months of negotiations. This indicates that our two governments have strong confidence in each other's commitment. I believe our cooperative ties will become even closer in the future," Muller said.

He went on to say that the opening of the embassy symbolizes a giant step forward in bilateral ties. "The embassy will do its utmost to provide prospective Taiwan investors with the latest market information on the Marshall Islands. I hope the ROC will assist in my country's economic development and that more Taiwan entrepreneurs will invest in the Marshall Islands."

Kabua, heading a 46-member entourage, arrived in Taipei on Friday for a weeklong state visit. This is Kabua's first visit to Taiwan since the Pacific island nation forged formal ties with the ROC on Nov. 20, 1998.
The Marshall Islands delegation sang a traditional festive song at the inaugural ceremony to express its country's joy and satisfaction with the establishment of diplomatic ties with the ROC.

The Marshall Islands first lady said the song is a favorite melody of fishermen in her country. "When our fishing boats return with full loads of fish and marine products, all the crew members and their families will sing this song to express their gratitude and joy. The rendition of this song symbolizes that our people attach great importance to friendship with the ROC," Mrs. Kabua explained.

The Marshall Islands is expected to appoint an ambassador to Taipei in the near future. Meanwhile, the ROC Embassy in the Marshall Islands is currently located in a hotel in that country's capital of Majuro, but construction of a new ROC Embassy building will start soon, Foreign Ministry officials said.
Kabua met with ROC Economic Minister Wang Chih-kang on Tuesday morning to exchange views on ways to boost bilateral economic cooperation.
During their talks, Wang promised that the ROC will assist the Marshall Islands in training managerial personnel to boost the development of its small- and medium-sized enterprises.
Wang said the ROC will also help the Marshall Islands expand its foreign trade and establish a comprehensive trade promotion mechanism.

Among the members of Kabua's entourage is Chen Tzu-ying, chairman of the Bank of the Marshall Islands. Chen hails from the ROC, and used to work in Taiwan's Chang Hwa Commercial Bank before emigrating to the Marshall Islands 17 years ago and opening his own bank.

The bank did very well, and the Marshall Islands government bought part of the bank's equity in 1992 to make it a national bank. At present, the Marshall Islands government controls 65 percent of the bank's equity and the remaining 35 percent is controlled by private investors.
Chen said the Marshall Islands has rich fishery and tourist resources, and has offered many incentives to attract foreign investment.

According to Chen, there are about 100 ROC nationals residing in the Marshall Islands at the moment, most of whom are business people. Chen said he hopes direct flight services between the two countries can be opened in the near future to facilitate bilateral exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE EXPECTED TO TOP 5% NEXT YEAR: WEFA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 8 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The US-based Wharton Econometric Forecasting Association (WEFA) forecast on Monday that Taiwan's economic growth rate will exceed 5 percent next year.
The association also forecast that the island's economic growth rate this year will be 4.5 percent, much higher than the 1.1 percent it predicted for Asia as a whole.

WEFA said that the performance of Asia's economy this year will remain weak, with this year's growth rates of Indonesia, Malaysia, Hong Kong and Japan estimated to remain negative, while the growth rate for Singapore is expected to be zero.

The estimated figure for global economic growth rate this year is 1.4 percent, while the average figure for G-7 industrialized nations is 1.3 percent. All the figures are much lower than those forecast earlier by the International Monetary Fund.

WEFA forecast mainland China's economic growth rate this year to be 7 percent, and 7.2 percent next year. WEFA's estimated economic growth rate for Hong Kong this year is -1.6 percent, while that for next year will be 1 percent.

WEFA indicated that several developments in mainland China will help its economy this year, such as recent amendments to its constitution to recognize the status of non-state enterprises, and loosened restrictions on foreign banks operating there.
It is also expected that mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji will promise to further open up mainland China's market during a visit to the US later this year, the WEFA forecast said.

The WEFA economic forecast figures are estimated based on a supply-demand model. On the demand side, there are four main indicators: consumer expenditure; investment; public expenditure; and net export growth.
Because foreign trade contributes significantly to Taiwan's economic growth rate, its export performance this year will be crucial to the upward or downward revision of its economic growth rate.

WEFA forecast that Japan's economy will shrug off its recession to register a growth rate of 0.5 percent next year, while South Korea and Malaysia will enjoy growth of 4.8 percent and 4.1 percent, respectively.
WEFA also reiterated its belief that mainland China's renminbi will not be devalued this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOY MANUFACTURERS ACHIEVE SUCCESS AT NUREMBERG EXHIBITION

TEXT.P: A total of 127 toy manufacturers from Taiwan took part in the "1999 Nuremberg Toy Exhibition," making Taiwan the fourth-largest exhibitor in the trade show.

The seven-day exhibition being held in the southern German city started on Feb. 4 and will continue until Feb. 10. Taiwan manufacturers together with those from Hong Kong total 342, accounting for more than 10 percent of the participants at the event. Counted alongside mainland China, the three regions have become the world's principal source of toys.
Altogether, 2,759 manufacturers from around the globe are participating in the show, among which German enterprises account for 1,236, followed by Hong Kong with 215, and Italy with 186.

With an eye to raising Taiwan's international image in toy manufacturing circles, the Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) and the Taiwan Toy Manufacturers Association are sponsoring a range of activities to attract international buyers.
To date, Taiwan manufacturers have received more than 300 letters of inquiry from possible purchasers during the show, while on-the-spot orders have already doubled over last year's figure.

Lee Jia-yi, director of CETRA's Trade Service in Dusseldorf, pointed out that 42 of the 127 Taiwan manufacturers attending the Nuremberg exhibition are displaying their products as a group under the auspices of the Taiwan Exhibition Pavilion, put together by CETRA.

In recent years, according to informed sources, a division of labor has become apparent in the toy business, with Taiwan accepting orders, mainland China being in charge of production, and the United States responsible for sales.
Toys manufacturers from Taiwan are putting great emphasis on the advantages of this labor division at this year's show, in which they are introducing the most popular toys made in Taiwan in 1999.

Some of Taiwan's most prominent manufacturers, such as Metro Toys, Genius Toys, Lucky Star, and Thunder Tiger Model Co., have also established good relations with foreign customers during the exhibition, according to the sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES, FUTURES FALL AGAIN

TEXT.P: Investors' reluctance to buy, and their moves to sell shares before the lunar New Year holiday, caused the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) to fall on Tuesday, with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, plunging 99.25 points to close at 5,723.73.
The local bourse is scheduled to close on Wednesday for the lunar New Year, which falls this year on Feb. 16.
Turnover for the day amounted to NT$47.67 billion, much lower than the NT$74.19 billion recorded in the previous session.
The bourse opened low and maintained a downward trend throughout the day.
The over-the-counter market also closed lower, with the market's index sliding 3.34 points to finish at 146.16 on a turnover of NT$2.36 billion.
Meanwhile, Taiwan stock index futures also closed lower.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for February sank 65 points to close at 5,770, with 1,545 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for March dropped 71 points to close at 5,806, with 2,853 contract transactions, while those for June were down 46 points to 5,868, with 14 contract transactions. No contract transactions were recorded for September and December futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO SURPASS TAIWAN IN COMBAT CAPABILITY BY 2005: MND

TEXT.P: Republic of China Defense Minister Tang Fei said on Tuesday that mainland China is developing cruise missiles which will eventually pose a far greater threat to Taiwan than guided ballistic missiles and nuclear arms.
Tang, a former chief of the General Staff, issued the warning at his first news conference as defense minister.
"The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has sufficient evidence to believe that mainland China is devoting its full energy to developing cruise missiles," Tang said.

He pointed out that the MND discovered that mainland China had acquired cruise missile technology from Russia shortly after mainland China test-fired M-class guided ballistic missiles into waters near Taiwan in the run-up to Taiwan's first direct presidential election in March 1996.

At that time, Tang said, the MND still didn't know whether Russia had transferred cruise missile technology to mainland China. "By now, however, we have come to understand that mainland China has achieved positive results in cruise missile development," he said.
This is the first time that the ROC military has confirmed that mainland China has made progress in its cruise missile technology.
According to Tang, mainland China's cruise missiles are similar to Russia's SS-N-22 missiles and the US-made Tomahawks.
He went on to say that mainland China has launched an all-out effort to modernize its weaponry systems and military equipment, as well as its personnel training.
Against this background, Tang said, mainland China is very likely to overtake Taiwan in combat capability by 2005.
Tang said mainland China is reinforcing its C4ISR technology and combat capabilities. C4ISR refers to command, control, communications, intelligence, electronics and reconnaissance technologies.
The minister said that the mainland has taken delivery of a fourth Kilo-class submarine from Russia and will soon deploy advanced missile destroyers.
Moreover, Tang said, the mainland is assembling a fleet of Russian-originating Su-27 fighters and upgrading its airborne fueling and avionics combat capabilities.
"All these developments will pose an ever-increasing threat to Taiwan's security," Tang said.
Meanwhile, Tang was quoted by an opposition legislator as saying that there are 120 mainland Chinese missiles of various types aimed at Taiwan every day.
Tang reportedly made the statement during a closed-door meeting with Legislator Chang Chun-hsiung, convener of the legislative caucus of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

Commenting on a proposal that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait establsih a military hotline to minimize possible miscalculation and misunderstanding, Tang said such military exchanges cannot become reality until cross-strait political dialogue reaches "some stage" or achieves some results.

As for Taiwan's poarticipation in the US-initiated theater missile defense (TMD) system, Tang said the military is still evaluate whether to import or manufacture on its own low-altitude missile defense systems.

As for the high-altitude missile defense system, Tang said the whole development program is not yet mature. It's still too early to make any comment on whether Taiwan should participate in TMD system, he added. (By Sofia Wu) ENDITEM/J
