DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 10, or the 25th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1763: The Treaty of Paris is signed, ending seven years of war and heralding Britain's emergence as the leading world power. Britain gained both Canada and Florida and established dominance in the East.
1840: Queen Victoria of Britain and Ireland and empress of India, whose sense of duty and strict moral code had great influence on 19th-century British society, marries her first cousin, Prince Albert.
1890: Boris Pasternak, the Russian author famed for his prize-winning novel "Doctor Zhivago," is born.
1904: The Russo-Japanese war breaks out after Japan formally declares war on Russia.
1923: William Rontgen, the German physicist who discovered X-rays and developed X-ray photography, thereby revolutionizing medical diagnosis, dies in Munich at the age of 77.
1939: Haikuo falls after Japanese troops land on Hainan Island in southern China.
1946: In the first Jakarta (Batavia) meeting between the two sides, the Netherlands government bows to the inevitable and agrees to let Indonesia become independent, on the condition that Indonesia forms a confederation of states.
1955: Thousands of armed South African police begin evicting 60,000 black people from their homes in Sophiatown near Johannesburg, with bulldozers flattening the township in their wake.
1955: All 14,483 residents of the ROC-held Tachen Islands near mainland China's Chekiang Province are evacuated to Taiwan.
1962: In a historic exchange, captured US spy-plane pilot Gary Powers starts walking from the communist side of a Berlin bridge, while the highest-ranking Russian spy ever caught, KGB Colonel Rudolf Abel, sets off from the American side.
1964: The government of the Republic of China recalls its envoy from France and announces the severance of diplomatic relations with that European country.
1964: More than 80 people die as HMAS Voyager, a destroyer of the Royal Australian Navy, sinks after a collision with HMAS Melbourne.
1985: The Ministry of Finance orders the 10th Credit Cooperative of Taipei to stop transactions for three days for violating operating regulations.
1996: On the Japanese island of Hokkaido, a landslide crushes a highway tunnel, killing 20 people.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Is moral life something remote or difficult? If a man will only wish to live a moral life -- there and then his life becomes moral."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI NOT SURPRISED BEIJING HAS CUT TIES WITH MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: Vice Foreign Affairs Minister David Lee said Wednesday the Republic of China is not surprised that Beijing has announced the severing of diplomatic ties with Macedonia in protest of the Balkan state's recent establishment of formal relations with the Republic of China.
Lee, who was instrumental in the forging of ties between Taiwan and Macedonia, said the situation is under control and that Taiwan is now working to enhance bilateral exchanges with Macedonia.
The two nations established relations on Jan. 27.

Beijing announced via its official Xinhua news agency Tuesday evening that it had severed diplomatic ties with Macedonia over the Balkan state's decision to forge official relations with Taiwan. Mainland China announced it would also bring to a halt the implementation of all agreements between the two governments.
Lee said Beijing's bitter reaction is expected and understandable, adding, "We are not overjoyed at the outcome, and we are now doing what has been planned to bolster the newly normalized relations."

Beijing will likely to attempt to punish Taiwan for Macedonia's decision to switch recognition from Beijing to Taipei, Lee said, adding that Taipei is bracing for possible retaliation. Such retaliation could come in the form of moves by Beijing to lure away ROC allies or to undermine UN peacekeeping forces in Macedonia.
The Republic of China's top priority now is to firmly consolidate relations with Macedonia, its 28th diplomatic ally and the first in the Balkan Peninsula, Lee said.
ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu and his Macedonian counterpart, Aleksandar Dimitrov, signed a joint communique in Taipei on Jan. 27 that established full diplomatic relations between the two countries.
Mainland China was unaware that the two countries were planning to establish relations. Once discovered, however, the moves drew a strong protest from Beijing.
The move also provoked a strong rebuttal from Macedonian President Kiro Gligorov, a communist who is friendly toward Beijing.
But Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, who spearheaded the campaign to establish relations with Taiwan, reaffirmed repeatedly over the last days that the decision will not be changed.
The Macedonian Cabinet Conference on Monday passed legislation establishing formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China.

Macedonian Information Minister Rezxep Zllatku is currently visiting Taipei at the head of a 30-member delegation of journalists who have come to the island to better understand the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR MAINLAND HIJACKERS TRANSFERRED TO TAIPEI FOR QUESTIONING

TEXT.P: Four convicted mainland Chinese hijackers who were planning to hijack a plane taking them to the offshore island of Kinmen for eventual repatriation were returned to Taiwan Wednesday for interrogation.

Yang Mingde, Lin Wenqiang, Shi Yuebo and Wang Zhihua were transferred from Kinmen to the Taipei Detention Center Wednesday after they were detained Tuesday by the Kinmen District Prosecutor's Office on charges of assault and intent to commit violence.

One of nine mainland Chinese convicted hijackers who were to be repatriated Tuesday, Yang assaulted Straits Exchange Foundation Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyn-horng with a portion of a metal door handle. Jan suffered a 7-centimer gash in his neck and required two stitches.
The assault occurred while the plane carrying the hijackers was landing at Kinmen's airport on Monday.
After the attack, Yang was removed from the plane under police guard. During questioning by Kinmen police Yang admitted the assault was premeditated.
In 1993 Yang and his wife hijacked a plane and forced it to land in Taiwan. That same year Lin, Shi and Wang hijacked another mainland Chinese airliner.
At the time repatriation proceedings were initiated, the four were on parole after having spent several years in prison.
Yang's wife was repatriated in 1997 after serving several years in prison. Their son, 11-year-old Yang Yang, was repatriated on Feb. 6 of this year after spending five years in Taiwan.
Months ago the four men hatched a plan to hijack whatever type of vehicle -- boat or plane -- was used to repatriate them to the mainland, according to Kinmen police.

According to the Taipei District Prosecutor's Office, the four could face trial on at least four charges: assault, attempted murder, infringement of public order and hijacking. If prosecuted under laws related to civil aviation, the four could face heavier punishments than they would face otherwise, Taipei prosecutors said.

Meanwhile, Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen on Wednesday admitted that security oversights played a role in Yang's attack. Police did not demand that the hijackers change into new clothes and slippers before boarding the airplane that was going to take them from the detention center in northern Taiwan city of Hsinchu to Kinmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESSMEN SUPPORT TAIWAN'S BID TO JOIN WHO
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 9 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Twelve US congressmen have sent a letter to US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, asking her to inform the House of the steps the US will pursue in securing World Health Organization affiliation for Taiwan.
The move by House members followed the introduction of a similar Senate resolution last month.
The letter, signed Feb. 8, was initiated by Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio), who has long advocated Taiwan's participation in the WHO.

Eleven colleagues co-signed the letter were Michael Bilirakis (R-Fla.), Dan Burton (R-Ind.), Peter Deutsch (D-Fla.), Dana Rohrabacher (R-Calif.), Brad Sherman (D-Calif.), Peter King (R-N.Y.), Joe Barton (R-Texas), Patrick Kennedy (D-R.I.), Pete Sessions (R-Texas), Deanna DeGette (D-Colo.), and Nita Lowey (D-N.Y.).

The letter noted that Taiwan has been blocked from participating in the WHO since 1972. As a consequence, the children of Taiwan suffer needlessly because doctors there are "denied access to the latest WHO protocols," according to a press release by the non-profit Formosan Association for Public Affairs.

"Unfortunately, with each passing year our administration worsens Taiwan's plight by supporting China's assertion that its neighbor is not a nation and therefore should not be represented in the international community," the letter added.
Rather than a threat to Beijing's security, Taiwan's participation in the WHO would enhance the quality of life of mainland China's 1.2 billion inhabitants, the letter said.
The letter said it is distressing that the US government refuses to help Taiwan in its struggle to conquer diseases that are already exterminated in the United States.

Senator Frank Murkowski (R-Alaska) introduced a resolution on Jan. 20 requesting the United States help Taiwan to secure meaningful participation in the WHO. He also called on the State Department to report to the US Congress on what action the Clinton Administration will take at the May 1999 WHO meeting in Geneva to support Taiwan's meaningful participation in the world health body.

The stance of the US government is that it will not support Taiwan's membership in international organizations in which statehood is a requirement. The WHO, a UN-affiliated agency, currently has states as its members.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO REPATRIATE 400 ILLEGAL MAINLAND IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is scheduled to repatriate a total of 400 illegal mainland Chinese immigrants before the Lunar New Year, sources from the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) reported on Wednesday.

The illegal immigrants will be returned on Saturday and Sunday via the offshore island of Matsu where ferries from the mainland Chinese Red Cross Society will be waiting to transport them home, SEF officials said.

Since there is no binding agreement on the repatriation of illegal immigrants across the Taiwan Strait, SEF officials said the return of the immigrants will follow the pattern used in previous repatriations based on safety and humanitarian concerns.

SEF officials said to allow the mainlanders to safely return to their hometowns before the Lunar New Year, which falls on Feb. 16, mainland Chinese detention homes in Hsinchu in northern Taiwan and Ilan in eastern Taiwan have begun to send the detainees to Matsu in recent days.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN ECONOMY OUTLOOK SEEN AS POSITIVE

TEXT.P: The Australian economy will continue to grow strongly for at least the next six months, according to a survey by the National Australia Bank (NAB).

The NAB index of business conditions in Australia rose for the sixth consecutive month in January, suggesting that the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) would continue to delay any move to cut official interest rates due to the country's strong economic performance.

NAB chief economist Alan Oster said the jump in the NAB index was consistent with a non-farm gross domestic product growth rate of around 5 percent. He said the economy had enough strength to continue to expand for at least the next six months.
But he also warned that Australia would still experience the anticipated post-Asian crisis hangover -- predicting economic growth would slow in the second half of 1999 to 2.25 percent.
He said there was a 50 percent chance the RBA would cut interest rates within the next six months.

He predicted the Australian dollar would fall against the US dollar in the next six months with weaker commodity prices and a significant deterioration in the current account deficit expected to reassert downward pressure on the country's currency.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, HONG KONG AMONG ASIA'S MOST COMPETITIVE TELECOM HUBS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and Hong Kong are among the 10 most competitive telecommunications hubs in Asia, according to a survey of 13 countries in the Asia-Pacific region by the National University of Singapore.
The Australian Financial Review had reported that Canada led other countries as the most competitive telecommunications hub.

But in a survey of more than 100 corporate end-users of telecom services in 13 countries, Singapore University's Center for Tele-Media Strategy found Singapore was the most competitive with a score of 66.
Australia came second and Hong Kong third with scores of 65 and 64, respectively. Japan was fourth with a score of 62 South Korea, New Zealand and Taiwan followed in the listings.
The least competitive group comprised Malaysia, Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia, India and mainland China, according to the survey.

The results were based on respondents' ratings of the quality and price of, and the range of choices in, a country's telecom services, as well as on the country's telecom regulations. Services covered by the study were international direct dial, leased circuits, frame relay and Integrated Services Digital Networks (ISDN).
In terms of pricing, Singapore ranked first, followed by Taiwan, Hong Kong and Australia. On choice, South Korea ranked first, followed by New Zealand, mainland China and Australia.
In terms of service, Japanese international long-distance carrier KDD was rated most highly followed by Australia's Telstra, Hong Kong Telecom and Singapore Telecom.
In terms of regulation, Hong Kong was the leader, ahead of Australia, Japan and New Zealand.

In terms of Internet use, Canada ranked first, Australia second and the United States third; they were followed by Singapore, New Zealand, Germany, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Malaysia, mainland China, the Philippines, Thailand and Indonesia, according to a survey conducted by ACNielsen of Australia.
In the survey of 140,000 respondents in 16 countries, ACNielsen found that one in four people in Australia and Singapore regularly use the Internet.

By comparison, only about 13 percent of people used the Internet in Hong Kong and Taiwan. Just 2.9 percent of mainland Chinese citizens in Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou regularly use the Internet, according to the Australian survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: ZHU SPLITS WITH NPC OVER RATE OF GROWTH

TEXT.P: Mainland China's State Council and National People's Congress are in disagreement over the economic development for the first half of the next decade, the South China Morning Post reported on Thursday.

A group headed by Premier Zhu Rongji has begun to draft the 10th five-year plan for 2001 to 2005. The group's deputy is Vice-Premier Li Lanqing while others include Zhu's aide Gui Shiyong, head of the State Development Planning Commission Zeng Peiyan and State Council Secretary-General Wang Zhongyu.

However, veteran congress deputies have drafted their own proposals in keeping with the increasing assertiveness of the legislature which is no longer content to rubber stamp government decisions, the report quoted a Beijing source as saying.

A key difference between the two reports was the growth rate. Zhu has said the average growth rate during the 10th five-year plan period should be 7 percent to 8 percent. This would be better than the development speed of well-off countries, he reportedly said, adding that the economy must avoid fluctuation.
But NPC economists support a more ambitious program, the report said.
"Heavyweight legislators think the growth rate could go up to 10 or 11 percent at least in one to two years during the plan's period," a parliamentary source was quoted.
These deputies had criticized Zhu for "excessive force" in cooling the economy from 1995 to 1997. They also believe a high growth rate is needed to contain social problems such as unemployment.

It is understood that one NPC deputy, a well-known professor, disputed Zhu's point that there was a glut of electric products in the market such as TV sets and VCD players. The academic said the potential for growth was vast in the countryside, where only about 5 percent of the population had color TV sets.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE PM EASES RULES ALLOWING MINISTERS TO OWN SHARES

TEXT.P: Prime Minister John Howard has watered down his code of conduct for his ministers by allowing them to own shares in companies involved in their portfolio areas, reversing his previous tough stance, which cost seven senior Cabinet officials their jobs between 1997 and 1998.

Howard on Tuesday announced his controversial change. Under the revised regulations, ministers now will be required to transfer control of such shares to "an outside professional nominee or trust, providing the minister or immediate family exercises no control on the operation of the nominee or trust."

Howard introduced his tough ruling after he beat former Prime Minister Paul Keating in March 1996 elections. The ruling was intended to avoid the appearance of conflicts of interest among Cabinet officials.
Howard on Tuesday night defended the change to his rules, denying they had been "softened."

"They're made more common sense, they're made more realistic," he said. "You will never get a satisfactory set of guidelines and I don't think you'll ever get rid of argument in this area, unless you have parliament full of people who've never owned an asset, who've never sought to be successful in business, who've never showed any kind of independent entrepreneurial imagination."
"While ever you have people who are jealous of the success of other you are going to have criticism that guidelines aren't tight enough," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: REVELATION LIKELY TO TROUBLE US-PRC RELATIONS

TEXT.P: A secret report on mainland China's efforts to acquire sensitive US technologies will likely become a serious bump in bilateral relations, an influential US member of Congress said on Tuesday.
The findings "almost certainly will strain US-China relations over the near term" once the report is declassified, according to Doug Bereuter, chairman of the House Asia and Pacific subcommittee.

Much of the Cox Report -- so called because Christopher Cox was chairman of the special panel that produced it -- is expected to be made public around the same time as the first official visit to the United States by Zhu Rongji as mainland China's prime minister.
"I think that this will be a substantial bump in Sino-US relations; it could be a very serious one," he said after a speech at the Heritage Foundation in Washington.

The senior congressman belongs to the nine-member, bi-partisan House Select Committee on US Security and Commercial Concerns with the People's Republic of China, which produced the 800-page report in late December.
Without disclosing any details, he said mainland China's practices, including espionage, have caused "great and extraordinarily damaging losses to US national security."
The select committee's investigation was prompted by allegations that two US satellite communications companies, Loral and Hughes, had illegally transferred missile-related technology to the Chinese.
Bereuter said that these cases were "minor problems" compared with the other things that the panel discovered during their six-month investigation.
However, he also said most countries normally conduct espionage and the primary criticism should be targeted at US administrations over the last 20 years.
"The focus needs to be on the US and how we could be so inept, so naive and so lacking in security procedures to have made this kind of major espionage prevail," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LANTERN FESTIVAL TO KICK OFF FEB. 27

TEXT.P: More than 10,000 people carrying lanterns are expected to gather in front of the Presidential Office on Feb. 27 to kick off the Lantern Festival, the Taipei City Government said on Wednesday.
The spectacular sea of lanterns is expected to earn the city a niche in the Guinness Book of Records as the longest line of lanterns.
The Lantern Festival -- which falls on March 2 this year, or the 15th day of the Chinese lunar new year -- will be moved to Feb. 27.
As a part of celebrations, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will lead volunteers in a parade around the city along four different routes. They will then converge into a circle near the Presidential Office.
Four topics have been chosen for this year's Lantern Festival theme, they are ethnic harmony, equal emphasis on the new and old, public participation and the next millennium.
President Lee Teng-hui will light the main lantern and its light will then be projected to a giant balloon to create the image of love and harmony to formally kick off the Lantern Festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.008 against the US dollar on Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at 32.280.
The local currency opened at 32.278 and experienced a high of 32.270 and a low of 32.315.
Interbank US dollar trading amounted to US$463.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPRECIATION OF PHILIPPINE PESO TEMPORARY: GOVERNMENT SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The depreciation of the Philippine peso against the US dollar is temporary and will not affect efforts to keep interest rates low, the government assured the public on Wednesday.
Presidential spokesman Jerry Barican said Wednesday's trading showed that the slight drop was merely temporary as the peso regained strength to 39.06 against the dollar as of noon.

The peso closed at 39.30 on Monday and dropped by another 20 centavos the following day. Barican also noted that when the auction of government treasury bills took place on Monday, there was slight drop in the 91-day rate despite a drop in the peso that day.
He said the Central Bank of the Philippines attributed the slight depreciation to weakening regional currencies, its purchase of dollars, and high corporate demand.
The fears that the government may not be able to keep interest rates low is unfounded, Barican told reporters during a press briefing.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, MARSHALL ISLANDS SIGN JOINT COMMUNIQUE

TEXT.P: ROC President Lee Teng-hui and Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua signed a joint communique on Wednesday, reaffirming their commitment to further expanding bilateral cooperation.

The two leaders expressed satisfaction with existing relations between the Republic of China and the Marshall Islands. They pledged to redouble efforts to further boost bilateral exchanges and cooperation for the common well-being of their people.
In the communique, Lee and Kabua vowed that they will never resort to military force to resolve domestic and overseas disputes or political differences.

"We'll resolve all disputes through peaceful discussion and consultation based on the principle of national equality and in a manner that can safeguard people's rights and interests as well as national dignity," the communique stated.
Lee and Kabua also signed an agreement on agricultural cooperation and a civil aviation accord to pave the way for increased exchanges and cooperation in the future.
Before sealing the joint communique, the two leaders exchanged views on matters of mutual concern and on general international and regional affairs.

Kabua, heading a 46-member entourage composed of senior government officials, senators and business executives, arrived in Taipei last Friday for a week-long state visit. This is Kabua's first trip to Taiwan since the two countries forged full diplomatic ties on Nov. 20, 1998.
During his stay, Kabua has met with senior ROC officials to discuss possible cooperative programs and visited Taiwan's major economic, industrial and cultural institutions.
On Tuesday, Kabua and ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu jointly cut the ribbon to officially open the Marshall Islands Embassy in Taipei, ushering in a new stage in the bilateral relationship.

Vice President Lien Chan, on behalf of President Lee, presided over a military ceremony at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex in downtown Taipei Wednesday to bid farewell to Kabua. President Lee has not yet fully recovered from the flu.
The Marshall Islands head of state and his entourage are scheduled to leave Taipei for home on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN ERROR SHUTS DOWN MUCHA LINE FOR FOUR HOURS

TEXT.P: A human error on Wednesday brought the Taipei Rapid Transit System's (TRTS) Mucha Line to a standstill for four hours on Wednesday, affecting some 20,000 commuters.

The most serious shutdown of Mucha Line's operations over the past year occurred at around 2 a.m. when a senior engineer of a contracted company for the line's maintenance mistakenly hit "restore" in the maintenance computer program -- erasing the entire communication-related configurations, including that which runs the electric power transmission.
The default caused a comprehensive stop of power supply, a Taipei Rapid Transit Co. (TRT) spokesman said.

After spending two hours trying to fix the power-supplying systems and the defaulted computer programs, TRT and the contracted company could still not fix the problem at the central control room for the Mucha Line operation, the spokesman said.

They were forced to mobilize all Mucha Line engineers to manually and separately repair power systems at five power converting plants located along the line, which runs through the southern and eastern parts of downtown Taipei.

When scheduled operations were supposed to begin for the day at 6 a.m., workers were still unable to fix the defaulted system. At some 10 a.m., the system was still not fully recovered, the TRT officials said.
The four-hour shutdown caused an uproar among commuters who were caught by surprise by the incident. They were forced to take alternative transportation such as buses and taxis.

While the TRT provided a supply of buses to transport commuters into Taipei, the company still received angry complaints as MRT users had to line up for ticket refunds and found themselves stuck on crowded buses.
Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou expressed his grave apology to the Mucha Line commuters, and stressed that efforts would be taken to prevent a reoccurrence of the incident.

Wednesday also marked the day when Lee Puo-wen officially assumed the post of chairman to the Taipei government-run TRT. During a morning ceremony, in which Lee was sworn in and received the TRT seal from Ma, the new leader expressed regret over the incident.

Lee said both the contracted maintenance company and TRT should be held fully responsible for the incident. He noted he will demand that the TRT conduct an investigation into the company's internal operations including the function of their crisis task force.
The Mucha Line, opened to traffic in March 1995, was the first TRTS line completed Taiwan. It uses the patented VAL unmanned transit system of France's Matra Transport Co.

Construction on the Mucha Line began in 1988 at a cost of around NT$20 billion (US$621 million). During its construction, the line was plagued by one problem after another. Operation defects have not stopped even after the MRT line began public services.
The line has been operating well during the past year until the latest shutdown.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW STRESSES IMPORTANCE OF SOUND FINANCE

TEXT.P: A strong financial foundation is indispensable in government, Premier Vincent Siew stressed on Wednesday.
Therefore the government must pay close attention to any amendments to bills concerning the increase or decrease of the government's expenditures to ensure affordability, Siew noted.

He made the remarks at the weekly meeting of the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT) Central Standing Committee after the finance minister and head of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics (DGBAS) made their reports.

Wei Duan, director general of the DGBAS, and Finance Minister Paul C.H. Chiu, delivered reports on the central government's budget starting from June 1999 to Dec. 2000, according to regulations of the new budget law.

The reports revealed that the new budget for the central government is characterized by a deficit which amounts to 20.7 percent of the whole budget. Particularly noteworthy is that the deficit arises from a zero deficit in the 1998 budget.

The premier further noted that the financial conditions of the central government have been much improved in the past three years. However, he said, due to the debt incurred by the central government -- attributed to the downsizing of the provincial government -- the central government is now facing another financial plight.
Siew disclosed that a debt foundation will be established with an eye to deal with the government's debt effectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES, FUTURES RALLY

TEXT.P: Despite overnight heavy losses on the New York Stock Exchange and the scheduled withdrawal of the stock market stabilization task force, share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) rose on Wednesday.
The weighted price index, the market's key barometer, finished at 5,798, up 74.27 points from the previous day's closing level.
The local bourse will be closed from Thursday through Feb. 19 for the Chinese Lunar New Year holidays. This year's lunar New Year falls on Feb. 16.
Turnover for the day amounted to NT$55.08 billion, up from the NT$47.67 billion recorded in the previous session.
The bourse opened low but managed to turn it around to an upward trend for the rest of the session.
The over-the-counter market also closed higher, with the market's index rising 0.89 point to finish at 147.05 on a turnover of NT$2.66 billion.
Meanwhile, Taiwan stock index futures also closed higher.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for February rose 70 points to close at 5,840, with 1,373 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for March rose 69 points to close at 5,875, with 3,934 contract transactions, while those for June were up 62 points to 5,930, with 23 contract transactions. No contract transactions were recorded for September and December futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT BACKS PEACEFUL SOLUTION OF CROSS-STRAIT ISSUES
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Feb. 9 (CNA) (By P. C. Tang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The European Parliament (EP), the legislative arm of the 15-member European Union, on Tuesday passed a resolution supporting the peaceful settlement of disputes across the Taiwan Strait.
The Strasbourg-based EP passed the resolution, introduced by EP member Pierre Bernard-Reymond, at a plenary session on Tuesday.
The resolution supported a European Commission-initiated proposal that the EU forge a global partnership with mainland China. The European Commission is the EU's executive arm.
The statement also urged mainland China to respect human rights and launch political reforms. It further called on all EU member countries not to strike any arms deals with mainland China.
In addition, the resolution expressed concern about relations across the Taiwan Strait.
The stated commitment said the EP hopes tensions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will ease and that cross-strait cooperation in all sectors will develop smoothly.
The resolution welcomed the visit to mainland China last October by Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing.
It further said the EP supported a peaceful settlement of the so-called "Taiwan question" and called on the European Commission to take concrete steps to contribute to this goal.
The resolution also expressed the hope that a long-term solution to the "Taiwan question," which complies with international law and the principle of self-determination, can be found.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELDERLY PAINTERS MAKE SPIRITUAL JOURNEY THROUGH ART (I)

TEXT.P: A portrait of a woman of self-confidence and strength. A street scene with a touch of nostalgia. A crayon drawing of a lush garden that speaks of spring, sunlight, warmth and happiness.
These images are among the 104 paintings currently on display at a gallery in the Taipei 228 Memorial Museum.

The works were created by 16 elderly amateur artists who hail from different ethnic groups and have varied family and professional backgrounds. They began to study fine art just three years ago when they joined a workshop organized by Liu Hsiu-mei, an accomplished artist who has held five solo exhibitions in the past few years.
Liu said she opened the workshop for elderly people with no professional artistic training based on her belief that everybody can paint.

"I want to experiment with my ideas and concepts. Our older generation grew up in a tumultuous period. Their lives were full of hardship and challenges. My observation is that many elderly people have great resilience and unused energy, and I hope to inspire them to use paintbrushes to record their life stories and express their emotions deep within," Liu said in an interview.
With her years of experience in teaching elderly people painting techniques and artistic creation, Liu said she has high reagard for their creativeness and originality.
"I respect these elderly students because they paint with great passion and enthusiasm. I have often been moved by their devotion and no-nonsense attitude toward creating art," Liu said.

Participants to the workshop are all in their late 60s or 70s. They speak different mother tongues, from the Taiwanese dialect and Hakka to Mandarin Chinese. Some of them are retired civil servants, schoolteachers or business executives, while others are former street vendors, craftsmen, blue-collar workers or housewives.

Nevertheless, their previous social status and identity have disappeared since they joined the workshop. All are equals before fine art. Their love for painting has helped narrow the social gaps between them, and they find no difficulty communicating or exchanging artistic concepts, aesthetic views, personal experiences and emotions.
Liu said her studio is not aimed at instructing elderly art lovers in the techniques of landscapes, floral or bird paintings. "My workshop focuses on creative painting."
At the beginning, Liu said she encouraged her students to choose their painting medium based on their personal preferences, specialties, disposition or flair.
"For instance, I have encouraged a grandmother good at embroidery to use crayons as her main medium. Some calligraphy fans choose paint brushes, while others opt for oil," Liu said.

All students first receive basic training, painting still lives and self-portraits. "With their strong urge to learn, my students work hard from the very beginning. Many of them practice painting skills day and night, and never tire of their craft," Liu said.

"Many of my students have told me that they have become stronger and more spirited since they began to study the art of painting. Some of them said they feel their lives have become richer and more meaningful. Painting has bringing them into a new world of visual and spiritual adventure," Liu observed.
In addition to pursuing technical expertise of fine portraiture, the students are also taught basic principles of design and composition.

"I introduced some professional books to my students to help them cultivate a good sense of color and light, discussed with them various themes or subject matters, and encouraged them to do soul-searching," Liu said.

Gradually, Liu said, she inspired her students to contemplate and muse on every stage of lives, from childhood, formative years, career, marriage, parenthood to aging. "I then induce them to depict images from the depths of their memories," Liu said.
She pointed out that the greatest appeal of elderly people's paintings lie in the rich life experiences they bring to their work. (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: SPIRITUAL JOURNEY (II)

TEXT.P: "Without the constrictions of traditional academic training, these elderly painters enjoy great freedom to express their sad and joyful emotions from deep within themselves. Many of their creations are reflections of their life's challenges and rewards," Liu said.

With Liu's encouragement and assistance, workshop students formed the Ha Ha Ha Laughing Painters Club last year to boost their pursuit of further artistic refinement. The current exhibition in the 228 museum is the club's first major achievement in this regard.
The themes or subject matter of the 104 paintings on exhibit can be roughly divided into four categories -- war experiences, childhood memories, women's lives, and personal emotions.
Liu said the works feature many forms of pictorial expression and arouse nostalgic feelings.

"A number of paintings reflect Taiwan's past way of life, social customs, mores, business activities, and entertainment. For instance, one delicate work created by Hsieh Chao-chih portrays busy, boisterous scenes in the kitchen of a wealthy family in Taiwan's olden days," Liu said.

Hsieh, a 70-year-old grandmother from an immense, bustling family in Taipei's old Wanhua district is also showing a watercolor featuring a parade of a large variety of dowries collected by a bride from a rich family. The procession is led by a female matchmaker sitting on a tricycle, which is followed by a long line of rickshaws carrying various trousseaus, ranging from men's and women's clothing, quilts, jewelry boses and footwear, to furniture, screens, lanterns and so forth.

"In the old days, local society cared about rites. Some poor families couldn't afford to give luxury dowries to their daughters, and had their daughters adopted by wealthy families instead. This sometimes, resulted in the suicide of their daughters. Fortunately, such social customs have faded away nowadays," Hsieh said.

Some other women painters portray erstwhile women's lifestyles. A work presented by Liao-Lin Yao is a sketch of a woman using a thread to pluck the facial hair of a young woman in the frontyard of a house. This was a facial skin care practice popular in ancient Taiwan which is rarely seen today.

Wu Ching-nan, a retired construction industry contractor, is showing an oil on canvas depicting a street scene he saw on his first trip to Taipei from his rural hometown of Hsinchu to take part in a junior high school extrance examination during the latter years of World War II. The work features Taipei's historic "North Gate" and in one corner of the painting can be seen a teenage boy carrying a small bag of rice while checking into a hotel named "Chiying Hotel."

"The boy is me. It was time of hardship. Taiwan was still under Japanese colonial rule. Rice supplies were rationed, and anyone who intended to stay in a hotel had to bring his or her ration. Otherwise, he would be denied entry," Wu explained.

Workshop instructor Liu said all these works are like pictorial or illustrated oral histories. "I think many paintings can serve as supplementary materials for historical, anthropological and sociological studies," she remarked.

Of all the exhibits, those featuring war experiences are the most impressive. All the club members have experienced various types of was and social turmoil, from World War II and the communist rebellion, to the February 28 Incident of 1947 (more commonly known as the 228 Incident)and the "wite terror." Memories of wartime scenes and events still haunt these elderly arts fans.
One watercolor, presented by Shen Chung-wu, depicts a devastating scene witnessed by the painter on a voyage from Ningpo in Zhejiang province to Shanghai aboard a passenger liner some 54 years ago.
Shen, a Shanghai native, who moved to Taiwan after the Chinese communists took control of the mainland in 1949, recalled that at the time, the Sino-Japanese was was at its peak.

"I was frightened when I saw an imperial Japanese warship sailing close beside us. But no sooner had the ship gone by than I sighted a second Japanese warship nearby exploding into two pieces and many Japanese seamen aboard the ship sinking beneath the waves. My uncle told me the ship hit an underwater mine," Shen said.

The 71-year-old former civil servant said the horrific episode made a strong impact on his outlook on life. "I still remember the incident vividly and it always reminds me of the brevity and fragility of human life and of the importance of making good use of one's time." (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: SPIRITUAL JOURNEY (III)

TEXT.P: Hsu Hsin-hsiang, a 74-year-old Hakka from rural Miaoli County has also painted a work inspired by his wartime experiences. Hsu's painting features a group of young soliders crowded into an air-raid shelter. The image of a middle-age woman appears in one corner of the picture.

"I was drafted into the Japanese army in the latter years of World War II. As Taiwan was then a Japanese colory, American warplanes bombed Taiwan nearly every day and 'take cover, air strike' became an order of the day. During those dreadful moments, I always thought of my mother. Memories of my mother's courage and fortitude in raising me and my siblings on her own helped me overcome my fear and anxiety during my military years," Hsu recalls.

The 228 Incident, to which the Taipei 228 Museum is dedicated, has also left scars on many club members. A number of their works reflect their emotions over the tragic incident sparked by the arrest and beating of an elderly Taiwanese female street vendor selling untaxed cigarettes in Taipei on Feb. 28, 1947, shortly after the ROC government recovered Taiwan from Japan in 1945. Subsequent islandwide rioting, ethnic clashes and anti-Kuomintang protests, followed by a brutal military crackdown, caused the death of thousands of innocent people all over the island.

Tang Ren-hsi, a Shanghai native who traveled to Keelung alone in 1946 to live with her aunt because her stepmother would not let her continue her high school education, painted an episode she witnessed during the 228 Incident.

"One morning, I saw a man with a mainland accent being chased by a group of Taiwanese mobsters near a bustling marketplace in the port city. Later, the man managed to run into a house for temporary shelter. When the mobsters followed him to the house and questioned its owner, an elderly Taiwanese woman, about the man's whereabouts, the woman said she hadn't seen anyone pass by. I was moved by the woman's kindness in providing shelter for the man," Tang says, adding that she hopes similar ethnic clashes will never happen again.

Some club members are particularly interested in painting landscapes. Cheng Chung-jen, 77, has painted many poetic, fishing port scenes that highlight his sentimental attachment to his coastal hometown of Hsiangshan in Hsinchu County.
Cheng said he has long yearned for a life of quiet reflection, study and painting. "I like landscape painting because I feel that Nature can be viewed as the best book on living."
Chen Yu-chen, a soft-spoken, warmed-hearted grandmother, has created a series of watercolors featuring flower subjects that convey feelings of delicacy and sensibility.

"I have a fascination with floral painting. Flowers arouse an instinct to protect and appreciate them. Their tenderness kindles a sense of compassion and understanding. Like life, their beauty is fleeting. I want to honor them," says the 74-year-old painter. (ENDITEM)

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S POPULATION SET TO HIT 4 MILLION

TEXT.P: Singapore's population may hit four million this year, according to government statistician Paul Cheung, and that could make 1999 "Year X" -- the milestone planners had expected the country to reach only after 2010.
The faster-than-expected population growth, from just three million in 1990, is the result of a rapid increase in immigration.
The trend is clear from already published statistics. The government's latest monthly digest of statistics in December put the total population in mid-1998 at 3.87 million.
The growth rate in the past two years was 3.5 percent. If that rate is maintained, the population will break the four million mark later this year.
In the early 1990s, four million was regarded as the number of people Singapore could house comfortably.

According to the latest issue of Singapore Facts and Figures, the land area in 1997 was about 648 square kilometers. If this is unchanged, the population density will be higher than anticipated, at 6,173 persons per square kilometer.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU SCIENCE PARK REVENUES LAST YEAR UP 14%

TEXT.P: The 1998 revenues of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park totaled NT$455.77 billion, up 13.9 percent over the preceding year, according to official figures released on Wednesday.
The Science-based Industrial Park Administration said that of these revenues, IC products accounted for NT$231.6 billion, up 15 percent over 1997.

The major sales from other categories were computers and computer peripherals, up 12 percent to NT$159.9 billion; communications, up 2 percent to NT$26.5 billion; optoelectronics, up 7 percent to NT$29.7 billion; precision machinery, up 120 percent to NT$7.5 billion; and biotechnology, up 41 percent to NT$600 million.
A total of 272 companies have been in operation in the park since 1980, and the workforce has topped 72,600, of which 3,057 are Chinese experts from abroad.

Yen Tseng-ming, director of the Investment Division under the Science-based Industrial Park Administration, told the media that the park will continue to achieve steady growth this year of between 15 and 20 percent.
Meanwhile, statistics show that 42 new companies were established at the park last year, with approved capital totaling NT$32.23 billion.
Of the new companies, 16 are funded by investment from Chinese experts from abroad, 23 are local firms, two are joint ventures, and one is funded by foreign investors.
In addition, 84 existing companies were allowed to increase their capital in 1998. The increased capital amounted to NT$134.61 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: QANTAS SECOND AUSSIE AIRLINE TO SUSPEND FLIGHTS TO SHANGHAI

TEXT.P: Qantas Airways, Australia's leading airline, will follow a partial step of Ansett Australia to suspend its flights to Shanghai, though it will maintain its six weekly services to Beijing.
Ansett Australia last November suspended its flights to mainland China because passenger loads were too light.
Qantas plans to from a code sharing agreement with China Eastern Airlines that will enable passengers to book flights on either of the two airlines through either carrier.

"Following discussions between the airlines throughout 1998, Qantas and China Eastern now propose to commence code sharing with effect from March 28, 1999," Qantas said in a letter to the International Air Services Commission of Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTAINERS AND CARGO HANDLED BY TAICHUNG HARBOR INCREASED

TEXT.P: The amount of freight which passed through Taichung harbor in central Taiwan increased by 1.5 percent in 1998 to 70.8 million metric tons while the number of containers was up by 4.5 percent to 880,000 TEUs (20-feet equivalent units), harbor authorities said.

Assessed as the best transportation agency under the Department of Transportation of the Taiwan Province Government in 1998, the Taichung Harbor Bureau is expanding its site by reclaiming some 220 hectares of land and is widening all of its navigation channels to 400 meters wide at a cost of NT$4.2 billion (US$129.23 million), said the bureau.

Also underway are plans to streamline the harbor's ship administration system to speed up vessels' sail-in and sail-out times, and the construction of a new wharf which will increase the harbor's bulk cargo handling capacity by 350,000 metric tons a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN PM APOLOGIZES FOR MISSING HUSSEIN FUNERAL

TEXT.P: Jean Chretien, prime minister of Canada, apologized Tuesday for missing the funeral of Jordan's King Hussein on Monday.

The apology came after strong media and opposition criticism that Canada was alone in the international community in not sending its head of government or chief of state. Its Foreign Minister Lloyd Axworthy attended the ceremony in Amman.
"I'm sorry," Chretien said last night from a family skiing holiday at Whistler, in western Canada. "Nobody knows when somebody will die."
He offered his apology again Tuesday when he visited the ambassador of Jordan, and "he understood very well," Chretien said.
"They know that we have good relations with Jordan. I'm sorry that I could not make it and I expressed such to the ambassador, who understood," he added.
Chretien dismissed suggestions he should have canceled his weekend ski trip, given reports that Hussein was being flown home to die following failed cancer treatment in the United States.
"Listen, for me, I wasn't going to stay in Ottawa to wait," he said. "I had organized this. I went skiing with my grandchildren."

In the House of Commons, opposition members spent the whole day criticizing the Liberal government for shaming Canada and snubbing Jordan. Newspaper opinion pages and radio talks shows were also filled up with unfavorable comments on Chretien's "unwise" decision.

The Liberals were taking the charges so seriously that Gen. Maurice Baril, the chief of staff of Canada's Armed Forces, was to issue a statement later in the day explaining why Chretien could not have been transported to Jordan in time for the funeral.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC TO MAINTAIN LOOSE MONETARY POLICY AFTER LUNAR NEW YEAR HOLIDAY

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) will maintain a loose monetary policy in order to stimulate the recovery of the domestic economy after the lunar New Year holiday, a high-ranking CBC official said on Wednesday.
The CBC official's remark came in advance of a Cabinet meeting on domestic financial issues scheduled for Friday.
Taiwan's domestic business sector has asked the CBC to submit concrete plans at the meeting to cope with the current domestic economic and financial situation.

The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics on Tuesday announced a downward revision of its estimate for the nation's economic growth rate this year to 4.74 percent, considerably lower than that forecast earlier by several local economic research institutes that the nation's economic growth rate this year would exceed 5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISITS TO HK BY TAIWANESE INCREASE IN NUMBER, BUT SPENDING DECREASES
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Feb. 10 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The number of visitors to Hong Kong from Taiwan increased in 1998, but the amount they spent in the "Pearl of the Orient" decreased, according to statistics compiled by the Hong Kong Tourist Association (HKTA).
A total of 1.81 million tourists from Taiwan visited Hong Kong during 1998, or 1.7 percent up on the previous year, making Taiwan Hong Kong's second-biggest sources of visitors after mainland China.
The moderate surge in the number of Taiwan visitors was credited to a relaxation of visa regulations by the Hong Kong government.

Spending in Hong Kong by this group, however, decreased to a total of HK$10.73 billion (US$1.37 billion), which translated into an expenditure of HK$5,924 (US$759.48) per head, or 16.2 percent lower than the 1997 figure.

The plummet in spending was blamed on the financial storm which has been ravaging the region over the last year, leading to currency devaluations in many Southeastern Asian states. This has made commodity prices in Hong Kong relatively high because of the linkage between the HK dollar and the US dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SPECIAL ENVOY LEAVES FOR AMMAN

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday appointed Legislative Yuan Vice President Yao Eng-chi as the government's special envoy to travel to Jordan and extend condolences over the death of King Hussein.
Yao, who was scheduled to leave for Amman on Wednesday, will also express his congratulations on behalf of the ROC government over the ascension to the throne of King Abdullah II.

The ROC Foreign Ministry said in a news release that the ROC and Jordan have traditionally maintained a close friendship and firm unofficial relations, despite the lack of diplomatic ties between the two countries.

Abdullah has visited Taiwan three times and is said to attach much importance to cooperative bilateral relations. ROC officials believe that Taipei's substantive relations with Amman will be further strengthened in the future.
Following his trip to Jordan, Yao plans to proceed to Europe and the United States to meet with local Taiwanese businessmen and overseas Chinese residents. He will return to Taipei on Feb. 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: US REITERATES OPPOSITION TO BEIJING STANCE ON MACEDONIA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 9 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The United States on Tuesday reiterated its opposition to Beijing's possible veto of the extension of the mandate of United Nations peacekeeping forces in Macedonia.

The US position was made clear following an announcement by mainland China that it was suspending diplomatic relations with Macedonia and reconsidering its position on the extension of the mandate of the UN Preventative Deployment Force in Macedonia in retaliation for the Balkan nation establishing official ties with the Republic of China.

Answering reporters at a routine State Department news briefing, State Department spokesman James Rubin said that the issue of whether to extend the stay of UN peacekeeping forces in a potential trouble spot was last raised when Beijing backed down on a threat to veto a 1997 resolution to send a UN peacekeeping force to train police in the Caribbean nation of Haiti.
The US position is that the issue should not be linked to Beijing's objections regarding the relationship between Macedonia and its diplomatic allies.
Rubin stressed again that the US supports the extension of the UN Preventative Deployment Force's mandate in the southeast European country. The current mandate expires on Feb. 20.
He pointed out that the permanent members of the UN Security Council should keep in mind that their special status makes them obliged to give priority to international peace and security.
Rubin also reiterated that the US should maintain its unofficial relations with Taiwan under the US "one China" policy. (By Jay Chen & David Hsu) ENDITEM/J

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI BLAMES BEIJING FOR STALLING OVER TAIWAN VISIT BY ARATS HEAD

TEXT.P: It is Beijing rather than Taipei which is stalling over a visit to Taiwan by the head of its top negotiator with the Republic of China, according to a statement on Wednesday by Shi Hwei-yow, vice chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

Shi made the comment in a rebuttal of claims by Beijing's mouthpieces in Hong Kong that Taiwan is blocking the visit of Chairman Wang Daohan of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) by backtracking on a consensus reached by Wang and his Taiwan counterpart, Koo Chen-fu, last October.

Beijing criticized Taipei's forsaking of the Koo-Wang agreement to open dialogue on economic and political issues during Wang's Taiwan trip by refusing to dispatch a SEF deputy secretary-general to exchange views with his mainland counterpart on the agenda for Wang's visit.
Accusing Beijing of trying to impose its will on Taipei, Shi said Wang's trip, which mainland China has promised will take place within this year, should not be subject to any preconditions.
Beijing's attempt to force the island to sit at a political negotiating table, and make this a condition of Wang's proposed Taiwan trip is the real hurdle to the Koo-Wang meeting in Taiwan, said Shi.
Both Taiwan and mainland China said they are looking forward to the meeting but the two sides are bickering fiercely on when and how the meeting should take place.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTOR'S OFFICE TO INVESTIGATE CITIBANK'S CREDIT CARD OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's law-enforcement authorities have started to investigate whether Citibank is taking usurious interest from credit holders for delayed payments and contract-breaching fines.
It is reported that Citibank's interests are 20 percent for delayed payments and 36 percent per annum for contract-breaching fines.

The Taipei District Court has asked Citibank to lower its interest rates in these regards, and has summoned a Citibank executive in charge of credit card operations to give an explanation, but the summons has been ignored by the bank.
The court has sent a written document to the Taipei Prosecutor's Office charging the bank with violating the Criminal Code for charging usurious interest.

Citibank in turn issued a statement on Wednesday evening saying that its executive did not receive a summons from the court or the prosecutor's office. It added that the executive will appear in court or the prosecutor's office when he receives a summons.
Taiwan's Central Bank of China is also looking into the matter, and has asked Citibank to present a report to the central bank within one week.

Meanwhile, three local banks are also found to have been charging 36 percent annual interest for contract-breaching fines. The Taipei District Court has ordered the three banks to set "an appropriate" rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN RULING PARTY UNDECIDED ON HABIBIE FOR PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Indonesia's ruling Golkar Party has not yet decided if it will nominate President B.J. Habibie as its presidential candidate in November, even though he now appears to be its strongest contender, party chairman Akbar Tandjung has been quoted as saying.

In somewhat cryptic remarks mirroring a reluctance among party elders to anoint the president for a full five-year term after the June general election, he told reporters that several other ministers along with Habibie were potential nominees.
The party will name its candidate before the June 7 election for the 500-seat parliament, he added.

The 500 MPs will join another 200 appointees -- most of whom will be picked by Habibie -- in the People's Consultative Assembly (MPR), which will elect the new president and vice president in November.
"Certainly, he is the best candidate that Golkar could nominate," Akbar was quoted as saying by the Bisnis Indonesia newspaper on Tuesday.
The three leading opposition parties have indicated they will contest the June polls on the strength of their presidential candidates -- in each case their party chairman.

With no party likely to win with a clear majority, the clustering of coalition partners could pivot around their choice of presidential candidates, with the support of the military and its bloc of 38 seats extremely crucial in a tight contest.

Several Golkar leaders, including some in the Cabinet, have indicated that in line with a general consensus among Jakarta's intelligentsia that Habibie would not be a popular choice because of lingering perceptions that he is a crony of ousted former President Suharto, they would prefer to keep the party's options open.
Akbar himself is seen as a more natural choice, with Justice Minister Muladi described as a "dark horse."

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTRY PUBLISHES PLANS TO STABILIZE CAPITAL MARKET

TEXT.P: The Finance Ministry on Wednesday made public long-awaited plans to stabilize the local capital market which has suffered unexpected turbulence in the wake of a series of corporate failures.

The plans, which are aimed at improving the market in the long term, was worked out by the ministry under the instruction of Premier Vincent Siew and will be further discussed at a national meeting on the financial and economic situation to be held on Friday and Saturday.

Under the plan, listed companies or those whose stocks are traded on the over-the-counter market will be required to immediately publish information regarding their operations. In addition, a stock investors protection law will be enacted.

The plan will call for heavier penalties for company directors violating related laws and regulations, and for the establishment of a workable system to counter insider trading and other crimes relevant to stock trading.

According to the plan, the government will seek to implement a treasury stock system, regulate corporate mergers, help the private sector participate in the island's infrastructure projects, accelerate the inflow of foreign capital into the domestic stock market, and increase the ratio of institutional investors on the stock market.
The ministry will seek to upgrade the status of the Securities and Futures Commission, streamline its organization, and give it a greater authority to supervise market trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST SINGAPORE BUSINESSES GLOOMY OVER 1999 PROSPECTS

TEXT.P: Singapore's commerce sector expects less favorable business conditions for the first half of 1999, with wholesalers and retailers anticipating a drop in business.
The survey of business expectations of the city state's commerce and service sectors for the first quarter of 1999 was conducted in December 1998.
Catering trade establishments expressed positive sentiments, while firms engaged in transport and real estate foresaw a business slowdown in the next six months.
The business services industry was also less optimistic about the business situation. Financial institutions forecast a downward trend in their business activity for the period.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The Ministry of Finance unveiled a new package of measures to boost healthy development of domestic capital market.
The China Times:
Beijing accused Taiwan of refusing to open political dialogue.
The United Daily News:
Mainland China steps up missile deployment; 150 to 200 mainland missiles target at Taiwan everyday.
The Liberty Times:
The government will offer tax incentives to encourage corporate merger.
The Commons Daily:
The Ministry of Finance encourages corporate merger.
The China Post:
Citibank credit card rates are illegal: judge.
The China News:
Top HK official will visit Beijing over abode row.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURPLUS OF IMPORT, EXPORT EXCHANGE SETTLEMENT HIT 2-YEAR HIGH

TEXT.P: The balance of import and export foreign exchange settlements in Taiwan's favor totaled US$2.07 billion in January, a two-year high for a single month, the Central Bank of China (CBC) reported on Thursday.
The increased surplus in foreign exchange settlements underlined an upturn in Taiwan's foreign trade sector, said You Ming-nan, deputy director general of CBC's Foreign Exchange Department.

CBC statistics showed that January's export exchange settlements soared 18.4 percent from the year-earlier level to US$10.6 billion, while import exchange settlements were up 4.5 percent to US$8.53 billion, leaving a balance of US$2.07 billion in favor of Taiwan.
You attributed the apparent climb in the settlement surplus mainly to exporters selling their foreign currencies to obtain New Taiwan dollars for the Lunar New Year holiday.
The foreign exchange settlements for exports were 8.1 percent and those for imports 8.1 percent less than the customs-clearance figures.
You pointed out that the statistics gap was a result of different calculation methods and delays in foreign exchange payments.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG TYCOON RETURNS HOME

TEXT.P: Business tycoon Lim Por-yen on Thursday returned to Hong Kong after paying NT$40 million (US$1.24 million) in bail and spending over a year in Taiwan, including 34 days in detention, for involvement in a land bribery scandal.

Lim, chairman of the Hong Kong-based Lai Sun Group and a major shareholder of Hong Kong's Asia Television, said upon his departure that he is pleased be heading home before the Lunar New Year and is thankful for the concern Taiwan people have shown him over the past year.
Lim was arrested in Taipei in December 1997 on charges of bribery and was released on a NT$10 million bail on Jan. 19, 1998.

The 88-year-old business magnate was convicted on bribery charges and on Feb. 6 this year, he was sentenced to three years and two months in prison. The court agreed to lift his travel ban in exchange for a NT$30 million bond while his lawyers file an appeal with the Taiwan High Court.

According to Taipei District Court verdict, Lim offered US$4.14 million to Taipei County government officials to ensure he would be compensated to the tune of NT$890 million (US$27.64 million) for land he owned that was to be used as part of the site for the new National Taipei University.
Located in Sanhsia in Taipei County, Lim's plot of land was the site of his Dollar Textile Manufacturing Co., which went out of business several years ago.
Lim, who also runs other operations in Taiwan, said he will return to the island in March for business and will respond to any Taiwan court summons in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOWNPLAYS TAIWAN'S INTEREST IN TMD SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Taiwan's interest in the US' theater missile defense (TMD) system is primarily informational, US State Department spokesman James Rubin said on Wednesday.
Rubin was responding to a London Financial Times report stating that the increased number of mainland Chinese missiles targeted at Taiwan justifies providing the island with the defense system.

"We carefully monitor the military balance in the Taiwan Strait on an ongoing basis. The Defense Department is preparing a comprehensive assessment of the military balance in the region, including missile deployments," the spokesman said at a news briefing here.
Rubin reiterated Washington's vow to adhere to the Taiwan Relations Act and noted that the Defense Department's report is expected to be passed on to the Congress very soon.

He said: "Consistent with our obligations under this law and part of our policy, we regularly consult with Taiwan on its defense requirements. As part of these defense requirements, we have briefed Taiwan, as we have many other friends, on theater missile defense. We do expect (the Pentagon's) report that has generated this article in this specific newspaper to be submitted shortly, but it would be impossible for me to talk about a report that has not yet been submitted or to comment on information that might be of a sensitive nature."

As to whether Taiwan has sought information about the purchase of Patriot missile systems, Rubin replied, "As I indicated, their interest in theater missile defense appears to be primarily informational."

On the question of China's breaking relations with Macedonia and the possibility of the Macedonian peace talks being disrupted, the State Department spokesman said: "The decision whether or not to recognize Taiwan is for the Macedonian government to make. The US takes no official position on whether countries establish diplomatic relations with other countries. We have no position on China's decisions regarding its relations with Macedonia."

The US supports the extension of the UN mission in Macedonia by the Security Council, Rubin stated, adding that, "we will urge all Security Council members to do the same. We believe that the UN mission in Macedonia contributes to peace and stability in the region, particularly in light of the continuing crisis in Kosovo. We see no reason to connect UNPREDEP's role and mandate with other issues."

Rubin refused to comment on any potential US-China contacts about the subject. "There is a history of times when this has been a problem, so we're not unconcerned about it, but we hope and expect that other countries will make their decisions based on the important role that the UNPREDEP plays in promoting stability in the region," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANILA URGES SENATE TO APPROVE THE VISITING FORCES PACT

TEXT.P: The RP-US Visiting Forces Agreement should be treated as a separate issue from the conditions a senator is seeking in exchange for the ratification of the accord, a government official said on Wednesday.

Presidential spokesperson Jerry Barican said the three conditions -- the return of the Balangiaga bells to the Philippines, the passage of the Veterans Equity Bills by the US Congress, and the correction of the perception of the Philippine-American War -- are already being addressed by the government.

"Suffice it to say that the Philippine government is not neglecting the issues of the return of the bells of Balangiaga, the Veterans Equity Bill, and the erroneous perception of the Philippine-American War as an insurrection," Barican said in a news briefing in Manila.
He noted that the Philippines is already lobbying for the return of the Balangiaga Bells and the passage of the Filipino Veterans Equity Act.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENIOR AUSTRALIAN OLYMPIC OFFICIAL RESIGNS

TEXT.P: A senior International Olympic Committee member was forced to step down from the Sydney committee organizing the 2000 Olympic Games following accusations that he accepted trips in exchange for his vote in the 2002 bid.

Phil Coles resigned from the board of the Sydney Organizing Committee for the 2000 Olympic Games after reports that he accepted lavish trips to the United States and other gifts before Salt Lake City won the bid to host the 2002 Olympic Games.
Coles has denied the allegations, saying he would not resign from the IOC.
Olympics Minister Michael Knight of New South Wales made it clear Coles must respond to the accusations. "We'd like to hear what Mr. Coles has got to say just as I'm sure you would," he said.
Coles said the trips were all private holidays and he paid all the expenses. "I have got all the records. I'm very comfortable with my actions because they were all private holidays."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SHOULD PUSH FOR TRADE LIBERALIZATION: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Australia should push for continued trade liberalization, Trade Minister Tim Fischer said in a report on trade prospects.
Key trading economies must resist "reform fatigue," Fischer said, adding that the appetite for trade liberalization will likely be more restrained due to Asia's financial downturn.

During the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) leaders meeting in Bogor, Indonesia in 1995, a trade liberalization timetable was set for developed countries at 2010, and for developing countries at 2020.

The minister noted that the momentum for trade liberalization among APEC member countries is not encouraging, but it would benefit all APEC member countries, particularly Australia, which was hit with sizable trade deficits as a result of trade barriers from its trading partners.
Australia's trade deficit hit A$10 billion (US$6.3 billion) in calendar 1998, up sharply from 1997 level.

DOC.HEADLINE: CORPORATE YEAR-END BONUSES DECLINE AMID ECONOMIC SLOWDOWN

TEXT.P: Year-end bonuses for private sector workers in 1998 generally fell below 1997 levels due to the lingering economic slowdown, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) reported on Thursday.

The Cabinet-level council cited the results of a recent survey as showing that 60 percent of private businesses planned to offer year-end bonuses to their employees with an average amount of 1.64 months of their monthly salaries, slightly lower than 1997's 1.75 months.
Of all the different employment categories, those working in utilities topped other industrial sectors by receiving an average of 2.18 months of salary as a year-end bonus.
In the service sector, banking and insurance took the lead, with an average bonus of 2.48 months of salary, higher than 1997's 1.98 months.

According to the CLA study, the average year-end bonus in the industrial sector in the 1997-98 period was 1.63 months, down 0.2 month from the 1996 level; while that for the service sector remained at 1.66 months for the third straight year.

The survey also found that the 1998 average year-end bonus in the manufacturing sector was 1.65 months, but about 70 percent of manufacturing companies said their year-end bonus could reach two months.

Meanwhile, 70 percent of companies in the recession-hit construction industry said they would offer their employees year-end bonuses with an average amount of 1.47 months, lower than 1997's 1.68 months.

The 1998 year-end bonus for workers in the mining and gravel industries was 1.11 months on average, but about 50 percent of workers in the two industries said their year-end bonuses fell below the one month level.

In the service sector, those working in commerce and trading services can expect to receive an average of 1.62 months of salary as a year-end bonus for 1998, compared to 1.51 months for those in the transportation, warehouse and communications sectors, and 1.42 months for those in social and personal services.

CLA officials said large enterprises usually offered higher bonuses to their employees than small- and medium-sized companies. Survey results also showed that corporate earnings are an important factor in determining the amount of year-end bonuses.
Another interesting finding was that more and more companies dispatched company stocks or dividends to their salaried workers as year-end bonuses to enhance employee loyalty and work performance.
