DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 11, or the 26th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1810: French Emperor Napoleon I, a brilliant military strategist whose military and political might gripped Continental Europe, marries Marie-Louise, daughter of the first emperor of Austria, Francis I.
1847: Thomas Alva Edison, the American who invented the incandescent light bulb and patented more than a thousand other inventions, is born. He patented his motion picture projector on his birthday in 1909.
1920: The League of Nations convenes its first council meeting in London.
1929: Pope Pius XI and the Italian government of Benito Mussolini sign the Lateran Treaty which gives Vatican City the Status of an independent sovereign state.
1946: US Secretary of State James Byrnes makes public the Yalta Secret Agreement. With victory in the war with Germany virtually assured, the three allied leaders, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Winston Churchill and Joseph Stalin, met on Feb. 4, 1945 at a secret meeting in the Black Sea resort of Yalta to map out Europe's future.
A secret agreement, among other conclusion, is reached on Feb. 11 by the three that the USSR shall enter war against Japan on condition that its former rights (in China) plundered by Japan in 1904 shall be restored. The three leaders also agreed that Adolph Hitler's Nazi forces must surrender unconditionally.
1953: Walt Disney's animated film Peter Pan goes on general release in the United States.
1958: Ernest Jones, the Welsh psychoanalyst who was a disciple of Sigmund Freud and founded the International Journal of Psychoanalysis, dies at the age of 79.
1970: Japan successfully launches its first satellite into orbit around the earth.
1970: The Taiwan Provincial Bureau of Mines is established with Tien Wei-wu serving as its first director-general.
1971: The United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty in Washington banning undersea nuclear testing.
1975: For the first time in its 300 year history, Britain's Conservative Party names a woman leader when Margaret Thatcher defeats four rivals to succeed ex-leader Edward Heath who lost the last election to the Labor Party.
1976: The Organization of African Unity (OAU) formally admits the People's Republic of Angola as a member.
1979: Islamic revolutionaries take control of Iran's government after the shah, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, fled Iran the previous month after mass demonstrations, strikes, and riots against his rule.
1990: Nelson Mandela, a South African political leader who was imprisoned for 27 years for his anti-apartheid activities, is freed.
1991: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev sends a letter to government leaders of the Warsaw Pact nations proposing that the military structure disbands by April 1.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the knowledge of letters and arts, I may perhaps compare myself with other men. But as for the character of a good and wise man who carries out in his personal conduct what he professes -- that is something which I have not yet attained."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC REVIEWS REPATRIATION INCIDENT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) met on Thursday to review the stabbing incident which occurred during the repatriation of mainland Chinese hijackers on Monday.

MAC Vice Chairman Wu An-chia headed the meeting which was attended by Yu Yi-tan, deputy director-general of National Police Administration (NPA); Hou You-yi, deputy director of Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB); and Hsieh Fu-yuan, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) director of the Department of Legal Affairs, and other related officials.
The victim in the incident, Jan Jyh-horng, SEF deputy secretary, also attended the meeting.

While Wu declined to reveal the contents of the meeting, he said its purpose was to exchange views on the process of repatriation and discuss solutions to problems to avoid similar events from occurring again.
There was no discussion on possible disciplinary measures for those responsible for the unfortunate incident, Wu said, adding that the MAC and SEF will take responsibility.
Jan also said that the meeting was to review the repatriation purposes and not to point fingers.

As Jan was escorting the mainlanders to be repatriated, he was attacked by one of the nine hijackers who was armed with a sharp metal object. Jan sustained a cut to the neck which required two stitches.

The attacker, Yang Mingde, and three others -- Lin Wenquiang, Shi Yuebo, and Wang Zhihua -- were detained and later transferred to Taipei to face prosecution while the other five were sent back to the mainland as scheduled.
After initial investigations, authorities discovered that Yang's attack was premeditated and that the four men planned to carry out another hijack during the repatriation process.
Meanwhile, the NPA on Wednesday meted out disciplinary measures against several officials over the lapse in security.

Hu Yi-kang, director of Hsinchu detention center where the nine hijackers were sent before leaving Taiwan, was reprimanded for negligence in management which resulted in the hijackers arming themselves with metal objects taken from the center.
CIB official Chou Wen-ke, who escorted the nine mainlanders during the repatriation process, as well as CIB Director Cheng Chin-sung were also reprimanded.

The incident has damaged the prestige of the government as well as that of the police, NPA Director-General Ting Yuan-chin said, adding that he will submit himself for punishment from the Ministry of the Interior.

DOC.HEADLINE: US HAS NO POSITION ON COUNTRIES' HAVING TIES WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 10 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The United States has no position as to which countries should have diplomatic relations with Taiwan, Stanley Roth, US assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, said on Wednesday.
Roth made the remark at a hearing on US policy toward the Asian-Pacific region, organized by the Asia-Pacific Subcommittee of the House International Relations Committee.
Commenting on reports that the US ambassador to Macedonia had allegedly attempted to persuade Macedonia not to establish diplomatic relations with Taiwan, Roth said he had not heard about the matter.

He said that Secretary of State Madeleine Albright reiterated on Feb. 3 when she met with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski that the United States has no position on the question of whether other countries should have diplomatic ties with Taiwan.
Roth also said that he hoped Macedonia's links with Taiwan would not affect mainland China's role in the United Nations.
Beijing on Tuesday suspended diplomatic ties with Macedonia and warned that it would reconsider whether to veto an extension of the mandate authorizing UN peacekeeping forces in Macedonia.
Roth said the United States supports the mandate's extension.

Commenting on a US-proposed Theater Missile Defense (TMD) system that would cover portions of East Asia, Roth said the US Defense Department would submit before this weekend a report on the deployment of such a system.

In regard to relations across Taiwan Strait, Roth said last October's meeting between the top negotiators from both sides of the Taiwan Strait was an important development in bilateral relations between mainland China and Taiwan. The meeting showed there is room for the two sides to proceed with dialogue, Roth said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCREASING AMOUNT OF TAIWAN IT PRODUCTION MOVES TO MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Taiwan's high-tech industries are following in the footsteps of labor-intensive industries that have moved their manufacturing operations to mainland China, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported on Thursday.

Noting that less than 60 percent of Taiwan's information technology (IT) products were actually manufactured on the island last year, while nearly 30 percent of the products were made in the mainland, CEPD officials warned that the trend could develop into a serious issue that would require close monitoring.

CEPD officials cited statistics compiled by the Market Information Center of the Institute for Information Industry (III) as indicating that the volume of locally made Taiwan IT products has fallen in recent years, while overseas manufacturing has risen.

The III tallies showed that in 1995, locally made products constituted 72 percent of Taiwan's total IT production, while 14 percent was made in mainland China and another 14 percent was made in Thailand, Malaysia and other countries.

In 1996 67.9 percent of Taiwan's IT products were made locally, while 16.8 percent were made in the mainland. Local manufacturing percentages fell to 62.6 and 57.3, respectively, in 1997 and 1998, while mainland-based manufacturing rose during those same two years to 22.8 percent and 28.9 percent.
From 1995 to 1998 notebook computers were the only IT product that Taiwan companies manufactured on the island exclusively, according to III tallies.

More than 80 percent of Taiwan's desktop personal computers, keyboards, power supplies, and mice are now made overseas, while more than 70 percent of the monitors and computer cases carrying made-in-Taiwan labels are processed overseas.
Desktop image scanners, which all Taiwan companies made locally until 1997, are now being built in the mainland as well. Now 38 percent of Taiwan scanners are built there, III officials noted.

CEPD officials said manufacturing operations based on well-developed technologies tend to be moved overseas to lower production costs. But products involving relatively new technologies or ones that require continued research and development efforts are still being manufactured mainly in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: COLD WEATHER EXPECTED DURING LUNAR NEW YEAR HOLIDAY

TEXT.P: After several days of warm weather, temperatures dropped Thursday afternoon as a cold front settled over Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau said.

Weather forecasters said the mercury will dip ever lower between Friday night and Saturday morning. Temperatures are expected to plunge to as low as 11 degrees Celsius, and rain is expected for some portions of the island as well.
During the Chinese lunar New Year holiday, Feb. 15 to 18, the weather is expected to be dry and cold.
Forecasters advised people to watch for rapid changes in the weather during the holidays and to avoid catching cold.

Meanwhile, Taipei City traffic police noted that Friday will be the last working day for most people before the lunar New Year holiday. The annual exodus of people from Taiwan's capital as they return to their hometowns in the other parts of the island, is expected to begin Friday afternoon.
Anticipating congestion on the island's major highways, police advised motorists to be prepared for heavy traffic.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SOFTWARE PROVIDER AVANT! TO SET UP TAIWAN R&D CENTER

TEXT.P: Avant! Corp. of the United States will establish a Taiwan research and envelopment center that can employ 100 computer software experts, according to the company's president, chairman and CEO, Gerald C. Hsu, who is currently visiting Taipei.
After his arrival in Taiwan Wednesday, Hsu said he believed the greater Chinese community comprising Taiwan, Hong Kong, and mainland China will become a leading software producer very soon.

Headquartered in Fremont, California, Avant! develops, markets and provides support for integrated circuit design automation (ICDA) software for designing sub-micron ICs including microprocessors and micro-controllers.
Its revenue amounted to more than US$227 million in 1998, posting 38-percent growth from one year earlier. Avant! is listed on the New York Stock Exchange under the name VAHN.
Hsu said that as a new century approaches, the information technology industry will serve as one of the driving forces in the world's continued economic development.

The Chinese people have been successful in the production of information technology hardware, and evidence of their ability can be seen not only in Taiwan and mainland China but also in Silicon Valley in the United States, said Hsu, an ethnic Chinese.
But fewer Chinese people have been involved in the production of software, a market that is only beginning to take off and which still has enormous potential, he said.
Now is the best time for Chinese companies worldwide to get into the software business, he said.

Speaking on the company's future research and development center in Taiwan, Hsu said that qualified manpower is the most important requirement for a software maker. The company's Taiwan center will provide training in software design.
Taiwan has many skillful IT product designers. Provided with the proper training, they can become skilled software designers as well, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD REFOCUS ITS IT PRODUCTION EFFORTS: CEPD

TEXT.P: The average growth of Taiwan's information technology (IT) industry production value dropped during each of the past two years from 20 percent average growth in 1996, said officials from the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) on Thursday.
CEPD officials under the Executive Yuan suggested companies focus on the development of high-added-value products, so that Taiwan's information industry may have a bright future.

The domestic production value of Taiwan's information industry before 1996 had stable growth. Taiwan's total IT production value totaled US$11.58 billion in 1994, which represented year-on-year growth of 19.5 percent. Production values climbed to US$14.07 billion in 1995 and US$16.99 billion in 1996, as year-on-year growth amounted to 21.5 percent in 1995 and 20.8 percent in 1996, said CEPD officials who were citing statistics provided by the Institute for Information Industry (III).

The growth rate declined, however, starting in 1997, when Taiwan's IT production value totaled US$19.07 billion, only 12 percent higher than in the previous year. Growth in 1998 amounted to a scant 1 percent, as Taiwan's IT production value totaled US$19.22 billion.
The plunge in Taiwan's domestic IT production value was related to Taiwan companies' moving their manufacturing operations to mainland China, noted CEPD officials.

The IT production value growth of several advanced countries continues to outpace Taiwan, even though they have higher labor costs, officials said. Last year production values climbed 10 percent in Britain, 8 percent in the United States, 5 percent in Germany and France, and 3 percent in Japan.
This shows there is still room for growth in the production of high-added-value products, an area on which Taiwan manufacturers should focus, said CEPD officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACEDONIA MINISTER VISITS AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION SITE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Macedonian Information Minister Rezxep Zllatku, leading a 30-member press group, on Thursday visited the Yunlin-based Han Kuang Fruit and Vegetable Production Cooperative Society in central Taiwan to study the cooperative's production and sales methods.
Zllatku was accompanied by Lin Shiang-nung, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, and by several Republic of China foreign affairs officials on the fact-finding visit.

He said he was very impressed by the island's ability to grow and sell produce, noting that cooperatives similar to Han Kuang that were established in the former Yugoslavia during the country's period of communist rule performed poorly.
Macedonia could learn from Taiwan in trying to establish agricultural production and sales systems, he said.
Han Kuang's turnover amounted to more than NT$540 million (US$16.77 million) last year, far above the levels of other cooperatives around the island.
The state-run cooperative currently has 213 members and its fields span 160 hectares. Twenty different kinds of fruits and vegetables are grown by the cooperative, according to Han Kuang executives.

Han Kuang's distribution channels include wholesale outlets and supermarkets, while it also sells vegetables under its own brand name. Looking to expand its markets, the group developed a membership system in which organically grown vegetables are delivered to member companies and households.
Zllatku arrived in Taipei on Sunday for a six-day visit, which is the first of its kind since Taipei and Skojpe set up officials links on Jan. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TIGHTENS INSPECTION OF AUSTRALIAN BEEF

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection (BSMI) said on Thursday it has tightened inspection of beef from Australia after South Korea detected that a batch of Australian beef contained excess endosulfan pesticide residue.

South Korean inspection and quarantine authorities found in late January that a batch of Australian beef contained 0.16 ppm (parts per million) of endosulfan residue, higher than the acceptable level of 0.1 ppm. South Korean customs service then impounded the contaminated Australian beef.
As South Korea is Australia's third largest beef market, after Japan and the United States, the incident has caused much concern in the Australian beef industry.

The Republic of China government has also expressed concern about the incident because Australia is one of Taiwan's major beef import sources. Taiwan imports an average of NT$2.4 billion (US$74.3 million) worth of beef from Australia annually.
The Cabinet-level Department of Health and the BSMI said they have taken necessary steps to prevent imports of contaminated Australian beef.

Meanwhile, the Australian Commerce and Industry Office (ACIO), which represents Australian interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, said the Australian government is concerned about the contamination incident and that the Australian quarantine office has cooperated closely with the ROC's public health and food inspection authorities in strengthening inspection of Australian beef.

An ACIO spokesman said that starting last November, Australian authorities have carefully inspected each batch of Australian beef to be imported to Japan and Taiwan. "Only those passing the examination would be exported. After the South Korean incident, we have even further tightened the inspection to ensure safety and wholesomeness of our products," he stressed.

The Australian representative said he feels that South Korean media had exaggerated the incident after one of 462 samples examined by South Korean authorities was found to contain excess pesticide residue.

An ROC inspection official said that the tolerable endosulfan content rate is set at 0.1 ppm in Taiwan. "Since we began to strengthen inspection of Australian beef, we have not yet found any sample containing excess endosulfan residue," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC NATURAL GAS PRICES LOWERED

TEXT.P: The advisory committee on oil and electricity prices under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) decided on Thursday to lower domestic natural gas prices.

The changes will go into effect immediately upon approval by the MOEA and will be retroactive to Feb. 1. After the price reductions are approved, China Petroleum Corp. (CPC) will then cut its natural gas prices.
Domestic-use natural gas prices will fall 11.1 percent, while prices for industrial-use natural gas will be lowered by 5.1 percent.
It is estimated that as many as 6 million domestic-use and 500 industrial-use customers will benefit from the price reductions.
The CPC sells natural gas to re-sellers in cities throughout Taiwan. The companies then sell the gas to the public, basing their prices on the cost of purchase.
The CPC is expected to enact several price reductions:
-- Locally produced natural gas for industrial use will fall in price from NT$7.26 to NT$6.89 per cubic meter;
-- Imported natural gas for industrial use will fall in price from NT$8.08 to NT$7.66 per cubic meter;
-- Locally produced gas for co-generation use will fall in price from NT$6.64 to NT$6.30 per cubic meter;
-- Imported natural gas for co-generation use will fall in price from NT$7.39 to NT$7.01 per cubic meter;
-- Natural gas from Taiwan Power Company's (Taipower) that is imported during the summer will fall in price from NT$6.91 to NT$6.55 per cubic meter; and
-- Natural gas from Taiwan Power Company's (Taipower) that is imported during non-summer months will fall in price from NT$6.56 to NT$6.22 per cubic meter.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCALLY BUILT HEART DEVICE TO START CLINICAL TRIALS

TEXT.P: The National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) announced on Thursday that it has successfully completed animal experiments with a locally built ventricular assist device and will apply to conduct human clinical trials soon.
NTUH Vice President Chu Shu-hsun said the new device, dubbed Taita (National Taiwan University) No.1, can allow patients with serious heart disease to wait longer for a heart transplant.

The device was designed and produced entirely by a group of NTUH cardiologists and experts in chemical engineering, electric engineering and other relevant fields from National Taiwan University, Chung Yuan Christian University and the National Science Council.

Chu, himself a cardiologist, said the device has already undergone trials with 30 small cattle weighing between 80 and 100 kilograms. One of the cattle died of pneumonia after the Taita No. 1 had been in place for 129 days.

"The 30th cattle in the trial, which is still under way, has had the device in place for 115 days," Chu said, adding that the cattle, which suffers from a heart condition called mitral insufficiency, is faring very well with the assistance of the Taita No. 1. "We hope it will set a new record for the use of the device."

Chu said NTU Hospital has applied for patent rights to the new device. "We will also apply for permission from the Department of Health to conduct human clinical trials on the Taita No. 1 in the near future."
With the success of the animal experiment, Chu said he is convinced that there will be no major problems for human beings using the new device.
Chu went on to say that the Taita No. 1 is smaller, lighter and cheaper than similar foreign-made instruments.
For instance, the pump installed in the Taita No. 1 weighs only 650 grams, while its battery weighs slightly more than 2 kilograms.

"The device can easily be transported by the average person. It is equipped with an 'intelligent controller' to adapt to the individual carrier's physiological conditions, and can be used for six hours on a single charge. More important, it is easy to operate, can be used repeatedly after sterilization and costs only NT$200,000 for each use," Chu explained.

In contrast, Chu said, similar foreign devices are usually bulky and very expensive. "The pump installed in a similar foreign instrument alone weighs 2 to 3 kilograms, and it costs NT$1 million for each use," he noted.

Chu said the device can help reduce the load on the heart, allowing patients with heart deficiencies to be able to wait longer for a heart transplant. "The longest recorded use of a ventricular assist device at NTU Hospital is 287 days," he said.
According to Chu, an average of 200 patients need heart transplants here each year, 10 to 20 of whom die during the waiting period for a suitable donor organ.
Chu said the new locally developed device is expected to help some of these patients to survive until a new heart becomes available for them.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slid NT$0.005 against the greenback Thursday on the Taipei market, closing at 32.285.
Dealer said sentiment toward the local currency will likely remain cool for a while because of a weak Japanese yen.
Japan's apparent inability to get its economic house in order could push the yen down even further, and a falling yen would likely drag down the NT dollar as well, dealers said.
There is concern on the market as to whether Taiwan's central bank will allow this to happen, they said.
The NT dollar opened at the day's high of 32.275 to the US dollar and fell to a low of 32.295 in the day's trading.
Interbank US dollar trading in Taipei reached US$253 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNET ID CARDS COMING TO SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: In a few years people in Singapore will carry an Internet identity card (IC) that they can use to apply for passports, pay traffic fees and renew drivers' licenses.

Stephen Yeo, chief executive of the National Computer Board (NCB), declined to say when the cards will be made available, though he did say that by 2001 half of Singapore's government services will be available online.
With the cards, government agencies could verify a person's identity before releasing important information or approving a transaction.
In the event of a dispute, the electronic trail left by the Internet IC would help to clear things up.
Yeo made the remarks at a press conference marking NCB's release of Electronic Transactions (Certification Authority) Regulations.
These regulations lay down the licensing guidelines for companies who want to issue online ICs and electronic signatures, which certify a person's identity in online transactions.
The regulations designate the NCB as the licensing and regulatory body of the certification industry.
Singapore currently has only one certification body -- Netrust -- which is owned by NCB and the Network for Electronic Transfers. Yeo said NCB will sell its stake now that it is a regulator.
The NCB's licensing scheme is open to all who meet its licensing and operational criteria, including foreign companies. But they must be based in Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: CREW OF PANAMANIAN FREIGHTER RESCUED

TEXT.P: The Republic of China military has sent a helicopter to rescue the crew of a Panamanian-registered freighter that ran aground off Keelung, northern Taiwan, on Thursday.
The crew was to be rescued before towing the freighter because of the difficulty involved in towing the freighter, the military said. Marine police also sent patrol boats to assist the operation.
The freighter ran aground Wednesday morning 17.5 nautical miles from Keelung Harbor. The freighter's Japanese and Philippine crew were all reported safe, as was the freighter's cargo.
The 6,225-ton freighter is scheduled to berth at Keelung Harbor.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOUSTON MAYOR BROWN VISITS PREMIER SIEW

TEXT.P: Houston Mayor Lee P. Brown met with Premier Vincent Siew Thursday to exchange views on how to enhance economic cooperation and to push for the establishment of direct flight connection between Houston and Taipei.

Brown, who is visiting Taipei at the head of a 10-member trade delegation, told Siew that Houston has transformed from an important energy center to a big high-tech center, and that the Houston international airport prodigiously serves 40 million passengers each year. He expressed the hope that a direct air link between Houston and Taipei will be established as soon as possible.

When they talked about the financial crisis sweeping Asia, Siew admitted that the crisis has considerable impact on Taiwan's stock market and export trade. The government is mapping out plans to turn the crisis into "a turning point for the better." Taiwan will be able to weather the Asian financial storm, partly because its economic fundamentals are still good, its consumer prices are stable, and its foreign exchange reserves are abundant, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REAFFIRMS WELCOME TO MAINLAND TOP NEGOTIATOR'S VISIT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Thursday reaffirmed its welcome to a planned visit to Taipei by mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan.
"We sincerely welcome Wang Daohan's planned visit to Taiwan," said Jan Jyh-horng, deputy secretary-general of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

Jan was responding to an allegation by mainland China's mouthpiece in Hong Kong, the Wen Wei Pao, saying that Taiwan's continued refusal to open political dialogue with the mainland will hinder Wang's Taiwan visit.
Jan said the Wen Wei Pao cannot represent the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
"What we really care is ARATS President Wang Daohan's personal opinion. Since Wang has expressed his desire to visit Taiwan, we'll wait for ARATS' response to our invitation," Jan said.

SEF faxed a message to ARATS on Jan. 22 inviting its mainland counterpart to send a deputy secretary-general to Taipei in late February to discuss details concerning Wang's planned Taiwan visit. ARATS already agreed to send a deputy secretary-general to Taipei to discuss the issue, but the timing has yet to be decided.
Jan said he hopes Beijing-affiliated organizations or media will not make unfounded allegations or politically-motivated rumors to affect the atmosphere for cross-strait engagement.
Wang's planned Taiwan visit is a reciprocal event to SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu's ice-melting visit to the mainland last October.
SEF and ARATS are semi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

Meanwhile, a senior mainland affairs official said on Thursday that cross-strait talks should first focus on issues related the well-being and legitimate rights and interests of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Wu An-chia, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland and oversees SEF operations, said now is not the right time for cross-strait political dialogue.

"If the two sides start discussion on highly sensitive political issues, such as unification, right now, no concrete results can be achieved. Worse yet, such talks would only make cross-strait relations become less flexible and even deadlocked," Wu explained.
He pointed out that the ROC's stance on cross-strait dialogue has been clear and consistent.
"We have consistently advocated consultation on the many practical issues arising from cross-strait civilian exchanges over the past 12 years," Wu said.

"Such issues include the repatriation of mainland hijackers, cross-strait fishing disputes, repatriation of illegal mainland immigrants and protection of personal safety and property rights of Taiwan investors on the mainland," Wu said, adding that all these problems should be resolved as soon as possible to boost the common well-being and rights of people on both sides of the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DENIES CANADIAN REQUEST TO ALLOW IMPORTS OF LIVESTOCK PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: Although Taiwan has agreed to open its market to limited imports of US livestock products before its entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), it will not concede to a similar demand from Canada, agricultural officials said on Thursday.
Taiwan's agriculture negotiations with Canada under the WTO framework are closed, and will not be reopened, said Cheng Chung-chiang, an official at Taiwan's Council of Agriculture (COA).

In order to join the WTO, Taiwan has completed negotiations with 26 WTO member states to ensure their support for its membership bid. All of them have signed bilateral agreements to endorse Taiwan's WTO bid, except for Canada and Hong Kong.
Hong Kong has refused to sign out of respect for Beijing's insistence that Taiwan should not be allowed to enter the trade regulatory group before Beijing's membership has been granted.

Canada has been stalling over its demands that it be accorded the same preferential treatment Taiwan granted to the United States, namely, annual imports from the United States of 1,000 metric tons of poultry, 5,000 metric tons of pig belly and rib, and 7,500 metric tons each of pig and cattle offal before the island's formal initiation into the WTO -- a so-called "down payment."
Cheng said that acceding to Ottawa's demands might cause other member states to renege on their signed agreements in order to get similar treatment.

Noting that Taiwan has already had to face numerous demands from WTO member states intent on prying open Taiwan's market, the official said that Taipei will not complicate its own application by bowing to Canada's demands.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN FIRMS TO BE AWARDED FOR PROCURING TAIWAN PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will present awards on Feb. 24 to several major international procurement organizations stationed in Taiwan for their contributions in procuring Taiwan products last year.

According to the MOEA, the five-star top award will go to Compaq, whose procurement of Taiwan-made computers and related products amounted to more than US$5 billion, accounting for 5 percent of Taiwan's total exports for 1998.

Two-star awards will be given to IBM, Dell and Hewlett Packard, whose buying ranged between US$1.5 billion and US$2.5 billion. Gateway 2000 and Apple will get one-star awards for procurements of between US$500 million and US$1.5 billion.
Awards will also be presented to Intel, Hitachi and NEC, whose purchases ranged between US$100 million and US$500 million.
Intel, HP and IBM will be given additional awards because their 1998 procurements in Taiwan increased by more than 50 percent over the preceding year.

Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang, Board of Foreign Trade Director-General Chen Ruey-long, and China External Trade Development Council Chairman Lin Chen-kuo will present the awards to the outstanding foreign companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDYING WAYS OF COUNTERING MAINLAND CHINA MISSILE THREAT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Defense Minister Tang Fei said on Thursday that Taiwan has not yet decided whether to join the theater missile defense (TMD) system, but has been studying ways of countering the missile threat from mainland China.
Tang made the comments in response to a foreign press report that mainland China has deployed 150-200 M9 and M11 missiles in southern China, aimed at Taiwan.

He said the mainland move was apparently prompted by Taiwan's study of whether or not to take part in the US-proposed TMD system, adding that Beijing's move "will heighten the tension between Taiwan and the mainland."

The defense minister noted that besides the M9 and M11 missiles, mainland China also possesses submarines, missile destroyers and SU-27 jet fighters, deployment of which would definitely affect the stability of the region.

Tang pointed out that mainland China's missiles are certain to greatly affect the morale of the people of Taiwan, and cited as an example of this the worry and apprehension caused here by mainland China's military exercises in the Taiwan Strait three years ago.
Although the study of ways to defend the island against mainland missiles is very costly, he went on, the country should maintain sufficient defense capability to protect the security of the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO PULL TAIWAN THROUGH ECONOMIC STORM

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew expressed confidence on Thursday that Taiwan will weather the regional financial storm and became an "unsinkable aircraft carrier" in the economic field.

On the eve of an extraordinary conference on the current economic problems and their resolution, Siew said that Taiwan is feeling the bite of the regional economic tumult through its finances and falling exports, but has been spared the blunt of the crisis because of its freedom from problems regarding trade deficit, lack of foreign reserves, fleeing foreign capital, and fluctuating exchange rates which have plagued its neighbors in Southeast Asia.
Taiwan's problems stem from inside rather than outside, said Siew, referring to the heavy exposure to high-leverage ventures in the bourse and property market by some local firms.
The failure of those firms threatens the fabric of the economy and has significantly eroded investor confidence, he said.
In order to address the issues, Siew said his government has prescribed both short-term measures to calm down the market, and a long-term cure to revamp the ailing economic structure.

The short-term measures, aimed at stabilizing the economy and financial market, will be subject to regular review to ensure they will not disrupt the effect of the long-term measures by affecting market forces.

He spelled out five directions for the government's future efforts: the streamlining of the financial and fiscal system; the revamping of the labor market; the reviewing of the policies on land and property; and the reorganization of businesses.

Warning that the financial crisis is not yet over, Siew called on the private sector to join forces with the government and work true to form as the leader of the "four Asian tigers" by pulling the nation through the current crisis.
Friday's economic conference will bring together 140 representatives from the government, industry, academic circles, and lawmakers for two days of discussions.
The government is hoping the meeting will chart a map that will guide the country out of the economic doldrums.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MISSILE DEPLOYMENT UNFRIENDLY: MAC CHIEF

TEXT.P: Beijing's deployment of missiles targeting Taiwan is an unfriendly move and will adversely affect the feelings of the people of Taiwan toward mainland China, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Su Chi said on Thursday.
In the face of the missile threat, Taiwan is entitled to consider ways to enhance its defenses, Su said in an exclusive interview with CNA.

He was referring to news reports that Beijing has targeted 150 to 200 of it's M-9 and M-11 missiles deployed in southern mainland China at Taiwan, and that Taiwan is assessing the possibility of participating in the US-initiated Theater Missile Defense system (TMD).

Su, who was deputy secretary-general to President Lee Teng-hui before taking his MAC post on Feb. 1, urged all the countries of the world to pay attention to Beijing's recent military build-up, saying it will not only worry neighboring Japan, but also pose a threat to the security and interests of the United States, Australia, and the countries of Southeast Asia.
On Beijing's objection to Taiwan's role in the TMD system, Su said that it's still too early to say whether Taiwan will join the system.
Beijing's opposition to the TMD, like its recent arrest of 30 mainland dissidents preparing to form a new political party, is nothing but a strategy "to nip trouble in the bud," Su said.
Rebutting Beijing vice premier Qian Qichen's allegation that the shrinking of Taiwan's diplomatic space is becoming a trend, Su said: "It's Beijing that has been pushing this trend.
"Without the `pushing hand' (Beijing), the trend would be reversed," he added.

On the timing of a long-awaited visit to Taipei by Wang Daohan, mainland's top negotiator with Taiwan and chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), Su said that Taipei will not set any specific date for Wang's visit. "He will be welcome here any time this year."
Wang's Taipei trip in 1999 was part of the consensus reached between Wang and Koo Chen-fu, Chairman of Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) late last year in Shanghai.

Spelling out his expectations for Wang's visit, Su said that the visit, if it proceeds well, will help improve cross-strait relations, thus giving a boost to the possibility of a historical meeting between Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, and contributing to regional peace and security.

Su also rejected Beijing's snub of Lee's concept of "neo Taiwan persons," a new term spelled out by the president while campaigning for Taipei mayoral candidate Ma Ying-jeou in last December's election.

"What we term ourselves is our internal affair, one which Beijing is not in a position to interfere with ... and if the Beijing authorities are not happy with our calling ourselves the Republic of China, why can't we say we are Taiwan?" he added.

With regard to the stationing of mainland reporters in Taiwan on a regular basis, Su said Taipei would welcome mainland reporters to Taiwan, but their long-term stay in the island should be decided only after negotiations between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Existing statutes devised to stimulate industrial development and restructure will be prolonged for another 10 years, says Premier Vincent Siew.
The China Times:
The status of the Security and Futures Commission will be raised.
The United Daily News:
The Security and Futures Commission proposes credit monitoring before stock transactions are made, following with immediate settlement.
The Liberty Times:
Industrial and business sectors call for the government to issue bonds which can be used to purchase blue-chip stock issues.
The Commons Daily:
Opposition Democratic Progressive Party condemns the Kuomintang as the source of money- and gang-politics.
The China Post:
KMT to blame for ROC's woes, says opposition.
The China News:
Cash injection to lift economy -- NT$30 B. debt fund part of long-term policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: BURGHARDT TO REPLACE JOHNSON AS AIT TAIPEI DIRECTOR
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 11 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Raymond F. Burghardt, the US consul general in Shanghai, has been selected by the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) as the new director of its Taipei office, replacing Darryl N. Johnson, AIT headquarters in Washington said on Thursday.

AIT Chairman and Managing Director Richard Bush said the appointment represents a further progression in an outstanding career. "He will be an able successor to Darryl Johnson, and I look forward to working together with him in building US-Taiwan relations," Bush said.
Bush said he has known Ray Burghardt for a number of years, and has always been impressed by his intelligence, his seriousness and his dedication.

The State Department, meanwhile, announced that Burghardt will depart his post in Shanghai this summer, and will take up his new post in Taipei after returning briefly to the United States for a vacation.

According to an AIT news release Thursday, Burghardt was appointed the American consul general in Shanghai in 1997, which gave him the status of minister-counselor in the United States Foreign Service. He had previously served as Deputy Chief of Mission at the US Embassies in Manila from 1993 to 1996 and in Seoul from 1990 to 1993.
In Seoul, he was the charge d'affaires ad interim in 1993 during the first six months of the first Clinton administration.

Burghardt's previous positions also included an stint with the National Security Council staff as a special assistant to former President Ronald Reagan and as senior director of Latin American affairs. His earlier Latin American experience included service at the US embassies in Honduras and Guatemala, according to the AIT news release.

Burghardt was a political counselor in Beijing from 1987 to 1989. He has also worked as a political officer in Hong Kong and Saigon and as deputy director of the State Department's Office of Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia Affairs.

Burghardt was born in New York City in 1945 and grew up in the New York metropolitan area. He received a B.A. from Columbia College in 1967 and did graduate work at the Columbia School of International and Public Affairs. He served as a Peace Corps volunteer in Colombia, South America, before joining the Foreign Service in 1969.
Burghardt is married to the former Susan Day. They have two daughters. He speaks Mandarin Chinese, which he studied in Taichung, as well as Spanish, Vietnamese and French.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 12, or the 27th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1809: Abraham Lincoln, the US president who was assassinated a few days after the end of the Civil War, is born.
1851: Fortune hunters rush to the town of Bathurst in the Blue Mountains of New South Wales, Australia, in search for gold.
1895: Japan scores an impressive victory at Weihaiwei in northern China where the Japanese forces quickly breach the Chinese defenses and sink most of its northern navy after the war between the Ching court and Japan broke out in 1894.
1899: Germany purchases the Marianas Islands, the Caroline Islands and Palau in the Pacific from Spain.
1908: The first global Grand Prix is inaugurated at Times Square in New York.
1912: Henry Pu Yi abdicates as emperor of China, ending the rule of the Manchu dynasty.
1941: A group of researchers led by Howard Florey of Australia and Ernst Chain of Germany develop a method of extracting and purifying small amounts of penicillin, which was first used by physicians to treat a human being a day later when the drug was given to a British policeman suffering from blood poisoning.
1964: Japanese Premier Shigeru Yoshida arrives in the Republic of China to confer with President Chiang Kai-shek.
1970: An express trains collide north of Hsinchu, killing 10 and injuring 47.
1974: Soviet Nobel Prize winner Alexander Solzhenitsyn is arrested in Moscow and exiled the following day.
1975: People in South Korea vote to adopt a new constitution that gives the president almost unlimited power and permits him to serve an unlimited number of terms.
1980: Hong Kong's subway is formally inaugurated.
1987: The US Air Force successfully launches "Titan 3B" missiles into orbit above the North and South Poles.
1996: Faced with threatening military maneuvers undertaken by Beijing, the Executive Yuan sets up a temporary policy-making task force to closely follow developments and coordinate the actions of various agencies to respond to the situation.
1997: Hwang Jang Yop, a confidant of North Korean leader Kim Jong Il, defects in Beijing and seeks asylum in South Korea.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Extravagance leads to excess; thrift to meanness; but it is better to be mean than to be guilty of excess."

DOC.HEADLINE: US PLEDGES CLOSE MONITORING OF CROSS-STRAIT SITUATION

TEXT.P: The US government on Thursday played down the significance of news reports about mainland China's missile build-up against Taiwan, but promised to monitor closely the military balance across the Taiwan Strait.
Government spokesmen also reiterated strong US interest in peace and stability in the area and said it will continue to assist Taiwan in meeting its defense needs.
"We have a strong interest in maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait," said Joe Lockhart, the White House press secretary.
"We have supplied, for this reason, defensive arms to Taiwan consistent with the Taiwan Relations Act," he added.

Answering questions at a regular briefing, he said that the United States will continue to closely monitor the military balance in the Taiwan Strait and to provide Taiwan with the arms it needs for adequate defense.
The assurance came after several news reports this week about mainland China's massive missile build-up vis-a-vis Taiwan.
But Lockhart and the spokesmen for both the State Department and the Pentagon refuted any suggestion of major new changes in mainland China's missile deployment.
Growing deployment near Taiwan "is not a new threat" but in fact stretches back more than five years, said James Foley, deputy spokesman of the State Department.
"Reports that suggest that there has been a sudden new deployment are wrong," he said.
He refused to be drawn when asked whether the deployment poses a threat to Taiwan that needs a US response.
"Military capabilities are military capabilities, he said. "And what is often as important are intentions, the political context behind military capabilities."
He reiterated the United States' intention to continue to assess the requirements for maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.
At briefings at the White House, the State Department and the Department of Defense, the US reaction to mainland China's missile intimidation of Taiwan three years ago was mentioned.
"The testing of these missiles in 1996 precipitated the US deploying to the area two carrier groups to the Strait," said the White House press secretary.
On the question of whether Taiwan would be included in the US-led Theater Missile Defense (TMD) umbrella, both Foley and Lockhart said that relevant technologies are some years away from maturity.

They said that a decision will be made in the future, "taking into account the development of such technologies, Taiwan's defense needs, and how, in our view, it is best to maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait."
Both Foley and Capt. Michael Doubleday, the Pentagon's deputy spokesman, also pointed out that Taiwan is addressing its own defense needs and so far their interest in TMD is primarily informational.
Capt. Doubleday also said that two Taiwan-related studies mandated by Congress are still being reviewed by Pentagon officials and will be submitted in the near future.
One of the reports deals with the establishment of TMD for US allies in East Asia and the other addresses the military balance across the Taiwan Strait.
Their submissions have been delayed from Jan. 1 and Feb. 1, respectively, amid reported differences between the Pentagon, the State Department and the National Security Council over the contents.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER VISITS PARAGUAYAN PRESIDENT, TOURS SCHOOLS
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Feb. 10 (CNA) (By Ramond Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The minister of the Republic of China's Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) met with Paraguayan President Raul Cubas Grau on Thursday and invited him to visit Taiwan on behalf of ROC President Lee Teng-hui.
Chiao Jen-ho was formally introduced to Cubas at the meeting by Paraguayan Foreign Affairs Minister Dido Florentin Bogado.

After the 60-minute meeting, Chiao said in an interview with CNA that during the talk he thanked Cubas for ensuring the protection of ROC nationals living in Paraguay. He said such safety guarantees would attract more ROC business investment into the Latin American country.

Chiao on Thursday also visited Chinese schools in Paraguay. Speaking of OCAC's works to promote overseas Chinese education, the minister stressed that promoting Chinese-language courses in schools overseas has been one of the OCAC's major tasks.

The OCAC spends half of its funds each year to supply equipment to overseas Chinese schools and to improve the quality of instruction at those schools. The commission is now working to develop online Chinese-language courses available over the Internet, he said.

Meanwhile, Chiao added, the OCAC is also very willing to serve as "matchmaker" that works to establish sister ties between educational institutions in Taiwan and those that serve ethnic Chinese students overseas.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI WELCOMES BURGHARDT'S APPOINTMENT AS HEAD OF TAIPEI AIT OFFICE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Friday welcomed the appointment of Raymond F. Burghardt as the new director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), the de facto US embassy in Taiwan.

Chen Ming-cheng, deputy director of MOFA's Department of Information and Cultural Affairs, said Burghardt's selection is appropriate as he is a seasoned diplomat especially familiar with East Asian affairs.
Formerly deputy chief of mission at US embassies in South Korea and the Philippines, Burghardt has enjoyed favorable comment among diplomatic circles in Asia, Chen noted.
Darryl Johnson, who has been AIT's Taipei director for nearly three years, is expected to leave his post this summer when his current tenure expires.
The AIT, established by the Taiwan Relations Act of 1979, is authorized to handle US-Taiwan relations in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLAR WORRIED ABOUT BEIJING-HONG KONG RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Objections by mainland Chinese authorities to a decision by Hong Kong's Court of Final Appeal has set the stage for a profound crisis in mainland China's relationship with Hong Kong, a scholar said .

In an article in The Australian Financial Review on Friday, Yash Ghai, professor of public law at the University of Hong Kong, said central to this principle is not only a high degree of autonomy for the region, but also the maintenance of separate economic, political and social systems.

Mainland China appeared to be taking a largely hands-off approach to Hong Kong until last week. But the decision by a Hong Kong court granting mainland-born children of Hong Kong citizens the right to live in the former British colony has drawn fire from mainland authorities.

Ghai said: "Legality was always considered central to the security of the arrangements for the autonomy of Hong Kong. First there are international legal foundations for the autonomy in the shape of the Sino-British Joint Declaration under which Britain agreed to transfer Hong Kong to China in return for assurances of high autonomy."
He said the Basic Law of Hong Kong, which translates these assurances into domestic constitutional law, has the high status of an Organic Law of the National People's Congress.
The rule of law is universally regarded as indispensable to Hong Kong's market economy, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO BE TRANSFORMED INTO FINANCIAL CENTER

TEXT.P: Prime Minister John Howard wants to turn Australia into a global financial center that would compete with Hong Kong and Singapore, by introducing tax changes to attract multinational companies to the country.
Howard has asked his Cabinet to convene a meeting next month to submit relevant measures, including changes to the tax system that would remove key obstacles, government officials said.
They said the changes include changing aspects of Australia's capital gains tax and personal tax for expatriates.
Howard is considering a visit to the United States in the second half of this year to promote Australia as a strong and stable destination for foreign investors, the officials said.
He has asked Financial Services Minister Joe Hockey to map out measures that could make Australia competitive as a global center.
"We are in a three-way arm wrestle with Hong Kong and Singapore. We want to win," Hockey told reporters on Thursday.

"At the moment, you have 10 or 11 global financial centers. That will come down to six in the next 10 years. We will not be a New York or a London, but we want to make sure we are in the top six. We are anxious to move. There is no doubt that the rapid convergence in international financial institutions is speeding our timetable," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWAZILAND TO ESTABLISH EMBASSY BY JULY: MOFA

TEXT.P: Swaziland, one of eight African diplomatic allies of the Republic of China, will establish an embassy here by the end of July, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday.
The government welcomes the plan, which is pending the approval of Swaziland's Parliament, to set up an embassy here, said Timothy Yang, director-general of MOFA's Department of African Affairs.

Yang noted that the Republic of China and Swaziland have had formal diplomatic ties for three decades, and both sides have participated in extensive exchanges and cooperation programs in various fields, adding that the establishment of an embassy will help boost bilateral cooperation, facilitate Taiwan investment in the African county and boost bilateral relations.
He said that it is expected that Swaziland will set up an embassy here by the end of July.
Swaziland's ambassador to South Korea, Clifford Mamba, will serve concurrently as its ambassador to the Republic of China, Yang said.

Swaziland will be the sixth ROC ally in Africa to set up an embassy here, joining Liberia, Gambia, Senegal, Chad and Burkina Faso. Among the ROC's African allies, only Malawi and Sao Tome and Principe have yet to establish embassies here.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING LEADER ADVISED TO VISIT TIBET: REPORT

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin is mulling over a proposal from advisers that he visit Tibet later this year to help pacify anti-Beijing sentiment, according to a report carried in The South China Morning Post on Friday.
Pro-independence activities in Tibet and Xinjiang are deemed serious threats to stability, the report said.
It quoted a Beijing source as saying that the authorities had mobilized new resources to ensure law and order in Tibet in the run-up to the 40th anniversary of an anti-Beijing uprising in the spring.
"Jiang will only go to Tibet when the situation has calmed down," a diplomatic source was reported as saying.
"His party standing will be immensely boosted if his visit there can help cool anti-Han Chinese sentiments."
The source said a trip to Tibet in the 1980s by late party general-secretary Hu Yao-bang paved the way for a temporary improvement in Beijing-Tibet ties.

But analysts said Beijing has found it more difficult to deal with splittist activities in Xinjiang. Security agents, the report said, have recently discovered new channels through which Xinjiang activists were smuggling explosives and other weapons into the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: JEFFREY KOO SUGGESTS GOV'T CREATE BOND FUND TO SAVE LOCAL BOURSE

TEXT.P: A domestic business tycoon suggested on Friday that the government raise NT$400 billion by selling government bonds and use the money to buy blue chip stocks on the local stock market in an effort to save the bourse.

Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, offered the suggestion after three major industrial and commercial groups made similar proposals at a national meeting on Taiwan's economic and financial situation organized by the Cabinet.
The national meeting on Taiwan's economic and financial situation opened Friday and will close Saturday.

Koo noted Japan's success in using funds generated through bond sales to prop up a sagging stock market two years ago. Japanese banks and securities brokerage companies jointly set up a 230-billion-yen government bond fund in 1997, when Japan's stock market was in the doldrums. The fund produced impressive results, he said.

Issuing government bonds to generate funds for purchasing blue chip stocks would not only stabilize the market but also increase the national treasury's revenue through the imposition of securities transaction taxes, Koo said.

Kao Ching-yuan, chairman of Chinese National Federation of Industries, said that although the government established a NT$200 billion stock market stabilization fund to prop up the market in recent days, only NT$40 billion of the fund was used to purchase shares. The effect of the government's purchases on the market was not significant, he said.

Kao said that if the government raises funds to purchase blue chip stocks through the sale of government bonds, then perhaps government intervention into the market would have the desired stabilizing effect.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNFI CHAIRMAN HOPES TO VISIT MAINLAND IF CROSS-STRAIT TIES IMPROVED

TEXT.P: An influential Taiwan business leader said on Friday that if Beijing's top negotiator with Taiwan visits Taipei as planned, and cross-strait talks proceed in a harmonious atmosphere, he may consider visiting mainland China this year.

Kao Chin-yen, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) and chairman of the President Group, made the remarks during an economic conference sponsored by the Executive Yuan.

Kao is also a member of the ruling Kuomintang's policymaking Central Standing Committee. He last visited mainland China in August 1996, at the head of a major business delegation. During that trip, he met with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.

It was the first trade promotion delegation to mainland China since cross-strait ties became strained earlier that year when Beijing conducted a series of war games in waters near Taiwan in an attempt to influence the island's first direct presidential election.

Kao said that he is looking forward to the visit to Taiwan by Chairman Wang Daohan of Beijing's Association for Relation Across the Taiwan Strait, and that he believes the visit will help improve cross-strait relations.
He also said that a successful visit by Wang might prompt the ROC government to relax its restrictive policy toward investment in the mainland.
The policy was initiated by President Lee Teng-hui in the wake of Kao's 1996 visit, a move which was aimed at avoiding Taiwan's over-reliance on the mainland Chinese market.
Since then, Kao has taken a low-key attitude toward the issues of cross-strait trade and economic exchanges.

The business tycoon's statement on Friday broke his silence on the matter, as he announced his wish to lead another economic and trade delegation on a market-inspection visit to mainland China before he steps down from the position of CNFI chairman at the end of February 2000.
