DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO RESHAPE ROC ECONOMIC STRUCTURE

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Friday vowed to strive to reshape Taiwan's economic structure and systems in order to make the island into an "unsinkable aircraft carrier" in the Asia-Pacific economic arena.

Addressing the opening of an extraordinary conference on Taiwan's current economic problems and their resolution, Siew said that although Taiwan has been fortunate enough to retain its status and flexibility as Asia's "economic little giant" amid the Asian financial meltdown, it needs to restructure its economy and related systems from the top down.

Although Taiwan has not been able to free itself entirely from the Asian economic storm, the country managed to achieve a 4.8 percent growth rate in 1998, which Siew described as "really something, even though not very satisfactory."

In recent months, however, Taiwan has become mired in a series of economic and financial problems, which have stemmed from the inside rather than the outside. These problems have included heavy exposure to high-leverage ventures in the bourse and property market by some local firms. The subsequent failure of those firms now threatens the fabric of the economy and has eroded investor confidence, Siew pointed out.

Despite the irregularities, he said, various indices show that most of the problems are still under control. For example, he said, the rate of overdue loans given by domestic banks is at an average of under 5 percent, while the rate of self-held capitalization by enterprises averages 54 percent, much higher than in other Asian countries.

Siew stressed that Taiwan has absolutely no need to worry about being caught in the last stages of the Asian financial meltdown. Taiwan has an economy which is basically healthy, solid foreign exchange reserves, considerable creditor's rights on debts to foreign countries, and commendable crisis-handling experience in both the public and private sectors, he noted.

Meanwhile, P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, who also spoke at the opening session, forecast that Taiwan's exports will resume growth this year, with investments from the private sector being the prime mover behind the country's overall economic growth.
With the telecommunications, oil, and domestic aviation markets opening further, Chiang predicted that Taiwan's overall economic growth will top 5 percent this year.
The economic conference has brought together nearly 200 representatives from the government, industry, academic circles, and lawmakers, for one-and-a-half days of discussions.
It is hoped that the meeting will chart a map that will guide the country out of the economic doldrums.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WATCHING REPORTS FROM VATICAN CLOSELY

TEXT.P: The government is taking careful note of reports that the Vatican would switch its embassy from Taipei to Beijing if mainland China were to allow it, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday.

R.T. Yang, director-general of MOFA's Department of European Affairs, said that he was not surprised by the news that the Vatican hopes to establish ties with mainland China, pointing out that the Vatican has always wanted to set up such ties to protect the religious freedom of the mainland's Catholic population.

Yang made the remarks after an AFP report quoted Cardinal Angelo Sodano, the secretary of state of the Holy See, as saying that "the Taipei nunciature is the nunciature in China," at a reception at the Italian embassy to the Vatican to mark the 70th anniversary of the Latteran accord between Italy and the Catholic city state.
"The Church would move it back to Beijing this evening if the (mainland) Chinese authorities permitted," Sodano was also quoted as saying.
But he also said that the move would not entail breaking off relations with Taiwan.
Yang stressed that the ROC's ties with the Vatican have always been close, and that exchange visits from both sides have been extensive.
The Vatican was the ROC's only diplomatic ally in Europe prior to Jan. 27 this year, when ties were established with Macedonia.

Beijing does not recognize the authority of the Vatican over Catholics in the mainland, and appoints its own bishops of its "patriotic" church. This has been the main hurdle preventing the establishment of relations between the two.
It is understood that the mainland would require the Vatican to sever ties with the ROC before it would consider entering talks about establishing ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF HOPES SENIOR ARATS OFFICIALS WILL VISIT TAIWAN IN FEBRUARY

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) wrote to its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), once again on Friday to ask it to send an official to Taiwan to discuss matters concerning its chairman's trip to Taiwan.
Sheu Ke-sheng, vice chairman and spokesman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), told reporters that Taipei welcomes the earliest possible visit by ARATS' Chairman Wang Daohan.
Sheu said the MAC consented to the SEF's contacting ARATS again to request a visit by a deputy secretary-general to Taiwan to discuss Wang's trip to the island.
Responding to questions from reporters, Sheu said the SEF letter had no relation to a recent violent incident when a mainland Chinese hijacker attacked an SEF official while being repatriated.

Four of nine mainland Chinese hijackers who were scheduled to be handed over to mainland authorities were held for questioning on Monday after one of them slashed the neck of SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng, who was overseeing the repatriation.

Regarding Wang's Taiwan trip, the SEF last contacted ARATS on Jan. 22, expressing its hope that ARATS would send a deputy secretary-general to Taiwan to discuss relevant matters before the end of February. ARATS agreed to the request on Feb. 1, and said it would inform the SEF about the appropriate time for Wang's trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: VATICAN MAINTAINS CONTACTS WITH BEIJING, SAYS ROC AMBASSADOR

TEXT.P: Although the Vatican maintains cordial relations with the Republic of China, it has also been in continuous contact with Beijing in the hope of protecting the rights and interests of the Catholic community in mainland China, ROC Ambassador to the Holy See Raymond Tai said on Friday.

In a telephone interview with the CNA, Tai said that both Beijing and the Vatican have always wanted to improve their bilateral ties, and have constantly exchanged views on the issue through private channels.
Secretary of State of the Holy See Cardinal Angelo Sodano said on Thursday that the Vatican would switch its embassy from Taipei to Beijing if the Chinese communist authorities would allow it.

Sodano made the remarks during a cocktail party held at the Italian embassy in Vatican City on Thursday. He also noted that the move would not mean breaking off formal relations with Taiwan, but would entail returning the nunciature to Beijing.

Tai said that there are still a number of stumbling blocks preventing ties between Beijing and the Vatican, including Beijing's demands that the Vatican sever diplomatic ties with the ROC and not interfere with mainland China's internal affairs.

The Vatican, meanwhile, maintains close and cordial ties with Taipei, and insists that all bishops around the world should be named only by the Pope. In defiance of that rule, Beijing names its own bishops to its rival "Patriotic" church.
Some 4 million mainland Chinese belong to the "Patriotic" church, while an estimated 10 million maintain their allegiance to the Vatican despite harassment and persecution by the Beijing authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: COSTA RICAN AMBASSADOR PRESENTS CREDENTIALS

TEXT.P: Oscar Alvarez Araya, Costa Rica's new ambassador to the Republic of China, presented his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui on Friday.
President Lee extended a warm welcome to the new ambassador on behalf of the ROC government and the people, and asked him to convey his greetings to Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez.

Lee noted that the ROC and Costa Rica are traditionally close allies, and that various projects are under way in the Central American country with ROC assistance, such as the establishment of an industrial zone, the nurturing of local talent, and road and bridge construction.
He also said that the two sides should maintain close contact in order to improve the quality of life for the people of Costa Rica.
Forty-nine-year-old Ambassador Alvarez said he considered it an honor to work in the Republic of China, and vowed to serve the job to the best of his ability.

He also expressed appreciation for the assistance extended to his country by the ROC over the years, and added that both countries share the same ideals of democracy, freedom, love of peace and the protection of human rights. He also pledged that Costa Rica will continue to support the ROC's bids to enter international organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.007 against the greenback Friday on the Taipei market, closing at the day's high of 32.278.
The local currency opened at 32.286, and had a low of 32.306.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$388 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, PHOENIX MARK 20 YEARS OF SISTERHOOD TIES
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Feb. 11 (CNA) (By Lawrence Chu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Phoenix City, the capital of the US state of Arizona, on Thursday kicked off a weeklong "China festival" to mark the 20th anniversary of its sisterhood ties with Taipei.

Taipei City Councilor Wei Yi-lung, traveling at the head of a large-scale delegation composed of personnel of the Taipei City Council and Taipei City Government, went to Phoenix to take part in the event.

The two cities became sister cities 20 years ago when ROC President Lee Teng-hui was serving as Taipei City mayor. Over the past two decades, the two sides have cultivated a profound friendship through a broad range of exchanges.

A seminar will be held on Thursday to find ways to strengthen bilateral economic exchanges, while the local Chinese community will sponsor an exhibition displaying arts and crafts from China and the United States.
On Friday evening, the Taipei Municipal Chinese Music Symphony Orchestra will stage a recital.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAD BUSINESS MANAGEMENT WEAKENING TAIWAN'S ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's sluggish economy has been mainly caused by bad management in the country's enterprise sector, according to Chairman Kao Chin-yen of the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI).

At an Executive Yuan conference on the island's economic straits and strategies on Friday, Kao rebutted reports blaming Taiwan's declining economic development on the Asian financial meltdown, and urged the government to help promote domestic business operations.

The business tycoon stated that further opening of the labor market to imported foreign workers and incentive measures to encourage private investment and domestic demand are the only sure ways to pump up the island's economic energy.

Asked whether or not he supports a call from the business sector demanding that the government lower the stock trading tax, Kao said he thinks the authorities should assess the feasibility of such a move before making any decision.
He pointed out that a NT$50 billion (US$1.55 billion) reduction could be expected in the government's tax revenue each year if the tax is lowered. (By Elizabeth Hsu) ENDITEM/J

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CONTACTS ARATS FOR TOP ENVOY'S VISIT

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) on Friday contacted its Beijing counterpart to offer Chinese New Year greetings and to urge it to speed up the visit of mainland China's top envoy.
The faxed message to the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) called on authorities to send ARATS officials to Taipei soon to discuss ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan's Taiwan visit.

A meeting between SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu and Wang last October laid a solid foundation for increased bilateral exchanges, SEF Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow said. He added that efforts from both sides, rather than prerequisites set by just one side, are needed to implement the four points of consensus reached during the last Koo-Wang summit.

Stressing that Taiwan and mainland China should further strengthen their dialogue, Shi said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should first resolve pressing issues of major concern -- such as the repatriation of mainland hijackers and illegal mainland immigrants as well as cross-strait fishing disputes -- instead of wasting time on lofty political matters.
Shi said the SEF and ARATS have already worked on these issues during their previous talks and the two sides should continue efforts to wrap up talks on these matters.

Regarding Wang's planned visit to Taiwan, the SEF has already sent a letter to ARATS on Jan. 22, asking it to dispatch officials of vice secretary-general rank to Taipei by February for talks to pave the way for the ARATS chairman's Taiwan trip.
In a response dated Feb. 1, ARATS said it will send a vice secretary-general to Taipei and will notify the SEF at a proper time.
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official organizations authorized by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to deal with bilateral exchanges in the absence of official contact between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL ADVISOR PROPOSES CAPITAL MARKET STABILIZING MEASURES

TEXT.P: A senior advisor to President Lee Teng-hui on Friday proposed effective measures be taken to stabilize the domestic capital market.
Koo Chen-fu made the suggestion at a Cabinet-organized national meeting on the economic and financial situation, which opened on Friday and will close on Saturday.
The measures proposed by Koo, who is also honorary chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, included:
-- News media should refrain from publishing unconfirmed reports and speculation that might impact investor confidence;
-- The government should actively crack down on people who spread rumors that adversely affect the stock market;
-- A sound bond market should be established and the 0.1 percent bond transactions tax should be abolished; and
-- The Securities and Futures Commission under the Ministry of Finance should be promoted to Cabinet-level.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR SEEKS TOUGHER ACTION ON DOMESTIC VIOLENCE PREVENTION

TEXT.P: Between 11.7 percent and 35 percent of Taiwan's women are living under the threat of domestic violence, making it an issue to which the government should pay close attention, Legislator Pan Wei-kang said on Friday.
Pan made the remarks in a press conference at the Legislative Yuan shortly after her return from a domestic violence prevention fact-finding mission to the United States.
According to US statistics provided by Pan, one woman every 15 seconds is a victim of domestic violence, and four women die every day as a result of this form of abuse.

While Taiwan's situation is not as serious as that of the United States, several recently reported local domestic violence cases show that deep economic problems are involved, making the issue more complex than a simple social problem. Pan therefore urged the responsible government agencies to give the matter the attention it deserves.

With the approach of Feb. 14 -- Valentine's Day -- Pan said the best Valentine gift she can present to the island's families is a pledge to cooperate with the legislature, the judiciary, the police, and medical and social work organizations to form an alliance to battle domestic violence, and to go even further by forging a relationship with the US-based anti-domestic violence union.

Another member of Pan's mission, who is also a high court judge, suggested empowering the police with more authority when they are summoned to incidents of domestic violence, to encourage them to get more actively involved in such cases.

Meanwhile, the Sexual Abuse Prevention Committee under the Ministry of the Interior, which was also present at the press conference, said that new laws on domestic violence will be implemented in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, MACEDONIA INK NEWS EXCHANGE AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: An agreement for promoting news exchanges between Macedonia and the Republic of China was initialed in Taipei Saturday.

Director General Chen Chien-jen of the Government Information Office, who initialed the agreement with Macedonian Information Minister Rezxep Zllatku, said the agreement will promote mutual understanding and facilitate the promotion of mutually beneficial relations between the two countries, which established diplomatic relations on Jan. 27.
Zllatku arrived in Taipei Sunday at the head of a 30-member press delegation for a six-day visit.

An official said Foreign Minister Jason Hu will lead a large delegation of Taiwan businessmen to Mocedonia in late February to study the investment climate in the country in Europe. Vice Foreign Minister David T. Lee will also visit the country at the head of a similar delegation in late March. The premiers and other government leaders of the two countries will also exchange visits in the near future, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT RECEIVES MACEDONIAN INFORMATION MINISTER

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan on Friday received Macedonian Information Minister Rexhep Zllatku, stating that Taipei will engage in cooperation and exchanges in all fields with the southern European country.
The ROC and Macedonia established diplomatic relations on Jan. 27 which prompted Beijing to sever its formal ties with Macedonia early this week.
Lien told Zllatku that, "The relationship across the Taiwan Strait is not a zero-sum game. We hope to see a win for both sides."

He voiced regret over Beijing's move to sever ties with Macedonia, saying that the ROC does not want to see Beijing cut off relations with any country following that country's establishment of relations with Taipei.
Zllatku said his country's policy of setting up diplomatic relations with Taipei has been firm, adding that he hopes the two countries will strengthen bilateral cooperation and exchanges.
Earlier in the day, Zllatku and a 20-member press delegation from Macedonia visited the Legislative Yuan. They exchanged views with Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and several legislators.

Wang told the Macedonian delegation that with the establishment of diplomatic relations, he believes Taiwan and Macedonia will help each other benefit in the area of politics, economy, science and technology, culture, and sports.
Zllatku arrived in Taipei on Feb. 7 for a weeklong visit, becoming the first Macedonian minister to visit Taiwan following the establishment of diplomatic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: JORDAN'S NEW KING RECEIVES ROC ENVOY

TEXT.P: An ROC mission led by Legislative Yuan Vice President Rau Yin-chi on Thursday visited Jordanian King Abdullah to convey Taiwan's condolences over King Hussein, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday.

According to a news release made public by MOFA, Rau and the Republic of China delegation were warmly greeted by Jordanian authorities as King Abdullah and three of his brothers received Rau personally at the royal palace.

Rau delivered two letters from ROC President Lee Teng-hui to Abdullah. One was to relay Lee's sympathy for King Hussein's death on Sunday, while the other was to congratulate Abdullah for being crowned king of Jordan.
In addition to thanking the ROC delegation for traveling to Jordan, Abdullah also assured Rau that cordial relations between the two countries will continue.
Later the same day, Rau and other delegates met with Jordanian parliamentarians, with the two sides promising to further enhance two-way exchanges.
Rau was traveling at the head of an ROC mission which included Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu. They flew from Taipei to Amman on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY: KMT LIKELY TO NAME LIEN CHAN AS PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: According to the results of a survey of Taiwan's rural and urban township chiefs and mayors, Vice President Lien Chan will most likely be the ruling Kuomintang's candidate for next year's presidential election.
Survey respondents named former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian as the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's most likely presidential candidate.

The telephone poll was conducted by the National Development Foundation for Education and Culture among 309 township chiefs and mayors between Jan. 20 and Feb. 3. A total of 236 responded to the poll, and the results were made public on Friday.

The most likely presidential candidates as indicated in the poll are Lien Chan, 94.5 percent; Chen Shui-bian, 84.3 percent; former Taiwan Governor James Soong (KMT), 59.3 percent; former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang, 37.7 percent; Jaw Shau-kong (New Party), 7.2 percent; and Wang Chien-shien (New Party), 6.4 percent.
The survey showed that 95.3 percent of the survey respondents believed the KMT will nominate Lien Chan as the party's candidate for next year's presidential election.
Only 18 percent thought James Soong may quit the KMT to run for president, and only 24.2 percent thought he has a chance to win the election if he does so.

DOC.HEADLINE: VATICAN HAS NOT CHANGED POSITION ON ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Feb. 12 (CNA) (By Bear Lee & Chung Hai-tai)

TEXT.P: The Vatican's secretary for relations with states, Jean Louis Tauran, reiterated on Friday that the Holy See's position on the Republic of China will remain unchanged.
Tauran made the assurance in a meeting with Raymond Tai, the ROC ambassador to the Vatican.
Tai called on the ranking Vatican official, asking him to clarify foreign wire reports that the Vatican would move its embassy from Taipei to Beijing if Beijing would allow it.

According to an AFP report, the Catholic Church's secretary of states, Cardinal Angelo Sodano, said at a reception at the Italian embassy in the Vatican on Thursday "the Taipei nunciature is the nunciature of China," and the church will move it back to Beijing "not tomorrow but this evening if the Chinese authorities permitted."
The Vatican was the only European state to maintain diplomatic relations with Taiwan before Jan. 27 when Taiwan and Macedonian established official ties.
Taipei was concerned about Sodano's statement and asked its envoy in the Vatican to look into issue.
Tai told Tauran that the cardinal's remarks represent an ignorance of the reality that China is divided and is ruled by two equal political entities on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Besides, Tai added, it would be inappropriate for the Vatican to move its embassy from Taipei to Beijing as the Vatican's envoys have presented their credentials to the ROC government in Taipei.
Tauran in reply said despite the statement by Cardinal Sodano, the Vatican's stance with regard to Taipei will remain unchanged.

He said the Vatican would not develop relations with Beijing at the expense of its ties with Taipei, and it will take care of the interests of the three parties involved in the process of establishing ties with Beijing.

There are over 10 million Catholic people on the mainland. It is believed that Beijing's refusal to accept the Catholic church and the naming of bishops for its patriotic churches is one of the major hurdles to bilateral relations between the two sides.

Meanwhile in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Cardinal Paul Shan said he believes the Vatican would not switch its embassy to Beijing before Beijing shows respect for human rights and allows religious freedom.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EASES PASSPORT REQUIREMENT FOR HONG KONG CITIZENS

TEXT.P: Hong Kong citizens who have applied for residency in Taiwan and later canceled it will no longer need a Taiwan passport to legally enter the island, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) officials said on Friday.
Last September, the Bureau of Entry and Exit stated that Hong Kong citizens who registered for Taiwan residency were required to apply for a Taiwan passport.
The move met with protests by Hong Kong citizens who complained to the Bureau of Hong Kong Affairs under the MAC about the great inconvenience.
As a result, the MAC held a special meeting and invited officials from the Ministry of Justice, the Bureau of Entry and Exit as well as the Bureau of Hong Kong Affairs to discuss the issue.
During the meeting, it was decided that the requirement be relaxed for those who have previously registered in Taiwan and have since canceled their registration.
However, those who maintain their registration in Taiwan, must still apply for a Taiwan passport to enter the island, the MAC said. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER'S ARTICLE FEATURED IN JAPANESE MAGAZINE

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said in an article for a Japanese magazine that Asian leaders should cooperate to speed up the integration of an Asian economy and to promote the "Asian dollar" concept.
Siew's article, titled "Asian Financial Crisis and ROC Countermeasures," was carried in the Feb. 16 issue of the biweekly economic magazine "Zaikai," which has a circulation of 120,000.
The premier described the Asian financial turmoil as the hardest test for Taiwan since the energy crisis.

To reduce the impact of the financial storm, he said, the ROC government has adopted several counter measures including loosening its monetary policy, expanding domestic demand, increasing public investment, and enforcing supervision of financial institutions.
Siew noted that Taiwan fared well compared to other Asian nations. The island registered 5 percent real economic growth last year and its foreign exchange reserves soared to US$90.3 billion.
He said the major reasons for Taiwan's performance were sound economic fundamentals, the gradual opening of Taiwan's financial market, and improvement of its industrial structure.

For instance, the premier said, products from the heavy chemistry and technology-intensive sectors already accounted for 76 percent of the output by Taiwan's manufacturing industry last year, up from 1982's 56 percent and 1991's 66 percent.

After the Asian financial crisis hit, Taiwan's central bank lowered its rediscount rates while the government has devised a plan to expand exports and will pour some US$5 billion into public investment projects in the next two years.

The premier said President Lee Teng-hui has urged Asian leaders to be aware of the international economic situation and to promote the "Asian dollar" concept to recreate a new economic miracle for Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 14, or the 29th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1766: Thomas R. Malthus, the British economist who wrote "An Assay on the Principle of Population," is born. His 1798 work argues that populations tend to increase faster than food supplies unless the increase is checked by moral restraints or by war, famine, or disease.
1779: Captain James Cook, the British navigator and explorer who commanded three major voyages of discovery, charting and naming many islands in the Pacific Ocean, is killed by a native's spear in Hawaii.
1893: Hawaii is annexed to the United States by treaty.
1924: Thomas John Watson, the American industrialist who worked for the National Cash Register Company (now NCR Corporation) for 15 years, is made president of a company that became International Business Machines Corporation (IBM).
1929: Seven Chicago gangsters, rivals of Al Capone's gang, are killed in what became known as the "Valentine's Day Massacre."
1933: The League of Nations refuses to recognize the Japanese puppet regime known as "Manchukuo." To deflect world condemnation of their hegemony, the Japanese invaders of northern China installed the Manchukuo regime in 1932. This "land of the Manchu" proved to be no more than another stepping stone for the extension of Japanese aggression.
1943: Soviet troops recapture Rostov from German invaders.
1944: Carl Bernstein, the American journalist who along with Bob Woodward exposed the Watergate scandal which brought down President Richard Nixon, is born.
1950: The Chinese communist regime and the Soviet Union sign the "Sino-Soviet Friendly Alliance and Mutual Assistance Treaty" in Moscow.
1962: General Hu Chung-nan, strategic advisor to President Chiang Kai-shek, dies in Taipei at the age of 68.
1972: Mexico establishes diplomatic relations with mainland China.
1972: Washington relaxes trade restrictions against Beijing, putting it on same basis as Moscow.
1975: The Marinas Islands in the Pacific become territory of the United States.
1977: Shih Wei-liang, a noted ROC musician, dies in Taipei at the age of 54.
1989: Ayatollah Khomeini, Iran's religious leader, issues a "fatwa" or death sentence against British writer Salman Rushdie for blasphemy in his book, "The Satanic Verses," sending him into years of hiding.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Earnestness without judgment becomes pedantry; caution without judgment becomes timidity; courage without judgment leads to crime; uprightness without judgment makes men tyrannical."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The US Senate acquitted President Bill Clinton, ending impeachment trial.
The China Times:
The US Senate acquitted Clinton of both impeachment counts -- charges of perjury and obstruction of justice.
The United Daily News:
Premier Vincent Siew announced consensus reached at an economic summit aimed at diagnosing the causes of the island's ailing economy.
The Liberty Times:
Premier Siew chaired an economic seminar on Friday to remedy Taiwan's economic ills.
The Commons Daily:
Liu Tai-ying, the ruling Kuomintang's top financier, became target of criticism at an economic summit called by the Cabinet on Friday to diagnose Taiwan's economic ills.
The China Post:
The US Senate was poised to acquit President Bill Clinton.
The China News:
US President Bill Clinton was acquitted.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LAWMAKER PREDICTS NO VISIT THIS YEAR BY ARATS CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the opposition New Party predicted on Saturday that mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan will not visit the island this year.
Legislator Feng Hu-hsian, who just returned from a trip to mainland China on Saturday, made the remarks at a news conference.

Feng said he met Tang Shubei, vice chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), during his visit, who told him clearly that the idea that ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan will visit Taiwan this spring was not a decision reached by both sides, but was rather a unilateral proposal by the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

In addition, other factors such as Taiwan's establishment of diplomatic ties with Macedonia, the possibility of its joining the United States-initiated Theater Missile Defense system, and a new round of constitutional reforms slated for April which may allow the holding a referendum to decide the fate of Taiwan, have all escalated the tension between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Feng claimed.
Against this background, Feng predicted that Wang will not visit Taiwan by May, or even within this year.
The New Party lawmaker also called on the ROC government to stop the arms race and the diplomatic war with mainland China, and to replace confrontation with dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: US MARINE CORPS OFFICER TO VISIT BUNUN HOMETOWN
DOC.DATELINE: Puli, central Taiwan, Feb. 13 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A US marine corps officer who belongs to Taiwan's Bunun aboriginal tribe is expected to arrive in Taiwan on Sunday to seek her roots and thank the Norwegian missionary couple who saved her life more than 30 years ago.

Sarah Elizabeth Mangels, who served in the Persian Gulf War and has been stationed in US bases in Japan, will visit Bjarne and Alfhild Jensen Gislefoss, two Norwegian doctors who have devoted some four decades of their lives to providing medical care to Taiwan's aboriginal people in central Taiwan.

The couple have both served as presidents of the Puli Christian Hospital over a period spanning more than 30 years, and have taken care of numerous sick aborigines, including the young Mangels and her Bunun mother.

Mangels, whose Bunun name was Langs, was first brought to the hospital when she was less than five years old. A skinny child practically dying of pneumonia, Langs was taken to the hospital together with her mother, the 21-year-old wife of a 90-year-old Bunun tribesman, who had also contracted the then-deadly disease.

With an aged father and a sick mother, the young Langs was kept in the hospital for a couple of years under the special care of Mrs. Gislefoss, who in later years has been called A-Mah (grandmother) by hospital staff and patients.
Langs' father died during this two-year period, and her mother also passed away a few years later.

Contacting the Puli Christian Hospital, Mangels, who has recently been promoted to the rank of first lieutenant, said the top priority of her first visit to Taiwan is to pay tribute to A-Mah for her unselfish care of the child whose life she saved from pneumonia and who she raised until the age of seven.

By the time she was seven, the young Langs was not only healthy but as beautiful as a little doll. Mrs. Gislefoss then decided to have the child adopted by an American GI couple, believing that if she was taken to the United States, the child would have a better chance at life.
Soon afterward, Langs left Puli for California with her adoptive parents, who also adopted another Taiwanese girl, and in later years, had three children of their own.
Langs became Sarah Elizabeth Mangels, and never returned to Taiwan. Described as being as happy as a lark and an outgoing girl, Mangels joined the US military some 10 years ago.
She is expected to be met at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport on Sunday by her older brother, who she has never met, and staff members of the hospital.

The Puli Christian Hospital, a general hospital famed for its care of aboriginal people in central Taiwan, was established in January 1956 by Lilian Ruth Dickson, an American missionary working with limited church donations.

In 1960, Dr. Bjarne Gislefoss, who helped train 150 local nurses for the hospital, became the second president of the institution. In 1963, Gislefoss married Alfhild Jensen, a graduate of Oslo Medical School who had worked as an anesthetist in the United States and was dispatched to Taiwan on a missionary and medical mission.

Mr. and Mrs. Gislefoss, who have received numerous citations from the government and from private groups in Taiwan over the past several decades, have always said that "Norway is our mother country, but Taiwan is our home."

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S JUMPY STANCE ON ABM CALLED DOUBLE STANDARD

TEXT.P: A Canadian newspaper said on Friday that mainland China is jumpy at the thought of a ballistic missile defense system because its umbrella might be extended to cover Taiwan.

The National Post claimed that at the moment, there are "more than 100 Chinese ballistic missiles aimed at Taiwan," which the Beijing regime wishes to reunite with the mainland -- forcibly, if need be.

In an editorial, the daily called mainland China's criticism of US plans to circumvent the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile (ABM) Treaty a "double standard." The treaty prohibited the Soviet Union and the United States from building an anti-missile defense system which would fend off chemical, biological or nuclear missile attacks by rogue states such as North Korea and Iran.

Mainland China is not party to the ABM, the daily pointed out. However, it is mainland China that is "the world's foremost proliferator of weapons of mass destruction and missile technology" according to a US Senate committee report.

Mainland China has pledged adherence to the Missile Technology Control Regime, acceded to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, and signed the Chemical Weapons Convention as well as the Comprehensive Test-ban Treaty. Nevertheless, it has "either broken, or helped others to break, every one of these solemn undertakings," according to the newspaper.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA THANKS MACEDONIAN PARLIAMENT FOR PASSAGE OF ROC TIES

TEXT.P: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) thanked the Macedonian parliament on Saturday for passing a bill approving the decision to set up diplomatic ties with Taipei.

The Macedonian parliament passed the bill on Friday by a vote 65-7, with two abstentions. It also added its seal to a joint communique signed by ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu and his Macedonian counterpart, Aleksandar Dimitrov.

Chen Ming-cheng, deputy director of the MOFA's Information and Cultural Affairs Department, told CNA that the ROC government is very grateful for the Macedonian parliament's backing. He voiced the hope that the move will open the way for a bright future of bilateral ties between Taiwan and the southeast European nation.

Echoing Macedonian Information Minister Rezxep Zllatku's view, Chen said the ROC government expects that its dealings with Macedonia will set a good example for other European countries in the region.
If the ROC government can promote its "Taiwan experience" to the other nations of southeast Europe through Macedonia, it will benefit both Taipei and Skopje, he said.

Speaking prior to his departure following a six-day visit to Taipei, Zllatku said that the establishment of diplomatic relations between Taipei and Skopje will have a positive impact on Macedonia's neighbors.

Taipei and Skopje announced on Jan. 27 that they would forge official diplomatic ties, provoking a strong protest from Beijing, which on Feb. 9 announced the suspension of its own diplomatic ties with the Balkan state.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESOLUTION TO HELP TAIWAN INTRODUCED IN US CONGRESS

TEXT.P: United States Representative Robert E. Andrews (D-NJ) called attention on Friday to an article in The Washington Post on Thursday entitled "Chinese Missiles Menace Taiwan," and urged support for a House resolution to help Taiwan in case of a military attack by mainland China.

"The United States has a strong interest in helping to preserve the safety and security of the people of Taiwan," wrote Andrews in a letter, adding: "Accordingly, I have introduced House Concurrent Resolution 22, a resolution calling on the president to seek a public renunciation by the People's Republic of China of any use of force against Taiwan."
The congressman noted that the resolution also "acknowledges that the United States should help Taiwan defend itself in case of threats or a military attack by mainland China.

The House passed a resolution by a vote of 411-0 last June urging President Bill Clinton to seek a public renunciation by the PRC of any use of force, or threat of use of force, against Taiwan. But Beijing has refused to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.

Andrew's resolution reminds the Clinton administration that the mainland Chinese military threat against Taiwan is still in existence and, therefore, the United States should continue protecting the security of Taiwan and maintaining peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region in accordance with the terms of the Taiwan Relations Act.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIANS DISMISS N. KOREAN NUCLEAR ATTACK ON MONTREAL

TEXT.P: The belief by the US military that North Korea would flatten Montreal with a nuclear missile was dismissed as laughable on Friday by Canadians.

"Based on my 17 years in the foreign service, including four in the intelligence community, I don't think I'd be in a big rush to sell my house in Montreal," said Daryl Copeland of the Canadian Institute of International Affairs.

The reports originated from a war game scenario cooked up by the US Army's War College. Three Canadian members of parliament were briefed on the scenario by US army officials during a NATO meeting, and two of them told the media what they heard.

America believes North Korea dare not attack the United States directly, but would hit a close ally that does not have nuclear weapons, Conservative Party MP David Price said. They consider this "a very serious scenario," Art Hanger of the Reform Party noted.

The US military wants Canada to contribute US$600 million toward the US$10 billion it is about to spend on a North American ballistic missile defense shield, and raising the specter of a missile strike on Montreal would not hurt the US lobbying efforts, the Canadian press said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDICAL TEAMS FROM AFRICA RECEIVING TRAINING HERE

TEXT.P: The government has started arranging for medical personnel from its African allies to come to Taiwan to receive medical training, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Saturday.

Timothy Yang, director-general of MOFA's Department of African Affairs, said that Taiwan used to send medical missions to its African allies, but due to difficulty it has experienced in recruiting enough people to join these missions, MOFA came up with the idea of asking the allies to send their own teams to receive training here.
Yang said that a four-member medical team from Swaziland is currently taking a three-month training course in an intensive care unit at National Taiwan University Hospital.
A team spokesman described medical standards in Taiwan as high, and said that this kind of training sets a fine example for bilateral medical exchanges.

Starting this year, Chad, another African ally of the ROC, will also send a five-member medical team to the Tri-Service General Hospital to take three- or six-month training programs. The first such group, which is expected in early March, will include an obstetrician, emergency unit nurses, a midwife, and an optical technician.

Yang noted that Taiwan has in the past helped improve the medical capabilities of its African allies through sending medical missions, providing pharmaceuticals, medical equipment, and basic medical facilities.
He said that Taiwan has also set up scholarships to help medical staff of these allies to visit neighboring countries to study and attend short-term camps.
Eight of 29 allies that maintain diplomatic relations with Taiwan are in Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN SHIPPING FIRM TERMINATES SERVICE TO NEW ZEALAND

TEXT.P: BHP Transport, an affiliate of Broken Hill Proprietary Ltd., Australia's biggest industrial conglomerate, is withdrawing its liner shipping services between Australia and New Zealand.
A company spokesman said BHP can no longer compete with the influx of foreign ships.

BHP will withdraw its two remaining ships on the Australia-New Zealand route and terminate their charters early next month. Crewmen on the vessels will be redeployed within BHP's fleet where possible, but there are likely to be job losses, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO HOLD TALKS WITH INDONESIA ON EAST TIMOR

TEXT.P: Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer will go to Jakarta to hold talks with President B.J. Habibie on Feb. 25 after the Indonesian leader indicated that East Timor may become independent as early as Jan. 1, 2000.
In a statement faxed to the CNA on Saturday, Downer said: "I will meet Indonesia's President Habibie in Jakarta for in-depth discussions on East Timor."
He said circumstances relating to the future of East Timor are evolving rapidly and the Australian government is keen to see a peaceful and orderly process in this regard.
Downer said he will also meet Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas and other Cabinet ministers, as well as several prominent East Timorese figures.
He said Canberra has repeatedly made clear that Australia will accept whatever outcome the principal parties agree to.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEX-CHANGE OPERATIONS NOT COVERED BY NATIONAL HEALTH INSURANCE

TEXT.P: The cost of sex-change operations are not covered by the National Health Insurance (NHI) program, officials from the National Health Insurance Bureau (NHIB) said on Saturday.
However, they added, people who have trouble with their gender orientation can have therapy from hospital psychiatry departments, which is covered by NHI.
Officials from NHIB's Medical Management Department said that neither sex-change operations nor cosmetic surgery are covered by the NHI according to existing national health insurance laws.

A group of transsexuals on Saturday took their plight to the street, attending a hearing at the Legislative Yuan where they appealed that sex-change operations should be included under the NHI umbrella.

Lin Kuo-hua, who recently underwent a sex-change operation in Bangkok, where surgery costs are about one-third of Taiwan's, said there are about 200 people in Taiwan who are waiting for the surgery to allow them to lead normal lives.

Calling themselves "the right souls in the wrong bodies," Lin said they are a group of people, most of them men, who face apparent discrimination in the job market, and difficulties carrying out their military service.

Lin and his companions rebuked the NHIB statement that they can have psychiatric treatment under the NHI, saying that they are not people with mental disorders, but simply people who need physical treatment to "correct" their gender.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE: CARING FOR OVERSEAS CHINESE IS GOVERNMENT POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 13 (CNA) (By Raymond Huang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, in a television address to be aired in the United States on Feb. 15-16, talked about the importance of the overseas Chinese community to the ROC government.

Lee noted during the program, which will be broadcast on Chinese-language stations as a part of Chinese Lunar New Year programming, that "overseas Chinese have been a supportive strength for national development."

He stated that the ROC government will continue to strengthen communications with the Chinese community abroad, and will take positive actions to provide assistance in the educational, cultural and economic fields.
The two-hour special program, called "Celebrating Chinese New Year from Four Seas," was produced by the Taipei-based China Television System.

In addition to President Lee, other government leaders to be featured on the program are Premier Vincent Siew and his wife, Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Chairman Chiao Jen-ho, and Government Information Office Director-General Chen Chien-jen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, US AGREE ON NECESSITY OF CROSS-STRAIT MILITARY BALANCE

TEXT.P: The Republic and China and the United States agree that it is necessary to maintain a balanced military might across the Taiwan Strait, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Saturday.
A MOFA official made the remarks after the New York Times reported on Friday that the number of missiles Beijing has deployed against Taiwan will increase.

The report said a study by the Pentagon on Taiwan, which is about to be presented to the Congress, showed that Beijing began to deploy 60 missiles against Taiwan in the 1990s, and that number will increase to 600 in the next three years.

The MOFA official, who requested anonymity, said MOFA will not comment on military issues, but added that the stance of the US and Taiwan is identical -- both sides of the Taiwan Strait should maintain an equilibrium in terms of military to attain the goal of solving cross-strait problem peacefully.

The official noted that the White House, State Department and Pentagon reconfirmed that the US will abide by the Taiwan Relations Act and continue to sell defensive weapons to Taiwan so it will be capable of defending itself.
This indicates that the US government believes it is necessary to maintain the military balance on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to help solve cross-strait problems peacefully, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC FORUM SEEKS GOVERNMENT INTERVENTION IN STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: The government should grant more power to the Securities and Futures Commission to handle the stock market amid reports that several listed companies are experiencing financial troubles, an Executive Yuan economic forum concluded on Friday.

The forum was attended by government officials, academic figures and prominent businessmen. They included Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the Kuomintang's Business Management Committee; Koo Chen-fu, honorary chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce; KMT and DPP legislators; and professors of finance and banking.

Forum participants unanimously urged the government to thoroughly implement and regulate strict rules in stock trading to avoid further potential damage. A DPP legislator even suggested that hasher punishment be imposed against financial crimes such as embezzlement.
As for the treasury records of listed and over-the-counter companies, they suggested that companies allow the government access to company records to allow for more efficient surveillance.
They also recommended that investors in the stock market stick to the stable profit of long-term shares instead of short-term speculation.

Meanwhile, a financial and banking professor from the National Taiwan University said Taiwan's economy is basically healthy despite the poor performance in the stock market. She said the losses had less to do with Taiwan's economic climate and more to do with the necessity to improve the financial and banking industries. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC REMEDIES TO BE INTRODUCED WITHIN A MONTH: SIEW

TEXT.P: Remedies for Taiwan's ailing economy will be introduced in a month to keep the economy from slipping further, Premier Vincent Siew said on Saturday upon the conclusion of an economic summit.

Stating that economic problems should be solved with economic means, Siew said other relevant measures, which require legislative support, will be handed to the Legislative Yuan for screening within the next three months.

Siew noted that authorities are still debating whether to lower or remove taxes on stock transactions to prop up the slumping bourse. He hinted that the government is inclined against such a move as it may only be a temporary solution and will damage the stock market in the long run.

The proposal to prolong the existing statutes devised to encourage upgrading of industrial structures for another 10 years will be handed to the Legislative Yuan for approval within a month, while the government will decide on the implementation of the NT$150 billion in home loans a week after the Lunar New Year holiday, Siew added.
The one-and-a-half day conference on Taiwan's current economic problems and possible solutions ended Saturday at noon with participants at odds over the cure's foundation.

Three prominent proposals made by Taiwan's three major industrial and business groups -- the removal of stock transaction taxes, raising rates of bank reserves, and government issuance of more bonds to fund blue-chip stock issues -- were unfavorably received.
The economic summit brought together nearly 200 representatives from the government, industry, academic circles, and lawmakers for discussions.
It was hoped that the meeting's participants would chart a map to guide the country out of the economic doldrums.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSES URGE MALAYSIA TO LIMIT RUBBER-TREE LOG EXPORTS
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, Feb. 13 (CNA) (By Chin Yok-pin and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan furniture making businesses in Malaysia on Saturday called on Kuala Lumpur authorities to impose a limit on the export of rubber-tree logs as they are facing a timber shortage.
An eight-member delegation from the Taiwan businesses association in Malaysia made the call during a meeting with Primary Industries Minister Lim Keng Yaik.

Ting Chung-cheng, at the head of the petition delegation, told Lim that Malaysia's unlimited timber exports led most Taiwan furniture makers in the Southeast Asian country to fall victim to a lack of wood supply.

Ting gave Lim a petition stating that costs for rubber-tree timber material are skyrocketing due to a shortage. The fact has considerately harmed the interests of furniture manufacturers from Taiwan, who relocated their factories to Malaysia because of low-overhead costs and sufficient raw material.

The memorandum pointed out that decreased profits would force Taiwan companies to shrink their operations or "again" relocate their factories to another country. As a consequence, there would be many lay-offs in those companies, causing the country's unemployment to grow.

In effort to lure foreign investments, Kuala Lumpur has promised to provide an abundant workforce and raw material to Taiwan furniture businesses. Ting said the government's promised was initially realized, noting that was the reason why they put their interests in Malaysia.
Because of these initial expectations, they are now all trapped, the business delegates from Taiwan complained.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER REBUTS MOODY'S COMMENT ON STOCK INTERVENTION

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Paul Chiu on Saturday defended his actions against remarks made by global ratings agency Moody's Investors Service.

Moody's said Taiwan's official request asking banks to support the local bourse and real estate market with an earmarked NT$200 billion would jeopardize the island's financial and banking systems and hinder normal operations.

Chiu said the buying and selling of shares is one of the bank's businesses. Banks target blue chip stocks, ruling out negative influences the sagging stock market could possibly have on them, he added.
Meanwhile, Vice Minister of Finance Sean Chan declined to comment on Moody's remark, only saying that he respects freedom of speech.
But he added that the ministry has done its best to strengthen Taiwan's financial market despite the ratings agency's unpopular comment. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: UTAH STATE BACKS TAIWAN'S WHO MEMBERSHIP
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Feb. 12 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The State of Utah's Senate and House of Representatives on Friday passed resolutions supporting Taiwan's entry to the World Health Organization (WHO), giving a boost to the island's bid to joint international organizations.

The resolutions called on US President Bill Clinton to support Taiwan's entry to the WHO through "meaningful" and "proper" ways, as Taiwan's participation in the United Nations affiliated organization will benefit the entire region and the whole world.

The resolutions, which passed by votes of 25-0 and 69-0 in Utah's Senate and House, respectively, urged the Clinton administration to support Taiwan and its 21 million people to join the WHO as an "observer" despite the fact that Taiwan is not qualified to be represented as a full member.

Tseng Ching-yuan, head of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in San Francisco, immediately delivered speeches in both Utah's Senate and House after learning of the development. In addition to expressing appreciation for Utah's backing, Tseng also reiterated Taiwan's desire to contribute to the international community.

Noting that TECO's long-term efforts have paid off by winning the support of Utah state, Tseng pointed out that it was also an indication that Taiwan's drive to take part in international activities has gained the attention of the American public. Bilateral relations between Taiwan and Utah will be further enhanced, Tseng added.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT STRESSES IMPORTANCE OF IMPROVING QUALITY OF LIFE

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan on Saturday stressed the importance of improving the public's quality of life as the country has already become a democratic nation.
Lien made the remarks at a year-end luncheon attended by the chiefs of more than 300 important social organizations throughout the island.
In the pursuit of democracy and economic success, people must also pay attention to improving the standard of living and social welfare, he said.
To attain the goal of national modernization and everlasting development, Lien said war must be prevented, and people must help each other, respect each other and care for each other.
The luncheon was co-hosted by Taiwan Governor Chao Shou-po and President Kao Chin-yen of the Hsiangho Social Development Foundation for Culture and Education.
Lien praised the country's social organizations for offering a service to improve society, calling them the "warm currents" and "beacons of light" in the community.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FUGITIVE REPATRIATED FROM MAINLAND

TEXT.P: A Taiwan fugitive who fled to mainland China to evade swindling charges was repatriated to Taiwan under an agreement signed between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said on Saturday.
CIB officials said Liu Chiu-hwai, 60, borrowed NT$4.12 million (US$12,716) from his victim surnamed Mao in 1994, claiming that he needed the money to buy a tour coach.
But Liu, who was previously convicted on weapons possession charges, then defaulted on the payment and fled to the mainland in 1996.

CIB officials said the repatriation was conducted under Kinmen agreement signed between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in 1990. The agreement governs the repatriation of hijackers and criminals and their pickup locations to facilitate a cooperative effort in cracking down on cross-border crime.
Red Cross officials from the mainland escorted Liu from Mawei, in Fuzhou to Taiwan's offshore island of Matsu on Saturday morning. Liu was then picked up by Taiwan Red Cross officials.
CIB officials later escorted Liu from Matsu to Taiwan where he will face prosecution.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 13, or the 28th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1542: Catherine Howard, wife of English King Henry VIII, is beheaded for treason.
1912: Dr. Sun Yat-sen tenders his resignation to the provisional senate which was established in Nanking on Jan. 28, 1912. He also agrees to relinquish the provisional presidency of the Republic of China to Yuan Shih-kai who promises to establish a republican government.
1935: A judge sentences Bruno Hauptmann to die in the electric chair after a New Jersey jury found him guilty of kidnapping and murdering flying ace Charles Lindbergh's infant son three years earlier.
1945: US warplanes bomb Dresden, Germany, killing over 35,000 civilians in World War II while allied forces capture Budapest, Hungary.
1954: Chou Lu, a veteran revolutionary leader of the Kuomintang, dies in Taipei at the age of 70.
1957: The British Defense Ministry announces the production of its first H-bomb.
1958: Taipei area records lowest temperature (2.6 degree Celsius) in half a century.
1960: The French test their first atomic bomb in the Sahara Desert in Africa.
1966: The list of winners of the first ROC's 10 outstanding female youths is announced.
1971: Spiro T. Agnew, vice president of the United States under President Richard M. Nixon, hits three spectators with his golf ball during the Bob Hope Desert Classic tournament.
1976: Lieutenant General Olusegun Obasanjo becomes the new head of state of Nigeria, succeeding Nigerian junta leader General Murtala Ramat Muhammad who is assassinated in a coup attempt.
1984: The Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party elects Constantin Ustinovich Chernenko as its secretary-general.
1989: Soviet troops leave Kabul, capital of Afghan.
1990: Boxer James Douglas is recognized as the new world heavyweight champion after knocking out Mike Tyson in Tokyo two nights earlier.
1990: The Mainland Affairs Task Force permits Taiwan's performing artists to stage commercial performances on the mainland and to participate in activities sponsored by the Chinese communists.
1991: A US missile hits an air-raid shelter crowded with civilians in Baghdad, killing more than 300 people.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is composed and happy; a fool is always worried and full of distress."

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SMILING SIEW' HAS NEVER LOST THE SUPPORT OF HIS WIFE

TEXT.P: The wife of Premier Vincent Siew on Saturday expressed solid support for her husband as "Smiling Siew" mapped out strategies to revitalize Taiwan's sluggish economy in a two-day economic conference which began on Friday.
Watching her husband, who has headed the Executive Yuan since September 1997, as he buries himself in difficult work and never complains, Chu Chuh-hsien said she feels very touched.
Chu said although her husband has spent all his energy on administrative affairs in the hope of maintaining and enhancing the country's stability and prosperity, he still faces criticism.

That kind of reaction is unfair to a man devotes himself to improve the welfare and happiness of his people, she said, adding that in a democratic society, there are no unanimous opinions or thoughts.

"In a person's mind, everyone knows whether or not you have done the right thing; time reveals a person's heart," Chu said, reflecting her support for "Smiling Siew" who won the nickname because of his soft character.

As she recalled over 30 years of marriage to Siew, Chu said harmony has always been a cornerstone in their relationship. She noted that Siew has never changed his character. "He is a honest person, very genuine and natural," Chu stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PASSENGERS PROTEST AFTER FINDING LUGGAGE WAS LEFT BEHIND

TEXT.P: Some 30 passengers arriving at Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan, protested to EVA Air on Saturday after finding that their luggage was left behind in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan.

The BR-901 shuttle plane, carrying 112 passengers, landed at Hsiaokang International Airport in Kaohsiung at noon. Among the passengers were 30 members of a tour group returning home from a trip to the United States.
After they could not find their luggage at the baggage claim area, the tour group passengers discovered that EVA Air removed their luggage in Taoyuan to balance the plane's weight.
The passengers protested at EVA Air's Kaohsiung counter and asked for compensation.
Airline officials explained that the shuttle is a smaller BAE-146 plane, and could not carry all the weight of the passengers' luggage so they removed some luggage before taking off.
They apologized to the passengers for failing to notify them in advance and vowed to send them their luggage by the evening. The amount of compensation will be left for future discussion.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MEMBERS IN US PLAN TO SUPPORT LIEN IN PRESIDENTIAL RACE
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Feb. 12 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Some Kuomintang members abroad are considering supporting Vice President Lien Chan in next year's presidential election after an opinion poll indicated that he is the most likely choice for the KMT ticket.
Several KMT officials in the San Francisco area are reportedly planning to form a group called the "Association of Lien Chan's Friends" to push forward such a campaign.
A recent survey showed that 95 percent of Taiwan's township chiefs and mayors believe that Lien will be nominated as the KMT presidential candidate.
KMT Secretary-General John Chang remarked in San Francisco several days ago that the KMT plans to call a National Congress in August to select the party's candidates for president and vice president.

The National Congress is the highest authority of the ruling party. The KMT officials in the San Francisco area plan to invite some 180 KMT delegates living abroad to join the "Association of Lien Chan's Friends" as a concrete move to boost Lien's bid for the presidency.

Cheng Kuang-chih, a KMT official in the San Francisco area, said on Friday that the association organizers will meet next week to discuss details. He said the association will not be limited to KMT members.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF WELCOMES PLANNED VISIT OF ARATS OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) on Saturday welcomed the planned visit of a high-level official from its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
SEF received a message from ARATS on Saturday afternoon, saying that it would send a deputy secretary-general to Taipei in March to discuss the arrangements for a visit by ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan.
The message did not identify which deputy secretary-general will be making the trip or the date of his visit to Taiwan.
The two sides agreed Wang would visit Taiwan after he met SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu in mainland China last October.

SEF sent a message to ARATS on Jan. 22 and again on Feb. 12, extending an invitation for Wang to visit Taiwan, and asking that ARATS send officials to the island soon to discuss details of Wang's visit.
SEF and ARATS are two semi-official agencies set up to deal with cross-strait exchanges in the absence of diplomatic ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Executive Yuan sets deadline to carry out economic remedies.
The China Times:
Executive Yuan earmarks special funds for loans to first-house buyers.
The United Daily News:
Economic forum neither scrapes nor cuts down Stock transaction tax.
The Liberty Times:
Funds for loans to first-house buyers to be replenished after Lunar New Year.
The Commons Daily:
Democratic Progressive Party presses for political party act.
The China Post:
Siew vows to enhance stock market discipline.
The China News:
Capital tax safe in reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 14, or the 29th day of the 12th month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1766: Thomas R. Malthus, the British economist who wrote "An Assay on the Principle of Population," is born. His 1798 work argues that populations tend to increase faster than food supplies unless the increase is checked by moral restraints or by war, famine, or disease.
1779: Captain James Cook, the British navigator and explorer who commanded three major voyages of discovery, charting and naming many islands in the Pacific Ocean, is killed by a native's spear in Hawaii.
1893: Hawaii is annexed to the United States by treaty.
1924: Thomas John Watson, the American industrialist who worked for the National Cash Register Company (now NCR Corporation) for 15 years, is made president of a company that became International Business Machines Corporation (IBM).
1929: Seven Chicago gangsters, rivals of Al Capone's gang, are killed in what became known as the "Saint Valentine's Day Massacre."
1933: The League of Nations refuses to recognize the Japanese puppet regime known as "Manchukuo." To deflect world condemnation of their hegemony, the Japanese invaders of northern China installed the Manchukuo regime in 1932. This "land of the Manchu" proved to be no more than another stepping stone for the extension of Japanese aggression.
1943: Soviet troops recapture Rostov from German invaders.
1944: Carl Bernstein, the American journalist who along with Bob Woodward exposed the Watergate scandal which brought down President Richard Nixon, is born.
1950: The Chinese communist regime and the Soviet Union sign the "Sino-Soviet Friendly Alliance and Mutual Assistance Treaty" in Moscow.
1962: General Hu Chung-nan, strategic advisor to President Chiang Kai-shek, dies in Taipei at the age of 68.
1972: Mexico establishes diplomatic relations with mainland China.
1972: Washington relaxes trade restrictions against Beijing, putting it on same basis as Moscow.
1975: The Marinas Islands in the Pacific become territory of the United States.
1977: Shih Wei-liang, a noted ROC musician, dies in Taipei at the age of 54.
1989: Ayatollah Khomeini, Iran's religious leader, issues a "fatwa" or death sentence against British writer Salman Rushdie for blasphemy in his book, "The Satanic Verses," sending him into years of hiding.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Earnestness without judgment becomes pedantry; caution without judgment becomes timidity; courage without judgment leads to crime; uprightness without judgment makes men tyrannical."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S USED NUCLEAR FUEL TO BE SHIPPED BACK TO US IN JUNE

TEXT.P: An agreement between Taiwan and the United States to ship Taiwan's spent nuclear fuel back to the United States has been reached, and the agreement will go into effect after it is approved by the Executive Yuan after the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday.

The first batch of spent fuel could be dispatched from Taiwan to the United States as early as June. It will be carried on a ship built exclusively for transporting nuclear fuel, said officials from the Atomic Energy Council.
The pact caps three years of strenuous negotiations between the council and the US Energy Department.

Taiwan now has about a hundred spent nuclear assemblies stored separately at National Tsinghua University and at the Institute of Nuclear Energy Research under the Atomic Energy Council, the two institutes engaged in nuclear research in Taiwan.

The material will be ferried to the United States, along with nuclear waste from South Korea, Indonesia and the Philippines. Neither South Korea nor Indonesia will pay to have the waste shipped to the United States, although Taiwan has been asked to pay NT$140 million (US$4.34 million).

It was the United States that originally supplied Taiwan with the nuclear fuel, and it has been a long-standing US policy to have spent nuclear fuel returned to its country of origin for fear that it will be used for military purposes.
The practice was interrupted because of strong opposition from US anti-nuclear power groups. It was resumed, however, after 1997 when the US government won a lawsuit brought by environmentalists.
Taiwan was said to have kept a low profile during the negotiations so as not to attract attention.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS FROM MAINLAND CHINA REPATRIATED

TEXT.P: A total of 434 mainland Chinese who snuck into Taiwan illegally were repatriated on Saturday and Sunday through Matsu Island, one of Taiwan's frontline islands.

To ensure they would return home before the start of the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday -- a holiday marked by family reunions -- both Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and its mainland counterpart sped up the repatriation process.

The immigrants, who had been living at a Taiwan detention center, were taken by ship to Matsu on Wednesday, but were not handed over to personnel from the Red Cross Society of the mainland Chinese province of Fujian until Saturday because of rough seas and bad weather.
One group of 223 mainland Chinese were sent to Matsu Harbor by bus early Saturday and then boarded at midmorning a boat bound for the mainland and chartered by the Fujian Red Cross Society.
The boat left Matsu for Mawei, in Fujian province, at 10:00 a.m. Among the 223 illegal immigrants on board were 13 females and an 8-month-old baby born to one of the women.
A second group of 211 illegal mainland immigrants were repartiated Suday morning from Matsu to Pingtan, Fujian province by the same means.

DOC.HEADLINE: US MARINE CORPS OFFICER RETURNS TO BUNUN HOMETOWN
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan, Feb. 14 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: A US Marine Corps officer who is a member of Taiwan's Bunun aboriginal tribe returned to her central Taiwan hometown of Puli on Sunday to seek out her roots after 30 years of living abroad.
Sarah Mangels was warmly greeted by her brother and by Bunun tribesmen at the airport upon her arrival. She then went directly to Puli, which she last saw 32 years ago.

Mangels cried when she met with Bjarne Gislefoss, honorary president of Puli Christian Hospital, and his wife. The couple saved the life of Mangels when she was a girl and were responsible for her emigration to the United States.

Mangels, whose Bunun name is Langs, contracted what was then a life-threatening case of pneumonia when she was under 5 years old. Both she and her mother, who had contracted pneumonia as well, were taken to central Taiwan's Puli Christian Hospital.
For several years Mangels remained hospitalized under the special care of the Gislefosses. Bjarne Gislefoss was then president of Puli Christian Hospital.
The girl's father died during her hospitalization, and her mother died a few years after.

The Gislefosses arranged for Mangels, then 7 years old, to be sent to the United States, where she was to be adopted by a couple that had also adopted another Taiwanese girl. After arriving in California Langs was renamed Sarah Mangels.
Mangels joined the US Marines about 10 years ago and was recently promoted to the rank of first lieutenant. She is married with three children and lives in California.
Mangels is scheduled to stay in Taiwan for the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday. She is scheduled to leave Taiwan for California on the evening of Feb. 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE: ROC WILLING TO CONTRIBUTE TO WORLD'S DEMOCRATIZATION

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said on Sunday that Taiwan has accomplished democratic reform and is willing to make contributions to the world's movement toward democracy.
He made the statement in a written message to an International Democratic Union (IDU) forum that opened in New Delhi on Sunday.
Lee lauded the IDU's contributions to the establishment of a peaceful new world order, and extended congratulations to the meeting on behalf of the 21 million people of Taiwan.
The president noted that in the past half century, the Republic of China has focused on economic development and political reform, creating the so-called "Taiwan miracle."
The 1996 direct presidential election in Taiwan indicated that the Chinese people are able to realize democratic political ideals, and that Taiwan's democracy has matured, he said.
In spite of this, Lee said the Republic of China is not content with its achievements, adding that it will work to bring about further political reforms.

He stated that the Republic of China is willing to make contributions to the world's democratization by sharing its experiences with, and providing assistance to, countries seeking to embrace democracy.

The president said that the region's financial turmoil has dealt a heavy blow to most Asian countries. But he said he believes all difficulties can be conquered with the wisdom and strength generated from democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: 42 PERCENT OF PRIVATE BUSINESSES TO RAISE WAGES: CLA SURVEY

TEXT.P: Although Taiwan's domestic economy is in the doldrums, 42 percent of private businesses said they would raise employees' wages this year, a survey conducted by the Council for Labor Affairs (CLA) showed on Sunday.

According to the survey, the average monthly wage for employees of companies in Taiwan's service and manufacturing sectors between January and November of last year was NT$39,843, a 3.12 percent increase over the same year-earlier period. The 1997 figure, however, was 5.01 percent higher than during the 1996 period, indicating that the rate of growth has slowed as a result of the region's financial turmoil.

Wages are expected to rise an average of 2.33 percent over the coming year. Manufacturing sector wages will rise by an estimated 2.46 percent, while wages in the construction industry will rise by 2 percent; in the utilities sector, 1.58 percent; and in the mining and gravel industry, 0.75 percent.

Service sector wages are expected to rise 2.43 percent, according to the same survey. The biggest gains will likely be seen in the industrial and commercial services industry, where wages are expected to rise 3.26 percent during this year. Meanwhile, transportation, commodity warehousing and communications industry wages are expected to rise 2.45 percent; retail industry wages, 2.42 percent; social service industry wages, 2.16 percent; and finance, insurance and real estate industry wages, 1.76 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWEDEN EXTENDS 450-MILLION-RAND GRANT TO SOUTH AFRICA

TEXT.P: South Africa will receive a 450-million-rand (about US$74 million) grant from the Swedish government over the next three years under an agreement signed by Swedish Foreign Minister Anna Lindh and South African Deputy Foreign Minister Aziz Pahad Saturday.
The grant is to be used for education, housing, arts and culture, urban development, economic cooperation and the development of a democratic government.
The agreement, signed in Cape Town, also envisions the two countries working more closely to eradicate poverty and to promote human rights in southern Africa.
