DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE: GOVERNMENT TO FOCUS ON ECONOMIC ISSUES THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said on Monday that the government will focus on economic and financial issues this year to boost investor confidence.
The president made the statement in his message to the people on the eve of the Chinese Lunar New Year, which starts Tuesday.

Lee said economic and financial issues have become the central concern of the public in the past year, as several enterprises and individuals have gone bankrupt one after another. Government measures have failed to strengthen investor confidence, he noted.
He urged domestic investors not to lose confidence, as many foreign institutions still regard the Republic of China as having a sound economy.
For instance, the president said, a recent report by the US Department of Commerce on 20 major export destinations for US goods ranked Taiwan third in terms of its overall economic prospects.

Despite the emergence of some financial problems in Taiwan, Lee pointed out that the nation's economic performance and financial fundamentals are better than those of most other newly developed countries.

He stressed that the government will concentrate its attention to economic and financial issues this year, and engage in the reorganization and reform necessary to improve Taiwan's economic and financial fundamentals.
The president noted that various changes in Taiwan and in the international community over the past year have brought about many new challenges to the country.

He said that among the major changes were last December's elections for legislators and Taipei and Kaohsiung mayors, the impact of Asia's financial turmoil, US President Bill Clinton's trip to mainland China, mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's visit to Japan and the resumption of talks between Strait Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu and Chairman Wang Daohan of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.
The president said that all emerging difficulties will be conquered eventually and that the country will march toward a bright future through the joint efforts of the people of Taiwan.
Lee's message was to be broadcast Monday night in Mandarin, Taiwanese and Hakka on local and satellite television stations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER'S VISIT TO MACEDONIA DELAYED TO EARLY MARCH

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu's first visit to Macedonia, originally scheduled for late this month, will be put off until early March.
An official with the Foreign Ministry said on Monday that technical requirements related to the arrangement of Hu's schedule has made the postponement unavoidable.
Under new travel plans, Hu will visit Macedonia March 3-5 at the head of a mission comprising Taiwan businessmen and journalists, the source said.
The Republic of China and Macedonia established diplomatic relations in late January, which resulted in mainland China severing its ties with that southern European country last week.

Meanwhile, several working-level officials and specialists from the International Cooperation and Development Fund and the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research will leave for Macedonia on Tuesday to pave the way for Hu's visit.
Following Hu's visit, Vice Foreign Minister David Lee will lead another ROC mission to Macedonia in late March or early April.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE AFFAIRS COMMISSION CHIEF VISITS BRAZIL

TEXT.P: Chiao Jen-ho, chairman of the Executive Yuan's Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC), attended a meeting of the World's Federation of Taiwan Chambers of Commerce in Brazil on Sunday, according to OCAC officials.
The officials noted that while most government leaders in Taiwan are off on their Chinese Lunar New Year's vacation, Chiao is still working, visiting the Chinese community in Brazil.
They said that Chiao left Taipei on Feb. 3, and has so far visited Chinese communities in Chile, Argentina, Paraguay and Brazil.

On Feb. 13. Chiao visited several Chinese organizations in Brazil, including a Fokuanshan Buddhist temple, the Chunghua Association, the Chinese Teaching Association, the South American Chinese Writers Association, the Taiwan Benevolent Association and a local Chinese-language newspaper.
OCAC officials said that Chiao will meet with local Chinese community leaders in Brazil on Sunday. Afterward he will return to Taipei via Los Angeles on Feb. 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNI AIR PLANE MAKES SUCCESSFUL EMERGENCY LANDING

TEXT.P: A faulty landing gear forced a Uni Air plane to make an emergency landing on Monday in which none of the plane's seven passengers or two crew was injured.

The Dornier-228 plane, which took off from Taitung, eastern Taiwan, around 7:20 a.m., was bound for Green Island, southest of Taiwan. The plane had to return to Taiwan after the captain found that he could not land due to the faulty landing gear.
For safety reasons, the captain decided to head to the better equipped Hsiaokang Airport in Kaohsiung, northern Taiwan, around 8:30 a.m.
Firefighters spread foams along the runway before the plane landed to prevent teh plane from catching fire as it hit the tarmac.
While the landing was successful, air traffic in the area was thrown into chaos because of the incident and returned to normal only after 10:50 a.m.
Uni Air apologized to teh flight's passengers and presented each with NT$1,000 (US$20.86) in compensation. The passengers continued their trips aboard other flights.
Uni Air has three German-manufactured Donier-228 planes traveling routes connecting Taiwan to Matsu, Lanyu (Orchid Island) and Green Island.
The airline has ordered three DH-2000 planes that can accommodate 36 people. The first will arrive in early March and will be used to fly to Matsu.
The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) has sent three officials to the airport to investigate the cause of the Dornier-228's problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC URGED TO BE ON GUARD AGAINST FIRE

TEXT.P: Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen on Monday urged the public to be on guard against fire during the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday that runs from Monday through Thursday.
Huang noted that last year there were 12,737 fires, which resulted in 917 injuries and deaths and NT$2.65 billion (US$7.7 million) in property losses.

He said that fires most often occur between 3 p.m. and 6 p.m. The top five causes of fire last year were the burning of weeds and garbage; short circuits in electrical appliances; cigarette butts; cooking accidents; and faulty machine equipment.

Serious injuries or deaths from fires could come as the result of being severely burned, inhaling poisonous gases, being hit by foreign objects, jumping to the ground from high elevations and being caught in a building as it collapses.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TRADE DEFICIT WITH JAPAN CLIMBS TO RECORD HIGH IN 1998

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan continued to widen in 1998 as it reached a record high of US$17.6 billion, the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said on Monday.
BOFT officials noted that Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan has grown over the past three years. The deficit totaled US$13.8 billion in 1996, US$17.3 billion in 1997 and US$17.6 billion in 1998.

BOFT officials attributed the increasing trade deficit mainly to a decline in Taiwan's exports to Japan. Exports amounted to only US$9.3 billion in 1998, down from US$11.7 billion in 1997 and US$13.6 billion in 1996.

In 1996 the United States was the largest exporter of goods to Japan, follwed in order by mainland China, South Korea, Indonesia and Taiwan. Since then, however, Taiwan has fallen to seventh place among exporters to Japan, while Australia and Germany have risen to third and fourth place, according to the semi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA).

BOFT, in analyzing the decline in exports to Japan, said that the top 10 Taiwan exports to Japan all suffered double-digit declines last year. Exports of machine equipment and electrical appliances, which together accounted for 46.5 percent of Taiwan's exports to Japan in 1998, fell by 11.1 percent and 15.3 percent, respectively, last year.

CETRA is now formulating plans to address the ballooning trade deficit. It is expected that there will be 70 promotional activities this year aimed at bolstering Taiwan exports to Japan, and from these activities as much as US$850 million is expected to be generated for Taiwan manufacturers.

Japan's slumping economy will bottom out this year and begin to pick up next year, CETRA officials said. The organization's promotional efforts will focus on the electronics, information technology and communications industries, and it will work to help domestic manufacturers to set up marketing footholds in Japan.
CETRA will also encourage Japanese businesses to purchase more Taiwan-made products.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECOND TERMINAL AT CKS AIRPORT TO HELP DOUBLE ACCOMMODATION CAPACITY

TEXT.P: The construction of a second terminal at CKS International Airport is now in its final stage, and it is expected that after its completion the accommodation capacity of CKS International Airport will be doubled.

The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said that currently around 12 million passengers pass through the airport each year, about double the number expected when the airport was originally designed.
To upgrade the quality of the airport, the CAA began to plan a second terminal in 1989 and started construction in 1994. The second terminal is expected to be completed by June this year.
To avoid the chaos that surrounded the opening of a new airport in Hong Kong, the second terminal will undergo a six-month test period before it is officially inaugurated in January 2000.

CAA officials said the new terminal is carefully designed to handle the transfers of both domestic and international passengers and cargo. It will also help boost Taiwan's emerging service and production industries.
The second terminal, with a size of 208,000 square meters, will cost NT$22.16 billion (US$683.95 million), and is designed to accommodate 14 million passengers a year.
CAA officials said that they are now planning to construct a third terminal to meet the anticipated needs of the airport in the year 2010.

To fully develop Taiwan into an aviation transportation hub in the Asia-Pacific region, the CAA will also develop the land surrounding the airport into a commercial area that will include posh hotels, convention centers and shopping malls to attract more visitors from the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIBLINGS OF DEAD TAIWAN BUSINESSMAN LEAVE FOR MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The siblings of a Taiwan businessman who was found dead at his residence in Taizhou, Zhejiang province in southeastern mainland China on the eve of the lunar New Year, left for the Chinese mainland on Thursday to handle the aftermath.

Hu Chun-teh, who operated a scrap metal business in Taizhou, and his son Hu li-chung, were found dead on Monday evening, while Hu's wife Tseng Chao-chin and daughter Hu Fang-chen were found to be in critical condition due to poisoning.
Mainland public security authorities said the Hus were poisoned by carbon monoxide. Both Hu's wife and daughter were later reported in stable condition after receiving medical treatment.

With the assistance of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), five members of the Hu family managed to obtain entry permits from the mainland authorities and left for the mainland via Hong Kong on Thursday morning.
SEF is a semi-official intermediary body authorized by the ROC government to handle exchanges across the Taiwan Strait in the absence of official ties.
Hu's elder brother Hu Chun-yen said prior to his departure from the Kaohsiung International Airport that he will help his family handle the aftermath of the tragic incident.
He said he also will ask the mainland authorities to investigate the cause of the incident.

There were reports that the deaths were caused by food poisoning, not gas poisoning as claimed by mainland public security authorities. The Hus reportedly had eaten some bad sauces during the lunar New Year Eve's family reunion feast.
Hu's wife and two young children traveled to the mainland earlier this month for a Chinese New Year family reunion.

1517: Mary Tudor, the English queen known as "Bloody Mary" because of her relentless persecution of Protestants, is born.
1546: Martin Luther, German theologian and the 16th century Protestant reformation leader who confirmed the Augsburg Confession in 1530, effectively establishing the Lutheran Church, dies in Eisleben, Germany, at the age of 63.
1564: Michelangelo Buonarotti, Italian sculptor, painter, architect, poet, and the most brilliant representative of the Italian Renaissance who created some of the greatest works of all time, including his marble sculpture "David," the paintings on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel, and the plans for Saint Peter's Church, dies in Rome at the age of 89.
1678: John Bunyan, English preacher and writer celebrated for his "Pilgrim's Progress," the allegorical tale of Christian's journey from the City of Destruction to the Celestial City, publishes the first part of his masterpiece.
1915: German submarines start a maritime blockade of Great Britain.
1930: Clyde William Tombaugh, an American astronomer, discovers Pluto, the sun's ninth and smallest planet, at the Lowell Observatory in Flagstaff, Arizona.
1932: Japan announces that the "Manchukuo" regime will be installed in northeastern China. The "land of the Manchu" proved to be no more than another stepping-stone for the expansion of Japanese aggression.
1945: Battle for Iwo Jima starts in the Pacific.
1951: Prime Minister Tran Van Huu announces the formation of a new government in Vietnam.
1965: The West African nation of Gambia proclaims independence.
1967: Robert Julius Oppenheimer, the American physicist known as the father of the A-bomb, dies at the age of 65.
1972: The Supreme court of California abolishes the death penalty.
1984: McDonald's, the Chicago-based fast-food chain, opens its first branch in Taiwan.
1986: The Asian Development Bank votes to admit mainland China.
1988: Boris Yeltsin is ousted from the ruling Communist Party Politburo in Moscow.
1992: A delegation from the US President's Export Council arrives in Taipei to promote ROC-US trade.
1994: Lin Wen-chiang, a mainland Chinese hijacker, commandeers a Southwest Airlines passenger plane from the mainland to Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man may have abilities as admirable as our Lord of Chou (Chinese history's equivalent of Moses or Solomon), but if he is proud and mean, you need not consider the other qualities of his mind."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER VISITS THE VATICAN

TEXT.P: ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu arrived in the Vatican on Thursday at the start of a three-day visit, according to diplomatic sources.

Hu's Holy See visit has captured attention, as foreign wire service reports quoted Vatican Secretary of State Angelo Sodano as saying last week that if mainland China can reach consensus with the Vatican on certain issues, the Vatican is willing to move its embassy from Taipei to Beijing.
However, Foreign Ministry sources said Hu's visit has nothing to do with Sodano's remarks, but was arranged long ago and is mainly aimed at strengthening bilateral diplomatic relations.
During his visit, Hu will meet with Sodano and Jean Louis Tauran, the Vatican's secretary for foreign relations. Hu is not expected to have an audience with Pope John Paul II.

As Hu had to make transit stops in several countries with which the Republic of China does not maintain formal diplomatic ties, he had kept his travel plans secret to avoid possible sabotage by Beijing.

The Vatican is one of the ROC's two diplomatic allies in Europe. Local observers said Hu's visit is part of the government's efforts to shore up ties with the Holy See ahead of a visit to Europe by mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in March.

Meanwhile, Hu is tentatively scheduled to head a delegation of business executives and journalists to visit the ROC's other European ally -- Macedonia -- from March 3 through March 5. The ROC forged full diplomatic ties with Macedonia on Jan. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S GIO DEPUTY CHIEF URGES BEIJING TO RENOUNCE USE OF FORCE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 18 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Beijing should renounce the use of force to solve cross-Taiwan Strait problems, said Government Information Office Deputy Director-General Frederic Chang in an interview carried by the Japan Times on Thursday.
Chang arrived in Tokyo on Tuesday for a six-day visit.
He said in the interview with the English-language newspaper that mainland China should respect that Taiwan is ruled separately, and should employ only peaceful means to solve the reunfication issue.
Chang noted that Taipei expects Chairman Wang Daohan of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) to visit Taipei soon to strengthen cross-strait relations.

He also expressed the hope that Taiwan's ARATS counterpart -- the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) -- will resume consultations on practical non-political issues such as illegal immigrants, hijacking, smuggling, and poaching.
Talking about the island's economic development, Chang said that despite the impact of the Asian financial turmoil, Taiwan still managed to attain 5 percent real growth last year.

A day earlier, Chang paid a call on Chuang Ming-yao, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Japan, and visited the Japan Times, the Nihon Keizai Shimbun and other Japanese press institutions.
He met with the leaders of the Institute for World Peace, and executives of the Sankei Shimbun newspaper on Thursday, and is scheduled to leave for Seoul for a three-day visit from Osaka on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN READY TO DISCUSS AGRICULTURAL COOPERATION WITH MAINLAND

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is ready to discuss agricultural cooperation with mainland China, said Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Su Chi on Thursday.

Agricultural cooperation between Taiwan and the mainland was among the topics raised by Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu when he held talks with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in Beijing last fall.
Jiang indicated at the time that he had "interest" in Koo's overture.
Su said that ROC President Lee Teng-hui first took up the issue of cross-Taiwan strait agricultural cooperation in April 1995.
Now that Beijing appears to have the intention of considering such a proposal, he said, Taipei is ready to discuss this issue with Beijing when the opportunity emerges.

Lee's concept is that "Chinese must help Chinese," and the MAC chairman said that Taiwan will promote agricultural cooperation with the mainland on a "mutually beneficial, complementary, and reciprocal" basis.
Su said that Taiwan has wide experience in agricultural development, and that he believes both Taiwan and the mainland can enjoy a "win win" situation from agricultural cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE FINANCIAL ORGANIZATIONS ISSUE NT$-DENOMINATED BONDS

TEXT.P: Many major international financial organizations have come to Taiwan over the past year to issue New Taiwan dollar-denominated bonds in order to raise funds for various development projects in emerging markets.

Financial observers say such moves not only signify the Republic of China's sound economic fundamentals and strength but also strengthen Taiwan's status as a regional funding center and a capital supplier in the international community.

Among others, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) is scheduled to issue NT$10 billion-worth of NT$-denominated "Dragon Bonds" after the Chinese New Year holiday to help its Asian member states revamp their economies after the 1997-1998 financial turmoil. The ADB has issued several batches of NT$-denominated bonds over the past few years.

The European Investment Bank (EIB) issued NT$6 billion-worth of NT$-denominated five-year bonds for the first time in April 1998. Of the amount, NT$4.5 billion-worth of the bonds offer a fixed interest rate, while the remaining NT$1.5 billion-worth offer floating interest rates. The EIB was the first international financial organization to issue NT$-denominated bonds with floating interest rates.

On April 17, 1998, the European Bank of Reconstruction Development (EBRD) floated NT$6.6 billion-worth of NT$-denominated three-year bonds, with a fixed annual interest rate of 6.75 percent. It was the third time that the EBRD had issued bonds in Taiwan. The bank has so far floated a total of NT$15.6 billion-worth of NT$-denominated bonds.

The Inter-American Development Bank (IADB) issued NT$7.6 billion-worth of NT$-denominated, five-year bonds for the first time on May 21, 1998 to raise funds for several economic stimulus plans in Latin America.

The North European Investment Bank again floated NT$6 billion-worth of NT$-denominated bonds in Taiwan on June 29, 1998, with an interest rate of 6.9 percent per annum. It was the second time that the bank has issued bonds here.

Meanwhile, the Central American Bank for Economic Integration also floated NT$3.5 billion-worth of NT$-denominated, seven-year bonds in Taiwan on July 28, 1998, with an annual interest rate of 7.4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, KAOHSIUNG MAYORS TO ATTEND ASIA-PACIFIC MAYORAL SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh will attend the Asia-Pacific Mayoral Summit in Brisbane, Australia, in early March.

As the mayors from several mainland Chinese cities are also expected to attend the summit, political observers say that this may develop into another round of the "diplomatic war" between Taiwan and the mainland.

The summit, which is being sponsored by the capital city of the state of Queensland, will be held from March 1-3, and the major topics on the agenda will include the region's economy, business, finance, and environment.
For Ma and Hsieh, this will be the first time they will have attended an international meeting since their elections last December.
Other Taiwan cities and counties that have been invited to the summit are Tainan County, Tainan City, Keelung City, and Taichung City.
Beijing and several coastal cities of mainland China, including Shanghai, have also been invited.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO STRENGTHEN COMMUNICATIONS WITH US OVER IPR ISSUES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 17 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative office in the United States said on Wednesday that it will strengthen communications with the US Trade Representative (USTR) office over intellectual property rights (IPR) issues.

Teng Chen-chung, economic division chief at the de facto ROC embassy in Washington, D.C., made the statement after the US-based International Intellectual Property Alliance (IIPA) requested to the Clinton administration on Tuesday that Taiwan should be maintained on the "watch list" of this year's annual special 301 review.
Meanwhile, a major US pharmaceutical industry association even suggested that Taiwan be put on the more threatening "priority watch" list.
Teng said some of the commercial piracy allegations made by US companies or trade associations against Taiwan are unfounded.
"We have discussed some alleged IPR infringement issues with senior IIPA executives and have offered them detailed explanations of their concerns. We'll continue to communicate with them," Teng said.

More important, Teng said, his division will strengthen communications with the USTR office because it has the final say on whether Taiwan should be included on the special 301 list. Individual American companies and trade associations can only made recommendations to the USTR and these suggestions may not necessarily be adopted, he noted.

Israel is the prime target of the IIPA's anti-commercial piracy campaign this year. The IIPA report accuses Israel of being a key production and marketing center for pirated music recordings, and recommends that Israel be put on the most threatening "priority foreign country" list.
The IIPA report also mentions for the first time that Taiwan-produced pirated music products, particularly compact discs (CDs), have been exported to the United States via Israel.
Teng said this is the first time that he has heard of such an allegation, adding he does not believe Taiwan pirates are as smart as the IIPA alleges.

The USTR is scheduled to unveil its annual special 301 review at the end of April. "We'll do our utmost over the next two months to help US trade officials understand our determination to protect IPR and eradicate commercial piracy, as well as pointing out our achievements in this regard," Teng said.

Since the United States began issuing an annual special 301 review of IPR violations by its major trade partners more than 10 years ago, Taiwan had consistently been put on various watch lists, except for November 1996, when the USTR decided to take Taiwan off the watch list during a special review. However, the island was put back on the list in August 1998, on the grounds that Taiwan had not done its best to enforce IPR protection regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPERTS HELPING PHILIPPINE FARMERS GROW PONGLAI RICE
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Feb. 18 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Three rice experts from the Republic of China have successfully helped Philippine farmers grow Ponglai rice, a special strain of Taiwan rice.
With the assistance of the three agronomists, the Philippine farmers planted Ponglai rice on a 36-acre plot of farmland in Northern Samar province and began their first harvest on Feb. 10.
Reports from the province said local farmers are excited by the success of the experiment. More importantly, the reports said, the harvest is even better than they had anticipated.
According to the reports, the Ponglai strain, more commonly known as Pineapple rice in the Philippines, has a yield three times higher than the average Philippine rice strain.
This was the first bilateral privately funded ROC-Philippine agricultural cooperative program to have been implemented.

The program was initiated by Taiwan's Hsieh Clan Association, which donated funds to hire the three agronomists -- Pan Hsing-wang, Chen Chun-liang and Huang Ching-hai -- to teach Philippine farmers to grow the Ponglai rice.
Emil Ong, an adviser to Philippine President Joseph Estrada, provided the piece of farmland for the experimental crop, and in just six months, the program has reaped a better-than-expected harvest.
The Philippine government has now decided to introduce the cooperative program throughout the country with the aim of realizing the country's eventual goal of food self-sufficiency.
Meanwhile, the ROC and the Philippines is also negotiating an official-level agricultural cooperative program. This program is expected to be implemented in the not-too-distant future, sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD STAY ON SPECIAL 301 LIST: IIPA

TEXT.P: The US-based International Intellectual Property Alliance (IIPA) requested to the US government on Tuesday that Taiwan should be maintained on the "watch list" of this year's annual special 301 review.

The IIPA submitted its recommendations to US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky in a 1000-plus-page industry report on the annual special 301 review of copyright piracy and market access problems around the world.
It discussed a total of 62 countries or economies and reported that US copyright industries lost an estimated US$12.4 billion due to copyright piracy in these countries in 1998.

Taiwan, which was put back on the special 301 watch list last August by the USTR, caused US$303 million in trade losses in 1998 to the US copyright industries due to piracy as compared to US$237.2 million in 1997, according the IIPA.

The report said the increase was attributable mainly to optical media piracy, namely CD and CD-ROM products; piracy rates increased for the sound recording and music industries from 10 percent in 1997 to 20 percent in 1998.
"Taiwan must take further steps to bring the problems of copyright piracy under control," said Eric H. Smith, president of the IIPA.

The report noted that Taiwan "must immediately implement effective measures against CD and CD-ROM piracy," and the government must conduct raids on plants producing unauthorized products, seize infringing copies and machinery, and impose criminal penalties to deter the organized manufacture and distribution of pirated products.

The IIPA recommended that the USTR put Taiwan on the watch list along with 32 other countries or economies. It also recommended Israel to be on the priority foreign country list, and mainland China and Paraguay to stay on the Section 306 monitoring to make sure of their bilateral copyright commitments following past 301 actions against these countries.

The IIPA is a Washington-based coalition of associations representing US copyright-based industries. Its member associations include: The Association of American Publishers; the Business Software Alliance; the Interactive Digital Software Association; the Motion Picture Association of America; the National Music Publishers' Association; and the Recording Industry Association of America.

DOC.HEADLINE: US VICE PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN SOUTH AFRICA FOR MEETING

TEXT.P: United States Vice President Al Gore arrived in Cape Town on Wednesday for a meeting of the US-South Africa Binational Commission.
The meeting scheduled to be held on Thursday will be co-chaired by Gore and South African Deputy President Thabo Mbeki.

Among the major topics to be discussed will be job creation and anti-crime cooperation, while a trade and investment framework agreement is expected to be signed at the end of the meeting. This agreement will create a mechanism for managing trade disputes.

US Commerce Secretary William Daley, Agriculture Secretary Daniel Glickman, Energy Secretary Bill Richardson and other senior US officials arrived in South Africa on Tuesday, and have already held talks with their South African counterparts.
US Attorney General Janet Reno, who arrived in Cape Town along with Gore, will also participate in the meeting on Thursday.
The US-SA Binational Commission was established in 1995 to promote relations between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE EXPERTS GIVE SOME INVESTMENT ADVICE

TEXT.P: In an interview with the Singapore-based The New Paper, four investment experts gave their advice and recommendations to investors with S$20,000 (about US$1,250) to play with as follows:

-- Professor Ngiam Kee Jin, National University of Singapore: Put S$5,000 in fixed deposits; Put S$5,000 in one or two stocks, like bank shares; Put S$10,000 in unit trusts which invest in foreign countries.
Or, put one-third in Singapore stocks, fixed deposits and unit trusts; put one-third in US dollar fixed deposits; Put one-third in Euro fixed deposits.
-- Dr. Edwin Feulner, president of the Heritage Foundation: Buy bonds; invest in some conservative mutual funds.
Or, put half in US stocks; put one-quarter in Asian stocks; put one-quarter in bonds or fixed deposits.
-- Vikram Khanna, newspaper columnist: Buy commodity or oil stocks, try real estate companies; avoid yen deposits.
-- Prem Shankar Jha, economist: Buy bonds; buy preference shares; put your savings in US dollars or French francs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Y2K BUG WILL AFFECT ASIAN AIR TRAVEL: CBC

TEXT.P: Only 70 percent of Asian airlines say their planes will fly at midnight on New Year's Eve because of the threat of the so-called millennium bug, according to a report on Monday by the Canadian Broadcasting Corp.
Air China of mainland China is the only airline of the 20 surveyed that said its computers are free of the millennium bug, according to the CBC.

The Y2K problem is the inability of some computer systems to recognize the date 2000. The glitch may cause them to malfunction or shut down, and most modern planes rely on computers to keep them flying.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN HOUSING TECHNOLOGIES MAKING INROADS INTO JAPAN

TEXT.P: Everything from Canadian lighting and floors, to paint and drywall, to carpets and windows, and even kitchen plumbing is finding its way into new energy-efficient Japanese homes.

The first-ever Japanese home built under Natural Resources Canada's Super E Program was unveiled on Monday in Sapporo, Japan. Canadian and Japanese dignitaries and members of the public attended the official opening.

The program introduces Japanese importers to Canada's best housing technologies and building practices, offering them products that are more energy efficient and environmentally responsible than conventional homes.

"The Super E houses use 20 to 30 percent less energy for heating than the average Japanese house built today, helping to reduce carbon dioxide emissions," Canada's Natural Resources Minister Ralph Goodale said.

Japan is Canada's largest overseas customer for manufactured housing and building products. Canadian exporters anticipate that more than 50 houses will be constructed in Sapporo over the next year, and that the program will be expanded to Tokyo later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY `WILL CHANGE LIVES': SINGAPORE SENIOR MINISTER

TEXT.P: The technological revolution, especially information technology, biotechnology and genetic engineering, will radically change people's lives, Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew said.

In an interview with Global Views Monthly, Lee pointed out that the old constraints that kept people confined to a specific place and limited them to the resources of that particular location will no longer hold. Wherever people are, they can, if they have the means, access information and knowledge, move rapidly from country to country, or get food, medicines and other things transported to them.
It will be a revolution in how human societies organize themselves. And with cloning, we can replace our deceased organs. The possibilities are as infinite, he said.
The following are Lee's replies in the interview:

-- Few at the end of the 19th century could have predicted the gigantic explosion of population from 1.6 billion to six billion people. No one foresaw the two great wars that broke up the European empires. But the greatest changes were brought about by technological advances. Man has conquered more of nature. He has disproved Malthus' theory that there would not be enough food for rapidly-growing populations. At the same time, man's inventiveness has produced terrifying weapons of war.
-- It is impossible to predict what will happen by the end of the 21st century because the population explosion will not be a simple extrapolation at today's rate of growth.

-- Asia is not at the forefront of this technological revolution. Only Japan is keeping abreast with certain frontiers of new technology. Therefore, the space for catch-up is vast. Those countries that invest in their people and master new technology will make great advances. Those peoples who quickly learn to adapt and use new information and knowledge will make more progress.
Based on past performance, they will be the people from South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore -- because of their great emphasis on education that is oriented to science and technology.
Taiwan is likely to continue to do well because of its many start-up companies in information technology.
-- Mainland China will make great strides as its education levels improve, with a higher percentage of its students acquiring university and post-graduate qualifications.

The mainland needs modern infrastructure, efficient administration without red tape, and the rule of law. If it can put right its systems, it will pose a sharp competitive challenge to the economies of Southeast Asia.

-- Association of Southeast Asian (ASEAN) countries will recover from the present setbacks, varying from two to five years depending on how they clean up their financial systems, recapitalise their banks and their corporations. They will be able to make 4 percent to 6 percent annual growth. They have not concentrated as much on education, and will have to do more to catch up. Their abundance of natural resources will help them.

-- It will be presumptuous for anyone in Asia to give a message to the people of the 21st century. I can only express my hope that nations will avoid disastrous wars that destroy and set their peoples back.

I hope that they will keep population growth under control so that the environment will not be much further degraded. And that they will increase trade with and investments in each other, and have free movement of goods, capital, people and technology so that all countries can provide better living standards and environment for their people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL BE ONLY ASIAN TIGER TO GROW THIS YEAR: ANALYSTS

TEXT.P: Of the four so-called "Asian Tigers," only Taiwan is expected to grow this year, with Japan expected to grow a mere 0.2 percent, according to an Australia-based forecasting firm, BIS Shrapnel.
Taiwan is expected to grow 5.6 percent, and 6 percent in 2000 while mainland China might grow 7 percent this year and next year.

Singapore is one of six Asian economies expected to shrink this year -- by 1.8 percent. The others are Indonesia (-6.7 percent), Hong Kong (-2.9 percent), South Korea (-2.8 percent), Thailand (-1.1 percent), and Malaysia (-0.3 percent).

The firm's Nigel Hatcher expressed grave doubt about the economies of Hong Kong and Singapore. In a press statement released on Monday, the firm said Singapore's construction sector is on the brink of a major downturn. It expects a further 25 percent decline in construction activity this year. Private consumption spending will likely continue to shrink, and investment in equipment will decline.

"But this year will represent the bottom of the trough and more solid signs of recovery will emerge in 2000," Hatcher said. "More economies will reduce their financial constraints and restart production. Exports will increase significantly, foreign investment inflows will return and exchange rates will strengthen. Governments will be freer to increase their own spending and reduce interest rates, as some of the pressure comes off exchange rates."
The firm expects all countries in the region to grow in 2000. Even Indonesia is forecast to expand 2.3 percent, Thailand 3.6 percent, and Japan 2.3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA CONTINUING TO INTIMIDATE TAIWAN: US NEWSPAPER

TEXT.P: No serious talks between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait seem possible while mainland China is stirring fresh doubts about its appetite for negotiations, heating up the regional arms race and alarming the people of Taiwan, according to The Washington Post.

The influential American newspaper on Sunday published an editorial titled "Still Rattling Missiles," which said that mainland China is back with another show of force to Taiwan. Three years ago it fired missiles into the Taiwan Strait. Now, it is systematically moving missiles -- reportedly by the hundreds -- into the part of mainland China closest to the territory it regards as a breakaway province.

This development seems to have no specific trigger beyond an evidently continuing desire to intimidate Taiwan and keep it from eventually creeping under an American anti-missile umbrella and thus be even less likely to reunify with the mainland, said the editorial.

As signals of force, the multi-year coastal deployments are less dramatic "but no less objectionable than the previous firings," noted the Post, adding that in Taiwan, at any rate, the effect may be the same -- "to advertise to the Taiwanese people the benefits of independence from Beijing and to turn them further against any early consideration of reunification."

The United States and other interested countries should not hesitate to remind Beijing that in their view reunification can come about only peacefully. "Chinese missile rattling has no place in the proceedings," noted the editorial.

The rattling is also bound to increase Taiwan's appetite for anti-missile protection. That could come to mean, over the years, the inclusion of Taiwan under an American missile umbrella. A broad American policy choice may be emerging. The United States is directed by longtime bipartisan policy as well as by statute to help provide for Taiwan's defense and to ensure that the island's future unfolds by peaceful means, continued the newspaper.

But a missile shield, once developed and deployed, does not stop at protecting the intended beneficiary, here Taiwan. It is in the nature of such a shield that it also could embolden Taiwan to feel it did not really have to negotiate seriously with the mainland Chinese. But all of this is a long way from happening, if it even happens at all, added the editorial.
The Washington Post concluded that negotiations ought to take place without coercion and on the basis of mutual interest.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWEDEN EXTENDS GRANT TO SOUTH AFRICA

TEXT.P: South Africa is to receive a US$73.7 million grant from the Swedish government over the next three years under the terms of a development agreement signed on Saturday by Swedish Foreign Minister Anna Lindh and South Africa's Deputy Foreign Minister Aziz Pahad.
The grant is to be used for education, housing, arts and culture, urban development, economic cooperation, and the development of democratic government.
The agreement signed in Cape Town also envisions the two countries working more closely to eradicate poverty and promote human rights in the southern African region.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE SENATOR WANTS SOUTH CHINA SEA NAME-CHANGE

TEXT.P: A Philippine senator called on Monday for the government to change the name of the South China Sea to the "Kalayaan (Freedom) Sea."

Senator Francisco Tatad's resolution came after it was reported that mainland China had instructed all its missions abroad to avoid any public discussion of the Spratlys issue which involves the Philippines, Mainland China, Vietnam, Brunei and Taiwan.

In his resolution, Tatad said part of Philippines' national territory and the 200 mile Executive Economic Zone as recognized by the United Nations convention on the Law of the Sea lies within the body of water known as the South China Sea.

Because of its name, this body of water is sometimes perceived as belonging to the country that bears its name, he claimed. In fact, he continued, on Feb. 25, 1992, mainland China's national assembly passed a "Law on Territorial Waters and Adjacent areas of the People's Republic of China," declaring the South China Sea as territorial waters.

"To avoid confusion that the body of water in question belongs to China and to declare to the world that the sea is open to the freedom of navigation of all innocent and friendly parties," the Philippines should now start calling what is referred to as the South China Sea as the Kalayaan Sea, Tatad said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES TO CONTINUE MONITORING SPRATLY ISLANDS CONSTRUCTION

TEXT.P: The Philippines will continue with its "diplomatic offensive" in resolving its dispute with mainland China over the Spratly Islands in the South China Sea, while it continues to monitor the construction of mainland structures in the contested area, a presidential spokesman said on Thursday.
Jerry Barican said in a radio interview that the government will stick to bilateral and multilateral approaches in dealing with Beijing over the issue.
He said: "We are monitoring developments, but we can only pursue diplomatic talks."
Barican said the government will continue monitoring developments in that area, while the Department of Foreign Affairs arranges talks between the Philippines and Beijing to discuss the issue.

President Joseph Estrada and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin agreed to resolve the issue through diplomatic means when they met on the sidelines of the 6th Leaders Summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum last November. (By Timothy Sun) ENDITEM/J

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 19, or the fourth day of the first month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1473: Nicolaus Copernicus, the Polish astronomer who advanced the theory that the Earth rotates daily on its axis and, with the other planets in the solar system, revolves around the sun, is born.
1878: Thomas Edison, the American inventor who once described genius as "1 percent inspiration and 99 percent perspiration," is granted a patent for his phonograph.
1909: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th US president who won the 1906 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese War, and an avid big-game hunter, calls for a world conference on conservation.
1921: A helicopter with two huge rotors powered by a motor of a mere 25-horsepower, which was built by French engineer Etienne Oehmichen, makes a successful test flight in Paris.
1927: The Chinese Nationalists extract a reduction of concessions from Britain at Hankow and Kiukiang.
1932: The United States refuses to recognize the Japanese puppet state of "Manchukuo" (State of Manchuria).
1934: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National Military Council of the Republic of China, launches the "New Life Movement" in Nanchang, Kiangsi province.
1942: Japanese forces invade Bali in Indonesia and make their first raid on the Australian mainland when they bomb the Northern Territories port of Darwin.
1945: US forces launch an invasion of the island of Iwo Jima, killing most of the 22,000 occupying Japanese troops and eventually taking the Pacific island on March 26 at the cost of 6,821 American dead.
1951: Andre Gide, the French writer who won the 1947 Nobel Prize for literature and was noted for his diaries and novels such as "The Immoralist," and "Lafcadio's Adventures," dies at the age of 82.
1953: The Republic of China and the Kingdom of Spain sign the "Sino-Spanish Friendship Treaty" in Madrid.
1955: The Southeast Asian Treaty Organization (SEATO) is established, with eight countries participating.
1963: US president John F. Kennedy says the Soviet Union has agreed to pull out several thousand of its troops from Cuba by March 15.
1964: The Sungshan International Airport building in Taipei is inaugurated.
1972: Japan establishes diplomatic relations with the Mongolian People's Republic.
1976: Iceland severs diplomatic relations with Britain in a further installment of the "cod war" that soured ties between the two nations four years earlier.
1977: Representatives of the disabled celebrate their first "Torch-Light Day" at the Taipei New Park.
1985: A Spanish Airlines Boeing passenger plane crashes in a mountainous area, killing 142 people aboard.
1990: The Liberal Democratic Party under Toshiki Kaifu wins a general election in Japan.
1991: Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian Federation, urges Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to resign, accusing him of sacrificing reform for "absolute personal power."
1997: Communist China's paramount leader Deng Xiaoping, who ruled mainland China from 1978 until his retirement from his last official post in 1990, dies in Beijing at the age of 93.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who educates himself for three years without improvement is seldom to be found."

DOC.HEADLINE: MODERATE DRINKERS HEALTHIER, WEALTHIER: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Drinking less can not only improve health, but also can allow people to perform better at work and pick up fatter pay packets, according to the results of a new Australian survey.
The survey, conducted by economist Garry Narrett of the University of New South Wales, said moderate drinkers earn more than total abstainers and also more than heavy drinkers.
His research, which was not conducted at the pub, is backed up with complex equations that enabled him to mix and match data on drinking behavior and wages among a wide range of workers.
He said: "The major finding from the analysis is that there is a significant, positive wage differential for moderate drinking, and a significant wage penalty for heavy drinking."
He said temperate drinkers tend to have better jobs than employees who don't drink at all or who don't know when to stop.

"The wage premium for moderate drinkers, relative to both abstainers and heavy drinkers, is predominantly due to greater returns to personal and job characteristics rather than to differences in the level of those characteristics," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN AUTHORITIES NAB ILLEGAL WORKERS

TEXT.P: The Australian authorities have arrested a big group of illegal workers from mainland China, Vietnam, Indonesia, Malaysia, Israel, South Korea, and Samoa, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs reported on Friday.
In a statement faxed to the CNA, Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said the 44 illegal workers were arrested at two tomato farms in the state of Victoria.
He said: "The operation was in response to complaints made to the department by local residents who were angry that jobs were being taken by illegal workers."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN FOREIGN MINISTER SEEKING STABILITY IN EAST TIMOR

TEXT.P: Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer will meet detained East Timorese independence leader Xanana Gusmao in Jakarta next week before traveling to Portugal to seek an international push to ensure a peaceful settlement to the East Timor problem.

In addition to Gusmao, Downer will meet Indonesian President B.J. Habibie, Defense Minister Wiranto, and Foreign Minister Ali Alatas, as well as opposition figures including Amien Rais and possibly Megawati Sukarnoputri.
In a statement faxed to the CNA on Friday, Downer said he will also discuss East Timor at a joint ministerial meeting between Australia and Singapore before heading to Indonesia.
Downer said he will put all of his efforts into making sure that the issue of East Timor is "finally, peacefully and satisfactorily settled."

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE DEFENSE MINISTRY TO PLUG INTO SOLAR POWER

TEXT.P: A solar-powered Singapore military is on the way, with the first Defense Ministry installation to harness the power of the sun on a large scale expected to be up and running by 2002.
Defense Ministry engineers concluded that solar power can be harnessed economically here by incorporating solar panels into buildings.

In the first major test of its kind here, the ministry's Land and Estate Organization (LEO) installed an S$80,000 (about US$50,000) solar power system at Tuas naval base in 1997, with 56 rectangular solar panels on the roof and part of the building's facade.

From the pilot project, LEO believes that building integrated solar panels, which are connected directly to the power grid, are the only application of solar power which hold potential for large-scale commercial use.

A senior manager in LEO's electrical engineering department pointed out that with the cost of solar panels expected to fall by as much as 40 percent in the coming years, LEO expects to be able to use the next generation of solar cells, which will be less than 50 microns thick, whereas the cells used at Tuas are 350 microns thick.
Up until last December, the Tuas system generated 5,700 kW/h, sufficient to meet the needs of an average five-room household."
A LEO electrical engineer said that all the energy was collected in an area of about 30 square meters, only 3 percent of the entire facade.
"If more panels are installed, solar energy can easily power up to 30 percent of the building load for a two-story building during daytime," he said.

The engineer added: "This reduction in initial investment, together with a long lifespan of more than 20 years for a solar panel, makes it possible for solar energy to compete with a conventional power supply."

DOC.HEADLINE: ALBRIGHT EXPECTED TO DISCUSS TAIWAN PROTECTION ISSUE IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The US-initiated Theater Missile Defense (TMD) system is expected to be high on the agenda of upcoming talks between the United States and mainland China, according to an Australian news report.

US Secretary of State Madelaine Albright is scheduled to visit Beijing later this month and Beijing is expected to oppose any US plans that could extend US protection from Japan and South Korea to Taiwan.

The Australian Financial Review on Friday reported that the US move is no surprise, as the threat posed by regional ballistic missiles in countries such as Russia, mainland China, North Korea, Iraq, Iran, India, and Pakistan, has been a focus of American concern ever since the Gulf War in 1991.

The daily also reported that Australia has participated in the development of TMD system with "Project Dundee" -- the 1997 testing of radar equipment in Western Australia designed to detect the launch of ballistic missiles in the Asia Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR SURGES TO TWO-AND-A-HALF MONTH HIGH ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The US dollar surged on Taiwan's foreign exchange market on Friday, in the first trading session after the four-day Lunar New Year holiday.
The greenback climbed by NT$0.128 to NT$32.406, the highest close in two-and-a-half months.
A total of US$145 million changed hands.
The US currency opened at the day's low of NT$32.359, and surged at one point to NT$32.438.

Analysts put the greenback's surge down to the 0.1 percent dip in Japan's interest rate on loans and the strength the US dollar gain against other currencies after the end of the impeachment process against President Bill Clinton.
However, local dealers said they expected the Central Bank of China to intervene to defend the NT$32.5 barrier.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA'S PRESIDENT QUOTES DENG XIAOPING ON MILITARY LINE

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin has quoted Deng Xiaoping on the relationship between military parades and the prestige of a supreme leader, Hong Kong's South China Morning Post reported on Friday.
The report quoted a Beijing source as saying that Jiang is confident a parade to be staged on National Day in October will consolidate his position as mainland China's undisputed helmsman.
In talks with his advisers, Jiang reportedly quoted Deng as saying: "During the tenure of Chairman Mao, the core of the first-generation leadership, military parades were not that rare.
"However, I only organized one parade, in 1984. And the core of the third-generation leadership should also hold parades only on major occasions."
Diplomatic analysts said Jiang will also try to boost his position as a "new-style philosopher king" through revising the constitution at the National People's Congress next month.
"A key revision was to enshrine Deng Xiaoping theory as a state dogma," the newspaper report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEWLY DISCOVERED GENE COULD REVERSE DISEASES

TEXT.P: Scientists at Montreal's McGill University said on Thursday they have discovered a new human gene that might eventually help "deprogram" cells in the body and reverse diseases like cancer.
The cells might also help in organ transplantation and cloning, they believe.
The researchers' early experiments on lung-cancer tissue, published this week in the British journal Nature, reveal that an enzyme called demethylase is key to changing how cells operate.
"We've been missing the microchips of biotechnology that we need and now we think we've found one of them," said Moshe Szyf, the associate professor of pharmacology who led the research.
He cautioned that the discovery's role in a potential cure for cancer is still small and any practical applications in medicine are still a long way off. His team will test their theory on mice.

For decades, scientists have thought enzymes can change the way cells work, but didn't know how, or which enzymes. They knew that, in the embryo, cells carry in them a person's complete DNA, and that as it develops, each cell breaks down that information for specific uses in the body. That's how individual organs are formed.
But what was less understood was how, in the embryo, humans change the pattern of cell modification inherited from their parents and form their own patterns, making them unique.
Now, Szyf and his team of researchers have come up with an answer: the inherited DNA patterns are "erased" by the demethylase enzyme.
With that knowledge, they believe science now has a key to unlock people's genetic programs and change what cells do.
For example, in a cancer patient whose cells have "modified" themselves out of control, drug therapy based on the right enzymes could be used to reverse the process, the team believes.
That same ability to modify cells would be a boon for transplantation: Organs could be grown specifically to match a person's biological makeup, with no fear of rejection.
Calling the work "very high-quality science," McGill University's dean of medicine Abe Fuks said it is as promising as the early research on tissue cultures that led to a vaccine for polio.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FM RECEIVES ASSURANCES FROM HOLY SEE COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu called on his Vatican counterpart Jean-Louis Tauran on Thursday at Vatican City, a press release issued by the ROC Foreign Ministry in Taipei announced on Friday.

Hu expressed Taipei's concerns over remarks made by Vatican Secretary of State Cardinal Angelo Sodano last Thursday. At a reception at the Italian embassy to the Vatican, Sodano was quoted as saying that the Catholic Church would move its embassy in Taipei "back to" Beijing immediately if the mainland Chinese authorities allowed it.

Hu told Tauran that the ROC, under the leadership of President Lee Teng-hui, is a country which enshrines human rights and pursues peace. It supports the Holy See's efforts to advance human rights and peace around the world, said the press release.

Noting that Pope John Paul II encourages contact between Taipei and Beijing, Hu said that Taiwan looks forward to dialogue with mainland China to iron out their differences and lay the groundwork for peaceful bilateral ties.

He emphasized that Taipei understands the Holy See's concern for the millions of Catholics in mainland China, and urged the church not to improve its ties with Beijing at the cost of Taipei, let alone forsake its followers in Taiwan.

In an attempt to address Hu's concerns, Tauran downplayed the significance of Sodano's remarks, saying that it was only the church's wish and that there has been no progress in its contacts with Beijing thus far.
He said the Vatican is pleased with its ties with Taipei, and understands Taipei's anguish over its reported contacts with Beijing.

Until recently the ROC's only ally in Europe, the Vatican makes no secret of its intention to forge ties with Beijing. It has shrunk from doing so only because Beijing demands the power to appoint bishops and insists that the Vatican should break ties with Taiwan.
Hu arrived in Rome on Thursday unannounced. He flew in from Jordan where he had conveyed Taipei's condolences over the death of King Hussein Bin Talal.
Although the Foreign Ministry statement did not disclose the length of his stay in Rome, Hu is expected to stay there until saturday, and to have a meeting with Sodano.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC FDI MART TO TAKE PLACE IN SEOUL IN JUNE

TEXT.P: The APEC Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) Mart will run from June 2-5 in Seoul. The theme of the mart is "The New Asia-Pacific: Investors' Choice for the 21st Century."

Throughout the mart, member economies will promote their business environments and investment opportunities to interested investors. Sessions on individual economies will be held on June 3 and 4, and special lectures by prominent experts are scheduled for June 2 and 3.
The mart is being organized by the Korea Trade-Investment Promotion Agency (KOTRA) and sponsored by the Ministry of Commerce, Industry & Energy, along with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs & Trade.

At the 6th APEC Leaders Meeting in November 1998 in Kuala Lumpur, the leaders stated their determination to work together to overcome the present economic challenges, and the FDI mart is one of their efforts to contribute to the economic development of economies in the region through the facilitation of investment in APEC.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE ELECTRONICS INDUSTRY CAPACITY GROWING

TEXT.P: The capacity of mainland China's electronics industry is growing, with its output of televisions, stereo equipment and telephones ranking first in the world, according to statistics released Friday by mainland China's Ministry of Information Industry.
Xinhua news agency quoted the statistics as reporting that manufacturing in this sector performed well last year.

A total of 2.48 billion renminbi has been invested in the establishment of infrastructure and technological innovation, and earnings from the domestic sale of its products has reached 310 billion renminbi, with exports accounting for US$27 billion.
The Xinhua report said the southeast coastal region is still the main area leading the growth of manufacture of these products.

The report said eight provinces and cities on the southeast coast gave the sector a 24 percentage point growth in 1998, with a production value accounting for 85 percent of mainland China's total production value in the sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMY HIGH ON AGENDAS OF RULING PARTY AND GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: The most urgent priority of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang is maintaining a healthy capital market to calm investors, said President Lee Teng-hui at a KMT gathering on Friday.

Speaking at a KMT meeting during which the attendees extended greetings to each other after the four-day Lunar New Year holiday, Lee, who is concurrently the KMT chairman, warned that economic issues, if not managed carefully, could lead to disaster.

He urged those party members at the helm of the government to work out comprehensive ways to expand domestic demand, revamp the financial system, re-invigorate flagging real estate markets, and restructure private enterprises.

Warning that economic rather than political issues will take center stage this year, Lee encouraged his party follower to win the public's confidence by turning the nation's economy around as the party did in the last decade in its advancement of Taiwan's democracy.

Recalling that the party has led the nation from poverty to prosperity over the last five decades, Lee told those present at the meeting that he is confident the KMT can lead the country through the current crisis as it has done many times in the past.
Meanwhile, Premier Vincent Siew echoed Lee's call in a pep talk to his Cabinet during a similar gathering at the Executive Yuan on Friday morning.
Siew urged his Cabinet to maintain the stability of economy while pursuing its development.
He also promised the public that a package of measures to boost the domestic bourse, as well as the economy, will be announced within a month.
A meeting of the Cabinet on economic issues was scheduled for later on Friday to discuss the conclusions reached at an economic forum earlier this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 20, or the fifth day of the first month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1694: Voltaire, French philosopher and writer and moralist who waged a lifelong campaign against intolerance and injustice, is born.
1811: Austria declares itself bankrupt.
1915: The Panama-Pacific Exhibition, in celebration of the opening of the Panama Canal between the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, opens in San Francisco.
1916: The Battle of Verdun bigins after chief of the German General Staff Falkenhayn chose to attack the French city of Verdun, despite believing that France would defend Verdun to the last man.
1919: Afgahn head of state Habibullah Khan is assasinated. He was succeeded by one of his sons, Amanullah Khan.
1922: Hong Kong police fire at workers who are on strike, killing two and heavily injuring seven.
1933: The US House of Representatives passes an act to abolish the law banning the consumption of alcohol in the United States.
1938: British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden resigns in protest against Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's policy of appeasement of Italy's Fascist dictator Benito Mussolini and German's Nazi dictator Adolf Hitler.
1942: Portugal protests to Japan after Japanese troops invade Portuguese Timor.
1946: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China declares the Yalta Secret Agreement not binding on China.
1947: Britain's labor government gives Lord Louis Mountbatten the task of supervising peaceful transition to independence for India after centuries of British rule.
1952: Meeting on the Treaty of Peace between the Republic of China and Japan is held in Taipei.
1962: Astronaut John Glenn circles the Earth three times in less than five hours to become the first American to orbit the planet.
1966: Chester William Nimitz, American admiral of the Pacific fleet during World War II, who halted Japanese expansion and ultimately destroyed the Japanese fleet with a strategy based largely on the use of aircraft carriers, dies at the age of 81.
1967: President Sukarno surrenders all executive power to General Suharto, keeping only the title of president of Indonesia.
1971: Major-General Idi Amin Dada heads the new government of Uganda as president after the Uganda Army overthrew Apollo Milton Obote.
1979: Mount Sinira erupts in Indonesia, claiming 175 lives.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who is not in office in the government of a country, should never give advice as to its policy."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
MOFA TO HOST SME SEMINAR FOR EAST EUROPEAN COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will host a 20-day business seminar to introduce Taiwan's developmental experience to three European countries.

MOFA, in conjunction with the Medium and Small Business Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs and Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, will hold the "Workshop on Development of Taiwan Small Businesses and Government Policy" from Feb. 21 to March 12 in Taipei.

Officials in charge of economic planning, financial management and government tax systems from Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary will take part in the symposium to learn about Taiwan's economic development experience, its macro-economic policy, the private sector's production and marketing strategy as well as its globalization bid and research and development drive, MOFA officials said.
While here, officials from the three countries will also tour relevant government agencies, local economic establishments, and the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan.

The seminar represents enhanced substantive ties between Taiwan and east European countries, MOFA officials noted. They added that Taipei's recent establishment of diplomatic ties with Macedonia indicates that economic development is a prime consideration for many new emerging countries when establishing their foreign policies.
