DOC.HEADLINE: US TRADE DEFICIT WITH TAIWAN HITS 9-YEAR HIGH
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 19 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Due to a sharp decline in exports to Taiwan, the United States' trade deficit with the island hit a nine-year high of US$15 billion in 1998, the US Department of Commerce reported on Friday.

According to statistics compiled by the US Commerce Department, bilateral US-Taiwan trade totaled US$51.28 billion last year, down 3.2 percent from 1997. US exports to Taiwan fell by 10.8 percent to reach about US$18.16, while Taiwan exports to the US grew by 1.5 percent to around US$33.12 billion.

An ROC trade official based in the United States pointed out, however, that US government statistics seemed to be exaggerated, as ROC customs figures put the 1998 trade gap between the two countries at US$9.7 billion, a difference of US$5.3 billion.

The official attributed the cause of the island's sluggish demand for foreign imports to the persistent Asian financial turmoil. As Taiwan was not the sole country affected by the crisis, the official said the US government should take this into consideration.

As part of the island's terms for joining the World Trade Organization, Taipei and Washington reached a bilateral agreement in February 1998. In it, Taiwan agreed to open its agricultural market to the United States and sent delegations on several large-scale buy-American missions to purchase US$1.1 billion worth of US farm products over the past year.

US government statistics also showed that all Asian countries experienced sharp declines in imports from the United States during last year since the region's financial woes broke out in the second half of 1997.

Indonesia posted the largest decrease in US imports of 49 percent in 1998, followed by South Korea with 34 percent, Hong Kong with 14.5 percent, Japan with 11.7 percent and Singapore with 11.4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: EARTHQUAKE JOLTS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 5.9 on the Richter scale hit Taiwan on Saturday morning, but no casualties were reported, the Central Weather Bureau said.
The bureau said the epicenter of the quake was located in waters 51 kilometers east of Orchid Island off the coast of Taitung in eastern Taiwan.
The temblor was felt in eastern and southern parts of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA VOWS TO LAUNCH RADARSAT-2 DESPITE NASA REFUSAL

TEXT.P: NASA is refusing to launch a new high-tech Canadian radar satellite because American intelligence agencies feel it poses a threat to US national security.
"We'll launch it," Industry Minister John Manley said Thursday. "Launching a satellite is not a difficult thing. There's lots of ways to get satellites launched."

Canada's Radarsat-2 satellite has an advanced radar scanner that can pierce through clouds and the dark of night. The scanner can help forecast crop yields, direct mineral exploration and help vessels navigate around Arctic ice.

The new satellite can reveal objects as small as three meters across. An older generation Radarsat-1 can only reveal objects seven meters across. This forward leap in technology reportedly unnerves US officials.
"Anything below five meters causes concern to the US intelligence community," said Hugues Gilbert, director of strategic development for the Canadian Space Agency.

He said the Americans are worried they might sell sensitive images to private businesses or other governments. "But we think that having the three-meter resolution is really crucial to Canadian industry. It's very important for tapping into new markets," he added.
The market for radar satellites is steadily growing. The Canadian Space Agency said it is ready to have the C$305 million satellite launched by another space agency if necessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA ARRESTS RECORD NUMBER OF ILLEGAL MIGRANTS

TEXT.P: Australian authorities arrested a record number of 70 illegal immigrants in their latest battle against illegal migrant laborers, the Immigration Department reported.

In Victoria, 51 farmhands were captured while 19 were apprehended in Queensland, Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said. The immigrants came from mainland China, Vietnam, South Korea, Malaysia, Indonesia, Samoa, Fiji, Israel and Britain.
Authorities began investigating the situation after local residents complained to police that they could not find jobs because farmers were employing illegal workers.

Charles Li, a Chinese-Australian, is accused of being a Sydney-based agent who introduced illegal migrants to work in a Victoria tomato farm. He allegedly charged about US$300 per person plus bus fare to Shepparton, a small town in that state. Li has denied any wrongdoing in the case.
Federal officers came under public criticism after they resorted to using rope to restrain a group after running out of handcuffs.
Migration agent Marion Le said she was shocked to hear of the use of rope to detain workers, noting that she has never known the department to ever do so.

Meanwhile, Victorian Agriculture Minister Pat McNamara said the government should make it easier for backpackers and other overseas workers to gain employment where there is a shortage of fruit and vegetable pickers.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING CLAMPS DOWN ON CORRUPTION IN ITS RICHEST PROVINCE

TEXT.P: Beijing is conducting a sweeping crackdown on corruption in Guangdong, the mainland's richest province, but foreign analysts believe it may be an impossible task, the Sydney Morning Herald reported.
In more than 20 years of reforms, Guangdong has become a chaotic mixture of roughneck capitalism, rampant corruption and flagging one-party rule, the paper noted.

Mainland President Jiang Zemin and Premier Zhu Rongji are worried that the mess will pose a serious threat to the country's political and economic stability and have launched an all-out offensive to bring the province to a heel.

Guangdong accounts for 10 percent of the mainland's gross national product and 40 percent of its total exports, but the province's economic growth is falling and unemployment is reaching dangerous levels. The crackdown so far has exposed and punished 171 corrupt mid-level government officials in the province. From May to July 1998, 1,252 cases involving corruption were brought to court, the daily reported.

To tighten control, local government stalwarts have been replaced with trusted officials from other provinces, almost every customs official has been replaced with outsiders to curb smuggling and censorship has been intensified over what had been mainland China's most daring and independent press, the daily reported.
Despite the high-profile crackdown, many ordinary people in the province believe graft in the government is now so pervasive that it will be impossible to remove.
The daily reported the biggest challenge for mainland China's central leadership in restraining the region may be much more intangible than corruption and financial irresponsibility.
Two decades of economic reforms have led to an increase of private businesses and a bigger middle class among Guangdong's 70 million people than anywhere else in mainland China.

Analysts believe these people, who have historically been at the forefront of political change, are becoming a much more effective pressure group for property rights and the rule of law than the dissident community.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM'S EUROPEAN TRIP PRIVATE: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Saturday that Foreign Minister Jason Hu's current trip in Europe is of a private nature and he is not taking part in any official activity there.
The ministry was responding to local news reports that Hu, before visiting the Vatican, traveled to Hungary and met with Hungarian officials.
Foreign Ministry Spokesman Roy Wu said the minister is vacationing with his family and other than his stay in the Vatican City, has no official activity in Europe.

After visiting Jordan with Legislative Yuan Vice President Yao Eng-chi on Feb. 10 to extend the ROC government's condolences over the death of King Hussein Bin Talal, Hu arrived in the Vatican, the ROC's only diplomatic ally in Europe.
Hu on Thursday called on his Vatican counterpart Jean-Louis Tauran and expressed Taipei's concern over remarks made by Vatican Secretary of State Cardinal Angelo Sodano last Thursday.

At a reception at the Italian embassy to the Vatican, Sodano was quoted as saying that the Catholic Church would move its embassy in Taipei "back to" Beijing immediately if the mainland Chinese authorities allowed it.

Hu told Tauran that the ROC, under the leadership of President Lee Teng-hui, is a country which respects human rights and pursues peace. It supports the Holy See's efforts to advance human rights and peace around the world, according to a press release issued by the ministry on Friday.

Noting that Pope John Paul II encourages contact between Taipei and Beijing, Hu said that Taiwan looks forward to dialogue with mainland China to iron out their differences and lay the groundwork for peaceful bilateral ties.

He emphasized that Taipei understands the Holy See's concern for the millions of Catholics in mainland China, and urged the church not to improve its ties with Beijing at the cost of Taipei, let alone forsake its followers in Taiwan.

In an attempt to address Hu's concerns, Tauran downplayed the significance of Sodano's remarks, saying that it was only the church's wish and that there has been no progress in its contacts with Beijing thus far.
He said the Vatican is pleased with its ties with Taipei, and understands Taipei's anguish over its reported contacts with Beijing.

Until recently as the ROC's only ally in Europe, the Vatican has made no secret of its intention to forge ties with Beijing. It has refused to do so only because Beijing demands the power to appoint bishops and insists that the Vatican should break ties with Taiwan.
Hu is scheduled to call on Cardinal Angelo Sodano late in the day, and will return to Taipei Feb. 23. (By Bear Lee).

DOC.HEADLINE: SUHARTO'S SON-IN-LAW DEFENDS TROOP DECISION

TEXT.P: The son-in-law of former Indonesian President Suharto admitted on Friday to having mobilized troops last May, but his aim was to protect newly-appointed President B.J. Habibie, he said in a written statement.

Lieutenant General Prabowo Subianto, who was ousted as head of the powerful Strategic Reserve Command after the incident, also maintained that he had kept armed forces chief General Wiranto informed of his actions.

The signed four-page statement from Amman, Jordan, where he is now living, was in response to Habibie's allegations that the general launched military deployments outside the new leader's residence to challenge his appointment following Suharto's downfall.

Habibie told participants at the Asian-German Editors Forum this week that he had received reports of the troop concentration from Gen. Wiranto, who asked how he should respond. The president then ordered his military commander to pull out the soldiers.

Lt. Gen. Prabowo, who was removed from his post the next morning, said in his statement that he was merely following procedures in securing the capital, given the devastating riots and political uncertainty.

Prabowo said troop concentrations near the houses of the president and vice-president were in line with operational orders issued at that time. He maintained that it was inconceivable he would want to challenge Habibie's appointment.

It is not very clear why Habibie chose to announce Lt. Gen. Prabowo's alleged actions more than seven months after the incident. Political observers told The Straits Times that the German-trained engineer was keen to impress his foreign audience that "he was not handed power on the silver platter and that he had to fight for his position."

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR, SHARE PRICES UP IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Fueled by a strong US dollar against the Japanese yen, the US dollar broke the 33 New Taiwan dollar mark on Saturday in the Taipei foreign exchange market, closing at 33.275 up NT$0.75 from Friday's finish.
The greenback traded at a high of 33.305 and a low of 32.511 after opening at 32.573.
Interbank transactions totaled US$254 million.
Meanwhile, the Taiwan Stock Exchange was boosted by a string of measures announced by the government aimed at propping up the local stock market and the banking sector.

Share prices opened higher and rallied by 274.33 points on the first day of trading following the Chinese New Year holidays. The weighted index, the bourse's key benchmark, rose above the 6,000-point level by closing at 6,072.33.
Stocks in the eight major categories all surged, with financial shares registering the largest increase of 6.7 percent. Other issues also jumped ranging from 2.5 percent to 6.1 percent.
A total of 1.85 billion shares changed hands, while market turnover hit NT$57.89 billion.

Finance Minister Paul Chiu expressed delight over the stock market's performance, saying that it marked a good beginning for the year of the rabbit. He promised that the government will do its best to form a good investment climate for the general public and help build a more stable capital market.
The Finance Ministry's measures, which were announced on Friday, are as follows:

-- revenue taxes for banks will be lowered to 2 percent from the present 5 percent, a move which the Finance Ministry said is expected to increase revenue for the banking sector by about NT$132 billion over the next four years which banks can use to write down bad loans;
-- the existing 0.1 percent tax on transactions of corporate bonds will be abolished; and
-- incentives will be implemented to encourage mergers of financial institutions.

The Central Bank of China (CBC) also announced it will slash the average reserve requirement ratio from the current level of 7.65 percent to 6.41 percent, which hopefully will release a record high of NT$166.8 billion worth of capital to the market, reflecting the CBC's resolve to build a loose monetary climate.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S POPULATION NEARS 22 MILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's population reached nearly 21.93 million by the end of 1998, an increase of 185,776 from a year ago, statistics compiled by the Ministry of the Interior showed.

According to the figures, there were 6.36 million households in the Taiwan area as of the end of last year with an average of 3.4 persons for each family. Compared with 1997, Taiwan's population registered an annual growth of 0.854 percent.

In terms of density, Taipei, Taiwan's largest city, took the lead with 9,713 people residing in each square meter. The southern and central port cities of Kaohsiung and Taichung ranked second and third, respectively, with their population density hitting 9,520 and 5,616 people in each square meter.

Taitung County in eastern Taiwan posted the lowest level in population density, which translated into 71 people per square meter. Neighboring Hualien County and central Nantou County followed, with 77 and 133 people living in each square meter, the statistics indicated.

Life expectancy reached an average of 74.61 years in the Taiwan area last year, with 71.96 years for men and 77.9 years for women. The number of people aged over 65 accounted for 8.26 percent of the island's total population, higher than the 7 percent level set by the United Nations for the definition of a so-called "elderly society."
In 1998, a total of 145,976 couples married, while 43,603 couples divorced. On average, Taiwan men married at the age of 31.5, while women married at 28.4.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 21, or the sixth day of the first month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1917: Modern China's founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen completes "The Fundamental Knowledge in Democracy," a book dealing with the procedures of parliamentary rule.
1950: The United States suspends diplomatic ties with Bulgaria.
1952: US movie star Elizabeth Taylor weds hotel tycoon Conrad Hilton, Jr.
1957: Israel defies a UN resolution and holds on to the Gaza Strip.
1960: Cuban President Fidel Castro nationalizes all the country's private businesses.
1972: US President Richard Nixon visits mainland China.
1986: Mainland Chinese air force pilot Chen Baozhong defects to South Korea in a MiG-19 fighter.
1986: Shigechiyo Izumi, the world's oldest man, dies in Japan at the age of 120.
1989: Czech writer Vaclav Havel is imprisoned for initiating demonstration. Havel later became president of Czechoslovakia.
1990: Salvadorean President Alfredo Cristiani visits the Republic of China.
1991: British prima ballerina Dame Margot Fonteyn dies in Panama at the age of 73.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Appearance of high spirit without integrity; of dullness without humility; of simplicity without honesty;--of such men I really do not know what to say."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NURSING STUDENT BELIEVED MISSING IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: A Kaohsiung couple has lost contact with their 18-year-old nursing student daughter who is believed to be in Australia, the family said on Sunday.

Liu Liang-yin reportedly left for Australia on Jan. 21, the last day before the winter semester break, without telling her family of her plans. Between Jan. 21 and Feb. 16, Liu contacted her home only four times without revealing her whereabouts.
According to Liu's mother, Liu last called home on Feb. 16 and spoke with her grandmother who said Liu was crying when she said she had run out of money.

The Liu family, wanting to send her money, did not have an address or other related information other than a telephone number. After dialing the number, the family only heard an English-language message on an answering machine.
Liu had apparently purchased a plane ticket and had her passport prepared through a travel agency without her parent's knowledge.
Liu's mother noted that her daughter is an avid Internet user who may have made friends in Australia through online contacts and went there to meet them.
Meanwhile, Liu's father said he will apply for a suspension at Liu's nursing school on Monday, the first day of classes, so she may resume her studies upon returning to Kaohsiung.
The Liu family has sought assistance from both the Taiwan and Australian authorities to help locate the missing student.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER MEETS VATICAN SECRETARY OF STATE
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Feb. 20 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu called on Vatican Secretary of State Cardinal Angelo Sodano on Saturday and exchanged views on a wide range of topics.

During the meeting, Hu stressed that ties between the Republic of China and the Vatican represent a marriage of ideals, as both sides uphold the principles of peace, compassion and human rights. The Republic of China and the Vatican are good partners in the business of accelerating religious freedom in mainland China, he noted.

Hu, who arrived in the Holy See after attending the funeral of Jordanian King Hussein Bin Talal, briefed Sodano on the latest developments in cross-strait relations and on the present state of the dialogue between Taiwan and mainland China.

It is hoped that through constructive dialogue, Taiwan and mainland China will redress their differences and bolster mutual understanding, which will ultimately lead to peaceful reunification, Hu said. The entire process, however, will require the support of ROC allies, such as the Vatican, he added.
He reiterated the ROC government's wish that all people throughout mainland China will be blessed with democracy, freedom and human rights, which is also the wish of the Vatican, Hu said.

For his part, Sodano said the Vatican will not normalize relations with Beijing until religious freedom is commonplace in mainland China. He stressed that the Vatican would never do anything that would compromise the interests of the people of the Republic of China on Taiwan.

The Vatican, which was the ROC's only European ally until Taiwan forged ties with Macedonia last month, has made no secret of its desire to establish relations with Beijing. So far, however, the two countries have remained deadlocked over the appointment of bishops and Taiwan.
Beijing insists that it, and not the Vatican, has the right to appoint bishops in mainland China, and that the Vatican must sever diplomatic ties with Taipei to establish relations with Beijing.
Hu is scheduled to return to Taipei on Feb. 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: WIFE AND DAUGHTER OF TAIWAN MERCHANT STILL UNAWARE OF HIS DEATH

TEXT.P: A Taiwan national and her daughter, who are recovering from carbon-monoxide poisoning in a mainland Chinese hospital, are unaware that the incident claimed the lives of her husband and son, relatives said.

Hu Chun-te and his son Hu Li-tsung both died of carbon-monoxide asphyxiation while Hu Chun-te's wife Tseng Chao-chun and daughter Hu Fang-ching lost consciousness due to an old water heater in their apartment bathroom on Wednesday evening, medical reports indicated.
According to the family's relatives, Tseng and her daughter have not yet been informed of the deaths of Hu Chun-te and Hu Li-tsung as they are still weak and need to recover their strength.

Hu and his son had been in Taizhou in Zhejiang province in connection with their hardware-salvaging business. Tseng Chao-chun and her daughter Hu Fang-ching made the trip to Taizhou from Taiwan recently for a family reunion over the Chinese Lunar New Year holiday.

Five members of Hu's extended family left Taiwan for the mainland on Friday to deal with the funeral arrangements. They have visited Hu's wife and daughter at the Taizhou People's Hospital, but did not inform them about the deaths.

Hu's relatives said they would tell Tseng and her daughter the news only after they recover enough to withstand the tragedy. The relatives added that they will decide with Tseng on the details of returning the remains of her husband and son back to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF NORTHBOUND CARS ON CHUNGSHAN FREEWAY HITS RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: The number of automobiles traveling northbound on the Sun Yat-sen (Chungshan) Freeway on Saturday reached a record high over the Chinese Lunar New Year, which concludes on Sunday, the National Freeway Bureau said.

Although a total of 1.43 million cars traveled on the North-South Freeway on Saturday -- compared to 1.58 million on Thursday and 1.50 million on Friday -- 832,000 cars were recorded on the freeway's northbound lanes, a record for a single day.
The number of passenger cars using the Chungshan Freeway on Sunday is expected to be less than that of Saturday, bureau officials said.
Before 1 p.m. Sunday, the entire freeway will remain toll-free in both directions. Traffic controls, which require a minimum of four passengers per car, will also remain effective throughout Sunday.

The North-South Freeway was designed to accommodate a maximum of 870,000 passenger cars per day. During the 1998 Chinese New Year, however, as many as 1.54 million cars used the freeway daily. In 1996, an average of 1.08 million passenger cars used the freeway each day, according to National Freeway Bureau tallies.
To ease traffic conditions during the Chinese New Year, the National Freeway Bureau imposed full-occupancy traffic controls and dropped the toll fees.
Despite the two measures, the average speeds reached 30-40 kilometers per hour during 3 p.m. and 6 p.m. on Saturday when traffic was at its heaviest, bureau officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY WORSE LAST LUNAR YEAR THAN IN YEARS BEFORE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Nearly 90 percent of people in Taiwan believe the nation's economy was worse in the last lunar year than in those before, according to survey results released on Sunday.

Eighty-nine percent of respondents in the survey, conducted by the Taipei-based Brotherhood Cultural and Educational Foundation, said Taiwan's economy was worse off during the just-ended Year of the Tiger than in the previous several lunar years.
The Year of the Tiger ended Feb. 15, 1999.
The people of Taiwan are pessimistic in regard to the state of the economy, said Wu Poh-hsiung, senior advisor to the president and chairman of the foundation, at a press conference Sunday.

Questioned about the cause of Taiwan's economic problems, 40.6 percent of respondents said that an unhealthy economic system at home was responsible. Meanwhile, 32.5 percent of respondents attributed Taiwan's economic problems to last year's global economic sluggishness, while 20.6 percent said both a global slowdown and an unhealthy economic system at home were the cause. About 6 percent said they did not know or declined to answer.
The public has little confidence in both Taiwan's future economic growth and the government's strategies to improve the economy this year, Wu said.

Nevertheless, 53.1 percent of those polled said Taiwan's sound economic fundamentals would help the island to overcome its current economic turmoil, and 61.1 percent of respondents said most Taiwan companies would survive, while only 24.2 percent answered otherwise, according to the survey.
Noting public apprehension regarding the state of the economy, Wu suggested the government map out efficient and comprehensive middle and long-term measures to pump up the economy.
He added that the government must also explain its efforts to revive the economy to the public.
In the random telephone survey, which was conducted Feb. 12-13, usable responses were obtained from 1,090 Taiwan citizens 21 and older. The survey's margin of error was 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA TO ASK AUSTRALIA TO SEND PROMISED KOALAS TO TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on Sunday said he will set off for Australia on Feb. 28, and during his trip he will try to persuade Australia to send to Taipei a pair of koala bears promised by Australia's Gold Coast.

Ma revealed the plan during a Chinese Lunar New Year activity at the Taipei City Zoo. He explained that his predecessor, Chen Shui-bien, had arranged for two koalas to be presented to Taipei as a gift by Taipei's Australian sister-city Gold Coast.
The presentation has not yet taken place because the Australian government has not yet approved it, Ma said.
The city zoo has built a koala home stocked with eucalyptus trees, Ma said, noting the Australian animals can move into their new home at any time.

Ma is traveling to Australia to take part in an upcoming Cities of Asia-Pacific Conference that will be held in Brisbane. It is his first foreign visit aimed at promoting city-to-city diplomacy since winning Taipei's mayoral election last Dec. 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH SEEN AS BEST AMONG ASIAN DRAGONS: CBC

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's economic growth for 1999 will likely rank on top among Asia's four dragon economies, said senior officials with the economic research office of the Central Bank of China (CBC).

CBC officials made the remark on Sunday despite the downward revision on projections for Taiwan's 1999 economic growth by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) under the Executive Yuan before the Chinese Lunar New Year.

Among the four Asian dragons, the economic growth for South Korea, Singapore and Hong Kong are expected to register 0.6 percent, zero and negative 1 percent respectively, a far cry from Taiwan's estimated 4.7 percent, according to CBC officials.

Even compared with the growth of European and American economies, Taiwan's economic performance can be considered rather outstanding, said Shea Jia-dong, CBC's deputy governor. Taiwan's economic prospects will soon be at the end of the tunnel, Shea added.
The deputy governor expressed hope that people in Taiwan will not be too pessimistic about the country's economic prospects.
The economic growth of the US, Germany, Britain, France, Canada and Italy are expected to be 2.4 percent, 1.9 percent, 1 percent, 2.1 percent, 2.2 percent and 1.8 percent, respectively.
While in regard to Southeast Asian countries, figures for the Philippines, Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia are 3.7 percent, 0.5 percent, negative 0.8 percent and negative 3.9 percent, respectively.

What is noteworthy is that Japan, Asia's economic giant, is expected to register a negative 1.3 percent growth this year, indicating that Japan is still under a shadow of economic recession, noted CBC's officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE VISITOR MAY LOSE EYESIGHT AFTER ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: A Japanese man who accidentally stabbed himself in the eye with a chopstick could lose his eyesight in that eye, staff members of National Taiwan University (NTU) Hospital said Sunday.

Satoshi Kinoshita stabbed himself with a chopstick in his right eyeball Sunday morning at Taipei's Lai Lai Sheraton Hotel, where he was staying. He was eating a bowl of instant noodles and packing when he tripped over something on the floor.
The chopstick pierced his eyeball and lodged itself inside to a depth of about 3 centimeters. The stick was embedded so far into Kinoshita's eye that he could not remove it, he said.
After the accident, Kinoshita called room service and asked for help. When hotel staff and an interpreter arrived, Kinoshita apologized for his carelessness and asked to be sent to the hospital.
He was rushed to nearby NTU Hospital, where doctors determined that his injury was not life-threatening, although they said he could lose his eyesight in his right eye.
The doctors were expected to remove the chopstick Sunday, and Kinoshita will have to stay at the hospital for several days for observation, NTU Hospital staff said.
According to Luo Wei-chun, manager of Lai Lai Sheraton's Room Service Department, both the chopsticks and the bowl of instant noodles were bought into Taiwan from Japan by Kinoshita.
The hotel has informed Kinoshita's wife, who is leaving for Taiwan.
The hotel expressed its regret over the accident and has offered to give Kinoshita a discount on his stay. He was to have left Taiwan for Japan Sunday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO BIG PROBLEM IN TAIPEI-VATICAN TIES, SAYS FM HU
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Feb. 20 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: There is no problem in relations between the Vatican and the Republic of China, and differences between the two are not as great as has been speculated, ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said Saturday.
Hu, who concluded a three-day visit to the Holy See and left for New York Sunday, said both sides have come to understand each other better as a result of his visit.
"How to work out a formula of interaction that is comfortable for both sides is a challenge to us, and we should strive to accomplish it," Hu said upon his departure.
Over the last three days, Hu has met with ranking officials in the Holy See, including Vatican Secretary of State Cardinal Angelo Sodano, for in-depth talks.

Hu said he recognized that the common goal of Taipei and the Holy See is to avoid harming the interests of the Taiwan people under any circumstances, even as the Vatican expands its contacts with mainland China.
Taipei shares the Holy See's ideals in regard to promoting religious contacts with people in mainland China, Hu added.

Commenting on a recent spate of remarks by Vatican officials about a desire for closer relations with mainland China, Hu said the true purpose of such remarks is to bring about greater religious freedom for the people of mainland China. There are no significant differences between Taipei and the Holy See on that point, Hu added.

It is challenging to work out a formula to achieve the goal of promoting religious freedom in mainland China on the one hand while ensuring that the Vatican is not being used by Beijing or sacrificing Taiwan's interests on the other, Hu said.
Hu, who attended the funeral of Jordanian King Hussein Bin Talal before visiting the Vatican, left Saturday evening for New York, where he will meet with his family.
The foreign minister is expected to hold a press conference after he returns to Taiwan Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CARDINAL SHAN EXPLAINS VATICAN'S RECENT CALL TO BEIJING

TEXT.P: Cardinal Paul K. H. Shan on Sunday explained that a recent call to Beijing by the Vatican in which Vatican officials mentioned the possibility of relocating the Holy See's Taiwan embassy was simply aimed at urging mainland authorities to respect the religious beliefs of the people of mainland China.

Cardinal Shan offered the explanation after the appearance of foreign-wire reports that Cardinal Angelo Sodano, the Vatican's secretary of state, indicated the Vatican would relocate its embassy from Taipei to Beijing, a move that implies a switch in relations.
Shan, who is scheduled to leave for the Holy See on Monday, said Sodano's remarks came during a regular call to authorities in Beijing. Such calls have been made for dozens of years, he said.

"This is no longer newsworthy," Shan said, adding that the Holy See has never lost concern for the religious freedoms of mainland China's 15 million Catholics, nor has it ever stopped working to ensure greater religious freedoms for the church's mainland Chinese followers.

He noted that as a Pole, Pope John Paul II did not forge formal relations with his motherland until it ridded itself of its Communist regime and embraced democracy. It is impossible for the pope to change his pro-democratic stand now, Shan stressed.
Anyone who knows anything about diplomacy will know that the call is not cause for worry, Shan said, adding that he will not mention the call in an upcoming meeting with the pope.

There are now more than 2,000 ethnic Chinese living in Rome, and Shan said he would lobby during an upcoming visit to the Vatican for a special church to be set up for them. Shan is visiting the Holy See to take part in a meeting of Asian bishops. He is scheduled to return to Taiwan on March 7.
