DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REPATRIATES 30 SUSPECTED CRIMINALS DURING LAST FIVE YEARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan has repatriated over the past five years 30 foreign nationals suspected of having committed crimes overseas amid efforts by local police authorities to crack down on international crime, the Ministry of Justice's Investigation Bureau (MJIB) reported Monday.

Most of the 30 were from Hong Kong, Macao and Southeast Asia. Their ability to enter Taiwan was aided by the similarity of their languages and hair and skin color to those of the people of Taiwan, according to MJIB authorities.

In 1993 Hong Kong police authorities informed their Taiwan counterparts through Interpol that a gangland figure and drug trafficker suspected of having committed homicide and whose capture carried a HK$100,000 reward might have snuck into Taiwan.

After a lengthy investigation Taiwan police discovered that the man was working as a waiter at a tea house in western Taipei's Wanhua District. The man, who had been leading a quiet life during his stay in Taiwan, was apprehended and repatriated.

In 1994, the MJIB received information from the Philippine government that a murderer from that country may have fled to Taiwan. The Philippine government asked for Taiwan's help in tracking down the man.
MJIB investigators found that the Filipino had entered Taiwan with a phony passport and was working as an overseas laborer at a factory in central Taiwan's Nantou. He was apprehended and repatriated.

In another case, one of Thailand's most notorious drug lords lived in Taiwan for two years before being caught by police, who found the man working as a senior executive at a multinational company in Taipei, according to MJIB officials.

Canadian officials once asked Taiwan police authorities to help track down an "easy rider" gang leader who merchandised heroin with postal stamps. Local police found the man teaching English in the eastern Taiwan city of Taitung.
In addition to tracking down suspected foreign criminals in Taiwan, police have also cooperated with foreign police authorities in finding foreign nationals who have gone missing.

Acting on information provided by British police authorities, MJIB investigators located an Englishman who went missing after having a fight with his wife in Britain. The man was found teaching English at a Taipei cram school.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGAL, TAX SERVICES MOST SOUGHT BY TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN MAINLAND

TEXT.P: The services most needed by Taiwan businessmen investing in the mainland are legal and tax counseling services, a survey conducted by the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) showed on Monday.
CETRA conducted the survey recently to learn the difficulties faced by Taiwan businessmen in the mainland.

According to the survey Taiwan businessmen also frequently need help in obtaining bank loans from mainland banks, obtaining information on mainland Chinese trade and its economy, communicating with various Taiwan manufacturers, solving management problems in mainland plants, training mainland officials and resolving trade disputes.

Extra expenses resulting from social activities were cited as the most nagging problem facing Taiwan businessmen. Other management problems included the trouble companies' Taiwan staffs had adjusting to living in the mainland, difficulties in obtaining local bank loans, intervention by mainland Chinese bureaucrats and the difficulty in prying local markets there.

Taiwan businessmen also complained of a lack of sincerity among mainland businessmen in implementing contracts, rising inventory costs, an insufficient infrastructure -- such as electrical, communications and transportation facilities -- difficulties remitting profits overseas and disputes between labor and management.

To help Taiwan businessmen CETRA will increase its collection of information on the mainland market, help Taiwan businessmen establish marketing networks, upgrade the image and profile of Taiwan-produced products and promote a strategic alliance between Taiwan and foreign businesses in the mainland to help tap the mainland market.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE INVESTIGATING ATTEMPTED EXTORTION FROM 7-ELEVEN PARENT

TEXT.P: Police are investigating the attempted extortion of NT$21 million from President Chain Store Corp., which is responsible for Taiwan's 7-Eleven convenience store chain, sources from the corporation confirmed on Sunday.

On Feb. 10, just before the start of the recent Chinese Lunar New Year, President Chain Store Corp. received a letter in which the authors, who signed the note "super men with a thousand faces," threatened to inject cyanide into products sold at 2,000 7-Eleven stores islandwide during the Chinese Lunar New Year unless they received NT$21 million.

Police said the corporation received subsequent threats on Feb. 15 and 19 indicating that the toxin had already been injected into products at one store. President Chain Store Corp. has since begun checking up on its stores and has been in close contact with police.
The police are now checking up on all people with criminal records and collecting related information in a bid to apprehend the extortionists.
This case is the 11th of its kind since June 1987, and suspects were brought into custody in all 10 previous cases.
Threats to inject cyanide into store products first occurred in Japan before 1987. In that case as well, suspects were apprehended.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER US PRESIDENT CARTER TO VISIT TAIWAN IN LATE MARCH

TEXT.P: Former US President Jimmy Carter will visit the Republic of China on Taiwan in late March at the invitation of a private think tank here, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Monday.
MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said the itinerary and other details concerning Carter's Taiwan visit have yet to be finalized.
Wu said as the MOFA is not responsible for organizing Carter's visit, it is not proper for the ministry to make any comment on Carter's activities here at the moment.
"At any rate, we welcome Carter's visit," Wu told a routine news conference, adding that the MOFA will make necessary explanations of Carter's itinerary when the time is right.

This will be Carter's first visit to Taiwan. His visit is expected to inspire much discussion in local society as his handling of switching diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing 20 years ago had hurt the ROC's national dignity and interests.

According to a local newspaper report, Carter is scheduled to make a three-day visit to Taiwan in late March. The report said Carter will deliver a public speech and meet with ROC President Lee Teng-hui and Vice President Lien Chan during his visit. Carter may be accompanied by his wife and three grown-up children on his planned visit.

Government spokesman Chen Chien-jen extended a warm welcome to Carter's visit, saying it is a good thing for Carter to come to Taiwan to witness the island's phenomenal political and economic development over the past two decades.

Chen was working in the ROC embassy in the United States when Carter abruptly announced in late 1978 that his administration would "normalize" relations with mainland China and cut diplomatic ties with the ROC from Jan. 1, 1979.

"It is painful to recall that moment," Chen said, adding that he believes if Carter himself or his key aides had visited Taiwan before making such a crucial decision, his administration's handling of the issue might not have been so hurting.
Chen said even though the ROC disagrees with Carter's decision, it still welcomes his visit. "We hope to make friends with as many people as possible," he noted.
Moreover, Chen said he is convinced that Carter will come to a better understanding of Taiwan after his visit.

"We have not been daunted by Washington's switch of diplomatic allegiance. Instead, we have managed to weather through many adversities and have grown even stronger and become a mature democracy since that dark moment," he stressed proudly.

Chen said Carter has won much acclaim for his diligent efforts to promote world peace, human rights, global democratic development and many other public-spirited programs since he ended his presidential tenure in January 1981.
Noting that Carter is a devout Christian, Chen said he is impressed by Carter's sincerity and down-to-earth working style.

Carter set up a "Carter Center" in his hometown of Atlanta, Georgia to promote global peace, democracy and human rights shortly after stepping down from the presidency. Over the past 20 years, he has traveled to Ethiopia, Haiti, Bosnia, the Korean Peninsula and the Middle East as a special envoy of the US president to mediate peace in those turbulent areas.
Carter has made five trips to mainland China over the past two decades. He last visited the mainland in July 1997.

Carter has seldom made comments on US foreign policy in recent years. But he said after the 1996 Taiwan Strait missile crisis that one consensus reached between him and the late mainland Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping while discussing normalization of bilateral ties was that any Taiwan-mainland disputes should be resolved by peaceful means, not by military force.

Mainland China test-fired missiles and conducted live-fire war games in waters near Taiwan in the run-up to Taiwan's first direct presidential election in March 1996. The event is now commonly called the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Feb. 22, or the seventh day of the first month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1732: George Washington, the first US president, is born.
1819: Spain cedes the state of Florida to the United States.
1902: The first clash breaks out among members of the US Senate.
1932: Edward Kennedy, US senator and younger brother of John F. Kennedy, is born.
1940: The 14th Dalai Lama is enthroned in Lhasa, Tibet.
1948: More than 20,000 students demonstrate against the Yalta Secrete Agreement and call for the Soviet Union to withdraw its forces from China.
1967: Indonesian President Sukarno announces the end of his rule and transfers political power to Gen. Suharto.
1979: The Caribben island of St. Lucia announces independence from Britain.
1993: The Republic of China film "The Wedding Banquet" wins a Golden Bear Award for Best Picture at the 43rd Berlin International Film Festival.
1996: The French government announces the abolishment of conscription and the adoption of a voluntary system for military service.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In education, study always as if you have not yet reached your goal and as though apprehensive of losing it."

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA'S RIGHTISTS VOTE TO CREATE NEW PARTY

TEXT.P: Canada's right-wing political forces decided Sunday to create a new party to replace the current Reform and Conservative parties.
Delegates at the United Alternative conference in Ottawa voted in favor of creating a new political party in an effort to unite-the-right in Canada.
The right-wingers know that without a united right, they will never unseat the Liberals in the federal government.

The 1,500 delegates at the conference voted on a number of options that would allow the Reform and Tory parties to join forces so they will have a chance of defeating the Liberals in the next federal election.
The options included: uniting behind an existing party; merging established parties; cooperating in choosing candidates at the riding level; or the creation of a new party.
The voting was by preferential ballot with delegates ranking the options in order of preference. The last option was the only one to receive a majority vote.

But Conservative leader Joe Clark has rejected the conference, which means it is uncertain whether the vote will have any real impact on the right. Many delegates have questioned the value of creating a new party when there is already a national conservative party that is established across the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA, NZ TO EXPLORE FREE TRADE PACTS WITH AMERICAS

TEXT.P: Australia and New Zealand will jointly explore free trade agreements with the United States and South American countries so that both Australia and New Zealand can expand exports.
The move came after a series of talks between Australian Prime Minister John Howard and his New Zealand counterpart, Jenny Shipley, in Queenstown in New Zealand.

Both leaders said they would step up efforts to pursue trans-Pacific free trade agreements and that they were interested in exploring new opportunities with the United States and the Mercosur trade group in South America, which includes Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay and Paraguay.
Both Howard and Shipley also had a lengthy discussion on ways to restore momentum and credibility to the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, which will meet in New Zealand later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE TO TEE OFF 'TAI-SHANG' CUP GOLF TOURNEY

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui will be invited to tee off at the First Tai-shang (Taiwanese merchants in mainland China) Cup golf tournament, scheduled to be held in mid-June, at about the time of the Dragon Boat Festival, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) reported Monday.

The Tai-shang Cup golf tournament is one of several activities to be jointly sponsored by SEF and the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) this year to bolster relations and communications between Taiwan authorities and Taiwanese merchants who maintain business or industrial operations in mainland China.
SEF and MAC are also working on sponsoring a summer camp exclusively for the children of Taiwanese merchants who maintain business or industrial operations on the Chinese mainland.

Officials from SEF, MAC, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and representatives from the Chinese National Federation of Industries met Monday at the Grand Hyatt Taipei for a Chinese New Year's cocktail party. The party was also attended by more than 200 Taiwanese merchants.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-MACEDONIA TIES ARE FIRM AND SOLID, MOFA STRESSES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Monday said the newly established diplomatic relations with Macedonia are firm and solid, and will not be altered by any foreign intervention or scenario.

MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said the ministry is keeping abreast of the latest foreign reports concerning relations among the ROC, Macedonia and mainland China as the deadline for the renewal of UN troops in Macedonia nears.

Wu said Taipei is closely monitoring all relevant situations in regard to Macedonia, but the truth and validity of formal diplomatic relations between the ROC and Macedonia are unaffected by any reports, allegations or suggestions from the international community.

The latest foreign wire reports have said that France is hoping Macedonia will review its diplomatic ties with Taiwan before Feb. 28, the date the mandate for the UN Preventive Deployment Force known as UNPREDEP, expires.
Reports said France wants Macedonia to maintain only economic relations with Taiwan but not recognize Taiwan as a separate state.
Some international diplomats also fear that Beijing will make good on its threat to veto the UN troop operation in retaliation of Skopje's new relations with Taiwan, the reports added.

Commenting on the news, Wu said France's efforts are at most a suggestion and formal diplomatic relations between Taipei and Skopje forged last month is a firm, formal and precise diplomatic agreement.
ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu and his Macedonian counterpart, Aleksandar Dimitrov, signed a joint communique in Taipei on Jan. 27 on the establishment of full diplomatic relations.
Macedonia, which achieved independence from the former Yugoslavia in 1991, became the second European state to have diplomatic ties with the ROC, after the Vatican.
Wu reiterated that the Taipei-Skopje ties, forged in the spirit of sovereignty and principles of equality and reciprocity, are fully supported by the government and the people in Taiwan.
He noted that although there have been noises in Macedonia resistant to the new diplomatic shift, the establishment of ties was officially passed by the Macedonia cabinet and parliament.

Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, who spearheaded the campaign to establish relations with Taiwan, reaffirmed repeatedly at home and during a visit to Washington, D.C. recently that the decision to forge formal ties with the ROC will not be changed.
Wu repeated that international concerns, either out of goodwill or not, are not affecting the truth and validity of formal diplomatic ties between the ROC and Macedonia.
The UN peacekeeping force was deployed in Macedonia in 1995 to monitor borders and deter the spread of fighting to Macedonia from Bosnia and other parts of the former Yugoslavia.
Meanwhile, Foreign Minister Jason Hu, who was originally scheduled to leave for Macedonia on Feb. 23 for a formal visit, has postponed his trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW DPP REPRESENTATIVE LEAVES FOR US VISIT

TEXT.P: The main opposition Democratic Progressive Party's new representative to the United States, Chiou Yi-jen, left for Washington, D.C. on Monday for a 12-day visit.
Chiou, who once served as DPP's secretary-general, said prior to his departure that his current trip is aimed at establishing communications channels with US authorities and forging mutual trust.

Chiou will attend a change-over ceremony to be held at the DPP's representative office in Washington, D.C. on Tuesday afternoon. Chiou will succeed Parris Chang as the DPP's new envoy to the United States. Chang, an incumbent Taiwan legislator representing the overseas Chinese community, will also be present at Tuesday's change-over ceremony.

During his stay in Washington, Chiou will visit US Congress and the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), which is authorized by the US government to handle exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.

In addition, Chiou will call at prestigious US think tanks, including the Heritage Foundation, the Brooking Foundation and the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), as well as meet with senior American media executives.
Chiou will also visit New York before returning to Taipei on March 5. Chiou will formally assume his new post in late March.

Chiou said he will develop extensive contacts with the US executive branch, Congress, private think tank researchers and media organizations to allay their misgivings about the DPP's stances on Taiwan independence and several other major political issues.

"Americans still have plenty of misunderstanding about our party, including our pro-independence platform and our positions on Taiwan's national security, foreign policy and trade strategy," Chiou said.
He pointed out that the DPP, while advocating Taiwan independence, will fully respect Taiwan people's free will in deciding the island's future.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER US DEFENSE SECRETARY TO VISIT TAIWAN: REPORT

TEXT.P: Former US Defense Secretary William Perry will visit both sides of the Taiwan Strait next month, as he did in January 1998, a Hong Kong daily reported Sunday.
The Sing Tao Yih Pao reported that Perry will visit in March amid rising concerns regarding a visit to Taiwan by Wang Daohan, mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan.

Wang, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), agreed during a meeting with his Taiwan counterpart Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), in October in the mainland to pay a reciprocal visit to Taiwan.
Taipei and Beijing are still discussing the date of Wang's visit.

In January 1998 Perry headed a delegation to Taiwan that included former National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft, former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff John Shalikashvili, former Commander-in-Chief of the Pacific Command Ronald Hayes and several senior researchers. During that visit Perry conveyed the message that the United States encouraged both sides of the Taiwan Strait to resume dialogue.

The main issues to be dealt with during next month's visit are expected to be Wang's visit to Taiwan and the sensitive question of whether a US-proposed theater missile defense system would cover Taiwan, according to the report.
Reports said that Perry met with Wang in July 1998 in Hawaii, which Beijing's official Xinhua News Agency said was a "second tract" of dialogue, complementing the official one.
After the Hawaii meeting, the mainland delegation invited Perry to a follow-up meeting in Shanghai in March this year.

Reports said that Perry is expected to visit mainland China in early March and Taipei in mid-March, suggesting that he is continuing his attempt to promote "second tract" dialogue with the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: PERMANENT RESIDENCE DRAFT LAW FOR FOREIGNERS DUE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior has completed a draft law which will allow foreign nationals living in Taiwan to apply for permanent residence.

According to the ministry, foreigners may apply for permanent residence in Taiwan as long as they have a clean police record and have sufficient income during their stay here and meet the following requirements:
-- those over the age of 20 who have legally lived in Taiwan for more than seven consecutive years for more than 270 days each year;

-- those over the age of 20 who are married to a Taiwan national and have a domicile registered with household authorities, and those who have lived for more than five consecutive years in Taiwan for at least 183 days each year; and
-- foreign children of ROC nationals who are over the age of 14 and have resided in Taiwan legally for more than five years.

Foreigners under the age of 20, those with a bad record with local police stations, those whose residence permits have ever been revoked over the past seven years and those who have failed medical checkups are exempt from applying for permanent residence.

Those who have taken part in activities not compatible with the purposes stated in their visas or those who have committed crimes or lack the ability to make a living while living in Taiwan will be repatriated within a week, the Interior Ministry added.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE TOURIST TO UNDERGO FURTHER TESTS AFTER ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: A Japanese tourist who was accidentally stabbed in the eye with a chopstick will undergo more medical tests in the next few days, the National Taiwan University Hospital said on Monday.

The bizarre accident took place Sunday morning after Satoshi Kinoshita, 47, tripped over his luggage in his room at the Lai Lai Sheraton Hotel and fell onto the chopstick which lodged itself to a depth of about 2 centimeters in his eyeball.

He was rushed to the nearby NTU hospital and underwent nearly three hours of surgery. Doctors successfully removed the stick from his eye but will have to conduct computer topography and other tests to see if his eyesight is still intact.

Police said Kinoshita, who usually eats instant noodles every morning, brought noodles and the chopsticks from Japan. He was reportedly packing his luggage, as he was scheduled to leave Taipei on Sunday, before planning to eat his noodles when the accident occurred.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRISIS TO BOTTOM OUT SOON: POLL OF GERMAN BUSINESSMEN

TEXT.P: German businessmen in Asia are optimistic that the region's economic crisis will bottom out by the middle of this year, with mainland China, Taiwan and Singapore emerging as the least affected, results of a recent poll indicated.

Only 22 percent of those questioned fear that 1999 will be worse than last year, according to the findings of a survey of 1,500 German firms in 10 Asian countries by the international management consultant firm Droege & Comp.

Singapore would likely see positive growth by the start of 2000, and might chalk up 5 percent growth by the start of 2002, businessmen predicted. Meanwhile, they said Asia as a whole had to accept the fact that the years of 10 percent annual economic growth were over as a more realistic outlook for the coming years was annual growth at 3 percent to 5 percent, they added.
Evaluating the impact of the crisis on German business, the survey found that the credit crunch has been the biggest obstacle to doing business, with 40 percent saying "funding is urgently required."

This is in stark contrast to the pre-crisis days, when German business cited the lack of skilled personnel as their main obstacle which is now a distant second, according to the survey which also polled 500 firms based in Germany with operations in Asia.
Some 96 percent of the German firms surveyed felt that Asia will become more important in the future, and 84 percent intend to increase their presence in Asia.

The highest rate of growth in market share is expected in mainland China, Taiwan, Thailand and Singapore, but there is concern that the German market share may contract in Indonesia, Hong Kong and Malaysia.
Signaling their confidence in the region, 94 percent of those surveyed said the next millennium would start with Asia in the lead.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR'S RECENT DROP AGAINST GREENBACK IS SHORT-TERM: CEPD

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar's dramatic fall against the US dollar in the last few days is due mainly to the decline of the Japanese yen and is a short-term phenomenon, an economic official said on Monday.
Thomas Yeh, director of the Economic Research Department under the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, made the remark to reporters during a press briefing.
As more than a half of Asia-Pacific countries are destinations for Taiwan exports, the recovery of the economies in the region would be conducive to the stability of NT dollar, he noted.
Yeh said the local currency's downward trend in the last few days has indeed been affected by short-term market factors. He added that the phenomenon will not last long.

Citing the yen's dramatic drop to 150 against the greenback from 110 in July 1997 and then its rally to the 110 level within a half year, Yeh said the drop and rise of the yen was a natural market reaction in view of the fact that Japan's economy has not achieved a prompt improvement.

As long as Asian-Pacific economies recover, Japan's economy does not decline further, and the renminbi remains stable, the NT dollar exchange rate is expected to be stable in the second half of 1999, Yeh stated.

The NT dollar registered three consecutive days of decline and has slid to 33.275 against the greenback last Saturday, falling for the first time in two and a half months to below the 33-level. It closed at 33.102 on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar jumped against the greenback on Monday in the Taipei foreign exchange market, rising NT$0.155 to close at 33.102.
It marked the largest single-day appreciation over the past four months. However, the appreciation was reportedly due to intervention by the central bank.
Dealers said continued weakness of the Japanese yen pulled down the value of most Asian currencies in recent days, and the NT dollar was unable to free itself from the trend.

At the opening of Monday's session, the local currency initially fell against the US dollar and did not post gains until halfway into the trading session, brokers said, noting the rise was attributed to the central bank's move to make "adjustments."

In the near future, the local unit will continue to face pressure to depreciate due to the fact that the Japanese government supports the yen's devaluation which is seen enhancing the competitiveness of Japanese exporters.
The NT dollar opened at 33.05 and fluctuated between 33.035 and 33.45.
The interbank US dollar trading amounted to US$651 million on the on Monday, the largest single-day turnover in the past 45 days.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMIC PERFORMANCE TO REBOUND IN THIRD QUARTER: MOEA

TEXT.P: Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials are taking a prudently optimistic view of Taiwan's economic prospects in 1999 which are expected to rebound in the third quarter, said the head of MOEA's Statistics Department on Monday.

A sharp devaluation of the island's currency, which lost close to NT$1 against the US dollar over the past two trading days, will surely benefit Taiwan's foreign trade, noted Chang Yao-tsung, director-general of the Statistics Department under the MOEA.

The MOEA had planned to release figures for the total volume of export orders received by Taiwan manufacturers on Monday, but postponed the announcement due to the busy Chinese Lunar New Year holiday season, noted the director-general.
Taiwan's economic prospects are expected to bottom out in the first quarter of this year, level off in the second quarter, and rebound in the third quarter, Chang added.
Although the NT dollar is actually under-valued, its recent devaluation is following the suit of the yen-dollar rate, remarked Chang.

Currency devaluation is aimed at defending competitiveness of Taiwan products abroad, many of which compete with Japanese products. Therefore, the NT dollar's exchange rate closely mimics the yen-dollar rate.
Chang indicated further that January's volume of exports would certainly exceed that of the same period last year, because the Lunar New Year holidays fell on January 1998.

In view of having more working days in January this year than last year, double-digit growth can be expected. A total of US$8.46 billion worth of exports was recorded in January 1998, while the figure for January 1999 can be expected to reach US$9 billion, concluded Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIER SIGNS ACADEMIC COOPERATION PACT WITH PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) signed a memorandum of academic cooperation with the Philippines' mass communications research center on Monday to form an "ROC-Philippine forum" mechanism.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu said at the signing ceremony that in light of the intensive commercial activities between the ROC and the Philippines, the bilateral academic cooperation will be conducive to the collection of commercial information and market research in the future.

Lin said Taiwan and the Philippines are close in proximity and it would be very convenient to technically support Taiwan's manufacturers in the Philippines. He added that the signing of the pact will help achieve this goal.
TIER said the ROC-Philippine forum mechanism is to combine the two nations' industrial, government and academic sectors knowledge to help promote substantial bilateral relations.

Through the mechanism, scholars and experts from the two sides will release articles on bilateral politics, economy, agriculture, labor and cultural issues to provide the governments with suggestions for various policies.

TIER and the Philippine mass communications research center will hold the first ROC-Philippine forum meeting in May with "the development of agriculture and manpower resources" as the topic of the meeting.

The first ROC-Philippine forum meeting will emphasize the use of Taiwan capital and agriculture technology in helping make the Philippines Taiwan's agricultural overseas processing base, granary and overseas leisure resort.

In addition, forum delegates will also discuss issues related to some 200,000 Philippine laborers working in Taiwan, and the use of high ranking technical personnel to help Taiwan develop its economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CLAIMS JURISDICTION OVER KILLINGS ABOARD MUTINY VESSEL

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has asked Mauritius to repatriate for trial the captain of a Taiwan-registered fishing boat who allegedly killed two of his crewmen, Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu said on Monday.

"We have received a report from our representative office in Mauritius concerning the killing by Kung Tai-an of two mainland Chinese sailors aboard the Kaohsiung-based Ching Ching No. 12 tuna fishing boat in the Indian Ocean on Feb. 16," Wu said.
According to the report, Kung was taken into custody by Mauritius police authorities when the 500-ton vessel docked at that country's Port Louis on Saturday.

Nine other surviving crew members, including four from Taiwan, three from mainland China and two from the Philippines, have also been detained for questioning, while the Ching Ching is still docked at Port Louis, the report said.

Kung allegedly shot to death two mainland sailors -- Li Xingzheng and Yang Yong -- on Feb. 16 when the Ching Ching was operating in the Indian Ocean some 1,000 nautical miles northwest of Mauritius. Thirteen other mainland crewmen jumped ship in panic, and their fates remain unclear.
Wu said that as the incident took place on the high seas aboard a Taiwan-owned ship, and because the suspect is a Republic of China national, the ROC has full jurisdiction over the case.
The spokesman added that the Foreign Ministry has ordered ROC Representative to Mauritius Lee Tzi-nan to negotiate with Mauritius for Kung's speedy repatriation for trial.

However, Wu pointed out, because the ROC does not maintain formal diplomatic ties with Mauritius and there is no extradition agreement between the two countries, there may be some difficulty obtaining Kung's repatriation. "But anyway, we'll try our best to seek Kung's return to stand trial in our court," Wu said.

The fishery department under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture said it will ask the Criminal Investigation Bureau to send police officers to Mauritius as soon as possible to escort Kung back to Taiwan for trial.

Local press reports said mainland China's embassy in Mauritius has asked the Indian Ocean island nation to turn over the case to its jurisdiction because all the killed and missing sailors were mainland nationals.

However, ROC representative Lee said in a telephone interview with CNA that he had not heard of any such reports. Lee said he met with Kung on Saturday evening, adding: "The 42-year-old captain told me that he will assume full responsibility for the incident."
Lee also said that he has already assisted the Ching Ching's agent in Mauritius to hire a lawyer to help handle the case and protect Kung's legal rights.
He further said that one Taiwan crewman, identified as Lee You-lai, sustained injuries to his arm in the incident. "The sailor is in stable condition after receiving surgery," he added.
The Ching Ching No. 12 left Kaohsiung on Feb. 20, 1996 to fish for tuna in the Indian Ocean. A total of 25 men were aboard the ship when the incident occurred.
A spokesman for Ching Ching Fishing Co., owner of the vessel, said initial investigations show that only the ship's captain was involved in the tragic incident.

"We feel regret over the incident. Kung had just been promoted from first engineer to captain. He has worked in our company for 10 years. He is moderate and has a good performance record. It is hard to believe and beyond our imagination that the incident has occurred," the spokesman said.

He said two of the company's senior executives will leave for Mauritius on Tuesday to handle the situation. He said the company will offer generous compensation to the families of the two dead sailors.
"We have also asked ships operating in the Indian Ocean near Mauritius to help in the search and rescue of the 13 missing mainland crew members," he added.

According to Mauritius press reports, mainland Chinese members of the crew had refused to work since the ship left Port Louis last August on grounds that their contracts had expired. The incident might be related to mainland sailors' refusal to work, the reports said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 157 JOBLESS WORKERS APPLY FOR UNEMPLOYMENT ASSISTANCE

TEXT.P: Some 157 Taipei citizens have applied for unemployment assistance to the Taipei City Government since the beginning of this year, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said on Monday.

Speaking at a seminar on Taipei labor affairs and the city's economic outlook for 1999, Ma admitted that Taipei's unemployment rate has already increased to 2.5 percent. Although the ratio is not the highest compared to figures for other parts of the island, the mayor said, it is already an alarming level.

Attributing the rising joblessness to persistent sluggish business conditions islandwide, Ma said his administration has allocated a larger budget for economic development for the next fiscal year, in the hope of creating more job opportunities by implementing public construction projects.

On the new unemployment assistance, Ma said the Employment Service Center under the city government began screening applications for the subsidy from Taipei citizens on Jan. 4. So far, a total of 157 applications have been approved, he added.

Judging from the information obtained from unemployed applicants, the center's director, Hsiao Shu-yen, said that contrary to what is widely assumed, joblessness is most noticeable in the construction sector and small trading companies, which have been hardest-hit by the Asian financial crisis, rather than in the manufacturing sector.
The worst-affected are those in the 30-40 age group, with women outnumbering men, she noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK EQUITIES EXPECTED TO OUT-PERFORM BONDS

TEXT.P: In the next 10 years, equities will not likely achieve the high nominal returns they have enjoyed during the last 20 years, but they should outperform bonds or cash, a Hong Kong investment advisor said on Monday.

Simon Rigby, director of Schroder Investment Management (Hong Kong) Limited, said in a document entitled "Investment Strategy for Hong Kong Retirement Plans," that since 1970, the average Hong Kong dollar return for Hong Kong equities has been 20.7 percent a year.
This is well above the 9.8 percent annual return that would have been achieved by investing in US Treasury bonds.

"Periods of poor performance during the 1970s and during the early 1980s have more than made up for the period as a whole. The higher return from equities is compensation for market volatility," he said. (Stanley Cheung)

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER ONE MILLION MAINLAND CHINESE CAN LIVE IN HK

TEXT.P: Over one million mainland Chinese are eligible to live in Hong Kong, according to a recent estimate by the government of Hong Kong.
An informed source said the estimate was made after the Court of Final Appeal ruled recently that Hong Kong people's children on the Chinese mainland are eligible to live in Hong Kong.
The Hong Kong government has not made the estimate known to the public, because the number is suprisingly big, he said.

In 1996, about 320,000 mainland Chinese were eligible to live in Hong Kong, according to a survey made by the government for that year, he said, adding that the number has increased rapidly as a result of the recent court rule.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILLING TO TALK WITH BEIJING UNDER CERTAIN CONDITIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is willing to open a dialogue with mainland China on any topic, so long as the island's security is assured and Beijing acknowledges that mainland China and Taiwan are ruled by two different administrations, said Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Su Chi on Monday.
At a New Year reception for Taiwan businessmen investing in mainland China, the MAC head reiterated a call made by Premier Vincent Siew on Nov. 2 at a conference on mainland affairs.

Siew said at that time that Beijing's respect for the actual division between Taiwan and mainland China, and its renouncement of military threats against the island will dispel Taiwan's concerns about security.
Su also called for Beijing's cooperation in maintaining stability in bilateral ties, and its help in making this stability a positive factor with regard to peace in Asia as a whole.

Hailing the trip to the mainland by Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu last October as ushering in a new chapter in Taipei-Beijing ties, Su described the visit as the result of the government's persistent efforts which have laid the groundwork for systematic exchanges between the two sides.

Admitting that there is no sign that the confrontation between Beijing and Taiwan will disappear any time soon, given Beijing's continuous military build-up and its incessant diplomatic campaign to isolate Taiwan, Su said Taiwan still holds out cautious rather than wishful hopes for a better relationship with Beijing this year.

He spelled out four priorities in handling bilateral ties: pressing ahead with constructive bilateral dialogue; exploring the possibility of agricultural cooperation with Beijing; improving the organization of bilateral exchanges; and seeking better protection for Taiwan's investments in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN BANKS FACE TOUGH FIGHT FOR RETAIL DEPOSITS

TEXT.P: Southeast Asian and Hong Kong banks face great competition in gathering retail and corporate deposits as they strive to regain their strength in the wake of the regional financial crisis.

A survey by The Asian Banker Journal has also revealed that the region's banks will become less differentiated in their customers, products, and approach to delivery. The survey covered 50 banks in seven of the region's economies.

Many banks want to compete for retail deposits, according to the survey, while fee-based activities, including trade finance, credit cards, cash management, and third party funds, were the other areas where competition is expected to be fierce.

The survey, which sought to determine the impact of the financial crisis on business plans, aspirations and budgeting priorities, particularly in information technology and other infrastructure spending, found financial institutions in the region putting forth a defensive business strategy by shrinking expenditure and consolidating operations.
The countries covered were Singapore, Hong Kong, Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, Indonesia, and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO DIVISION IN DPP OVER PRESIDENCY DISPUTE: DPP REPRESENTATIVE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will not split because of internal disputes on the party's presidential candidate, the DPP's new representative to the United States said on Monday.
Chiou I-jen, who once served as DPP secretary-general, made the remarks before leaving on a 12-day trip to the United States, when he will formally assume his new responsibilities.
Chiou said that he will use his new position to build improved communication channels with the US authorities, and to forge mutual trust.

Chiou said he knew nothing about a reported March meeting between DPP presidential hopefuls Hsu Hsin-liang and Chen Shui-bian, who are supposed to negotiate with each other on who will be the presidential candidate for the party.
However, he added that if Hsu and Chen cannot reach agreement on which of them should run, the party will seek to settle the problem in the National Congress, the DPP's highest authority.

Hsu, who is one of DPP's founders and has served as party chairman, has never renounced his interest in running in Taiwan's second democratic presidential election in 2000, while Chen's presidential ambitions have wide party support.

The situation has created a dilemma in the DPP, with reports saying the party might be split, a situation which occurred once before when some DPP radical members advocating Taiwan independence left the party to establish the Taiwan Independence Party in 1996.

Meanwhile, asked about his new job, Chiou indicated that he will not move to the United States to carry out his tenure because his party cannot provide funds for the move. Instead, he said, he will be forced to commute between Taipei and Washington.
During his upcoming US visit, Chiou said, he will only tour Washington and New York to visit US congressmen and officials dealing with Taipei-Washington relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER URGES BEIJING TO SEEK COMMON GROUND

TEXT.P: "Seek common ground and agree to disagree" is the best way for mainland China and Taiwan to break their current impasse in ties, Premier Vincent Siew said on Monday.

In a speech at a dinner hosted by heads of Taiwan businessmen associations around mainland China, the premier urged Beijing to shelve the issues on which the two sides are far apart, while engaging constructively in talks on issues on which the two sides see eye to eye.
"In this way, and with patience," ties will move in a positive direction, the premier said.

He recalled the trip to Beijing last August by Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu, saying it signaled the thaw of a three-year hiatus in ties, and touted the four-point consensus Koo reached with his mainland China counterpart Wang Daohan, including a promise from Wang to reciprocate Koo's trip by visiting Taiwan within this year.
In a gesture to Beijing, Siew said that Taiwan has completed its preparations for Wang's visit and is looking forward to maintaining the momentum started by Koo's mainland trip.

Reiterating the principles he announced on Nov. 2, Siew said that Taiwan could ease its state of alertness against Beijing, or relax its "avoid haste, exercise restraint" policy toward mainland China investment, and could even weigh the possibility of opening direct postal, trade and transportation links with mainland China, so long as Beijing respects the fact that Taiwan is governed separately and renounces military intimidation against the island.
He also vowed to stick firmly to the current policies of beefing up exchanges with Beijing to deepen mutual understanding and dispel hostility.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET AGREES TO CONDITIONAL STOCK TRANSACTION TAX ADJUSTMENT

TEXT.P: In the face of tremendous pressure from leading business groups and legislators, the Executive Yuan on Monday said it would allow a "reasonable adjustment" of the stock transaction tax.
Government spokesman Chen Chien-jen said that the Cabinet will seek a revision of the regulations on stock trading tax as long as the change complies with the principle of justice and fairness.
He said that the scale of the adjustment and its timing will have to be further discussed by a task force comprised of representatives from academic, industrial and official sectors.
Chen made the announcement after Finance Minister Paul Chiu met with Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng on the proposed cut for the tax, which is currently at 0.3 percent.

Several leading business bodies and lawmakers have vigorously pressed for a cut in the stock trading tax in an effort to shore up the sagging stock market, which has lost steam in the face of Asia's financial crisis.
Kuomintang Legislator Lo Chung-chin recently proposed lowering the tax to 0.05 percent.
Chen said that the proposed adjustment will not necessarily mean a cut only, adding that it could also take the form of an increase.

Meanwhile, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) immediately expressed opposition to the Cabinet's plan, saying it will only increase stock speculation and widen the government budget deficit.

At a press conference, DPP Legislative Yuan party whip Chang Chun-hsiung said that the move once again exposes the government's irregularities in "trying to safeguard the interests of some privileged corporations at the expense of those of individual investors."
Chang said in order to protect these individual investors, all the DPP lawmakers will act unanimously to boycott the passing of the revision of the stock transaction on the legislative floor.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The Cabinet agreed to adjust the stock transaction tax rate under certain conditions.
The China Times:
The Cabinet agreed to revise the stock transaction tax law to pave way for more flexible adjustment of taxation rates.
The United Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui expressed explicit support for flexible stock transaction tax rates.
The Liberty Times:
Consensus on flexible adjustment of the stock transaction tax rate has been reached among various government departments.
The Commons Daily:
The Cabinet agreed to adjust the stock transaction tax rate.
The China Post:
The Cabinet will be handed power to alter stock trade tax.
The China News:
The Cabinet agrees to cut stock tax.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Feb. 23, or the eighth day of the first month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1836: The siege of the Alamo begins in San Antonio, Texas. The siege ended on March 6 with all the Texans killed by Mexican troops.
1848: John Quincy Adams, the sixth president of the United States who helped formulate the Monroe Doctrine, dies at the age of 81.
1905: Paul P. Harris, a lawyer in Chicago, establishes Rotary International. There are about 24,500 Rotary clubs in 167 countries, with about 1.1 million members.
1913: Mexican President Francisco I. Madero is murdered, and General Victoriano Huerta seizes power.
1933: Japanese forces occupy Chinese territory north of the Great Wall in China.
1945: US marines plant the Stars and Stripes on Mount Suribachi in Iwo Jima, a strategic island 750 miles from Tokyo after 74 days of bombardment and four days of a bitter ground battle.
1955: The first meeting of the South-East Asian Treaty Organization (SEATO) is held in Bangkok, Thailand.
1957: Major-General Chiang Wei-kuo weds Miss Helene B. Chiu in Tokyo, Japan.
1958: Taiwan's first Cobalt 60 medical instrument for curing cancer arrives in Keelung from the United States.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with Cameroon.
1968: Thailand's Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda is overthrown in a bloodless coup.
1968: Britain abolishes theater censorship.
1969: Chang Chun-li, chairman of the China Democratic Socialist Party, dies in San Francisco at the age of 83.
1970: British Guinea ends its association with Britain and sets up the Republic of Guyana.
1990: Prince Sihanouk returns to Cambodia after 11 years in exile.
1991: The National Unification Council holds its fifth meeting and passes the Guidelines for National Unification, which are now the highest directives governing the ROC's mainland policy. Its long-term goal is to establish a democratic, free and equitably prosperous China.
1991: Thailand's Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhaven is arrested after the armed forces seize power in a bloodless coup.
1997: The Legislative Yuan passes the amendment to the fourth article of the February 28 Incident Disposition and Compensation Act, stipulating that February 28, also named "Peace Memorial Day," be a national holiday.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "How toweringly high and surpassingly great in moral grandeur was the way by which the ancient Emperors Shun and Yu came to the government of the Empire, and yet they themselves were unconscious of it."

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO TIGHTEN SUPERVISION OF DEEP-SEA FISHING BOATS

TEXT.P: The Fisheries Administration under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture said on Tuesday it will tighten its supervision of deep-sea fishing boats to prevent them from illegally hiring foreign sailors.

The administration made the statement after the captain of a Kaohsiung-based tuna fishing vessel allegedly killed two mainland Chinese crewmen last Tuesday and frightened 13 other mainland sailors who jumped overboard.

The administration said the incident, which took place on board the Chin Ching No. 12 in the Indian Ocean some 1,000 nautical miles northwest of Mauritius, has again exposed the problems regarding the employment and management of foreign sailors by local deep-sea fishing boats.

Chen Yu-chen, head of the Fisheries Administration's deep-sea fishing division, said the 490-ton Chin Ching No. 12 apparently violated government regulations by hiring more non-ROC nationals onto its crew than permitted.

According to current regulations, a fishing boat weighing between 300 tons and 500 tons should employ at least six Taiwan crew members. The Chin Ching had only hired five Taiwan crewmen, including its captain. The 20 other crewmen included 18 mainland Chinese and two Filipinos.
Present rules also stipulate that the number of foreign sailors, including those from mainland China, working aboard a local fishing boat do not exceed half of its total crew members.
Chen said some of the Chin Ching crew members boarded the ship not in Taiwan, but at its overseas operational base.

It is not uncommon for Taiwan-registered deep-sea fishing boats to employ a larger proportion of foreign and mainland sailors, Chen said, adding that this is partly because the cost of hiring foreign and mainland crew members is cheaper than employing Taiwan nationals. The salary for a Taiwan crewman is far higher than that of a mainland sailor.
Another reason is that the penalty for violators is too lenient, Chen said. "The maximum fine for a ship owner who violates the employment rule is only NT$150,000 (US$4,630)," he noted.
According to Chen, Taiwan fishing boats have usually hired mainland Chinese sailors through the mediation of shipping companies.

"Many mainland crewmen do not have previous experience in fishing operations on the open seas. Long working hours, sometimes 18 hours a day, and heavy workloads have often led to clashes between mainland sailors and Taiwan management aboard the ships," Chen said.
In the face of so many problems, Chen said, the Fisheries Administration has decided to conduct a comprehensive review of all existing regulations and make necessary amendments.
"We will more tightly inspect the number of crewmen aboard local deep-sea fishing boats and will impose harsher penalties on law breakers," Chen added.

Chin Ching captain Kung Tai-an, 42, has been taken into custody by Mauritius police, and the nine surviving crew members, including four from Taiwan, three from mainland China and two from the Philippines, have also been detained for questioning. The ship is now docked at Mauritius' Port Louis while the fate of the 13 mainland crewmen who jumped ship in panic last Tuesday remain unclear.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SUGGESTS ECONOMIC MEETING WITH CENTRAL AMERICA IN MAY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has suggested holding an economic ministerial-level conference with Central America nations in May, Chen Ruey-long, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT), said on Tuesday.

The meeting has been proposed for either in Nicaragua in May or in Taiwan earlier that month, after which Taiwan officials will travel to Paraguay to attend the ROC-Paraguay economic ministerial meeting there, Chen said.
He also said Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu has suggested that Taiwan and Panamanian officials discuss a proposal on the establishment of an ROC-Panama free trade zone.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA PLANS SWEEPING TAX RATE CUT TO LURE FOREIGN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: The Australian government is planning sweeping tax reforms aimed at reducing its tax rate to 30 percent from the current 36 percent to attract more foreign investors.

The plan was revealed by John Ralph, who chaired the Review of Business Taxation, at a news conference on Monday. He said a 30 percent corporate tax rate would entice more foreign companies and create more jobs especially in the service sector.
Ralph said the 30 percent tax rate "is a move to encourage people to set up businesses here, but because of that, it means you will have less investment in fixed capital, plant and equipment."

"The offset we'd be looking for is an increase in the kinds of jobs in the service sector and areas of business that don't have high capital costs," he noted, adding that the tax changes would "certainly disadvantage" manufacturers.
The manufacturing sector was concerned rather than alarmed by the tax changes, given that the 10 percent goods and services tax already delivers significant advantages for capital investment.
Federal Treasurer Peter Costello said the 30 percent rate would help make Australia one of the best places to do business in Asia.
The difference in the tax rate would be made up by axing special tax breaks, particularly accelerated depreciation, saving businesses around US$1.3 billion a year.
The plan is expected to be finalized on June 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN FIRMS AT FOREFRONT IN MINING GOLD IN THAILAND

TEXT.P: Australian companies are at the forefront in the mining of gold in Thailand after Bangkok eased its rules to allow foreigners to mine bullion due to the Asian financial crisis, the Australian Financial Review said on Tuesday.

Leading Australian companies such as BHP, CRA and Phelps Dodge & Nemont gave up mining gold in Thailand years ago because the Thai government was reluctant to have foreign firms make away with precious local resources.

Renewed interest from gold mining companies, mainly smaller outfits from Australia and Canada, has now found a much more sympathetic ear from the Mineral Resources Department of Thailand. The easing of restrictions was the result of Thailand's economic meltdown, the daily reported.

Australian miners said they estimated Thailand's gold reserves could become the second largest in Southeast Asia, trailing behind only those in Indonesia. They said the production cost for gold mining in Thailand is within the lower 10 percent of world gold cost production.
Australia is the world's third gold producer and exporter, selling its bullion to Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore, India and other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA TOP DESTINATION FOR INTERNATIONAL CALLS FROM ROC

TEXT.P: Mainland China was again the top destination of international telephone calls made from Taiwan in 1998, the Ministry of Transportation of Communications said on Tuesday.

Ministry officials said calls from Taiwan to mainland China totaled 240 million minutes last year, accounting for 27.4 percent of the total amount of time spent on international calls from the island.

This was followed by calls to the United States, a total of 160 million minutes accounting for 18.8 percent; calls to Hong Kong and Macao, a total of 76.17 million minutes, or 8.9 percent; and calls to Japan with 75.46 million minutes, or 8.8 percent.

In terms of the growth of international calls over the past decade, the officials noted that since the opening of calls to mainland China in June 1988, growth has been rapid, averaging 61.9 percent growth each year over the ten-year period.

In 1994, calls to the mainland surpassed those to the United States for the first time, and 1998 marked the fifth consecutive year that the mainland has been the top destination of international calls from Taiwan.

But in terms of average length of calls, calls to the US topped the list with an average of 4.7 minutes, followed by 3.3 minutes for Japan, 3.1 minutes for the mainalnd, and 2.3 minutes for Hong Kong and Macao.

However, the officials noted that the growth of international calls has slowed somewhat, adding that people in Taiwan made 260 million international calls last year for a total of 860 million minutes last year, up 7.4 percent and 9.1 percent, respectively, from the previous year.
The figures are well down in comparison with the average growth rate of 16.6 percent and 18.7 percent, respectively, over the past decade, the officials said.
They also pointed out that with the rising use of fax machines and the Internet, changes in the methods of international communications are well worth watching.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN DEFENSE FORCE ACADEMY TAKES TO TAI CHI

TEXT.P: The Australian Defense Force Academy in Canberra has replaced its regular exercise regime with the traditional Chinese form of martial arts known as tai chi, the Sydney Morning Herald reported on Tuesday.

The academy's commander, Commodore Brian Adams described tai chi as the "thinking person exercise," and introduced it to cadets due to its versatility in light of the changing demands of their duties.

"Adaptability is a trait required of all officers in the defense force in the 21st century as they are required to deal with a wide range of situations, from disaster relief and peacekeeping to potential conflict," Adams was quoted as saying.

Officer cadets and midshipmen have been learning the art of tai chi for the past five weeks as a part of a new program designed to make the transition from civilian to military life smoother. They have also received training in conflict resolution, negotiating skills as well as equity and diversity.

All 302 cadets underwent the five-week tai chi lessons, headed by Hua Wang who doubles as a lecturer in oceanography at the academy. And cadets can now choose whether they will continue with the exercises, Adams said.
Although there was no formal assessment of the program, staff said they received fewer reports of injury and a lower drop-out rate than in previous years, Adams noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN CELL PHONE 'SPEAKS' CHINESE

TEXT.P: A Calgary company, eyeing mainland China's huge consumer market, has developed a way to cram complex Chinese characters into the memory of a cell phone, the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. reported on Monday.
Zi Corp. cell phone users may program their own phone directory in Chinese by using a set of eight basic keystrokes, and send written messages to another phone.
The developers said this was only the beginning. Their device can also be used to write Chinese characters in other electronic equipment.

"It'll be in everything, from cameras, digital cameras to VCD players to cell phones," the CBC quoted Wally Ritchie of Zi Corp. as saying. "The cell phone is the starting point. It's an exciting market -- there's 12 million cell phones shipped per year in China today, many more than computers."
The technology, which has been approved by the mainland Chinese government, can eventually be adapted to other countries that use Chinese characters, like Japan and Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: VINYL MEDICAL BAGS CONTAIN TOXIC ADDITIVE: GREENPEACE

TEXT.P: Plastic vinyl intravenous bags that deliver blood and medicine to patients contain toxic levels of a softening additive, Greenpeace said Monday.

These medical products "are delivering their toxic additives straight to the patient's bloodstream," Rich Whate, a spokesman for the coalition Health Care Without Harm, said about the Greenpeace finding based on lab tests in Chicago. The coalition represents 160 health organizations in North America.

More than 80 percent of intravenous bags, and many bags used to store blood products, are made of plastic vinyl chloride (PVC) containing the additive DEHP (di-2-ethylhexyl phthalate), according to Greenpeace. The softening additive is a cancer-causing agent linked to heart, lung, liver, testicle and kidney damage, it added.
However, a Health Canada spokeswoman said the cancer-causing effects have only been shown in animal test subjects.

Still, as a result of the report, Canadian officials will meet with Greenpeace representatives on Thursday to assess the findings, said Beth Pieterson, acting director of the medical devices bureau and therapeutic products program.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA'S ABORIGINALS TO HAVE OWN TV NETWORK

TEXT.P: The Aboriginal Peoples Television Network (APTN) will begin broadcasting on Sept. 1 following the approval by the Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission (CRTC) on Monday.

The CRTC, in its approval of Television Northern Canada's application to operate APTN, said the nation-wide distribution of APTN programs will reflect the culture, history and concerns of aboriginal peoples that are in the public interest.

APTN programs will be distributed as part of the basic service packages offered by large and mid-size cable companies, direct-to-home satellite broadcasting systems as well as multipoint distribution systems. APTN is authorized to charge a maximum monthly fee of 15 cents per subscriber.

Under the terms of its license, APTN will broadcast 120 hours of programming each week in English, French and up to 15 different aboriginal languages. When only native languages are used, English or French subtitles will be used.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CHAMBER OF COMMERCE PREDICTS SLOWER GROWTH IN 1999

TEXT.P: US Chamber of Commerce chief economist Martin A. Regalia predicted on Monday that the US' real GDP will grow 3.1 percent in 1999 -- much slower than in previous years.
"While the outlook for 1999 is not as rosy, we nevertheless expect the economy to continue to expand," said Regalia during a meeting of the US Chamber board of directors.
Regalia attributed slower growth to global economic problems and warned that net exports would continue to drag down growth.
He forecasted that the inflation rate as measured by the percentage change of consumer price index (CPI) will be 2.1 percent this year, half a percent higher than that of last year.
The unemployment rate, which was at 28-year low of 4.5 percent last year, will rise to 4.7 percent this year, according to the forecast.

The White House predicted in its annual "Economic Report of the President" early this month that the GDP will grow 2.0 percent in 1999, while the CPI and unemployment rates will grow 2.3 percent and 4.8 percent respectively.
"In both 1997 and 1998, strong growth in consumption and investment offset a deteriorating trade sector, I'd expect that pattern to hold true in 1999 as well," said Regalia.

He expected consumption to slow noticeably in 1999, bottoming out at about a 2.5 percent rate in the second half of 1999. This slower growth, however, is strong enough to keep the economy moving forward despite continued weakness in international trade.
"The trade sector is expected to remain the weak link, as it will take some time for Asia and Latin America to stabilize and ultimately improve," Regalia continued.
The US Chamber of Commerce is the world's largest business federation representing more than three million businesses and organizations of every size, sector and region.

DOC.HEADLINE: GPS TO BE USED TO CURB ILLEGAL HILLSIDE DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Taipei County Chief Su Tseng-chang said on Tuesday that the county authorities are to study the feasibility of using the global position system (GPS) to curb illegal development on hillsides around the county.

Su made the remarks at a New Year meeting at which county officials reported that the Department of Agriculture and Forestry under the Taiwan Provincial Government will subsidize the county's purchase of GPS equipment to monitor and control development on slope land under its jurisdiction.

Pointing out that any illegal development or construction on a site larger than 15 square meters can be easily traced using a GPS system, Su instructed the county's Agriculture Bureau to contact Chung Yuan Christian University to discuss the possibility of cooperating on the project.

Vast areas of hillsides in northern Taiwan, including Taipei and Taoyuan counties, have been illegally logged, mined, or planted over the past few years, and the Justice Ministry has vowed to stamp out these criminal activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT TRADE DIRECTOR RAYMOND SANDER TO LEAVE

TEXT.P: Raymond J. Sander, who has been on the frontlines of numerous trade negotiations with Taiwan in the past 10 years, will leave the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) on March 26 to pursue a career in the private sector.
Sander, who is the AIT's director of trade and commercial programs, told CNA he will join the New York Life Insurance Co. as vice president for international government affairs.

He joined the AIT in July 1988 after a 22-year career in the federal service. His previous posts included being the associate director of the management programs and budget staff at the US Department of Justice; four years as director of the office of management planning in the office of the Secretary of Transportation; and eight years as the executive director of the urban mass transportation administration.

Stephen Chen, chief of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office (TECRO) and de facto ROC ambassador to the United States, said his impression of Sander was that he was "very smart." Chen noted that Sander has the rare ability to make friends during trade negotiations with his Taiwan counterparts and maintain US interests.
John Deng, director for the economic division with TECRO, praised Sander for his successful role as a bridge between the US and Taiwan in trade issues over the decade.
Although Sander does not read and write Chinese, he managed to learn Chinese idioms to add more spice into his speeches delivered to Chinese audiences.

Sander would almost always watch the late night news on Taiwan television. Although he was unable to understand every word, he took note of what he saw and asked his TECRO friends about the news items he was interested in the next morning

Richard C. Bush, chairman and managing director of AIT, said during a congressional reception last year, Sander was an "invaluable treasure" the AIT had. Several former AIT chairmen, including David N. Laux and Natale H. Bellocchi felt the same way.

Sander has been involved in over 75 negotiation sessions with Taiwan in the last 10 years. Covering the full spectrum of trade and market liberalization issues including intellectual property protection, banking and financial services, as well as tariffs and trade barriers. Last February, Sander participated in the 17th-round of WTO bilateral negotiations with Taiwan which resulted in a final open market agreement.
Sander will start his new job on March 1. The AIT's Washington, D.C. headquarters have planned a reception in his honor for Feb. 25.
