DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE INSURANCE FIRM APPROVED TO SET UP TAIWAN BRANCH

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) announced on Tuesday that it has given its approval for Japan's Mitsui Marine and Fire Insurance to set up a branch in Taiwan.
MOF officials said Mitsui will be the first Japanese insurance company to set up a branch here since the opening of the domestic insurance market to foreign companies.

The officials said that Mitsui Marine and Fire Insurance, set up in 1918, has a capital of NT$19.5 billion (US$600 million). It now has written premiums of about NT$168.2 billion (US$5.17 billion), ranking it third in Japan in terms of premium income. The company's major premium income includes voluntary automobile insurance and savings-type fire and earthquake insurance.

The officials said that the Japanese insurance company has been in business in Asia for 50 years, and that the premium income from the region has topped that of all other Japanese property insurance companies. It also has businesses in America, Europe, and the Middle East. Standard & Poors gave Mitsui an AA+ rating in 1998.

The officials said that after setting up its Taiwan branch, Mitsui will help speed up the globalization of the local insurance market, upgrade the damage investigation system in the automobile insurance market, design and develop new insurance packages, and introduce new product marketing systems.
There are currently 17 domestic and nine foreign insurance companies operating in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.074 against the greenback Tuesday in Taipei, closing at 33.028.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 32.95 and had a low of 33.108.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$584.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ ASSIGNS PROSECUTOR TO HANDLE SHIPBOARD KILLINGS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) on Tuesday appointed Su Wei-ta, a chief prosecutor at the Kaohsiung Prosecutor's Office, to handle a case involving two deaths aboard a Taiwan fishing boat.

Su, who has previous experience of this type of case through his work on the controversial Maersk Dubai case in 1996, said he will immediately start collecting evidence relating to the alleged killing of two mainland Chinese crewmen by the captain of the Chin Ching No. 12 on Feb. 16 when the ship was operating in the Indian Ocean some 1,000 nautical miles northwest of Mauritius.

If necessary, Su said, he will travel to Mauritius to collect first-hand information about the case, in which 13 other mainland sailors are said to have been panicked by Captain Kung Tai-an's shooting rampage into jumping overboard.

"Even though the suspect has not yet been repatriated, I'll start working on the case," Su said, adding that he has asked local police authorities to furnish him with transcriptions of police interviews with Chin Ching Fishing Co. executives for reference.

Meanwhile, Vice Justice Minister Tseng Yung-fu reiterated that the Republic of China has full jurisdiction over the case in accordance with international law, as the incident took place aboard a Taiwan-registered vessel and the suspect is an ROC national.

Some local observers said there might be some difficulty in obtaining the captain's repatriation, because Mauritius recognizes Beijing, not Taipei, and because all 15 of the dead and missing crewmen are mainland Chinese nationals.

A senior official at mainland China's embassy in Mauritius has reportedly expressed Beijing's concern to Mauritius authorities over the issue. According to local press reports, Beijing may claim jurisdiction over the case and ask Mauritius to extradite the suspect to the mainland for trial.
Foreign Minister Jason Hu said he hopes Mauritius will handle the case strictly in accordance with the law, and will avoid allowing political forces to influence its decision.

"We also hope the mainland authorities will fully adhere to international regulations governing this kind of case, and understand our determination to handle the case in a just and impartial manner," Hu said, adding that the ROC does not wish to become embroiled in political wrangling over the incident.

A legal affairs official with the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said the relevant government authorities should also send a lawyer to Mauritius to study its regulations governing the repatriation or extradition of criminal suspects.

Acceding that Mauritius has the right to decide on whom to hand over jurisdiction of the case -- Taiwan or mainland China -- the official said Taiwan should negotiate with Mauritius, not mainland China, for the return of the suspect for trial.

According to international law, the country where a crime takes place has priority over the right to demand extradition of the suspect; followed by the country to which the suspect belongs; and finally the country to which the victim belongs.
"In the Chin Ching case, the ROC has priority jurisdiction because the shooting took place on a Taiwan fishing boat, which is seen as the ROC's floating territory," the MAC official said.

Chin Ching captain Kung Tai-an, 42, has been taken into custody by Mauritius police, and the nine surviving crew members, including four from Taiwan, three from mainland China and two from the Philippines, have also been detained separately for questioning. The ship has been docked at Mauritius' Port Louis since Feb. 20 while the fate of the 13 mainland sailors who jumped ship in panic remain unclear.
A spokesman for Chin Ching Fishing Co., owner of the ship, said two senior company executives already arrived in Port Louis on Tuesday to handle relevant affairs.
"As far as we know only the captain was involved in the case. We hope Mauritius will allow other crewmen and our ship to leave for home as soon as possible," the spokesman said.
According to press reports, the shipboard killings might be related to mainland sailors' demand for pay raises and their refusal to work in recent weeks on grounds that their contracts had expired.
The 490-ton tuna fishing boat left Kaohsiung for operations in the Indian Ocean on Feb. 20, 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SLUMP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices tumbled on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, the result of heavy profit-taking in the wake of sharp gains over the past two sessions.
The TAIEX weighted price index, the market's key barometer, plunged 132.69 points to close at 6,180.94.
A total of 3.51 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$108.66 billion (US$3.28 billion), against the NT$87.01 billion traded in the previous session.
Losers outnumbered gainers 402 to 60, with 32 stocks unchanged.
Financial issues posted the only gains among the eight major stock categories, surging 2.5 percent.

Construction shares saw the largest fall of 5.9 percent, followed by textile issues, which lost 4.5 percent; construction stocks, 4.2 percent; cement issues, 3.2 percent; foodstuff shares and plastic and chemical stocks, 3 percent each; and paper and pulp shares, 2.5 percent.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market also posted a drop of 2.48 points, closing at 154.77, for a market turnover of NT$6.45 billion (US$195.46 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: JAKARTA `AT FAULT' FOR DISPLACING CHINESE: INDONESIAN MINISTER

TEXT.P: The Indonesia government is to be blamed for the number of ethnic Chinese who study abroad and take up citizenship elsewhere because of its past discriminatory practices, Indonesian Education and Culture Minister Juwono Susarsono said on Tuesday.

"I told President Habibie during meetings that it is basically our fault for displacing the Chinese," he told Singapore's The Straits Times newspaper in an interview. "It is time we recognize our mistakes and not blame everything on the Chinese."
He said that the former Suharto regime in particular pursued a policy of imposing a 10 percent limit on Chinese entry into the medical, engineering, science and legal studies in universities.
It is not difficult to predict the response of a minority group that is not given equal opportunities, he said.
"Many went abroad to study and later resided with their families in countries like Singapore and Australia because of the opportunities given to them, and their children were born in these places."
He said Justice Minister Muladi had brought to Habibie's attention the large number of Chinese Indonesians studying in Singapore, some of whom had been called up for national service there.
A 1958 law stipulates that Indonesians will have their citizenship revoked if they are inducted into the military of a foreign country. Dual citizenship is also prohibited.

Habibie has become concerned about the "divided loyalties" of Indonesians, according to the newspaper, so much so that in December, he wanted to ban Indonesians from studying abroad. He later changed his mind.
Juwono said he advised Habibie that the only way to keep Indonesians, especially ethnic Chinese, in the country, was to discard past discriminatory practices in the education system.

Habibie has pledged to eradicate biases against ethnic Chinese, who number between eight and 10 million in the country, but political observers say that institutional and social discrimination is still all-pervasive.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC BLUEPRINT TO BE SUBMITTED TO EXECUTIVE YUAN

TEXT.P: A blueprint aimed at strengthening Taiwan's economic system over a longer time frame will be sent to the Executive Yuan for approval on Thursday, the head of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said on Tuesday.

A detailed plan will then be released within one to three months, said CEPD Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, adding however, that if any revisions of the law are involved, they will require a further three to five months to finalize.
He also noted that the Finance Ministry has not included the "flexible adjustment" measures regarding the stock sales transaction tax into the wide-ranging economic revitalization package.

The CEPD head was speaking to the press after a meeting attended by ministers without portfolio and relevant Cabinet-level officials, to discuss feasible options regarding conclusions reached at an earlier convention held just before the Lunar New Year holiday.
That government-sponsored two-day meeting was attended by the country's leading economists and business leaders.
An economic plan originally mapped out by the CEPD contained 47 suggestions, but an additional 19 amendments were also discussed at the earlier meeting, Chiang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH APPROVES SALE OF NEW BREAST CANCER PILL

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) announced on Tuesday that it has approved the sale in Taiwan of Xeloda -- a new, orally administered tablet for treating breast cancer.

Hu Yo-fu, director of the DOH's Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs, told a news conference that Xeloda is suitable for the treatment of locally advanced or metastatic breast cancers where chemotherapy with paclitaxel and anthracycline has failed.

Noting that Xeloda is non-cytotoxic, Hu said the new will not kill healthy cells as it destroys the malignant cancerous growth. Nevertheless, Hu warned pregnant and lactating women not to use the product.

Xeloda, which contains capecitabine as its active ingredient, will be available in the local market in doses of 150 mg and 500 mg. It will be positioned alongside F-HU, another established product for breast cancer therapy, and will be available only with a doctor's prescription.
Hu said that local distributors will be required to provide the DOH with regular six-month reports over the next seven years regarding any side-effects reported, either at home or abroad.

The number of breast cancer patients has increased significantly over the past decade, according to DOH tallies. Breast cancer is now the fifth-biggest killer of women in Taiwan, and its incidence rate ranks second.
More than 2,000 Taiwan women die from the disease each year, and the number of new breast cancer victims increases by 3,000 annually.
The addition of Xeloda in the arsenal of anti-cancer treatments is expected to bring new hope to patients of locally advanced and metastatic breast cancer, Hu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER CLARIFIES MACEDONIAN TIES

TEXT.P: The newly forged Taipei-Skopje ties are based on mutual agreement, but that does not mean Taipei can shrug off Beijing's attempts to isolate Taiwan diplomatically in the future, Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Tuesday.

Stressing that mainland China has never ceased in its efforts to isolate Taiwan in the international arena, Hu said the establishment of diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Macedonia was approved by both governments, but added: "We will never start believing that our ties will continue happily ever after without work."

Hu, who had just returned from a damage-control trip to Vatican City that morning, made the remarks after foreign wire services on Monday reported a French "suggestion" that Macedonia maintain only economic links with Taiwan, rather than recognize the island as an independent state.

After an investigation of the reports by the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Hu said the report has been proved "groundless." Macedonia's decision to set up ties with Taiwan was "an act by a sovereign country," and France did not make any official or unofficial comment in this regard, he noted.

Taipei and Skopje announced the formation of diplomatic ties on Jan. 27, provoking a strong protest from Beijing and a threat by the communist regime to veto the continuation of a United Nations peacekeeping operation in Macedonia.
Mainland China is one of the permanent members of the United Nations Security Council with the power of veto over any security council decisions, and the threat is considered a serious one.

Hu had originally planned to visit Macedonia this month, but postponed his departure for the Balkan state to March 1 after being notified by the Macedonian government that his Macedonian counterpart will be in Bulgaria until then.

In addition to media reporters, a delegation composed of government trade officials and representatives of state-run enterprises will accompany Hu on his visit to Macedonia to seek business and investment opportunities in the southeastern European country.

The leader of the delegation, Vice Economic Affairs Minister Lin Yi-fu, said bilateral Taiwan-Macedonia trade remains limited. In 1998, Taiwan exports to Macedonia totaled US$1.86 million, while imports from that country were just US$593,000.
According to Lin, Macedonia's investment climate will be suitable for Taiwan's textile and machinery sectors to set up footholds there.

Apart from building a distribution warehouse in Macedonia, an economic cooperative package worked out by the ROC government also suggests that Taiwan businesses increase their purchases of raw materials and liquor from there.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA SAYS COMMUNIST REBELS HAVE YET TO SHOW SINCERITY IN TALKS

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Ejercito Estrada ordered Tuesday a review of the government's efforts to reach a peaceful settlement with the Communist Party of the Philippines-National Democratic Front (CPP-NDF) to ascertain if the negotiations "are still in keeping with our national interests."

The president told the Cabinet Committee on the Peace Process headed by Executive Secretary Ronaldo Zamora and the government peace panel dealing with the CPP-NDF under Ambassador Howard Dee to re-evaluate the negotiations in the wake of a series of terrorist acts perpetrated by leftist rebels.

The chief executive was referring to the abduction by the New People's Army (NPA) of Gen. Victor Obillio, commander of the 55th Engineering Brigade, and his aide, Capt. Eduardo Montealto, in Davao City, followed by the kidnapping of Chief Police Inspector Roberto Bernal of the Philippine National Police in Sorsogon.

Estrada said the government has been faithfully executing confidence-building measures to end more than 30 years of bloody confrontation with communist rebels. The NDF, however, has yet to prove its sincerity.

"These acts of the communist rebels are simply unacceptable," Estrada said. "The abduction of non-combatant military officers and a police officer, who was trying to go after a wanted person in the area, is contrary to the goals of the peace process."
"We have yet to see the NDF prove their sincerity. While we are initiating confidence-building measures, the NDF-NPA have been doing the exact opposite," the chief executive said.
In response to an NDF request, he said, his administration has been reviewing the cases of jailed members of the NPA, the armed wing of the CPP-NDF.
Moreover, he said the government has extended safe conduct passes to NPA leaders so they could resurface and consult with their cadres.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S CONSUMER PRICE INDEX SLIGHTLY HIGHER IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: Singapore's consumer price index in January 1999 rose 0.4 percent compared with the previous month.

Food prices rose 1.1 percent mainly because of dearer leafy vegetables and seafood. The cost of transport and communication edged up by 0.3 percent because of higher car prices, while clothing prices rose 0.4 percent and the nation's education index, 1.9 percent.
The cost of housing and the price of miscellaneous items fell 0.5 percent and 0.4 percent, respectively, while the cost of health care remained unchanged from its December 1998 level.
Compared to the same month a year ago, the consumer price index in January 1999 fell by half a percent, the eighth consecutive monthly decline.

The consumer price index is the most widely used indicator of inflation for consumption expenditures. It measures the average change in prices over time on a fixed basket of goods and services commonly consumed by households.
The basket of goods and services is deliberately kept fixed so that changes in the index reflect only price changes uninfluenced by changes in the types of goods and services purchased.

This series is based on the fixed basket as determined in the Household Expenditure Survey conducted from October 1992 to September 1993. The average price during this period is taken to be 100 index points against which indexes of subsequent periods are compared to measure price changes. The index is compiled monthly.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES SAYS SOUTH CHINA SEA DISPUTE WILL BE MENTIONED AT ASEM

TEXT.P: The Philippines remains confident that the territorial dispute over the South China Sea will be discussed in the upcoming Asia-Europe Meeting (ASEM) meeting in Berlin, Germany, next month.

Secretary Domingo Siazon Jr. of the Department of Foreign Affairs (DFA) said Tuesday that discussing the issue is inevitable because it pertains to political and security conditions in Asia and Europe.

"The issue has to be discussed because it relates to political and security conditions in Asia, as we will also be discussing political and security conditions also in Europe," Siazon said in an interview at Malacanang Tuesday afternoon.
He added that while delegates to the meeting may not refer directly to the territorial dispute between the Philippines and mainland China, there may be other ways to refer to the issue.

"It doesn't have to be specified a 'Mischief Reef' or something like that, but the issue has to be discussed," he said. Siazon added that diplomats at the meeting will likely find a way to refer to the issue.
Siazon was responding to reports that Germany is not inclined to back the country's move to include the South China Sea issue in the ASEM agenda.

The Philippines and mainland China are among six claimants to parts or all of the potentially oil-rich Spratly chain of islands in the South China Sea. The other four are Malaysia, Brunei, Taiwan and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP THREATENS NO-CONFIDENCE VOTE AGAINST PREMIER

TEXT.P: Anger by Taiwan's main opposition party over the Cabinet's support for a reduction in Taiwan's stock transaction tax is swelling, as the Democratic Progress Party (DPP) threatened on Tuesday to sponsor a no-confidence vote against Premier Vincent Siew.

Tsai Min-hsian, the DPP's whip in the Legislative Yuan, said his party will propose a no-confidence vote if Siew does not explain to the DPP's satisfaction why his Cabinet now endorses the tax reduction, which it opposed until recently.

Siew had been opposed to the tax's reduction or elimination, which some business leaders had proposed. On Monday, however, he agreed to set up a panel to mull the possibility of lowering Taiwan's stock transaction tax.

The DPP has vowed to boycott any attempt by the legislature to approve the measure, but the party's ability to influence the legislature's actions is limited, as it has only 70 seats in the 225-seat body.

Citing Siew's fierce opposition to the idea during an economic conference last week, Tsai said Siew's about-face demonstrates his vulnerability to pressure from business magnates. It has also cost him the DPP's trust and will spell his doom as premier, Tsai said.

There is a consensus among legislators familiar with economic issues that the proposed reduction is not a guaranteed bourse booster, and that is why the opposition has reservations about the measure, said Tsai.
If the ruling Kuomintang tries to railroad the proposal through the legislature, the DPP will do its utmost to block it, and it will appeal to the public and to scholars for support, he said.

Lin Chung-cheng, a DPP member and legislator at large, likened the proposed reduction to short-term stimulants that become addictive over time. Moreover, the benefits brought by the reduction would be wiped out by further financial turmoil, either at home or abroad, he said.

Blaming the stock market's plunge over the past several months on the collapse of Taiwan's real estate market, Lin said tumbling property prices increased the number of bad loans by banks and led to a credit crunch that deprived companies of access to cash and triggered the current crisis.

The bourse, as a secondary market, has no direct impact on economic development, said Lin. Instead of pulling out all the stops to shore up stock prices, the government should boost consumption, improve Taiwan's investment environment and prod banks to offer businesses reasonable credit, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CHANGE AT PRESENT ON TAIPEI-VATICAN RELATIONS: HU

TEXT.P: While explaining on Tuesday the state of relations between Taiwan and the Vatican, Foreign Minister Jason Hu sighed, noting that although no changes are expected at the present time, he cannot guarantee that relations will never change.

Hu made the statement at a Taipei press conference after returning from a Feb. 12-23 visit to Jordan and the Vatican. While in Jordan he extended condolence to the Jordan government over the death of King Hussein Bin Talal.

Speaking on his visit to the Holy See, Hu said he made clear to Vatican authorities that while Taiwan supports the promotion of religious freedom in mainland China, it does not want efforts to that end to harm relations between the Vatican and the Republic of China.
Taiwan hopes the Vatican will remain mindful of Beijing's hostility toward Taiwan and that it will not "neglect the one sheep at home while searching for the 30 or 40 lost sheep," Hu said.
He said it is understandable that the Holy See is concerned above the well-being of mainland China's estimated 11 million Catholics, but he noted that there are also 300,000 Catholics in Taiwan.

The foreign minister told reporters that the Vatican and mainland China could forge relations only if the mainland were to grant its people greater religious freedom and relax its control over church affairs or if the Vatican were to abandon its push for greater religious freedom for the people of mainland China.
While there are currently no signs either event is likely to happen, Hu said he cannot predict whether the situation will change in the future.

Taiwan cannot unilaterally dictate its fate with regard to the Vatican, he said. All Taiwan can do is to strengthen communications with the Catholic Church and try to help them better understand the Republic of China.

"We need the Holy See to know that the democracy, freedom and human rights that the Republic of China has been sparing no efforts to promote and defend are not different from the religious freedom and democracy the Vatican is trying to introduce to mainland China," Hu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAIR OF ROC OFFICIALS AWARDED PRIZES BY GROUP OF ITALIAN JOURNALISTS
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, Feb. 23 (CNA) (By Chung Hai-tai and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Two Taiwan officials were named winners of the 1998 Beresshit Prizes by a group of Italian journalists last week.

The Republic of China's representative to Rome, Joe Hung, was honored for his achievements as a diplomat, while the deputy director for public affairs at the Presidential Office, Ting Yuan-chao, was noted for his contributions to journalism.

In a ceremony on Feb. 20, Mario Ciotti, president of "Journalist Without Boundaries," the group that administered the prizes, complimented Hung on his efforts to consolidate ties between Taipei and Rome over the last five years, despite the absence of formal relations between the two countries.
Ting was praised by Ciotti for his performance on job and for the two books he wrote on ROC President Lee Teng-hui.
Ciotti said Ting's works help shaped Taiwan's image in the West, helping to clear away some of the outdated stereotypes about Taiwan portrayed in the Western press.
Describing the award as a great honor, Hung vowed at the awards ceremony to work to continue improving ties between Italy and the Republic of China.
Ting, who was absent from the ceremony, will be presented with his prize in Taipei by Ciotti when he visits in May.
Beresshit Prizes are awarded to people worldwide in 12 fields, including art, literature, justice, medicine, public service and music. Winners are chosen by a panel of experts.
ROC Ambassador to the Holy See Ramond Tai won the 1996 Beresshit Prize for distinguished diplomacy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Kosovo Albanians conditionally accept a peace plan.
The China Times:
Senior Presidential Office officials said Premier Vincent Siew didn't mention resignation during Monday's meeting with President Lee Teng-hui.
The United Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui rejected Premier Vincent Siew's resignation offer.
The Liberty Times:
Executive Yuan Secretary-General Hsieh Shen-shan denied reports that Premier Vincent Siew intends to resign.
The Commons Daily:
The Presidential Office denied that Premier Vincent Siew has offered to resign.
The China Post:
The stock transaction tax cut may cost the premier his job.
The China News:
Premier Vincent Siew may quit over stock trading tax row.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING CALLS FOR END TO UN PEACEKEEPING FORCE IN MACEDONIA
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 23 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Beijing's envoy to the United Nations on Tuesday said mainland China opposes the six-month extension of a UN peacekeeping mission in Macedonia, according to diplomatic sources.
In closed-door discussions by the UN Security Council, mainland Chinese Ambassador Qin Huasun spelled out Beijing's opposition, saying the UN force had already accomplished its mission.

Of the 15 nations taking part in the discussions, mainland China was alone in opposing the extension. Qin mentioned no connection between Beijing's stance on the issue and Macedonia's recent establishment of formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China on Taiwan.
ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu and his Macedonian counterpart, Aleksandar Dimitrov, signed a joint communique in Taipei on Jan. 27 that established full diplomatic relations between the two countries.
Macedonia, which achieved independence from the former Yugoslavia in 1991, became the second European state to have diplomatic ties with the Republic of China, after the Vatican.

A Canadian representative who presided over the consultations said the Security Council will continue to discuss on Wednesday the UN Preventive Deployment Force in Macedonia, whose mandate expires Feb. 28.
The 1,049-member UN peacekeeping force was deployed in Macedonia in 1995 to monitor borders and deter the spread of fighting to Macedonia from Bosnia and other parts of the former Yugoslavia.
Last Thursday UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan recommended the six-month extension to prevent fighting in Kosovo from spilling over into Macedonia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Feb. 24, or the ninth day of the first month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1500: Charles V, the Holy Roman emperor and King of Spain as Charles I who summoned the Diet of Worms and the Council of Trent, is born.
1815: Robert Fulton, the American engineer who developed the first useful submarine and torpedo and invented the steamboat, dies at the age of 50.
1868: Andrew Johnson, the 17th president of the United States, becomes the first president to have impeachment proceedings brought against him by the House of Representatives. He was acquitted by one vote.
1891: The Ching court pays indemnity to Russia for the return of Ili Valley in northwest China.
1909: The world's first color movie is shown in England.
1920: The Nazi Party, or the National Socialist German Workers Party, announces its program to set up the Third Reich.
1920: American-born Nancy Astor becomes the first woman to speak in Britain's House of Commons.
1933: The League of Nations votes 40 to one to pass a resolution refusing to recognize "Manchukuo," a puppet regime installed by the Japanese. Japan walks out of the international organization after the vote.
1945: US forces liberate Manila from Japanese occupation in World War II.
1945: Ahmed Maher Pasha, premier of Egypt, is shot dead in Parliament just after declaring war on the Axis.
1948: The Labor Union of Taiwan Province is established.
1950: The Legislative Yuan holds its first meeting in Taipei.
1962: Dr. Hu Shih, the president of Academia Sinica who proposed that literature be written in the vernacular language rather than in the classical style, dies in Taipei at the age of 72.
1966: Ghana's President Kwame Nkrumah is overthrown in an army coup while he is visiting communist China. He was forced to exile in the Republic of Guinea.
1968: US and South Vietnamese troops recapture the old Vietnamese imperial city of Hue after a fierce battle.
1969: A passenger plane of the Far East Air Transport Corps crashes in Kuijen village, Tainan County, killing all 36 people on board.
1974: Pakistan officially recognizes Bangladesh as an independent nation.
1978: The construction of the first-phase of Taiwan Railway Administration's railway electrification project is completed and is open to traffic.
1989: The funeral rites for Japanese Emperor Hirohito, who reigned since 1926, is held in Tokyo. His son, Akihito, becomes emperor.
1997: A fire in a Hindu religious activity in eastern India claims more than 200 lives and injures over 500 others.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I do not now see a man who can love moral worth in man as he loves beauty in woman."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA KEEPING CLOSE WATCH ON DEVELOPMENT IN UN FORCE IN MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Wednesday it will keep close watch on the development of a proposal to extend the mandate for UN peacekeeping force in Macedonia.

MOFA spokesman Roy Wu made the statement after mainland China said on Tuesday it opposed plans for a further six-month extension of the UN Preventive Deployment Force, known as UNPREDEP, in the former Yugoslav republic.
"We have taken note of mainland Chinese Ambassador Qin Huasun's comments made during a UN Security Council (UNSC) closed-door meeting on the UNPREDEP mandate issue," Wu said.
As the UNSC will continue to discuss the issue in the next two days, Wu said the MOFA will closely monitor follow-up developments concerning the mandate extension proposal.
Wu said the MOFA has collected information about the full text of Qin's speech and general reactions to his remarks through proper channels.
Macedonia forged formal diplomatic ties with the Republic of China last month, making it the ROC's second ally in Europe. The other European state which recognizes the ROC is the Vatican.

"We attach great importance to our newly won diplomatic ally. We treasure our friendship with Macedonia and are highly concerned about its national security, well-being and stability in the region," Wu said.
UN Secretary-General Kofi Anna recommended last week that the UNPREDEP in Macedonia be extended until Aug. 31. The UNSC must vote this week to renew the UNPREDEP mandate which expires on Saturday.

The 1,100-member force includes about 360 troops from the United States, 640 from Scandinavia and about 50 from Indonesia. It was originally deployed to monitor borders and deter the spread of fighting to Macedonia from Bosnia. It is also monitoring a UN embargo against Yugoslavia, including Kosovo province where ethnic Albanians are battling Serbian security forces. Macedonia also provides logistical support for European civilian monitors in Kosovo, and is a base for NATO operations in the region.

Mainland China severed diplomatic relations with Macedonia because of the Balkan country's new ties to the ROC. It remains unclear whether mainland China, a UNSC permanent member, would use its veto to kill the UN peacekeeping mission in Macedonia.

Beijing exercised its first veto in nearly 25 years in January 1997 against 155 military observers to monitor peace accords in Guatemala, which has maintained diplomatic ties with Taiwan as do several other Central American and Caribbean nations. Beijing reversed its decision two weeks later, with diplomats presuming Guatemala had promised not to back UN membership for Taiwan.

Previously, mainland China also twice threatened to veto UN troops in Haiti for the same reason. The move forced the UNSC to change the name of the Haiti mission and then have the United States and Canada pay for the troops.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HARDWARE MAKERS SECOND MOST COMPETITIVE TO US: US MAKERS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 24 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: American hardware makers on Tuesday said their Taiwan counterparts are the second-toughest competitors in the world, after those from mainland China.

In a world market survey report, the American Hardware Manufacturers Association (AHMA) said hardware manufacturers from mainland China are the toughest competitors, followed in order by those from Taiwan, Germany, Japan and South Korea.

Delegates from the AHMA, which comprises 1,100 American hardware manufacturers, presented the report during a hearing sponsored by the federal International Trade Commission on the impact of mainland China's joining the World Trade Organization on US industries.

The AHMA survey looked at 10 types of hardware, including building materials, manual and electrical tools and kitchen utensils. On a ratings scale in which higher numbers indicated greater competitive threats, mainland China received a rating of 67.1, while Taiwan was assigned a rating of 51.2 and Germany, 23.2.
For American hardware manufacturers, the greatest competitive threats come from mainland China and Taiwan.
The most favored markets for US hardware makers are Mexico, Brazil, Canada, Germany and mainland China, according to the same report.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUYING OF TAIWAN COMPUTER PRODUCTS BY US, EUROPEAN FIRMS UP SHARPLY

TEXT.P: Despite the recession of the global economy, the purchase of Taiwan computer products by US and European firms grew sharply in 1998.

Statistics released by the International Procurement Office (IPO) show that the top 10 US firms that procured Taiwan computer products bought a total of US$13.31 billion worth in 1998, an increase of 45.8 percent compared with the previous year.
The top five European firms that procured Taiwan computer products bought a total of US$1.28 billion worth last year, up 75.3 percent from the previous year, according to IPO statistics.
In Japan, however, the top 10 firms that procured Taiwan computer products bought a total of US$1.53 billion worth in 1998, down 22.2 percent from year-earlier levels.
The negative growth for Japanese firms was due mainly to Asia's financial turmoil.
In all about 70 foreign firms bought US$18 billion worth of Taiwan computer products in 1998, compared with total purchases of US$13.4 billion in 1997.

Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang on Wednesday announced the names of the US, European and Japanese firms that bought the most Taiwan computer products last year. The names were announced at an awards ceremony organized by the task force for the promotion of Taiwan's information industry under the Ministry of Economic Affairs and by the China External Trade Development Council.
The top 10 US firms are Compaq, IBM, Dell, HP, Apple, Intel, Micron, Unisys, Gateway2000 and A&A.
The top five European firms are Actebis, Elonex, Philips, Siemens and Wintop.
The top 10 Japanese firms include Alps, Fujitsu, Hitachi, Mitsubishi, NEC, Panasonic, Sharp, Sony and Toshiba.
