DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT MONITORING SYSTEM ACTIVELY HELPS CRACK DOWN ON PIRACY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Export Monitoring System (EMS), a newly established center that monitors Taiwan's computer software exports in an attempt to stem product piracy, is speeding up its monitoring operations to curb infringements on intellectual property rights (IPR), a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Wednesday.

Devised by the Directorate General of Customs through the concerted efforts of the ministries of finance and economic affairs and the Institute for Information Industry, the EMS identified between August 1998 and January 1999 131 products suspected of having violated IPR laws.
Of that number, however, only one was found to be a pirated product, said Lin Tsan-huei, deputy executive secretary of the Intellectual Property Office, MOEA.
Established last Jan. 26, the office oversees Taiwan's efforts to protect intellectual property and to crack down on piracy.

According to the US Department of Treasury, the US Customs Service seized US$8.61 million worth of pirated products from Taiwan in 1998, up 44.5 percent from year-earlier levels. According to that figure, Taiwan was the second-largest source of pirated products to the United States last year. Most of the goods were computers and their peripherals and components.

Commenting on the latest report, Lin said that cracking down on piracy is a painstakingly long-term project. Even in industrially advanced countries such as the United States and Japan, piracy has not been eliminated.

Quoting tallies from the Intentional Intellectual Property Alliance Lin noted that about 27 percent of the computer software used in the United States is pirated, compared with 40 percent in Japan and 60 percent in Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China.
As for Taiwan's effort to stem such piracy, Lin said, "Better late than never," adding that the EMS is effectively doing its job and will speed up its monitoring operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: POORER, LESS EDUCATED MORE LIKELY TO SUFFER HEART ATTACKS: STUDY

TEXT.P: Heart specialists in Canada said gender, socio-economic standing, place of residence and choice of hospitals are often factors in deaths from strokes and heart attacks.
That is the conclusion of a report released Tuesday by the Heart and Stroke Foundation of Ontario and the Institute of Clinical Evaluative Sciences.
The study found that poorer Canadians and those with less education are much more likely to suffer from coronary disease and related conditions.

It noted that people in the lowest economic group are more likely to have higher risk factors for heart disease than more affluent people. Such factors include high blood pressure, diabetes and obesity.
The report says heart disease is still the leading cause of death in Canada. Researchers also found that women die more frequently from heart attacks than men do.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN COMPANIES REGISTER STRONG PROFITS DESPITE ASIAN CRISIS

TEXT.P: Australia's corporate sector defied dismal expectations for the last quarter of 1998, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).

ABS figures show gross company profits rose 3.7 percent in the final three months of 1998 in seasonally adjusted terms, reversing the previous quarter's decline and lifting annual growth to 17.3 percent.
Australian economists said strong gains would likely continue in the first half of 1999.
They said the strong profit results in 1998 were driven by a combination of higher turnover from Australia's strong domestic demand and vigorous corporate cost-cutting.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS, GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS TO ATTEND CONFERENCE ON TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Some 80 scholars and government officials from the Republic of China and Australia will converge in Melbourne to attend the 1999 Taiwan Update conference, which starts Thursday.
This year's host is Monash University, and the theme this year is "Taiwan Faces the 21st Century."
Professor Bruce Jacobs of Monash University said that as the new millennium approaches, Asia faces the dual challenges of economic crisis and human rights abuses.
He said Taiwan stands apart in being able to maintain its economic prosperity as it builds a vibrant democracy.
In addition, Taiwan faces strong external pressure from mainland China, he said.
"This conference will explore and analyze the lessons of Taiwan's successes as well as the challenges which Taiwan faces in the 21st century," he said in statement.

Scholars from Australian and Taiwan universities are expected to present papers on various topics, while Professor Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council, will give a speech on how Taipei views last October's visit to the mainland by Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu.
The two-day conference is an annual event that began four years ago.

One of the main purposes of the annual conference is to foster mutual understanding between Australia and the Republic of China. It also examines how Taiwan faces political and economic challenges and how it deals with mainland China's attempts to reunify the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: US GOVERNMENT REJECTS HUGHES' SATELLITE EXPORT REQUEST

TEXT.P: The Clinton administration has decided to reject a request by Hughes Electronics Corp. to sell a communications satellite to Beijing, saying that the transaction poses a threat to national security because the technology could be used by the People's Liberation Army, Tuesday's Los Angeles Times cited a US government official as saying.
The report indicates that the rejection of the export request by Hughes is the first such rejection since the recent eruption of a controversy over technology transfers to mainland China.

In interagency consultations, officials of the State Department, Pentagon and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency opposed the sale, while the Commerce Department alone favored it, according to The Los Angeles Times.
Hughes officials had told the State Department that the potential financial loss to the company and impact on its work force would be substantial if the license application was rejected.

For years, the administration has promoted sales of commercial satellites to Beijing and other nations. But in recent months, it has faced criticism that the sales could aid mainland China's military and improve Beijing's missile-launching capabilities.

The US$450-million satellite Hughes seeks to export is intended to help expand badly needed civilian communications capacity in mainland China and 20 other East Asian countries. But the craft's sophisticated 40-foot-long antenna would make it useful for military purposes, the report noted.

For example, the satellite could facilitate communications between military units on the ground. It also could be used for electronic eavesdropping, according to Henry Sokolski, a former Bush administration defense official who is now with the Nonproliferation Policy Education Center in Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE NATION PARTY DISINTEGRATING AFTER 5 MPS QUIT PARTY

TEXT.P: About eight months after an unprecedented election victory in state elections, Australia's One Nation Party is disintegrating after five members of the Queensland Parliament resigned from the party.
The latest resignations have reduced the number of party members in the state parliament to five from 11 in June 1998.
Criticizing One Nation as undemocratic, the five said the party is controlled only by its president, Pauline Hanson, and her two senior advisers -- David Oldfield and David Ettridge.
The party has been regarded by many as anti-Asian, anti-immigration and anti-Aboriginal people.

In her maiden speech in September 1996 after being elected to the House of Representatives, Hanson captured the attention of the nation by declaring that "Australia is in danger of being swarmed by Asians." Her remarks sparked a nationwide debate on racism.
Queensland Premier Peter Beattie said One Nation should lose its status as a recognized political party because it does not contain enough members of parliament to qualify as one.
Hanson on Tuesday denied the defections would damage her party in elections in New South Wales (NSW) on March 27.
"People in NSW are not concerned about what's happening in Queensland. They are concerned about what's happening here," she told reporters during a campaign stop in western NSW.
One Nation won 11 seats in Queensland's parliament in state elections last June 13.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE TOURISM INDUSTRY DOWN IN 1998, BUT REBOUND EXPECTED THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Australia's tourism industry was hit by the Asian financial crisis in calendar 1998 with a decline in visits by foreign tourists and losses in revenue, but a turnaround will be seen in 1999, the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) said on Wednesday.
In a statement faxed to CNA, ATC Managing Director John Morse said preliminary figures show the total number of foreign tourist arrivals in Australia was down 3.7 percent in 1998 from 1997 levels.
Revenue losses, meanwhile, amounted to about US$430 million in 1998.
But the 3.7 percent decline in the number of inbound tourists in 1998 was still better than the 7.1 percent drop predicted by earlier forecasts, he said.
"The forecasters predicted a decline in overall numbers of around 7 percent in 1998. Today's figures indicate the reality was considerably better, with a decline of just 3.7 percent," Morse said.

He attributed the lower-than-expected decline to strong gains in the arrivals of tourists from the Americas, Europe and New Zealand, which together offset the decline from major markets in Asia, including Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Malaysia, Indonesia and Thailand.
He said another factor contributing to the lower decline was the depreciation of the Australian dollar, which made Australia more attractive and competitive as a tourist destination.
Tourist arrivals from Taiwan fell about 2 percent in calendar 1998 from 1997, according to the ATC.
In December, however, 10,800 Taiwanese tourists went to Australia, up 5.7 percent from the same 1997 month.
In all Australia attracted 4.32 million foreign tourists in calendar 1998.

Federal Tourism Minister Jackei Kelly said the overall drop of 3.7 percent in the flow of inbound tourists in 1998 was "minuscule" and contrary to predictions of a massive downturn off the back of the Asian economic collapse.
"Last year was always going to be the year which broke the pattern of record growth rates and in the circumstances the results are a commendable achievement," she said.
Both Morse and Kelly were optimistic about a tourism turnaround in 1999.

"While I am confident we will return to around 5 percent growth this year, the most important issue for the industry will be preparing for the enormous opportunities available to us in 2000," Morse said.
He said growth in 2000 could range from 5 percent to 10 percent.

Tourism industry promoters expect more visitors from Taiwan and Hong Kong after the two areas are included in an electronic travel authority agreement that facilitates entry into Australia. The service will be extended to the two regions starting July 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHIPBOARD KILLINGS SHOULD NOT AFFECT CROSS-STRAIT TIES: MAC

TEXT.P: The ROC government hopes the recent shooting deaths of two mainland Chinese crewmen allegedly by the captain of a Taiwan deep-sea fishing boat will not affect relations across the Taiwan Strait, a senior official said on Wednesday.

Johnnason Liu, director of the Legal Affairs Department under the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, was responding to reports that the skipper of the Kaohsiung-based Chin Ching No. 12 tuna fishing boat killed two mainland sailors on Feb. 16 while the ship was in the Indian Ocean some 1,000 nautical miles northwest of Mauritius.

Liu said relevant ROC government agencies, including the Ministry of Justice, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Council of Agriculture (COA), are actively handling the case in which 13 other mainland sailors were said to have jumped overboard in panic amid the shootings.

"We are determined to handle the tragic incident in a just and impartial manner, and we are hopeful that the case will be dealt with strictly in accordance with the law to minimize its possible adverse effect," Liu said, adding: "Only by so doing can the rights and interests of people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait be fully protected and cross-strait relations not be affected."

Fishery officials said in the past, key suspects involved in similar criminal cases which occurred aboard Taiwan-owned fishing boats, regardless of their nationalities, had all been repatriated to Taiwan to stand trial.

"We hope Mauritius will repatriate the sole suspect in the Chin Ching case to Taiwan for trial as soon as possible since the killings took place in open seas aboard a Taiwan fishing vessel, which is considered our floating territory," said a COA official.

Meanwhile, a senior executive with the Kaohsiung-based Chin Ching Fishery Co. -- owner of the 490-ton tuna fishing vessel -- said skipper Kung Tai-an, 42, has confessed to the shootings and promised to assume full responsibility for the incident.

Chin Ching Co. manager Wang Ming-chi said two company executives have arrived in Mauritius and met with Kung as well as seven other surviving crewmen who have been detained by Mauritius police for questioning since the ship arrived at Port Louis on Feb. 20 after the incident.

"Kung admitted that he had gunned down the two (mutineering) mainland crewmen. He also said he is sorry for all the trouble he has caused to the company and will take full responsibility for the incident," Wang said, quoting a report from Mauritius by the company's two executives there.
Wang said the company's agent in Mauritius has helped employ a prestigious lawyer to assist in handling the case.

As there is still 50-plus tons of tuna aboard the Chin Ching No. 12, Wang said the company's local agent and lawyer are negotiating with Mauritius authorities for an early release of three Taiwan crewmen to take care of the catch.
"We will also do our best to seek an early repatriation of the skipper for trial and the return of our vessel," Wang said.

Wang would not speculate on the fate of the 13 missing mainland crewmen, but he said the sailors had not used a lifeboat when they jumped ship. Despite strenuous search and rescue efforts launched by Mauritius authorities in the past few days, the whereabouts of the 13 mainland crewmen remain unknown.

The two mainland sailors killed in the incident were identified as Li Xingzheng and Yang Yong. Local press reports said the cause of the shootings may have been related to the victims' demands for pay raises and their refusal to work in recent weeks as their contracts had expired.

The boat left Kaohsiung for the Indian Ocean on Feb. 20, 1996. It originally had 25 crew members, including the skipper. Nine sailors survived the incident, including four from Taiwan, three from mainland China and two from the Philippines. One Taiwan sailor remains in hospital after sustaining injuries to his left arm during the melee.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS SECOND LARGEST SOURCE OF COUNTERFEIT GOODS: US CUSTOMS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 23 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan was listed as the US' second largest source of counterfeit goods in fiscal 1998, behind only mainland China, according to statistics released Monday by US Customs officials.

The figures showed that the value of forged products seized from Taiwan by US Customs reached US$8.61 million last year, up 40 percent from the previous year. Authorities made 250 seizures of Taiwan products involved in violations of intellectual property rights.

Timing for the news is sensitive for Taiwan as the US Trade Representative Office will release its annual "Special 301 Watch List" on April 30, meanwhile, the island is working to be removed from the "black list."

Customs officials said in the 1998 fiscal year, which ended last September, authorities cracked down on 3,400 foreign counterfeiting cases and seized US$75.89 billion worth of illicit goods. The figure grew by 75.5 percent and 40.2 percent, respectively, against the levels of the previous fiscal year.

Of those items seized from Taiwan, computers as well as computer parts and components comprised the lion's share, valued at US$4.86 million and accounting for 56 percent of the total in fiscal 1998. In fiscal 1997, the most popular forged items were cellular phones and their parts and components, Customs authorities said.

Counterfeit electrical fans, lamps and lamp-related goods, and other electronic appliances, with a value of US$1.74 million, were the second most popular counterfeit products from Taiwan shipped to the US, followed by cellular phones and their parts and components.
Mainland China was the US' largest source of counterfeit goods. Some US$28.95 million worth of forged products from the mainland were seized in fiscal 1998, according to the customs statistics.
Hong Kong and South Korea ranked behind the mainland and Taiwan, the tallies showed, while India rounded off the top five countries.

Due to the fact that the number of Taiwan counterfeit goods surged despite efforts to stem such activity, an economics official from Taipei's representative office in the United States said they will put more effort into studying the cause and cooperate with US authorities in the battle against illegal business activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, FUTURES RALLY

TEXT.P: Share prices rallied on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday after the previous session's downward correction.
The TAIEX's weighted price index, the market's key barometer, rose 57.93 points to close at 6,238.87.
A total of 2.63 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$78.36 billion (US$2.37 billion), against the NT$108.66 billion traded in the previous session.
Losers outnumbered gainers 216 to 200, with 73 stocks unchanged.
The eight major stock categories closed mixed.

Those categories that closed higher were financial issues, rising 1.6 percent, followed by electronics issues, surging 1.5 percent; electrical shares, 1.5 percent; plastic and chemical stocks, 0.5 percent; and textile stocks, 0.1 percent.

Those categories that closed lower were construction shares, declining 2.1 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues, falling 1.6 percent; foodstuff issues, 0.6 percent; and cement stocks, 0.5 percent.
The over-the-counter market, however, posted a drop of 0.56 points, closing at 154.21, with a market turnover of NT$3.50 billion.
The Taiwan stock index futures also closed higher.

Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for March were up 110 points to close at 6,425, with 5,943 contract transactions, those for April were up 100 points to close at 6,450, with 157 contract transactions, June futures moved up 88 points to 6,449, with 23 contract transactions. No contract transactions were recorded for September futures.
December futures were up 95 points to 6,468, with four contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER US PRESIDENT CARTER TO VISIT TAIWAN IN LATE MARCH

TEXT.P: Former US President Jimmy Carter and his wife Rosalynn are scheduled to visit Taiwan in late March, a charity organization founded by the former president announced on Tuesday.

The Carter Center, based in Atlanta, Georgia, said Carter will speak at Taipei's Institute for National Policy Research about his non-profit center and the challenge of bridging the gap between rich and poor in the next century.
In addition, the Carter Center said in a news release, the Carters "have been invited to make an unofficial, courtesy call on President Lee Teng-hui."

In Washington, ROC officials and US observers welcomed the visit as a "friendly gesture" to Taiwan from the president who broke off official US relations with the country in favor of Beijing 20 years ago.
James Lilley, former director of American Institute in Taiwan, said Carter has always been a champion of human rights and democracy and these are Taiwan's "trump cards."
Stephen S. F. Chen, the ROC representative to the United States, said the Republic of China is "a real McCoy" when it comes to democracy, human rights and the distribution of wealth.
He said Taiwan should welcome visitors from all foreign countries and should not fear being compared with other places, much less mainland China.
AIT Chairman Richard Bush also said that it is a good thing for Carter to visit "one of East Asia's most successful democracies."

After he left office in 1981, Carter won much respect and admiration for his work in promoting peace, democracy and better livelihood for people in such countries as Haiti and several African nations.
The Carters will arrive in Taiwan on March 29 for a three-day visit after a week of building homes as volunteers for Habitat for Humanity in the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUHARTO'S SON LIKELY TO FACE GRAFT CHARGES

TEXT.P: The flamboyant youngest son of former Indonesian President Suharto is one step closer to facing corruption charges in a multi-million dollar land scam, The Straits Times reported on Wednesday.

The Attorney-General's Office in Jakarta has transferred the dossier of Hutomo "Tommy" Mandala Purtra to the prosecutor's office which has a week to look into the case before making a recommendation on whether to begin trial proceedings.

"The dossiers of the suspects have been submitted to the prosecutor," said Antonious Sujata from the Attorney-General's Office. "If the dossiers are deemed complete, the case will immediately be transferred to the court."

Hutomo, who was prohibited from leaving the country after he was declared a suspect in the case, is believed to be involved in a scam surrounding a 1997 real estate deal between the National Logistics Agency (Bulog) and a private company, Goro.

The deal allowed Goro, which is 40 percent owned by Hutomo and businessman Ricardo Gelael, to build a retail center on land in an affluent residential area in North Jakarta owned by Bulog. But Goro failed to keep its side of the bargain, which was to give 63 hectares of land to the agency. This resulted in an estimated loss of 52.5 billion rupiah (US$6.39 million) to the government.

Political observers in Jakarta said if Hutomo, who at one point refused to obey a summons by the attorney-general, is charged and convicted he may face a maximum of 20 years in jail. Some, however, speculate that the government's latest initiative is an attempt "to show the public it is sincere in its efforts to act against the Suharto family" in the wake of a potentially damning telephone conversation between President B.J. Habibie and Attorney-General Andi Muhammad Ghalib.

Hutomo, who has a playboy reputation and one of the highest profiles among Suharto's six children, is the first in the family to come close to be being charged. His elder sister Siti "Tutut" Hadiyanti Rukmana and brother Bambang Trihatmodjo are also facing investigations into their business activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA AND CAL FORGE BUSINESS ALLIANCES WITH HOTEL GROUPS

TEXT.P: To maintain profits amid a dismal tourist season, Taiwan's two leading airlines -- EVA Airways and China Airlines -- have forged strategic alliances with separate hotel groups.
EVA frequent fliers will be given 500 mileage points when they check into any Sheraton chain hotel around the world after the airline formalizes its new relations with the Sheraton Hotel Group.
The program will come into effect on March 1. Meanwhile, during the period from March 1 to May 31, the bonus points will be increased to 1,000, EVA said.
There are currently 36 Sheraton chain hotels worldwide which all are located in cities where EVA offers its flight service.

Meanwhile, former flag carrier China Airlines (CAL) established a partnership with the Ambassador hotel group. Over the next year, starting on Monday, CAL passengers on Taipei-Kaohsiung flights may enjoy a 60 percent discount on accommodations at Ambassador hotels in the island's two major cities.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slid NT$0.055 against the greenback Tuesday in Taipei, closing at 33.083.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 32.915 and had a low of 33.124.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$400 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCK TRANSACTION TAX ISSUE LIKELY TO REACH CONSENSUS THURSDAY

TEXT.P: The issue of slashing Taiwan's stock transaction tax rate will likely reach a consensus within the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) during a party-sponsored seminar on Thursday, according to informed legislative sources.
To date, there are two proposals for the flexible adjustment measures of the stock transaction tax rate -- zero to 0.6 percent and zero to 0.3 percent.

As business leaders have been in favor of cutting the transaction tax rate to provide incentives and to boost investor confidence, the approval of a zero to 0.6 percent flexible adjustment measure seems unlikely, said the sources, adding that an option of zero to 0.3 percent flexible tax rate will most likely be approved.

Although Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng declined to make any comment on that possibility, he stressed that the tax reduction measure is simply a kind of stimulant with an ultimate goal of attracting capital back to the financial market so a healthy operation of industries can be maintained.
Wang also clarified that the flexible adjustment tax rate measures was his idea rather than that of the legislature.
During Wednesday's KMT Central Standing Committee meeting, party Chairman Lee Teng-hui expressed confidence in Taiwan's economic prospects, according to Wang.

In the face of an economic crisis, Taiwan should develop its own way to handle it, Lee was cited as saying. In addition to the transaction tax cut, there will be many other measures to tackle Taiwan's economic problems, added Lee.

Wang emphasized that in view of the troubles Taiwan has been experiencing, an attempt to boost people's confidence in Taiwan's economic performance is justified. This will keep Taiwan's banking system from being dragged down by a poor financial market, he further indicated.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDEBTED LAWMAKER SAID TO DELAY RETURN TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Financially troubled lawmaker Liu Ping-wei, who fled to the United States after issuing over NT$100 million in bounced checks, may postpone his trip back to Taiwan, sources familiar with Liu's family said on Wednesday.

"It all depends on Liu himself whether he will come back or not. His family here has no way to control his itinerary," the sources said. They added that some of Liu's friends and relatives recently called him and said the lawmaker was slated to return to Taiwan by Thursday after a three-week stay.

Liu, a ruling Kuomintang legislator and former speaker of the already abolished Taiwan Provincial Assembly, flew to Los Angeles on a one-way ticket on Feb. 3 after local media reported that he had bounced checks worth more than NT$100 million.
Liu's departure led the local stock market to plunge 4 percent the following day. Share values of Advancetek Enterprise, controlled by Liu, also plummeted by a daily limit of 7 percent.

Prior to his departure at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport and upon his arrival at Los Angeles' Tom Bradley International Airport, Liu said he would return to Taiwan within five days after finding financial support in the US.

However, rumors reaching here on Tuesday suggested that Liu may have again changed his plans to return to Taiwan. Liu's relatives refused to reveal whether this delay is related to Liu's bid to seek financial rescue in America.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO HEAD DENIES PREMIER SIEW FILED RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: The government spokesman on Wednesday denied that Premier Vincent Siew had filed his resignation amid debate over the lowering of the securities transaction tax.
Chen Chien-jen, director general of the Government Information Office, made the remark after a routine weekly meeting by the ruling Kuomintang's Central Standing Committee.
KMT Central Standing Committee members discussed the current domestic economic and financial situation and the controversial issue of lowering the securities transaction tax.

President Lee Teng-hui, who is also KMT chairman, reiterated his assertion that the lowering of the securities transaction tax is not merely an issue of lowering the tax, but the securities transaction tax should also be flexibly adjusted according to the external economic and financial climate.
Premier Siew had insisted after a national meeting on the current domestic economic and financial situation held on Feb. 12-13 that the Cabinet did not intend to lower the securities transaction tax.
However, Siew's decision faced a strong challenge recently after President Lee said the securities transaction tax should be flexibly adjusted.
Vice Minister of Finance Yen Ching-chang said the issue of the rate for the tax will be discussed at a KMT-sponsored seminar on Thursday.

It was reported that the Cabinet will suggest the upper limit for the securities transaction tax rate at 0.6 percent, up from the current 0.3 percent, while legislators have vowed to maintain the 0.3 percent level. Meanwhile, industrial and commercial groups claim that the rate should be between zero and 0.3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW DPP REPRESENTATIVE TO US ASSUMES POST
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 23 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Chiou I-jen, the new representative to the United States from Taiwan's largest opposition party, assumed his post here on Tuesday.
The pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) representative office in Washington, D.C. held a cocktail reception at the US National Press Club to celebrate Chiou's inauguration.

Among the well-wishers were Stephen Chen, ROC representative to the United States, and Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) which is authorized by the US government to handle relations with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.

Speaking on the occasion, Chen said the Republic of China is now a mature democracy. "Our government is pleased to see any political party set up a representative office in the United States under our constitutional framework," he noted.

The de facto ROC ambassador to the United States went on to say that although he and Chiou may have different opinions on some issues, he looks forward to maintaining close contact with Chiou and cooperating with him to promote ROC-US relations.
Bush said the AIT hopes to develop extensive contact with Taiwan's various political parties. "We welcome Chiou's arrival and hope to maintain regular contact with him," he added.
For his part, Chiou said his priority is to understand Washington's political operations and its attitudes toward Taiwan and mainland China.
Chiou's predecessor Parris Chang said the DPP's representative office is aimed at promoting mutual understanding between Taiwan and the United States.

"Since its establishment in April 1995, the DPP office has scored achievements in three fields -- expressing our party's views on major issues related to Taiwan, forging contacts with the US executive branch, Congress, media and think tanks, and clarifying US misunderstanding about the DPP," said Chang, who is an incumbent ROC legislator representing overseas Chinese community.
Chang, a scholar-turned-politician, said he hopes the American friends he has made during his tenure will offer their support to Chiou.
Other prominent guests at the cocktail included former AIT Chairman Natale Bellocchi and former US Ambassador to mainland China James Lilley.

Chiou, a former DPP secretary-general, recently arrived in Washington. While here, he will meet with researchers at major US think tanks. He will also visit New York before returning to Taiwan on March 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT COMMITTED TO PROTECTING ACHIEVEMENTS: ROC REPRESENTATIVE

TEXT.P: The government of the Republic of China is committed to sustaining and protecting its accomplishments in political democratization, economic development and social modernization, ROC Representative to the United States Stephen Chen said on Tuesday.

Addressing the Center for National Policy, a Washington-based think tank, Chen also noted that on the eve of the new century, the peoples of the United States and Taiwan can look ahead to cooperation in almost every field of human endeavor and the cause of universal peace, progress, and freedom for mankind in the face of daunting challenges in the future.

Chen said he hoped that all the participants could comprehend the sincerity and merit of Taiwan's appeal for justice and understanding, saying the people of Taiwan "ask only for the same considerations enjoyed by all people the world over. In the process, they do not wish to antagonize or complicate life for anyone else.

"Simply allow us the same opportunity to work for justice, democracy, human rights, and peace along with others, and give us the chance to participate energetically in the (Asia-Pacific) region's economic recovery and prosperity. We ask no more, and we could ask no less," said the senior ROC diplomat.

After speaking on Taiwan's democratic development and economic dynamism, Chen told the audience that given their positive experiences of the past half-century, the people of Taiwan face the three-fold challenges ahead "with optimism and a sense of historic destiny."

First, the ROC government has a responsibility to consolidate and extend the achievements of the past two generations, while moving forward confidently toward new levels of prosperity and fulfillment for its people. "The people's right to enjoy peace, security, freedom, justice, and a comfortable standard of living must be defended and strengthened against all odds," he said.

Second, Taiwan must continue the task of improving its relations with mainland China. No one knows exactly when conditions will be ripe for political reunification, he said, but until they are, "we are committed to achieving better understanding and cooperation with our compatriots on the mainland."

Nevertheless, he stressed, China's reunification will not be achieved overnight, or by force. In fact, until the free and democratic people of Taiwan see the benefits of unification with the mainland, they will not support it. Therefore, he said, "both sides need to work toward reunification through a peaceful, evolutionary, and cooperative process in the new century."
Taiwan's third challenge will be to enhance the international identity and role of the 22 million people of Taiwan, based upon the economic stature and solid democratic system they have built.

For now, Chen said, "there are obviously two equal parts of a divided China under separate rule, with very different social and political systems." Thus, until reunification is realized, both peoples are entitled to separate and equal representation in the international community and in international organizations.

He went on: "Our people expect and deserve no less, and we ask only that Washington continues to observe its longtime practice of `parallel engagement' with both parts of divided China, rather than leaving Taiwan isolated or `in the dark.'"
Taiwan abandoned the "zero-sum game" approach to the China issue long ago, Chen said, and the world should adhere to the same pragmatic reality.

"Why anyone would intentionally reject or exclude Taiwan's valuable resources, talents, and willing cooperation on matters affecting stability, prosperity, and democracy in the Asia-Pacific region is beyond rational understanding. It accomplishes nothing at all," said Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPAQ TOPS LIST FOR TAIWAN COMPUTER PROCUREMENTS

TEXT.P: US-based Compaq was one of several foreign computer giants awarded on Wednesday for purchasing large quantities of computers, computer parts and components in Taiwan in 1998.

In presenting the awards, Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang noted that foreign information technology (IT) manufacturers have a high regard for Taiwan's IT industry and have in recent years set up their own semiconductor research and development centers, operation centers, distribution centers and PC research centers in Taiwan.

On the prospects of Taiwan's IT industry, Wang said the ministry will continue to push for Taiwan to become the world procurement center of parts and components, and promote strategic cooperation relations between local high-tech companies and their foreign counterparts.

Wang noted that Compaq's international procurement offices (IPO) in Taiwan topped the purchases by other foreign computer firms by more than US$5 billion in 1998, while IBM, Dell, HP purchased between US$1.5 billion and US$2.5 billion.
Despite the current international economic downturn, the US and European IPOs increased their purchases in Taiwan in 1998.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs said the IPOs of the top 10 US companies purchased a total of US$13.31 billion in Taiwan in 1998, up 45.8 percent from the previous year, while the top five European companies purchased US$1.28 billion in 1998, up 75.3 percent.
Affected by the Asian financial storm, the IPOs of 10 Japanese companies in Taiwan purchased US$1.53 billion in 1998, down 22.2 percent from the previous year.
The top 10 US companies are Compaq, IBM, Dell, HP, Apple, Intel, Micron, Unisys, Gateway2000, and A&A. The top five European companies are Actebis, Elonex, Philips, Siemens, and Wintop.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA REFUTES BEIJING'S ALLEGATION ABOUT ROC-VATICAN TIES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Wednesday refuted mainland China's allegation that Taiwan is an obstacle to its relations with the Vatican.

The ministry was responding to foreign wire service reports which quoted mainland China's Foreign Ministry spokesman as alleging that the Vatican's diplomatic relationship with the ROC is a major obstacle to the improvement of Vatican-Beijing ties.
MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said mainland China's accusation was a distortion of the facts.

"The greatest hindrance to the development of Beijing-Vatican ties lies in mainland China's lack of religious freedom, and has nothing to do with Taiwan or its relations with the Vatican," Wu stressed.
According to foreign wire service reports, mainland China's Foreign Ministry spokesman also criticized ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu's recent visit to the Vatican.

Wu said the mainland spokesman's criticism represented an interference in the Vatican's internal affairs. As mainland China has no diplomatic ties with the Vatican, Wu said, it is not in a position to make any comment on the Vatican's high-level exchanges with the ROC.
Wu said he is convinced that Beijing would often accuse the Vatican of interfering with its own internal affairs if the Vatican were to forge formal ties with mainland China.
The Vatican is one of the ROC's two diplomatic allies in Europe. The other ally is Macedonia which forged formal relations with the ROC on Jan. 27 this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: 600 DESIGNS TO BE DISPLAYED AT TAIPEI LANTERN FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: Despite the current sluggish business environment, the 1999 Taipei Lantern Festival, the city's 10th, will exhibit nearly 600 different lantern designs, the Tourism Bureau said on Wednesday.

About 550 lanterns will be entered in an annual competition, while more than 20 giant lanterns donated by foreign diplomatic and tourism-promotion missions, and five-star hotels, will also be on display, according to the bureau.

The tourism offices of Malaysia, Macao, Singapore, as well as the Far Eastern Plaza Hotel, the Grand Hyatt Taipei Hotel, the Grand Formosa Regent Taipei Hotel and the Grand Hotel, are among the foreign sponsors of the event, the bureau noted.

This year's lantern festival, which will run from March 2-4 at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex, is expected to attract more than 100,000 visitors. The annual jamboree of folk art and colorful activity has become a major attraction for foreign tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES WANTS INTERNATIONAL DISCUSSION OF SPRATLYS DISPUTE

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada has ordered the Department of Foreign Affairs (DFA) to work for the inclusion of the South China Sea territorial dispute in political discussions next month among foreign ministers at the Asia-Europe meeting (ASEM).

Presidential spokesman Jerry Barican said Estrada has instructed DFA Secretary Domingo Siazon Jr. "to exert best efforts to ensure the inclusion and discussion of the South China Sea territorial dispute in the political dialogue of the ASEM foreign ministers."
The Philippines and mainland China are among the six claimants to the potentially oil-rich Spratly chain of islands in the South China Sea. The other four are Malaysia, Brunei, Taiwan and Vietnam.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE GOVERNMENT SUSPENDS PEACE TALKS WITH LEFTISTS

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada on Thursday ordered the "immediate and indefinite" suspension of peace talks with the National Democratic Front-Communist Party of the Philippines-New People's Army (NDF-CPP-NPA).
The move came following the abduction by leftist rebels of two military officers and a police inspector.
Estrada also ordered the suspension of the Joint Agreement on Safety and Immunity Guarantees with the NDF-CPP-NPA, which had allowed some of their members to move freely.

"We cannot allow treachery and bad faith to succeed," the president said. "We will not tolerate this abuse of our goodwill, of our good faith, and of our deep and abiding commitment to bring peace to our countryside and our to our cities," he added.

He stressed, though, that all the other components of the peace process, especially those that address the root causes of the insurgency, will be continued "even more vigorously" by his administration.
These peace process components include social reforms, an anti-poverty program, amnesties, and peace initiatives at the local level, Estrada said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DENIES REPORTS OF PREMIER'S RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday gave a positive appraisal of the performance of Premier Vincent Siew and denied the reports that Siew has tendered his resignation.

Siew, who earlier said that he would never consider slashing the stock transaction tax, reportedly tendered his resignation on Monday because of the controversy over the Cabinet's about-face toward adjusting the tax rate.
At a lunar New Year banquet, Lee categorically denied that Siew had tendered his resignation, and said that he has confidence in Siew's performance.

Meanwhile, Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, said that Siew should not step down, as compared with other major national policies, the stock transaction tax issue is not very important.
He stressed that there is no one more qualified than Siew, with his rich background and experience in handling financial and economic problems, to be premier.
Koo said that the Executive Yuan's decision to slash the 0.3 percent stock transaction tax in the face of the sluggish stock market is a good one which will boost investor confidence.
He said that the government can raise the rate again when the stock market turns bullish.
To date, there are two proposals for the flexible adjustment measures of the stock transaction tax rate -- zero to 0.6 percent, and zero to 0.3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE COMPANIES FINDING SUCCESS IN EMERGING MARKETS

TEXT.P: More Singapore companies are now looking toward emerging markets such as mainland China, India, Indo-China, the Middle East, South America, Central & Eastern Europe, Africa, and Central Asia, for business opportunities, according to the Singapore Trade Development Board (TDB).

In 1998, the Singapore Trade Development Board organized a total of 19 fairs and missions to emerging markets around the world. The participating companies explored non-traditional markets such as Uganda, Iran, Latvia and Kazakhstan, which many would not have even considered for their market expansion plans a few years ago.

Not only do these emerging markets have huge consumer bases and business opportunities, they have also yielded a few success stories among local firms, such as Thakral, Excel Group, Keppel FELS, G & W Trading, Tolaram Group and Intraco.

Tay Thiam Peng, Deputy Chief Officer of TDB, said: "Increasingly, we are seeing a change in the local business community's perception of emerging markets. No longer are they viewed as far-flung inaccessible places, but rather as bright spots with great business opportunities."

G & W Trading, a company trading in consumer electronics, has been doing business with Africa since 1991. With the experience gained and the need to service their African customers, the company opened an office in West Africa. Recently, the company also set up a bonded warehouse in East Africa as a direct result of participating in a TDB mission to Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda in July 1998.

In August 1997, Keppel FELS, recognizing the vast potential in the oil boom in the Caspian Sea, entered into a joint venture to establish and operate a shipyard in Baku, Azerbaijan. In addition, the company has also embarked on the construction of residential and service quality apartments for upmarket clientele and expatriates in Azerbaijan.
Encouraged by the high interest in emerging markets, the TDB is planning 28 fairs and missions to those markets this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDENTS 3RD LARGEST GROUP OF FOREIGN STUDENTS IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 24 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: There are 4,033 Taiwan students studying in Japan, making the island the third-largest source of foreign students there behind mainland China and South Korea, according to survey results released by Japan's Ministry of Education.

The survey found that foreigners going to Japan to embark on graduate and post-graduate study programs have grown -- for the first time in three years -- by 0.5 percent to 51,298 in the 12 months ending in April.

Mainland Chinese students, including those from Hong Kong, is the largest foreign student group, numbering 22,810, or 44.5 percent of the total. The number of South Korean students ranked second at 11,467, or 22.3 percent of the total, while Taiwan students accounted for 7.9 percent.
Students from these three countries jointly made up 74.7 percent of the total number of foreign students.
Compared with one year ago, mainland Chinese students grew by 0.8 percent, South Korean students decreased by 2.7 percent and Taiwan students decreased by 6.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ENTERTAINS AMBASSADORS, REPRESENTATIVES

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Wednesday that the Republic of China's recent diplomatic efforts have borne fruit, despite the efforts by mainland China to strangle Taiwan diplomatically.

The president made the remarks at a banquet and "Ode to Spring" concert for ambassadors and representatives to the Republic of China which took place at a lantern-bedecked Presidential Office on Wednesday.
Lee pointed to the establishment of ties with the Marshall Islands and Macedonia as examples that justice is on the side of the ROC as it treats others with sincerity.
The president also spoke on the nation's political and economic development, as well as cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Lee said that Taiwan's three-in-one elections in December showed a more mature democratic development on the island, which he said has had a positive effect on the mainland, and is conducive to cross-strait stability.

He also pointed out that Taiwan's economic system now conforms with the standards required by international organizations, and expressed the hope that Taiwan can join the World Trade Organization soon.

On cross-strait relations, he recalled the October trip to mainland China by Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu, and adding that Koo stressed to the mainland leadership that democracy is an indispensable factor required before national unification can take place.

Koo has also reached agreement with his mainland counterpart Wang Daohan for the latter to make a reciprocal visit to Taiwan this year, according to Lee, who added that this visit will also be conducive to cross-strait understanding.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA TOPS CANADA'S REFUGEE CLAIMANT LIST

TEXT.P: Mainland China is the No. 1 source of refugee claimants and inadmissible travelers to Canada, Canada's ambassador to the Asian country said Tuesday.
Howard Bullock said in Vancouver, "China still is the source of our largest number of inadmissible passengers on airlines, our largest source of refugee claimants of any country in the world."
He told a China-oriented business luncheon that Canada has been accepting more independent immigrants from the Chinese mainland, but more open migration policies have increased problems of crime.
Bulloch was answering questions about the high rejection rate for student-visa applications from mainland China.

Visa rates have actually increased more than 100 percent, he said, while the refusal rate last year dropped below 50 percent from more than 60 percent in 1997. Some might view that as still too high, he added.
Despite recent crackdowns on pro-democracy activists, Bulloch said the Canadian government believes the trend toward reform in mainland China is irreversible.
Canada is helping mainland China in many areas, from legal reform to trade, investment and the environment, he pointed out.
"I can tell you that everywhere among the senior leaders who are in power today we find a commitment to broad systemic reform that is unabated," said Bulloch.
The shift to capitalism has created widening income disparity, and the sell-off of huge, over-manned state-run industries has fueled unemployment.
That makes the country's leaders fearful of political upheaval, he said, citing a conversation he had with one official.
"He said 'You must understand, our preoccupation with stability. It's stability for reform; it's not stability versus reform,'" he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING BIGGEST POTENTIAL THREAT TO REGIONAL STABILITY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Beijing's military activities in the South China Sea make it the greatest potential threat to regional stability, Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said on Wednesday.

In a meeting with visiting President Edwin J. Feulner Jr. of the Heritage Foundation, a right-wing US think tank , Siew said the publication of aerial photographs of Beijing's military installations on Mischief Reef in the Spratly Islands has caused great panic among the countries of Southeast Asia, especially the Philippines.

This demonstrates that Beijing is becoming the biggest threat to the stability of Southeast Asia, and brings home the necessity of some kind of collective defense mechanism among the states of Asia, Siew said.
The Spratlys is a chain of islets in the South China Sea claimed wholly or in part by mainland China, Taiwan, Vietnam, the Philippines, Indonesia and Brunei.

In a jab at Beijing's inability to judge international public opinion, Siew pointed out that mainland China is beefing up its supervision and control of dissidents to quiet the voice of protest from within in the hope of reversing the international community's judgment of the Tiananmen Square Massacre before the tragedy's 10th anniversary.

Beijing denies that the massacre in Tiananmen Square, when hundreds of unarmed students and workers were gunned down and crushed by communist tanks, ever took place, insisting that only a few people were killed in a legal crackdown on rebellion and sabotage.

Feulner, who came to Taiwan following a visit to Hong Kong and the Philippines, told Siew that his foundation, in conjunction with American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research, will host an international seminar on the Taiwan Relations Act in March.

The seminar will bring together US congressmen, officials and scholars to discuss the purpose and implementation of the Taiwan Relations Act to mark the 20th anniversary of its enactment, said Feulner.
The Taiwan Relations Act, was designed to maintain Washington's contacts with the island after the United States switched diplomatic recognition to mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCK TRANSACTION TAX SHOULD BE FLEXIBLE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: The stock transaction tax should be made more flexible rather than simply being lowered, President Lee Teng-hui said on Wednesday.
Lee, who is also the ruling Kuomintang chairman, told the KMT Standing Committee that the stock tax should be adjustable in accordance with the economic situation.

He made the remarks in an attempt to allay the outcry sparked by unconfirmed reports that Premier Vincent Siew has offered to resign after being ordered by Lee to cut the tax. Siew had publicly asserted that the government would never bow to pressure from Taiwan's business magnates to cut the tax.
Lee asked the committee staff to convey his remarks, as well as the concurring opinions aired by some business tycoons also on the committee, to party members in charge of government policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFORM PACKAGE APPROVED TO STRENGTHEN ECONOMIC FUNDAMENTALS

TEXT.P: Several new measures, including allowing investment and trust institutions to take part in futures transactions, will be put into practice in May, according to the terms of a draft to strengthen economic fundamental unveiled on Wednesday.
Premier Vincent Siew approved the package after listening to a report on the issue by P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development.
Siew said that the package will be put into practice in one to three months, while related draft legislation will be sent to the Legislative Yuan in three to five months.

The new measures include that the Ministry of Finance will allow securities and trust companies to conduct futures transactions from May. These institutions are currently banned from conducting futures transactions.
The MOF will also ease regulations on the listing of high-tech and research and development companies, and provide incentives for small- and medium-sized enterprises to be listed on the stock market.
The MOF will also seek to ease the definition of small-and medium-sized enterprises, which are currently defined as companies with capital of less than NT$60 million and with 200 or fewer staff.
The new measures also envision healthier operation of financial institutions, including the provision that chairmen and directors should have professional backgrounds in the field.

To speed up the reform of basic financial institutions, the MOF and the Central Bank of China will have to provide tax incentives to push credit cooperative banks to upgrade to commercial banks or merge with other banks to upgrade competitiveness.
The new measures were drafted after an economic conference of scholars and economic leaders which took place earlier this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui explained basic tenets of the government's financial and monetary policies.
The China Times:
President Lee Teng-hui denied that Premier Vincent Siew had offered to resign.
The United Daily News:
Premier Vincent Siew will stay on the job.
The Liberty Times:
President Lee Teng-hui said the government should straighten out all economic problems by the end of July.
The Commons Daily:
President Lee Teng-hui said he is convinced that the Taiwan economy will regain momentum by July.
The China Post:
President Lee Teng-hui said flexible stock transaction tax does not necessarily mean a tax cut.
The China News:
President Lee tries to calm recent outcry in wake of controversy over stock tax cuts.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT HEAD EXPRESSES REGRET OVER US PIRACY LIST

TEXT.P: The ROC government's efforts to stem piracy production are so strenuous that no other country in the world can compare, Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Director General Chen Ruey-long said on Thursday.

However, Chen said he regrets that Taiwan was identified by the United States recently as the second-largest source of pirated information technology products in America last year after the government has done so much to curb the infringement of intellectual property rights (IPR).

According to the US Department of Treasury, the US Customs Service seized US$75.9 million worth of imported pirated products in 1998, with US$8.6 million worth of goods from Taiwan. According to those figures, Taiwan was the second-largest source of pirated products to the US last year. Most of the goods were computers and their peripherals and components.
It is the second year in a row that Taiwan has been named the second-largest source of pirated products shipped to the US.

When it received news of this charge last year, BOFT asked US authorities for concrete evidence behind the list's compilation, including the names of the accused companies, the names of export and import sites, freighters or cargo companies, as well as the type of piracy (such as violations of trademark, patent or copyright), Chen said.

Instead of providing Taiwan with the information, the US government said the Customs authorities did not have enough manpower to compile the data and offering such details may violate relevant US statutes, Chen said.

Over the past year, the government has established an Export Monitoring System (EMS), a new arm that monitors Taiwan's computer software exports; established a CD-ROM identification system which allows the export of only those products with legitimate identification marks; and early this year, all of Taiwan's CD-ROM makers signed an anti-piracy self-restraint agreement to help eradicate computer software piracy, Chen noted.

He added that in addition to all these measures, police working under the instruction of related government agencies made a great number of raids on illicit software counterfeiters, seizing caches of pirated CD-ROMs and other software products.

Chen said an equal effort from the private sector is required if Taiwan wants to effectively curb infringements on IPR. Any achievement would be limited if only the government makes an effort to stem piracy, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSES IN AUSTRIA TO MAKE INROADS INTO MACEDONIA
DOC.DATELINE: Bonn, Feb. 24 (CNA) (By Lilian Lin and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan entrepreneurs' association in Austria will dispatch a fact-finding delegation to Macedonia on Feb. 28-March 3 to study the investment climate of Taipei's new diplomatic ally.
The business mission will include 11 members from the tourist, petrochemical, construction, information, electronics, foodstuff processing and dining business sectors.
The visit was promoted by the fact that the Republic of China on Taiwan forged diplomatic relations with Macedonia on Jan. 27.

During the Chinese New Year celebration, ROC officials in Austria encouraged Taiwan businesses there to take advantage of the new ties and bid for trade opportunities in the Macedonian market, according to the ROC representative office in Austria.

The call was echoed by the businesses association, which decided to organize a visit to Macedonia to coincide with ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu's coming Macedonian trip in early March, the office revealed on Wednesday.
Business sources said Taiwan restaurant owners in Austria have expressed interest in expanding their operations to Macedonia where there are now no establishments featuring Chinese cuisine.

DOC.HEADLINE: JIMMY CARTER WILL SEE TAIWAN'S PROGRESS FIRST-HAND

TEXT.P: Former US President Jimmy Carter's forthcoming trip to Taiwan will be an important opportunity for him to "see first-hand the dramatic advances Taiwan has made both economically and democratically in the last two decades," Jody Powell, White House spokesman during the Carter administration, said on Wednesday.

In a written statement issued in response to a press query about Carter's planned trip to Taiwan in late March, Powell noted that the people of Taiwan have created "one of the most mature and vibrant democracies in the world." He praised Taiwan as "a society that is a model for all of Asia."

"One of the issues most important to President Carter, both during his time in the White House and in the years afterward, is respect for basic human freedoms. Taiwan has embraced freedom of the press, freedom of religion and freedom of speech," Powell said.

Taiwan's advances in human rights, including its support of independent labor unions, respect for the rule of law and for the diversity of opinion through free media, is recognized all over the world, he continued.
Moreover, Powell added, Taiwan's system of free and open elections for representatives at all levels of government is "a triumph of democracy in Asia."
"These are all accomplishments of which Taiwan should be extremely proud," he said.

The former White House spokesman said he was pleased to learn that Carter will visit Taiwan next month, and that he has great admiration for the work Carter has achieved in many areas in the years since he left the presidency.
"Americans consistently rate him as one of our country's most respected statesmen," Powell said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALBRIGHT CITES PROGRESS IN MAINLAND CHINA ENGAGEMENT

TEXT.P: US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright said Wednesday that she expects serious discussions concerning the prevention of renewed tensions related to Taiwan as well as other important issues during her visit to mainland China March 1-2, stressing that "in our relations with China, engagement is not endorsement."

Sen. Jesse Helms (R-NC) noted in a budget hearing of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on US foreign policy that President Bill Clinton had uttered acceptance of Beijing's long-awaited "three noes" policy towards Taiwan while in China last July. However, Beijing then returned the favor with a draconian crackdown on dissidents, plus military exercises in November that mocked missile attacks on Taiwan as well as on US forces in Japan and South Korea.
Helms, the Senate committee chairman, then wondered, "just what are we getting from our policy of so-called 'engagement' with China?"

Albright sited in her testimony areas where the United States has seen progress in its strategic dialogue with China: weapon non-proliferation, economic reform, and the responsible role China has played during the current Asian financial crisis. "We need to recognize progress even as we press for more," she added.

Albright promised more tough talk with mainland Chinese leaders during her visit early next week. "I will reaffirm our commitment to dialogue and straight talk. I expect serious discussions about possible Chinese accession to the World Trade Organization, export controls, and the need to prevent renewed tensions related to Taiwan."
The secretary promised the senators that "I will also bring (to Beijing) a strong message of support for international norms of respect for human rights."

Albright said this will come as no surprise to Beijing, as the Clinton administration has repeatedly emphasized this principle in recent months by condemning the arrest of mainland Chinese citizens who peacefully tried to establish an opposition political party.

"Let me stress that in our relations with China, engagement is not endorsement. We continue to have sharp differences with Beijing, but we also believe that the best way to narrow those differences and to make progress where our interests coincide is through regular contacts and dialogue," continued Albright.

Meanwhile, she said, the United States is working with its allies and partners in the Asia-Pacific region to improve security cooperation, restore economic momentum and build democracy, noting that "In this region, there is no greater threat to peace and stability than the situation on the Korean Peninsula."

The United States along with its allies, Japan and South Korea, are having discussions with China and North Korea aimed at achieving a permanent end to tensions on the Korean Peninsula. The United States is also engaging in direct talks with North Korea on ways to resolve concerns regarding suspicious underground construction activities and long-range missile programs, added the secretary of State.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO VISIT HONG KONG

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou is scheduled to visit Hong Kong in his official capacity next week after attending the Asia-Pacific mayoral summit meeting in Brisbane, Australia, city government sources said on Thursday.

Ma will leave for Brisbane on Sunday for his first overseas trip since assuming his current post last December. The Harvard-trained mayor is scheduled to arrive in Hong Kong on March 4 to preside over an inaugural ceremony for a representative office there of the Taipei City Government-owned Taipei Bank.

Political observers said Ma's Hong Kong visit carries special significance because the former British colony is now under mainland China's sovereignty. Ma had applied for a visa to attend activities marking Hong Kong's handover on July 1, 1997 as a university professor, but his application was rejected.
To avoid possible conflict, Ma has kept a low profile on his Hong Kong visit.
Ma was born in Hong Kong and enjoys a high level of popularity there. When Ma was campaigning for the Taipei mayoral post last year, many Hong Kong residents threw their moral support behind his bid.

In addition to presiding over a cocktail reception to mark the opening of the Taipei Bank's Hong Kong representative office, the bank's sixth overseas foothold, Ma will also pay a courtesy call at the National Taiwan University (NTU) Alumni Club. Ma is an NTU graduate.

Ma will also tour some of Hong Kong's hillside residential communities to study its slopeland management strategy and supervisory measures. Improving Taipei's hillside management is one of Ma's main campaign promises.

Ma will head a large delegation of Taipei City Government officials and senior commerce and industry executives to attend the Second Asia-Pacific Mayoral Summit to be held in Brisbane, the capital city of the Australian state of Queensland, from March 1 through March 3. This will be the first time Ma will attend an international meeting in his capacity as Taipei mayor.

Ma, a legal professor-turned-politician, once served as vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, minister of justice and a minister without portfolio before becoming the administrative chief of Taiwan's largest city.

Several other Taiwan local government chiefs, including Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh, Tainan Mayor George Chang, Taichung Mayor Chang Wen-ying, Keelung Mayor Lee Chin-yung and Tainan County Magistrate Chen Tang-shan, have also been invited to attend the Asia-Pacific mayoral meeting.

Meanwhile, the mayors of Beijing and several coastal cities of mainland China, including Shanghai, will also attend the meeting. The summit agenda will focus on the region's economy, business, finance and the environment.
