DOC.HEADLINE: VISA CARD SPENDING IN 1998 TOPS US$10.51 BILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan consumers charged over NT$360 billion (US$10.51 billion) worth of goods and services on their Visa cards last year, accounting for 68 percent of total credit card spending in Taiwan.
Albert Hsiung, vice president and country manager of the Great China Region, said on Thursday that the number of Visa cards issued climbed to 9.4 million in 1998 from 1.92 million in 1994.

It is estimated that the number of cards issued would top 10 million in March or April this year. The amount spent by Visa card holders also surged to a record high of NT$362.7 billion in 1998 from NT$82.2 billion in 1994.

Hsiung said in consideration of the island's economic growth and other factors, Visa card usage in Taiwan will grow by 25 percent this year, showing that the credit card market has room to further develop in Taiwan.
Statistics showed that growth of circulated currency in Taiwan has dropped in the past five years, also an indication that credit card payment has gradually taken the place of cash.

Hsiung noted that of their total expenditures last year, consumers chose to pay on credit over cash in 9.1 percent of the cases, which is up from 3.5 percent from five years ago. He estimated that the rate would top 10 percent this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA'S SECOND VICE PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Panamanian Second Vice President Filipe Virzi departed on Wednesday for a four-day visit to the Republic of China.
ROC Ambassador Lan Chih-min, and Economics Counselor at the Embassy Chen Ming-shih were among those who saw Virzi off at the Panamanian Tocumen International Airport.
Virzi, accompanied by a five-member delegation, will travel to Taipei via the United States and is scheduled to arrive on Sunday.
While in Taipei, Virzi will meet with President Lee Teng-hui and his ROC counterpart Lien Chan.
Virzi will also call on Foreign Minister Jason Hu and visit economic installations including Taiwan Sugar Corp. and Chunghua Telecommunications Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Feb. 25, or the 10th day of the first month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1570: Queen Elizabeth I of England is excommunicated by Pope Pius V.
1778: Jose de San Martin, the Argentine revolutionary leader and national hero who played a big part in achieving independence for Chile and Peru, is born.
1841: The Ching court offers rewards for British heads as the Opium War rages.
1862: US President Abraham Lincoln introduces the "greenback," a new version of the dollar bill, to finance the Union's mounting Civil War costs.
1873: Enrico Caruso, Italian operatic tenor who with his powerful, pure, emotive voice is considered one of the greatest singers ever, is born.
1888: John Foster Dulles, the American politician, diplomat and secretary of state under President Dwight Eisenhower, is born.
1901: John Pierpont Morgan, American financier and philanthropist noted for his reorganization and control of major railroads, his art collection and the establishment of the Morgan Library in New York City, begins his consolidation of US Steel Corp.
1913: The federal income tax comes into force in the United States after ratification of the 16th amendment to the US Constitution.
1913: Emmeline Pankhurst, founder of the Women's Social and Political Union and Britain's suffragette movement, is in court on bombing charges.
1933: The Ranger, the first US carrier ship built especially for aircraft, sets sail from Virginia.
1950: Members of the Control Yuan bring impeachment proceedings against acting President Li Tsung-jen.
1953: President Chiang Kai-shek orders the abrogation of the 1945 Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1956: Soviet Communist Party leader Nikita S. Khrushchev denounces late dictator Joseph V. Stalin as a demigod and tyrant in a speech to the party congress.
1957: Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi forms new cabinet in Japan.
1964: Cassius Clay (Muhammad Ali) hammers Sonny Liston into the canvas in Miami Beach, Florida, to become the world's heavyweight boxing champion.
1977: Uganda's President Idi Amin Dada keeps 240 Americans as hostages.
1981: South Korea's Chun Doo Hwan is again elected president by the electoral college.
1983: Tennessee Williams, the American dramatist whose plays included "Sweet Bird of Youth," "A Streetcar Named Desire," and "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof," dies in New York at the age of 72.
1986: Philippines President Ferdinand E. Marcos resigns, and Corazon Aquino, whose husband was shot in Manila after leaving Taipei in 1983, announces an end to "the long agony" of 20 years of tyranny under Marcos.
1993: Kim Young Sam is sworn in as South Korea's first civilian president in 32 years.
1996: Haing Ngor, a Cambodian refugee and actor in the film "The Killing Fields," is murdered by three Asian street gang members in Los Angeles.
1997: Jiang Zemin delivers an eulogy for Deng Xiaoping, vowing that mainland China's opening to the outside world will continue.
1998: Kim Dae Jung, veteran pro-democratic campaigner, is inaugurated president of South Korea.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Suppose a man wants to raise a mound and just as it wants only one basket more of earth to complete the work, suppose he were suddenly to stop: the stopping depends entirely upon himself. Suppose again a man wants to level a road, although he has just thrown over it only one basket of earth; to proceed with the work also depends entirely upon himself."

DOC.HEADLINE: US MUST END ITS 'ENGAGEMENT' POLICY WITH MAINLAND: THINK TANK

TEXT.P: Washington should take advantage of the US secretary of State's coming visit to mainland China to reassess the Clinton administration's policy of engagement with Beijing, according to the Center for Security Policy.

The Washington-based think tank said in a newly published decision brief titled "Time for a Course Correction on China," that perhaps the most compelling piece of evidence to do so is China's growing propensity to utilize its ballistic missile force as a coercive instrument.

Last month, the Washington Times revealed that the United States has evidence that the mainland has conducted simulated missile attacks against US forces and facilities in East Asia during recent exercises.

What is more, Beijing's missile threat to both American personnel and assets and those of its allies has been sharply heightened of late. The Financial Times of London reported on Feb. 10 that a classified Pentagon report indicates that, "The Chinese military has stationed 150 to 200 M-9 and M-11 missiles in its southern regions aimed at Taiwan. It plans to increase the number to 650 missiles over the next several years."

Rep. Chris Cox (R-CA) said this build-up is part of Beijing's "effort to preempt US efforts to promote theater missile defense in East Asia -- efforts that are barely in the planning stage." The Chinese are no less adamantly opposed to the Clinton administration's purported interest in building a limited national missile defense.
Meanwhile, the US Commerce Department, the agency that has shown itself most determined to press ahead with high technology sales to China, is growing uneasy about the mainland's behavior.

A February 1999 report commissioned and published by the department's Bureau of Export Administration said, "Continued pressure on foreign (including American) high-tech firms to transfer advanced commercial technologies, if successful, could indirectly benefit China's efforts to modernize its military."

As a practical matter, the danger inherent in the Clinton administration's ambitious program of Sino-American defense exchanges and other Chinese practices, including espionage, technology theft and drug smuggling, "are exacerbating the dangers of US-Chinese conflict," the think tank said.

The United States, therefore, is left with no choice: "It must abandon 'engagement' as practiced by the Clinton administration in favor of a new approach, one that reasserts America's commitment to protecting its friends and interests in Asia and thwarting Chinese policies that threaten them. Such an alternative is made all the more practical given the PRC's internal problems ranging from unemployment, labor and ethnic unrest to corruption."

Unfortunately, the Center for Security Policy noted, if US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright has her way, she would surely prefer her trip to the mainland be like President Bill Clinton's visit last year -- emphasizing the positive and downplaying, if not denying outright, the negative.

Under present circumstances, she must not be allowed to have her way, the center said. "The fact is that the People's Republic of China is not now, and will never be, a reliable 'strategic partner' for the United States and the free world," the Center for Security Policy stated.
Albright is slated to visit mainland China from March 1-2.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN GIVES LOANS TO THAI EXPORTERS AND MANUCTURERS

TEXT.P: Thai exporters as well as small and medium scale manufactuers are expected to receive loans totalling US$ 1.35 billion from Japans's Export-Import Bank (Jexim) according to the official Thai News Agency.
The action comes as high levels of non-performing loans are limiting the ability of Thai banks to make new loans.
Jexim is expected to give US$500 million to the Industrial Finance Corporation of Thailand, US$2250 million to Krung Thai Bank and US$600 million in a co-financing arrangement.
The loans are parts of Japan's US$30-billion bail-out fund for regional economies.

Yohei Nishiyami, Jaxim's senior economist, said Thai exports were unlikely to increase significantly in the short term due to high levels of non-performing loans that limit Thai banks from making new loans, as well as uncertain global economic prospects.
In addition, the poor state of the Japanese economy also affects Thai exporters, he said.
Nishiyami suggested the Thai government restructure its export industry to focus on high-technology products such as electronics and computer products instead of labour-intensive goods.

DOC.HEADLINE: MJIB SEX SCANDAL NOT POWER STRUGGLE, SAYS JUSTICE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Yeh Chin-feng on Thursday ridiculed allegations that a sex scandal involving a Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) investigator was a power struggle within the bureau, stressing that it was only a simple and isolated incident of lack of discipline.

Yeh said a formal investigative report on the scandal, involving MJIB investigator Hua Jung-kan and a female journalist with whom Hua admitted to having improper physical contact during a Chinese New Year drinking binge, is not available yet, but that Hua and his supervisors were dealt with fairly according to the law.
Hua, an investigator of the MJIB's north Taiwan division, attempted suicide Wednesday after he was forced to resign for allegedly having sexually harassed the journalist.

Hua cut his wrist and poisoned himself with gas at his home in Peitou, northern Taipei Wednesday night. He was rushed to the Veteran General Hospital, where doctors on Thursday morning said Hua's wounds were not life-threatening, however the long term effect of gas to his brain remains to be seen.

According to other reporters who were at the Chinese New Year party on February 6 hosted by the MJIB at its headquarters in Taipei, the female journalist was drunk and began vomiting after consuming Kaoliang liquor. Hua offered to escort her to the lady's room where he allegedly sexually harassed her.
In a recent investigation, Hua denied rape, but admitted to "improper physical contact," saying he had lost control of himself after drinking too much.
The journalist, whose identity was concealed, reportedly said she didn't want to bring the harassment case to court.

After a preliminary investigation, the MJIB announced on Wednesday that Hua's resignation was accepted, while his immediate supervisor will be disciplined for inadequate supervision and reassigned to another post. Two other supervisors were also disciplined.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ACCELERATES PREPARATIONS FOR WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan is actively working with the World Trade Organization's (WTO) working party to arrange for multilateral talks on Taiwan's admission into the world body as soon as possible, said Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Yi-fu on Wednesday.

His remarks came in reaction to scheduled talks between Washington and Beijing on mainland China's WTO entry. The talks will take place when mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji visits the United States in April.

US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky said in a briefing held at Washington's Foreign Press Center on Wednesday that Taiwan has not yet held multilateral talks or completed all required bilateral talks with WTO member economies necessary to gain WTO entry.

Taiwan has completed bilateral talks with 26 members of the WTO. At present, only Canada and Hong Kong have not signed agreements with Taiwan on Taiwan's WTO entry. Canada is expected to sign an agreement on Taiwan's WTO entry in one to two months, Lin said.
Taiwan reached a bilateral agreement with the United States on Taiwan's WTO entry on Feb. 20, 1998.

With great courtesy, Barshefsky declined to answer whether the United States supports Taiwan gaining entry to the WTO before mainland China. Instead she said, "I think Zhu Rongji's visit provides China with a possible opportunity to seek progress."
She made the remarks in response to questions by Hong Kong news media after a lecture at the Foreign Press Center on US trade policy toward Africa.
The United States is urging mainland China to take advantage of this opportunity to reach a bilateral agreement with the United States on mainland China's WTO entry, she said.

Discussing the upcoming multilateral talks between Taiwan and the WTO, Lin said the Ministry of Economic Affairs is now working with the WTO's working group to determine the scope and substance of the talks.
As to whether Zhu's US visit will speed mainland China's WTO entry, Lin said the matter is between the United States and mainland China.

He said Taiwan will continue to adhere to its present position that the WTO entry of Taiwan and mainland China should be handled separately and that whichever side first completes all entrance requirements should be the first admitted into the WTO.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S WORKFORCE SHRINKS TO 17-YEAR LOW

TEXT.P: Taiwan's workforce, also known as the labor participation rate, dropped last year to 58.04 percent of its total population aged 15 or over, its lowest level since 1982, according to statistics by the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

A DGBAS report attributed the decline to the fact that an increasing number of college graduates are opting for advanced study instead of entering the workforce. An increase in the number of men retiring early and an aging population were factors as well, according to the report.
Because older people are accounting for a growing proportion of Taiwan's population, the labor participation rate is expected to drop 1.43 percentage points over the next 15 years, the DGBAS warned.

The report indicated that in the past decade, more men than women have been dropping out of the workforce. The labor participation rate among men in Taiwan has declined from 75.24 percent of Taiwan's male population in 1987 to 70.58 percent in 1998. During the same 11-year period, the labor participation rate among women slid only 1 percentage point.

In 1987 the average age of a worker being pensioned off was 57.79. Last year the average age was 56.44. Moreover, a survey of workers' attitudes found that workers aged 30 and under intend to retire eight years earlier than do workers 55 and older.

Anticipating a further decline in the size of Taiwan's workforce, DGBAS officials said, "Measures aimed at pumping up labor participation to help maintain economic development should be mapped out and carried out as soon as possible."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WEAPONS SMUGGLER REPATRIATED BY PHILIPPINES
DOC.DATELINE: Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Feb. 25 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A notorious Taiwan weapons smuggler who has fled the country for 10 years was repatriated by the Philippines to Taiwan Thursday.
Chang Hsien-ming, 45, was convicted of smuggling guns and ammunition via a fishing boat into Taiwan from the Philippines in 1989.
Chang and his accomplice, Wu Ho-kuo, were put on Taiwan police's wanted list in January 1990 after the pair fled the island during an investigation in late 1989.

Through the help of Interpol, Taiwan police authorities determined that Chang and Wu were hiding in the Philippines. In late 1990, Wu was nabbed by Philippine police and was repatriated to Taiwan on Dec. 4 of that year.
In April 1995 Philippine police had Chang nearly cornered in a fishing village called Bulan Sursgon in the central Philippines. In 1998 he again eluded police, who were tracking him.
Police successfully apprehended him on Feb. 22 and transferred him from the southern city of Tacloban to Manila on Feb. 23.
According to the Ministry of Justice's Investigation Bureau, the agency has had 141 convicted criminals from Taiwan repatriated since the bureau established a cross-border operations unit in 1984.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHERMEN PROTEST AGAINST SMUGGLED FISH HAULS FROM MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Fishermen on Taiwan's western coast on Thursday protested against the smuggling of fish from mainland China into Taiwan, where they are dumped on the local market.

Fishermen unfurled large white banners Thursday morning in Fangyuan Village, located in central Taiwan's Changhua County, to mark the start of their campaign. Fishermen from Changhua to Pingtung in southern Taiwan are expected to join the protest.

They intend to display more than 4,000 banners along Taiwan's western coastal highway to protest the smuggling into Taiwan of fish caught by mainland fishermen and to call for the protection of local fishermen's rights.
Fisherman Lin Kuan-tian from Changhua County said that the mainland began to dump large numbers of fish onto the Taiwan market late last year.
In particular, claims from mainland waters are larger than local ones and consequently more appealing to Taiwan seafood buyers.
Merchants can buy a kilogram of mainland clams for NT$7.8 and sell them for NT$75, while local clams go unsold, Lin said.
Lin called for local people to boycott mainland clams, saying that although local clams are small, they are fresher and more delicious than mainland ones.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES CLOSE HIGHER, FUTURES CLOSE MIXED

TEXT.P: Late profit-taking exhausted most of the early gains on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, rising a slight 36.66 points to close at 6,275.53.
A total of 3.02 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$94.70 billion (US$2.86 billion), against the NT$78.36 billion traded in the previous session.
Gainers outnumbered losers 291 to 122, with 87 stocks unchanged.
All eight major stock categories closed higher.

Pulp and paper stocks posted the largest gains, rising 3.6 percent. They were followed by cement stocks, which rose 1.5 percent; plastics and chemical shares, 1.2 percent; foodstuff shares, 1 percent; construction shares, 0.7 percent; electrical issues, 0.5 percent; textile issues, 0.4 percent; and financial issues, 0.1 percent.
The over-the-counter market also rose Thursday, with the market's index closing at 156.51, up 2.3 points over the previous session's close on a market turnover of NT$4.92 billion.
Taiwan stock index futures ended the day mixed.

Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for March were down 45 points to close at 6,380, with 5,210 contract transactions. Futures for April were down 25 points to close at 6,425, with 182 contract transactions. Meanwhile, June futures moved up 17 points to 6,466, with 15 contract transactions; September futures climbed 37 points to 6,440, with one contract transaction; and December futures fell 26 points to 6,442, with two contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS LEADERS THROW SUPPORT BEHIND LIEN PRESIDENTIAL BID

TEXT.P: The heads of three major business groups said on Thursday that they would support a 2000 presidential bid by Vice President Lien Chan.
Wang You-theng, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China, said that he is planning to mobilize the chamber's members and their enterprises to support Lien.
Wang, who is also a member of the Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang, said he will also form a "friends of Lien" club to drum up support.

In addition to mobilizing its members, chamber officials will discuss with the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce (CNAIC) and the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) measures to support Lien.
CNAIC Chairman Jeffrey Koo, a childhood friend of Lien's, said he would support the vice president as well if he were to run for president.
Koo also stressed that Lien is a perfect candidate for president, saying that he is a man of integrity who has an academic background as well as ample experience in politics.

CNFI Chairman Kao Chin-yen said that while he supports Wang's aim to form a "friends of Lien" club, he intends to tackle Taiwan's major financial and economic problems before attempting to mobilize support among CNFI members for a presidential bid by Lien.

DOC.HEADLINE: EARLY ECONOMIC REFORM IMPROVES CHANCES OF AVOIDING RECESSION: PREMIER

TEXT.P: The earlier Taiwan takes action to reform its economy, the better its chances of avoiding a long-term recession, such as the one now affecting Japan, said Premier Vincent Siew on Thursday.
The primary task of the Executive Yuan is to tackle the economic and financial issues that are of concern to all people in Taiwan, noted Siew.

The premier made the remarks during a Kuomintang (KMT) central policy coordination convention, which was held to iron out possible resistance to measures that would introduce flexibility to the island's stock transaction tax.

In response to the current economic problems Taiwan is experiencing, said Siew, the Executive Yuan has offered a wide-ranging economic revitalization package. The chief goals of the new stimulus package are to address Taiwan's economic and financial ills in a more fundamental way over the short-, medium- and long-term, Siew added.
Short-term measures will not interfere with Taiwan's long-term economic performance, while medium- and long-term measures will focus on a structural and systematic reform of the economy.
The Cabinet will submit to the legislature by the end of May a bill detailing all the Cabinet can do in this regard, Siew indicated.

The revitalization package involving structural and systematic economic reform was designed not at the behest of large business interests that have experienced financial hardships, said Siew. It was instead designed to deal with the global economic situation in the coming century, he added.

Six special measures taken last Friday by the Central Bank of China and the Finance Ministry to address Taiwan's financial woes in its money, bond and stock markets are all designed to strengthen Taiwan's economic structure, he said. One of the proposed measures is a reduction in banks' business income tax from the current 5 percent to 2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DOWN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The US dollar ended at 33.063 against the New Taiwan dollar on Thursday in the Taipei foreign exchange market, down NT$0.02 from Wednesday's finish.
The greenback opened at 32.985, and was traded between 33.13 and 32.985 during the day's trading session. Interbank transactions expanded to US$531 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TAIWAN PEOPLE KILLED IN MAINLAND CHINA PLANE CRASH

TEXT.P: No one from Taiwan was aboard the mainland Chinese passenger aircraft which crashed on Wednesday in the southeastern part of the country, the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) said on Thursday.

In a message sent to its Taiwan counterpart -- the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) -- ARATS confirmed media reports that no Taiwan passengers were aboard the Russian-made Tupolev Tu-154 plane belonging to China Southwest Airlines which crashed near the city of Ruian while approaching Wenzhou airport in coastal Zhejiang province.
All 61 people, including 50 passengers and 11 crew members, were killed. All were mainland Chinese citizens.
The SEF had immediately extended its condolences to ARATS after learning of the tragedy.
The SEF and ARATS are the semiofficial organizations authorized by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle bilateral exchanges in the absence of official contacts.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY CLARIFIES SHIPBOARD KILLING REPORTS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative office in Mauritius said on Thursday it will do its utmost to seek the extradition of the captain of a Taiwan fishing boat who allegedly killed two of his mainland Chinese crewmen in the Indian Ocean on Feb. 16.

ROC Representative to Mauritius Lee Tzi-nan made the statement in a telephone interview with CNA in response to a press report that mainland China's Foreign Ministry has claimed jurisdiction over the alleged Chin Ching No. 12 shipboard killing case, in which 13 other mainland sailors are also said to have jumped overboard in panic.
Lee said he had not heard that mainland China's embassy has asked Mauritius to turn over the case to its jurisdiction.

In the meantime, Lee said, the ROC's representative office has been focusing its efforts on pushing Mauritius to hand jurisdiction of the case over to the ROC and to repatriate the ship's captain for trial in Taiwan.

A local newspaper quoted Chen Meng-ning, the vessel's first engineer, as complaining on Wednesday that the ROC's representative office in Mauritius has not offered the surviving crew of the Chin Ching No. 12 any assistance since the ship arrived in Port Louis last Saturday.
Chen also told a China Times reporter that two mainland Chinese embassy staff members had expressed concern for the surviving crewmen and had accompanied them during police questioning.

Commenting on the reports, the de facto ROC ambassador to Mauritius admitted that mainland Chinese Consul Li Gueixi attended a police questioning session as a spectator on Monday afternoon. "Li left the Mauritius police office after the interrogation had finished, and all the surviving sailors were allowed to return to their ship," Lee said.
However, he stressed that none of the mainland embassy staff had visited any of the ship's crew.
Lee further pointed out that as Mauritius has been in turmoil in recent days with clashes between protesters and police, the investigation of the case has been disrupted.
Lee said only three of the 10 surviving crew members -- skipper Kung Tai-an, Chen Meng-ning and Lee You-lai -- have so far not been questioned.

"Kung's lawyer insisted that Kung can be questioned only in the company of his lawyer; Chen was allowed to return to the vessel to take care of its catch; and Lee You-lai is in a hospital receiving treatment for arm injuries sustained during the shooting melee," Lee said.

Responding to another China Times report that Kung shot a total of 11 of the mainland crewmen, and that four others jumped ship in panic, Lee said he cannot comment on such shocking reports before there has been further investigation.
Thus far, Kung has confessed to Mauritius police that he killed just two of the mainland crewmen, and that 13 others jumped overboard. The fate of the missing mainland sailors remains unclear.
Kaohsiung-based Chin Ching Fishery Co., owner of the 490-ton tuna boat, also said on Thursday that it cannot confirm the veracity of the China Times report regarding the number of deaths.

The boat left Kaohsiung for the Indian Ocean on Feb. 20, 1996. It originally had 25 crew members, including the skipper. In addition to Kung, nine other crewmen survived the incident, including four from Taiwan, three from mainland China and two from the Philippines. The tragic incident took place in the Indian Ocean some 1,000 nautical miles northwest of Mauritius.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECURITY NO. 1 CONCERN IN SATELLITE EXPORT LICENSING: LA TIMES

TEXT.P: Increasingly concerned about Beijing's progress in acquiring advanced military technology, the Clinton administration has decided to reject Hughes Electronic Corp.'s request to sell a $450 million communications satellite to a mainland Chinese consortium with ties to the People's Liberation Army, an editorial in Wednesday's Los Angeles Times noted.
The decision has focused attention on the issue of technology transfers to mainland China.

The editorial pointed out that the satellite Hughes seeks to export was developed to greatly expand telephone and other types of communications across mainland China and much of East Asia. But intelligence agencies and others believe it could also be used to bolster the mainland Chinese military's command and control systems and to carry out electronic eavesdropping against the United States and its allies.

According to a report in Britain's Financial Times, US officials had an even larger concern: Launching the satellite aboard a mainland Chinese rocket would have required sharing with Beijing potentially sensitive information of possible use in mainland China's missile program. Improved accuracy in mainland Chinese missiles, some of which are capable of reaching the United States, has captured Washington's attention.

A few months ago a select House committee issued a report, much of which will soon be declassified, calling for tougher security standards in the transfer of satellites and other technology to mainland China.

The Senate Intelligence Committee will soon release its own cautionary study. Strengthening economic and other ties with mainland China has been a fairly consistent goal for more than two decades, but that policy must be subordinate to US security interests, according to the Times editorial.
The editorial concluded by asking whether security concerns are being properly considered.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAT BUCHANAN URGES STRONG US POSITION TOWARD MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Conservative syndicated columnist Pat Buchanan urged on Wednesday President Bill Clinton to take a strong position in dealing with mainland China's potential threat to the security of Taiwan and American's interest in the region.
"No one wants a war with China, but appeasement invites it," wrote the famous columnist and commentator on current issues in an article titled "Chinese Missiles: Taiwan Gambit?"

Citing recent news reports that Beijing conducted mock strikes on US bases in Korea and Japan and that the mainland Chinese military has stationed 150-200 M-9 and M-11 missiles in its southern regions aimed at Taiwan, Buchanan asked why Beijing, by threatening Taiwan, would risk the disruption of trade ties that provide it with US$ 60 billion every year.

Clearly, mainland China fears that a window of opportunity is closing, said Buchanan, adding that with North Korea building rockets, mainland China may worry that Japan, South Korea and Taiwan may follow the example of India and Pakistan and develop independent nuclear deterrents.
"That would checkmate China's drive for hegemony in Asia," he noted.

When mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji arrives in Washington this spring, President Clinton should tell him to stop targeting Taiwan and US forces or start looking elsewhere to sell his exports, Buchanan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: POSSIBLE TAPPED PHONE CONTINUES TO TRIP UP HABIBIE

TEXT.P: Pressure is mounting on Indonesian President B.J. Habibie to clarify the substance of an alleged telephone conversation with his attorney-general over the investigation into former leader Suharto's wealth, as a senior opposition figure called for a parliamentary probe that could lead to impeachment proceedings, according to The Straits Times.

As controversy raged over the conversation's authenticity, analysts said that Habibie's continued public vitriol over the practice of phone tapping and the admission of a senior adviser that the phone call may be real offered fodder for the president's critics now crying for blood.
Zarkasih Nur of the Muslim-oriented United Development Party (PPP) fired the opening salvo by calling on Habibie to account for his actions.

The country's leading daily Kompas on Wednesday quoted him as saying that Parliament had the right to ask the president to explain why he had not adhered fully to a decree by the People's Consultative Assembly (MPR) to investigate Suharto.
"What is the point of having such laws if we do not use them?" he said.
Others went further, calling for impeachment proceedings against Habibie, the paper reported.

A recording of an alleged conversation between Habibie and Indonesia's attorney-general indicated the two were trying to make a probe into possible abuses of power by Suharto easier for the former ruler.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA CALLS FOR CONTINUED COMMITMENT TO FREE MARKETS, OPENNESS

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada declared Wednesday night his administration's commitment to free markets and globalization even as he urged the other Asian countries to be "open and competitive."

In his keynote address before the 10th Asia Society corporate conference at the Shangri-La Hotel in Makati City, the president said much of the growth of once-robust East Asian countries, including the Philippines, was achieved by their opening themselves up to the global economy.

Although the regional economic crisis that is still gripping most of Asia was partly caused by the region's relative openness and free market policies, there is no reason to abandon these policies now, and doing so would lead to more problems, he said.

Estrada said one of the most important lessons to be learned from the regional financial crisis is that "we all must do our national homework," adding that weaknesses in the financial and corporate sectors are now being addressed.
"Entire financial systems are now being addressed, entire financial system are undergoing needed shake-ups. Economic restructuring however painful is being pursued in earnest," the president said.
The Philippines has been steadily moving toward greater economic freedom since 1995, Estrada said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MARCHES INTO 21ST CENTURY WITH CONFIDENCE: GIO

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is marching into the 21st century with confidence despite facing enormous challenges ahead, Chen Chien-jen, director-general of the Government Information Office, said in a message to the 1999 Taiwan Update Conference in Melbourne on Thursday.

In a keynote message at the opening ceremony of the two-day conference at Monash University, Chen, who had to abandon at the last minute plans to attend to the conference, said Taiwan is facing three big challenges in the new millennium.

The message, read by Professor Bruce Jacobs of Monash University, said Taiwan is facing economic challenges despite the fact that its economy has emerged relatively unscathed from the Asian financial crisis.
Chen said to sharpen Taiwan's competitive edge in the world market, "the (ROC) government has placed top priority on strengthening and upgrading the economic structure at the earliest date."

"Internally, Taiwan also faces the enormous challenges of social transformation. Taiwan continues to go through a painful and confusing transformation from a simple, traditional society to a pluralistic, industrial society," he said.
He cited major problems such as widening income disparity among the island's 22 million people, rising crime rates, and concentrated power in the hands of special interest groups.
"To counter these problems, the ruling Kuomintang Party proposed a fair, just and new society in addition to prosperity, stability and a goof life," he said.
He said the second major challenge involves cross-strait relations between mainland China and Taiwan.
"Peking has yet to renounce the use of military force against Taiwan; therefore, relations between Taipei and Peking are a major factor affecting our existence and development," he said.

He reiterated that mainland China's "one country, two systems" policy "ignores reality" and "is unacceptable to the people of Taiwan. Peking and Taipei should reduce differences and promote mutual trust by holding constructive consultations and strengthening private exchanges."

"We are confident that under this gradual, progressive course, the two sides can be unified as a free, democratic, and equitably prosperous new China. This vision of a new China can meet the expectations of all people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait," he said.

The third challenge is facing comes from the international community, Chen said. He said Taiwan's efforts to promote political democratization and economic liberalization not only reflect domestic needs, but are also in accord with international trends because the Republic of China aims to play an active and constructive role in the international community.

"During the past five decades, we have not only shared the successful experiences of Taiwan's development with the Third World, but we have also repaid the international community with substantial assistance programs," he said.

But Chen said Taiwan's contributions "have not always resulted in fair treatment, since Peking repeatedly disrupted our normal diplomatic relations with other countries, tried to isolate us from the international community and malevolently described Taiwan as a 'troublemaker.'"
Despite the pressure from the Chinese mainland, however, "We will continue to forge ahead with a diplomatic policy of developing pragmatic relations with friendly countries," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S PRE-SCHOOLERS BECOMING STRONGER, TALLER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's youngsters have become taller and stronger over the past 17 years, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) reported on Thursday.
The department was reporting on an extensive survey of heights, weights and head sizes of local children aged between zero and six years conducted during the 1996-97 period.

"The growth curve based on the survey results show that the local pre-school children's growth curve is higher than Hong Kong's 1993 level and Japan's 1990 level," said Chang Tan-jung, a DOH public health expert.
Chang said the survey results also indicate that local pre-schoolers' growth situation matches levels in advanced countries.

Compared with figures recorded in a similar 1982 survey, the average height, weight and head size of local newborn babies in the 1996-97 survey were similar to the 1982 figures. One year later, however, they were found to have grown faster.

Two-year-olds were heavier than their counterparts in 1982 by an average of 0.5 kg.; 3-year-olds were heavier by 1 kg.; 4-year-olds were heavier by 1.5 kg.; 5-year-olds were heavier by 2 kg.; and 6-year-olds by 2.5 kg.
Meanwhile, 2-year-olds were 1 centimeter higher than their 1982 counterparts; 3-year-olds were higher by 2.5 cm; 4-year-olds were 3 cm higher.
The average head size of 2-year-olds was also 0.5 cm bigger than their 1982 counterparts, according to the 1996-97 growth curve.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION PARTY TO LAUNCH NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION AGAINST PREMIER

TEXT.P: The tiny opposition New Party legislative caucus decided on Thursday to put forward a no-confidence motion against Premier Vincent Siew on Friday to express their grave discontent with Siew's political flip-flops.
The move came as result of the Executive Yuan's abrupt about-face over the stock transaction tax dispute, according to Chen Yung-shui, deputy convenor of the caucus.

Yielding to pressure from the island's business magnates and President Lee Teng-hui's instructions, the Cabinet backed down on its once-insistent policy of no transaction tax cuts, and on Monday, Siew nodded his approval for the forming of a panel to mull the possibility of lowering or eliminating the tax in order to pump up the local bourse.

Chen said that his party has received a growing number of complaints from members of the public over deteriorating political, economic and social order attributed to a constitutional crisis -- the president holds absolute power over policymaking, but takes no responsibility for any policy failures.

The premier, who should be governing the country, now merely plays the role of the president's rubber-stamp, Chen claimed, while having to be responsible for all the consequences of his administration. Chen also described Siew as no longer the premier of the country, but only the president's chief consultant.
This weakness has aroused mistrust of the administrative authorities among the people, according to Chen.

The no-confidence motion will be carried out at the opening of the legislature's first session of 1999 on Friday, in which the premier has to brief the legsilature on policy, and receive interpellation from legislators.

The New Party move has won major support from the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), claimed Chen. DPP legislators are said to be prepared to add their signatures to the planned no-confidence bill, which needs the signatures of one-third of the 225 members of the Legislative Yuan to be put onto the formal legislative agenda, although it can only be passed with the approval of half of the legislature.
Chen said he will seek signatures from legislators with "consciences" from the ruling Kuomintang and other parties to give their support to his motion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MORE DISSIDENTS DETAINED IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Two more organizers of a seminar on human rights in mainland China, to be held on March 1-3 during US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's visit to Beijing, have been detained by police, a human right group said here Thursday.
The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said that Zhang Hanjiang and Jiang Hansheng were taken away from their home Thursday by police.

The seminar, to be sponsored by the outlawed would-be opposition China Democracy Party (CDP) and China Human Rights Observer, will be held in Wuhan, capital of Hubei province in central China. Zhang is vice chairman of CDP's Hubei provincial branch, while Jiang is a CDP member from Wuhan.

Two other organizers of the meeting, Chairman Cheng Zhonghe of the party branch and his colleague in the party Xiao Shichang, were detained two days earlier for defying the order of authorities not to proceed with the preparations for the seminar, the information center said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TAKES MEASURES TO PREVENT FISHING BOATS FROM OCCURRING MUTINIES

TEXT.P: The Fisheries Administration under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture is reviewing the current hiring system for deep-sea fishing crews, an administration spokesman said on Thursday.
The move comes after a recent alleged mutiny aboard the Taiwanese tuna boat, Chin Ching No. 12, on the high seas near the Indian Ocean island nation of Mauritius.
Two mainland Chinese sailors were reportedly shot dead by the skipper, who is from Taiwan, and another 13 mainland crewmen were missing after jumping overboard at gunpoint.
The Fisheries Administration has decided to strengthen the management of deep-sea fishing boats, and has outlined the following measures to prevent similar incidents from occurring in the future:

-- Invite the Council of Labor Affairs and the Mainland Affairs Council, both of which are Cabinet-level institutions, to discuss in the next few days the ratio of local to mainland Chinese and foreign crew, shipboard working conditions for sailors, as well as such issues as crewmen's salaries and regulations governing sailor manpower brokerage companies;
-- Impose punishments on vessels that violate fishing operation regulations;
-- Station fishery experts in major overseas fishery bases in order to manage the personnel who operate from those bases;
-- Increase leisure facilities for crewmen and provide recreation equipment in the facilities to allow crewmen to relax in foreign fishing ports; and
-- Strengthen officers' leadership abilities and evaluate their performance in order to decrease the number of violations of regulations overseas and the occurrence of mutinous incidents.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULD NOT ENGAGE WITH BEIJING AT THE EXPENSE OF TAIWAN: ANALYST

TEXT.P: The success of Taiwan's decade-long experiment with democracy, which stands as shining proof of what free people can achieve in a Chinese society, should prompt the US government to reassess its policies toward Beijing, the president of an American research institute said on Thursday.

Heritage Foundation President Edwin Feulner was speaking on the relationship between the United States and Taiwan over the last 25 years at the joint invitation of the Taipei-based Sino-American Cultural and Economic Association and the Vanguard Foundation, which is headed by former legislator Wei Yung.
Feulner began his speech with a review of the US relationship with mainland China.

The Clinton administration's pursuit of a "constructive strategic partnership" with mainland China consists of little more than "soaring rhetoric and frequent meetings," and does nothing to recognize and reward Taiwan, which is the real partner of the United States in democracy and free markets," said Feulner.

According to US policy toward the mainland, democracy should have spread and the market should have become more liberal, Feulner said. However, after the so-called "engagement" policies of the Clinton administration, instead of achieving these goals, Beijing is continuing to modernize its missile and space programs, technology for which is allegedly being given by or stolen from US companies, the head of the conservative think tank noted.

Regarding the free market, Feulner said that despite the mainland's strenuous efforts to obtain membership of the World Trade Organization, the United States still has to send high-level officials to push for faster market opening, as American economic policies toward the mainland are not being fully achieved.

Meanwhile, he continued, Beijing's constant military deployments in the Spratly Islands not only create unstable tension in the region, they also illustrate the poor performance of Washington's security policy toward the mainland.

These factors, Feulner stressed, have given the foundation every reason to urge Washington to reassess its policies regarding the mainland, and to continue to support the economically thriving and politically democratic Taiwan.

By consistently supporting Taiwan over the last two decades -- ever since the passage of the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act -- the United States has witnessed a "dramatic transformation" in Taiwan, Feulner noted. "Freedom has spread from the marketplace to the ballot box, making Taiwan one of Asia's best and proudest examples of a free-market democracy," he said.

US interests in the region have not changed since the passage of the Act, and neither should US policy toward Taiwan, Feulner said. "Even though the American government no longer recognizes Taipei as the legal government of all of China, the American people remain committed to the cause of freedom -- for that is the only principle that can give any government moral legitimacy," Feulner was quoted as saying.

The United States must honor its commitment to Taiwan by maintaining close unofficial ties with the government of Taiwan and by helping Taiwan become a full participant in international organizations such as the WTO, Feulner said.

The administration should also join Taipei in calling on Beijing to renounce its threat of military force to take the island, and should employ a regional missile defense system to protect US allies in North Asia, he went on.

As an important first step toward giving Taiwan the recognition it deserves, the US government should receive Taiwan's democratically elected leaders in the United States, Feulner said. The heads of several other states without diplomatic standing in the United States have already been received by the Clinton administration, such as Cuba's Fidel Castro and Palestine's Yasser Arafat. How, then, Feulner asked, can the administration justify shunning Taiwan's leaders?

As for the island's concerns over its inclusion in the US-initiated Theater Missile Defense system, Feulner expressed confidence that the US Congress will bring this into serious discussion, though he did not give a specific timetable.
In conclusion, Feulner said that the US-Taiwan partnership should play an important role in shaping American policy toward mainland China and in securing American interests in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: MUNICIPAL AD HOC COMMITTEE SET UP TO FIGHT ENTEROVIRUS

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government announced on Thursday the establishment of a task force to fight the enterovirus which claimed the lives of hundreds of children islandwide last year.

The task force, headed by L.T. Lee, deputy director of the Bureau of Health under the Taipei City Government, will launch a campaign next month to promote a series of measures among parents and teachers in the city to prevent children from being afflicted by the disease again this year.

Although the period between March and November is the peak season for the disease, bureau officials said scattered cases of enterovirus have already been reported in southern Taiwan since the beginning of the year.
Currently, about 50 children are being sent to hospital every week for treatment of enterovirus-like symptoms, according to the bureau.

Judging from the children admitted in the first two months of the year, children younger than three accounted for 75 percent of the total cases, the bureau added, while calling on the public not to overlook the potential threat posed by the epidemic.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAN NABBED FOR ROC PASSPORT FORGERY
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Feb. 25 (CNA) (By F.C. Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan man was arrested by Thai police on Thursday after investigators seized three forged Republic of China passports and a fake steel ink stamp of the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs at the hotel where he was staying.
Chen Jung-ter, 49, a Taipei resident who has lived in Thailand for several years, was detained by police in front of a bank in downtown Bangkok, according to Thai police authorities.

Chen admitted to police that he purchased stolen passports at cheap prices, doctored them and resold them to mainland Chinese people wishing to go to a third country. A false ROC passport with a valid visa for the United States or Japan can be bought for around US$40,000 or US$50,000, he noted.

The police also found that Chen himself was living in Thailand on a forged ROC passport, and had used the passport to enter Hong Kong and mainland China without being discovered by immigration officials. Police also found a name-list at Chen's hotel of mainland Chinese people who have bought forged ROC passports from him.
Chen, who will be tried by a Thai court, will be deported to Taiwan after completing his jail term here, police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG PEOPLE HOPING FOR CLOSER TIES WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Feb. 25 (CNA) (By M.N. Wang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Most people in Hong Kong hope that bilateral Hong Kong-Taiwan ties can be further strengthened, according to the results of a recent survey.

The poll, carried out by Hong Kong University, found that 53.1 percent of the residents of Hong Kong think the Hong Kong government should build a closer relationship with Taiwan. About 56.9 percent support Taiwan's efforts to create a greater international presence, while 27.6 percent voiced disagreement with the concept, the survey found.

Some 48.7 percent of the respondents said Hong Kong-Taiwan relations have gone through no major changes since the former British colony returned to mainland Chinese rule in July 1997, down from the 52.5 percent in a similar survey in June 1998. Only 13.7 percent said they believe two-way ties have improved, a slight increase from the 11.9 percent in the previous poll.

On the question of whether the Hong Kong government should set up a representative organization in Taiwan, the poll found that 78 percent of Hong Kong people agreed with the idea, ahead of the 74.2 percent in the earlier survey.

Turning to the question of the image that they have of Taiwan and mainland China, the respondents gave an average rating of 64.3 points to Taiwan, while mainland China scored just 57.2 points, according to the survey.
The poll, commissioned by Chung Hwa Travel Service, Taiwan's de-facto representative office in Hong Kong, was conducted in early February among 1,032 local residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: US TO REITERATE TO BEIJING POSITION ON CROSS-STRAIT ISSUES

TEXT.P: Amid seemingly heightened tension across the Taiwan Strait, the United States will soon reiterate its position to Beijing that any resolution of cross-strait issues should be peaceful, a senior US official said on Tuesday.
US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright will "send a very clear message" to mainland China when she visits Beijing next week, according to the State Department official.
The message will be "first about the importance which we attach to resumption of cross-strait dialogue," he said. "And she'll be sending the message that any outcome has to be peaceful."
This reiteration of the US position will come after a series of recent news reports on mainland China's missile build-up vis-a-vis Taiwan.
At a background briefing on Albright's visit to Asia, the official played down the significance of these reports, which were based on two Pentagon studies due to be released soon.

The official said that the Pentagon reports indicate "that China is in the process of ongoing military modernization, not in any kind of alarming stark or dramatic sense, but, rather, in terms of a long-term process."
"I don't think there should be any surprises," he said. "So I don't expect any increase in tensions as a result of either of those reports.
According to the official, one of the most important purposes of Albright's two-day visit to Beijing is to continue the regular strategic dialogue.
He said that North Korea and South Asia will be high on the agenda.
In addition, said the official, with Premier Zhu Rongji's upcoming visit to the United States, many bilateral issues will be discussed, including mainland China's WTO accession and market access.
Issues such as nonproliferation and human rights will also get high priority during the trip.
Albright is due to arrive in Beijing on Feb. 28 at the start of her three-nation tour. She will later visit Thailand and Indonesia.
On the possibility of agreement on mainland China's WTO accession being reached before Zhu's visit in the spring, the official said that "it is certainly conceivable; it is not definite."
"Both sides are negotiating seriously with good intent," he said.

On the question of whether the United States will resume support for a resolution condemning Beijing at the annual conference of the United Nations Human Rights Commission, the official said that no decision has yet been taken.
The official also said that Albright will discuss Tibet with her Chinese counterparts, "and we'll reiterate our concerns in a very clear fashion."

DOC.HEADLINE: FIXING ECONOMY RAPIDLY WILL BENEFIT EVERYONE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: A rapid fix of the wavering economy will benefit the people of Taiwan as a whole rather than just a small bunch of individuals or firms, President Lee Teng-hui said on Thursday.

In an effort to drum up support for the government's economic policies, especially the controversial decision to cut the stock transaction tax, the president told a lunar New Year gathering of business and labor leaders that all the economic policies are designed to remedy the ailing economy, and that their beneficial effects will trickle down to everyone on the island.

Lee put the blame for the current economic crisis on the island's decreasing exports; plummeting real estate market; businesses being deprived of normal access to credit; mounting bad loans on the part of financial institutions; and the investor pessimism about the country's economic prospects.
Although those issues are all intertwined, the government has worked out a package of measures to redress them, Lee said.
Lee made the remark in response to criticism that the government's economic policy favored a coterie of industrialists and business magnates at the expense of the general public.

Critics complained that soft loans offered by the government to first-time house buyers, rather that allowing market forces to set house prices, serve only to provide the construction industry with an unexpected windfall, while the proposed cut in the stock transaction tax is no less than a ploy to "rob the poor to pay the rich," whose funds are trapped in the bourse by plummeting stock prices.
The extension of a grace period to some troubled businesses by the same token is seen as a privilege to certain business tycoons.
In his opening speech at the gathering, Lee pressed home his point that economic recession hurts everybody and economic recovery helps everybody.
Later on Thursday, Lee forcefully denied that he dictated policy to Premier Vincent Siew, the chief of the executive branch under the Constitution.
In a meeting of legislators of the ruling Kuomintang, he said that Siew consulted with him on the issue of the stock transaction tax out of respect for his economic expertise.

The local press said that Siew, who dismissed categorically the proposal of cutting the stock transaction tax at an economic conference two weeks ago, was forced by the president to eat his words after Lee ordered him to heed the advice of business tycoons and lower the tax in a desperate attempt to revive the bourse.

Unconfirmed reports about Siew's offer to resign over the ensuing embarrassment caused an outcry in Taipei political circles, with critics accusing Lee of trespassing on Siew's Constitutional authority.

Denouncing the reports as "groundless," Lee said his knowledge of the Constitution is enough for him to be well aware that the premier is the national executive head accountable to the legislature and the president, and that although he appoints the premier, the president is not supposed to pull the strings in the government's policymaking process.

However, the vigorous denial failed to explain why Siew reversed his stance after meetings with Lee on Feb. 19 and 22, and opposition legislators, angered by Siew's sudden about-face on the issue, are threatening a motion of no confidence against him on Friday.
However, there is little chance of the motion passing through the chamber, as the ruling party commands a comfortable majority in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui outlined key points for resolving financial and monetary issues.
