DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Feb. 26, or the 11th day of the first month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1802: Victor Marie Hugo, the French writer who wrote such novels as "The Hunchback of Notre Dame" and "Les Miserables" and went into exile after Napoleon III seized power in 1851, is born.
1901: Chi Hsui and Hsu Cheng-yu, leaders of the "Righteous Harmony Fist" Rebellion, or the Boxer Uprising, are publicly beheaded by a court executioner in Peking, ending two years of unrest against the presence of foreigners in China.
1906: Angered by an incident in which a French missionary stabbed and injured the magistrate of Nanchang Hsien (county) in Kiangsi Province, Nanchang citizens kill a total of nine English and French missionaries in the county.
1935: Sir Robert Alexander Watson-Watt, a Scottish electronics engineer and inventor, demonstrates for the first time at Daventry in England the radar he helped develop.
1936: An army revolt to establish a more nationalistic government fails but three leading members of the civilian government are killed during the uprising and Japan's military leaders gain a firm control of the government.
1936: German Chancellor Adolf Hitler opens the first factory for the production of the Volkswagon, the so-called "People's Car," in Saxony.
1952: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill announces that Britain has developed an atomic bomb and will test it in the Australian desert.
1964: The ROC Air Force receives a number of F-104G jet fighters from the United States under a military aid program.
1970: The Executive Yuan decides to go ahead with construction at a meeting on the North-South Freeway.
1976: Spain gives up control of the Spanish Sahara and the region comes to be called Western Sahara which is divided into two parts and come under control of Morocco and Mauritania respectively.
1979: The Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan is formally opened.
1981: A French super high speed train connecting Paris with several cities in France travels at a top speed of 380 kph, a new world record.
1982: An ancient tomb dating back to the Han dynasty (206 B.C.-8 A.D.) is unearthed in Mawangtui, in suburban Changsha City, Hunan Province.
1988: Panamanian President Eric Arturo Delvalle, who dismissed General Manuel Antonio Noriega from his military command, is forced from his office by Noriega supporters.
1990: President Lee Teng-hui and President Prosper Avril of Haiti sign a joint communique calling for stronger bilateral cooperation.
1990: Vaclav Haval, Czechoslovakia's new president, announces in Moscow that all Soviet troops will leave his country by July, ending 21 years of armed occupation.
1991: Saddam Hussein orders Iraqi troops to retreat from Kuwait and declares a great victory.
1993: Two mainland Chinese basketball teams arrive in Taiwan to play exhibition matches against local teams, marking the first time in four decades that athletes from Taiwan and mainland will compete in Taiwan.
1995: Barings, the London finance house, collapses after losses run up in Singapore by trader Nick Leeson.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Youth should be respected. How do we know that their future will not be as good as we are now? Only when a man is forty or fifty without having done anything to distinguish himself, does he then cease to command respect."

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLAR CALLS TAIWAN TO IMPROVE POLITICAL QUALITY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 25 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A scholar in Asian studies at Seton Hall University on Thursday called on Taiwan to seek to further improve the quality of its democracy.
Winston Yang, who heads Seton Hall's Asian studies department, delivered a speech at New York-based St. John's University on the democratization of the two sides across the Taiwan Strait.

The ethnic Chinese expert in cross-strait affairs praised Taiwan's efforts to embrace democracy, citing the existence of legitimate opposition parties that serve to check the government. He also complimented Taiwan for the watchdog functions performed by its legislative institutions and media.

But elections in Taiwan are still tainted by allegations of bribery and violence, while criminal elements continue to wield power in local governments, as well as in the legislature, Yang said, calling this the dark side of Taiwan politics.
Speaking of mainland China's democratization, Yang said that while he doubts much will change in the short term, over the long term, democracy will take root in the mainland.

The present mainland Chinese leadership will eventually give way to a new generation, comprising intellectual elites educated in the United States and Europe, where freedom, democracy and human rights are advocated. The new leadership will build a country based on the principles of humanitarianism, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA REPORT REVEALS TAIWAN'S BEST-SELLING FRUITS AND FLOWERS

TEXT.P: Liucheng, also known as Taiwanese oranges, were the most popular fruit in Taiwan last year, as 17,270 metric tons were consumed by the public, sources from the Council of Agriculture (COA) reported Friday.

Meanwhile, shueimitao, a type of peach that are particularly flavorful and juicy, were the most expensive fruit in Taiwan, with wholesale prices topping NT$136 (US$4.20) per kilogram, according to officials from the council's Food and Agriculture Department.

In its latest market survey the council found the nine most popular types of fruit in Taiwan last year were, in order, liucheng, lianwu (wax apples), ponkam (Taiwanese mandarins), papayas, watermelons, bananas, mini watermelons, guavas and melons.
Wax apples were the star of Taiwan's fruit kingdom last year, climbing from sixth in 1997 to second last year in terms of popularity. In 1998 they ranked fifth in terms of cost.
The most expensive fruits in Taiwan last year were, in order, shueimitao, persimmons, sugar apples -- also known as custard apples -- litchi nuts, wax apples, chestnuts, loquats and pears.
Meanwhile, imported, thick-stemmed roses were the "queen" of fresh and cut flowers in Taiwan in 1998, with wholesale unit prices amounting to NT$312 (US$9.70) per dozen.
The roses were the most expensive flower sold in Taiwan last year, followed in order by Casablanca lilies, imported chrysanthemums and orchids.

Anthuriums were the most popular type of flower last year, as 9.54 million bunches, each of which contains 10 to 12 flowers, were sold. After anthuriums the most popular flowers were, in order, chrysanthemums, roses, potted plants, Casablanca lilies, African daisies, and gladioluses.
The COA report also noted that sunflower seed oil replaced soybean oil as Taiwan's best-selling cooking oil last year.

COA officials attributed the sunflower seed oil sales growth to increased health-consciousness among Taiwanese consumers. The oil contains alpha-type vitamin E, which can be absorbed directly by the human body. It is considered a good edible oil, said COA officials.
Sales of olive oil, not commonly used in Chinese cooking, rose as well last year, while sales of butter and lard declined slightly.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACEDONIAN UN ENVOY REAFFIRMS TIES TO ROC AFTER BEIJING'S UN VETO
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Feb. 25 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Macedonian Ambassador to the United Nations Naste Calovski said on Thursday that Beijing's veto of a proposed extension of the UN peacekeeping mission in Macedonia will not affect his country's relations with the Republic of China.

Calovski made the statement in response to a press inquiry after mainland China vetoed a UN draft resolution which had proposed a further six-month extension of the UN Preventive Deployment Force, known as UNPREDEP, in the former Yugoslav republic.
Stressing that ROC-Macedonian ties are strong and steadfast, Calovski said Beijing's veto will not change the reality of this situation.
Mainland China cut diplomatic relations with Macedonia shortly after the Balkan country forged official ties with the ROC on Jan. 27.

Calovski said he deplores the fact that mainland China has acted outwith "bilateral considerations" to cast its veto. He called for the continuation of the UN peacekeeping mission because of "the very real possibility of a new bloody war in the Balkans."

Calovski also said during a UN Security Council (UNSC) session before the vote on the peacekeeping mandate extension that no UNSC permanent member should abuse its veto power to hurt the rights and interests of other UN member states, because such moves violate the UN charter.

Mainland China's veto means that the 1,049-strong UN force in Macedonia, tasked with ensuring that ethnic tensions do not spill over from neighboring Kosovo, should technically be wound up when its mandate expires on Sunday.

Although mainland Chinese UN Ambassador Qin Huasun did not refer to Macedonia's ties with Taiwan in his speech during Thursday's Security Council open session, other council envoys made it clear that Beijing's veto was linked to the so-called Taiwan issue.
UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan recommended last week that the UNPREDEP in Macedonia be extended until Aug. 31.

The force includes about 360 troops from the United States, 640 from Scandinavia, and about 50 from Indonesia. It was originally deployed to monitor borders and deter the spread of fighting to Macedonia from Bosnia. It is also monitoring a UN embargo against Yugoslavia, including Kosovo province, where ethnic Albanians are battling Serbian security forces. Macedonia also provides logistical support for European civilian monitors in Kosovo, and is a base for NATO operations in the region.

US Ambassador to the UN Peter Burleigh said after Beijing's veto that his delegation hopes to "begin work immediately" with other council members "to find a way to allow the international community to continue to meet this critical need without disruption."

Beijing exercised its first veto in nearly 25 years in January 1997 against 155 military observers who were to monitor peace accords in Guatemala, which also maintains diplomatic ties with Taiwan as do several other Central American and Caribbean nations. Beijing reversed its decision two weeks later, presumably when Guatemala promised not to back UN membership for Taiwan, according to diplomats.

Mainland China in the past has also twice threatened to veto UN troops in Haiti for the same reason. The move forced the UNSC to change the name of the Haiti mission and then have the United States and Canada pay for the troops.

DOC.HEADLINE: RACISM ON THE RISE IN CANADA: JEWISH GROUP

TEXT.P: The Jewish service group B'nai B'rith said Thursday that anti-Semitism is on the rise in Canada.

In its annual audit, the League of Human Rights of B'nai B'rith Canada said there were 240 incidents of anti-Semitism reported last year, up 14 percent from 1997. Last year's growth reversed a two-year decline.
The report noted that many of the incidents involved threats, slurs or the distribution of hate propaganda.
Toronto, which has Canada's largest Jewish population, accounted for more than 50 percent of all anti-Semitic incidents in the country, according to the report.
The president of B'nai B'rith Canada, Lawrence Hart, said hate groups appear to be moving their operations to the suburbs and the Internet.

"I have received some pretty disgusting hate mail over the last several years," said Frank Dimant, executive vice president of B'nai B'rith Canada. "But I must admit it was particularly terrifying to be the target of a death threat on the Internet."
On the positive side, there were 42 reported incidents of anti-Semitic vandalism in 1998, down a significant 28 percent from the 58 incidents reported in the previous year.
This trend is consistent with police reports across the country and may be the result of a crackdown by a special Canadian police unit that focuses on hate crimes, said the group.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OFFICIAL SEES INTERNET AS HELPING ROC SPREAD ITS CAUSE

TEXT.P: The free flow of information through news media and the Internet is helping Taiwan seek peace with mainland China prior to their eventual reunification, Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said here Thursday.

In an interview with CNA and the Australian Broadcasting Corp.'s Radio Australia, Lin said the ROC government is optimistic that China will eventually be reunified in a peaceful fashion, as long as the following three conditions are met.
First, democracy prevails in both parts of the currently divided China. In this regard, Lin said, Taiwan is in a favorable position.
Second, information is allowed to flow freely through news media and the Internet. Again, Taiwan leads mainland China in this regard, he said.
Third, the trend of economic globalization continues as well. Such increased globalization will make the use of military force obsolete, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JANUARY GROWTH CLEAR AND POSITIVE: MOEA

TEXT.P: Both Taiwan's export orders and industrial production grew substantially in January, showing a remarkable turn-around from sluggishness over the past year, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported on Friday.

Taiwan exporters and manufacturers received US$9.81 billion (US$305 million)-worth of export orders in January, up 15.89 percent, or US$1.35 billion, over the year-earlier levels, according to MOEA tallies.

MOEA officials attributed the remarkable growth to stabilized prices of electronic products, particularly those of semiconductors and related products, and a relatively lower comparison basis posted in January of 1998.
Unlike 1999, the 1998 Chinese New Year holiday fell in January, which resulted in fewer working days in that month compared with January 1999. The 1999 Chinese New Year holiday fell in February.

If export orders received in February exceed US$8.2 billion, the MOEA will be comfortably safe to say that Taiwan's export orders in the first quarter of this year is likely to switch from deficit to growth, said Chang Yao-tsung, director-general of the MOEA's Statistics Department.

Bearing the brunt of the Asian economic meltdown, Taiwan's export orders had posted month-on-month declines since last March, resulting in an annual fall of 4 percent, or US$4.95 billion, from the 1997 figure. This decline represented the first annual negative growth in that category in Taiwan for 16 years.

In January, export orders placed by importers from the United States totaled US$3.48 billion, up 21.84 percent over the same month of the previous year. Export orders from Hong Kong soared 30.63 percent to US$1.64 billion, while those from Japan jumped 16.93 percent to US$970 million and those from Europe rose 2.28 percent to US$1.71 billion, MOEA tallies show.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's industrial production also rose significantly in January, with the month's industrial production index climbing 14.97 percent over that of the year-earlier level.

Evident growth in semiconductor manufacturing, iron and steel processing, and the information technology and telecommunications industries were cited as the prime movers behind January's industrial growth, said Chang.

Among all categories in the industrial arena, the manufacturing sector posted a growth of 14.34 percent in January over the same month of 1998, compared with growth of 56.13 percent in the housing and real estate sector, growth of 13.59 percent in mining, and growth of 8.78 percent in the public utilities sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: DAMNING AUSTRALIAN REPORT CITES INEQUALITIES AGAINST TAIWAN WOMEN

TEXT.P: Most Taiwanese women would prefer to be men if they had a choice, while the mjaority of European and Australian women are glad to be women, according to a survey by an Australian expert.

Presenting his paper at the 1999 Taiwan Update Conference in Melbourne on Friday, Dr. David Schak, head of the Taiwan Studies Unit at the School of Modern Asian Studies of Griffith University in Brisbane, said two-thirds of the Taiwanese mothers surveyed would rather be men.
"This is not surprising, given the inequality for girls growing up in Taiwan and seeing their brothers pampered, doted upon and privileged," he said.
"Parents do more for boys (in Taiwan), expect less domestic help from them while growing up, and give them more freedom as teenagers and young adults," he said.

He said that in Taiwanese families hard pressed to give all their children the standard of education each aspires to, boys are far more likely to receive family assistance, which sometimes means that a sister denied the education she may have wanted has to work to support her brother.
He said women in Taiwan also suffer disadvantages in the workplace.
He cited a survey by the Interior Ministry of Taiwan which shows employed women get only half to two-thirds of the pay given to men doing the same job.
He said sexual harassment is also a problem for women, both on the job and in generally in society. He said a street survey of women found that sexual harassment is relatively common in Taipei.
Female night school students are regarded as most vulnerable, but the most common form of harrassment is deliberate touching in crowds or public buses.

In an earlier survey, Schak said most female victims did not complain because it could endanger their jobs and because it is so hard to prove. There is no legal definition of sexual harrassment in Taiwan.
But this changed in early 1998 when the Taipei District Court handed down a ruling awarding US$3,100 to a woman who had accused her supervisor of sexual harassment. (Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC URGED TO HELP SET UP SCHOOLS FOR OVERSEAS CHINESE

TEXT.P: Second-generation Chinese in Australia and elsewhere need proper Chinese language education so that they can speak and write in their mother language, according to scholars.

The issue was raised on Friday at the 1999 Taiwan Update Conference in Melbourne, Australia, when several participants, mainly Chinese Australian scholars, asked why the Republic of China government has not provided financial help to set up Chinese schools in major cities in Australia so that their children can receive proper Chinese language education.
They said Chinese associations in Australia's major cities have to lease classrooms from Australian schools to give Chinese language education for only two hours per week.

They said two hours per week of Chinese education is not enough, and that they wanted proper schooling so that the children of Chinese descendants and even other ethnic groups can have the chance to learn about Chinese culture.

This issue came after professor Chen Tung-jung, director of the Cultural Division of the Taipei Economic and Cultural office in Canberra, finished presenting a speech by Deputy Education Minister Yang Kuo-shih, who was absent from the conference due to his busy schedule in Taipei.
In his speech, Yang said the ROC government has given top priority to education reform with the approach of the new millennium.

He stressed: "To ensure the success of our endeavors in the coming era, it is very important for us to place education at the forefront of the global agenda and to be well-prepared for all the changes in the diversified environment of our society."

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE TO VOTE ON NO-CONFIDENCE MOTION AGAINST PREMIER

TEXT.P: A no-confidence motion against Premier Vincent Siew, filed by 82 legislators, was accepted by the legislature on Friday, the first day of the first session of the 4th legislature.
The motion is scheduled to be put to the vote next Tuesday.

The 82 lawmakers of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and the New Party put forward the no-confidence motion to express their discontent with Siew's policy swing regarding the stock transaction tax.
It is the first no-confidence motion to be brought against the premier since the last amendment of the nation's Constitution.
At a meeting on the economic and financial situation held on Feb. 12-13, Siew had insisted that the Cabinet would not lower the stock transaction tax.

However, following a meeting with President Lee Teng-hui, he abruptly reversed his decision, although Lee later vigorously denied that he had instructed Siew to take such a course of action in order to benefit a small coterie of the island's business tycoons at the expense of the small investor.
The move resulted in fierce criticism from the opposition, who have branded the premier as nothing more than a rubber stamp for the president.
According to the Constitution, one-third, or 76, legislators' signatures are needed to form a no-confidence motion.

The Constitution also stipulates that once a no-confidence motion is lodged, the president of the Legislative Yuan must send the motion to the floor for a screening within 72 hours, while an open ballot must be held within 48 hours.

The no-confidence vote needs the approval of half of the legislators to secure the premier's resignation, whereupon he would have to resign within 10 days and request the president to dissolve the Legislative Yuan, according to the Constitution.
If the motion fails, no further no-confidence motions can be filed against the same premier within one year, the Constitution stipulates.

Siew's scheduled administrative report to the Legislative Yuan on Friday, and a general interpellation by the Legislative Yuan, were suspended because of the motion, and will not be resumed until after next Tuesday's vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.008 against the greenback Friday in Taipei, closing at 33.055.
The local currency opened at 32.93 and was traded between 32.918 and 33.08.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$394 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DETERMINED TO SETTLE FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Friday issued a report which said that resolving the nation's financial and economic turmoil is the top priority of his administration, and that he retains an open mind to any suggestions which can promote economic stability.

In a briefing to the Legislative Yuan on his administrative policies, Siew said his Cabinet will never yield to proposals which violate economic principles, and will be fully responsible to the public.

His determination to settle the island's financial and economic troubles, such as the sluggish economic development and bearish stock market, can be proved by the fact that in his 52-page written report, 15 pages are devoted to covering his ideas for resolving the economic problems, Siew said.

The report points out that financial crises dogging several domestic enterprises, and the bearishness of the stock and housing markets, should not be attributed solely to the Asian financial meltdown. The key factor, according to Siew, is that Taiwan opened its financial market without setting in place complete regulations on its management.
Under the circumstances, the report said, some enterprises misused their loans or overplayed their hands in the trading of stock and real estate.
Accordingly, the report indicated that "stability" and "reformation" will be the principle guidelines of the premier's economic and financial policy.

According to the report, the short-term measures of encouraging domestic consumption, providing assistance to financially strained companies, and providing low-interest housing loans have been effective.
In the near future, it adds, the Cabinet will take steps to formulate long-term measures to bring about comprehensive economic and financial reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENTAGON REPORT NOTES MOUNTING BEIJING MISSILE THREAT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The US Department of Defense has provided to Congress a report detailing the security situation in the Taiwan Strait in response to a provision of the FY99 Appropriations Bill.
The 27-page, non-confidential report addresses Taiwan's ability to defend against current and emerging capabilities of mainland China's People's Liberation Army (PLA).

The report addresses PLA and Taiwan force planning, strategy, and doctrine; projected PLA and Taiwan capabilities in 2005 in the areas of conventional theater ballistic and cruise missiles; information operations (C2W); air and air/missile defense assets; naval systems; special operations and conventional ground forces; and intangibles such as leadership, training, personnel and morale.

The report points out that during the 20-year period from 1979 to 1999, the security situation in the Taiwan Strait has exhibited simultaneously both significant change in some aspects and remarkable constancy in others.

According to the report, the greatest change has occurred in the political and diplomatic arenas, a reflection of the political changes which have taken place in both Taipei and Beijing, and between Taipei and Beijing.

On the other hand, the report says, despite the modest qualitative improvement in the military forces of both Taiwan and mainland China, the dynamic equilibrium of those forces in the Taiwan Strait has not changed dramatically over the past two decades, except in a few niche areas like mainland China's deployment of short-range ballistic missiles (SRBMs).

However, the report adds that despite anticipated improvements to Taiwan's missile and air defense systems, by 2005, the PLA will possess the capability to attack Taiwan with air and missile strikes which would degrade key military facilities and damage the island's economic infrastructure.
The report further says mainland China will continue to give priority to long-range precision-strike programs.

Similarly, the report says, despite improvements in Taiwan's ability to conduct anti-submarine-warfare (ASW) operations, mainland China will retain the capability to interdict Taiwan's sea lines of communication (SLOCs) and blockade the island's principal maritime ports.

Nevertheless, the report reminds mainland China that should it invade Taiwan, such an operation would require a major commitment of civilian air and maritime transport assets, would be prolonged in duration, and would not be automatically guaranteed to succeed.
"In the end, any of these options would prove to be costly to Beijing -- politically, economically, diplomatically and militarily," the report stresses.

Beyond 2005, the report says, development of a modern military force capable of exerting military influence within the region, achieving deterrence against potential enemies, preserving independence of action in domestic and foreign affairs, protecting its economic resources and maritime areas, and defending the sovereignty of its territory will remain Beijing's national priorities.

By then, the report says, Beijing will strive to create a smaller, more modern, better trained, more professional, and better logistically supported force, with an emphasis on air, naval and missile forces.
On the other side of the Taiwan Strait, the report says: "By 2005, Taipei will possess a qualitative edge over Beijing in terms of significant weapons and equipment.

The report says Taiwan's air force will have over 300 fourth-generation fighters by 2005. "And six French-built Lafayette-class frigates, eight US Knox-class frigates, and eight Perry-class frigates will form the nucleus of Taiwan's naval force."

By 2005, the report says, Taiwan will also possess an advanced air defense network, comprising an airborne early warning (AEW) capability, an automated C2 system, and several modern surface-to-air missile (SAM) systems, which will provide Taiwan with an enhanced defensive capability against both aircraft and missiles. Taiwan has purchase the Modified Air Defense System (MADS), an imporved variant of the Patriot SAM system. (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu) To be continued

DOC.HEADLINE: PENTAGON REPORT (II)
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 25 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Meanwhile, the report says, the mobility and firepower of Taiwan's ground forces will have been improved with the acquisition of additional tanks, armored personnel carriers, self-propelled artillery and attack helicopters.

The report further says that Taiwan's primary security goal beyond 2005 will be to maintain the status quo, while retaining its long-term objective of eventual peaceful reunification with mainland China on terms favorable to Taipei.
"Taiwan will seek to advance its international status, maintain a strong economy, modernize its military forces, and further democratize the island's political system," the report says.

At the same time, the report says, Taiwan will endeavor to expand political, cultural and economic ties with Beijing, thereby reducing tensions with mainland China and lessening the prospects of military conflict in the Taiwan Strait.
The report also points out that Taiwan's military strategy will remain defensive.

"Its success in deterring potential (mainland) Chinese aggression will be dependent on its continued acquisition of modern arms, technology and equipment and its ability to deal with a number of systemic problems -- primarily the recruitment and retention of technically-qualified personnel and the maintenance of an effective logistics system -- lest Taipei once again risk losing its qualitative edge," the report remarks.

As for the current Taiwan Strait situation, the reports says that nearly three years after communist China conducted provocative military exercises opposite Taiwan on the eve of the island's first popular presidential election in 1996, the security situation in the Taiwan Strait remains calm with no threat of imminent hostilities.

"There has been little change in the military balance; Beijing has limited its military activity in the region to routine training; Taipei has reduced the size and scope of its military exercises and played down other activities which Beijing might misconstrue as provocative and destabilizing," the report notes.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC TO STUDY MAINLAND SPOUSES' WORKING RIGHTS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) is to study issues arising from Taiwan people marrying spouses from mainland China, including the spouses' right to work in Taiwan and their right to National Health Insurance coverage.

MAC officials said on Thursday that issues concerning mainland spouses will be evaluated in terms of humanitarianism, the law, government policy, and social concerns. The council is also considering raising quotas for mainland spouses seeking entry to Taiwan.

Both the MAC -- the nation's top agency in charge of Taipei's mainland policy -- and the Ministry of the Interior attach much importance to problems attributed to cross-Taiwan Strait marriages, the officials noted.

According to current regulations, mainland spouses who are not permitted residency here are also prohibited from working in Taiwan while making family visits, but because many of them are forced by their economic condition to work illegally here, "social problems" arise as a result, the officials said.
They also said the issue has been discussed by the Council for Labor Affairs.

According to the fifth item of the 17th article under the Statute Governing Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the People of the Mainland Area, said a council official, people who have been permitted to live in Taiwan are allowed to work in the Taiwan area during their stay in Taiwan.
To date, government statistics show that a total of about 6,000 mainland spouses have been given legal resident status in Taiwan, while there are approximately 22,000 applications pending.

The current annual entry quota stands at 1,800, and although a proposal to raise the figure to 2,400 is under review by the relevant organizations, it will still require legislative approval before implementation, said informed sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE-THIRD OF JUNIOR HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS SMOKE

TEXT.P: More than one-third of Taiwan's junior high school students have tried smoking, according to the results of a recent survey made public on Friday.

According to the poll conducted jointly by the Department of Education of the Taiwan Provincial Government and Fu Jen Catholic University, 352 students, or 32.41 percent of the total polled, admitted they have smoked. Some 12.98 percent of them said they still smoke, while the remaining 19.43 percent said they have quit. The remaining 67.59 percent said they have never smoked.
The random telephone survey interviewed a total of 1,086 junior high school students islandwide, 608 boys and 478 girls.
Of the boys, 360, or nearly 60 percent, said they have never smoked, while 149 confessed they had started but quit, according to the poll. Only 99 said they were still smokers.
Of the girls, a vast majority of 78.2 percent, or 374 of the total, said they have never smoked. Some 62 said they had smoked but quit the habit, while 42 said they were still puffing.
Around 22 percent of the students surveyed said smoking helped relieve stress, the survey found. As high as 81 percent of the student smokers have fathers who also smoke.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, FUTURES CLOSE HIGHER

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) opened low before rallying to close higher Friday, with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, rising 42.99 points to close at 6,318.52, the highest level of the day.
A total of 2.10 billion shares changed hands on turnover of NT$61.94 billion (US$1.87 billion), against the NT$94.70 billion traded in the previous session.
Gainers outnumbered losers 238 to 158, with 98 stocks unchanged.
The eight major stock categories closed mixed.

Foodstuff stocks posted the largest gains, rising 1.6 percent. Other categories that closed higher were electrical stocks, up 1.4 percent; plastics and chemical shares, 0.6 percent; textile shares, 0.3 percent; and cement shares, 0.2 percent.
Those categories that closed lower were construction issues, down 0.3 percent; and pulp and paper issues, 0.1 percent.
Financial issues closed flat.
The over-the-counter market, however, suffered a setback with the market's index closing at 155.99, down 0.52 point over the previous session's close on turnover of NT$3.15 billion.
Taiwan stock index futures also ended the day higher.

Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for March were up 89 points to close at 6,469, with 4,658 contract transactions. Futures for April were up 75 points to close at 6,500, with 194 contract transactions. June futures moved up 53 points to 6,519, with four contract transactions. No contract transactions were recorded for September and December futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S VETO ON UNPREDEP MANDATE AN INSULT TO UN: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday that mainland China's veto on a proposed extension of the UN peacekeeping mission in Macedonia is an outright insult to the United Nations.

The ministry made the remarks in a written statement issued after mainland China vetoed a UN draft resolution which had proposed a further six-month extension of the UN Preventive Deployment Force, known as UNPREDEP, in Macedonia during a UN Security Council (UNSC) session on Thursday.
The ministry said Beijing has totally ignored the world's hope for peace in the Balkan region.

"Its veto to obstruct the renewal of mandate of the UNPREDEP in Macedonia not only undermines the UN's long-term effort and achievement in promoting peace in this region but also manifests Beijing's abuse of its veto rights and its hegemonic mentality against world peace," the ministry said in the press statement, adding: "Beijing's action is an outright insult to the UN and detrimental to the prospects of world peace."
The ministry went on to say that the establishment of diplomatic ties between the Republic of China and Macedonia is the behavior of two sovereign nations exercising their diplomatic rights.

"Such an action is not aimed at any third nation and should not be subject to interference by other nations," the ministry said. "Beijing's claim that our efforts in expanding the ROC's role in the international community 'undermines' world peace, implying that Macedonia's establishing official ties with us deserves punishment is absolutely not acceptable to us."
The ministry further said Beijing's claim is bound to be rejected by an overwhelming majority of nations in the world.

Meanwhile, the ministry said, it recognizes the efforts of the UN, the European Security Council, NATO, the European Union and other international organizations to maintain peace and stability in the Balkan region.

"We are convinced that the ultimate means of resolving the Balkan disputes lies in the establishment of a democratic system and a prosperous economy," the ministry said, adding that the ROC will continue to share its experience and resources in democratic reform and economic development with Macedonia.
The ministry said it believes cooperation between the ROC and Macedonia will directly and fundamentally contribute to promoting peace and stability in Macedonia and the Balkan region.
"This cooperation coincides with the aim of the peacekeeping force in Macedonia sent by the UN and NATO to eradicate the scourges of war," the ministry said.

It urged Beijing to view its diplomatic ties with Macedonia and the mandate of the UNPREDEP with reason and objectivity and adjust position by refraining from actions that counter the efforts of other nations in the world to maintain peace in the Balkan region.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE TO BE PRINTED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The mass-circulation English-language International Herald Tribune will start being printed in Taiwan on March 1, the Government Information Office (GIO) announced on Friday.
The move will enable local readers to obtain the paper in the morning, rather than having to wait for editions to be delivered from Hong Kong via airmail.

At a press conference called by the GIO to announce the event, GIO Director-General Chen Chien-jen welcomed the paper's decision to choose Taiwan as its 18th printing location in the world, and said he looked forward to an expansion of Taiwan's English-paper readership kept abreast of the latest world news.

The International Herald Tribune is the second renowned international newspaper to choose Taiwan as one of its global printing locations. The Hong Kong-based Asian Wall Street Journal began printing in Taiwan last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE GOVERNMENT TO MONITOR DISTRIBUTION OF MARCOS SPOILS

TEXT.P: The Philippine government will closely monitor the distribution of US$150 million in Marcos wealth to human rights victims to make sure that each claimant gets his or her share, a Philippine official said on Friday.

Executive Secretary Ronaldo Zamora said in a radio interview that the agreement forged between the government, the human rights victims, and the Marcos family will be submitted to President Joseph Estrada for approval, and eventually to the United States court which will oversee the distribution of compensation.
Zamora said the money will be divided according to a formula in which compensation will be based on the gravity of atrocities suffered by the claimant.
Zamora said the money will go to 10,000 human rights victims who won a class-action suit before a Honolulu court against the Marcos estate for torture, summary execution and disappearances.
He stressed that the government wants the agreement to be very transparent, noting that the accord was forged not just by the government and the Marcoses, but by the human rights victims as well.

DOC.HEADLINE: RISING TAIWAN NATIONALISM VERSUS MAINLAND CHINESE PAN-NATIONALISM

TEXT.P: The rise of Taiwan nationalism, helped by the democratization process, is challenging mainland China's pan-nationalism and putting China's reunification at risk, a China expert said on Friday.

In a paper delivered at the 1999 Taiwan Update Conference here, Associate Professor Baogang He of the Tasmanian University said the Chinese pan-nationalists play up the fact that most people in Taiwan are Han Chinese, and that mainland China and Taiwan share a Confucian legacy.

He said the pan-nationalist identity "constitutes a source of reunification cause. However, the rise of Taiwan nationalism, assisted by the democratization process, challenges the basic assumptions of Chinese pan-nationalism."

He said Taiwan and mainland China face different forms of the national identity question. "Taiwan has only the straightforward question of independence, while China confronts not only secession movements within the mainland, it also faces the question of reunification with Taiwan.
"China therefore has a more complex national identity than Taiwan has," he said.
He said an independent Taiwan would provide political leverage to the separatists of Tibet and Xingjiang in the eyes of Beijing.
"From the standpoint of Beijing, preventing Taiwan's independence and achieving reunification is one key to containing other secessionist movements in China," he said.

He noted that the rise of Taiwan nationalism has been associated with the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, which, he said, has invented and promoted Taiwan's identity as distinct from Chinese identity.
But he also said Taiwan nationalism had its birth following the ouster of Taiwan from the United Nations, the reduction of diplomatic ties with other nations, and the isolation by Beijing.

Mainland China wants to downgrade Taiwan by governing it under the "one country, two systems" formula used in Hong Kong, but Taipei insists it is a separate political entity and should be treated on an equal footing with Beijing. Taiwan also insists that reunification can only come about when the mainland embraces democracy under freedom and equitable distribution of wealth.
"The solution to the problem is very, very difficult and will take years or possibly decades to solve," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC APPRECIATES US CONCERN ABOUT TAIWAN'S SECURITY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China appreciates US concern about peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu said on Friday.
Wu made the statement in response to reports that the US Department of Defense has provided to Congress a 27-page report detailing the security situation in the Taiwan Strait.

The Pentagon report says mainland China will possess the capability to attack Taiwan with air and missile strikes which would degrade the island's key military facilities and damage its economic infrastructure.

Nevertheless, the report also reminds Beijing that should it invade Taiwan, such an operation would require a major commitment of civilian air and maritime transport assets, would be prolonged in duration, and would not be automatically guaranteed to succeed.
Responding to the Pentagon report, Wu said the ROC has consistently maintained close contact with the United States concerning peace and security in the Taiwan Strait.

Wu said US views on Taiwan Strait security issues have not only been expressed in this Pentagon report but also divulged in statements released by the White House, the Department of State and the Pentagon in recent years.

"Statements or comments made by senior White House, Pentagon and State Department officials in the past few years fully indicate that US authorities have taken note of mainland China's military threat to Taiwan," Wu said, adding that the US government has repeatedly reaffirmed its commitment to providing Taiwan with adequate defensive arms and military equipment in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act and keeping close monitoring and constant assessment of military balance in the Taiwan Strait.
Wu went on to say that the head of the US Central Intelligence Agency has expressed similar views on the Taiwan Strait security issues during a recent congressional hearing.
"We recognize the US concern about the security situation in the Taiwan Strait," Wu said.

Noting that the ROC has insisted that cross-strait issues be resolved strictly by peaceful means, Wu said the ROC is hopeful that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will continue peaceful dialogue to resolve their disputes or differences.
"We believe this stance complies with basic US position on the Taiwan Strait issues," Wu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO THREAT OF IMMINENT HOSTILITIES IN TAIWAN STRAITS: REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 26 (CNA) (By Bear Lee and Herman Pan)

TEXT.P: Nearly three years after Beijing's provocative military exercises caused unease in Taiwan the security situation in the Taiwan Straits remains calm with no threat of imminent hostilities, according to a report prepared by the US Defense Department.

The report, which was forwarded to the US Congress in both classified and unclassified forms on Thursday, was prepared in response to a provision inserted to the FY Defense Appropriation Act at the request of Senator Frank H. Murkowski (R-Alaska).

The report gives an analysis of the military balance between Taiwan and mainland China and addresses Taiwan's ability to defend against current and emerging capabilities of the People's Liberalization Army (PLA).

The report said that Taiwan currently has, and will continue to have, the more modernized air force and more advanced navy, but that mainland China's quantitative advantage in the number of its military personnel, vessels, submarines and fighters will ensure its capability to blockade the island.
Moreover, Beijing is likely to gain air superiority over Taiwan in the future under its military buildup program which has been underway the past two decades.
The report said that Beijing's continuous efforts to develop ballistic missies and cruise missiles will enable it to posses overwhelming superiority over Taiwan by 2005.
The reports emphasized that missiles deployed in southeastern and southern parts of the Chinese mainland pose an especially serious threat to Taiwan.
Senators from both the Democratic and Republican parties expressed their concerns over the report's findings.
"I am especially troubled by the findings that Taiwan's most significant vulnerability is its limited capacity to defend against the growing arsenal of Chinese ballistic missles," Sen Murkowski said.

"This report provides important new information that the Congress should consider in determining the quality and quantity of defense articles and services it provides to Taiwan in the coming years," he added.

"It is important that Congress engage in a serious analysis of the findings of these reports, especially as the findings relate to the effect of the modernization of the People's Republic of China's military on Taiwan's deterrent forces and on the need for cooperation on security issues between the US government and the government of the Republic of China on Taiwan," the senator said.
He said that based on the report, the US should reevaluate its priorities and reaffirm its commitment to Taiwan and its people.
Sen. Robert G. Torricelli (D-N. J.) said that Beijing's reluctance to renounce using force against Taiwan poses a continuous threat to regional security.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERT SEES GROWING PAINS IN TAIWAN DEMOCRATIZATION

TEXT.P: The defeat of former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian and setbacks of other minority party candidates in the Dec. 5 mayoral and parliamentary elections in Taiwan will help prolong the growing pains of the island's democratization, said an analyst on Friday.

Presenting his paper at the 1999 Taiwan update conference here on Friday, Associate Professor C.L. Chiou of the University of Queensland said that many are now pondering the difficulties of consolidating democracy in Taiwan after Chen's mayoral defeat and the poor performance of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the December election.
The ruling Kuomintang was the biggest winner, not only in the Taipei race but also in the legislature, where it now holds a comfortable majority.
According to Chiou, the way in which the KMT used traditional politics to win the elections will "maintain the continuous existence and effectiveness of traditional political culture and behavior."
He said the DPP's efforts to replace the KMT as the ruling party in order to end the dominant party system and democratize Taiwan's political culture, now seem further away.

He went on: "The election results show that the growth momentum of the DPP has been stopped, the New Party and the other opposition parties have become rather inconsequential in Taiwan democracy, and the steady erosion of the KMT ... has been arrested."

He noted that the way in which KMT candidate Ma Ying-jeou won the Taipei mayorship should cause particular concern, as he won on an "ethnic line." He pointed out that most "mainlanders," (referring to those who came to Taiwan following the 1949 defeat of Nationalist forces by the communists) who make up 30 percent of Taipei's population, cast their votes for Ma, including most New Party supporters.
"This is traditional ethnic, not modern party, politics in action," he said.
He noted that traditional socio-cultural elements are still alive in Taiwan politics, but that there is little likelihood of Taiwan's return to authoritarian rule in the foreseeable future.

However, he went on, if these socio-cultural elements -- money and gangster politics, factionalism, paternalism, nepotism, corruption and charismatic leadership -- which are still all-pervasive in Taiwan politics, are allowed to continue to dictate Taiwan's political agenda and distort Taiwan's democratic institutions, democratization will have a long and bumpy road ahead.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIN YUAN GROUP HAS LARGEST ASSETS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: The Lin Yuan Group was Taiwan's largest business conglomerate in 1997, with total assets worth NT$894.5 billion (about US$27 billion), according to the results of a survey made public on Friday.

Lin Yuan, which owns Cathay Life Insurance Co., Ltd., Taiwan's largest life insurance company, also scored the number one spot in the list of pre-tax profits in 1997, with figure hitting NT$24.2 billion, according to the survey conducted among Taiwan's 141 business conglomerates by the China Credit Information Service Ltd.
The Tatung Group, the champion concern registering the highest level of pre-tax profits in 1996, fell to 16th place in 1997, the survey indicated.

The poll also found that large business conglomerates are playing an increasingly important role in the Taiwan economy, as business incomes made by the 141 business groups in 1997 totaled more than NT$4 trillion, accounting for 45.6 percent of the island's overall gross national product in 1997.

Although affiliates belonging to the 141 largest business groups comprised just 1 percent of Taiwan's total firms, the survey pointed out that they contributed nearly 20 percent to the island's overall business revenues in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMED FORCES ARE WELL AWARE OF BEIJING'S MILITARY DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's armed forces are fully aware of Beijing's military building-up, according to Tang Yiau-min, the country's new chief of general staff.

Tang made the remarks, on Friday, when asked to respond to an assessment of the US Defense Department that Beijing will have an overwhelming military advantage over Taiwan with the deployment of its newly-developed missiles by the end of 2005.

The assessment was included in a report presented by the US Defense Department to the Congress on the military strength of both Taiwan and mainland China at a time when Congress is considering inviting Taiwan to join the US theater missile defense system. The system would supposedly shield the island from missile attacks.
Contents of the report were made public in Washington on Thursday.

Hosting a dinner in Taipei for a group of journalists, Tang said he couldn't go into details, but he was confident that the armed forces under his command have the capability, and then some, to defend the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENTAGON REPORT NOTES LOW MORALE PROBLEMS IN TAIWAN MILITARY

TEXT.P: The US Department of Defense, in a report on the security situation in the Taiwan Strait, has given higher evaluation of the quality of Taiwan's military servicemen than its mainland Chinese counterparts.

Nevertheless, the Pentagon report, which was sent to the US Congress earlier this week, pointed out some problems facing Taiwan's armed forces, including poor morale among the enlisted ranks and difficulties in retaining competent, educated service members in the face of stiff private sector competition.
The 27-page, non-confidential report said Taiwan's military leadership generally is competent and capable.

"Taiwan officers of all services and ranks exhibit a relatively high degree of professionalism. They generally are well educated, operationally proficient, and technically sophisticated -- especially when contrasted with their PLA (People's Liberation Army) counterparts -- and pro-US in their outlook," the report said.
However, the report added that Taiwan's officer corps functions within a culture that values caution over innovation and initiative.
The Taiwan military also faces an ongoing challenge in retaining qualified junior officers as employment opportunities in the civilian sector remain enticing, the report said.

It went on to say that morale, especially among the enlisted ranks, is generally assessed as poor, amidst efforts to retain competent, educated service members in the face of stiff private sector competition.
According to the report, continued personnel shortages stemming from low retention rates -- especially among non-commissioned officers -- will remain a serious problem affecting morale.

Taiwan's armed forces are also hampered by systemic problems of poor, antiquated management and a traditional military culture with very rigid command structures which discourages low-level risk-taking, decision-making, and innovation, the report said, adding that the Taiwan Army especially is facing morale problems stemming from the ongoing restructuring and downsizing.

The report further said President Lee Teng-hui strongly supports the promotion of native Taiwanese officers to senior military positions. "This trend will continue and probably will have a positive effect on the morale and cohesion of the lower ranks of the armed forces, who themselves are overwhelmingly native Taiwanese." (by Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S UNEMPLOYMENT RATE DETERIORATED IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: Although the government claims the island's economy is turning the corner, newly-released statistics show the unemployed population increased in January.

Data compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) indicated that there were 265,000 jobless workers in January, translating into an unemployment rate of 2.67 percent or a record high for any January.
Among the jobless, 89,000 were laid off due to plant closure or slack business which is the second highest one-month total, only behind the 90,000 of December.
The broad-scaled jobless rate jumped to 4.14 percent from 3.38 January of 1998, by taking into account 139,000 "disappointed labors" or those who didn't pursue new jobs although they intended to.
According to the statistics, the unemployed have been out of work for an average of 24 months, and 13,000 were first-time job seekers.

Putting a brave face on the worsening employment figures, the DGBAS said in an accompanying analysis that Taiwan's jobless rate is still the best in Southeast Asia, compared to 7.9 percent in South Korea, 5.8 percent in Hong Kong, 4.5 percent in Singapore and 4.3 percent in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-MAINLAND CHINA TWO-WAY TRADE DECLINES

TEXT.P: Trade between Taiwan and mainland China plunged 7.9 percent to US$22.51 billion in 1998, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Friday.
The figure comprised 10.5 percent of Taiwan's foreign trade.

A breakdown of the statistics shows that Taiwan exported US$18.4 billion worth of goods to mainland China, or 10.3 percent less than the previous year. Exports to the mainland were responsible for 16.6 percent of Taiwan's total exports.
Data released by mainland China's customs, however, shows that imports from Taiwan grew by 1.1 percent in the same period.

An analysis made by the Board of Foreign Trade under the MOEA attributed reduced mainland-bound exports to the Asian financial crisis which led to a slowdown of Beijing's exports and a weakened demand for raw materials, as well as, equipment from Taiwan.

The strong competitiveness posed by goods and materials from other Southeast Asian countries and Beijing's crackdown on smuggling, tax evasion and stricter foreign exchange regulations also contributed to the slowdown.

On the other hand, Taiwan imported US$4.11 billion worth of goods from mainalnd China in 1998, accounting for 3.9 percent of the island's total imports, an increase of 5 percent over the previous year.

The reasons behind the rise in imports were still booming foreign orders for Taiwan's information and telecommunication products as well as the expansion of the island's electrical power stations and electronic industries, all of which rely on raw materials from mainland China, according to the analysis.
As a result, even though Taiwan still enjoyed a trade surplus of US$14.29 billion with mainland China, the figure is 13.9 percent lower than one year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: EARLY DEMISE OF CHINESE COMMUNIST REGIME URGED BY DISSIDENT

TEXT.P: All anti-Beijing forces at home and abroad should unite for the purpose of overthrowing the oppressive communist regime in Beijing, mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng was quoted as saying recently in Munich, Germany.

A spokesman for the World Uygur News Network in Ankara told the CNA Friday that Wei made the remarks on Feb. 22 in Munich, where the leading mainland Chinese dissident promoted the sales of his new book.
Wei was quoted as saying that there are anti-Beijing forces in various parts of mainland China, especially in Xinjiang, where the democratic movement is deeply rooted.

The anti-Beijing forces in Xinjiang, Tibet, Inner Mongolia, and other places should unite for the early demise of the oppressive communist regime in Beijing, Wei said, adding that democracy can prevail on the Chinese mainland only after the demise of the communist regime.
Wei also expressed the hope that people in the free world would give a helping hand to Xinjiang people in their armed struggle for self-determination, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT BUDGET FOR NEW FISCAL YEAR TOPS NT$2 TRILLION

TEXT.P: The central government budget for fiscal 2000 will total approximately NT$2.25 trillion (US$59 billion), according to the budget proposal submitted to the Legislative Yuan on Friday.
The figure, representing a decrease of 7.2 percent from 1999, will likely cause a squeezing of administrative affairs.

The Executive Yuan outlined three objectives -- government restructuring, economic development and upgrading, and social rebuilding -- as the central government's major policy goals for the next fiscal year. At the same time, other major missions include increased environmental protection, strengthened national security, increased diplomatic offensives, educational reforms and a boost for aborigines and minority groups.

On the economic front, some NT$353 billion is earmarked for public construction and development projects. About NT$147 billion is allocated for national defense purposes, while NT$44 billion is budgeted for diplomatic missions, with a similar level put aside for educational spending.
More than NT$375 billion is allocated for a social rebuilding campaign, of which NT$52.7 billion will go to projects by the Interior Ministry to improve public security and social order.
According to the Executive Yuan, personnel spending for fiscal 2000 will top NT$676.9 billion, accounting for approximately 30 percent of the its overall budget of fiscal 2000.

The Executive Yuan admitted the ratio is high, only a slight 0.9 percent fall from the previous year, but promised it will do its best to reduce spending on personnel affairs in order to create a "small, beautiful but efficient" administration.

The number of government officials, including those in the central government and in the already downsized provincial government, is 172,662 at present, a drop of more than 3,500 people from a year ago, according to the Executive Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: US REPORT BLASTS MAINLAND CHINA'S HUMAN RIGHTS RECORD

TEXT.P: The United States said on Friday that mainland China's human rights record "deteriorated sharply" late last year and that Beijing "continued to commit widespread and well-documented human rights abuses".

In its annual human rights report, the State Department said that, during Beijing's latest crackdown against organized political opposition, dozens of political activists were detained for trying to register a political party.
"Three leaders were given harsh sentences in closed trials that flagrantly violated due process," the report added.

These developments overshadowed an earlier loosening of restrictions on political debate and Beijing's signature last October of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, according to the report.

Human rights abuses in mainland China during the past year included extrajudicial killings, torture and mistreatment of prisoners, forced confessions, arbitrary arrest and detention, lengthy incommunicado detention and denial of due process.

In 1998, according to the report, the Communist government infringed on citizens' private rights, continued restrictions on the freedom of speech and of the press with the infringements tightening towards the end of the year.
Other abuses included severe restriction on freedom of assembly, and continued restriction on freedom of association, religion and movement, etc.
On Taiwan, the 1998 Human Rights Report said that with the 1996 direct presidential election, Taiwan "completed its transition to an open, democratic system".

Problems remain, however, and these include corruption and political influence within the judiciary, as well as occasional instances of police abuse of detainees, physical abuse of military inductees and prison overcrowding.

Other negatives include some restrictions on freedom of association, discrimination and violence against women, child prostitution, child abuse, restrictions on workers' freedom of association and on their ability to strike.
The report noted Taiwan authorities have in the past resorted occasionally to libel laws, apparently to deter criticism of senior leaders, although in 1998, no such cases were reported.

DOC.TEXT:
