DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA SECOND VICE PRESIDENT TO ARRIVE FOR 4-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: Panamanian Second Vice President Felipe Virzi and an entourage of eight will arrive in Taipei on Sunday for a four-day visit.
During their visit, they will call on President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan, Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu, and other ROC government officials.
They will also visit several cultural and economic establishments before their scheduled departure on March 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Feb. 27, or the 12th day of the first month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1700: William Dampier, the English buccaneer and navigator who described his circumnavigation of the Globe in "A New Voyage Round the World," discovers Southwest Pacific island of New Britain while exploring the South Seas.
1782: The British Parliament votes to abandon the American War of Independence.
1844: The Dominican Republic gains its independence from Haiti.
1869: The US Congress passes the 15th Amendment to the US Constitution enshrining the rights of freed slaves as full US citizens.
1879: Constantin Fahlberg, a chemist at Johns Hopkins University, announces the discovery of saccharine, a synthetic sweetener.
1902: John Steinbeck, the Nobel Prize-winning American author whose works include "The Grapes of Wrath," and "East of Eden," is born.
1910: Dr. Sun Yat-sen sets up a US headquarters in San Francisco after organizing the Revolution Alliance in Tokyo in 1905 to sponsor an entire network of revolutionaries inside China.
1922: Dr. Sun Yat-sen issues a proclamation at a harangue-the-troops ceremony in Kuilin, Kwangsi Province, before a military expedition northward to eradicate various feuding warlords in central and northern China.
1932: British physicist Sir James Chadwick discovers the neutron, a subatomic particle which is used by scientists to make various elements radioactive.
1932: Elizabeth Taylor, the British-born American actress who won an Academy Award for "Butterfield 8," and "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" is born.
1942: Japanese forces sink three Allied destroyers and a cruiser in the first phase of the Battle of the Java Sea.
1948: The Czechoslovakian Communist Party seizes power in Prague with communists in all the top jobs in the new Cabinet.
1952: The United Nations convenes its first session in its new permanent headquarters in New York.
1962: Two mutinous Republic of Vietnam Air Force planes bomb the presidential office in Saigon. President Ngo Dinh Diem escapes unscathed.
1981: Beijing strongly protests against the Dutch government's decision to sell two submarines to the Republic of China, with both sides recalling their respective envoys.
1981: The Tempo Mas, an Indonesian ferry, catches fire and sinks off the island of Kalimantan, killing 431 aboard.
1990: Juan Ponce Enrile, former defense minister of the Philippines, is nabbed for supporting the 1989 coup attempt against Corazon Aquino.
1991: The Gulf War ends, with Saudi and Kuwaiti forces regaining control of Kuwait City as the Iraqi army flees northward.
1993: Taiwan Provincial Governor Lien Chan succeeds Hau Pei-tsun as premier of the ROC following his confirmation by the Legislative Yuan.
Confucius lesson of the day: "If you speak to a man in the strict words of the law, he will probably agree with you; but the important point is that he should so profit by what you say to him as to change his conduct. If you speak to a man in parables, he will probably be pleased with your story; but the important point is that he should apply the moral to himself."

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME US PRODUCE MAY HAVE UNSAFE LEVELS OF PESTICIDE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 26 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan consumers should take note of the fact that some US-originating fruits and vegetables may have unsafe levels of residual pesticide, since the island is a major importer of US produce.

According to a recent report published by the Consumers Union of the United States, although virtually all the 27,000 fruit and vegetable samples tested were safe to eat, with pesticide levels within legal limits, some products had such high levels of toxic residue that they could be dangerous for children.

Seven of the fruits and vegetables sampled -- apples, grapes, green beans, peaches, pears, spinach and winter squash -- had up to several hundred times higher toxicity than other foods analyzed, the report said.

In the largest-ever analysis of US government data on pesticide levels in domestic and imported produce, the Consumers Union said when the residue indices showed under 20, the toxic threat was considered "negligible," while indices in excess of 100 were considered "worthy of concern."
The report showed that squash had indices as high as 1,706, compared with apples (550), pears (435), spinach (349), grapes (228), and green beans (222).

It also showed that the above-mentioned seven items, along with tomatoes, had higher levels of toxic residues than produce from other countries, with American peaches having the highest levels of all at 4,848, about 11 times higher than those from Chile.

According to the US Department of Agriculture, Taiwan is currently the sixth-largest overseas market for American agricultural products. The island's imports of fresh fruit alone was valued at US$155 million in 1998, with apples, grapes, peaches and pears topping the list.

Edward Groth, Consumers Union director of technical policy and public service, said the analysis reveals that for a child, even one serving of some fruits and vegetables would exceed safe daily limits for certain pesticides. The findings were particularly pertinent to children because they eat more produce per pound of body weight than adults.

He said, however, that people should not be afraid to feed their kids fruit and vegetables because of the report. "We only want this information to enable them to make the best choices" of fresh produce, he added.
The Consumers Union, meanwhile, advised parents to avoid feeding their children produce with high levels of toxic residue, and to always peel apples, pears and peaches before serving.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI LANTERN FESTIVAL KICKS OFF SATURDAY EVENING

TEXT.P: The 1999 Taipei Lantern Festival, the city's 10th, is scheduled to kick off on Saturday evening with an exhibition of nearly 600 different lantern designs and a gathering of more than 10,000 lantern-bearers in front of the Presidential Office.
The spectacular sea of lanterns and the huge lantern parade together are expected to earn Taipei a spot in the Guinness Book of World Records, according to the sponsors.

President Lee Teng-hui is expected to light the main lanterns at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall plaza at 7 p.m. to define the theme of this year's lantern festival -- ethnic harmony, equal emphasis on the new and the old, public participation, and the next millennium.

The lantern festival, which does not officially begin until March 2, is also kicking off a month-long "Invitation to Spring" series of activities in the capital, including a concert in memory of the Feb. 28 Incident on Saturday night, and a gala party marking Lantern Festival Day, which falls on March 2 this year, or the 15th day of the first month of the lunar calendar.
Other programs to be hosted by the Taipei City Government in the following month include a concert to commemorate Arbor Day on March 12, and a party to mark Youth Day on March 27, sources said.

The Taipei Lantern Festival attracts more than 2 million visitors every year. For 1999, the Year of the Rabbit in the Chinese zodiac, more than 550 lanterns are being entered in an annual competition, while 20 mammoth lanterns financed by foreign diplomatic and tourism-promotion missions and five-star hotels will also be on display beginning Saturday evening, according to the Tourism Bureau, one of the sponsors of the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO ATTEND 2ND ASIA-PACIFIC MAYORAL SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will lead a 30-member delegation to Queensland's state capital of Brisbane, Australia, to attend the second Asia-Pacific Mayoral Summit, scheduled to be held on March 1-3.
Representatives of more than 50 Asia-Pacific cities are expected to attend the summit.
This will be the first time Ma will have attended an international meeting in his capacity as mayor of Taiwan's largest city.
In addition to Taipei City Government officials, members of the delegation will also include 22 senior commercial and industrial executives.

During his four-day visit to Australia, Ma will attend the first day of the Asia-Pacific Mayoral Summit, visit a university in Queensland, visit Taipei's sister city of Gold Coast just south of Brisbane, and visit the construction site of the Olympic Games in Sydney.

Ma's delegation is scheduled to depart Australia for Hong Kong on March 4, where delegation members will attend the inaugural ceremony of Taipei Bank's Hong Kong representative office and visit some Hong Kong municipal infrastructure projects on March 5.
After presiding over a reception for the inauguration of the Taipei City Government-owned bank, Ma is scheduled to return to Taipei on the evening of March 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER LOSING PUBLIC SUPPORT: SURVEY

TEXT.P: The no-confidence motion against Premier Vincent Siew in the legislature has jolted the public's trust in his administrative ability, according to the results of a recent survey conducted by the United Daily News (UDN).

The survey results, published in the mass-circulation newspaper's Saturday edition, show that 53 percent of 951 Taiwan citizens polled by telephone on Friday support Siew as premier, down 15 percentage points from a similar UDN survey conducted in August 1997, when Siew was first appointed to the post.
Fifty-two percent of those surveyed on Friday said Siew possesses sound judgment while dealing with influential policy issues, while 18 percent said the premier is ineffectual in this capacity.
Only 27 percent said they regard Siew as resolute in making decisions, while 42 percent criticized the government leader for often appearing hesitant and wavering.

The views on Siew's ability to sense public opinion saw a bipolar trend, with 33 percent saying Siew has a sharp sense of public opinion, and 33 percent responding that Siew has failed to note public outcry for a better living environment.
Meanwhile, 43 percent of those surveyed said they feel Siew is a responsible premier, while 27 percent had the opposite opinion.

The survey also shows that Siew's public support has dropped to 58 percent since legislators from two leading opposition parties on Friday launched the no-confidence motion against him. Siew's public support had been maintained at 61 percent prior to the move.
The telephone survey had a margin of error of 3.2 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUEBEC JUDGE JAILED FOR MONEY LAUNDERING

TEXT.P: A Quebec judge who was convicted last month of laundering C$1.7 million from a drug dealer, was sentenced on Friday to three years in prison.
Lawyers for Justice Robert Flahiff of Quebec Superior Court argued against prison time, saying his life would be in danger from criminal gangs sentenced by Flahiff.
The case goes back to when Flahiff was a practicing lawyer in the late 1980s and involves his relationship with a former client for whom he was accused of laundering money.
It is the first time in Canadian history that a federally appointed judge has been convicted of money laundering charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS WATCH CALLS FOR ACTION AGAINST MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: US Rep. Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) and Human Rights Watch on Friday challenged the Clinton administration to act on its acknowledgment of the mainland Chinese government's terrible human rights record.

Pelosi said in a brief statement that "The Chinese government has once again embarked on a severe crackdown on the brave supporters of freedom and liberty in China. The regime will not tolerate any attempt to question the authority of the Communist Party."
"The State Department Human Rights Report documents that reality. The question is whether this administration will adjust its policy to reflect its report," noted Pelosi.

She added that "If this hard-hitting report is to mean anything, the administration must now act on its words. It can start by immediately announcing it will pursue a resolution condemning China's human rights practices at the UN Human Rights Commission in Geneva."
Meanwhile, the New York-based Human Rights Watch said that the Clinton administration should do more to put its annual human rights report into practice.

"We're glad that the State Department made a special effort on human rights today," said Kenneth Roth, executive director of the largest human rights organization in the United States. "But what is the Clinton administration doing about human rights the other 364 days of the year? It's all very well to report that a country is abusing human rights. But the US government then ought to act on that information."

Roth urged the US government to use diplomatic, political and economic means to put stronger pressure on countries such as mainland China that abuse human rights. He also welcomed a unanimous Senate vote on Thursday calling on the Clinton administration to sponsor a resolution condemning mainland China's human rights practices at the upcoming session of the UN Human Rights Commission in Geneva.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON: BEIJING CANNOT BUY STABILITY AT EXPENSE OF FREEDOM

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton said on Friday that he believes mainland China will have to realize that in today's world, a country as full of potential as mainland China "simply cannot purchase stability at the expense of freedom."

In a foreign policy address delivered in San Francisco, Clinton noted that beyond economics, beyond the transformation of Russia and mainland China, beyond even many of America's security concerns, "we also have to recognize that we can have no greater purpose than to support the right of other people to live in freedom and shape their own destiny. If that right could be universally exercised, virtually every goal I have outlined today would be advanced."

He continued: "We have to keep standing by those who risk their own freedom to win it for others," adding the United States must make concentrated efforts to help Indonesia and Nigeria achieve the potential transition to democracy. But he failed to mention mainland China, which was criticized for its human rights practices in the annual human rights report published by the State Department on Friday.

Clinton said the first challenge for the United States in the 21st century is to build a more peaceful world, while the second challenge is to bring Russia and mainland China into the international system as open, prosperous and stable nations, because "the way both countries develop in the coming century will have a lot to do with the future of our planet."

The question mainland China faces is how best to assure its stability and progress. In Clinton's judgment, only a path of openness and engagement can really answer the challenges mainland China faces.

Mainland China has made incredible progress in lifting people out of poverty and building a new economy, but now its rate of economic growth is declining just as it is needed to create jobs for a growing and increasingly more mobile population. Most of mainland China's economy is still stifled by state control. "We can see in China the kinds of problems a society faces when it is moving away from the rule of fear but is not yet rooted in the rule of law," Clinton said.

The president claimed that mainland China's leaders know that more economic reform is needed, and that they know reform will cause more unemployment and unrest. At the same time and, perhaps for those reasons, they remain unwilling to open up their political system to give people a peaceful outlet for dissent, he said.

A third challenge is to build a future in which people are safe from dangers from proliferation, terrorism, drugs and the multiple catastrophes that could arise from climatic change. "In our case, that means recognizing that the most likely future threat to our existence is not a strategic nuclear strike by Russia or China, but the use of weapons of mass destruction by an outlaw nation or a terrorist group," said Clinton.
He added: "We are using all the means at our disposal to deny terrorists safe havens, weapons and funds. Even if it takes years, terrorists must know there is no place to hide."

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE EXPERT DOUBTS BEIJING'S ABILITY TO TAKE TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Feb. 27 (CNA) (By F.M. Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: While there is today only a slight difference in the air power of Taiwan and mainland China, Taiwan will likely gain an advantage over the next five years as it makes enhancements to its F-16 and Mirage fighters, a Japanese military strategist said on Saturday.
Professor Shigeo Hiramatsu of Kyorin University made the remarks in response to a recent report by the US Defense Department on the security situation in the Taiwan Strait.

The Pentagon report predicts that by 2005 mainland China's People's Liberation Army (PLA) will possess the ability to attack Taiwan with air and missile strikes that would degrade key military facilities and damage the island's economic infrastructure.
Hiramatsu, however, said in an article carried in Saturday's Yomiuri Shimbun that Beijing's present missile capabilities already give mainland China virtual superiority over Taiwan.
Beijing's current missile systems are sufficient to intimidate Taiwan, Hiramatsu said, adding that Beijing could do so merely by calling attention to its arsenal of M9 missiles.
But military action by the mainland against Taiwan would likely result in US intervention, he said, adding that he doubts the PLA would be able to repel the US military.

Hiramatsu said Taiwan and mainland China are at present about equal in terms of air power. In five years, however, after further enhancements are made to Taiwan's F-16 and Mirage fighters, it will have an edge over mainland China, he said.
He said it is unlikely that the PLA will launch a naval blockade and conduct an amphibious invasion of Taiwan in the coming years.

The 27-page unclassified US Defense Department report indicated that by 2005 Beijing would have the ability to implement a naval blockade and conduct an amphibious invasion of Taiwan. It would also have an advantage over Taiwan in terms of air power and information control by 2005, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WOMAN'S DEATH DURING CAR CHASE LEADS TO PUBLIC OUTCRY
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Feb. 26 (CNA) (By Chu Lu-sheng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A public call for restraint by San Diego's police force has grown louder after police officers killed a Taiwan woman earlier this month while engaged in a car chase.

A memorial service was held on Friday for Meng Yi-chiung, who was hit by a police car as she attempted to cross the street on Feb. 19. She was rushed to the hospital after the accident, but died later.
Meng worked at the San Diego office of Taiwan-based Acer.
Meng's husband, Hung Yi-ling, who also works for Acer, said he hopes his wife's death will result in improvements in the driving procedures followed by US law enforcement authorities.
The couple had a 4-year-old daughter.
Meng's parents, sisters and brothers flew from Taiwan to the United States for the memorial service, which was also attended by representatives of the San Diego police.

During the service, San Diego's "Citizen Against Speeding Cops in Traffic" launched a protest in downtown San Diego. The group called for legislation that would curtail for the sake of public safety the freedoms given to police officers.

Police in California were involved in more than 6,400 cat-and-mouse car chases last year, which resulted in the deaths of 18 suspects and five pedestrians, according to statistics from California's highway patrol.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD QUICKEN PACE IN JOINING WTO: US TRADE OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Feb. 26 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan should quicken its pace in seeking to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) if it hopes to join the world body at the same time as mainland China, US trade officials said on Friday.

Mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji will visit the United States in early April, and it is expected that Zhu will reach an agreement with the United States then on opening up mainland China's market on a phase by phase basis.

Robert Cassidy, US assistant trade representative for mainland Chinese and Taiwan affairs, is now in Beijing at the head of a three-member delegation for talks with mainland Chinese officials on the country's WTO entry. Deputy Trade Representative Richard Fisher is contacting the delegation every day to monitor the progress of the talks.

US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky is scheduled to visit Beijing next week. Officials said that Washington and Beijing hope to reach an agreement on the opening of mainland Chinese markets and to make an announcement to that effect during Zhu's US visit.

Although a consensus was reached among signatories to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the WTO's forerunner, that Taiwan should not be permitted to join the WTO before mainland China, that agreement has no binding effect on Taiwan's WTO entry status, officials said.

The officials said the agreement reached Feb. 20, 1998, between Taiwan and the United States on Taiwan's WTO entry was the impetus for European Union members' signing agreements with Taiwan on Taiwan's WTO entry.

If Taiwan hopes to join the WTO at the same time as mainland China, it should work to complete bilateral talks with WTO members as soon as possible. If mainland China were to join the WTO before Taiwan, it could work to delay or prevent Taiwan's WTO entry, they noted.

Taiwan has completed bilateral talks with 26 WTO members. At present, only Canada and Hong Kong have not signed agreements with Taiwan on Taiwan's WTO entry, and Canada is expected to sign an agreement in one to two months.

Because Hong Kong has returned to mainland Chinese sovereignty, it is possible that the territory will not sign an agreement with Taiwan until mainland China has finished completing its WTO entry requirements.

The officials said that if Hong Kong is the only WTO member that has not signed an agreement with Taiwan on Taiwan's WTO entry, the WTO can still regard Taiwan as having completed bilateral talks. This would allow Taiwan to begin the next phase of the application process -- multilateral talks with WTO members.
Taiwan could join the WTO at the same time as mainland China if the move were agreed to by two-thirds of the WTO's members, the officials said.

Although talks on mainland China's WTO entry have dragged on for more than a decade, Beijing will eventually achieve a breakthrough in its WTO entry negotiations, officials said. So Taiwan should work to quickly complete negotiations so that it will be ready to enter the WTO at the same time as mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL AIDS CONFERENCE OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Fifth International AIDS Conference in Taipei opened at Veteran General Hospital Saturday with more than 100 AIDS specialists and researchers from home and abroad taking part.
Discussions during the three-day conference will focus on the proliferation and treatment of AIDS in Asia, where there are now more than 10 million people with the disease.
Leading US AIDS researcher David Ho is taking part in the conference, where he will present a paper detailing his latest research.
Ho, who is of Chinese descent, was last year named an academician of Academia Sinica, the Republic of China's highest research institute.

During a press conference on Saturday, Ho said Asia is home to at least one-third of the 35 million people suffering from AIDS worldwide, and over the next few years more than 4 million new cases will be seen in Asia alone, he said.

According to World Health Organization (WHO) tallies, the number of people carrying HIV, the virus thought to cause AIDS, is expected to increase to 38 million worldwide by the end of the century. Asia will experience the fastest growth in the number of HIV carriers, he said.

The WHO said AIDS transmission through sexual contact is occurring at an appalling speed throughout much of Asia, particularly in India, Pakistan and mainland China, where the gap between the rich and poor is wide and where women are not well respected or educated.

Liu Wu-cheh, a local AIDS researcher, said finding ways to prevent AIDS from spreading across Asia is imperative since people in many of the countries where AIDS is spreading most quickly cannot afford expensive treatments for the disease, such as the "three-in-one cocktail" created by a group of researchers led by Ho.

In recognition of the fact that many poor Asian countries cannot afford the expensive long-term treatments for AIDS available today, the conference has selected "HEART: highly effective anti-retroviral transmission" at the theme of this year's conference.
Sponsors hope that by emphasizing prevention over treatment, safe sex and the equality of the sexes that doctors and researchers will be able to check the spread of AIDS in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGEST-EVER AMMUNITION SEIZURE BY POLICE OCCURS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Taipei police on Saturday raided the underground arsenal of a member of one of Taiwan's four largest gangs, seizing a large quantity of weapons, ammunition and drugs.
Police confiscated 13 handguns and rifles, 5,290 cartridges, 735 shotgun shells, a grenade and 21 knives, as well as some 1,800 grams of amphetamines and heroin.
The ammunition seizure was the largest ever by Taiwan police.
The ammunition belonged to 42-year old Hsiung Tzih-chun, a member of Taiwan's Pine United Gang.

The police arrested Hsiung, nicknamed Hsiao Hsiung (Little Bear), at his apartment in downtown Taipei Friday night. Some ammunition was found in the apartment, although the lion's share was found Saturday morning by police in a van owned by Hsiung.

Police allege that Hsiung was serving as the gang's provider of ammunition, although he has claimed the ammunition was left by a former gang leader, known as "Chih-wei," who was killed in mainland China four years ago.
Police speculated that Hsiung was stockpiling ammunition in hopes of expanding Pine United's power in Taiwan's underworld. "His motives for stocking ammunition are questionable," police said.
The police added that they also suspect "Little Bear," who has a record of assault and battery, theft, and offenses against personal freedom, was involved in several recent gun-related crimes.

The amount of ammunition seized was equal to one-seventh the amount confiscated islandwide by police in all of 1997. Size of the seizure has prompted concern by the National Police Administration. (By Elizabeth Hsu) ENDITEM

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Feb. 28, or the 13th day of the first month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1784: John Wesley, British religious leader who founded Methodism in 1738, signs the "deed of declaration" formalizing the establishment of the Wesleyan faith.
1806: French troops take Barcelona, Spain.
1825: Russia and Britain sign treaty settling the border between Canada and Alaska, then a Russian possession.
1854: US opponents of slavery, meeting at Ripon, Wisconsin, agree to form a new political party; the Republican Party was born later in 1854.
1900: The British Labour Representation Committee, which later becomes the Labour Party, is founded with Ramsay MacDonald as its secretary.
1909: Linus Pauling, American chemist and physicist who won the Nobel Prize for Chemistry in 1934 and Peace Prize in 1962, is born.
1942: Japanese troops land in Java, Indonesia, after the Japanese sink two more Allied ships on the second day of the Battle of Java Sea in World War II.
1946: Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Shih-chieh and French Ambassador to China Jacques Meyrier sign the "Sino-French Treaty Regarding the Revocation of French Exterritorial Jurisdiction and Related Privileges in China" in Chungking.
1947: Rioting breaks out in Taipei, following an incident between police and a peddler who violated the tobacco monopoly.
1951: The Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Dr. Chien Shih-liang as president of National Taiwan University.
1952: Vincent Charles Massey, Canadian politician who served as high commissioner for Canada in Great Britain, takes office as governor-general of Canada, the first Canadian to hold the office.
1956: Indonesia and India sign a mutual aid treaty.
1969: Hafez al-Assad, a Baath leader and defense minister, seizes power in Syria in a military coup.
1976: Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines and Thailand sign a treaty of friendship and cooperation.
1986: Prime Minister Olof Palme of Sweden is assassinated by a gunman on a street as he walks home from a movie in Stockholm.
1987: President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines announces full and complete amnesty to communist rebels who lay down their weapons.
1989: More than 200 people are killed in a riot in Caracas, Venezuela.
1992: The ROC and the Philippines sign an official investment guarantee agreement to protect investment by Taiwan businessmen.
1992: The United Nations Security Council approves peacekeeping force for Cambodia.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui expresses an apology to family of victims of the Feb. 28 , 1947 Incident at the Taipei New Park, where a monument commemorating the tragedy was built with government sponsorship.
1996: Britain's Princess Diana agrees to divorce her estranged husband Prince Charles.
1997: An earthquake hits western Pakistan, claiming more than 35 lives while another earthquake in Iran destroys over 20 villages and kills nearly 1,000 people.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Now when I find a man agrees with me in what I say, without being able to profit by it by changing his conduct, or one who is pleased with my parable without being able to apply the moral to himself--I can do nothing for such a man."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Clinton prods Beijing to rule by law.
The China Times:
Taiwan will buy four Aegis warships from the United States as part of its plan to join the US-led missile defense system.
The United Daily News:
US Secretary of State visits Beijing to reiterate US stance on Theater Missile Defense system.
The Liberty Times:
Taiwan opts for Aegis warships.
The Commons Daily:
May Taiwan be everybody's new home: Lee Yuan-tseh.
The China Post:
Police uncover island's largest firearms cache.
The China News:
Police seize gang arms.

DOC.HEADLINE: 19 PANAMANIAN FREIGHTER CREW RESCUED, ONE MISSING

TEXT.P: Nineteen crewmembers were rescued with one still missing after a Panamanian freighter lost power off Hualien, eastern Taiwan, Saturday, according to the military.

The 6,000-ton freighter, Abdhike Adiratna, was traveling 60 nautical miles south of Hualien Saturday afternoon, when it lost power due to rough seas. The freighter sent an SOS signal after tilting dangerously 60 degrees to one side.

The military immediately sent two rescue helicopters, but due to bad weather the rescue mission was called off. Before aborting the mission the helicopters alerted a nearby Norwegian freighter to approach for assistance.

Sunday morning, the rescue helicopters returned and were able to rescue eight crew, including the captain who was slightly injured and hospitalized. Another 11 crew members were rescued by other nearby vessels.
The Hualien Harbor police are still searching for the remaining missing crew member as well as investigating the cause of the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AGAIN LISTED AS MAJOR DRUG-TRANSIT COUNTRY

TEXT.P: Despite protests from Taipei, a US government report has once again listed Taiwan as one of the major illicit drug producing and/or transit countries.
For the third time in a row, the annual US International Narcotics Control Strategy Report (INCSR), released on Friday, also classifies Taiwan as one of the world's major money laundering countries.
However, President Bill Clinton has given Taiwan certification for its efforts in fighting drugs-related activities.
The US government cuts off non-emergency aid to those who are listed in the INCSR as major drug producing and drug-transit countries but who fail to win the presidential certification.
Taiwan objects to being listed out of concern for its image rather than for any practical reasons because Taiwan does not receive any foreign assistance from the United States.

In 1996, the United Nations removed Taiwan from its list of major drug transit countries. "Everyone agrees, however, that individuals from Taiwan continue to be involved in international narcotics trafficking," the INCSR for 1999 said.

"This assessment derives from regional trafficking patterns and concern that Taiwan's ports are used by narcotics traffickers to transship drugs destined for the United States," according to the report.
Looking to the future of bilateral cooperation in the fight against drugs, the report said that a mutual legal assistance memorandum of understanding is a high priority.
The United States also hopes that a framework will be set up to allow Taiwan authorities to perform end-user pre-export checks for narcotics precursors.

In addition to Taiwan, 27 others are listed in this year's INCSR as major illicit drug producing and drug-transit countries, including mainland China, Hong Kong, Vietnam, Thailand, Laos, Guatemala, Haiti, etc.
Mainland China is also listed as a major precursor chemical source country and a major money laundering country.
The White House Office of National Drug Control Policy announced Friday that, of the 28 "majors", only Afghanistan and Burma fail to win certification for US aid.

The president determined that even though Cambodia, Haiti, Nigeria and Paraguay did not fully meet the criteria for certification, their certification should be granted on grounds of vital US national interests. (End, by Jay Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: SOLEMN CEREMONIES HELD TO MARK 2-28 INCIDENT

TEXT.P: Solemn ceremonies were held around Taiwan Sunday to mark the 52nd anniversary of the 2-28 incident with Premier Vincent Siew vowing to protect human rights and never to repeat past mistakes.
Siew noted in a ceremony held at the 2-28 Memorial Park in downtown Taipei that the government in the past did not handle the incident well, resulting in casualties.

Calling the 2-28 incident a tragic chapter in Taiwan's history, Siew said the victims and their families have suffered from the incident. But he also noted that the truth of the incident has gradually emerged in the past decade, and vowed to "avoid past mistakes and to protect human rights."

Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, speaking in Taiwanese on the same occasion, said that it was the abuse of power by the government rather than ethnic rivalry that triggered the 2-28 incident in 1947 and the subsequent white terror in the 1950s, noting that the victims covered the spectrum from all provinces, gender and ages.

Ma said that most of the mainlanders that withdrew to Taiwan in 1949 following a Nationalist Government defeat in the Chinese civil war should not be held responsible for the tragedy that took place two years before.
Ma also presided over the opening of Ke Chao-chih artifact exhibition. Ke has collected materials related to the 2-28 incident and turned them over to the government for reference.
Ma expressed the hope that the public face the history in sincerity, identify with local culture and devote themselves to the democratic development on the island.

Siew, Ma and Huang Ta-chou, chairman of the 2-28 incident foundation, later laid wreaths before the 2-28 memorial monument, rang a peace bell, released doves, and prayed for the victims of the incident.
Similar ceremonies were held in Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan and Taichung in central Taiwan respectively.

The 2-28 incident was triggered by a monopoly bureau inspector's beating of a woman selling countermand cigarettes in Feb. 28, 1947. Thousands of casualties were reported in the subsequent riots and crackdown.

Public discussion on the incident was suppressed for decades. But the government lifted the lid on discussion of the incident in the early 1990s, and the first native-born president, Lee Teng-hui, has apologized to the public on the state's behalf.
The government has also set up a foundation to handle compensation or assistance to the victims or their spouses and subsidized research on the incident and related activities.
The foundation reported that in the past three years it has issued NT$5.9 billion (US$181.53 million) in compensation, a far cry from the original estimate of nearly NT$100 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS DISPUTE US CRITICISM OF TAIWAN OVER DRUGS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is victim of narcotics rather than a transit point for drugs, said law enforcement officials on Friday.

In a rebuttal of a US report which named Taiwan as a major drug-producing and drug-transiting country, anonymous officials from the Investigative Bureau pointed out that Taiwan's all-out efforts to crackdown on narcotics has been acknowledged by US President Bill Clinton and that they cannot understand why the Department of State will put the opposite in its report.

Taiwan is clear of drug-producing plants because of the island's unfavorable climate for opium crops or coca shrubs, and a draconian anti-drug law. The strict enforcement of that the anti-drug law has ridded the island of major drug manufacturers, said the officials.

Citing the 30-odd drug rings busted last year in Taiwan, with a narcotics haul of more than 500 kg., including some 200 kg. of heroine, the drug agents said that most of the contraband was smuggled in from other countries, with only a few was made on the island.

As a matter of fact, Taiwan's anti-drug crusade, including education programs among students to raise their awareness of the danger of consuming amphetamines, has made the island an "high risk area" among drug-traffickers, said the officials.
As a result, according to officials, many drug-producers have shifted their illegal operations from Taiwan to southern China.
As to containers transited from Taiwan's ports, Taiwan authorities are not in a position to check their contents, and should not be blamed for any drugs stashed in them.
Also repudiated was the charge made in the report that Taiwan is a major money laundry center, saying that the island is the first country in Asia with a law outlawing money laundering.
The law obliges banks to report to law enforcement authorities any transaction with a sum beyond NT$1.5 million (US$45,454), said the officials.

Regular financial checks conducted by the Ministry of Finance on financial institutions as well as the alertness of a special anti-money-laundering unit under the Investigative Bureau has left little space, in any, for money laundering, said the officials.

The US Department of State was asked by the Congress to submit an annual report assessing the anti-drug efforts by countries around the world which will be taken into account by the Congress in approving the government's foreign aid programs.
Taiwan is regularly covered by the report, although it is not a recipient of any US aid.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRAIN-DEAD PATINET BECOMES JAPAN'S FIRST ORGAN DONOR

TEXT.P: A 44-year-old female Japanese brain-dead patient on Sunday became the first donor of organs in Japan since the country's Organ Transplant Law went into effect in October, 1997, as well as only the second heart transplant donor in Japan since August, 1968.

The woman, whose organs were removed Sunday afternoon, was taken to a Kochi Prefecture hospital February 22 after suffering a subarachnoid hemorrhage and falling into a coma. She was diagnosed as brain dead after two legal tests.

Organs including the heart, liver, kidneys and eyeballs were removed for transplants to several patients. Doctors failed to remove her lungs. Transplant operations are to be conducted by several medical university hospitals, including Osaka University, Shinshu University, Tohoku University and Nagasaki Central Hospital.

Since being hospitalized February 22, the woman, who gave prior written consent for organ transplants, never recovered consciousness and was judged by doctors as "clinically brain death" on Feb. 25. Her family members approved the donations under condition that her brain death was legally certified.

The first test for brain death was carried out on the evening of Feb. 27, with the second test six hours later. Both test results, met a five-point requirement and led to a judgment of legal brain death. To ensure the objectiveness, Japan's law requires two or more doctors, not involved in transplant operations, conduct the diagnosis and produce a document to certify the results.

A set of guidelines by the Ministry of Health and Welfare in 1985 defines the conditions that determine brain death as: deep coma, dilated pupils, loss of voluntary breathing, loss of brain-stem response and flat brain waves. (by Mike Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER HU LEAVES FOR MACEDONIA MONDAY

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu of the Republic of China will leave for Skopje Monday for an official visit to Macedonia.
He will be accompanied during the three-day visit by Taiwan entrepreneurs, trade promoters, bankers, representatives of state-run enterprises, and officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

This will be the first official visit by ROC officials to the Southeast European country since the two countries established diplomatic relations in January. Macedonian Information Minister Redzep Zlatku visited Taiwan in early February.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL TRADE REVENUE SET RECORD IN 1998

TEXT.P: Thanks to the launch of a five-day work week every other week, Taiwan's commercial trade revenue set a new record in 1998 despite the regional financial storm.
The data prepared by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) showed that Taiwan's commercial trade stood at NT$3.48 trillion (US$105.66 billion) in 1998, up 5.24 percent over one year ago.
Retail trade grew by 5.92 percent to NT$2.3 trillion (US$69.9 billion), while wholesale trade grew 5.92 percent to NT$1.17 trillion (US$35.72 billion). The two categories compose commercial trade.
The increase, a happy surprise amid the regional economic tumult, was credited mainly to increased consumption triggered by the lengthened leisure time people enjoyed under the shorter work week.
The proliferation of convenient stores and hypermarkets also contributed to the booming business of commercial trade, said the MOEA.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE SURVEY SHOWS OPINIONS DIVIDED ON ORGAN DONATION

TEXT.P: A survey released by the Japanese Prime Minister's office Sunday, the day of the country's first organ donation, shows opinions on the part of the Japanese people are almost equally divided on whether to donate organs in the event they become brain-dead.

According to the survey, held last October, 31.6 percent would donate their organs in case of brain death, with a majority of younger people responding positively, while 37.6 percent said they would not donate.

While some 63 percent knew about donor registration cards, 30 million of which have been distributed by the Ministry of Health and Welfare as of the end of January, only 2.6 percent held the cards, and of those approximately 60 percent had not yet decided whether to fill out the card.

The three major reasons given by those without donor registra- tion cards were: a negative feeling towards organ transplants (29.2%), not knowing how to obtain a registration card (23.5%), and not knowing enough about organ transplants (21%).
The survey held last October, among 3,000 men and women aged 20 or older, marked the first anniversary of the enactment of Japan's Organ Transplant Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAYORS LEAVES FOR BRISBANE'S ASIA-PACIFIC MAYORAL SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Kaohsiung City Mayor Frank Hsieh set off for Brisbane, Australia, Sunday afternoon on the same Singapore Airline flight for the second Asia-Pacific Mayoral Summit, scheduled for March 1-3.
The non-governmental forum of regional cities is expected to bring together representatives from 50-odd Asia-Pacific cities.
It will be the two mayors' first overseas trip since they took office on December 25.
In addition to Taipei City Government officials, there are 22 senior commercial and industrial executives from Taipei in Ma's entourage.

During his four-day stay in Australia, Ma will visit a university in Queensland, call on Taipei's sister city of Gold Coast just south of Brisbane, and tour the construction site of the Olympic Games in Sydney.

While Hsieh's detailed schedule was not disclosed, a press release issued by his office said that he will bid to host the summit in the future and will try to deepen his understanding of other Asia-Pacific cities as well as Brisbane which became Kaohsiung's sister city in 1997.

Ma and his delegation are scheduled on March 4 to depart for Hong Kong where they will attend the inauguration ceremony of Taipei Bank's Hong Kong representative office and visit some Hong Kong municipal infrastructure projects on March 5.
After hosting a reception for the Taipei City Government-owned bank, Ma is slated to return to Taipei on the evening of March 5.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS URGE CORRESPONDING POWER AND RESPONSIBILITY OF LEADERS

TEXT.P: The lack of corresponding rights and responsibility of government leaders has resulted in the first no-confidence motion in the Legislative Yuan's history, according to scholars participating in a seminar over the weekend.
Legislators from the major opposition parties, Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and New Party, presented a no-confidence motion on Friday over the controversy surrounding the stock transaction tax.
Local reports earlier this week stated that Premier Vincent Siew had tendered his resignation because of difference with the president over the stock transaction tax.

The scholars, in a seminar sponsored by a foundation to discuss the first no-confidence proposal in ROC history Saturday, said that the reason behind the recent flap could be attributed to constitutional reforms in 1997, which they said gave too much power to the president.

Professor Lu Ya-li of National Taiwan University said that after the constitutional reforms two years ago, the president could appoint the premier without the approval of the Legislative Yuan. The premier therefore is responsible to the president but not to the public. The president has real power, but does not take corresponding responsibility.

Lee noted that Siew, who had insisted in not adjusting the stock transaction tax, softened his stance after President Lee said that he is in favor of lowering the tax. The about-face in such a short time showed that the decision making power lies in the president, not in the premier, Lee added.

Another NTU professor Chang Lin-cheng said that current system has allowed the president to intervene too much in policies, and she asked that a clear line be drawn between the power of the president and the premier.

Chang said that the president should not be involved in every matter, suggesting that the president provide opinions on major policies such as national defenses, diplomacy and cross-strait relations, but give a free rein to the premier on matters concerning the everyday life of the public.
Legislature Chen Chung-hsin of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, who pushed vigorously for constitutional reform in 1997, said that the 1997 reforms indeed are deficient.

Chen explained that the original intention was that if the president belongs to the majority party of the Legislative Yuan, then the president will have real power, but if the president is not in the majority party, then the power will lies with the premier.

The Legislative Yuan is expected to cast a vote on the no-confidence motion next Tuesday. As the ruling Kuomintang holds 123 seats in the 225-seat legislature, it is expected that Siew will survive the no-confidence motion, which requires one half to pass.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIAGRA TO DEBUT IN S'PORE SOON

TEXT.P: Singapore, February 28 (CNA): Viagra is set to make its debut in pharmacies in Singapore in about four or six weeks' time, after its manufacturer, Pfizer, said it could comply with the Ministry of Health's (MOH) conditions for the sale of the anti-impotence drug.
The Health Ministry has already reviewed the drug and set seven conditions last November for the drug company to meet before it would approve the sale of Viagra.
It required that Pfizer insert warning pamphlets into the packaging and produce information booklets for all users.
The ministry had said then that it was taking a cautious approach because Viagra was a new drug and had been linked to deaths in the United States.
Mr. Michael Khor, Pfizer's marketing director in Singapore said that as of Friday afternoon, the firm had received verbal con- firmation that all of the MOH conditions had been met.
"Going by the registration of previous drugs, I expect a product license for Virgra in about two weeks," he said.
It will take two to four weeks after receiving the license for stocks of the little blue pill to arrive.
After that, doctors can start prescribing it.
Pfizer's product license will be valid for six months before MOH re-evaluates the situation, Khor said.

In line with ministry conditions, Viagra's insert will carry a list of statements on proper use. One is a warning for heart patients on nitrates. Another is directed at men with certain eye conditions.
Reports have surfaced that some men on the drug have blue-tinted vision, and ophthalmologists have voiced concern that the long-term use of the drug could damage eyesight.
Viagra will be available in Singapore only on prescription. Each pill is expected to cost around US$10.
The pill has been approved in more than 42 countries, including Taiwan, Australia, most of Europe, the Philippines and Thailand. (Sherman Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJORITY OF FAMILIES WILLING TO TAKE CARE OF AIDS PATIENTS

TEXT.P: The majority of families of AIDS patients are willing to take care of them, and the care provided by the mothers and wives to their children and spouses is most admirable, according to a staff member of the Veteran General Hospital on Sunday.
Su Yi-hung, chief of nurses at the hospital, spoke of her experience in observing more than 100 patents during the second day of a three-day International AIDS Conference in Taipei.

Su said that 90 percent of families are willing to take care of their sick children, spouses or siblings, but fathers, husbands and male siblings have not given the same degree of care to their infected children, wives, and female siblings as their female counterparts.
She also said that as AIDS patients have suffered from the stigma of shame and agony of uncertain treatment, they are more incline to commit suicide than the average patient.

She noted that several studies show that many families will not let their relatives, friends and colleagues know that they have AIDS patients at home. Many families, as a result, suffer from hypertension due to the long-term care needs of the patients with no way to seek emotional consolation. All indications show that families of AIDS patients need support to help them tide over the difficulties, adding that such groups are very limited in Taiwan, Su said.
Meanwhile, statistics released by the Department of Health (DOH) showed that the ratio of patients contracting AIDS has topped one case per day since last year.

DOH said that the first AIDS case was reported in Taiwan in 1984, and the number only reached 100 in the subsequent five years. But in last year alone, local AIDS cases topped 398 and combined with the number of foreigners living in Taiwan discovered to have contracted the virus, the cases totaled 440, topping the one new case per day ratio for the first time.
